orange bitters blend, spritzed from an atomizer (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Spritz orange bitters blend on top.

title: Featherweight
intro_philosophy: Bartenders Tommy Ho and Alex Negranza collaborated on this cocktail, riffing on a sour formula for a drink built to beat the Texas heat.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces white rum, preferably Plantation 3 Star
3/4 ounce white port, preferably Warre's Fine white port
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients and shake with ice.
2. Strain over crushed ice in a chilled rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a sprig of mint.

title: Last Caress
intro_philosophy: This equal-parts cocktail was conceived as a nightcap, something thatJackson Merciercould serve to guests as the last drink of an evening, or enjoy himself after closing Bryant’s Cocktail Lounge. The name comes from the title of a song by punk rock band the Misfits. “A dark and brooding song became the basis for a dark and brooding cocktail,” explains Mercier of his drink, which combines bonded apple brandy, Averna and génépy (Mercier prefers the Wisconsin-made Heirloom génépy brand). Finally, a few dashes of Peychaud’s bitters bring an aromatic nose that acts as “the rug that ties the room together,” says Mercier.
ingredients: 1 ounce 100-proof apple brandy, preferably Laird’s Bottled in Bond
1 ounce génépy, preferably Heirloom (yellow Chartreuse may be substituted)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Pour over fresh ice into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Moko Jumbie
intro_philosophy: The cocktails on the menu atSavannah Caféare named after Caribbean colloquialisms, Trinidadian towns and calypso lyrics. Owner Natalie Lamming calls her version of a whisky mule the Moko Jumbie, after the ghostly character who glides through crowds during the annual Carnival parades. Silky and spiced, the cocktail pairs mauby, a classic, bittersweet drink made from tree bark and spices, with blended Scotch whisky, lime juice and cinnamon.
ingredients: 1 ounce mauby(freshly brewed, or made from store-bought concentrate)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker over ice.
2. Shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a copper mug filled with ice.
4. Garnish with a mint leaf and a lime wheel.

title: Saffron Almonds
intro_philosophy: An at-home variation on the salty snacks served in classic aperitivo spreads, best accompanied by a spritz and golden hour.
instructions: 1. Place oil and saffron threads in a saucepan over very low heat.
2. Let sit, stirring occasionally so the saffron releases its color and aroma into the oil.
3. In a separate saucepan, toast the nuts lightly over medium heat until just golden brown, about 2 minutes.
4. Transfer to a bowl and let cool. Add the saffron oil, toss to coat, and serve warm.

title: Noce Vecchio
intro_philosophy: Made from entirely Italian ingredients, the Noce Vecchio (literally “old nut”)  is a Futurist play on theOld Hickory, a New Orleans cocktail that mixes sweet and dry vermouth with a healthy helping of bitters. Derived from the Italian Futurist art movement, Futurist mixology follows several tenants, including using Italian ingredients and creating unexpected circumstances within drinking experience. This cocktail remakes an American classic into a very efficient Futurist aperitivo, crostini garnish included.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir quickly.
3. Pour over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a cube each of bread, cheese and salami arranged on a cocktail skewer.

title: Dauphine’s Roffignac
intro_philosophy: At  New Orleans–themed bar Dauphine’s in Washington, D.C., the house Roffignac eschews the drink’s traditional Cognac base. Instead, Neal Bodenheimer and beverage director Donato Alvarez swap in tequila, complemented by cranberry shrub and soda.
ingredients: 2 ounces club soda, preferably Fever-Tree, chilled
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, combine tequila and shrub.
2. Add club soda.
3. Add cube ice and stir gently.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Treasure Trove
intro_philosophy: In this sherry-spiked Piña Colada variation, “the menthol qualities of Branca pair perfectly with the sweet notes of the strawberry” for a subtle flavor boost, says Peter Arnone.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce overproof rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
1/4 ounce Pedro Ximénez sherry, preferably Lustau
instructions: 1. Muddle the strawberry in a shaker tin, then add remaining ingredients to the shaker. Hard shake with 3 Kold-Draft cubes.
2. Double-strain into a tiki mug.
3. Garnish with mint and a skewered strawberry.

title: Palio Julep
intro_philosophy: Considering the bright landscape of the Italian Alps in Bormio, and the aromatic botanicals used to make Braulio, Chris Amirault had a particular craving for a refreshing, herbaceous julep. He turned to chamomile—the scent of which he associates with alpine amaro—for a bespoke cordial that adds both sweetness and aromatics. “This is a drink that is meant to be sessionable,” he says.
instructions: 1. Add the mint, tarragon, sage, and chamomile cordial to julep glass and gently muddle until combined.
2. Add the Braulio and Cognac and fill the glass with crushed ice.
3. Stir the ingredients with a swizzle stick until chilled.
4. Top off with more crushed ice and garnish with the grapefruit twist, chamomile, juniper, and mint.

title: Japanese Slipper
intro_philosophy: The Japanese Slipper—a simple sour built of equal parts, shaken, served up and garnished with a maraschino cherry—is exactly what a drink born in the ’80s should be: boozy, tart-sweet and unabashedly neon. Though it may have been born in the Dark Ages, on closer inspection, the cocktail’s simple build and reliance on fresh citrus make the Japanese Slipper—much like New York’sCosmopolitanand London’sBramble—Melbourne’s primary contribution to the early days of the cocktail revival.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Fine-strain into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.

title: Neal Bodenheimer’s Absinthe Suissesse
intro_philosophy: The Absinthe Suissesse went through many twists and turns before landing in New Orleans and morphing into the creamy drink it is today. Neal Bodenheimer’s spec plays up the drink’s “anise-y eggnog” quality, which he thinks makes it the ideal cocktail first thing on Mardi Gras morning.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce crème de menthe, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Dry-shake the egg white vigorously for 30 seconds.
2. Add the absinthe, cream and simple syrup and fill the shaker with ice.
3. Shake until chilled.
4. Double-strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
5. Float the crème de menthe on top, and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Trailblazer
intro_philosophy:
Vince Bright takes the turn-key combination of vermouth and tonic in a new direction by adding an element of vanilla spice, courtesy of rhum agricole. He swapped in several different sweet vermouths before settling on the light and floral Dolin Rouge. A splash of fresh lemon juice helps cut the natural sweetness; it also carries the spice notes of the rhum agricole as well as the ginger and cardamom elements of Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water, which tops off the drink.  “The angostura bark brings a ton of versatility, and goes a long way to elevate a tonic drink by adding bitterness,” says Bright.

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: 1 ounce  sweet vermouth, preferably Dolin Rouge
instructions: 1. Combine the rhum agricole, sweet vermouth and lemon juice in a Collins glass.
2. Fill with ice, and give it a quick stir.
3. Top with tonic water.
4. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Isle Delfino
intro_philosophy: “This drink came out of multiple failures of trying to do tea well in a drink,” says Garret Richard. An avid tea drinker, Richard wanted to incorporate jasmine tea into a modern take on the Daiquiri, which he does by infusing it in milk-washed rhum that’s then run through a centrifuge to clarify. The citrus component is comprised of acid-adjusted grapefruit and a pineapple syrup acts as the sweetener. “I really wanted to do something with jasmine and grapefruit—I’d seen it in a lot of perfumes but not necessarily in a lot of cocktails,” says Richard. “I’ve had success with jasmine and pineapple together so those two things were in the back of my mind. This drink just kind of came together from multiple loves really.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce acid adjusted grapefruit juice (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with one large ice cube and two smaller ice cubes.
2. Strain into a large coupe.
3. Garnish with a pansy.

title: Trident
intro_philosophy: The Trident is a nautically-inspired interpretation of theNegroni, created in 2000 by Robert Hess, a cocktail enthusiast from Seattle. In his endeavor to reinterpret the classic, Hess reappointed the Negroni’s trifecta of ingredients—strong, bitter, sweet—with distant cousins of the same flavor profile, each hailing from a seafaring country. Gin is swapped for aquavit, Campari for Cynar, and sweet vermouth for sherry, with a dash of peach bitters on top. The Trident has become a Seattle staple, enjoying an extended reign at theZig Zag Café, one of the city’s best-known cocktail joints.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Milk Biz
intro_philosophy:
Created by Shannon Ponche when she worked at Clover Club, it is meant for use in the Thai One On cocktail but has become an employee favorite for all sorts of drinks.

Try it in aCoconut Julep,Tom & JerryorIrish Coffee.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bottle, seal and store refrigerated for up to two weeks.

title: Phil Ward’s Mezcal Martini
intro_philosophy: Riffing on an early Martini formula, Phil Ward tames the mezcal base with the citric notes of orange bitters and a grapefruit twist.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Old Haitian
intro_philosophy: “I had the pleasure of visiting Haiti and seeing some clairin production last year and have been subbing it into classics since then,” says McCray of his decision to update theOld Cuban, a modern classic from Audrey Saunders, itself an inventive spin on theMojito. By serving it over crushed ice rather than up in a coupe, McCray finds middle ground between the presentation of the two classics.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rhum agricole, preferably Boukman Rhum
1/2 ounce rich cane syrup (2:1, cane sugar: water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a swizzle glass over crushed ice.
2. Garnish with a bouquet of mint.

title: Master Bandit
intro_philosophy: At Cote, Sondre Kasin, the principal bartender at both the New York and Miami locations, conceives of new cocktails with an eye toward showcasing uniquely Asian flavors like ume plums and perilla leaves, and presents them within the framework of a modern steakhouse, where prized cuts of beef are seasoned with more than just salt and pepper. Kasin cites the Master Bandit as an example, which incorporates Hwayo Soju, navy-strength gin, lemongrass syrup, lime and even a trace of MSG.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces navy strength gin, preferably Fords Officers' Reserve
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Fine strain into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a bay leaf.

title: Telegraph
intro_philosophy: In this elegant Martini variation, pear eau de vie, Cocchi Americano and Mathilde Poire liqueur scrimmage in place of the usual vermouth. A drop of eucalyptus extract adds a touch of mystery—something every good Martini ought to have.
ingredients: 1 drop Terra Spice Company Eucalyptus Extract (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Bottle all ingredients and freeze until cold.
2. To serve, pour into a chilled Martini glass or coupe and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Black Thorn Highball
intro_philosophy: Inspired by Southern sweet tea, this highball features a concentrated black tea with notes of rose petals “for a floral counterpoint.” The tea is deliberately brewed strong, so the flavor still stands out when diluted with soda water.
ingredients: 1 ounce  rose black tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass with ice, and gently stir.
2. Twist the lemon peel over top of the drink to express essential oils, then garnish drink with lemon peel.

title: Jim Kearns’ Alaska
intro_philosophy:
Jim Kearns describes this drink as perfect for early autumn. “AMartiniis a bright, summery drink,” he explains. By comparison, “an Alaska’s got that saffron-honey quality from the yellow Chartreuse, and that’s bolstered by the softness of the Old Tom gin,” a lightly sweetened style. Taken together, it’s a Martini-style drink with less bite and a little more roundness.

In addition, Kearns readily admits that the 2 1/4 measure of gin is “a little funky,” so he offers this nifty trick: fill a 3/4-ounce jigger three times with gin, which adds up to 2 1/4 total. That same 3/4-ounce jigger can then be used to measure the yellow Chartreuse. “You don’t even have to switch jiggers!”
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces Old Tom gin, preferably Hayman’s
1 dash orange bitters, preferably Bitter Truth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express the lemon peel and use as garnish.

title: Borrowed Time
intro_philosophy: This take on the Old-Fashioned, from Alec Bales, sees Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon accented with dark rum from St. Lucia. Rich, molasses-like sorghum, thinned with water, provides a Southern-style sweetener. “It’s common throughout the Southeast,” Bales says. Since only a quarter-ounce is used to add complexity to this drink, he encourages drizzling the remainder over pancakes or waffles.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
3/4 ounce  St. Lucian Bounty dark rum
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a rocks glass. Stir 10 or so spins to combine, then add a couple of ice cubes, and stir again to chill.
2. Twist the lemon peel over the top of the drink to express its oils, then drop in the glass to garnish.

title: Bamboo Spritz
intro_philosophy: Allison Everittdescribes her low-ABV, refreshing Bamboo Spritz as “a thirst-quenching patio crusher.” A sparkling riff on the classic Bamboo, Everitt opts for a split base of manzanilla sherry, for salinity, and bianco vermouth, for an herbaceous, citrusy quality. A topping of both cava and hop water brings the drink into spritz territory, while aromatic cucumber rounds out the drink by way of a long ribbon garnish.
ingredients: 2 ounces hop water, preferably Lagunitas Hoppy Refresher
instructions: 1. Add the first two ingredients, plus the bitters, to a wine glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Top with cava and hop water.
3. Garnish with a long cucumber ribbon.

title: Artist’s Special
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake.
3. Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with the lemon peel.

title: Old Sister Tamarind
intro_philosophy: Though a traditional Old-Fashioned is made with whiskey, “you can put in a little something else,” says Leyenda proprietor Ivy Mix. At her bar, which spotlights the spirits and cultures of the Caribbean and Latin America, the “something else” can mean a measure of Jamaican rum. In this variation, jam made with tamarind—a sweet-sour fruit frequently used to sweeten drinks and food in Mexico—plays against the mild acidity of verjus, the pressed juice of unripened grapes.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
½ ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton Reserve
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Pour into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

title: Hakuna Banana
intro_philosophy: This Old-Fashioned variation leans into distinctive tropical notes of bananas and brown sugar while making sure the dark rum is still the star of the show. Christine Wiseman warns against overpowering the rum with too many ingredients, lest it become a background player. And, to avoid overdiluting, she prefers “to build my Old-Fashioned directly in the glass,” she says. “I like to have my Old-Fashioned a little ‘hot’ to start, to really taste the rum,” and experience how it changes over time.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Ten To One Caribbean Dark Rum
1/4 ounce  aged rum (preferably Bacardí 8 or Mount Gay)
1/3 ounce  banana liqueur (preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane)
1/4 ounce  coconut Demerara syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a mixing tin with ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an orange twist and dried banana chips. If you’re feeling extra festive, sprinkle with edible glitter.

title: Tattersall’s Aviation
intro_philosophy: The deployment of theAviation’s defining ingredient, crème de violette, has always beenthe monkey wrench in this cocktail. Too much and the drink tastes like scented bath soap; don’t use any and the drink isn’t really an Aviation. Tattersall Distilling seems to have solved this problem by using their own Tattersall Crème de Fleur, a lovely distillation of six flowers, which is now available in several states. For the violet color Aviation drinkers expect, the gin is steeped in dried butterfly pea flower.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces butterfly pea flower-infused gin (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except the soda water to a shaking tin, and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and top with soda water.
3. Garnish with a lemon slice.

title: Passionfruit Sgroppino
intro_philosophy: Dante’s updated take on the Sgroppino, the palate-cleansingintermezzoand postprandial digestivo born in Venice, swaps in seasonal sorbet and a touch of aperitivo bitter for a bubbly drink you can either sip or scoop up with a spoon.
instructions: 1. Place the passionfruit sorbet in a frozen coupe glass.
2. Add the Contratto Aperitif and top off with prosecco.
3. Garnish with a spritz of orange flower water.
4. Serve with a metal spoon or straw.

title: Mai Tai Spritz
intro_philosophy:
Like the many maligned Mai Tai recipes floating about in the cocktail ether, the originator of this tiki classic has been muddied, with accounts naming Don the Beachcomber and others fingering his rival, Victor “Trader Vic” Bergeron. Either way, Vic’s version is the one that lingers as the canonical formula. Austere compared to many kitchen sink–style tiki drinks, the Mai Tai pairs lime, almond syrup (orgeat), dry curacao, and, often, two styles of rum—Jamaican and Martinican. Martin Cate’s spritz-ified version pares down the rum content in lieu of a Champagne topper in a nod to Trader Vic’s French heritage.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail, with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC. Photography credit: Dylan + Jeni © 2016
ingredients: 1 ounce Denizen Merchant's Reserve Rum  (or Appleton Estate Reserve Rum)
1/2 ounce  Pierre Ferrand Dry Orange Curaçao
instructions: 1. Combine the lime juice, orgeat, curaçao, and rum in a small container and refrigerate for an hour or two.
2. Pour the chilled mixture into a Collins glass, fill to the rim with ice, top with Champagne, and add the garnish.

title: G&T&C&R
intro_philosophy: Dan Sabo of Hotel Figueroa puts an unexpected twist on a commonGin & Tonicgarnish: the cucumber. Rather than floating cucumber slices in the drink, Sabo includes a cucumber juice ice cube that allows the drink to evolve over time and play off the cucumber notes that define Hendrick’s Gin, his preferred brand for this recipe.
instructions: 1. Combine the gin and bitters in a Collins glass.
2. Fill glass almost to the top with ice cubes.
3. Using a bar spoon held vertically with the bowl touching the bottom of the glass, pour the tonic slowly down the handle.
4. Place the cucumber ice cube so it floats at the top of the drink.
5. Garnish with a cucumber slice and a lime wheel.

title: Media Combinación
intro_philosophy: One of the earliest recorded recipes for the Combinación comes from Pedro Chicote, one of Spain’s most famous bartenders, in his1927 book,El Bar Americano en España. His formula calls for dry gin and vermouth in equal proportions, plus a small measure of red Curaçao and Angostura bitters. Fast-forward almost a century andCabrera has reimagined the classicwith minor tweaks, calling it the Media Combinación, as the drink is better known in Madrid. (Similar drinks with varying proportions appear in different regions under different names, like the Marianito in the Basque region.) Cabrera’s bar, Viva Madrid, ditches the Curaçao and uses a house blend of sherry and sweet vermouth, specifically Navarro vermouth, which is made from raisins and without added sugar.
ingredients: heavy 1 1/4 ounces fortified wine blend (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a rocks glass with ice and briefly stir.
2. Garnish with half a lemon slice and a lemon twist.

title: Palomar’s Turf Club
intro_philosophy: In this cocktail, the Turf Club, a lesser-known Martini variation, takes a spin through the tropics courtesy of pineapple-infused gin. “Maraschino usually steals the show when you throw it in the mix, but with our version it takes a back seat,” explains Jordan Valls, bar manager at Palomar. Valls also notes that of all the methods he’s tried, sous vide provides the best extraction of the pineapple flavor, and he adds that immersion circulators have become more affordable—he picked one up from Costco for $40. Plus, once it’s made, the pineapple gin can be used in an array of classic gin cocktails, from a G&T to a Corpse Reviver No. 2.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces dry vermouth, such as Dolin
1/4 ounce maraschino liqueur, such as Luxardo
2 dashes orange bitters, such as Regans’
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with an olive and a pineapple wedge.

title: Chinotto Fizz
intro_philosophy:
This savory N/A fizz from New York’s San Sabino has a secret weapon in the way of coconut aminos, a soy sauce alternative made from the fermented sap of a coconut palm flower. It amplifies the nuttiness of the orgeat and the sweet-bitter notes of Stappi Chinotto, a bitter orange Italian soda. It’s a drink that can do double duty as a meal opener and as a light-on-its-feet finisher.

NB: The orgeat in this recipe can be swapped out foroat-geator other alternatives.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce orgeat, preferably Small Hand Foods
2 dashes coconut aminos, preferably Coconut Secret
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a stemmed rocks glass and stir briefly to integrate.
2. Garnish with an orange wheel and a cherry on a pick

title: Bare Minimum
intro_philosophy: A reference to the classic recipe of spirit, bitters, sugar and water, Lasher-Walker believes his drink fulfills the “bare minimum” of requirements to qualify as an Old-Fashioned. He even skips the garnish, insisting that the nose actually benefits without one.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Aperol and Giffard Banane Du Brésil Liqueur Batch (See Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a rocks glass over a jumbo ice cube, stirring five or six times.
2. Serve with no garnish.

title: Puppy Pose
intro_philosophy: Appearing on the bar’s 2023Tantrick Dogmenu, the Puppy Pose is a showcase for the care and technique the bar has applied to nonalcoholic drinks since its inception. A clarified probiotic yogurt punch of sorts, the drink’s combination of ingredients garnered so much interest that folks would routinely ask if they could “get that with alcohol.” (Politely, they could not.)
instructions: 1. Mix together the first four ingredients. Pour the batch into the yogurt and let it stand for 1 hour.
2. Pour the mixture into a coffee filter placed inside a chinois.
3. Once the batch has settled and begun straining one drip at a time, switch out the receiving container.
4. Allow to fully strain. Let the resulting cocktail rest overnight before use.
5. To serve: Stir and strain over a large cube in a double Old-Fashioned glass. Express a grapefruit peel and discard.

title: Tom Macy’s Last Word
intro_philosophy: Taking second place in our recent tasting, Tom Macy’s Last Word is a bigger drink than the original—each component amped up by a quarter-ounce. His gin of choice was Tanqueray 10. But the twist that perhaps nudged his mix to the front of the pack was the Jack-Rose-like trick of a splitting the citrus element between lime and lemon juice.
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, preferably Tanqueray No. Ten
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice for about 12 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Express a lemon peel and discard.

title: Once Over #2
intro_philosophy:
Ryan Gannon originally created the Once Over #2 for an agave spirits pop up at New Orleans’s Cure. With a name inspired by an ’80s punk rock song, The Once Over #2 is the frozen, boozier, spin on the Cure’s original Once Over, a low-proof, refreshing summer sour.

“I decided to do the #2 frozen,” says Gannon, “with a float of mezcal, because it’s hot, and frozen drinks look great when you present them in a fancy glass, with a big bouquet of mint stuck in!”

Special thanks to our friends atWest Elmfor outfitting ourfrozen drinks photoshoot.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except the mezcal to a blender.
2. Add two cups of ice, and blend until smooth.
3. Pour into glass and garnish with a mint bouquet and a float of mezcal.

title: Sun City
intro_philosophy: “In general, I lean toward stirred cocktails,” says Richard Beltzer, citing theOld Palas a particular favorite. (“As I get older,” he jokes, “too many citrus drinks… It hurts.”) To the expected rye and dry vermouth components, he adds both Ramazzotti Rosato and Cap Corse blanc quinquina as a substitute for the expected Campari. It lends a lighter, less cloying quality to the drink, while a barspoon of yellow Chartreuse adds both complexity and body.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Cap Corse Mattei Blanc Quinquina Aperitif
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with lemon peel.

title: Rudolph’s Apple Sling
intro_philosophy:
Created for Boilermaker’s Christmas pop-up, Sam Gauthier’s apple sling combines apple brandy and maple syrup with a dose of St. George’s pine-y Terroir gin.

“The idea for this drink came through trying to create the sensory experience of sitting around the Christmas tree eating baked apple pie,” he explains. “You smell the pine and you taste apples, dark sweetness and warming spices.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce apple brandy, preferably Laird's Straight Apple Brandy
gin, to mist, preferably St. George Terroir
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, except gin for misting, to a mixing tin and mix.
2. Mist a Nick and Nora glass with extra gin. Pour contents of mixing tin into glass.

title: Harvey Wallbanger
intro_philosophy: It’s been said that this cartoonishly-named cocktail was created in the 1950s by Hollywood bartenderDonato Antone of Duke’s Blackwatch Bar. However, the drink didn’t earn its stripes until the 1970s when it appeared as part of a brand campaign for Galliano, the cocktail’s supporting Italian liqueur. It’s been surmised by drinks writer Robert Simonson that Antone collaborated with the brand’s importing company either to revive or create the Harvey Wallbanger, which, if true, would make himone America’s first cocktail consultants. Recently, Galliano returned to its original liqueur recipe from the 1890s, lending the Wallbanger a bit more legitimacy than it might’ve enjoyed in prior years.
ingredients: 2 ounces orange juice (Golden Cadillac uses clarified OJ)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a salted orange wheel.

title: Del Estroibo
intro_philosophy: “Prickly pear adds electricity to cocktails,” says Chris Elford of Seattle’s tropical-inspired bar, Navy Strength. “It’s so craveable, and of course the color is compelling.” The cactus-grown fruit lends a distinct, highlighter-bright hue to drinks, but also a singular flavor reminiscent of strawberries, raspberries and watermelon. Seen in Elford’s “eminently crushable” Del Estroibo, the Daiquiri template is sweetened with a combination of prickly pear syrup with an added tang from citric acid.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce white rum, preferably Uruapan Charanda
2/3 ounce prickly pear syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/3 ounce toasted corn syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with sprig of mint and lime wheel.

title: New Crush
intro_philosophy: Inspired by Spain’s Vermut & Tonic, this subtly savory riff uses cucumber and tomato to create depth and intrigue. The Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water highlights the herbal qualities of the Lustau white vermouth.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  simple syrup (1:1, sugar to hot water)
Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water, to top
instructions: 1. Wrap a cucumber ribbon around the inside of a highball glass, then fill the glass with ice. Set aside in the freezer.
2. In the bottom of a cocktail shaker, muddle cherry tomatoes in simple syrup.
3. Add vermouth, lemon juice and ice to the shaker.
4. Shake well, and fine-strain into the prepared highball glass.
5. Top with cucumber tonic water.
6. Garnish with a cherry tomato on a pick.

title: I Don’t Mind You Shooting Me, Frank, But Take It Easy on the Rum
intro_philosophy:
“I would totally make [this] on the spot to express the Yuletide spirit,” says Mockingbird Hill owner Derek Brown. In true holiday spirit, this drink takes a classic Christmas staple, candy canes, and mixes it with booze—here, in the form of crème de menthe and two types of rum.

For those wondering, the name is a quote from holiday classicScrooged, modified to stave off a Bacardi lawsuit.

“We could muck it up with bitters and perhaps use conifer tincture, as we’ve done in other drinks,” he adds. “But, for me, ripping candy canes by the dozens off the Christmas tree is what Christmas is all about. Add rum, and we’re set.”
ingredients: 1 1/2  ounces silver rum, preferably Chairman's Reserve
1/2 ounce overprooof rum, preferably Denros Strong
1/2 ounce crème de menthe, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin and shake with ice until cold.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass. Garnish with a mini candy cane.

title: See You on Wednesday
intro_philosophy: “This is every juicy, spicy, savory dream wrapped up in a festive salt-speckled bow,” writes Natasha David in her book,Drink Lightly. This nonalcoholic drink folds in layers of vegetal, piquant flavor, balanced with agave nectar for texture and weight.
instructions: 1. Prepare a double rocks glass by dipping the rim in Tajín.
2. At the bottom of a shaker, muddle the jalapeño, cilantro and agave nectar.
3. Add the celery juice, lime juice and salt solution. Add ice and shake.
4. Fine-strain into the prepared glass over large-format ice.
5. Garnish with a celery spear.

title: Smog Cutter
intro_philosophy: Dan Greenbaum of Attaboy opts for a lighter interpretation of theMargaladaomachallenge. Ginger juice makes for a fresh spin on the spice of aMichelada, while mezcal and lime recall the classicMargaritacombo. To lengthen a laPaloma, a generous dose of Negra Modelo lifts the drink while still keeping it dark and meaty.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for beer in a shaking tin.
2. Shake with ice and strain into an ice-filled Collins glass while topping with beer at the same time.

title: Dandelo
intro_philosophy: Imagine a spritz with the sweet, sour, refreshing zip of aPimm’s Cupand you have Keith Larry’s Dandelo. Refreshing, effervescent and low-ABV, Larry insists that it’s a worth companion to any meal, including breakfast.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass.
2. Add ice and the cucumber slices.
3. Cover with a shaker tin and shake to chill and bruise the cucumber.
4. Top with prosecco.

title: Rebel Without Applause
intro_philosophy: Seeking something “light and bright” for guests to enjoy on the riverside patio, Mendez came up with this juicy, high-octane cocktail. The bite of white overproof Jamaican rum and pisco are tamed by the addition of Giffard Caribbean Pineapple Liqueur and lime, while the enduring fizz of the Topo Chico ensures that the drink maintains its refreshing properties, no matter the heat index. “It drinks like a funky tropical Collins,” says Mendez.
ingredients: 1 ounce white overproof Jamaican rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
3/4 ounce pineapple liqueur, preferably Giffard Caribbean Pineapple
1 bottle ice-cold Topo Chico, half of contents poured into another container
instructions: 1. Combine first four ingredients in a shaker with ice and briefly shake, then strain into a mixing glass.
2. Pour into a half-full bottle of Topo Chico.
3. Stir and top with more Topo Chico.

title: 100-pt Julep
intro_philosophy: Chris Amirault’s homage to the popular Cynar Julep is bolstered with a foundation of high-proof rhum and vanilla syrup that results in a less sweet, more refreshing take. The supporting flavors of fresh mint and tart grapefruit juice play off the banana notes of the rhum and complement the herbaceous notes of Cynar. “It’s a high-proof vegetal sipper that goes down quite easy,” he says.
instructions: 1. Combine the fresh mint and vanilla syrup in the bottom of a julep cup or double Old-Fashioned glass, then muddle lightly to release the fragrant oils in the mint.
2. Fill glass with crushed ice.
3. Pour the Cynar, rhum and grapefruit juice over the ice.
4. Top with more crushed ice, and garnish with fresh mint sprig and a grapefruit twist. Serve with a short straw.

title: Perroquet
intro_philosophy: ThePerroquet—which translates to “parrot,” a nod to its bright green hue—belongs to a canon of pastis-plus-syrup combinations that can be found throughout France, including another popular rendition made with grenadine that’s simply called Tomate, or “tomato.” “I like the names that are super simple and super cute and very descriptive,” says Paris bar owner Margot Lecarpentier, whose take on the classic calls for a mint shrub in place of syrup for a more zippy, balanced take.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce pastis or Pernod (or similar anise liqueur)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a rocks glass over ice.
2. Garnish with a bouquet of mint.

title: Sakura Martini
intro_philosophy: Bar Goto’s houseMartiniutilizes the salted cherry blossom as a replacement for the hint of saltiness that an olive typically brings, combined with the subtle florality and sweetness of maraschino and the dry, vinous quality of sake.
ingredients: 1/4 teaspoon  maraschino liqueur, such as Luxardo
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a glass and garnish with a salted cherry blossom.

title: Pineapple Martini
intro_philosophy: Created in 1997 at London’s Met Bar in the Metropolitan Hotel, Ben Reed’s Pineapple Martini was a sensation for its novel use of freshly squeezed juice. The addition of lime juice to bolster the acidity of the pineapple was ahead of its time making the Pineapple Martini one of the more famous fruit-forward ‘tinis of the era.
ingredients: 1/8 ounce rich simple syrup (2:1, sugar:hot water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

title: Harvard
intro_philosophy: The original Harvard cocktail—equal parts Italian vermouth and brandy (plus gum syrup andAngostura bitters), stirred, strained and topped with seltzer—first appears in George J. Kappeler’s 1895Modern American Drinks.WhileSother Teaguethinks the original equal-parts recipe was likely poured long, with plenty of seltzer (“similar to how we think of a spritz”), he opts for a 2-to-1 ratio of Cognac to vermouth, with a smaller portion of fizz to finish—“more like a Manhattan,” he says.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the soda water, in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Southern Nights
intro_philosophy: Originally conceived of as a carrot cake cocktail for the “Flip” section of the Death & Co. Denver menu, Alex Jump ultimately cut the carrot element from the equation. “I worked on that drink for two months and it was terrible,” she jokes. “It never tasted like carrot cake.” Consisting of aquavit, Cognac, peanut-infused oloroso sherry, lemon and mascarpone and topped with crushed ice and peanut brittle, it still evokes a dessert-like quality. “I’m like an allergist’s nightmare, I love peanuts and peanut butter,” she says.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Cognac, preferably Pierre Ferrand Ambre
3/4 ounce peanut-infused oloroso sherry, preferably Lustau Don Nuño (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Fine strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with peanut brittle.

title: Tomate o Tomaté
intro_philosophy: Many tomato cocktails taste fresh and somewhat green, like tomato leaves. This highball atFrijolerostasted a little heavier and more autumnal. It has a sense of savoriness without entering dirty Martini territory.It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce bell pepper cordial (see Editor’s Note)
barspoon absinthe, such as Mata Hari
instructions: 1. Rim a highball glass with za’atar salt.
2. Add all ingredients except soda water to a shaker and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the prepared glass over ice, then top with soda water.

title: Paradise Lost’s Saturn
intro_philosophy: At Paradise Lost, the Saturn stands out not just because it’s garnished to the nines and served in a cloud of liquid nitrogen, but also because the bar’s falernum is made with a measure of bird’s eye chile, giving new dimension to the tropical gin drink in a way that feels like it should’ve been there all along.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce navy-strength gin, preferably New York Distilling Co. Perry’s Tot Navy Strength Gin
1/2 ounce Old Tom gin, preferably Hayman’s Old Tom Gin
1/4 ounce Thai spice falernum (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with 8 ounces of pebble ice and flash-blend for 5 seconds or until tin is frosty.
2. Pour into a rocks glass and top with an additional 4 ounces of pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel, lime wheel, cocktail fan and plastic alien toys.

title: Abigail Gullo’s Manhattan
intro_philosophy: In this recipe, Abigail Gullo, of Loa in New Orleans, calls for Rittenhouse rye as the base and splits the vermouth portion between thesherry-based Lustau Vermut Rojoand Carpano Antica, though the typical 2:1 ratio remains intact. (Gullo typically uses La Quintinye Rouge in place of Lustau, but it can be difficult to find in certain markets). Two dashes of Angostura bitters complete the recipe, which the judges at our Manhattan blind tasting found to be pleasantly spice-forward.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Lustau Vermut or La Quintinye Rouge
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with cracked ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express a lemon twist from high over the surface of the drink and discard.
4. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.

title: Fernet Ramos
intro_philosophy: Bartender Camille Razo recommends using a “fat third” of both the lemon and lime juices in her bitter Fernet Ramos. Also of note: the Coca-Cola is poured into the Collins glass first, not last (“the bubbles help it coagulate,” Razo explains). After mixing, the drink is set in the freezer to help solidify the froth on top.
ingredients: 1 ounce blended Scotch, preferably Monkey Shoulder
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the Coca-Cola in a mixing tin with ice.
2. Shake well, then strain ingredients into a second mixing tin.
3. Shake again without ice.

4. Pour Coca-Cola into a Collins glass, then pour the contents of the shaker over the cola. (The drink will fizz up, and you’ll likely have three or four ounces of the alcohol and cream mixture left over. Set it aside.)
5. Place the glass in the freezer for three minutes.

6. Remove the glass from the freezer. Use a straw to poke a hole in the middle of the drink, then pull it out. If excess bubbles cling to the straw, put the drink back in the freezer for a couple of minutes, and repeat the process.

7. Swirl the mixing tin containing the remaining the alcohol and cream mixture to stir the contents. Pour the contents into the glass, through the hole made with the straw. The meringue top should rise above the glass like a soufflé.
8. Lay a straw across the top of the meringue and serve.

title: LaCroix Boi
intro_philosophy: Borrowing from themusic videoof the same name, Abigail Gullo’s LaCroix Boi pays homage to the flavored sparkling water by combining berry- and lemongrass-infused Aperol, Jamaican rum and lime cordial directly in a can of coconut LaCroix.
ingredients: 2 ounces berry- and lemongrass-infused Aperol (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Pour out 3 1/4 ounces of the coconut LaCroix.
2. Add remaining ingredients directly into the can.
3. Garnish with a lemongrass stalk, blackberries, raspberries and a lime peel.

title: Black Manhattan
intro_philosophy: The Manhattan’s simple construction is a foolproof formula for the Mr. Potato Head approach to drink creation. Simply swapping the vermouth quotient for Averna, as Todd Smith did at San Francisco’s Cortez in 2005, will yield the Black Manhattan, a modern classic that gave the then-obscure amaro a notable boost in recognition
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a cherry.

title: Room for Improvement’s Nuclear Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: One of three featured drinks onRoom for Improvement’sdedicated Daiquiri menu, this spin on the modern classic subs in génépy for the expected Chartreuse. The small but considered change is typical of the bar’s approach, which sticks to the classics, often incorporating subtle tweaks, like using “cranpari” cordial in their house Cosmo.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce unaged overproof Jamaican rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
3/4 ounce génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy le Chamois
1/2 ounce falernum, preferably John D. Taylor’s Velvet Falernum
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a cocktail shaker, then shake vigorously until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: ABV’s Piña Verde
intro_philosophy: “We’ve tried génépy in all kinds of cocktails where we’d normally use green Chartreuse,” says ABV’s Ryan Fitzgerald, of the herbal, pine-scented liqueur. In this cocktail—”a sort of tribute to [San Francisco bartender] Marcovaldo Dionysos, creator of the Chartreuse Swizzle and lover of tequila”—génépy meets blanco tequila, lime and pineapple, for a summer sipper that’s refreshing and ever-so-slightly bitter.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Tapatio Blanco 80pf
3/4 ounce génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy des Alpes
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients and fine-strain into chilled coupe.
2. Garnish with compressed pineapple.

title: St. John Frizell’s Irish Coffee
intro_philosophy: One of the most beloved Irish Coffees in New York, St. John Frizell’s recipe was one of only two in our recent blind tasting to call on fresh espresso rather than coffee. It tied for first place with the recipe from The Kerryman in Chicago.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Irish whiskey, preferably Powers Gold Label Irish Whiskey
whipped heavy cream, to top (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add the whiskey and simple syrup into a mixing tin.
2. Add a small amount of boiling water to an 11-ounce mug to heat it, and nestle the tin in the mug so that the tin heats as well.
3. Dump the water out of the mug, add the whiskey-sugar mixture and top with boiling water to about 1 inch below the rim of the glass.
4. Pour the espresso shot directly into the mug.
5. Float the cream on top and garnish with freshly grated cinnamon.

title: Barber of Seville
intro_philosophy: Named for the 19th-century Rossini opera of the same name, the Barber of Seville is part julep, part Spanish swizzle. A base of dry manzanilla sherry paves the way for bitter Cappelletti—a crimson Italian aperitivo. Both are then bolstered by rye whiskey, creamy orgeat and the sweet aromatics of orange bitters and orange flower water. Served in a frosty julep tin over crushed ice and topped with Marcona almonds and orange zest, the result is reminiscent of a tikified julep with European flair.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a julep tin or rocks glass and top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with crushed marcona almonds, finely channeled orange zest and a fancy cocktail parasol if you've got one.

title: Alta Linea’s Frozen Negroni
intro_philosophy: Alta Linea’s Frozen Negroni takes the classic Italian staple and gives it a new summer look by serving it frozen. At the restaurant, it’s made in large batches and served via a slush machine, but it can be made at home with the help of grapefruit sorbet.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bowl and mix with a whisk.
2. Pour the mixture into a rocks glass and top with an additional splash of Campari, if desired.
3. Garnish with a slice of orange.

title: MARTINI & ROSSI® Negroni Sbagliato
intro_philosophy: Dubbed the “mistaken” Negroni for its use of Prosecco rather than the original’s call for gin, the Sbagliato has become a classic Italian cocktail in its own right. MARTINI & ROSSI Rubino Vermouth mingles with MARTINI & ROSSI Bitter Liqueur to create a bittersweet backbone, then is topped with Prosecco to lighten and lengthen. For a pinker-hued version, swap the Prosecco for sparkling rosé.
ingredients: 1 ounce  MARTINI & ROSSI Riserva Speciale Rubino Vermouth
1 ounce  MARTINI & ROSSI Prosecco Or Rosé Italian Sparkling Wine
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a rocks glass.
2. Stir gently to integrate.

title: Peachie
intro_philosophy: Created as a spring/summer aperitivo, this “feminine and delicate” spritz riff accents the citrusy essence of Italicus with a small measure of peach liqueur, plus grapefruit bitters to balance the sweetness. Dario Doimo, an Italian native who grew up in the middle of the region that produces Prosecco, lengthens the spritz in the classic style, using both soda water and his homeland’s native sparkler.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  Giffard Crème de Pêche de Vigne
instructions: 1. In a large wine glass, combine all ingredients over ice. Stir gently to combine.
2. Garnish with grapefruit peel and edible flower.

title: King Buzzo
intro_philosophy: Often described as bitter and grassy in flavor, szechuan buttons offer up a characteristically mouth-numbing, tingling finish that’s not dissimilar to the electric sting of a handful of Pop Rocks. At Brooklyn’s Montana’s Trail House, beverage director and managing partner Austin Hartman incorporates them into a rimming salt for the King Buzzo, a drink built on tequila, fake lime juice (adapted from Dave Arnold’sLiquid Intelligence) and honey syrup, topped off with a splash of sparkling rosé.
ingredients: 1 generous bar spoon lime acid (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass with a half rim of szechuan button salt.
2. Combine all ingredients except the rose in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared rocks glass.

title: Grenadine
intro_philosophy: Historically made from tart-sweet pomegranate juice and sugar, grenadine is perhaps the most enduring in the category of concentrated fruit syrups that were popular cocktail ingredients in the late 19thcentury. The name most likely comes from France, a translation of the word pomegranate (grenade), which is also the country that cocktail historians speculate first gave rise to the syrup’s popularity. Today, grenadine makes an appearance in cocktails such as the Pink Lady, Mexican Firing Squad and non-alcoholic drinks such as the Shirley Temple.
instructions: 1. Add sugar and pomegranate juice to a small sauce pan and set over low heat.
2. Stir over low heat until sugar dissolves into juice.
3. Let cool, bottle and refrigerate.
4. Keeps for 2 weeks refrigerated.

title: Gargoyle and Spire
intro_philosophy:
I live in the Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, in a building that had been, until the mid-1980s, home to the Brooklyn Cathedral Preparatory Seminary. In a nod to the building’s neo-Gothic architecture, Cathedral Prep’s yearbook was calledGargoyle, and its newspaper theSpire. And there’s a squadron of very impressive gargoyles perched around the upper perimeter of the building. These aren’t squat grotesqueries lurking in the shadows, but lean creatures with wings folded back and mouths agape, stretching out from the building as if they’re about to strafe the pedestrians on the sidewalk below.

Using Strega, whose name means “witch,” in the Gargoyle & Spire seems fitting. Aged in ash barrels, it’s a spellbinding Italian liqueur dating back to 1860 that’s made up of dozens of herbs and spices, including saffron, which is the secret to Strega’s distinctive yellow hue.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Combine the gin, Strega, simple syrup, and bitters in mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a highball glass filled with ice and top off with the Champagne or sparkling wine.
4. Garnish with the orange twist.

title: East India Negroni
intro_philosophy:
This drink, from Jim Meehan of PDT, really began with the rum. More specifically, it began with Joseph Banks—an eighteenth-century explorer and Captain Cook’s sidekick on his first voyage. The 5-Island rum used in this drink is a tribute to Banks and Cook’s maiden voyage, as is the East India, an old-school style of sherry that was originally matured in the same way as early madeira (via tumultuous sea voyage on masted ships). “The rum takes its namesake from a dude who would’ve been on the same ship that the East India sherry would’ve traveled in,” says Meehan. The interplay of the subtle funk of the rum with the raisiny woodiness of Lustau’s East India sherry makes for a cocktail that drinks like a Negroni best consumed near the equator.

Reprinted with permission fromSherry,by Talia Baiocchi, copyright 2014. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House LLC.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sherry, preferably Lustau East India
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients but the garnish to a mixing glass, then add ice.
2. Stir and strain into a rocks glass with one large ice cube.
3. Garnish with the orange peel.

title: Early Morning Breeze
intro_philosophy: “I love, love, love tomatillos and I’ve been trying to figure out how to get it into a cocktail without it being overbearing or too vegetal,” says Arianna Hone, who landed on a syrup in this spritz-style drink, which combines gin and small amounts of Strega, mezcal and basil eau de vie alongside lime and yuzu juice. “A lot of people who order this drink at my bar don’t like tomatillos or are really intimidated by the ingredients,” says Hone, “but with a little bit of convincing, they end up loving it.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce St. George Basil eau de vie
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except soda water and prosecco in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a wine glass and top with soda water and prosecco.
3. Garnish with a shiso leaf.

title: Green Mango Martini
intro_philosophy: At the New York barSuperbueno, drinks are grounded in Mexican American tradition, many of them designed to honor specific ingredients and dishes. The Green Mango Martini, one of the bar’s bestsellers, highlights mango through both an infusion of the unripe fruit in tequila and a mango eau de vie. Tying everything together is a drop of costeño chile oil, which evokes the spice of Tajín sprinkled on a fruit.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces green mango–infused tequila (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce honey syrup (1:1, honey to water)
2 dashes of Maldon salt solution (1:10, Maldon salt to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass.
2. Stir until cold, then strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a drop of chile oil.

title: Smuggler’s Cove’s Zombie
intro_philosophy: Adapted from Donn Beach’s Zombie, created in 1934, Martin Cate’s version of the classic tiki cocktail hews close to tradition. A potent mix of rum, citrus and sweetener, the original drink was shrouded in myth about its madness-inducing properties, including menu warnings about a two-per-person limit imposed “for your own safety.” Today, it’s no wonder that Cate advises to garnish “with a mint sprig and a healthy dose of trepidation.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Smuggler's Cove cinnamon syrup (see Editor's Note)
1 teaspoon Smuggler's Cove grenadine (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce velvet falernum, preferably John D. Taylor's
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a drink mixer tin with 4 to 6 standard "agitator" ice cubes.
2. Pulse for three to four seconds to aerate, dilute and chill the drink while leaving much of the ice intact.
3. Pour into Zombie or highball glass allowing most of the contents into the glass before using a gated finish to ensure the entire drink fits in the serving glass.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: True Chesapeake Oyster Co.’s Southside
intro_philosophy: True Chesapeake Oyster Co.’s Southside is an ode to the drink’s history at Baltimore-area country clubs and is enjoyed across the region at “hunt cups,” steeplechase-like events that have a strong tailgating tradition and Derby-like costume. The tall, refreshing drink is served on crushed ice, topped with ginger beer, and uses the bar’s house Southside mix—a traditional means of preparing Baltimore-style Southsides for many decades now.
ingredients: 2 ounces aged rum, preferably Mount Gay Eclipse
instructions: 1. Combine rum and Southside mix in a 16-ounce glass.
2. Top with pebble ice and stir briefly.
3. Top with ginger beer.

title: Skeleton Cruise
intro_philosophy: At Tiki Tatsu-Ya in Austin, the Skeleton Cruise is served in a bespoke boat, accompanied by light and sound effects as the drink heads to the table. The recipe, which combines Japanese whisky with a blend of rums and pineapple, lemon and guava, is inspired by the Bali Ha’i cocktail from Hanalei Plantation Resort and the Pago Pago from the 1940 edition ofThe How and Whencocktail book.
ingredients: 3 ounces lightly aged rum, preferably Probitas
2 ounces Demerara rum, preferably El Dorado 12 Year
1/2 ounce maraschino liqueur, preferably Luxardo Maraschino
instructions: 1. Mix all ingredients besides Champagne together in two mixing tins, with a cup of crushed ice in each.
2. Flash-blend using a spindle mixer, then pour into a large vessel that fits at least 3 quarts. Top with more crushed ice to fill. (Make sure the ice is solid on top for garnish.)
3. Top ice with tropical fruits, flowers and large straws. Float Champagne on top of the drink immediately before serving.

title: Caribbean Queen
intro_philosophy: In this tropical Old-Fashioned variation that’s currently on the menu at Llama San, Natasha Bermudez calls on a split base of amontillado sherry and Japanese whisky. “The Nikka Coffey Malt whisky has a lot of banana on the nose and vanilla, with a very light smoke at the back of your palate. Amontillado sherry is salty, nutty—they work really nicely together.” A small measure ofParanubes Oaxacan agricole rumadds a “green grassy note,” says Bermudez, underscoring the tropical through-line of this drink.
ingredients: 1 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Amontillado Principe de Barbadillo
1 ounce Japanese whisky, preferably Nikka Coffey Malt
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express lime peel and discard.
4. Garnish with a dehydrated pineapple slice.

title: Japanese Whisky Highball
intro_philosophy: Ubiquitous in Japan, the whisky highball, like so much of Japanese drinking culture, has become an object of fascination on this side of the Pacific for years. Here, the dead simple two-ingredient formula.
instructions: 1. In an ice filled highball glass, pour the whisky.
2. Top with soda water, being careful not to pour directly onto the ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon expression.

title: F.A.F. Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: “There’s a Don the Beachcomber quote, ‘What one rum can’t do, three rums can,’” says Jim Kearns. “If you swap in different types of rum, you will always create a more complex flavor profile—the rums will play off of each other.” The approach, which has become something of a go-to move. Here he incorporates no fewer than five base rums and introduces both Trinidadian and Guyanese examples into the mix.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce white rhum agricole, preferably Niesson L'Esprit
1/4 ounce overproof white rum, preferably Wray & Newphew TK
1/2 ounce aged rum, preferably Pusser's 15 year
1/2 ounce Trinidadian rum, preferably The Scarlet Ibis
1/2 ounce aged rum, preferably Plantation Barbados
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice and a lime disc.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Super Lyan G&T
intro_philosophy: Team Lyan’s recipe for the beloved G&T recreates its flavors without the addition of tonic water or quinine.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over ice.

title: Turn Down Service
intro_philosophy: Dan Greenbaum’s Turn Down Service is, as the name implies, that final treat before turning in, like the chocolate on your hotel pillow. With just a touch of St-Germain alongside Scotch and tawny port, this spirit-forward drink is the final indulgence of the day, complete with the requisite cherry on top.
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain over a large ice cube into a double rocks glass and garnish with a cherry.

title: Cane & Table’s Royal Hawaiian
intro_philosophy: After servingRoyal Hawaiiansat Cane & Table for over a decade, Matt Young is very particular about every aspect of the drink, from the overproof gin to the freshly juiced pineapple and exacting orgeat. Young breaks with the original spec and makes the drink more New Orleans–friendly by serving it over pebble ice.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces London Dry gin, such as Bombay Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Add a handful of pebble ice and whip-shake.
3. Pour into a chilled double rocks glass, and top with more pebble ice.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet and serve with a straw.

title: Thad Vogler’s El Presidente
intro_philosophy: The Cuban classic gets an update from Obispo bar owner Thad Vogler who swaps in bianco vermouth for the traditional dry. An extra portion of rum and the addition of orange bitters make for a fuller, more rounded take on the original.
ingredients: 1 barspoon grenadine, preferably Small Hand Foods
instructions: 1. Stir and strain into a chilled stem glass.
2. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Sarah Morrissey’s Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Sarah Morrissey‘s recipe took third place in our recent blind Gimlet tasting. Hers was the simplest construction of all, blending two ounces of Tanqueray, three-quarters of an ounce of simple syrup (1 1/2:1) and one ounce of fine-strained lime juice. The panel found it “well-knit.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Away Colors
intro_philosophy: Created at the now-closed Lion Lion in New York, the Away Colors is a simple stirred cocktail that’s ideal for after-dinner drinking. Taking its name from a soccer idiom for playing away from a team’s home, the recipe’s ingredients, like añejo rum and banana liqueur, find themselves across continents and meridians.
ingredients: 2 ounces añejo rum, preferably Ron del Barrilito or Cruzan Single Barrel
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Green Park Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Eric Lorincz, head bartender atThe Savoyin London created this riff on one of the hotel’s most famous eye-openers, theCorpse Reviver No. 2. The original mix of gin, Lillet, Cointreau is replaced with Old Tom gin, basil, celery bitters and egg white for a fizzy, herbaceous play on Harry Craddock’s early 20th-century original.
instructions: 1. In the bottom of a cocktail shaker, gently muddle the basil with the simple syrup.
2. Add remaining ingredients, add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Daiquiri No. 3
intro_philosophy: The Daiquiri No. 3, Constantino Ribalaigua Vert’s Cuban masterpiece now commonly referred to as the Hemingway Daiquiri, was served blended—or as a “frappé”—according to his original recipe at the Floridita. Just like its shaken version, the No. 3 is a base of white rum, grapefruit and lime juices and maraschino liqueur. But do us a favor, and don’t prepare it the way Hemingway demanded it, with “double the rum and none of the sugar.”
ingredients: 4 ounces crushed ice, prepared with a Lewis bag and mallet or a food processor
instructions: 1. In a blender, combine the rum, simple syrup, lime juice, grapefruit juice and maraschino liqueur with 4 ounces crushed ice.
2. Blend on low speed until smooth.
3. Pour into a chilled wine glass or large coupe.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge and serve with a straw.

title: Summer Fling
intro_philosophy:
“I love spritzes in general,” saysNatashaDavid of the designated spritz section onNitecap’s menu, which changes twice yearly. “It’s the kind of drink I love doing because you can take the alcohol down a bit and then can pump it up with bubbles.”

ThisAperol Spritzvariation riffs on one of David’s personal favorites: a simple Aperol sour. Here, she ups the citrus and fruit while still hewing to the classic, low-ABV spirit of the original.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except sparkling wine into an ice-filled shaker tin.
2. Shake well and strain into a wine glass over ice.
3. Top with sparkling wine.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit crescent and a lime wheel.

title: Bitter Mai Tai
intro_philosophy:
Perhaps the most riffed-upon cocktail in the tiki canon, the Mai Tai serves as the inspiration for Jeremy Oertel’s decidedly bitter spin. Intrigued by a version he encountered that used Angostura bitters in place of rum, Oertel takes his bitter iteration in a different direction, incorporating red-hued Campari. A measure of funky Jamaican rum provides extra fortification in this version that was a staple of the now-closed Brooklyn bar Dram, where Oertel first created it.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce aged Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
2. Strain into a large rocks glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with mint sprig.

title: Half Court Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Simply sherry, sugar and citrus, shaken, poured over crushed ice and slurped through a straw, the originalSherry Cobbleris thought to have originated sometime in the 1820s or early 1830s. But like most 19th century drinks, its origins are foggy. Greenbaum sticks to the Cobbler’s original architecture, but adds a dash of Cynar and honey syrup for bittersweet complexity.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces amontillado sherry (preferably Gonzalez Byass Viña AB)
instructions: 1. Muddle citrus with honey syrup in a Collins glass.
2. Add sherry, Cynar and crushed ice.
3. Swizzle with a straw or spoon to mix.
4. Garnish with an orange and lemon wheel.

title: Silver Chawari
intro_philosophy:
This highball is named forchawari, a classic shochu serve. “Chameans ‘tea’ in Japanese, andwaru(orwari) means ‘to cut’ or ‘to mix with,’” Julia Momosé explains. “This serve is an izakaya staple,” often made with green tea or oolong tea.

For this version, she selected a sencha from her hometown of Kyoto, paired with the “exquisite” Hakutake Ginrei Shiro shochu, a rice-based silver shochu fermented with ginjo sake yeast at very low temperatures for extra aromatics. Bermutto, a new aperitif from Japan, adds pleasantly bright, herbaceous tones. “Bermutto is spelled as such, a play on the way we pronounce ‘vermouth’ in Japan,” Momosé explains, but it’s not a true vermouth, as the base is nihonshu and rice shochu, not wine. Imbued with citrus fruits kabosu and yuzu, sansho pepper and yomogi (also called Japanese mugwort), these botanicals highlight the fruity and green notes of the tea, as well as the tropical fruit notes found in the shochu. A final note from Momosé: The drink “does not need any garnish, as it is eloquently aromatic as is.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  Oka Kura Japanese Bermutto sake vermouth
3 to 4 ounces  chilled Ryokucha (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice. Stir to chill and strain off the melted water.
2. Measure the shochu, Bermutto and chilled ryokucha into the glass.
3. Give a gentle stir, and serve.

title: Mauby Mojito
intro_philosophy: AtSavannah Caféin Brooklyn, Mojitos are mixed with a splash of mauby, a classic Caribbean brew, made from mauby tree bark, warm spices and sugar.
ingredients: 1 ounce mauby(freshly brewed, or made from store-bought concentrate)
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle mint leaves, lime juice and sugar.
2. Add rum, mauby, triple sec, cinnamon bark and ice, and shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a tall glass, one-third full of ice.
4. Top with club soda and garnish with lime wheel and mint sprigs.

title: Hot Toddy
intro_philosophy: Though the modern definition of the toddy almost always points to any alcoholic beverage served hot, it wasn’t always so. One of the ancestral drinks of the cocktail world, the toddy’s traditional formula loosely meant a base spirit (usually rum or whiskey), plus a sweetener, served either hot or cold. There were some medicinal connotations for the practice, especially when it included citrus. Today the usage encompasses a wide swath of drinks that swings from the most basic recipe of a base spirit plus sugar to more complex iterations with cream, egg, fruit, liqueurs, spices and garnishes a plenty. This version is a template prime for riffing with a base of any dark spirit, plus hot water, citrus, honey and spices.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon or rye (or any dark spirit including aged rum or cognac)
instructions: 1. Add spirit and honey or maple syrup to a mug.
2. Top with hot water and stir gently to dissolve honey or maple syrup.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel and a cinnamon stick.

title: Dan Sabo’s Champagne Cocktail
intro_philosophy: AChampagne Cocktailwith a little something extra. Bartender Dan Sabo slips a half-ounce of Hennessy VSOP into the mix, which the taste buds detect not so much for its flavor, but for the added kick and body it brings to the drink. Further finessing the recipe is a bright accent of orange bitters.
ingredients: Champagne, preferably Perrier Jouët Brut NV, to top
instructions: 1. Dash the bitters onto the sugar cube before placing it in the chilled flute.
2. Add the Cognac.
3. Top with Champagne.
4. Garnish with an expressed lemon peel (discarded), a long horse's neck lemon peel and a brandied cherry.

title: I’m a Loner, Toddy, a Rebel
intro_philosophy: If you’re not lucky enough to be standing in Prague’s Old Town Square and snapping photos of the astronomical clock, this is the next best thing on a cold winter day, explains Brian Bartels of this Becherovka-based take on a toddy.
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a coffee cup.
2. Top with hot water.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Espresso Martini (N/A)
intro_philosophy: To make a nonalcoholic version of the ubiquitous Espresso Martini, Ryan Castelaz, who heads up a coffee company and a zero-proof cocktail bar, reaches for two N/A spirits from Lyre’s that are modeled onKahlúaand rum. He rounds out the drink with a housemade vanilla syrup and coffee that’s brewed with an ultrasonic jewelry cleaner—an unorthodox gadget used in some high-tech bars—for optimal creaminess. At home, you can use cold-brew concentrate in its place.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in the small half of a shaker tin.
2. Dry-shake for 15 to 20 seconds to aerate the mixture, then fill the small half of the shaker tin with ice. Seal and hard shake for 12 seconds.
3. Double-strain into a coupe or small Martini glass.
4. Garnish with 3 coffee beans and an expressed and discarded lemon peel.

title: The Date Night Highball
intro_philosophy: This drink subtly unpacks the nuances of its base spirit, gin, in a fizzy highball that’s long on complexity. An infused tonic brings lemony herbs to the fore, while a housemade cordial offers vegetal, nutty notes. Absinthe brightened with a touch of raspberry highlights the gin’s licorice notes and helps bind all the elements.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces lemon essence tonic (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the gin, tonic, cordial and raspberry absinthe to a highball glass.
2. Add crushed ice to nearly fill the glass, then add club soda.
3. Stir two or three revolutions and cap with more crushed ice.
4. Mist the top with toasted sesame oil, then garnish with a pickled cucumber marshmallow and a straw.

title: Talea Beer Co.’s Beermosa
intro_philosophy: Beer-based drinks “are inherently effervescent, typically more volume to drink and easy to make,” says Tara Hankinson, co-founder and co-CEO ofTalea Beer Co.Her brewery and taproom, with outposts in Williamsburg and Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, offers beer-based delights like “beermosas” (sometimes referred to as“bromosas”elsewhere) and beer pops.
ingredients: 3 ounces hazy IPA, preferably Talea Beer Co. Sun Up Hazy IPA
3 ounces sparkling white wine, preferably RGNY
instructions: 1. Combine the IPA and sparkling wine in a 13-ounce stemmed glass, pouring the wine slowly to maximize volume.
2. Garnish with the dried orange wheel.

title: TGI Fridays’ June Bug
intro_philosophy: Tracing the strange and recursive popularity of this unnaturally colored concoction is full of side streets and detours.The June Bugwas born in a TGI Fridays in Michigan in the late 1980s—or was it an outpost of the chain restaurant in Busan, South Korea? Depending on who you ask, it’s been around since as far back as the 1960s, lurking in Midwestern neighborhood bars and the memories of airport bartenders. Now, it’s having a moment in the cocktail scene of Great Britain. Though the drink is often reimagined and updated, here it shines in its original glory, sour mix and all.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass with ice and briefly stir.
2. Garnish with a pineapple wedge and a cherry.

title: Canelli Sour
intro_philosophy: Stacey Swenson, head bartender at New York’s Dante, pulls from the family of Italian red bitters in her Canelli Sour. Building on a base of Contratto Bitter and tequila, plus grapefruit and lemon juices, Swenson dresses the summer-ready flavors for fall in this frothy sour.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and dry shake.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Vermouth
intro_philosophy: Eryn Reece, of New York’s Freeman’s and Banzarbar, finds apple cider vinegar to be a useful tool in offsetting the round, sometimes sour notes of verjus, and will often use both ingredients together. Her Vermouth cocktail, for example, is a lower proof, modern spin on the Martini built on a vermouth base, with an unexpected crisp, refreshing finish thanks to the combination of verjus and vinegar.
ingredients: 2 teaspoons Leopold Bros. New York Sour Apple Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the Champagne, in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Top with Champagne.

title: Stinger
intro_philosophy: This iconic pre-Prohibition cocktail—an unlikely combo of white crème de menthe and Cognac shaken and served up—stormed bar menus in the 1920s, becoming a favorite among high society (the mint flavor supposedly helped to disguise alcohol on one’s breath). According to David Wondrich’sImbibe!,New York playboy Reginald Vanderbilt was known for mixing them religiously every day at cocktail hour, often with a dash of absinthe.It has pop culture credentials too, tallying up screen time in the 1957 Cary Grant vehicleKiss Them for Me, as well as in 1956’sHigh Society, featuring Bing Crosby and Frank Sinatra. This version is an update adding a bit of freshness with muddled mint and a dash of orange bitters to blend it all together.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce crème de menthe (preferably Tempus Fugit)
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, muddle mint with crème de menthe and orange bitters.
2. Add cognac and ice, and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass or strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a small sprig of mint.

title: Romance In Graceland
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to highlight the natural properties of Cognac” says of this brandy-based cocktail, observing that the dried fruit notes of the spirit remind him of a cheese board. His first instinct was to incorporate mascarpone into the recipe, but during the workshopping process—while snacking on a peanut butter and banana sandwich—inspiration hit. Taking a cue from the timeless pairing, Cruz opted instead to fat-wash the Cognac in peanut butter, play up the banana notes with banana liqueur, and the nuttiness with amontillado sherry, while adding acidity with fresh lemon juice. The element that ties it all together is a house-made “creamy agave syrup,” made from condensed milk and agave nectar that adds silky texture to the cocktail.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces peanut butter fat-washed VS Cognac (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane Liqueur
1/2 ounce creamy agave syrup (see Editor’s Note)
2 dashes chocolate bitters, preferably Fee Brothers Aztec Chocolate Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled frappe glass over crushed ice.
3. Top with more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with lemon peel spiral, a dried banana flag and grated nutmeg.
5. Serve with a straw.

title: L’Aperitivo Caffè
intro_philosophy: Afternoons in Italy spent sipping spritzes and recharging with espresso were the inspiration for Julia Momose’s L’Aperitivo Caffè. “I was thinking about one of my current favorites, which is the Americano, a combination of fortified wine with bitter liqueur, topped off with soda,” says Momose. “This is just a couple of steps away from that.” Barley shochu and L’Aperitivo Nonino’s delicate flavors combine with coffee liqueur and tonic to create a simultaneously rich yet refreshing late-afternoon sipper. “An aperitivo is meant to give you a little pick-me-up.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  barley shochu  (preferably Kintaro Roasted Barley Shochu)
1/4 ounce  coffee liqueur  (preferably Don Ciccio & Figli Concerto)
instructions: 1. Build in a chilled highball glass over ice, and garnish with an expressed lemon peel and a swath of lemon peel.

title: Springy Chuhai
intro_philosophy: Chuhai is a Japanese term for a shochu highball. This bright, crushable cocktail combines Calpico with California citrus, lemongrass-infused shochu and gin, topped with what Karen Fu calls a “zesty, yet delicate” tonic water. The addition of Calpico lends texture and body that’s “serendipitously milk and slightly fizzy.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce cane syrup (1:1 evaporated cane sugar to water)
1/2 ounce shochu, preferably Mizu Lemongrass Shochu
1 1/2 ounce gin, preferably Roku or Martin Miller’s
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and muddle kumquats. Shake.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Top with tonic water.
4. Stir to integrate.
5. Garnish with kumquat slice.

title: Fruit Me Out
intro_philosophy:
With her Fruit Me Out, Natasha Bermudez offers a spirited take on the union of a Kingston Negroni and Sbagliato, marrying fragrant berry preserves, bitter Campari and a Jamaican rum rich with notes of caramelized tropical fruit. She takes things into highball territory by topping it off with Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic Water, a delicate, aromatic mixer with a softer-than-usual bitter kick from using less quinine in the mix. “It has lasting bubbles and fresh-tasting ingredients,” says Bermudez. “It softens the dryness and adds a beautiful bittersweet note on your back- and midpalate.”

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: ¾ ounce  Jamaican white rum,  preferably Habitation Velier Forsyths WP 502
1 barspoon  fruit preserves, preferably Bonne Maman Four Fruits Preserves
2 ounces  Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic Water, chilled
instructions: 1. Add the fruit preserves, Campari and rum to a mixing glass, then fill with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Fine-strain into a rocks glass filled with ice.
4. Top with tonic water.
5. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Silhouettes
intro_philosophy: At the Denver location of Death & Co., the Silhouettes has recently “soared in popularity,” according to bar manager Jake Powell. The Gimlet riff adds Empirical Spirits’ Plum, I Suppose (a bright, floral spirit), vanilla syrup and grenadine to the template, putting an unexpected twist on the classic.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces gin, preferably St. George Terroir
1/2 ounce Empirical Spirits’ Plum, I Suppose
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Georgetown Club
intro_philosophy: The Georgetown Club appears in the pages ofCharles H. Baker Jr.’s 1951South American Gentleman’s Companion.
