The recipe that Baker recorded is a trinity of the “finest white rum available,” dry vermouth and the Caribbean spiced cordial falernum.Bartender Frederic Yarm created his spin on the recipe by adding a quarter-ounce of rhum agricole blanc to enhance the drink’s tropical flavor. Finally, he opts for a lime twist over the called-for lemon or orange, to complement both the rum and the falernum.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces unaged or lightly aged rum, such as Privateer New England White Rum
1 ounce dry vermouth, such as Dolin
1/4 ounce rhum agricole blanc, such as Rhum J.M Agricole Blanc 80°
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with a lime twist.

title: Meloncholia
intro_philosophy: Lynnette Marrero, bar director for Llama Inn and Llama San, and bartender John Ware build on a base of pisco, watermelon and rosé with the balancing heat of habanero in the Meloncholia. It’s equal parts “crushable”  and surprising.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the club soda in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice and top with club soda.
3. Garnish with a manicured lime peel.

title: Chain Reaction
intro_philosophy: A traditional Japanese ume liqueur was the jumping off point for this Collins-style cocktail, made in collaboration between bartendersAlicia Perryand Ewan Bennie. Complemented by California-made Amaro Angeleno (with its notes of orange, gentian and jasmine), peach liqueur and lime juice, all topped with soda, it’s simple, bright and refreshing.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Choya Single Year plum wine
3/4 ounce peach liqueur, preferably Giffard Crème de Pêche de Vigne
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, apart from soda water, in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.
3. Top with soda water and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Velvet Jukebox
intro_philosophy: In this sloe gin- and ginger-infused take on a sour, Andrew Meltzer splits the base between blanco tequila and manzanilla sherry. “The benefit of doing a split base,” explains Meltzer, “is it allows manzanilla to shine hand-in-hand with whatever you’re pairing it with.” Here, manzanilla’s inherent salinity complements tequila much the same way a salt rim might in a traditional Margarita formula.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake until thoroughly chilled.
2. Fine strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Kentucky Mai Tai
intro_philosophy:
The name of this Mai Tai riff nods to the source of its bourbon base, but that’s not the only update Dan Sabo makes to the original. Mezcal, peach liqueur, and Cynar, a bittersweet Italian artichoke liqueur, make an appearance alongside the expected lemon and orgeat.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1 ounce bourbon, preferably Evan Williams Black Label
1 ounce mezcal, preferably Nuestra Soledad Espadin Joven
1/2 ounce peach liqueur, preferably Combier or Giffard crème de pêche de vigne
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
2. Strain into a rocks glass half filled with crushed ice. Add more crushed ice to fill the glass.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig, cherry, and pineapple slice.

title: Smoked Tomato
intro_philosophy: St-Germain has a great flowery and sweet flavor that is so much fun to play with,” explains Los Angeles-based bartender Matthew Biancaniello, who pairs the elderflower liqueur with elements pulled directly from the dinner table.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce agave syrup (1:1, agave nectar: water)
2 ounces smoked tomato-infused St-Germain (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a shaker, muddle all of the ingredients except the infused St-Germain.
2. Add the St-Germain and ice and shake.
3. Double strain into a coupe.
4. Garnish with flowering garlic chives.

title: Gattopardo
intro_philosophy: With his Gattopardo, Garret Richard gives the Garibaldi the clarified treatment, trading the drink’s signaturefluffy citrus cloudfor an elegant, streamlined finish.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce clarified, acid-adjusted orange juice (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Espresso Mexicano Martini
intro_philosophy:
Proof that not all Vodka Espressos are made with vodka: “If a ticket came in for an Espresso Martini at my last restaurant, I would find the guest and ask them if a Mexican-inspired one with tequila and cinnamon was alright instead of a classic vodka one,” Yarm recalls. “This generally got not only a nod of approval, but the ticket frequently jumped from one to two or three drinks.”

He notes that the amount of simple syrup may need to be tweaked based on the bitterness and acid in the espresso.
ingredients: 1 ounce espresso, freshly pulled and slightly cooled
1/4 ounce simple syrup(or more if needed)
1 dash mole bitters, preferably Bittermens Xocolatl
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Use a straw to taste for sweetness balance; add simple syrup in ¼ ounce increments as needed.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Garnish with coffee beans, floated in a triangle on the espresso foam.

title: Niesen Buzz Bomb
intro_philosophy: This was the preferred concoction of Gertrude Niesen, an actress and singer and frequent patron of Manhattan’s Stork Club in the 1930s and ‘40s. It’s a hell of a drink—like the prickly cousin of a Long Island Iced Tea—but if you cut out the vodka and go heavy on the Champagne as Dear Irving’s Tom Richter does in his updated version (see Editor’s Note), it turns into a lovely French 75-esque cocktail.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except Champagne to a mixing glass and mix with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass and top with Champagne.

title: Sangue di Gambi
intro_philosophy: “When I think of a great winter drink, I look for something that warms you up, has great texture and has notes of baking spices like cinnamon, clove and allspice,” says John Filkins, beverage director for Washington, D.C.’s Officina. “And for winter cocktails, I love incorporating alpine styles of amaro.” His Sangue di Gambi, named after a notorious Italian pirate from the early 1800s, marries a lightly sweet Demerara rum redolent of baking spices, a rich, alpine-inspired amaro and a bright and vinous aperitvo liqueur for a much heartier Negroni riff.
ingredients: 2 ounces aged demerara rum, preferably El Dorado 12 Year Rum
1/2 ounce Cappelletti Vino Aperitivo Americano Rosso
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Lost Time
intro_philosophy:
Lauren Corriveau’s Lost Time is no doubt a highball in formula and simplicity, but it’s been seriously elevated with an easy-to-make mix of Calvados, infused with fresh celery,x and the gentian-based French aperitif Suze. “I wanted to create something that could be simply added to a glass with limited fuss or bar tools needed and stay true to a classic highball build,” says Corriveau. She uses Fever-Tree Elderflower Tonic Water to bring on the crisp bubbles—its “floral and earthy complexity” plays well with the earthy notes of Suze and the vegetal, mineral-forward Calvados infusion.

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: 3 ounces  Fever-Tree Elderflower Tonic Water, chilled
instructions: 1. Add the Calvados and Suze to a Collins glass filled with ice.
2. Top with tonic water and stir.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel or two.

title: Hot Buttered Rum
intro_philosophy: Hot. Buttered. Rum. Is there anything sexier than a glass of melted butter mixed with warm golden spirits? No, we think not. Americans have been whipping up a spiced butter batter and dousing it with rum and hot water since before they were Americans. This fancified version, created at Boston cocktail bar The Hawthorne, brings the winter warmer to its full velvety potential. With the crucial addition of ice cream and black tea, this variant closes the disappointing gap between expectation (decadent) and reality (greasy, watery) that often taints the hot buttered rum experience.
ingredients: rum, dark (preferably Old Monk and English Harbour)
instructions: 1. Add first ten ingredients to a mixing bowl and blend with an electric mixer.
2. Refrigerate batter until ready to use.
3. When ready to serve, prep mugs by filling with hot water to warm them. Let stand for a minute or two, and discard.
4. Add one tablespoon of batter to prepped mug.
5. Top with two ounces hot tea, and stir to mix.
6. Add one ounce of each rum, and then top with two more ounces hot tea.
7. Rum will form a 1/4 inch cream over the top of the drink.
8. Garnish with a whole star anise.

title: Black Yukon Sucker Punch
intro_philosophy: In the fifth episode of the second season of 1990s television showTwin Peaks, Agent Cooper (Kyle MacLachlan) encounters Twin Peaks’ local specialty, the Black Yukon Sucker Punch: A split-level drink with a tar-colored bottom and a foamy, blue upper. New York City bartender, Maxwell Britten, brought this cocktail to life with a mix of coffee bean-infused sweet vermouth, bourbon and crème de cacao, all topped with blue-tinted whipped cream.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, coffee infused (preferably Carpano Antica); see Editor's Note
blue curaçao whipped cream (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add first three ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass.
4. Top gently with whipped cream pouring over the back of a spoon held near the drink's surface to ensure the cream lays over the drink (instead of sinking).

title: The Gibson’s Pauline
intro_philosophy: When on the hunt for a lesser-known rum classic, Jewel Murray and her team workshopped several cocktails fromThe Savoy Cocktail Bookuntil they found a winner:the Pauline. Bartender Daniel Sanchez spearheaded the development of the spec, which leans on an unusual Haitian rum that combines two clairins and an unaged rum. The wormwood bitters of the original recipe are here replaced by a combination of absinthe and orange bitters, while the original recipe’s nutmeg had to stay for this winterized rum sour.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces unaged rum, preferably San Zanj Haitian rum
1 dash orange bitters, preferably Regans’ or Fee Brothers
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice, seal and shake to chill.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with nutmeg.

title: Donn Day Afternoon
intro_philosophy: Martin Cate of Smuggler’s Cove pays tribute to the cinnamon-grapefruit pairing ofDon’s Mix, but forgoes the fresh grapefruit altogether in favor of grapefruit-flavored beer Stiegl-Radler.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce SC cinnamon syrup (see Editor's Note)
2 ounces rhum agricole blanc, preferably AOC Martinique
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a double Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Gently add cracked or cubed ice and stir.
3. Express oil from the grapefruit peel and then drop the peel into the drink.

title: Maison Premiere’s Pimm’s Cup
intro_philosophy: Like many ofMaison Premiere’sdrinks, the Pimm’s Cup is classically inspired and rooted in New Orleans. “At Maison, we lean toward the New Orleans influence of a Pimm’s more than we do the English,” says Maxwell Britten, head bartender. It’s a classic order at theNapoleon Houseon Chartres Street in the French Quarter and one of the few drinks that allows for ample play on the original. At first, Maison presented the drink with fresh mint, cucumber water and ginger. The riff was so well-received they decided to continue the tradition with a new version each season. “We get funky with it,” says Britten.
ingredients: scant 1/2 ounce ginger syrup (1:1, sugar: ginger juice)
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle cucumber slices, mint, orange wheel and lime wedge.
2. Add Pimm's, ginger syrup and ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Garnish with a bouquet of mint and a cucumber slice.

title: Shady Grove
intro_philosophy: Jon Mullen’s Shady Grove imagines an aperitivo twist on the Paloma, with a brief layover in France—what he dubs a “Palomaperitivo.” He achieves this by mixing together silky bianco vermouth with the bitter French gentian liqueur Suze and Calvados, though you can also can sub in another clear spirit with fruity or vegetal qualities, such as tequila, gin or rhum agricole.
ingredients: 1 1/3 ounces  Bianco Vermouth,preferably Bordiga Vermouth Bianco
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the grapefruit soda in a mixing tin filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled, and fine-strain into a Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Top with grapefruit soda.

title: Dry Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: At Satan’s Whiskers, Kevin Armstrong serves the modern classicDry Daiquirithat he originally created at Match Bar in 2005. The riff on the rum sour introduces bitter Campari and a “dash of pash”—Armstrong’s signature touch of passion fruit syrup—to the drink, which has become a favorite among London bartenders.
ingredients: Heavy 1 1/4 ounces lightly aged rum, preferably Havana Club 3 Year
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
2. Shake vigorously to chill and dilute, then strain into a frozen coupette glass.
3. Garnish with a flamed orange twist (optional).

title: Hold Up
intro_philosophy: Drawing on Alex Anderson’s time atCane & Table, Hold Up spotlights a funky Jamaican rum mixed with quinine-fortified wine, grapefruit liqueur and lemon—all in equal parts. She notes that it resembles a Culross Cocktail, aSavoy Cocktail Bookclassic featuring the no-longer-extant Kina Lillet alongside rum and apricot brandy. But, true to form, Anderson turns the flavors up to 10 with a whopping14drops of celery bitters. “It’s a very bold cocktail.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Hamilton Jamaican Pot Still Gold rum
3/4 ounce grapefruit liqueur, preferably Giffard Crème de Pamplemousse Rose
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express orange peel and discard.

title: White Witch
intro_philosophy:
“I try not to drink more than two of these at a time,” saysEzra Star, general manager of Boston’strailblazing cocktail barDrink. “The last time I did, I ended up dancing on the bar top.”

Star first came across this oddball, white crème de cacao-spiked recipe about seven years ago, flipping through an old copy ofTrader Vic’s Bartender’s Guideand has since applied her own personal tweaks: crushed ice instead of cubed (a more refreshing format),dry Curaçaoin lieu of Cointreau (tempering the sweetness) and no powdered sugar (too messy).
ingredients: 1 ounce overproof rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass filled with crushed ice.
2. Swizzle to integrate.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with hollow lime and mint.

title: Mel Waters
intro_philosophy: According toMorgan Schick, rainwater Madeira is a natural companion for whiskey. Riffing on the bourbon, bitter and fortified wine construction of aBoulevardier, Schick incorporates a housemade blueberry bitter aperitivo, but subs in rainwater for sweet vermouth. “Sweet vermouth is a little too flabby [in the drink],” he explains, adding that rainwater Madeira’s dry, naturally woody edge helps to keep the spiritous drink in balance.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce rainwater Madeira, preferably Henriques & Henriques
5 dashes pepper-rose hip bitters (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

title: Neon Moon
intro_philosophy: At Death & Co. Denver, every section of the menu starts with a no-ABV and a low-ABV option. Neon Moon is a non-alcoholic recipe, consisting of Seedlip Spice 94, a syrup made of makrut lime leaf, lemongrass and shiso, along with kefir whey and egg white, from the “Fizz” section of the current menu. “It just kind of came out of my obsession of putting dairy and weird things in the drinks,” says Alex Jump, adding, “it’s super fresh, not very heavy, and bright.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces makrut lime leaf, lemongrass and shiso syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Fine strain into a fizz glass.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Garnish with a star anise pod.

title: Brandy Lift
intro_philosophy:
Slanted Door bartender Jennifer Colliau invented this drink in 2012 for a cocktail competition. It’s a mix between a fizz and a Brandy Milk Punch—essentially a New York egg cream with alcohol.

Reprinted with permission fromThe Slanted Doorby Charles Phan © 2014. Published by Ten Speed Press. Photography © 2014 by Ed Anderson.
instructions: 1. Add brandy, Bénédictine, orgeat and cream to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into an 8-ounce fizz glass.
4. Slowly add soda water while paddling back and forth with a bar spoon in the glass until the liquid reaches the top of the glass.
5. Allow the drink to rest for 15 seconds and then slowly add 1 more ounce of soda water to lift the foam above the glass.

title: Ni De Aqui Ni de Alla
intro_philosophy: AtBar Providenciathis plantain-infused cocktail marries together mezcal and bourbon. It pairs especially well with the bar’s desserts. It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, such as Mal Bien
instructions: 1. Prepare a glass with a banana leaf inside.
2. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Jeff Berry’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy: The original drink dates to circa 1978, created at the Aviary Bar of the Kuala Lumpur Hilton in Thailand. Jeff “Beachbum” Berry rediscovered the drink in a 1989 paperback by John J. Poister,The New American Bartender’s Guide, and republished it in his 2002 book,Intoxica!This version uses dark Jamaican rum and maintains a heavy pour of pineapple.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker, and shake well with plenty of ice cubes.
2. Pour, unstrained, into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with an orchid, and a cocktail cherry speared to lemon and orange wheels.

title: Milk Punch
intro_philosophy: This elegant, bright punch has just enough structure and body to stand up to a month of aging in glass. The deep sweetness of the homemade Mango “Milk” will carry through and lend a solid base for the botanicals in the gin, which is infused with wormwood and green apple, to shine.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bottle.
2. Label it and let age for one month in glass.
3. To serve, chill and pour the cocktail into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a slice of mango and a sprig of mint.

title: Yayo Hipster
intro_philosophy: Natasha Bermudez givesthe Yayo, the classic gin-based cocktail from Madrid, a Brooklyn makeover, inspired by her time living and working in Spain. Her version served at Bar Llama in Madrid features olive brine tonic, but at Brooklyn’s Llama Inn she makes one with Roku gin, Spanish sweet vermouth and a rosemary-grapefruit tonic. “The Brooklyn version of the Yayo is a top-three seller every day,” says Bermudez.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Lustau Vermut Rojo
1 1/2 ounces London Essence Grapefruit & Rosemary Tonic
instructions: 1. Build ingredients in a double Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Stir with a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with the olives.

title: Harvey Girl
intro_philosophy: In the late-19th century, Fred Harvey started his chain of Harvey House restaurants along the Santa Fe Rail Line as havens for weary travelers. Staffed solely by single waitresses, these wayward establishments provided young women the opportunity to leave home and start a new, independent lives. Rhachel Shaw of Westbound in Los Angeles took inspiration from these intrepid women for her Bacardi 8 rum swizzle riff, which combines sage-infused vermouth, pineapple, chamomile and smoky rhubarb amaro. “The sage and chamomile are reminiscent of the vegetation that you would see going west,” says Shaw. “It’s a cool, tall and refreshing. Just what you’d want after a long train ride.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  sage dry vermouth  (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients except the Amaro Rabarbaro in a Collins glass.
2. Add crushed ice and swizzle.
3. Top with more crushed ice and float the amaro on top.
4. Garnish with two sage leaves.

title: Chocolate and Vanilla Essential Oils Spray
intro_philosophy: Chocolate and vanilla creates a rounded, sweetening effect. Pair it with any drink made with cherries, or a bracingMint Julep, to add perceived sweetness without any extra sugar when sprayed on an accompanying napkin.
ingredients: 8 drops chocolate essential oil, preferably Aftelier Perfumes
2 drops vanilla essential oil, preferably Aftelier Perfumes
instructions: 1. In a small spray bottle, combine vodka and essential oils.
2. To use, spritz on a napkin for extra aromatics, then set the drink on the napkin.

title: El Diablo
intro_philosophy: First published inTrader Vic’s Book of Food and Drinkin 1946, the refreshing El Diablo combines tequila with the black currant liqueur crème de cassis, all topped with spicy ginger beer.
instructions: 1. Add the tequila, lime juice and crème de cassis to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a Collins glass.
3. Top with ginger beer.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Thad Vogler’s Mojito
intro_philosophy: This is a no-muddle Mojito. After witnessing how the drink was made in Cuba–lined up on the bar in multiples, with the mint allowed to steep in rum to extract the flavor and aroma of the fresh herb–Thad Vogler developed this effortless variation for the now-closed Obispo.
ingredients: 6-12 mint leaves, depending on the size of the leaves
2 ounces dry white rum, preferably Royal Standard or El Dorado 3 Year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except bitters and soda water, in a Collins glass.
2. Allow to sit for at least 5 minutes, or up to an hour. (Not longer, or the rum “cooks” the mint).
3. When ready to serve, add bitters and ice to fill the glass.
4. Top with soda water.

title: Bonfire Kiss
intro_philosophy:
In Atlanta, Kellie Thorn of Empire State South gets whimsical with her take on the “something smoky” request: the Bonfire Kiss, a mix of mezcal, sherry and crème de cacao topped with apple bitters and garnished with a cinnamon stick, which is intended to resemble a wintertime log on the fireplace.

The cocktail is best made with a mezcal—specifically Del Maguey’s Vida—which, according to Thorn, offers some fruitiness. “It already has great fruit notes that plays well with the liquor and bitters,” she explains, adding that the sherry’s perceivable acidity balances out the drink’s sweetness. “There is something familiar and nostalgic about these flavors coming together,” she says. “[It] reminds me of being at a fair with your loved one on a cold night, eating caramel apples.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
1 ounce oloroso sherry, preferably Toro Albala Marques de Poley
1/2 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
5 dashes apple bitters, preferably Bar Keep
instructions: 1. Combine mezcal, sherry and créme de cacao in a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled double Old Fashioned glass over one large cube of ice.
3. Top with five dashes of apple bitters.
4. Garnish with a cinnamon stick that has been split in half lengthwise.

title: Tita Nita’s Milk Punch
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to create a cocktail that kind of encapsulates the Filipino American experience,” saysNapier Bulanan, who translates the ubiquitous fruit punch of family gatherings into cocktail form. A base of lambanog, a distilled palm spirit, is bolstered by aquavit, sweetened with lychee syrup and given a tart kick from fresh lime juice. The whole mixture is then clarified, milk punch–style, using coconut milk.
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients in a large container to create a cocktail mixture.
2. Pour the coconut milk into a separate large container, then add the cocktail mixture. Stir the mixture and let rest for 30 minutes.

3. Line a large chinois with a clean kitchen napkin, and set it inside a large container. Slowly pour the mixture through the chinois. (You may have to pour it in batches, because the straining process takes time.) Pour the clarified cocktail into a reusable bottle and refrigerate.
4. When ready to serve, pour 3 ounces of the mixture into a mixing glass with ice, and strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
5. Garnish with a spritz of pinipig tincture and an orchid.

title: The Suburban
intro_philosophy: The Suburban is both a classic race and a classic cocktail. In ode to Zivo, the impressive New York-bred winner of this year’s Suburban stakes at Belmont Park, and his shot at the Breeders’ Cup Classic 2014, is this drink—a New York original and the only cocktail we’re aware of that combines whiskey, port and rum.
ingredients: 2 ounces whiskey, 77 Local Rye and Corn
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry and an orange slice.

title: Midnight Bouquet
intro_philosophy: “A great nightcap is the perfect mix of strong and sweet,” claims Meaghan Dorman, whose Midnight Bouquet incorporates St-Germain alongside grapefruit for a bittersweet companion to the salinity and smokiness of mezcal and tequila.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce mezcal, preferably San Andrés Alipus
instructions: 1. Stir all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Express the grapefruit twist over the surface and garnish.

title: Frozen Sgroppino
intro_philosophy: To the repertoire of classicaperitivococktails at Alta Linea, Joe Campanale adds his Frozen Sgroppino, made in large batches and served via a slush machine at the restaurant. At home, this easy-to-make mix gets its texture from a scoop of lemon sorbet.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bowl and mix with a whisk.
2. Pour the mixture into a glass and garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Sharpie Mustache
intro_philosophy: One of the most recognized and well-traveled drinks to come out of New York’s Amor y Amargo is the Sharpie Mustache, created by bartender Chris Elford. Elford now lives and works in Seattle, but when he was at Amor y Amargo in 2011 and 2012, he happened to be on a Meletti kick when a guest askedfor the dealer’schoice. Elford recalls that splitting the bases, rye and gin seemed like “strange but awesome bedfellows,” and the tiki bitters and orange twist “made the drink pop just right.”
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until chilled and strain into a chilled Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed orange twist inserted into the glass.

title: Jessica Collins
intro_philosophy: Part of the classic Collins lineage, the Jessica Collins is named for cookbook author and legendary hostessJessica Seinfeld. The tall, warm-weather drink—created specifically for an August cocktail party—is built upon the timeless Collins formula of gin, citrus and soda. In this case, the clean profile of Hendrick’s gin pairs with mouth-puckering ruby red grapefruit and tangy lime. Sugar that’s been rubbed with grapefruit peels forms the base for a sugar syrup, and a splash of Aperol transforms the drink from simple Collins into a bittersweet, pink aperitif that sates like aTom Collins, with the grace of a Greyhound.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce grapefruit simple syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add gin, Aperol, grapefruit juice, lime juice, simple syrup and rhubarb bitters to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Garnish with a long, curling grapefruit peel.

title: The Waterfront
intro_philosophy: Damon Boelte describes this as a “pretty aggressive highball.” It was on the opening menu of the now-closed Prime Meats in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, where it remained until the end. The drink caught on with industry but as it became more popular he would ask servers to offer a verbal disclaimer to customers just to make sure they knew what they were signing up for. “It’s a medicinal, bitter, and minty Dark ’n’ Stormy,” says Boelte. “The darkest Dark ’n’ Stormy.”
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a highball glass filled with ice.
2. Top with ginger beer and briefly stir.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel or wedge and a mint sprig.

title: Fast Rigging
intro_philosophy: Muddled celery, ginger and mint make this bright, citrusy rum drink from Atlanta’s Greg Best zingy and green, while a cracked pepper garnish bumps it up the savory spectrum. Best came up with this drink as part of the spring edition of PUNCH’s House Cocktail Hack.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, gently muddle mint, ginger and celery together with the lemon syrup and lime juice.
2. Let stand for a few minutes and then fine strain the liquid into a clean shaker.
3. Add Cocchi Americano and rum, and shake with ice until chilled.
4. Strain into a coupe, and garnish with a small sprig of mint and crack of black pepper.

title: Poetic Justice
intro_philosophy: Named after the song by Kendrick Lamar, this cocktail was created for a frequent guest at the Kimpton Gray Hotel. “We had a regular that stayed in the hotel for about two weeks a month,” explains Mony Bunni, former bar manager at the property, “since he’d come hang out at the bars, he made his way through the menu fairly quickly.” This blend of spicyrye, bitter Bonal and nutty oloroso, which gets an unexpected boost from a caramel pu-erh tea syrup, was a dealer’s choice creation that later became a fixture of the menu.
ingredients: 1 ounce sherry, preferably Lustau Don Nuno Oloroso
1/4 ounce Caramel Pu-erh Syrup (see Editor's Note)
1 dash Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas Decanter Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a cubed ice.
3. Express orange peel and discard.

title: Flower Power Sour
intro_philosophy: This frothy gin sour is inspired by the profile of Fords Gin and adds floral interest twice: first with an infused simple syrup made with dried lavender, then on top of the drink via an elegant garnish of crème de violette liqueur.
ingredients: ½ ounce   lavender simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Shake until chilled and strain to remove ice.
3. Shake again, without ice.
4. Double strain into a Collins glass over ice.
5. Garnish with crème de violette, dotted over top of drink from a dropper bottle.

title: City Island Colada
intro_philosophy:
The Henny Colada, aPiña Coladamade with Hennessy Cognac, has been a staple at seafood shacks on the Bronx’s City Island for more than two decades.“The only way to improve on a Piña Colada is to add aged rum, and aged rum is a lot like Cognac,” says bartender and Bronx native Giuseppe González, who grew up going to City Island every summer.

While Henny Coladas have seen popularity in bars and nightclubs around the city, it’s rare to see them at more serious cocktail bars. Still, prior to the closing of his Lower East Side bar, Suffolk Arms, González made sure to put a Henny Colada on the menu as a tribute to a place he loves. While the drink calls for Hennessy VS, González recommends Hennessy Privilege as an upgrade, “if you’re feeling fancy.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a hurricane glass filled with 16 ounces of cracked ice.

title: Chris Elford’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy: A complex but craveable riff on the classic Jungle Bird, this version combines the richness of a coffee-vanilla buttered rum with the subtly coconut-like tones ofpandanfor a layered and bracing tropical bite.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces coffee buttered rum (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce lime oleo saccharum (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over big ice cubes.
3. Garnish with a pineapple frond.

title: Yellow Jacket
intro_philosophy:
The Yellow Jacket cocktail was inspired by chance circumstances and a little harassment. For weeks, we had toyed with the idea of mixing together Partida Reposado tequila and St-Germain elderflower liqueur, but there was a piece of the puzzle missing. Then one evening, a bunch of obnoxious cocktail geeks came intoEmployees Onlyto stump the bartenders by ordering theLast Wordcocktail. After being satisfied with that drink, they asked if we knew of another drink withChartreuse. At that moment,Yellow Chartreuse became the ingredient needed to bind together the elderflower and tequila. So pretty and elegant, the rich yellow color grabs your attention. The true beauty of this drink, though, is the interplay of the ingredients. The light oak on the Partida Reposado tequila works so well with the St-Germain, and they in turn produce a perfect ground for Yellow Chartreuse to bring it all into balance. The orange bitters play a key role. This cocktail is similar in style to the Widow’s Kiss cocktail, as they both contain very sweet herbaceous ingredients balanced by high alcohol content. It’s named for the yellow jacket wasps that inhabit agave farms and tequila distilleries.

instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Tarragon Fix
intro_philosophy: Herbal and easy-drinking, the Tarragon Fix fromSan Francisco’s ABVis emblematic of the bar’s approach, which cleverly stretches classic cocktail blueprints without losing the thread. Here, the Fix is transformed with tarragon, pineapple and absinthe, and served up.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Milano-Torino
intro_philosophy: First served around 1860 in Gaspare Campari’s café in Milan, this drink—often shortened to “Mi-To”—takes its name from the birthplaces of Campari (Milan) and Vermouth di Torino (Turin) and represents the bittersweet blueprint for aperitivo classics like theAmericanoand theNegroni.
instructions: 1. Build the drink in an Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
2. Stir and garnish with an orange slice.

title: Austin Hartman’s Rum Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Coming in second place at our blind rum Old-Fashioned tasting was Austin Hartman’s recipe. The judges were able to immediately identify the rum, which bar owner Paul McGee noted was “unmistakably Foursquare”—thePappy van Winkle of rum—on the first sip. All found the drink to be “a delight,” as St. John Frizell noted.
ingredients: Heavy 1/4 ounce ROF mix (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass.
2. Add a large ice cube and stir for 5 seconds.
3. Garnish with a lemon and orange twist.

title: Lickety Split
intro_philosophy: Drawing from the ingredients that she herself would most want at the end of the night, Kimberly Rosselle pairs dry vermouth with the floral notes of St-Germain and the bitterness of Amaro Lucano, combining “Bold, bright flavors…with delicate floral notes to soothe and relax one before wrapping up the night.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass and garnish with the lemon peel.

title: Only Fans Martini
intro_philosophy: Though far from archetypal, the Only Fans Martini, with its vanilla-infused cachaça base, won over the judges at our Pornstar Martini blind tasting. The vanilla outshone the passion fruit here, but it only added to the indulgent, opulent quality of the drink. It was hands-down the most lavish of the group, “a guilty-pleasure drink” according to bartender Izzy Tulloch; despite the departure in base spirit, the trait felt in keeping with the essence of the original.
ingredients: 2 ounces vanilla-infused cachaça, preferably Avua Prata (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce Petite Canne Sirop de Canne
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients, except Champagne, in a shaker with ice and shake vigorously until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a pineapple crescent and an orchid.
4. Serve with a sidecar of Champagne.

title: Tokyo Drift
intro_philosophy: “There are so manyManhattanvariations, but I hadn’t seen one done with Japanese whisky yet,” says bartender Brad Farran. With this blueprint in mind, Farran substituted American whiskey with the subtly complex Yamazaki, while adding layers to the sweet vermouth via the addition of spicy Cardamaro and saffron-infused Strega. Farran named his cocktail in reference to the third installment of theFast and the Furiousmovies, which he thinks, “is pretty hilarious.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Japanese whisky, preferably Yamazaki 12 Year
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass (or a Nick & Nora if you're fancy).
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Tom Macy’s Rob Roy
intro_philosophy: In a recent tasting for Rob Roys, the winning drink came from Tom Macy. A clear favorite, as well as a true exemplar of the modern Rob Roy style, it was composed of two ounces of Highland Park 12-year, one ounce of Carpano Antica vermouth, two dashes of Angostura bitters and a cherry garnish. The drink found wide favor upon first sip. It was on the light side, but had good body and a touch of smoke. “I would pick that out blindfolded as a Rob Roy,” declaredJoaquin Simó.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a Luxardo cherry.

title: Lesser Key Martini
intro_philosophy: Part of a growing crop of modern ’tinis—a class of drinks parading around under the Martini name with only a passing resemblance to the gin or vodka classic—the Lesser Key Martini is made with coconut and pistachio fat-washed rum, matcha-infused Japanese gin, plantain brandy and Japanese vermouth, an apt interpretation of the drink for the rum-focused cocktail bar Paradise Lost.
ingredients: 1 ounce coconut and pistachio fat-washed rum (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce Oka Kura Japanese Bermutto Vermouth
1 teaspoon plantain eau de vie, preferably Edénico Plátano
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass and garnish with a bamboo leaf and an orchid.

title: Vieux Carré (Microwaved)
intro_philosophy: “The beauty of microwave infusion is that the application of intense heat for a short time teases out flavors without overcooking,” saysRyan Chetiyawardana. The method works well for a batched variation on this popular classic, with fragrant, delicately spiced Tasmanian Leatherwood honey fresh and dried aromatics replacing the traditional Benedictine.
ingredients: 10 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Martini Rosso
1 heaping teaspoon Leatherwood honey or other dark, rich raw honey
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a vacuum-sealable, microwave-proof bag. Shake to agitate and dissolve the honey.
2. Microwave for on medium power for 5 minutes, then allow to cool. Strain and bottle.
3. Add 3 ounces to a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
4. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Hot Aperol
intro_philosophy: Jessica King, co-owner of Brother Wolf in Knoxville, Tennessee, makes this hot drink during the holiday—and cold and flu—season. The drink takes inspiration fromhot Aperol, the European Christmas staple and winter cousin of the Aperol Spritz, and adds complexity to the format with single malt Scotch and Italian soda.
ingredients: 1 ounce single malt Scotch, such as Kilchoman Machir Bay
1/2 packet vitamin C powder (Brother Wolf uses a tangerine-flavored version)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in your favorite mug and microwave on high for 1 minute, 45 seconds.
2. Garnish with a slice of orange.

title: Ultra-Cosmopolitan
intro_philosophy: “Just like we’re better versions of ourselves 20 years later, so too is this Ultra-Cosmopolitan,” writes John deBary in his ’90s-inspired book,Saved by the Bellini. His take on the drink includes homemade saffron-spiked grenadine, which gives the cocktail “another layer of accessories.”
instructions: 1. In a shaker, combine all ingredients.
2. Add ice and shake vigorously for 15 seconds.
3. Strain into a coupe glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel on the rim of the glass.

title: Cardinale
intro_philosophy:
This cocktail from Dante’s Naren Young “looks light, dainty and somewhat innocent, but because of the dry vermouth, it’s much more austere and bone-dry,” he says. Supposedly dating back to Rome in the 1950s, this riff on the Negroni alters the ratios and swaps Campari for slightly spicy Contratto Bitter and sweet vermouth for dry, making for a more complex and all-around drier cocktail.

As Young puts it, “This is for the Negroni drinker that wants to be challenged.”
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, such as Dorothy Parker
3/4 ounce dry vermouth, such as Lo-Fi
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir and strain over ice into an etched rocks glass.
3. Express the lemon twist over top and discard. Garnish with dehydrated lemon peel.

title: L’Alaska
intro_philosophy:
Inspired by the tisane blend taken as a bedtime drink by the Carthusian monks—makers of Chartreuse—beverage director Estelle Bossy creates her own cold infusion of mint, lemon verbena, linden and orange flower to lengthen the house Alaska at Le Rock while boosting its herbal complexity. Paired with the distinctive botanical profile of Monkey 47 gin and a finishing spray of the potent Chartreuse Élixir Végétal, the drink has a freshness and depth of flavor that set it apart from the very first sip.

When preparing this recipe, rather than converting to ounces, we suggest using a measuring cup with milliliter demarcations for a more precise result.
ingredients: 600 milliliters gin, preferably Monkey 47 Schwarzwald dry gin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a glass bottle.
2. Store the bottle in the freezer for several hours or overnight.
3. To serve, pour 4 ounces into a chilled Martini glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist and a spritz of Chartreuse Élixir Végétal from an atomizer.

title: Pecan Swirl
intro_philosophy: This mashup of a Brandy Alexander and an Espresso Martini offers a sweet and creamy hybrid with a spirited kick from Cognac, rich and bittersweet coffee amaro, and a sweet pecan milk that ties everything together. “If you want to get wild, add a shot of espresso as well,” advises Christine Wiseman.
ingredients: 1 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Mr. Black
1 ounce pecan milk (preferably THIS PKN brand, or see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Insta-Shandy
intro_philosophy: The Insta-Shandy is a prime example ofT.J .Lynch’s playful approach to bartending. To further simplify an already effortless beer cocktail, theshandy, Lynch throws lime juice and spicy ginger syrup directly into a can of kolsch.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce ginger syrup (1:1, ginger juice: granulated sugar)
instructions: 1. Take a sip of the beer.
2. Add the lemon juice and ginger syrup directly to the can.

title: Lion’s Fang
intro_philosophy: This riff on the Lion’s Tail doubles down on the tiki aspect of the drink, adding rum,falernumand even a splash of absinthe for extra bite. “This never made it to any of my menus, but I keep it in my arsenal to use as a Dealer’s Choice,” Austin says.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon demerara syrup (1:1, demerara sugar: water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients and a scoop of crushed ice in a cocktail tin.
2. Using a Hamilton spindle mixer, flash blend for three seconds.
3. Pour into an rocks Old-Fashioned or rocks glass.
4. Top with additional crushed ice.
5. Garnish with mint.

title: Gin & It
intro_philosophy: “I first read about the Gin & It inRegarding Cocktailsby Sasha Petraske and Georgette Moger-Petraske, [who] offered sample sizes in Mason jars as a party favor at their wedding. This drink had to mean something to these cocktail gurus, so I decided to give it a shot—despite its surface-level simplicity,” says Justin Brody, head bartender at The Port of Call in Mystic, Connecticut. It quickly became a favorite of his. “To me, it bolsters the notion that nearly everything behind a bar can be mixed well into a balanced drink, you just have to know how,” he says.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a glass on the rocks.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Stirred Bird
intro_philosophy: A clarified take on the Jungle Bird that uses both clarified lime and pineapple juices for a silky, stirred spin on the classic. As Jack Schramm notes, “Remember that clarification is an opportunity—push it to the outer limits and create something new.”
ingredients: 1 ounce blackstrap rum, such as Cruzan
3/4 ounce clarified lime juice (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce clarified pineapple juice (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce overproof Jamaican rum, such as Smith & Cross
1/4 ounce Nicaraguan rum, such as Flor de Caña 7 Year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Always Disco
intro_philosophy: 53AD, the Brooklyn bar from the Empirical Spirits team, uses an unorthodox ingredient for its milk punch—which contains no milk at all. Silken tofu and lactic acid solution, blitzed together, act as the clarifying agent and give the drink its round texture.
ingredients: 450 milliliters (15 ounces) gin, such as Neversink
200 milliliters (6 3/4 ounces) Hana Makgeolli Yakju rice wine
100 milliliters (scant 3 1/2 ounces) coffee liqueur, such as Mr Black cold-brew liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine the gin, Empirical SOKA, citrus juices, tea, rice wine and coffee liqueur in a large container.
2. In a blender, combine the simple syrup, silken tofu and lactic acid solution. Blitz until runny and smooth, then add this mixture to the first container of ingredients, stirring to combine.
3. Let the mixture curdle for about 15 minutes, then slowly pour it through a coffee filter.
4. Like most milk punches, the first portion of the strained liquid will still be cloudy. Collect the cloudy liquid and strain again, repeating as necessary until the mixture becomes clear.
5. Chill the clarified punch. To serve, pour 4 ounces into a chilled rocks glass with a large block of ice.
6. Garnish with a coffee bean.

title: Grasshopper Swizzle
intro_philosophy: “This drink premiered at my last shift atPrime Meats, a ‘70s pop up that was a tribute to Stan Jones and disco-era drinks,” bartender Garret Richard recalls. The inspiration to turn the Grasshopper into a swizzle came from many visits to LA’s famedTiki-Tilounge, where creamy drinks are oftenflash-blendedand served over crushed ice. “I always found this practice makes dessert-style drinks more palatable and lighter.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce white crème de cacao, preferably Marie Brizard
1/2 ounce dark crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Flash blend the first six ingredients in a drink mixer with 8 ounces of crushed ice.
2. Pour into a wine glass over crushed ice.
3. Top with 3 or 4 dashes of bitters.
4. Garnish with mint and grated nutmeg.

title: Smoke-Filled Room
intro_philosophy: Jonathan Lam’s funky, peaty, rum-based riff on the Old-Fashioned, featuring banana syrup and root beer bitters named for the smoky, closed-door politics of yore.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir all ingredients with ice until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass.

title: Garden G&T
intro_philosophy: Yes, it’s only two ounces of tonic/club soda: “The tonic syrup is very concentrated,” warnsGin Roomproprietor Natasha Bahrami. In place of combining the house tonic syrup with club soda, a more generous amount of Fever-Tree Sparkling Lime & Yuzu Tonic may be substituted.
ingredients: 1 ounce Spring Tonic Syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a large balloon glass over 2 large (2-inch-by-2-inch) ice cubes.
2. Add lemon zest and swizzle drink to combine.
3. Garnish with edible flowers.

title: Unlikely Negroni
intro_philosophy: “The Unlikely Negroni is exactly that: a preposterous combination of flavors that somehow works,” says Naren Young, of New York’s Dante. The drink sees Campari combined with pineapple drinking vinegar, oil, coconut and banana liqueurs and a hit of housemade spicy Thai chile tincture, for a riff on the Italian classic by way of Thailand.
ingredients: 1 barspoon pineapple drinking vinegar, preferably Som
1 dropper Thai chile tincture (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Strain into silver coupe.
3. Garnish with banana chip.

title: Black Flag Grog
intro_philosophy: The popular New York City tiki party, Tiki Mondays, has always been equal parts heavy metal and tropical breeze. Enter, head tiki bartender Brian Miller’s Black Flag Grog. A heavy-hitting mix of four kinds of rum with a spicy tart supporting cast of nutmeg, orgeat and fruit juices, this head-splitting mix is sure to pave the way for an evening of swashbuckling and head banging.
ingredients: 1 ounce Appleton 12 year rum or Plantation Jamaica 2001 rum
3/4 ounce orgeat, Orgeat Works macadamia nut orgeat
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients (except soda water) to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Add soda water and strain over ice into a large old-fashioned glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel and a pirate flag.

title: Otto’s High Dive’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Taking top honors at our2024 Daiquiri blind tasting, this archetypal recipe cleverly calls on a lime oleo saccharum as the sweetener, bringing the sharp, flavorful oil of the peels into the equation for a drink that is crisp, balanced and refreshing—as every Daiquiri should be.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce lime oleo saccharum (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, then add ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.

title: Knob Kriek
intro_philosophy: Created by illustrator John Perry Yates for the 2014 World Cup match between the U.S. and Belgium, this distant relative of the John Collins pairs sweet, oaky American bourbon with the tart funky cherries of a traditional Belgian brew. Use an unsweetened lambic if possible. If you can’t find unsweetened, dial down the maraschino liqueur to taste.
instructions: 1. Add bourbon, lemon juice and maraschino to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with lambic and stir gently.
5. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Fermented Kool-Aid Cosmo
intro_philosophy: Instead of cranberry juice, this irreverent Cosmo variation from Austin’s Elementary uses fermented Kool-Aid to add sweet-tart flavor. Specifically, Chris Arial brews a honey mead that’s flavored with the childhood-favorite powdered beverage. For a home-friendly variation, simply bypass the mead-making process and use an ounce of Kool-Aid.
ingredients: 3 drops saline solution (4:1, water to salt, or use a pinch of salt)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a Martini glass.
3. Twist the lemon peel to express the essential oils over the top of the drink and the glass’s rim and stem. Then drop the peel in the glass.

title: Caffè Florian’s Tramezzini
intro_philosophy:
The omnipresent Italian snack food, tramezzini are small, crustless sandwiches made with white milk-based bread, and stuffed with anything from tuna and hard-boiled eggs to porchetta and radicchio depending on the season and the region. Born in Torino in the 1920s—allegedly at the gilded Caffè Mulassano—tramezzini were the Italian answer to the English tea sandwiches, made immediately more appealing by replacing vegetables with things like prosciutto and tea with alcoholic beverages.

Interestingly enough, the tiny sandwiches weren’t actually dubbed “tramezzini” until the 1930s, when writer and philosopher Gabriele D’Annunzio supposedly coined the word, which is meant to sound like a combination oftriangolo(triangle),trabetween), andmezzo(middle). Milk-based bread was not traditionally prevalent in the Italian diet, but became a café staple post-WWII, thanks to American and English influences.
ingredients: 6 slices white sandwich bread, crusts removed
instructions: 1. Spread three slices of white bread with the mayonnaise.
2. Top 1 with a layer of egg slices.
3. Place the second piece of bread, mayonnaise side up, on top, creating a new layer.
4. Add a layer of parma cotto and layer the last slice of bread, mayonnaise side down, on top of that.
5. Slice into 4 triangles and assemble, 2 each, on a large skewer.
6. Repeat with the remaining three bread slices, parma cotto, and egg.

title: Martin Cate’s Mai Tai
intro_philosophy: At a recent Mai Tai tasting,Martin CateofSmuggler’s Covetook second place. Denizen Merchant’s Reserve, which aims to replicate a rum faithful to Trader Vic’s formula, was the rum of choice, complemented by the bar’s proprietary orgeat and rich simple syrup.
ingredients: 2 ounces blended aged rum, preferably Denizen Merchant's Reserve 8-Year Rum
1/2 ounce Smuggler's Cove Orgeat (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce Mai Tai Rich Simple Syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with 12 ounces of crushed ice and a few cubes.
2. Strain into double rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with spent lime shell and mint sprig.

title: Rolls Royce
intro_philosophy: Originally published inThe Savoy Cocktail Bookin 1930, theRolls Royceis essentially a perfect Martini accented with Bénédictine. At Tigre in New York, William Elliott’s version is a top seller, despite being an old-timer on a mostly 1970s-inspired menu. The expected London dry gin and a barrel-aged, apple-based expression together form the base, which is layered with a moscato chinato in place of the two vermouths, plus Bénédictine, saffron liqueur, orange bitters and expressed lemon oil. Elliott revived hissomewhat controversial up-rocks presentationfor this drink, both for the added dilution and for its aesthetic similarity to a grand old Rolls.
ingredients: 1 ounce barrel-aged gin, such as Neversink Reserve
1 ounce London dry gin, such as Old Raj Red Label
1/2 ounce moscato chinato, such as Maura Vergano Luli
1/4 ounce saffron liqueur, such as Apologue
3 dash orange bitters, such as Angostura
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir to chill.
2. Strain into a coupe over a large ice cube.
3. Express a lemon twist over the drink, then discard.

title: Strange Encounters
intro_philosophy: A growing number of craft producers in recent years has encouraged the wide use of eau de vies in both classic and contemporary cocktails. In Strange Encounters, carrot eau de vie complements a base of amontillado sherry and adds a layer of freshness to the ginger and honey syrups.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces amontillado sherry, preferably Lustau Los Arcos amontillado
1/2 ounce carrot eau de vie, preferably Reisetbauer
1/4 ounce ginger syrup (2:1, sugar: ginger juice, blended)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Fives Bar’s Sazerac
intro_philosophy: Taking the third spot inour 2024 Sazerac blind tasting, this recipe from Fives Bar, a relative newcomer to the New Orleans cocktail bar scene, builds on a base of Wild Turkey 101 rye (ordered in situ, the rye is fat-washed with bone marrow). A rich cane syrup and two types of bitters—the expected Peychaud’s and Angostura—round out the drink, which is served in an Herbsaint-coated glass. All the judges commented on the rich body of this version, with one taster observing that “it has some weight to it, it’s velvety—it doesn’t have the density of water.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce rich cane sugar syrup (2:1, cane sugar to water, preferably made with unrefined Louisiana cane sugar)
instructions: 1. Generously coat the inside of a frozen rocks glass with the Herbsaint.
2. Combine the remaining ingredients in a mixing glass.
3. Stir with Kold-Draft or similar cubes, being careful not to overdilute, then strain into the prepared glass.
4. Express a lemon twist and drop it into the cocktail.

title: The Chill of the Night
intro_philosophy: Kristina Magro, of Lone Wolf Tavern in Chicago, typically gravitates toward tequila, so when she set out to make a cocktail that evokes the switch from early to late fall—its brisk air and changing leaves—she paired an aged tequila with the spicy flavors of Becherovka and honey syrup spiked with cinnamon and nutmeg, along with L’Aperitivo Nonino.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  ounce spiced honey syrup  (2:1 ratio of sunflower honey to water, spiced with cinnamon and nutmeg)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass over ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain over a large ice cube into a double Old-Fashioned glass. Garnish with a marigold and grated cinnamon.

title: Just the Paperwork
intro_philosophy: What does a bar owner drink to wash down the end-of-night bookkeeping, long after the ice bins are emptied? New York’s Sother Teague created a beverage just for this occasion, aptly named Just the Paperwork. It’s a nod to 19th-century scaffa, a format of mixed drink that is un-iced and consumed at room temperature. Simple, sippable and a tad bitter, of course.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Cognac, preferably Pierre Ferrand Cognac
instructions: 1. Build in a rocks glass and stir to combine.

title: Campari Soda
intro_philosophy: There is a significant amount of technique involved in Masayuki Kodato’s Campari Soda, which is served at his Ginza bar, Bar Shake. First, you must chill both the Campari and the soda water so that the ice (just one small piece of cracked ice, in this case) doesn’t immediately melt and water down the drink. Kodato’s addition of lemon juice to the template brightens the flavors of the drink and somehow binds them, and an aggressively effervescent soda water, Wilkinson Tansan, provides nodogoshi, a term that describes the refreshing feeling you get when a sparkling drink hits the back of your throat.
ingredients: scant 6 1/2 ounces very effervescent soda water, preferably Wilkinson Tansan, chilled
instructions: 1. Add Campari and lemon juice to a Collins glass with one small piece of cracked ice.
2. Top with soda water.

title: KiKiKōlada
intro_philosophy: “If a Blue Hawaiian and a piña colada had a baby,” it might look and taste something like Fanny Chu’s KiKiKōlada, a free-spirited drink that toasts to both the Caribbean and the 50th state. A starting-point split base of grassy, vegetal Hawaiian agricole rum and funky, overproof rum from Jamaica leads to thepiñaportion of the program: fresh-juiced fruitandthe 40-proof Giffard Caribbean Pineapple, “which has the charred, baking-spice character that I’m looking for, almost like an upside-down pineapple cake,” says Chu. Cream of coconut and coconut milk, along with a touch of Giffard Blue Curaçao to add eye-popping color and an undercurrent of bitter orange, complete the recipe.
ingredients: ¾ ounce  KōHana Hawaiian agricole rum
¾ ounce  Rum-Bar White Overproof Jamaican rum
¾ ounce  coco mix (3 parts Coco Lopez:1 part coconut milk)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and add pebble ice.
2. Whip shake.
3. Dump full contents of mixing tin into a chilled bamboo Collins glass or tall tiki-style glass.
4. Garnish with pineapple, mint, lemon and umbrella.

title: Dirty Old Man
intro_philosophy: At Barely Disfigured in New York City, the Dirty Old Man takes thespicy with tequilatemplate and brings mezcal, lime and pineapple juices and agave nectar to the mix, while red chile–infused Aperol brings the heat.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce red chile–infused Aperol (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.

title: Donna’s Mai Tai
intro_philosophy: Brooklyn bar Donna’s houseMai Taivariant calls for a blend of four rums, plus the wildcard addition ofCreole Shrubb.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce aged Guyanese rum, preferably El Dorado 12 year
1/2 ounce aged Venezuelan rum, preferably Santa Teresa 1796
1/2 ounce Wray & Nephew white overproof rum
1/2 ounce Jamaican pot still rum, preferably Hamilton Black
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a snifter over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with lime zest, a mint sprig and an edible orchid.

title: The Benevolent
intro_philosophy: Espresso martini variants abound, but a focus on Mexican flavors (tequila and mole bitters) is what makes h.wood group bar director Justin Campbell’s version stand out at the semi-private Santa Monica club, Mason. Campbell recommends using packaged cold brew coffee, but room-temperature brewed java can work as a swap-in, as well.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake without ice.
2. Add ice to the mixing tin and shake to combine a second time.
3. Strain into a cocktail glass.

title: The Best Year
intro_philosophy: A blender drink combiningvodka, Licor 43 and blue Curaçao with pineapple and lime juices, The Best Year is a disco-era original from Valerio “Bobby” Batugo. A Filipino prizefighter turned award-winning bartender, Batugo made his name in and around Hollywood in the ’70s. Attracted to its not-too-sweet flavor profile,Jeff “Beachbum” Berryadjusted Batugo’s original specs to appeal to contemporary palates, upgrading canned juices to fresh and cutting the vodka base with a small measure of aquavit.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend for 30 seconds and serve in a tall glass.
3. Add crushed ice to fill the glass.
4. Garnish with a fresh pineapple stick and a channel-cut lime peel.

title: Buena Fortuna
intro_philosophy: “What more can you hope for at the end of the year or looking ahead to the start of a new year than good fortune?” asks Sean Beck, who turns to pomegranate, an ingredient long tied to good luck, in a cocktail he calls the Buena Fortuna. “It just screams Mexico to me. I love the tartness, the texture and that beautiful natural color.” He incorporates fresh pomegranate in a syrup flavored withpiloncillo, the unrefined pure cane sugar that’s a popular sweetener in Mexico, adding body without overpowering the tequila. “El Tesoro™ Single Barrel Tequila is one of the few [aged] tequilas that is judicious with oak where the herbal and attractive green qualities still come through,” says Beck.
ingredients: 1 part El Tesoro™  Single Barrel Tequila
instructions: 1. Combine the El Tesoro™ Single Barrel Tequila, brandy, lemon juice, lime juice and Pomegranate-Piloncillo Syrup in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
2. Zest a touch of fresh ginger into the shaker, and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a dried apple slice and a few pomegranate seeds.

title: Qui’s Tepache
intro_philosophy:
Walk down a bustling city street in one of Mexico’s major cities and it won’t be long before you run into a street vendor peddling a curious lineup of Technicolor beverages from industrial-sized plastic containers. Within these jugs one can find an array ofaguas frescas—from horchata to tamarindo—but most interesting istepache, a tangy, fermented beverage whose alcohol content places it outside the realm of fruit juice. It’s a staple on the streets of Mexico and has been consumed and produced all over the country since pre-Columbian times. Corn was the original base ingredient for the drink up until at least the early 1500s (hence the nametepache, which comes from the nahuatl wordtapiatlmeaning “drink made from corn”), but today it’s most commonly made with pineapple flesh and rinds, invigorated with cinnamon, clove and other spices, and sweetened withpiloncillo(Mexican brown sugar).

At Qui in Austin, head bartender Justin Elliott’s housetepacheexplores the bolder end of the spectrum. He describes it as similar to Jamaican ginger beer that’s been sweetened with molasses, but not as syrupy. “It has an almost creamy, yeasty mouthfeel,” combined with “a funky pineapple flavor.” He mixes it with beer, as is traditional in Mexico, and also features it in hisTepache Collins—a drink that combines thetepachewith Balcones Rumble (a Texas spirit made from honey, figs and turbinado sugar), lemon, honey, mint and Thai basil.
ingredients: 1/2 cup "mother" (this applies only if making a batch from a tepache that has already been fermented)
instructions: 1. Cut crowns and butts from the pineapple. Leave the rest of the skin.
2. Slice pineapple into roughly 1”x1” cubes and put into a food-safe bucket for fermentation.
3. Add the sugar, spices, water and, if this isn’t your first go-round, the "mother."
4. Seal the bucket and place somewhere temperature-stable, ideally in the range of 78-82 degrees F.

5. After two days, open the bucket and give it a stir. The sugar should be completely dissolved and the liquid should be slightly warmer than room temperature and the tiniest bit fizzy. A lovely, pungent, tropical funk should be in the air. If these things aren’t true, seal it again and check back in one day. (See Editor's Note)
6. If the correct aroma is present, it's time to harvest. Skim the large solids out of the bucket, then using a paper cone filter inserted into a chinoise, strain the liquid.
7. Finally, pour this fine-strained tepache into hermetic bottles and seal.
8. Store these bottles warm for another 4 hours.
9. "Burp" them once (open bottle to release pressure), then refrigerate.
10. Reserve and refrigerate one small bottle (no more than a cup and a half) to be reserved as your Mother, assuming you intend to make tepache again.

11. Be sure to burp the bottles regularly, especially if your refrigerator temperature isn't at a constant temperature below 33 degrees F. If not burped regularly, the tepache will turn to vinegar, but can be used to start another batch. Just pour off most of it, reserving the yeast collected at the bottom and add it to your next batch.

title: James Bolt’s Corpse Reviver No. 2
intro_philosophy: Third place in our recent blind tasting went to James Bolt of The Gin Joint in Charleston, South Carolina. Bolt went for the standard equal parts ratio, choosing Big Gin from Washington State as his spirit, Leopold Bros. as his absinthe, and, in an unusual move, Cointreau Noir, a blend of Cointreau and Cognac, for the liqueur. Like the Death & Co. drink, it was regarded as an upstanding representation of the cocktail.
ingredients: 3 to 4 dashes absinthe, preferably Leopold Bros. Absinthe Verte
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake hard with ice for 5 to 7 seconds.
2. Double strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed lemon peel then discard.

title: Poor Richard
intro_philosophy: Low-proof kings Paul Calvert and Greg Best of Atlanta’s Ticonderoga Club double down on fall with their variation of a low-proof punch made for holiday entertaining. The Poor Richard features dry cider and cranberry cordial alongside Italian vermouth, lemon juice and freshly grated nutmeg, for added spice.
ingredients: 1 ounces Italian red vermouth, preferably Cocchi Torino
instructions: 1. Combine and serve over ice, with a little nutmeg grated on top.

title: Frozen Moscow Mule
intro_philosophy:
Originally created in the 1940s the Moscow Mule is a delectable mix of vodka, ginger beer and lime juice. Named in homage to vodka’s Russian roots, this frozen riff sticks closely to tradition and the recipe remains almost entirely unchanged.  The sole addition is ice, which transforms the Moscow Mule from a classic cocktail to a very cold classic cocktail.

Special thanks to our friends atWest Elmfor outfitting ourfrozen drinks photoshoot.
ingredients: 3 ounces ginger beer (preferably Fever Tree or Fentimans)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender.
2. Add ice and blend until smooth.
3. Serve in a copper mug and garnish with a lime wheel.

title: The Seven-Per-Cent Solution
intro_philosophy: Drew Record takes inspiration from two classic neon green disco drinks: TGI Fridays’June Bugand theJapanese Slipper. This low-ABV spin, according to Record, “speaks to the flavor memories of both of these recipes, and mingles” the best elements of both.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces fluffy pineapple juice (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 to 1/2 ounce lemon juice, to taste (you’ll need more lemon when pineapples are ripe in season and less when they are tart and out of season)
1 bar spoon banana liqueur, such as Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with ice.
2. Shake and double-strain into an oversize coupe.
3. Garnish with decoratively cut pineapple fronds.

title: Aaron Polsky’s Citrus Blend
intro_philosophy: Los Angeles bartender Aaron Polsky developed this citrus stock formula, which uses peels, rather than whole husks, and does not require any cooking or added heat. He’s incorporated various iterations of the recipe into cocktails designed for Coachella and other large music festivals, as well as for kegged cocktails prepared forHarvard & Stone.
ingredients: 20 grams discarded lemon peels (see Editor's Note for lime version)
instructions: 1. Place all ingredients in a blender, then blend and strain, discarding the solids.

title: Shannon Tebay’s Paloma
intro_philosophy: Coming in on top in our Paloma tasting was this version by Shannon Tebay of Death & Co. New York. Her 2-ounce pour of El Tesoro Blanco tequila was supplemented by one and a half ounces of pink grapefruit juice, three-quarters of an ounce of lime juice and half an ounce of simple syrup, all shaken together, then joined by two ounces of Topo Chico sparkling water, poured into the bottom of the glass before being topped with the shaken mixture. The full salt rim pleased the judges, who called the drink well-rounded and plump.
ingredients: 2 ounces tequila, such as El Tesoro
instructions: 1. Salt the rim of the Collins glass, then add the Topo Chico and set aside.
2. Combine all the remaining ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the Collins glass, add ice, and garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Eggnog Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Created at New Orleans’ Manolito, this wintertime Daiquiri gets blitzed in a blender, so it’s lighter in texture and brighter in flavor than a traditional eggnog recipe. The nog is used more like a syrup, and a little goes a long way to flavor the finished product.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged Demerara rum, preferably El Dorado 5-Year
instructions: 1. Add the ice, eggnog and sugar to a blender. Turn the blender on and, while it’s running, pour in the rum. (Cuban blended cocktails are about texture. When done properly, a blended drink should have a little vortex, about the size of a 50-cent piece, in the middle of the pitcher.)
2. Serve up, with grated nutmeg on top for garnish.

title: Pornstar Martini
intro_philosophy: The provocatively named cocktail, created at the Townhouse in London in 2003 by Douglas Ankrah, is a Martini in name only, but has gone on to become a modern classic. Made with vanilla vodka, passion fruit liqueur and passion fruit purée, the final flourish is a shot glass of chilled Champagne served alongside the drink (intended to alternate with the cocktail as a palate cleanser).
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces vanilla vodka, preferably Grey Goose La Vanille or Absolut Vanilla
1/2 ounce passion fruit liqueur, preferably Passoã or De Kuyper
2 ounces chilled Champagne, to be served on the side
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Champagne, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
3. Garnish with half of a sliced-open passion fruit.
4. Serve with shot of chilled Champagne on the side.

title: Southern Border
intro_philosophy: In an American ode to the Pisco Sour, New York City bartender Pamela Wiznitzer adds the kitschy (and utterly delightful) element of blue Curaçao to color this cocktail bright cerulean blue. A layer of egg white lays a thick, frothy blanket over which Peychaud’s bitters are dashed to create the star-spangled affect of red, white and blue.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
4. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
5. Drop a dash or two of Peychaud's bitters over top to garnish.

title: Toreador
intro_philosophy: TheToreador, which is considered obscure stateside, is a well-known classic in Australia and a standard entry in the mental recipe book of most professional Aussie bartenders. Hayden Lambert, owner of Above Board in Melbourne, Australia, describes the drink as “classic but not extremely well-known,” which fits with the bar’s ethos of putting twists on traditional cocktails.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled, about 15 seconds.
2. Fine-strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Down By Law
intro_philosophy: Like a rebellious child,Shannon Tebay’s Down By Lawnot only sheds the White Negroni family name, but includes none of the original ingredients. The mixture of tequila, apple eau de vie, Luxardo Bitter Bianco, Absentroux and blanc vermouth might bear little resemblance to the fairer Negroni on paper, but, like any reluctant family member, it’s unable to shake the stirred herbal-floral essence that makes a White Negroni a White Negroni.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces blanco tequila, preferably El Tesoro
1/4 ounce apple eau de vie, preferably Double Zero Cyril Zangs Cider Eau De Vie
1/2 ounce blanc vermouth, preferably La Quintinye
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Shochu Sour
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

“Learning and understanding shochu and awamori as a category is very exciting and thrilling to me,” says Nikola Nikoletić. With the Pisco Sour as a jumping-off point, Nikoletić added ayuzu koshorock candy syrup for “depth, spice and brightness,” and juice from kaki apple, also known as Japanese persimmon, for a hit of tangy and sweet.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  yuzu kosho syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with about 10 pebble ice cubes, then shake again with Kold-Draft ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe. (The head from the egg white should hit slightly above the rim of the coupe glass.)
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Dutch Courage’s Southside
intro_philosophy: Brendan Dorr may be a Maryland native, but his allegiance to gin is yet stronger, which explains why he opts for the botanical-driven spirit over rum, the city’s preferred base spirit in a Southside.“I think the classic gin and mint go so well together. There’s botanicals, fresh herbs—it just pops.” His version opts for lime over the original South Side Sportsman’s Club’s lemon and skips the soda, giving the cocktail a minty Gimlet vibe.
ingredients: 2 ounces London dry gin, preferably Greenall’s
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Affix a mint sprig to the coupe using a tiny clothespin.

title: Rye-Nar
intro_philosophy: Many bartenders would chuckle at writing out a recipe for the industry favorite 50/50; it’s as easy as pouring equal parts of two different amari, or an amaro and a spirit, into the same glass. This pairing of bitter Cynar with the extra kick of higher-proof rye is a classic combination. For an extra flourish, chill the glass in advance.
ingredients: 1 ounce  rye, preferably Wild Turkey Rye 101
instructions: 1. Combine Cynar and rye in a small rocks glass.

title: Jane Danger’s LaCroix Cocktail
intro_philosophy: No stranger to dressed cans, Jane Danger’s LaCroix can cocktailriffs on Don the Beachcomber’s Demerara Dry Float, adding lime, rum and maraschino liqueur to a pink can of Passionfruit-flavored sparkling water.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce overproof rum, preferably Plantation O.F.T.D
instructions: 1. Pour out 2 1/2 ounces of passionfruit LaCroix.
2. Add remaining ingredients directly to the can.
3. Garnish with mint, lime shell or passionfruit shell filled with overproof rum and set on fire, a dusting of nutmeg and a straw.

title: Laughing Buddha
intro_philosophy: This buck-like cooler was created by Duggan McDonnell for San Francisco’s Cantina. Made with San Francisco–born citron vodka, five spice–infused agave nectar, ginger, serrano chile peppers and lime, the preparation of theLaughing Buddhaemphasized the freshness of the ingredients by juicing the citrus to order. McDonnell even made an effort to rely on citrus foraged from friends and neighbors to keep the radius of ingredients’ origins as small as possible.
ingredients: 2 ounces citron vodka (Hangar One or Charbay)
instructions: 1. In a mixing pint, muddle a few pieces of freshly diced ginger and a few slices of a serrano chile (to taste).
2. Add vodka, lime juice and agave nectar.
3. Add ice and shake.
4. Strain the contents into an ice-filled highball glass, while simultaneously pouring ginger beer.
5. Garnish with a fresh slice of ginger, and smile.

title: Italian Irish Coffee
intro_philosophy: At Italian restaurant Coda di Volpe, a minty amaro flavors the cream that tops the drink. “Mint pairs well with chocolate,” explains Jerrell Reynolds, plus Fernet Branca Menta “was a way to insert an Italian twist into our seasonal hot cocktail.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Fernet Branca Menta cream (see Editor’s Note}
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except cream, in a footed Irish Coffee glass.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with flavored cream.

title: Hibiscus Punch Royale
intro_philosophy:
