A riff on Smuggler’s Cove’s ever-popular Hibiscus Rum Punch—which is itself a riff on the Caribbean classic Spiced Hibiscus Punch—this large-format holiday recipe from Martin Cate combines aged rum and fresh lime with tart hibiscus syrup. Add a hefty pour of chilled Champagne and preserved hibiscus flowers and you’ve got a prime party-starter based on looks alone.

Many thanks to our friends atOne Kings Lanefor outfitting our holiday punches photoshoot, and toPrime Meatsfor allowing us to make a mess of your beautiful space.
ingredients: 18 ounces blended aged rum, preferably Appleton Estate Reserve Blend
12 ounces hibiscus syrup (see Editor's Note); or Jack From Brooklyn Sorel Liqueur
4 ounces rich demerara simple syrup, (2:1, sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients and chill for two hours before serving.
2. 20 minutes before serving, add chilled ingredients to punch bowl filled with cracked ice. Top with chilled Champagne and stir gently to combine.
3. Garnish bowl with preserved wild hibiscus flowers resting on lime wheels, and mint sprigs.
4. Ladle into cups to serve.

title: Spiced Sangria
intro_philosophy: Luis Hernandez uses an Instant Pot (a regular pressure cooker works as well) to quick-infuse red wine with apples, cloves, star anise, cinnamon and brown sugar for a spiced and fruity base for this sangria. After combining the wine mix with brandy, a squeeze of lemon adds bright, clean acidity. Pro tip: The leftover wine-soaked apples can be saved for a snack or to put on top of your oatmeal.
instructions: 1. Combine wine mix and brandy in a Collins or wine glass over ice.
2. Squeeze lemon wedge over the top and drop used wedge into the glass.
3. Garnish with 4 cucumber slices.

title: Exotic Orchard
intro_philosophy: “This was me just trying to dig into the syrup world again,” explains Jelani Johnson of his Exotic Orchard, a fall-friendly spin on theMai Tai, which calls on a blend of house-madeorgeatand four-spice syrup as sweetener. To this, Johnson adds the expected blend of rums—in this case Plantation O.F.T.D and Coruba Jamaican rum—atop a base of apricot eau de vie compounded by a measure of pear liqueur for a fruit-forward drink that lives up to its name.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Blume Marillen Apricot Eau de Vie
3/4 ounce Exotic Sugar (1:1, pistachio orgeat: quatre epices syrup), see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and briefly whip shake with ice.
2. Pour into a tiki mug.
3. Garnish with mint and grated nutmeg.

title: Godfather II
intro_philosophy: While this drink, a variation on the Godfather cocktail, can be made in a mixing glass and strained over ice, Tyler Caffall suggests that it’s perfectly acceptable to build the drink directly in the glass. “You gotta imagine making this drink like your grandfather would have made it,” Caffall insists. “Was your grandfatherDale DeGroff? If yes, by all means stir in a mixing glass and then strain it over fancy ice.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: The Cuj
intro_philosophy: The Cuj serves as the name of this bright, bittersweet take on a frozen Margarita as well as a nickname of the bar itself,Maracuja. Co-owner Erik Blambeck (he and his business partner, musician Kelly Winrich, took over the bar from its previous owners in March 2020) asked his friendJon Mullen, a bartender and proprietor of the drink-delivery service Quarantine Cocktail Club, to do a take-over one night to show off his drinks and asked him to whip up a featured drink on the fly to throw into the frozen-drink machine and this passion fruit-spiked cooler is the most popular cocktail, second only to a beer-and-shot combo.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until cold and smooth.
2. Pour into a chilled highball glass.
3. Garnish with a dusting of Tajín over the surface of the drink.

title: Frozen Mexican Martini
intro_philosophy: At Holiday in Austin, Texas, Erin Ashford reimagines theMexican Martinias a frozen cocktail. The recipe starts out like any other frozen Margarita, but it gets an olive brine float. Ashforduses the brine from Castelvetrano olives for this drink. “It’s saltier than other brines,” she says. “Plus, you get the perfect snack to pair with your cocktail.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce rich simple syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Prepare a cactus goblet or other stemmed glass with a half salt rim, if using.
2. Combine all ingredients except olive brine in a blender and add ice.
3. Blend on low power for 5 seconds, then blend on high for 10 seconds.
4. Pour into the prepared glass.
5. Float olive brine over the top of the drink.
6. Garnish with a straw and the cocktail skewer with olives.

title: Pouring Ribbons’ Grenadine
intro_philosophy: This unusual no-cook grenadine gets its reduced flavor and rich texture from pomegranate molasses. With a Vitamix, it comes together in seconds; a standard blender takes a moment longer but works just as well.
instructions: 1. In a Vitamix or blender, combine sugar, pomegranate juice and pomegranate molasses.
2. Blend until the sugar is dissolved, scraping down the sides of the blender if necessary.
3. Add orange oil.
4. The mixture will be light brown and opaque; allow to settle and clarify, then skim off light brown head before using.
5. Stored in the refrigerator, this grenadine will keep at least two weeks.

title: Hotel Nacional Special
intro_philosophy: Originally invented in 1930s Havana, the Hotel Nacional Special was invented by an expat bartender, likely Wil P. Taylor or Eddie Woelke, who worked for the Hotel Nacional and Casino Nacional respectively (the bars were owned by the same person). The recipe was preserved in Charles H. Baker Jr.’s 1939Gentleman’s Companion. At Collins, the lobby bar at the Fontainebleau Las Vegas, director of beverage development Juyoung Kang has perfected her spec to create a cocktail that’s historically accurate while also being easy, breezy and transportive.
ingredients: 2 ounces white rum, preferably Bacardí Superior
1/2 ounce apricot liqueur, preferably Giffard Abricot du Roussillon
1 ounce pineapple juice, preferably from golden Hawaiian pineapples
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Express the oils from a lemon twist onto the surface of the drink.
5. Add a dash of Angostura on top, moving the bottle as you do to create a line across the surface of the drink.

title: Alberto
intro_philosophy: Of the earlyMartinisstill awaiting their moment in the limelight, there is one that feels more ready than any. An equal-parts blend of gin, Cocchi Americano and fino or manzanilla sherry, the Alberto is low-proof, minimalistic, aperitivo-friendly and patiently waiting for you.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Rhythm and Soul
intro_philosophy: The Rhythm and Soul is Greg Best’s composite sketch of aManhattanand aSazerac. “I imagine the two cocktails getting into a tussle on the high street of a small frontier town,” says Best, “and then making up and having a love child.” With a base of bourbon and sweet vermouth, accented with the licorice fragrance of the absinthe-like Herbsaint, and balanced out with Averna and Angostura bitters, this drink has, as Best says it, “the rhythm of a Manhattan and the soul of a Sazerac.”
instructions: 1. Fill a rocks glass with cracked ice and add a bar spoon of Herbsaint. Set aside.
2. Add remaining ingredients to a mixing glass.
3. Add ice and stir until chilled.
4. Roll the Herbsaint and ice mixture around the inside of the rocks glass to coat. Discard.
5. Strain the contents of the mixing glass into the seasoned glass.
6. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Cane & Table’s Hurricane
intro_philosophy: At Cane & Table in New Orleans’ French Quarter, Kirk Estopinal has revived the Bourbon Street standby with house-made fassionola syrup and a blend of rums.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Puerto Rican rum, preferably Don Q
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and briefly shake.
2. Strain into a Hurricane glass filled with pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a cocktail umbrella inside out as if it's been broken by the wind.

title: Planter’s Punch
intro_philosophy:
Planter’s Punch can be traced back to a time when the West Indies were considered exotic, and recipes were written in verse. “Two of sour, one and a half of sweet, three of strong and four of weak,” directed one description from a 1908 article in theNew York Times.

Ingredient ratios vary from account to account as does the drink’s name—it’s been known as Jamaican Rum Punch (Savoy Cocktail Book) and Creole Punch (British novelist Alec Waugh)—but it almost always contains rum, lime, sugar and water. More modern versions like the one from tiki stalwart Trader Vic might include grenadine or curaçao. Really, it’s up to the drinker when it comes to additions beyond the nursery rhyme specs, just as long as they’re added to base of good, dark Caribbean rum.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a pineapple wedge, citrus wheels and/or mint sprig.

title: Garden State Julep
intro_philosophy: Near in spirit to theChampagne Julep—a heady mix of cognac and bubbly—Jared Schubert’s Garden State version gets its strength from a base of Laird’s Applejack, a New Jersey product through and through. Like any traditional julep, this one begins with gently muddled mint, which is combined with homemade lemon syrup, Applejack andan unorthodox topper of dry rosé wine. A bit of salt brightens and blends this seemingly diametric combination of ingredients, and recedes into the background once mixed with finely crushed ice. Given that the drink is named for the most verdant state in the union, lavish garnishing is practically ordained. Go wild.
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, gently muddle mint with lemon syrup to release oils.
2. Add Applejack and rosé, stir to combine.
3. Fill glass half-way with crushed ice, add salt and stir again.
4. Top with more crushed ice to mound over top.
5. Garnish with mint sprigs, red berries and a lemon wheel.

title: Pimm’s Spritz
intro_philosophy: This is a relatively simple Pimm’s Royale—that is, a basicPimm’s cuplivened up by a good dose of Champagne. The drink is emblematic of the restrained classicism to be found at the Houston bar Tongue-Cut Sparrow. The perennial argument regarding the proper garnish of this drink is answered with the use of both cucumber and mint.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Champagne, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a tulip glass over ice.
3. Garnish with cucumber wheels, orange wheels and cucumber pierced with mint.

title: On the Road Again
intro_philosophy: “The addition of mesquite adds notes of a cinnamon-like sweetness,” says creator Tyler Wilson, assistant general manager at The Brewer’s Table, a restaurant and nanobrewery in Austin. This riff on a Whiskey Sour uses mesquite pod–infused maple syrup with Old Overholt Straight Rye Whiskey with lemon juice and egg white, yielding a velvety sour with notes of smoke, earth and baking spice.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rye, preferably Old Overholt Straight Rye Whiskey
1/2 ounce mesquite maple syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Whiskey Business
intro_philosophy: Meaghan Dorman’s take on the Whiskey Sour doesn’t hold back on the spice. A split base of rye whiskey and chile liqueur brings the heat, while a rich cinnamon syrup delivers a hint of sweetness.
ingredients: 1 ounce chile liqueur, preferably Ancho Reyes
1/2 ounce rich cinnamon syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a glass over a ice.
3. Garnish with lemon wheel dusted in ancho chile powder.

title: Royal Bermuda Yacht Club
intro_philosophy: A Trader Vic original, the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club is Vic’s tiki-fied version of theDaiquiri. Instead of one-dimensional simple syrup, Vic substituted orange curaçao and spiced falernum to intensify the tropical flavors and presumably translate the feeling of a Caribbean port-of-call.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Mezcaletti
intro_philosophy: The ingredients of the Mezcaletti are telegraphed in the name: mezcal and Amaro Meletti, built in a rocks glass over ice. Strong, nutty and buttery, the drink—which is also on the menu at Brooklyn’s Fresh Kills—has a surprising amount of depth for such a simple drink.
instructions: 1. Build in a rocks glass over a large cube.
2. Gently stir 10 to 15 times.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Andrés & Cooper
intro_philosophy: This pork-centric cocktail, created for Pigtail in Chicago, is a love letter to Ibérico ham, once embargoed in the United States. Miguel Lancha, the bar director for José Andrés Group, designed the cocktail around the buttery cured pork by using Del Maguey’s Ibérico mezcal, which is flavored with Ibérico ham during its third distillation,alongside sweet vermouth and amontillado sherry.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Ibérico
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Yzaguirre 1884 Gran Reserva
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, and stir for about 30 to 40 rotations.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass with a large ice cube.
3. Express an orange peel on top of the drink and discard the peel.
4. Garnish with a cocktail pick with 2 olives and 2 thin slices of ham.

title: Poseidon
intro_philosophy: The Poseidon served atCrevettein New York is quite different from the sweet blue ’tinis and fizzes floating around the internet with the same name. Strong, stirred and bitter, the riff on the mezcal Negroni mixes the agave spirit with rum, Cynar and Punt e Mes, while saline solution rounds the entire cocktail out.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, such as 400 Conejos Mezcal
1/2 ounce aged white rum, such as Probitas
2 dashes orange bitters, such as Regan’s
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel and olive on a pick.

title: Libra
intro_philosophy:
AtTrick Dogin San Francisco, the menu changes seasonally based on one unifying concept. In winter of 2014, the bar introduced its zodiac menu, featuring twelve drinks that corresponded to each astrological sign.

Kind, flirtatious, diplomatic and gentle, Libras are said to be the most desirable sign of the zodiac (and one of the most attractive). Their time comes at the change of the seasons when the world is in flux, and we’re all settling into a new perspective and readjusting to our surroundings—drinking warmer things, taking out flannels and long underwear. Like a fluffy autumn sweater, Morgan Schick’s Libra cocktail is thickly blanketed in egg white, which covers a savory-sour mixture of tequila, tangerine and lime juices and housemade dill syrup—the final pull of summer’s herbs.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker, and shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Strain into a cocktail or coupe glass.
4. Garnish with a bit of matcha powder and a dill sprig.

title: Mickey Finn
intro_philosophy: TheMickey Finntakes its name from the devious proprietor of the Lone Star Saloon in Chicago, who, around the turn of the last century, put incapacitating agents into customers’ drinks in order to rob them. A cocktail of the same name was published in Crosby Gaige’sCocktail Guide and Ladies’ Companionin 1941, several decades after Finn’s heyday. At Whoopsie’s in Atlanta, the Mickey Finn transforms from its equal-parts template (with a touch of crème de menthe) to a house favorite with a 3:1:1:1 ratio. The result is a silky, herbaceous improved Martini that is surprisingly popular with customers, despite the “dangerous” half-ounce of absinthe.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces navy-strength dry gin, such as Plymouth
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, such as Dolin
1/2 ounce absinthe, such as Pernod Absinthe Supérieure
1/2 ounce crème de menthe, such as Giffard Menthe-Pastille
instructions: 1. Combine the ingredients in a mixing glass over cracked ice and stir until well-chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Dirty Martini Highball
intro_philosophy: Fanny Chuturns drinking dictums on their head with this tall rendition of adirty Martini. In addition to the expected olive brine, Chu adds a measure ofmanzanilla sherryfor a different kind of salinity.
instructions: 1. Combine the first 4 ingredients in a highball glass with ice.
2. Top with tonic water.
3. Briefly stir once to integrate the ingredients.
4. Garnish with an olive and a lemon twist.

title: Meadowood’s Quince & Asian Pear Brandy
intro_philosophy: With the help ofStillwater Spirits,Meadowoodbartender Sam Levy combined an apple mash with native yeast and fresh apples to distill his owneau de vie, which was then aged in American oak.  When applied to hisVieux Carré, Levy infused the eau de vie with winter-sturdy Asian pears and quince from Meadowood’s Napa Valley grounds along with spicebush, vanilla, nutmeg and orange.
instructions: 1. Peel, core and poach the Asian pears and quince, then add them to the brandy.
2. Add all spices to the mix and infuse. (If you want a heavier/roasted flavor, toast the spices, except vanilla & orange peel, in a pan until they just begin to smoke and then add to the infusion.
3. Infuse for a week (give or take a day or two), monitoring the balance of spices, removing any that become overpowering.
4. When ready to bottle, out all solids through at least a triple layer of cheesecloth or a Chemex coffee filter.

title: Fu Gwaa Falsetto
intro_philosophy: “Bitter melon has a very polarizing reputation, especially among those who grew up with it, due to its bitter taste,” saysTom Liu, head bartender at Thunderbolt in Los Angeles.To keep this bitter melon cocktail approachable to those who are new to the ingredient, he counteracted some of the bitterness with minerally sherry and citrus, and accentuated it with Suze, which he feels has a similar astringent flavor profile. To finish, li hing mui powder—made from preserved salted plums—offers sweet, sour and salty notes. “‘Fu gwaa (苦瓜)’ means ‘bitter melon’ in Cantonese, an ode to my heritage. When someone sings in falsetto, it is their own voice being used to sing at a much higher tone,” explains Liu. “For this cocktail, it is bitter melon, but it is bitter melon ‘singing’ at a refreshingly higher, more elevated tone.”
ingredients: 1 ounce bitter melon syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and whip-shake with pebble ice.
2. Pour into a pint glass.
3. Add more pebble ice, creating a mound on the top.
4. Garnish with a dusting of li hing mui powder.

title: The Smoke Also Rises
intro_philosophy: “Hemingway was obviously my inspiration,” says Orestes Cruz of his Papa Doble variation. “I love Hemingway, and I love Cuba…so I wanted to make an homage to this culture.” His rendition changes little from the rum-grapefruit-maraschinocombination of the original, he simply adds a half-ounce of Amaro Sfumato for a smokier variation that feels as timeless as the Cuban classic.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce amaro, preferably Cappelletti Sfumato Rabarbaro Amaro
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: The Shining Path
intro_philosophy: “Avèze has potency and lovely bitter notes that are very thirst-quenching,” says Will Elliott, who considers it anessential component to the backbar. Here, he pairs the gentian liqueur with one of its French cousins, Salers, plus lemon juice, lemon cordial and St-Germain. A float of bitter Rinomato balances it all out.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Fine strain into a footed pilsner glass filled with crushed ice.
3. Top with a float of Rinomato and garnish with microplaned lemon zest.

title: Fresa Y Cerveza
intro_philosophy: NoMad’s Leo Robitschek borrows Chef Daniel Humm’s strawberry pickling vinegar for a housemade shrub, which is shaken with cucumber and yellow Chartreuse and topped with a dose of wheat beer for a modern take on the radler. At home, white wine vinegar works in place of pickling vinegar.
ingredients: 1 ounce strawberry saline shrub (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass and top with Berliner Weisse.

title: Billie Jo
intro_philosophy: The Billie Jo, named for two of Bossart’s favorite style icons (Billy Porter and Billie Joe Armstrong) is a cross between two classic highballs—Scotch and soda and white port and tonic—that comes on playfully but goes much deeper beneath the surface. The “funky fresh” notes of the Glen Moray Chardonnay Cask help harmonize the two spirits, along with a touch of citrus and a pinch of sea salt. Taste the drink before and after applying the salt at the end to really taste the difference.
ingredients: 2 ounces  Glen Moray Speyside Classic Single Malt Scotch Whisky (Chardonnay Cask Finish)
instructions: 1. Add the Scotch whisky and port to a highball glass.
2. Add ice and top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with an expressed lemon twist placed on the rim of the glass and a dusting of sea salt.

title: Spritzus Narcissus
intro_philosophy: Fruit liqueurs are the obvious choice for warm-weather cocktailing, but let’s not overlook the sensory potential of flower-based liqueurs. Giffard Wild Elderflower, whose flavor comes from the maceration of actual wild elderflowers, “is very summery to me, with all its floral, tropical and citrus characteristics,” says Chantal Tseng. A creative, and truly international, tweak on the traditional spritz, Tseng’s Spritzus Narcissus begins with Giffard Wild Elderflower, to which she adds a touch ofretsina, the ancient Greek wine enhanced with pine resin, and dry sparkling wine from Greece. The cocktail’s name, of course, is a nod to a third Greek entity, the mythological hunter who’d likely gaze upon his namesake spritz the same way he ogled his own reflection.
ingredients: ¼ ounce  Garalis retsina (or other craft retsina)
3 ounces  Domaine Karanika Amyntaion Brut (or other Champagne-method dry sparkling wine)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except Perrier and sparkling wine in a chilled wine glass, then add ice.
2. Top wine glass with Perrier and sparkling wine.
3. Garnish with grapefruit peel.

title: Bramble
intro_philosophy: The Bramble, invented in 1984 by bartender Dick Bradsell, is one of the few drinks that fall into the category of “modern classics.” One of the founding fathers of London’s cocktail scene, Bradsell created this cross between aCobblerand a Gin Sour while working at Fred’s Club in SoHo. He considers it a sentimental play on aSingapore Slingusing entirely of British products—the blackberries lending a flavor “reminiscent of his childhood on the Isle of Wight.” Bartender and writer Toby Cecchini sums up its contemporary importance well calling it, “the riesling of the cocktail world, known by drinks weenies since seemingly forever.”
instructions: 1. Add gin, lemon juice and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over crushed ice into a rocks glass.
4. Drizzle crème de mûre over top, and garnish with blackberries and lemon wheel.

title: Praying Mantis
intro_philosophy: Bartender Brandon Bramhall of Attaboy in Nashville crafted the Praying Mantis in the mold of Sam Ross’Mosquito, anotherequal-parts citrus cocktail. Both rely on lemon and ginger juice to deliver the sour and sweet notes. But whereas the Mosquito features mezcal and Campari, the Praying Mantis combines smoky Scotch and Gran Classico as its spirit and bitter components.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweetened ginger juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with candied ginger.

title: Cynar & Tonic
intro_philosophy: For a refreshing aperitivo, simply top Cynar with tonic water. This pairing doubles down on the bitter qualities of both ingredients, while a finishing squeeze of lime cuts through it all with a bright hit of acid.
ingredients: 4 ounces  tonic water, preferably Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Indian Tonic Water
instructions: 1. Add Cynar to a chilled highball or Collins glass filled with ice.
2. Pour tonic into glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Death and Co.’s Corpse Reviver No. 2
intro_philosophy: Placing second in our recent blind tasting wasDeath & Co.‘s house recipe for the Corpse Reviver No. 2. This rendition was nearly textbook: equal parts Beefeater Gin, Cointreau, Cocchi Americano and lemon juice, with two dashes of absinthe, mixed with all the ingredients and no garnish. All judges commented on the drink’s fresh, bright quality. “Pretty damn standard,” said Tristan Willey.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Chapman
intro_philosophy: For Dare and Mosun Aderinokun, founders of Quacktails, a Lagos-based drinks company, this recipe is “comforting, nostalgic and timeless.” The Chapman is a classic in Nigeria, and the group’s bestselling nonalcoholic drink. “We love that it remains a shared memory across generations,” they say. They also serve a version made with gin, which you can add to your liking for a full-proof cocktail.
ingredients: heavy 1/2 ounce citrus syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a beer mug or chilled glass over ice.
2. Top with the slices of cucumber.
3. Serve with a straw.

title: Ichigo
intro_philosophy: Japan’s obsession with ichigo miruku, or strawberry milk, was the genesis for this highball, which combines Calpico with strawberry puree, cucumber juice and lemon. Plymouth or other soft gins allow the produce to shine, while the creamy texture of Calpico lends a dessert-like quality.
ingredients: 2 tablespoons cane syrup (1:1 evaporated cane sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the club soda, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Top with club soda.
4. Stir to integrate.
5. Garnish with cucumber slice.

title: Datu Datu
intro_philosophy: At Genever in Los Angeles, the Datu Datu is a pre-batched combination of gin, dry vermouth, ground garlic, fish sauce and datu puti spiced vinegar. That latter ingredient, a traditional flavored Filipino vinegar, lent the finished product a distinctive vinegar-y note that stood out from the more typical salt brines at our blind dirty Martini tasting, and appealed in its complexity. As Toby Cecchini noted, “it attacks you in 12 different ways,” but in a good way.
ingredients: 18 ounces London dry gin, preferably Fords
4 ounces dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat Original Dry
2 ounces datu puti spiced vinegar (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 750 ml bottle and shake well.
2. Store in the refrigerator or freezer to chill until ready to serve.
3. To serve, pour three ounces into a mixing glass and add ice.
4. Stir until chilled then strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
5. Garnish with a skewered olive and cocktail onion.

title: Zombie Spritz
intro_philosophy: Another standard-bearer in Dante’s aperitiki repertoire, the Zombie Spritz combines the bitter, bubbly, low-ABV spritz template with the Zombie’s famously layered build for a drink that feels firmly rooted to both.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Cava rosé, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a goblet or tiki mug over crushed ice.
3. Top with cava rosé.
4. Garnish with dehydrated grapefruit slice and fresh mint.

title: Safe Passage
intro_philosophy: A salty and bitter twist on a traditional spritz from the amaro-loving owner of Seattle’s Delancey and its neighboring cocktail bar, Essex.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce olive brine from Castelvetrano olives
2 1/2 ounce prosecco, or other sparkling wine
instructions: 1. Add Amaro Nardini, Aperol, lemon juice and olive brine to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Top with prosecco or sparkling wine, and garnish with olives.

title: Hotel San José’s Michelada
intro_philosophy: This meaty Michelada is built on the bones of a traditional south-of-the-border recipe that forgoes the tomato base. Instead, the Tex-Mex version from Hotel San José in Austin gets its savory flavor from the one-two punch of soy and Worcestershire sauce.
instructions: 1. Rim a pint glass with salt.
2. Fill the glass halfway with ice cubes.
3. Add all ingredients except for beer over ice and garnish with a lime wheel.
4. Serve with a stirring straw and beer on the side.

title: Mexican Firing Squad 2.0
intro_philosophy: In their postmodern take on this Margarita-adjacent classic, the crew behind Dandelyan and Cub call on fake lime juice and clarified tomato grenadine for a savory riff on the original.
ingredients: 3/4 ounces fake lime juice, see Editor's note
3/4 ounces clear tomato grenadine, see Editor's note
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

title: Fog Lights Milk Punch
intro_philosophy: At Boston’s Eastern Standard, bar manager Diego Peña takes inspiration from a London Fog (essentially an Earl Grey tea latte) in this wintry milk punch. It calls for a warming blend of bourbon, brandy and rum alongside Earl Grey syrup.
ingredients: 1 3/4 cup Earl Grey syrup (1:1 earl grey tea: granulated sugar)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, except milk and half and half (plus lemon and vanilla, if using), to a nonreactive container.
2. Combine the milk, half and half, lemon zest and vanilla over in a pot over the stove and heat to 180ºF.
3. Add milk to the nonreactive container and allow it to rest for approximately 3 minutes.

4. In a clean container, place a mesh strainer with a single thin layer of cheesecloth or coffee filter on top. Start the straining process by allowing the punch to pass through. Do not remove the curds—they help with the clarification. When you notice the rate of liquid passing through has slowed down, transfer the curd-filled strainer into a clean container.
5. Add the contents from the other container to the top of the strainer and slowly top of until its completely passed through. It takes some time depending on the batch.
6. Serve in a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
7. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: John deBary’s Singapore Sling
intro_philosophy: While the original recipe is unknown,John deBary’s rendition “isn’t really a departure from what’s now thought of as a classic build,” he says. He dials down the sweetness by using less pineapple juice and opts for a navy-strength gin, which lightens the drink and keeps it from being too cloying. Made properly, says deBary, a Singapore Sling should be “juicy, fruity and refreshing.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces navy-strength gin, such as Plymouth
instructions: 1. In a shaker, combine the drink ingredients. Add ice and shake for 15 seconds.
2. Strain into an ice-filled Collins or water glass. Garnish with the pineapple wedge and a cherry speared on a pick. Serve with a straw.

title: Japanese Cocktail
intro_philosophy: First appearing in Jerry Thomas’s 1862How to Mix Drinks, the Japanese Cocktail is accompanied with no explanation of its namesake, nor do its ingredients lead one to believe it is of any Asian persuasion. However, as David Wondrich surmises inImibibe!,this vanguard cocktail perhaps had something to do with a visit (or four) paid to Thomas’s New York City bar on Broadway by a member of Japan’s first diplomatic mission to America, Tateishi Onojirou Noriyuki, or “Tommy,” as he was known among the ladies. The delegation resided quite near Thomas’s saloon, and Tommy quickly drummed up a reputation for spending plenty of nights out on the town. It can be assumed that a raucous evening or two spent at the bar would be enough cause for Thomas to christen a cocktail in honor of his Japanese regular.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Rooftop Gardening
intro_philosophy:
“I wanted to make something with springy, fresh flavors to play along with the rhubarb liqueur,” say Liz Pearce. This cocktail comes with a dash of absinthe, “which harkens back to pre-prohibition style drinks, but with bright, warm weather flavors.”

Pearce adds that the syrup can be made with any herbs you have on hand, such as “rosemary, parsley, mint, oregano. If you’re using a delicate herb like mint or parsley, infuse it as the syrup cools. Hardier herbs like rosemary can be simmered with the syrup.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce herb syrup (1:1, sugar:water with herb of your choice)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except sparkling wine in a cocktail shaker and shake.
2. Double-strain into a flute and top with sparkling wine.
3. Garnish with a long lemon twist.

title: Breakfast
intro_philosophy: Akin to aManhattanor aBoulevardier, this cocktail is essentially “breakfast encapsulated,” says the drink’s creator, Aaron Polsky ofAmor y Amargo. “But breakfast with Sriracha.” The mezcal is the smoky essence of bacon or sausage. The Carpano is the orange juice and jam. And the coffee liqueur, is, well, the coffee. Add a few Sriracha bitters for blending and it, “tastes a bit like a black cup of coffee and breakfast at a diner.” All it needs is an egg.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth (preferably Carpano Antica Formula)
3/4 ounce Bittermens New Orleans Coffee Liqueur
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Express and orange peel over top and discard.

title: Au Poivre
intro_philosophy: Part of a trio of Martinis that form the Maison Martini section ofLe Rock’s bar menu, the Au Poivre builds on a base of vodka infused with Manzanilla olives and pickled green peppercorns, which add a savory element to this recipe. Made in large, pre-diluted batches, this recipe can be prepared ahead of time and stored in the freezer until ready to serve.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a large glass bottle.
2. Store the bottle in the freezer for at least 3 to 4 hours.
3. Fifteen minutes prior to serving, remove the bottle to thaw (you can shake the bottle periodically to speed up the process).
4. Pour 4 ounces into a cocktail glass.
5. Garnish with olives and a cocktail fork.

title: Temple Bar’s Gibson
intro_philosophy: Made with equal parts manzanilla sherry and gin, this is a50/50-style Martiniconceived by bartender Sam Ross. What pushes the serve into Gibson territory is the addition of sherry vinegar and onion brine, which bring acidity and salinity.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe and garnish with a pickled onion.

title: Something Tequila
intro_philosophy:
“All good tiki drinks have a great story behind them,” says John Bernard, proprietor of Cleveland’s Porco Lounge and Tiki Room. “Something Tequila was created in response to customers asking, ‘Do you make Margaritas? Could you make me something tequila?’ ” In the Something Tequila, Bernard creates a hybrid of a Margarita and a Rum Barrel (a tiki classic) with a combination of three types of citrus, passion fruit, and tequila. While the agave-based spirit was not a typical twentieth-century tiki ingredient, Bernard impresses upon his guests that “tiki is all about the adventure and exploring what you like.”

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce passion fruit syrup, see Editor’s Note
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
3. Pour the contents of the shaker into a barrel-shaped tiki mug and garnish with mint, citrus wedges or wheels, flowers, and swizzle sticks.

title: Toby Cecchini’s Gin & Tonic
intro_philosophy: The winner ofour Gin & Tonic tasting, Toby Cecchini’s take on the classic is derived from his father’s recipe. The lime skins are julienned into thin strips, which get muddled in the shaking tin then float atop the drink. “Present as such,” writes Cecchini, “making sure to tell the guest to mix the whole together before sipping.”
ingredients: 6 to 8 ounces Schweppes tonic water, well-chilled
instructions: 1. Clean well a fat, fresh lime. Cut in half and juice both halves, setting the juice aside for another use. Julienne the spent hulls into thin strips and put into a small mixing tin or glass. Add gin and muddle well for a minute or so.
2. In a large highball glass half-filled with ice, pour the tonic water carefully at a slant, so as to not disturb the effervescence, and slip a straw down the side of the glass.
3. Strain the gin-lime mixture over a spoon onto the top, so that it floats. With tongs or a spoon, garnish atop with the julienned strips of lime. Present as such, but mix lightly before drinking.

intro_philosophy: The breakout star of Trick Dog’s Chinatown menu, released in January 2015, this “spicy bourbon citrus banger” (as owner Josh Harris describes it) was right on trend. The bar sold upward of 11,000 #5s during the menu’s six-month run. The drink is typically garnished with a skewer of cilantro-infused mango cubes, but you can also use a dehydrated orange wheel and ginger candy for a similarly earthy, tart effect.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon, preferably Old Grand-Dad Bonded
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass with ice.
3. Garnish with skewered cilantro-infused mango cubes or a dehydrated orange wheel and ginger candy.

title: Commodore Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Most Daiquiris are shaken, but this unusual, vibrantly-hued variation is stirred.Brian Millersays that’s in homage to late bar legendSasha Petraske, who suggested the technique would yield a silky rather than frothy texture.
ingredients: 1 ounce white rum, preferably El Dorado 3 Year
1 teaspoon orgeat, preferably Orgeat Works HD
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with orchid.

title: Carrot Margarita
intro_philosophy:
LA photographer duo Dylan + Jeni start most days with a glass of homemade juice. They end most days with a cocktail. Often left with a surplus of their breakfast blend, they started combining their a.m. routine with their p.m. ritual for an in-house cocktail series they call Detox/Intox (the morning’s juice ends up in the evening’s cocktail). This one couples a spicy fruit and veggie blend—rendered orange with a bunch of fresh carrots—with the architecture of a blended Margarita.

They use a homemade juicer, but you can buy fresh juice from a juice counter or a green grocer. Crushed ice works best for making blended cocktails if you don’t have an industrial blender.
ingredients: 2 ounces homemade spicy carrot juice blend, see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass with a with asalt and cayenne pepper rim.
2. Add all ingredients to a blender.
3. Blend on low speed until smooth.
4. Pour into prepared rocks glass, and garnish with a lime wheel.

title: The Bachelor
intro_philosophy: This rum and amaro-based cocktail by Chris Flannery-McCoy ofMaison Premiererecalls the richness of anOld-Fashionedcrossed with the anise undertones of aSazerac. The full ounce of sweet Meletti amaro shines through the brown sugar rum base with notes of candied orange, caramel and saffron to pair withSt. George absinthe’sminty, herbaceous bite.
ingredients: 5 dashes aromatic bitters, preferably Bitter Truth
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Vernon’s Cloak
intro_philosophy: This variation of the Navy Grog, one of Sam Miller’s favorite tiki classics, takes its name from British Vice Admiral Edward Vernon—a “bitter old man,” Miller says, whose nickname was “Old Grog” for the coarse grogram cloak he wore. “This drink is tart and bitter, but finished with a hit of baking spice and balanced honey sweetness,” says Miller. “If someone is looking for a bitter cocktail that is still [easy-going], this is the drink for them.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with crushed ice and shake until chilled.
2. Pour the entire contents of the shaker into a chilled Mai Tai glass, then top with a layer of fresh crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a fresh mint sprig.

title: K-O.F.
intro_philosophy: “This was inspired by my journey in learning about Korean street food,” saysParker Luthmanof his modified Old-Fashioned. “I wanted to share flavor pairings and Korean cuisine that I’m excited about in an American cocktail format.” To a rye base, he adds a housemade gochujang-honey syrup, consisting of two core ingredients used in many Korean fried chicken recipes. The fermented chile paste adds a nuanced spice, complemented by the sweetness of the honey, which is reinforced through a splash of pineapple rum. “I think that there is a reason to celebrate these flavors, to bring them to the forefront without having to be gimmicky,” says Luthman.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably Old Overholt Bottled-in-Bond
1/2 ounce pineapple rum, preferably Plantation Stiggin’s
1/2  ounce gochujang honey syrup (see Editor's Note)
3 dashes Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas' Own Decanter bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a rocks glass over ice
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated pineapple chip.

title: Double Derby
intro_philosophy: This wine cocktail feels like an even-boozier riff on sangria and akalimotxo: It’s rich and dark, but still tart from citrus and tannic from wine. In the words of Robbie Nelson of Brooklyn’s Long Island Bar, this recipe fromPlayboy’s Host & Bar Book“tastes like Daddy’s tea.” If you’re serving a crowd, scale it up for a punch—and warn your guests. It’s a strong one.
instructions: 1. Pour bourbon, tea, Claret, red currant syrup, orange juice and lemon juice into a double old fashioned glass.
2. Add ice cubes to fill to brim. Stir well. Add orange slice.
3. *If redcurrant syrup is not available, redcurrant jelly to which a teaspoon of hot water has been added may be heated over a low flame and stirred constantly until jelly is liquid.

title: Feni Cocktail
intro_philosophy: This simple serve offeni, a pre-industrial spirit made from cashew fruit, with lemon-lime soda is enjoyed by most Goans daily, at their home or taverns. It can also be made withurak, a lighter, lower-proof version of feni.
ingredients: 2 ounces feni, preferably Spirit of India Cashew Feni
instructions: 1. Pour the feni into a highball glass with a few ice cubes.
2. Top with lemon-lime soda, such as Sprite.
3. Add a squeeze of lime and a pinch of salt.
4. Stir well.
5. Garnish with a slit green chile.

title: Bicicletta
intro_philosophy: According to a popular Italian legend, the Bicicletta—“bicycle” in Italian—was named after the elderly men who swerved all over the road while riding home after a few afternoon drinks at the café. In traditional aperitivo style, the cocktail mixes two of Italy’s favorite early-evening refreshments. Campari adds delightfully bitter complexity to dry Italian white wine, while a splash of club soda turns the combination into a refreshing spritz.
ingredients: 2 ounces white wine, Italian and dry
instructions: 1. Add Campari and white wine to a wine glass.
2. Add ice and top with soda.
3. Stir gently and garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Above Ground Pool
intro_philosophy: A riff on a Margarita, this bestselling cocktail atCobrain Columbus, Ohio—one of ourBest New Bars of 2024—demonstrates the bar’s playful approach to classics. The familiar template is kicked up with mango and serrano-cilantro cordials and a spicy Sichuan salt rim, bringing both a tropical and herbaceous edge to the drink. The name, meanwhile, nods to its bright green appearance.
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass by lining the rim with Sichuan salt.
2. In a cocktail shaker, combine all the ingredients with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared rocks glass over fresh ice.

title: High Chicago
intro_philosophy:
“This is an expression of sun-kissed beta-carotene plants and vegetables and colors,” says bar director Will Elliott of Maison Premiere’s High Chicago, a vegetal and stone fruit-driven blend of the Dutch liqueur kümmel, the Greek spirit mastiha, Austrian apricot eau de vie and French dessert wine.

Elliott describes it as a “clean, light and lifting stirred drink,” not to mention an international tour of some more obscure traditional spirits.
ingredients: 1 ounce apricot eau de vie, preferably Blume de Merrilen
instructions: 1. Build in mixing glass over one KD ice cube and stir.
2. Strain into Nick & Nora glass and garnish with cleaned, curled carrot peel, discarded orange and atomized carrot eau de vie.

title: The Red Light
intro_philosophy: Charles Joly invented this unusual, bitters-heavy drink in 2009 while at the Drawing Room in Chicago. Bothgeneverand Underberg were hard-to-find novelties at the time, making the cocktail rather adventurous. The odd trio of ingredients make for a fruity, herbal, and soothing drink that has a vaguely yuletide feel about it.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Watermelon Sgroppino
intro_philosophy: Mezcal meets watermelon sorbet in Fanny Chu’s updated Sgroppino. With a smoky-sweet profile, her modern take is more than an after-dinner drink, it’s an all-day affair. For a less smoky profile, try it with a different white spirit like gin, rum, tequila or vodka.
instructions: 1. Serve the sorbet in a coupe and top with mezcal.
2. Garnish with a mint leaf and a lime wheel.

title: La Viña
intro_philosophy: “People who swear they hate whiskey love [this] drink, but it also pleases the most inveterate Manhattan disciple,” says Joaquín Simó of La Viña, an equal-parts cocktail created by Death & Co. co-owner Alex Day.
ingredients: 1 ounce Lustau East India Solera Sherry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Tamarind Mate Cooler
intro_philosophy: “Combining chai-tamarind syrup with yerba mate tea was a perfect marriage,” according to Mr. Melo co-owner Nikolas Vagenas, who first created the Tamarind Mate Cooler as a bottled nonalcoholic option for guests at a wedding. Now, at the newly opened Mr. Melo in Brooklyn, the Tamarind Mate Cooler is served on tap, with the option to have it spiked with mezcal. It’s earthy, tart and refreshing. Vagenas explains: “The flavor profile for this drink was influenced by the time I spent in India, and my consequential obsession with Indian flavor profiles.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except soda water to a Collins glass.
2. Top with soda water and stir to combine.

title: Fleur-de-Lis
intro_philosophy: “When you need just a little lift in flavor,” says Tyler Stevens ofTeardropLounge in Portland, Oregon, “verjus could do it without masking a cocktail’s delicate, spiritual flavors.” He uses the fresh, unfermented grape juice in this drink, which features an entire ounce of Peychaud’s bitters alongside Pierre Ferrand Ambre. “I have never had a cocktail that boasts a full ounce of bitters taste so palatable,” he says. “Verjus can take an ingredient that is too condensed, harsh or bitter and blow it up like a microscope to reveal all of its beautiful complexities.”
instructions: 1. Add bitters, cognac, verjus, honey and lemon peel to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Top with sparkling wine.

title: Out of Office
intro_philosophy: In this summer-ready highball, The Botanist gin is infused with dried chamomile flowers that amplify the gin’s floral profile and soften its edges. Dry vermouth and bergamot liqueur bring further botanical complexity and some acid, while a cucumber-lime sherbet adds body and a verdant tint. Built over ice in a chilled highball glass before being topped with tonic water, the resulting cocktail drinks like a holiday.
ingredients: 1 ounce  chamomile-infused The Botanist gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Fill half of a chilled Collins glass with an ice spear or cubed ice.
2. Pour all ingredients except for the tonic water into the glass.
3. Top with more ice, and gently stir with a bar spoon to chill.
4. Add more ice as needed, then top with tonic water and garnish.

title: Orlando Franklin McCray’s Freezer Martini
intro_philosophy: Finding favor in our blind freezer Martini tasting was a unique specimen submitted byOrlando Franklin McCrayof Brooklyn’s Nightmoves, who put together high-proof, saffron-tinged Old Raj gin, La Quintinye Extra Dry vermouth and orange bitters. The judges liked the concentration of bold flavors but thought the recipe would have benefited from higher dilution.
ingredients: 750 ml gin, preferably Old Raj 55% ABV
150 ml extra dry vermouth, preferably La Quintinye Vermouth Royal
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 1 liter bottle and give it a quick shake.
2. Place in the freezer for at least two hours.
3. To serve, pour into chilled cocktail glasses and express a lemon twist over the surface of the drink.
4. Serve with olives or caper berries.

title: Hanukkah Cobbler
intro_philosophy: AtCurein New Orleans, the Hanukkah Cobbler is featured on the holiday cocktail list alongside aSorel Toddy, a spiked, chicory-infused eggnog and more. The base of the drink is Manischewitz’s concord grape-based wine.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and hard shake.
2. Strain into a metal cobbler cup over pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a straw and mint bouquet, and top the ice with more bitters.

title: Cape Town Cup
intro_philosophy: While many cobblers are built around sherry, this version swaps inMadeira, another fortified wine, and pairs it with the dark fruit notes ofByrrh, a French aperitif wine. The result is a robust base that can stand up to equally bold flavors such as nutty-sweet orgeat and tannic black tea. A dose of sparkling wine and bright accents like lemon and mint keep this drink lively and fresh.
ingredients: 1 lemon wedge (about 1/6 of an average lemon)
3/4 ounce bual Madeira, preferably Blandy's 5 Year
instructions: 1. Add the lemon wedge and orgeat to a mixing tin and muddle.
2. Add the tea, Byrrh and Madeira and swirl briefly.
3. Dump the contents of the tin into a chilled Collins glass.
4. Fill the glass 3/4 full with pebble or crushed ice and mix briefly with a spoon or metal straw to integrate.
5. Top with sparkling wine.
6. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Run Forest Run
intro_philosophy: In the hot, dry heat of Arizona, this drink is a bonafide thirst-quencher, with grapefruit liqueur and lemon juice enhancing the mellow orchard fruit notes of  Lake Bartężek from Belvedere Vodka’s Singe Estate Rye series. “We wanted to let the vodka stand on its own,” says Bar Manager Marcus Valenzuela. “It’s not too sweet and not too strong—a happy medium between the two.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Champagne flute.
3. Top with prosecco.
4. Garnish with a raspberry.

title: Coming Up Daisies
intro_philosophy: In Spanish,margaritameans “daisy,” which explains the name of this stirred Margarita variation. “When I think about a Margarita, I think about a drink that is a balance of salty, acidic, sweet and spirituous,” Favre says. This version “hits all the same notes as a Margarita, but has a completely different texture.”
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express lime twist over the drink, then garnish with the twist.

title: Anthony Schmidt’s Kingston Negroni
intro_philosophy: Taking top honors in ourKingston Negroni blind tasting, this recipe sticks to the tried and true Smith & Cross as the base, blended with Campari, Carpano Antica sweet vermouth (the brand used in theoriginal recipe) and the unexpected addition of a quarter-ounce of oloroso sherry. Further setting it apart, Schmidt recommendsstirring the drink with coffee beansdirectly in the mixing glass to impart another layer of flavor.
ingredients: 1 ounce overproof Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Taste occasionally to ensure the coffee bean flavor has infused the drink.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a half orange wheel and lime twist.

title: Benton’s Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy:
The Benton’s Old-Fashioned is the drink that introduced the concept of “fat-washing” spirits—a technique of flavoring liquor with cooking fats—to the cocktail world. Created by formerPDTbartender Don Lee, the Benton’s seemed, at first, overly labor-intensive. “Originally, I told him fat-washing was too much to ask of our barbacks,” says PDT owner Jim Meehan. “So I asked him to make the bourbon in his house.” And so Don Lee, a notoriously innovative bartender, began fat-washing bourbon in his kitchen. “To my surprise, it became our best selling cocktail,” says Meehan. “We make at least 150 a week, which means we go through upwards of 12 bottles of fat-washed bourbon in that same amount of time.”

Reprinted with permission fromThe PDT Cocktail Book© 2011 by Jim Meehan, Sterling Epicure an imprint of Sterling Publishing Co., Inc.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice (preferably a large cube).
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Sparkling Cosmo
intro_philosophy: At Nightmoves, this Cosmo variation is kegged, carbonated and served on draft. While this home-friendly, single-serve version uses lime juice, at Nightmoves the drink gets its tartness from Lolo’s Mix, a clarified, acidified ingredient made with malic acid, citric acid, water and sugar, which won’t clog the draft lines or create excess waste. “It’s the same pH and acidity as lemon or lime juice,” McCray explains. “My nickname is Lolo, so I named it for myself.”
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, combine all of the ingredients and stir to integrate them.
2. Carbonate using a soda maker or at-home carbonation system.
3. Pour into a rocks glass over ice, then stir briefly to chill.
4. Mist orange oil over the top of the drink.

title: Oliveto
intro_philosophy: The Marvel Bar in Minneapolis has been serving rafts of Olivetos since it opened in 2011. At its heart, the drink is a Gin Sour, albeit with a couple of left-field touches—Licor 43 and extra virgin olive oil—that were once all the rage in craft cocktail circles. But there is magic in the mixture; the olive oil and egg white yield an unusual texture that elevates this sour above its fellows.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, combine all ingredients with three ice cubes.
2. Shake until the cubes are nearly dissolved.
3. Strain into a stemless wine glass.

title: Thigh High Boots
intro_philosophy: This hard-hitting bourbon drink is a signature atT.J. Lynch‘s soon-to-be-opened bar, Loverboy, which will display the same irreverent style he honed atMother’s Ruin.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Gin Daisy (Old School)
intro_philosophy: This drink is a variation on the basic Daisy formula: a sour kicked up with the addition of seltzer or soda water. Like any of the classics, the Gin Daisy is divided into two distinct genres: the Old School and the New School. This one—the Old School—relies on orange liqueur for its citrusy backbone, while theNew Schoolknocks down the gin ratio and substitutesgrenadinefor a fruitier flavor.
instructions: 1. Add gin, lemon juice and orange liqueur to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass, and top with soda.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Dama’s Pan American Clipper
intro_philosophy: Pablo Moix favors a relatively youngCalvadosfor this drink (“not too woody, not too aged”), and a dash of absinthe, although “you could use a dash of pastis to be a little different,” he suggests. Taken all together, he describes this as a “good, bright drink” that pairs well with food.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with lime wedge.

title: Pillow Manhattan
intro_philosophy: This drink can be done one of two ways, either by aging for one month to two yearsin glass or, if you’re short on time, for two hours in a 100-degree Fahrenheit water bath. The water bath helps to “soften” the Manhattan and produce an effect similar to the initial marrying you’ll get from aging. If you’re feeling really adventurous you couldline the inside of your bottle with beeswaxto add another layer of complexity.
ingredients: 5 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients together in a jug.
2. If using the water bath method, seal the liquid into bags and cook in a sous vide machine set at 100 Fahrenheit for 2 hours. Cool, then store the drink in the refrigerator.

3. If aging the cocktail in bottle, add all ingredients to a large glass bottle and leave it to age for at least one month, or up to two years before transferring to the refrigerator.  To serve, pour straight into chilled cocktail glasses and garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Gin Fizz Tropical
intro_philosophy:
This drink comes from Charles H. Baker’s 1939The Gentleman’s Companion, which traces its roots back to Manila, circa 1920. The drink originally called for pineapple juice, which we’ve replaced with Small Hand Foods’ pineapple gum syrup, which is a mixture of pineapple juice and sugar thickened with gum arabic. We’ve also replaced the heavy cream with orgeat. The key to making a good fizz is to use three or four large ice cubes in your shaker and shake the drink longer than you might think necessary. Fifteen seconds is about right.

Reprinted with permission fromThe Slanted Doorby Charles Phan © 2014. Published by Ten Speed Press. Photography © 2014 by Ed Anderson.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce orgeat, such as Small Hand Foods
1/2 ounce pineapple gum syrup, such as Small Hand Foods
instructions: 1. Add gin, lime juice, orgeat, pineapple gum syrup and egg white to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double strain into a fizz glass or a small rocks glass.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Garnish with lime wheel and mint.

title: The Black Stallion Sets Sail
intro_philosophy: Consider this a neo-tiki Negroni, with blackstrap rum andFerrari(Fernet mixed with Campari) taking the place of traditional gin and Campari. Part of the Autostrada menu at Fox Liquor Bar, this drink was inspired byGiuseppe Gonzalez‘s revamp of theJungle Bird. The blackstrap rum gives it a rich, molasses-y spice, while the Ferrari offers herbal bitterness.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, combine the saline, Cocchi, Ferrari and rum. Add one large cube of ice and stir until very cold.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over large cube of ice. Garnish with orange twist and serve.

title: The Detroiter
intro_philosophy: Jacob Grier, author ofCocktails on Tap, loves this drink from 320 Main in Seal Beach, CA, for its use of the bitter-on-bitter formula in which IPA is paired with Cynar amaro. The wallop of this combination is rounded out by sweet honey syrup and apple brandy, resulting in an autumn-perfect beer cocktail.
instructions: 1. Combine the Cynar, brandy, lemon juice, simple syrup, and 1 ounce of the IPA in a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake first without ice to combine. Then add ice and shake again until cold.
3. Strain the drink into an ice-filled rocks glass.
4. Top with the remaining IPA and garnish with a grapefruit peel.

title: Keep Your Dreams A Burnin’
intro_philosophy: Simply sherry, sugar and citrus, shaken, poured over crushed ice and slurped through a straw, the originalSherry Cobbleris thought to have originated sometime in the 1820s or early 1830s. But, like most 19th century drinks, its origins are foggy. In this variation, New Orleans bartender Kirk Estopinal adds funk-heavy Smith & Cross rum, bitters and almond syrup to a base of bone-dry manzanilla. A lavish ensemble of citrus, sugar and cinnamon are in keeping with the typical tiki garnish regime.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients (including lemon peels) to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over crushed ice into a rocks glass (or a julep cup if you're fancy enough to own one).
4. Garnish with three half lemon wheels and a cinnamon stick.
5. Dust with powdered sugar and add two long straws.

title: Brainstorm
intro_philosophy: Al Sotack’s spec for the pre-Prohibition Irish whiskey cocktail gives plenty of space for the modifiers—dry vermouth and Bénédictine—to play off the base. It features an unusual structure in which the measure of vermouth is reduced and the liqueur gets equal billing, making the drink less like its more famous Scotch cousin, the Bobby Burns, and more like a modified Old-Fashioned.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice, and stir to chill.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Express a lemon twist over the drink, then discard the peel.

title: White Negroni Sour
intro_philosophy: In this fluffy take onthe modern classic, Orlando Franklin McCray swaps the traditional Lillet Blanc for quinquina, which adds spice, depth and a subtle bitterness. Lemon juice and a vegan foaming agent (in lieu of egg white) bring the drink firmly into sour territory.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanc quinquina, preferably Mattei Cap Corse Blanc
1 1/4 ounces gin, preferably Cadenhead’s Old Raj 55% ABV
1/2 ounce cane sugar syrup (1:1, cane sugar to hot water)
7 drops Ms. Better’s Bitters Miraculous Foamer
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with four or five ice cubes.
2. Shake for 30 seconds, then strain into a chilled rocks glass with ice.

title: Oaxaca Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy:
This is the drink that opened the American mixology world’s eyes to the potential of using tequila and mezcal in cocktails. According to Angus Winchester, British bartenders were making Old-Fashioneds with tequila much earlier. But if they were, the drinks were thrown down the gullet unnamed and unsung, and they likely didn’t contain mezcal. Ward called it his eureka moment when he figured out, regarding mezcal, “this shit works.” It has inspired countless imitations, with different names, but essentially the same recipe.

Reprinted with permission fromAProper Drinkby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Del Maguey San Luis Del Rio mezcal
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the orange twist in an Old-Fashioned glass filled with one large ice cube.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Top with a flamed orange twist, then drop the twist into the drink.

title: The Gift of Strawberries
intro_philosophy: Named for a chapter in the bookBraiding Sweetgrass,by Robin Wall Kimmerer, this milk punch celebrates strawberry, a plant that is sometimes known as the “heart berry” in Indigenous communities. “Having that rooted connection to the strawberry, I wanted to create a cocktail that shares my Indigenous identity as well as brings up a lot of nostalgia—a strawberry cream soda,” saysTrue Laurelprep lead and bartenderTone Arasa. Strawberry-infused tequila is complemented by strawberry syrup, bergamot liqueur and lime juice, all clarified using the milk punch technique.
ingredients: 375 milliliters blanc vermouth, such as Dolin
250 milliliters rich strawberry syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the milk in a large container.
2. Gently pour the milk into the cocktail batch, allowing it to curdle.
3. Pour the curdled batch over a fine-mesh strainer lined with a nut-milk bag.
4. Continue to pass the filtered batch back over the lined strainer until it runs clear.
5. Dispose of the curds when completely dry, once all of the liquid has strained out.
6. When ready to serve, pour 3 ounces into a cocktail shaker with 3 cubes of ice. Shake hard and double-strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
7. To garnish, place a card over two-thirds of the finished cocktail and top with strawberry dust.

title: Diced Pineapples
intro_philosophy:
This story is published in partnership with Diageo Reserve World Class, which supports hundreds of thousands of bartenders through its training and advocacy program. For this World Cocktail Day, on May 13th, World Class surveyed top bartenders around the globe—including World Class Bartender of the Year, Kaitlyn Stewart—on the most popular cocktails being ordered in their bars today; to see the results,click here.

This drink from Kaitlyn Stewart was inspired by sustainability and synergy between bar and kitchen. “We work closely with the kitchen, so if I’m taking mint and only need the leaves, I can give them back the stems and they can use it in a stock. If they’re juicing something and have leftover pulp, I can use that in syrups,” she says.

In this cocktail, pineapple kasu meets pineapple gomme, bitters and rejuiced lime husks, for a refreshing tropical drink served in a recycled pineapple can.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces gin, preferably Tanqueray No. Ten
1/2 ounce sake, preferably Junmai Nama Nigori
dash bitters, preferably Lem-Marrakech Bittered Sling bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake.
2. Fine strain into chilled recycled pineapple juice can over ice.
3. Garnish with black lime, dehydrated pineapple and pineapple leaves.

title: Föhr Manhattan
intro_philosophy: The light, sweetFöhr Manhattanwas introduced to the tiny German island of Föhr at the wedding of two Frisian Americans in the 1960s. At home, the cocktail isalwayspre-batched—locals consider it almost rude not to have a bottle in the fridge for guests who might pop by, served in “Oma’s liqueur glasses,” per Föhr bartender Arne Lübcke. Even he keeps backup bottles at Hotelbar Hygge in case he can’t keep up with demand, though he typically makes a single serving to order, stirred over ice, simple enough for anyone who’s not ready to commit to a 3-liter batch.
ingredients: 250 milliliters whiskey, such as Canadian Club, Jim Beam, or Jack Daniels
250 milliliters sweet vermouth, such as Martini Rosso
250 milliliters blanc vermouth, such as Martini Bianco
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing bowl and stir.
2. Using a funnel, pour the drink into a bottle and chill in the fridge until ready to serve.
3. To serve, pour 2 ounces into a small, stemmed liqueur glass.
4. Garnish with a cocktail cherry.

title: Sige Na
intro_philosophy: The name of this drink loosely translates to “go ahead,” whichNapier Bulanannotes can be read as either an invitation or a warning, depending on how it’s delivered. The drink itself is a simple, spirit-forward construction built around a base of aged Filipino rum, modified with pandan syrup and walnut bitters. “If you enjoy Old-Fashioneds, this is definitely up your alley,” says Bulanan.
ingredients: 2 ounces aged Filipino rum, preferably Don Papa 10 Year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lime twist.

title: Fort Nite
intro_philosophy: An equal-parts combination of rye, Jamaican rum, madeira andrancio sec, Fort Nite re-casts the Old-Fashioned at a lower octane without losing the integrity of the original—something that bartender Julia McKinley does particularly well. “I wanted to do something that obviously incorporated lower ABV ingredients, but still had enough of a punch.” Rye provides the traditional Old-Fashioned backbone, while Madeira and rancio sec add both sweet and dry complexity. “And of course rum,” says McKinley, “because I love rum.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce malmsey Madeira, preferably Blandy's 5 Year
1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton Reserve
1 barspoon Petite Canne Sugar Cane Syrup
instructions: 1. Express the lemon peel into a mixing glass and discard.
2. Add remaining ingredients and ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large cube of ice.

title: Stephen Palahach’s Caipirinha
intro_philosophy: For bartender Stephen Palahach, “It’s best not to overthink the preparation, as the Caipirinha is truly a drink anyone can make.” He suggests using an unaged cachaça for a traditional take on the drink, or a barrel-aged expression from Novo Fogo, Yaguara or Avuá for something a little richer.
ingredients: 2 ounces artisanal cachaça, preferably Novo Fogo, Yaguara or Avuá
instructions: 1. Slice the lime in half from end to end, cutting out the white, pithy core from each segment.
2. Slice the lime into quarters.
3. Gently muddle the wedges with the sugar in a rocks glass until sugar begins to dissolve.
4. Add the cachaça and 3 to 4 ice cubes.
5. Pour the contents into a cocktail shaker and shake until chilled, then pour the contents back into the rocks glass, or stir in the rocks glass until frosty. (see Editor's Note)

title: Second Serve
intro_philosophy: As a lower-alcohol, softer-hitting drink, Dan Greenbaum’s combination of Amaro Montenegro and fino sherry is a friendly Spain vs. Italy matchup.
ingredients: 1 ounce fino sherry, such as Valdespino Inocente
3/4 ounce simple syrup  (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except soda water to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake and strain into an ice-filled Collins glass.
3. Top with soda and garnish with a half orange wheel.

title: Blood Orange Cosmo
intro_philosophy: When it’s winter citrus season,a Blood Orange Cosmo is never a bad idea.Julie Reiner’s recipe combines orange-flavored vodka, Cointreau, and lime and blood orange juices with just a splash of cranberry.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces orange-flavored vodka, preferably Stoli Ohranj
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange slice.

title: June Bug
intro_philosophy: Bartender Clay Taylor’s June Bug takes inspiration from the insect’s role as a harbinger of summer—appearing right around Juneteenth. The drink, a combination of smoky mezcal, Byrrh, tart cherry and tarragon shrub and walnut bitters, “reminds me of summer cookouts during my time in the South with friends and family,” says Taylor.
ingredients: 2 ounces cherry tarragon shrub (see Editor's Note)
3 dashes Fee Brothers Black Walnut Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and shake with several large ice cubes.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass rimmed with pink peppercorn salt over crushed ice.

title: Leche de Pantera
intro_philosophy: At Barcelona bar Can Pumuki, owner Sergi Ramos (who goes by Pumuki) makes his version ofLeche de Pantera(Spanish for “Panther’s Milk”)—an oddball Spanish cocktail consisting of gin and condensed milk—with the unorthodox addition of whiskey. The bar also offers the Leche de Pantera Rosa, or Pink Panther’s Milk, a common twist on the drink with a splash of red currant syrup (his pink version also swaps out whiskey for Cognac), and a Leche de Pantera Verde (or Green Panther’s Milk), a house specialty made with crème de menthe.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the water in an ice-filled rocks or highball glass.
2. Stir vigorously until everything is well-mixed, then top with the water and stir some more.
3. Garnish with a dusting of cinnamon.

title: Sugar Monk’s Hanky Panky
intro_philosophy: Malty genever gives backbone and grainy flavor to this version of the classic Hanky Panky atHarlem’s Sugar Monk, while chile-infused bitters add a lingering hint of heat. “The orange bitters have big personality,” but won’t overwhelm the other flavors, says the bar’s beverage director, Ektoras Binikos, who sells bottles of the spiced orange bitters at the bar. Here, he shares an easy DIY version to make at home.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces unaged genever, preferably Old Duff Blended Dutch
1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula
3 dashes chile-infused orange bitters (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass.
3. Twist the orange peel over the top of the drink to express the essential oils from the peel, then use the peel to garnish the drink.

title: Oh Kale No
intro_philosophy: Think tequila-spiked green juice for this cocktail from Detroit transplant,Dorothy Elizabeth, which, as the name suggests, calls on kale-infused tequila for the base.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

title: Bananavardier
intro_philosophy: In a bit of shift drinks kismet, the Banana Boulevardier was born when Anvil GM Terry Williams attempted to kill the tail-end of a bottle of banana liqueur left over from a previous menu. After casually pouring it 50/50 with Campari, Williams was struck by how well the two complemented each other, and he decided to follow that hunch towards the classic cousin of the Negroni. Though this version reads a shade sweeter than the original, the banana lends a new richness and just a little funk, adding an air of intrigue to an old friend.
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients over ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass or rocks glass with one rock.
3. Garnish with a strip of orange zest.

title: American Trilogy
intro_philosophy: This Old-Fashioned riff nods to the spirits used in theDiamondback, a 20th century classic made with rye, applejack and yellow Chartreuse. Created at New York bar Little Branch by Richard Boccato and Michael McIlroy, the drink is emblematic of the popularity of Laird’s Bonded Apple Brandy, which was newly available in the city in the aughts.
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, add sugar cube and saturate with orange bitters.
2. Gently muddle to make a granulated paste.
3. Add whiskey and ice (preferably an oversized cube).
4. Garnish with a long, curly orange peel.

title: Tequila Grapefruit Mule
intro_philosophy: In his take on the mule, Aaron Polsky doubles down on grapefruit with the addition ofPamplemousseand grapefruit bitters, all balanced with a a measure of Aperol and ginger syrup.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce grapefruit liqueur, preferably Giffard Pamplemousse Liqueur
1 dash grapefruit bitters, preferably Bittermens Hopped Grapefruit Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water and garnish with a grapefruit peel.

title: Frozen Porn Star Martini
intro_philosophy: At Here and Now in Los Angeles, the Porn Star Martini comes refreshingly frozen. At the bar, the drink is batched in a frozen drink machine, but this home bar-friendly recipe makes a single serving in a blender.
ingredients: 2 ounces passion fruit syrup, frozen into cubes (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender, and process until smooth.

title: Toasted Rice Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Starchy Carolina Gold rice gets infused into both spirit and sweetener in this toasted take on the Daiquiri from Kingfisher in Durham, North Carolina. Not only do the grains impart a nutty flavor to the drink, but they also help the cocktail “hold incredible froth,” according to Kingfisher’s Sean Umstead.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake very hard with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: Mexican Firing Squad
intro_philosophy: The Mexican Firing Squad is one of the many cocktails documented by world traveler, cocktail writer and historian Charles H. Baker. The drink is recorded in hisGentleman’s Companion, Volume II: Jigger, Beaker and Flask, as having been discovered at the La Cucaracha Bar in Mexico City in 1937. A dry formula, the Firing Squad is almost arickeywith the addition ofgrenadineto sweeten only slightly. Some modern versions include the addition of soda to create a longer, cooling drink.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Anton Kinloch’s Pineapple Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: One of the winning recipes from our blind Pineapple Daiquiri tasting, Anton Kinloch’s take splits the base between unaged cachaça and Plantation’s Fancy Smoky Formula bottling of the pineapple rum. Fresh pineapple flavor is added via pineapple cubes thrown directly into the shaking tin. The finished drink has the requisite zip of acidity balanced by the right amount of sweetness. The ingredients come together in a way that recalls savory apple cider, leading one taster to describe it as “the perfect fall Daiquiri.”
ingredients: 1 ounce cachaça, preferably Novo Fogo Silver
1 ounce Plantation Stiggins’ Fancy Smoky Formula Pineapple Rum
1/2 ounce rich Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar to water)
5  pieces (approximately 1 inch x 1 inch) fresh pineapple
instructions: 1. Add the lime juice and pineapple chunks to a cocktail shaker and muddle briefly.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and ice, then shake until chilled.
3. Double strain into a Nick & Nora glass.

title: Coconut Julep
intro_philosophy: The product of a collaboration between Jelani Johnson andClover Clubhead bartender, Tom Macy, the Coconut Julep was conceived of as a sequel to the bar’s ever-popular Pineapple Julep. “We wanted to do coconut, but we couldn’t get it to taste coconut-y enough,” recalls Johnson. Ultimately, the pair called on both toasted coconut-infusedMellow Cornwhiskey as the base anda liquid sweetener dubbed“coconut sugar,” a blend of coconut liqueur and orgeat. This modern update is finished with a float of Smith & Cross Jamaican rum for a complex, tropical take on the cobbled classic.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces toasted coconut-infused Mellow Corn whiskey (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce Smith & Cross Jamaican rum, to float
instructions: 1. In a julep tin, gently muddle the mint sprig with the coconut sugar.
