2. Cap and chill the bottle to 22°F.  (Alternatively, store in a freezer for about five hours; remove before ice crystals form.)
3. To serve, pour about 4 ounces into a Nick and Nora glass.
4. Twist lemon peel to express lemon oil over the surface of the drink, then discard the peel.

title: Diamonds Are Forever
intro_philosophy: Based on aVesperand named for one of the few James Bond films in which he actually orders it, this restrained drink marries the berry-fruit of Aperol to cherry eau-de-vie from Portland, Oregon’s Clear Creek. “Everything else is about dynamic duos dancing,” explains Fu, “the salinity of Lustau Fino La Jarana and citrus peel ofblanc vermouth, a touch of Grey Goose vodka and gin for crispness.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce cream sherry, preferably Alvear Pale Cream
1/2 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi
1/4 ounce cherry brandy, preferably Clear Creek Kirschwasser
2 dashes "Feegans" bitters (1:1, Regans' orange bitters: Fee Brothers orange bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Ume Paloma
intro_philosophy: At Bar Goto, the house Paloma gets a Japanese twist thanks to umeshu, a liqueur sometimes known as plum wine, which adds a layer of sweet-tart flavor to the classic.
ingredients: 1 ounce blanco tequila, such as Olmeca Altos Plata
3/4 ounce umeshu, such as Choya Excellent
instructions: 1. If using, rim a highball glass with sea salt.
2. Fill the glass with ice cubes.
3. Add the club soda first, then the other ingredients.
4. Stir gently to blend.

title: Ibizan Cosmo
intro_philosophy: The herb-laden, anise-flavored liqueur has many possibilities as a cocktail mixer. This local version of the Cosmo comes from Ibiza’s largest producer of hierbas, Familia Marí Mayans.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with plenty of ice.
2. Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Coastal Grooves
intro_philosophy: “Citrus is available all year round, but there’s better citrus available in the winter,” notes Dan Greenbaum. While he spotlights blood oranges and navel oranges in this winter citrus cobbler, he encourages experimentation with whatever varieties are available at the moment. “Mandarins, Clementines, Cara Cara oranges—I’d play around with that,” he says.
ingredients: 1  blood orange wheel, cut in half
instructions: 1. Add the fruit and falernum to a mixing tin and muddle.
2. Add the wine and swirl briefly.
3. Dump the contents of the tin into a chilled Collins glass.
4. Fill the glass 3/4 full with pebble or crushed ice and mix briefly with a spoon or metal straw to integrate.
5. Garnish lavishly.

title: Cienfuegos’ El Presidente
intro_philosophy: Jane Danger, of NYC’s Cienfuegos and Mother of Pearl, is a big fan of bianco vermouth: “It has more sugar than dry vermouth, and it’s very vanilla forward, which helps round out and lengthen drinks.” Her variation on Cuba’s classic cocktail, El Presidente, swaps bianco in for dry to make it more full, resulting in a refreshing, rounded cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Dolin Blanc
3/4 ounce white rum, preferably La Favorite Rhum Blanc
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Twist lemon rind over top and drop into drink.

title: Harborside Orange Crush
intro_philosophy: Harborside Bar & Grill in West Ocean City, Maryland, invented the Orange Crush in 1995. It remains a signature, despite it being mimicked by bars up and down the East Coast. “Everybody says that they just taste better here,” says bartender Phil Lewis.
ingredients: 2 ounces triple sec, preferably La Quinta
lemon-lime soda, to top, preferably Sierra Mist
instructions: 1. Combine vodka and triple sec in a pint glass with ice.
2. Fresh-squeezed orange juice directly into glass.
3. Top with a splash of lemon-lime soda and drink immediately.

title: Saratoga
intro_philosophy: The Saratoga at L’Oursin brings together the pineapple and maraschino liqueur from Frank Meier’s original 1930s spec,but instead of a sparkling wine topper, it gets bone-dry cider from Normandy and is built over pebble ice. Zac Overman says the cider lends weight, rusticity and chewiness that a sparkling wine would not. Rounding out the Cobbler-like aesthetic are a mint sprig and an orange slice.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces pineapple-infused Cognac, preferably Dudognon Reserve (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce maraschino liqueur, preferably Leopold Brothers
instructions: 1. Fill a 10 to 12 ounce glass with pebble ice.
2. Add the Cognac, maraschino liqueur and orange bitters and top with more ice.
3. Top with cider and briefly stir to combine.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig and an orange slice.

title: Blinker
intro_philosophy:
This drink, first printed in 1934, looks crazy on paper but is surprisingly potent and refreshing drink. Modern renditions have tried to twist it into the shape of a traditional sour, but its true identity is as a sort of proto-Greyhound highball. Be sure to use a decent, potent rye, the more powerful the better, and a homemade grenadine.

Reprinted with permission from3-Ingredient Cocktails: An Opinionated Guide to the Most Enduring Drinks in the Cocktail Canonby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2017. Published Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the grapefruit twist in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled, about 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Twist a piece of grapefruit zest over the drink and drop into the glass.

title: Byrrh de Garde
intro_philosophy:
Whiskey cocktails are easily the most popular drinks category at Nashville’sPinewood Social,The Patterson Houseand the newly openedLe Sel, says beverage director Matt Tocco. “Whiskey is a huge part of the institutional memory and heritage of the south,” he explains, “but in the summertime our guests seem to want something more refreshing.”

In this shaken whiskey cocktail, Tocco blends bourbon with fruity and bitterByrrh, lemon juice and grenadine, before topping it all with a splash of soda water, for a drink that sits somewhere in between a Whiskey Sour, a Blinker and a Byrrh Cassis.
ingredients: 1 ounce bourbon, preferably Old Forester Signature
instructions: 1. Add the bourbon, Byrrh, grenadine and lemon juice to a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass and top with soda water.

title: Horchata
intro_philosophy: For Maycoll Calderón, executive chef ofCuna, this cocktail is a memory in a glass. “Horchata is something I grew up with,” he says. “I wanted to take that familiar flavor and reinterpret it for New York, blending tradition with a contemporary twist. By pairing the creamy, spiced notes of horchata with mezcal, we created a cocktail that feels both rooted and unexpected.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, such as Rosaluna Mezcal
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake well.
2. Fine strain into a chilled glass. Garnish with a dusting of cocoa powder.

title: Walk This Way
intro_philosophy: Essentially a tropical sherry sour, this drink—from the team behind Miami Beach’s alt-hostel oasis—mixes together rich cream sherry with tart passion fruit puree and hibiscus syrup for a veritable flower bed of a cocktail.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with mint sprig and a flower.

title: Garibaldi Spritz
intro_philosophy: The Garibaldi is traditionally just equal parts Campari and fresh orange juice. But this version, from PUNCH’s Editor-in-Chief, Talia Baiocchi, dials back the Campari (in a nod to Naren Young’s excellent version atDantein New York) and tops all with prosecco, turning the classic into a spritz.
instructions: 1. To an ice-filled Collins glass, add the Campari and orange juice and stir to combine.
2. Top with prosecco and garnish.

title: St. John Frizell’s Sazerac
intro_philosophy: Tying for first place inour blind Sazerac tasting in 2018, St. John Frizell’s straight-shooting recipe calls on a base of Old Overholt rye, complemented with both Peychaud’s and Angostura bitters and a touch of simple syrup. For the absinthe rinse, Frizell uses an atomizer to enhance the ingredient’s aromatics.
instructions: 1. Using an atomizer, mist a frozen Old-Fashioned glass 4 times with absinthe.
2. Combine the remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.
4. Garnish with an expressed lemon peel.

title: Apple Juice Arnold Palmer
intro_philosophy: In the growing world of nonalcoholic drinks, the Arnold Palmer has been here all along. Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s simple upgrade to the classic steeps the tea in apple juice, rather than water, for an extra flavorful take.
ingredients: 3 ounces rich simple syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Heat the apple juice over low heat on a stovetop or in a microwave until it’s around 150℉ (65℃).
2. Steep the tea bags in the hot apple juice for 5 minutes, then remove. Cover, and let cool.
3. Add the lemon juice and simple syrup to the apple juice.
4. Pour over ice into glasses, and serve with a lemon wedge.

title: Thou Shall Not Be Named
intro_philosophy: Working from the framework of a Boulevardier,Alicia Perrygives the drink an agave spin. Reposado tequila and mezcal stand in for the typical whiskey base, while Amaro Sfumato Rabarbaro stands in for Campari, which pulls out the bitter orange flavors from the Torino vermouth. Perry describes it simply as “stirred and direct.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces reposado tequila, preferably El Tesoro
1/2 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Million Dollar Cocktail
intro_philosophy: With a history in Japan dating to the 1910s or earlier, theMillion Dollar Cocktailhas a Singapore Sling-adjacent flavor profile, while also being an egg white sour. At Teruko in the Hotel Chelsea, bar director Brian Evans has updated the drink with a combination of Japanese and Italian gins, Cocchi Americano, acid-adjusted pineapple, yuzu, and the expected grenadine. The result is a take on the original that delivers all its tropical flavors with hints of umami, sansho pepper, and floral notes.
ingredients: 1 ounce Japanese gin, such as Nikka Coffey Gin
1/2 ounce tomato gin, such as Moletto
1 ounce acid-adjusted pineapple juice (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce yuzu juice, such as Yuzuco
instructions: 1. Combine all in a shaker tin and emulsify for 8 seconds using a frothing wand, or dry shake.
2. Add ice and shake hard for 12 seconds.
3. Double strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Pequeño Boxing Club
intro_philosophy: In this Ti’ Punch variation, Vince Bright swaps the expected rhum agricole for the similarly grassy blanco tequila. “I wanted to go completely into vegetation land and actually infuse roasted poblanos into blanco tequila,” he says of his base spirit of choice, which he complements with a touch of smokiness from half an ounce of mezcal. To bring out the spice while adding a touch of sweetness, he calls on pink peppercorn syrup, which adds a subtle floral hint. “The pink peppercorn enhances the poblano, which is contrasted with the smoke of the mezcal… The layers all circulate.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces poblano-infused tequila, preferably Corazon Blanco (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce pink peppercorn cane syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add cane syrup and lime coin to a glass and muddle.
2. Add ice and tequila and mezcal and give a gentle stir.
3. Garnish with Tajín.

title: Sour Cherry Negroni
intro_philosophy: London import Hawksmoor’s first New York City location opened last fall with a Sour Cherry Negroni on the menu, which has since become one of the top sellers. The riff on the classic aperitif uses acid-adjusted sour cherry juice and rosé vermouth to put a contemporary spin on the familiar template. “Our approach is simplicity and flavor without inundating guests with obscure ingredients or long-winded descriptions,” says Ciarrai Kelly, Hawksmoor’s head bartender.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Rubino
1/2 ounce Crème de Noyaux, preferably Tempus Fugit
1 teaspoon acid adjusted cherry juice (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Kirk Estopinal’s Rum Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Made with a split base of Guyanese and Jamaican rums plus a barspoon of apricot liqueur, the Rum Old-Fashioned served at Cane & Table fits right in with the vibe of the New Orleans bar, which leans tropical.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Guyanese rum, such as Hamilton 86 Demerara
1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, such as Hamilton Jamaican Pot Still Gold
1 barspoon rich Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar:water)
1 barspoon apricot liqueur, such as Giffard
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir for 30 revolutions.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a quarter-sized orange coin placed atop the ice cube.
4. Dust with a touch of freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Doug Phillips’s Grasshopper
intro_philosophy: With this recipe, Doug Phillips, of Heavy Feather in Chicago, took second place in our recent Grasshopper blind tasting. He went the classic Midwestern route, using a 6-ounce scoop of vanilla ice cream, to which he added 1/2 ounce each of Marie Brizard Menthe Verte, Tempus Fugit white crème de menthe, Tempus Fugit crème de cacao and Cognac. These were blended together until smooth, and topped with whipped cream. “Well, it’s just delicious,” stated Sarah Morrissey, seeing no need to embellish her appraisal further. (That particular drink did not last long among the judges.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce green crème de menthe, preferably Marie Brizard
1/2 ounce white crème de menthe, preferably Tempus Fugit
1/2 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Blend all ingredients until smooth.
2. Pour into glass of your choice.
3. Top with whipped cream.

title: Ringo Soda
intro_philosophy: “Mizu [a brand of Japanese shochu] has a full flavor that can work in most contexts that a clear spirit would, while not excusing itself by tasting neutral,” explains McCray of the choice to build a modern highball on a shochu base. In place of soda water, he calls on fresh-pressed apple juice, force-carbonated for perceived acidity: “Apple juice isn’t acidic enough on its own but the sensation of acidity can be achieved through bubbles with little added dilution,” he explains. “This is a long way of saying that spirit and juice can be as enjoyable as it is simple—don’t think too much about it.”
ingredients: 3 ounces fresh-pressed Granny Smith apple juice
instructions: 1. Pour the shochu into an ice-filled highball glass.
2. Top the drink with fresh-pressed apple juice, put through an iSi siphon.

title: Into the Wild
intro_philosophy: AtKing Pigeonin Cincinnati, menus change with the seasons, and seasons dictate the backstory of each elaborate drink. Currently, this is the bestselling cocktail. Owner Nick Kallenberg attributes that popularity to mushrooms: “The candy cap mushroom is an amazing ingredient that tastes like maple syrup (and mushroom) that adds this lovely savory note,” he says. The garnish, a small beech mushroom nestled in the glass, “is also downright adorable.”
ingredients: 2 ounces crémant, such as Victorine de Chastenay Crémant de Bourgogne
1 1/2 ounces reposado tequila, preferably Siete Leguas
1/2 ounce candy cap mushroom syrup (see Editor’s Note)
2 dashes salt solution (9:1, water to salt, by weight)
instructions: 1. Pour the crémant into a universal wine glass.
2. Shake all other ingredients in a shaker with ice, then fine-strain over the wine.
3. Garnish with a nasturtium leaf and a small beech mushroom floating on top.

title: Crystal Visions
intro_philosophy: When creating this wine-based aperitif, Lauren Corriveau of New York’s Nitecap was inspired by her ideal white wine: “It’s dry, crisp, vegetal and refreshing. You could drink a bottomless glass, or be in no rush to finish it at all. And obviously, bubbles make everything better.” Alongside Salers and fennel liqueur, the addition of St-Germain brings out the inherent floral elements of the drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces dry white wine, preferably sauvignon blanc
1/4 ounce fennel liqueur, preferably Don Ciccio & Figli
2 dashes citric acid solution (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a wine glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with cucumber ribbon.

title: Zac Overman’s Picon Punch
intro_philosophy: Picon Punch is a California drink dating back to the late 19th century that was adopted by Basque American communities across the Western U.S. At Bar Bayonne, beverage director Zac Overman values the drink’s food friendliness and takes it in a spritzy direction by replacing the traditional soda with cava.
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients, except for the sparkling wine, to a rocks glass over ice.
2. Top with sparkling wine, then garnish with an orange half-wheel.

title: Seapea Fizz
intro_philosophy: It’s said that the Seapea Fizz is named for song writer and composer Cole Porter (the sound of the name mimicking Porter’s initials, C.P.). The pale green cocktail first appears in Frank Meier’sThe Artistry of Mixing Drinksfrom 1934 as a simple—yet bracing—mix of sugar, lemon and “sweetened Anis” (specified as Pernod Fils pastis) shaken and topped with soda water. Not suited to today’s modern drinker, the astringent mixture is often updated by contemporary bartenders with the addition of an egg white for body and absinthe for backbone.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
4. Strain into a fizz glass or coupe.
5. Top with soda water.

title: Matthew Belanger’s Margaladaoma
intro_philosophy: Matthew Belanger’s super-sized mashup of aMargarita,Palomaand aMichelada—also known as aMargaladaoma.
ingredients: 1 bottle Mexican lager, preferably Modelo Especial
instructions: 1. Rim largest glass you can find with salt.
2. Squeeze the lime wedge into a shaker tin and put expressed lime at the bottom.
3. Add all other ingredients and ice, shake briefly and pour the glass without straining.
4. Fill the rest of the glass with cracked ice.
5. Take a mexican lager of your choice and insert it upside down into the glass.
6. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Joerg Wuz Here
intro_philosophy: This sour is inspired by the German modern classic, theGin Basil Smash. It gets its name from that drink’s creator, Joerg Meyer, and trades the herbs out for a “pinch” of arugula leaves instead. Josh Conley, who developed the recipe forBar Limina, says the vegetable adds an accent of pepperiness to the cocktail.
ingredients: 2 ounces black tea gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Double-strain into a rocks glass over a big rock.
3. Garnish with an arugula leaf resting on the ice.

title: Allen’s Flip
intro_philosophy: The Sombrero—a mix of the beloved Allen’s Coffee Flavored Brandy and milk—is Maine’s unofficial cocktail. The Allen’s Flip is Portland bartender Andrew Volk’s attempt to gussy up the standard (which is also known by the name Fat Ass in a Glass, among many others). Using the classic flip template, Volk bumped up the ABV with brandy and brings it all together with the avant-garde (it’s all relative in Maine) addition of coffee bitters.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Double strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with coffee bitters.

title: William Elliott’s Stinger
intro_philosophy: By design, this improved Stinger (“the world’s best Stinger,” says its creator, William Elliott) is diamond-clear like a Martini. Skip the lurid green crème de menthe and opt for a white version instead. This recipe can also beprebatched and frozenahead of time.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces Cognac, preferably Gourry de Chadeville overproof
3/4 ounce créme de menthe, preferably Giffard Menthe-Pastille
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe over a large piece of ice.
3. Express a lemon peel over the surface of the drink and discard.

title: Jackson Cannon’s Hot Buttered Rum
intro_philosophy: The East Coast has its own particular POV on the HBR, which involves adding another (gratuitous, but welcome) layer of richness to the butter batter by way of local vanilla ice cream. Jackson Cannon counters some of the sweetness with a touch of cayenne pepper.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged rum, preferably Old Monk, Appleton or Plantation 5-Year
instructions: 1. In a tempered 6- to 8-ounce mug, add 1 ounce of overproof rum.
2. Add batter, then top with hot water and stir to incorporate.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg or a cinnamon stick.

title: Montgomery Smith
intro_philosophy: Created by Nate Dumas atPDT, the Montgomery Smith is a favorite drink of bartenderDamon Boeltewho cites it as a particularly great use of Bénédictine liqueur. “It’s a really smooth, well-balanced cocktail,” Boelte explains. “It’s so simple…it’s truly a modern classic.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Brunelle Frappé
intro_philosophy: At Small Victory, Laura Maddox and her team have revivedthe Brunelle, an obscure oddball fromThe Savoy Cocktail Book, consisting solely of absinthe, sugar and lemon juice. As a twist, Small Victory serves the drink as a frappé—a natural choice for the history-driven program, given the onetime popularity of theAbsinthe Frappé. Maddox praises the Brunelle for its power to introduce absinthe to guests in an approachable, low-ABV way.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce absinthe, preferably Tempus Fugit Vieux Pontarlier
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Add a handful of pebble ice and whip-shake.
3. Dump into a chilled double rocks glass, and swizzle briefly.
4. Top with more pebble ice and garnish with a lemon wedge.

title: Sesame Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: This recipe feels like your standard daiquiri, only richer, a bit fattier, and with a slightly nutty aftertaste. It calls for sesame seed syrup, sometimes marketed as sirope de ajonjoli,which you can find in Puerto Rican markets, but we’ve included a housemade recipe that pumps up the nuttiness.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sesame seed syrup (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients well with ice.
2. Strain into a pre-chilled coupe.

title: Cabezaso
intro_philosophy: Ivy Mix’s advice when deploying mole bitters in stirred drinks is simple: “Use with caution.” Here, Mix uses a small amount of mole bitters in combination with habanero shrub to draw out the subtle undertones of the often-overpowering flavors of Irish whiskey and mezcal.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
3/4 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi
5 dashes Old Man bitters(1:1, Bittermens Hellfire Habanero Shrub to Bittermens Xocolatl Mole Bitters)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: David Wondrich’s Tom & Jerry
intro_philosophy: “It’s really not good for you,” saysDavid Wondrichof the excessively rich 19th-century drink known as the Tom & Jerry. “But it’s just so freaking delicious.” This recipe makes a lot of Tom & Jerries—at least 50, although you might need more milk to get there. Wondrich notes that any leftovers can easily be turned into eggnog by mixing two parts batter with two parts milk and one or two parts booze, plus grated nutmeg, then bottle and refrigerate.
ingredients: 1 bottle rich Jamaican rum, preferably Plantation Xaymaca
instructions: 1. Prepare the spice mix by combining the cinnamon, allspice and cloves.
2. Separate the eggs.
3. Put the whites into a non-reactive (stainless steel, ceramic, plastic or glass) bowl and beat them into stiff peaks. You can do this by hand but an electric egg-beater really is your friend here.

4. In your Tom & Jerry Bowl (or, of course, other ceramic bowl), beat the yolks, gradually incorporating 2 ounces of the rum and the spice mix (this one is best to do by hand). When they are completely liquid, gradually add the sugar (it seems like a lot; trust us, it’s needed), stirring until the mixture attains the consistency of a light batter.

5. Carefully fold the whites into the yolks until thoroughly incorporated. To prevent separation, add the cream of tartar. Keep this batter refrigerated until needed. It will probably need a quick whip before use.
6. Bring the milk to a low simmer.

7. Put a heaping tablespoon (20 ml) of the batter in a small mug or tumbler and stir in around half an ounce each of the cognac and the rum (these can be pre-mixed for speed). You don’t have to measure precisely, but if you add too much more than you’ll lose the ideal velvety texture that makes Tom & Jerry so irresistible.
8. Add two ounces or so hot milk and stir until you get foam.
9. Garnish with fresh nutmeg.

title: Scorpion Bowl
intro_philosophy: The Scorpion, like many tiki cocktails, has gone through countless iterations, from a gin and wine-laced libation to this contemporary version of Trader Vic’s 1946 recipe (even he prescribes several riffs in his own books). It’s difficult to know where the original recipe ends and the contemporary begins, especially when so much rum is involved. But it is thought that, while in Hawaii, Vic first tried the punch from which the Scorpion was modeled, which mostly likely contained okolehao, an indigenous spirit distilled from the Polynesian ti plant.Orgeatis a constant ingredient in most interpretations and is key to the balance of dark rum and fruit.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender with 1 cup of crushed ice.
2. Blend quickly and pour into a Scorpion bowl, or portion out into individual tiki mugs.
3. Add several large ice cubes to bowl or mugs.
4. To garnish, add freshly grated cinnamon, cinnamons sticks, a grapefruit peel or orchids.

5. For a flaming lime shell, invert half of a lime and place in the volcano of a Scorpion bowl, or atop an individual cocktail. Pour in a splash of overproof rum, and carefully light with a match or a lighter.
6. Be sure to extinguish flaming lime shell before attempting a sip. Serve with straws.

title: Campari Pineapple
intro_philosophy: The combination of Campari and pineapple checks off all the boxes in this easy-drinking summer cocktail: fruity, low-proof, and assembled in a matter of seconds. (And a splash of rum certainly wouldn’t hurt, either.)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a highball glass.
2. Stir to integrate.

title: Trick Dog Aperitif
intro_philosophy: The Trick Dog Aperitif may not have had the breakout success of some of the drinks on the bar’s themed menus, but it’s become an industry favorite. A loose, low-proof riff on the Negroni, the Trick Dog Aperitif has been on every menu. It shows how the team creates drinks that are restrained showcases for balance as well as those that are wildly conceptual.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir, then strain into a rocks glass with ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Blended Aperol Spritz
intro_philosophy:
Beverage manager Adam Bernbach loves both developing and drinking frozen cocktails, but often finds that the format results in faded flavor characteristics. Referencing his quest to slushify the timeless Aperol Spritz, he says, “I was trying to figure out a way to mimic the sharpness that comes from a sparkling wine, which gets lost when you freeze a cocktail.” The solution: adding orange zest and a pinch of salt–ingredients that mimic the “pins and needles” acid that makes the staple Italian cocktail so appetizing. “It’s making a drink that’s already vacation-y even more lighthearted, informal, and, in a way, goofy,” says Bernbach.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktails: Low-Alcohol Drinks for Any Occasionby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a blender and process until smooth.
2. Pour into a highball glass then garnish with an orange half wheel.

title: Full Sun
intro_philosophy: “It can be used in drops and dashes and even larger amounts like three quarters of an ounce” explains Kirk Estopinal of the go-to tiki ingredient, allspice dram. “The result can be everything from aromatic to bizarrely tactile and drying,” he adds. Here, Estopinal lands somewhere in the middle, using half an ounce to bring baked spice notes to the quasi-tropical mixture ofvodka, coconut milk and lime juice.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a hollowed out coconut or a double rocks glass over cracked or pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.

title: House on Fire
intro_philosophy: Julia McKinley’s alternative take on a Moscow Mule is a study in contrasting flavors, with the floral combination of yellow Chartreuse and Old Tom gin shaking it up with the and aromatic Applewood notes of the Fever-Tree Smoky Ginger Ale.
ingredients: 1 ounce Old Tom gin, preferably Ransom
half a lime, juice and hull
Fever-Tree Smoky Ginger Ale, to top
instructions: 1. Add the juice of half a lime and its hull into a chilled Collins glass.
2. Combine remaining ingredients except ginger ale over ice. Add the remaining ingredients except the ginger ale. Add ice and stir a few times.
3. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Smoky Ginger Ale.

title: Amaro Caldo
intro_philosophy:
Our good friend the Brooklyn restaurateur and sommelier Joe Campanale first had this warming combination of steaming hot water and amaro with a group of boar hunters in the Tuscan town of Panzano. It’s about as easy as it gets and reinforces our view that amaro is its own bottled cocktail—just add water.

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine the hot water with your favorite amaro in a tempered glass.
2. Express a lemon twist over the top and drop it into the glass.

title: The Right Hand
intro_philosophy: Mickey McIlroy’s The Right Hand, created during his tenure at Milk & Honey, reads like a rum-based take on the Negroni. Sam Ross, another Milk & Honey alum, and co-owner alongside McIlroy of Attaboy, created the Left Hand as a complement, spotlighting bourbon in place of rum.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Long Look Back
intro_philosophy: Kacie Lambert’s take on the Manhattan leaves vermouth out of the equation. Instead, she builds on a split base of Japanese and rye whiskeys, then adds herbaceous Amaro Braulio, Demerara syrup and Angostura bitters.
ingredients: 1 ounce rye whiskey, such as Woody Creek
3/4 ounce Japanese whisky, such as Toki
1/2 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass over a big ice cube and stir to integrate.
2. Express an orange peel over the top of the drink, and garnish with the orange peel.

title: Boisson’s Nogroni
intro_philosophy: Taking second place inour blind nonalcoholic Negroni tastingwas the equal-parts combination of Amass Riverine (a pine-forward distilled nonalcoholic spirit), Wilfred’s aperitif and Lyre’s Aperitif Rosso, all of which “dry drinks shop” Boisson sells as its preferred“NOgroni” bundle. Though the judges did not find it particularly Negroni-esque, the drink still stood out for its interesting earthy, botanical profile.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass over a large ice cube and stir.
2. Garnish with an orange slice.

title: Blood Orange Reduction
intro_philosophy:
This jewel-colored winter citrus reduction is one part of theBitter Handshake, a cocktail by Andrew Bohrer from Brad Thomas Parsons’ book,Bitters.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. In a small saucepan, bring the blood orange juice to a boil over medium-high heat.
2. Boil until reduced by a third.
3. Remove from heat and let cool.

title: Gin Basil Smash
intro_philosophy: At Le Lion, where this drink was created in 2008, 300 to 500 have been sold every week since its debut—22,000 a year—and the bar goes through more than 3,100 bottles of gin every 12 months. The drink is served at bars all across Germany—so much so that one bartender, griping about the amount of basil-muddling required to make it, once called it “Meyer’s curse.”
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, such as Rutte Celery Gin
instructions: 1. Muddle basil leaves in a shaker tin.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a rocks glass filled with ice.
4. Garnish with basil leaves.

title: Outlaw
intro_philosophy: Shannon Mustipher’s Outlaw was born from a “Manhattan template based on a funky Jamaican rum” that she’s been tinkering with for over a decade. The higher-proof Cynar 70 served as the key to solving this fresh take on the bitter and stirred Manhattan variations born in the late 2000s. “It’s a new way of looking at a drink that you already know and love,” says Mustipher.
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass.
2. Add a large ice cube, and stir to chill.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Hungry Hungry Hipster
instructions: 1. Add the Zwack, orange juice, and lemon juice to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass, top with Miller High Life, and add the garnish.

title: Erik Adkins’ Last Word
intro_philosophy: Erik Adkins’ take on the Last Word was the only winning recipe in our recent blind tasting to call on the traditional equal parts formula. The judges thought it balanced, juicy and bright.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Enzo
intro_philosophy: In this extra-bitter riff on the Americano, the Campari quotient of the drink is replaced with aFerrari, the beloved 50/50 shot of the bitter liqueur and Fernet-Branca. The two liqueurs marry with the orange peel and sweet vermouth’s (specifically Carpano Antica’s) richer, sweeter notes—like bitter, grown-up bubblegum—in the best way. The drink’s name is a nod to the founder of Ferrari.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, such as Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients to a Collins or highball glass over ice.
2. Top with soda water and garnish with an orange peel or a half-slice.

title: Killer Rabbit of Caerbannog
intro_philosophy: In the Killer Rabbit of Caerbannog—named after the character fromMonty Python(“Rabbits, English, carrots, you get the deal”)—Giuseppe Gonzalez of New York’s brand-new Suffolk Arms contrasts Scotch, a quintessential winter spirit, with spring-ready vegetable juices and that staple of warm weather and lawn parties: Pimm’s. The result is boozy and earthy, yet refreshing: the cocktail equivalent of a crisp trench coat.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in shaker and shake.
2. Pour over ice into a beer mug, top with soda and garnish with strawberry, cucumber and mint.

title: Archie
intro_philosophy: AtManuela, the Archie is an earthy mix of beet-rested mezcal, oro blanco and lemon. The deeply vegetal drink aligns perfectly with Manuela’s Southern comfort menu, filled with hearty cream biscuits and mammoth pork chops, but this cocktail is also worth a trip on its own.It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake well.
2. Strain into a glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Quarantine Order
intro_philosophy:
Building off the quintessential flavor combination created by Don the Beachcomber, William Prestwood marries cinnamon and grapefruit with passion fruit, lime, Angostura bitters, and heady Jamaican rum in his Quarantine Order. “I wanted to create a drink that could highlight the cinnamon notes in Angostura bitters,” says Prestwood. “I added some lime, passion fruit, and my favorite rums for mixing,” he says, citing the blend of Appleton Estate Signature and Rum-Bar Gold, a go-to mixture his team has since dubbed “Jam Tropics.”

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 3 ounces aged Jamaican rum, preferably equal parts Appleton Estate Signature and Rum-Bar Gold
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake vigorously until the ice breaks up into smaller pieces, about 30 seconds.
2. Pour the contents of the shaker into a snifter.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig and a cherry speared through a lime wheel

title: Eeyore’s Requiem
intro_philosophy: Inspired by what he calls “the most bitter character in literature,” Toby Maloney’s Eeyore’s Requiem is a “deep, dark Negroni, turned on its head.” The drink starts with a base of bitter complexity by stacking three different amari amped up with aromatic French vermouth and juniper-rich gin.
ingredients: 1 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Dolin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Express three orange twists over the surface of the drink, discarding the first two and saving the third for garnish.

title: Autumn Cobbler
intro_philosophy: While her Cobbler go-to is usually amontillado sherry, Tseng opts for the deeper flavor of oloroso in this fall-ready twist on the recipe. From there, an easy-to-make maple-chai syrup adds subtle spice to the drink, which is crowned with seasonal fruit, nutmeg and a mint bouquet.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Julep cup.
2. Fill the cup with crushed ice.
3. Stir to integrate.
4. Top with additional crushed ice.
5. Garnish with persimmon, cherry, mint and fresh orange zest and nutmeg.

title: Earthquake
intro_philosophy: The original Earthquake recipe consisting of equal parts Cognac and absinthe is commonly credited to Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, the influential French Post-Impressionist and early advocate of American cocktail culture. Chantal Tseng tweaks the recipe to be two parts Cognac to one part absinthe, and finishes the drink with a lemon twist, which lends a crisper, drier finish.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over cracked ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Georgian punch glass.
3. Garnish with expressed lemon peel.

title: Pousse Café
intro_philosophy: When Kenneth Vanhooser was making layered dive-bar shots for college kids in Nashville, he never could have imagined that experience might lead him to revive the Pousse Café. In his take on the baroque 19th-century classic, he brings together a group of both expected and surprising elements for a singular after-dinner experience.
ingredients: scant 1/2 ounce blue Curaçao, preferably Giffard
instructions: 1. In a small decorative flute or Pousse Café glass, build the first five ingredients in order. (The ingredients will naturally layer themselves on top of or right under the previous one, depending on density.)
2. Shake the aquavit with lemon peel and ice, strain into a small pitcher and layer on top.
3. Express a lemon twist over the drink and discard.

title: Cat’s Paw
intro_philosophy: In the latest iteration of the Japanese cocktail movement, umami flavors—miso, nori, tomato dashi—have seen a surge, reflecting a larger interest in savory cocktails.  At Raised by Wolves in San Diego,Erick Castrocalls for a dash of barrel-aged soy sauce to further enrich the intense nuttiness of a sesame oil–washed whisky.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sesame oil fat-washed Japanese whisky (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounces ginger liqueur, preferably Giffard Ginger of the Indies Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass ice.
2. Stir to integrate.

title: Doc Ramos
intro_philosophy: “It’s basically a Ramos Gin Fizz with carrot juice and grassy spirits,” says Annie Williams Pierce of this dessert-like creation inspired by a carrot pudding topped with a mousse made from the carrot greens served by a beloved local food truck.Cachaçaand wheat vodka comprise the earthy component representative of the carrot greens, while a house-made spiced syrup featuring coriander seeds, allspice and cloves complements fresh carrot juice; Fever-Tree Bitter Lemon soda stands in for the expected soda water for an extra bright finish.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  cachaça, preferably Avuá Prata Cachaça
1/2 ounce vodka, preferably Grey Goose Vodka
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except for heavy cream and soda to a cocktail shaker.
2. Dry shake vigorously without ice.
3. Add heavy cream and two ice cubes and shake until ice is completely gone.
4. Pour into a Collins glass.
5. Rinse the shaker tin with a bit of bitter lemon soda, and pour it down the spiral of a bar spoon, slowly, to lift the drink.
6. Garnish with makrut lime leaf and powdered coriander.

title: Matador Norteño
intro_philosophy: A riff on Trader Vic’s “Tequila Matador,” this drink showcases another agave-based spirit:sotol.  “This cocktail is helping the category of sotol to be more recognized,” says Alex Valencia, noting that the drink is a customer favorite. Use fresh-pressed pineapple juice if you can.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Twist lemon peel over top of drink to express essential oils, then discard the peel.

title: The NoMad Bar’s Orgeat
intro_philosophy: In the pursuit ofthe perfect Mai Tai, The NoMad Bar team developed their own housemade orgeat.
instructions: 1. Preheat the oven to 200°F.
2. Spread the almonds on a sheet pan and toast until lightly golden, about 20 minutes, and allow them to cool.
3. Crush the almonds using a food processor or a rolling pin.
4. Transfer the almonds to a large container, add the water and allow to sit for 8 hours.
5. Strain the mixture through cheesecloth into a bowl, squeezing the cheesecloth in order to extract all the liquid.
6. Add the sugar and orange blossom water and stir until the sugar is completely dissolved.
7. Store the orgeat in an airtight container, refrigerated, for up to 1 month.

title: Golden Lady
intro_philosophy: A play on the Vespersansgin, the Golden Lady is Grey Goose Ambassador Earlecia Richelle’s go-to Martini variation. Lillet adds a soft bitter note while Benedictine layers in an herbaceous round quality. Expressed orange peel brings it all together with a poppy bright note. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir and strain in a chilled small Martini glass or Nick & Nora-style cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed orange twist.

title: Saisonnière
intro_philosophy: The winter version of Lafayette’s seasonally changing staple—hence, the name Saisonnière, which means “seasonal” in French—is a riff on the basic sour. The New York restaurant mixes rich demerara syrup with lemon, autumnal poire Williams, sage and vodka for an easy-going, cold-weather refresher.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce demerara syrup (1:1, demerara sugar: water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Garnish with a sage leaf and a lemon twist.

title: Prince Henry Punch
intro_philosophy: At the forthcoming bar from Pablo Moix and Steve Livigni, the focal point of the beverage program will be tropical drinks—but don’t expect typical tiki. Instead, Moix will draw from the drinking cultures of the Caribbean, South and Central America as well as Mexico. “This type of drinking was the basis of the original riffs on Daiquiris and rum punches that created a fictional type of drink known as tiki,” explains Moix. Here, aged rum and blanc rhum agricole mingle with green Chartreuse, lime and raspberry, all served over a mountain of crushed ice.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce rhum agricole, preferably La Favorite Blanc
3/4 ounce aged rum, preferably Plantation Barbados 5 year
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a mountain of crushed ice.
3. Garnish with mint and fruits in season.

title: Red Beer
intro_philosophy: Add tomato juice to the MidwesternBeertiniand you get South Dakota’s Red Beer, which draws parallels to theMichelada—minus the spice.
ingredients: 8 ounces beer, preferably Busch Light, Coors Light or Grain Belt
instructions: 1. Combine beer and tomato juice in chilled mug and gently stir.
2. Add in green olives.

title: Double Reverse
intro_philosophy: At the nightclubAlter Egoin Tampa, Florida, co–bar leadDaniel Bareswiltcreates a roster of cocktails to win over clientele that he admitsmostly come “because the bar is beautiful and the music is good.” The drinks must be practical for the high-volume venue—the fewer bottle pickups, the better. This pragmatism has led Bareswilt to hone his own brand of crowd-pleasing minimalism. In his words, he likes to “make drinks that skew tropical, crushable and aromatic.” The Double Reverse is a liberal interpretation of a reverse Martini, made with Cocchi Americano, passion fruit liqueur and your choice of unaged spirit.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce passion fruit liqueur, such as Chinola
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until well-diluted and chilled.
3. Strain into a frozen coupe glass.

title: Pearl of Krishna
intro_philosophy: “This is my rendition of a coconut red curry Martinez,” explains bartender Javelle Taft. The botanicals reflected in the gin, specifically angelica root, jasmine, chamomile and coriander, “brought me back to vivid memories from my time spent in Hyderabad, India.” Meanwhile, Lustau sherry vermouth and coconut liqueur layer rich, savory nuttiness, evoking “the creaminess of curry.”
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces  Jin Jiji India Dry Gin
¼ ounce  Reisetbauer carrot eau de vie
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Twist orange peel over top of the glass to express essential oils, then garnish drink with peel.

title: Violet Eyes
intro_philosophy:
To explore the overlap between the worlds of drinks and music, we challenged bartenders to translate a song of their choice from a given era into cocktail form. Here, Derek Brown takes on grunge.

In creating this drink, Brown explains: “Violet Eyes is inspired by theMeat Puppets’ song of the same name…. I might have taken the easy route here and chosen the literal over the conceptual [by] using violet honey, [which] melds well with the floral characteristics of Singani … and burning a rose bud, which is taken directory from a lyric in the song:Plastic master, smoke drifts from a rose.

“I suppose the one conceptual aspect is that the song itself feels very layered and bit more polished than some of the Meat Puppets’ other, more raw-sounding songs. The cocktail is also very layered and takes a spirit that can feel a little raw at times … and renders it as elegant.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a dried, singed rose bud.

title: Saffron Chase
intro_philosophy:
Anything that involves Champagne needs to be served in an ice-cold glass. In order to get it as cold as it needs to be, you can either pop your flutes into the freezer for a couple of hours or, as we do in NOPI, simply fill the glasses with crushed ice and leave for 2 minutes before tipping the ice out into the sink.

Chase is a single-estate English distiller based in Herefordshire producing gin, vodka, and various liqueurs that, in our search for the finest, we love to use. There are other brands out there which are good, though: St-Germain elderflower, for example.

This is a nice and easy cocktail to make. You don’t even have to stir the ingredients in a mixing glass, if you don’t want to: you can just pour the ingredients straight into a chilled glass. With thanks to Niall Downey.

Reprinted with permission fromNOPI: The Cookbookby Yotam Ottolenghi and Ramael Scully, copyright © 2015. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
instructions: 1. Place the gin, elderflower liqueur, and lemon juice in a mixing glass.

2. Fill the glass half full with ice cubes and stir five times to the left and five times to the right with a spoon. It’s important to get the stirring right here—not too much and not too little—so that you don’t bring too much dilution to the drink.
3. Strain into the chilled Champagne flutes.
4. Stir 1/3 ounce of saffron syrup into each glass, top with the Champagne, and serve at once.

title: Rapscallion
intro_philosophy: The potent, stirred blend of Scotch and Pedro Ximénez sherry—served up in a pastis-coated Nick & Nora glass and garnished with a lemon twist—reached its final form at Copenhagen’s Ruby in 2007 after shape-shifting at bars in Edinburgh. The subtly sweet and smoky recipe has taken on a life of its own, appearing at bars around the world and in Jim Meehan’s 2011 book,The PDT Cocktail Book.
ingredients: heavy 1 1/4 ounces single malt Scotch, preferably Talisker 10
1/2 teaspoon pastis, preferably Ricard, to rinse
instructions: 1. Combine the Scotch and sherry in a mixing glass and stir to chill and dilute.
2. Pour the pastis into a chilled Nick & Nora glass, then dump the contents out to season it with the liqueur.
3. Strain the cocktail into the pastis-rinsed glass, then express a lemon peel over the drink and garnish.

title: Jeremy Oertel’s Margarita
intro_philosophy: In our recent blind tasting of Margaritas, Jeremy Oertel’s recipe secured itself a spot in the top three. In this quintessential take on the cocktail, Oertel calls for El Tesoro Blanco as the tequila base, and a traditional mix of Cointreau and lime juice, tied together with a salt rim.
ingredients: 2 ounces tequila, preferably El Tesoro Blanco
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with salt and set aside.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the rocks glass over ice.

title: Alicia Perry’s Corpse Reviver No. 2
intro_philosophy: The winning recipe from ourtasting, Alicia Perry’s Corpse Reviver No. 2 does not strictly adhere to the equal-parts doctrine. It contains one ounce of Plymouth Gin, and three-quarters of an ounce each of Lillet, Cointreau and lemon juice, while a quarter-ounce of simple syrup lends roundness to the flavor profile. A pastis rinse completes the formula.
instructions: 1. Rinse a coupe with pastis and set aside.
2. Combine all the remaining ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the prepared coupe.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Bizzy Izzy Highball
intro_philosophy: Al Sotack has been adding the Bizzy Izzy Highball, and renditions of it, to his menus for years. “It’s a wonderful cocktail, but it also strikes me as a fairly modern cocktail,” says Sotack, citing its split-base starting point and heavy reliance on sherry, a common move at the time of the drink’s creation at the turn of the century that has since come back into vogue.
ingredients: 1 ounce rye whiskey, preferably Wild Turkey 101
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Cobblers Make Kicks
intro_philosophy: Lee Zaremba concocted this drink as a tribute to a few of the places that have shaped his artistic sensibility: Txakoli nods to Spain, Meletti amaro to Italy, and Bombay Sapphire gin to Britain. “It’s a white wine cobbler with a play on words that brings it back around to the influence hip-hop has had on my bartending,” says Zaremba.
instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass with crushed ice, then add all ingredients. Swizzle until glass is chilled.
2. Sprinkle with a pinch of salt, express the lime peel over the drink and curl next to straw with two-thirds of the peel sticking out of the glass. Add toasted bay leaf.

title: Summer Lover
ingredients: 1/2 part Ancho Reyes Ancho Chile Liqueur
instructions: 1. Rinse a coupe with mezcal and discard the excess.
2. Combine the gin, lemon juice, chile liqueur, simple syrup, and Tabasco in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake vigorously.
3. Double-strain into the coupe and garnish with the dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Step Back
intro_philosophy: According to Jack Schramm, when using wine-based ingredients or lower-proof modifiers in force-carbonated cocktails, you can cut the dilution ratio from 2:1 down to 1:1, as demonstrated in this mixture of Sfumato amaro, Caperitif and dry vermouth. Schramm notes that ingredients like vermouth, amaro, sherry and other fortified wines are useful tools to play with in the carbonated format because they provide bitter and complex flavors without calling on fresh citrus or other perishable fruit.
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients except champagne acid in a carbonation bottle.
2. Chill to almost freezing.
3. Carbonate three times.
4. Pour into a chilled white wine glass and top with champagne acid.

title: Zombie
intro_philosophy:
Donn Beach, also known as Don the Beachcomber, was notorious for coding and obsessively fiddling with his recipes and housemade ingredients. Largely considered the founder of tiki cocktail culture, Beach opened Don the Beachcomber’s in Hollywood in 1934 and created a canon of drinks that built upon the base of fresh juices, exotic fruits, complex syrups and lots and lots of rum.

The Zombie is a prime example of his typical concoction: strong and rather mysterious (it contains two different proprietary mixes). Bar lore says the original was so potent that Beach mandated his customers order no more than two Zombies in one sitting. This recipe is Beach’s original from 1934 as translated by Jeff “Beachbum Berry” in his bookSippin’ Safari.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake with a few ice cubes.
3. Strain into a tiki mug over crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Sesame by the Sea
intro_philosophy: A kelp-inflected twist on a sour formula, this cocktail is amplified by furikake, tahini and lemon juice. Simultaneously salty and sweet, this drink, Jena Ellenwood says, is “addictive in its simplicity.”
ingredients: 2 ounces kelp- and tahini-washed reposado tequila (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce vegan furikake syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice, then shake again.
3. Strain into a chilled glass.
4. Garnish with furikake.

title: Guanabana Mist
intro_philosophy: At Tigre in New York’s Lower East Side neighborhood, executive bar director William Elliott has reimagined a category of drinks called “mists.” Originally appearing inPlayboy’s Host & Bar Book, published in 1971, mists consisted simply of straight spirits topped with crushed ice and the optional lemon twist. At Tigre, the quartet of mists prove that spirit-forward drinks need not be so dark and serious. Each mist is named after a fruit: Watermelon for instance, pairs its namesake with potent French pastis, a coupling inspired by one of bartender Orlando Franklin McCray’screations. The Guanabana (known as soursop, in English), meanwhile, spotlights sotol alongside lime juice and a teaspoon of coconut liqueur.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces sotol, preferably Sotol Por Siempre
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Fine-strain into a rocks glass and top with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a spritz of sotol and a manicured lime twist on a cocktail pick.

title: Chairs Up Daiq
intro_philosophy: Playing up pineapple cordial’s grassy side, Kelsey Ramage pairs the tropical-minded ingredient with two ounces of rhum agricole alongside lemon juice and orange bitters, for acidity and balance.
ingredients: 2 ounces rhum agricole, preferably Rhum Clément
3/4 ounce green pineapple cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Division Bell
intro_philosophy: Phil Ward, an early mezcal evangelist, was among the first bartenders in the United States to recognize the spirit’s adaptability, especially in spirit-forward constructions. HisOaxaca Old-Fashioned, created at New York’s Death & Co. in 2007, split the tequila base with a measure of robust, smoky mezcal to add depth to the familiar template in what would go on to become a modern classic. But he had even more luck letting mezcal stand in for the base spirit altogether in classic blueprints. His Division Bell, for example, sees mezcal take the place of gin and Aperol that of Chartreuse in a simple riff on the Last Word.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Express a grapefruit twist over the surface of the drink, then discard.

title: Lefty’s Fizz
intro_philosophy: ABV in San Francisco specializes in mezcal. This menu staple highlights Del Maguey’s smoky single-village Santo Domingo Albarradas, which gets mixed with sweet and sour grapefruit shrub, lime juice, dry curaçao and egg white. Served down over seltzer, the fluffed up fizz is equal parts sour, smoky and smooth.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal (preferably Del Maguey Santo Domingo Albarradas)
instructions: 1. Add soda water to a small Collins glass.
2. Add remaining ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
3. Dry shake (shake without ice).
4. Add ice and shake until chilled.
5. Strain over seltzer water into Collins glass.
6. Garnish with a grapefruit peel.

title: Tujague’s Grasshopper
intro_philosophy: When bartender Paul Gustings returned to New Orleans’ iconic Tujague’s he brought his personal recipe for the Grasshopper—a cocktail long associated with Tujague’s—along with him. Pre-batched and refrigerated, the deeply flavored drink includes both light and darkcrème de cacaoand white and green crème de menthe, plus a half-ounce of brandy and heavy cream. According to contributing editor Robert Simonson, you’re unlikely to find a Grasshopper that surpasses it.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Strain into a Champagne flute.

title: Funky Colada
intro_philosophy: “This cocktail is a journey,” says James Minier, owner of Bar Clandestino. The Piña Colada riff mixes Artesano Pot Still rum, which comes from a local distiller and offers a funky, grassy profile. Minier makes the creamy part of the cocktail with locally sourced mamey sapote purée and a housemade coconut cream sweetened with piloncillo (a form of raw cane sugar), then bolsters it all with cream sherry. Like the original Piña Colada, the Funky Colada is shaken, rather than blended, but “with a lot of ice,” he says.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces piloncillo cream of coconut (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce rum, preferably Artesano Pot Still
1 ounce cream sherry, preferably Lustau East India Solera
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients, except the Angostura bitters, in a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until cold.
2. Pour into a Hurricane glass and add crushed ice.
3. Float a few dashes of Angostura bitters on top.
4. Garnish with pineapple fronds and a chunk of coconut.

title: White Russian
intro_philosophy:
The proto “White Russian,” called, simply, “The Russian,” (c. 1930) was comprised of equal parts vodka, gin and crème de cacao—and for a creamier version, two parts vodka, one part crème de cacao and one part cream. In the following 30 years, several other versions would fall in and out of vogue, until, at long last, the addition of coffee liqueur was introduced. The combination of equal parts vodka, Kahlúa and cream that we now know as the White Russian rose to prominence in the 1960s, alongside the Black Russian (which, naturally, omits the last ingredient).

But for those born after the drink’s ’60s heyday, it is perhaps best known as the signature drink of  the Dude (Jeff Bridges’ character inThe Big Lebowski)—whose evangelism for the cocktail raised the White Russian from marginal to cult status. There now exist many variations on the drink (the White Canadian calls for goat’s milk and the Blind Russian for Bailey’s Irish Cream), but our preferred version is famed New York bartender Toby Cecchini’s riff, which allows for the option of aged rum instead of vodka, a new-school and old-school coffee liqueur and the added bonus of Toschi Nocello walnut liqueur and amaretto-spiked whipped cream.
ingredients: 2 ounces  vodka or rum (preferably Plantation 5-year Barbados Grande Réserve if using rum or Absolut Elyx if using vodka)
1 ounce House Spirits Series Coffee Liqueur
1/4 ounce amaretto (preferably Luxardo Amaretto di Saschira)
instructions: 1. Add heavy cream and amaretto to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add the coil of a hawthorne shaker and dry shake, without ice, for ten seconds or more, to aerate but not whip into stiffness. It must be lightened but still pourable.
3. Add the remaining ingredients to another cocktail shaker.
4. Add ice and shake until chilled.
5. Strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass.
6. Holding a slotted spoon closely over the surface of the drink, pour a finger's worth of cream through it to float atop of the drink.

title: Wei Lei (Taste Buds)
intro_philosophy: In the Wei Lei, which translates to “taste buds” in Mandarin, Jef Tate blends strong-aroma baijiu with equal parts brandy and falernum for a tiki-style cocktail, brightened with guava and lime juice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a tiki mug, Collins or rocks glass.
2. Add crushed ice.
3. Swizzle the drink with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet and freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Gage & Tollner’s Dirty Gin Martini
intro_philosophy: Gage & Tollner makes a house brine for its dirty Martinis, both vodka and gin variations. Olives aren’t part of the mix, “because olive brine from a jar is kind of gross and hard to work with if you’re trying to be serious about cocktails,” partner St. John Frizell observes. Instead, his bar uses a mix of saltwater with lactic acid, which adds olive-like tang.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces gin, such as Edinburgh Seaside Gin
heavy 1/2 ounce house brine (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an olive.

title: Pearl Diver
intro_philosophy:
The Pearl Diver is Don the Beachcomber’s iced take on hot buttered rum. Key to its construction is a proprietary mixture known as Gardenia Mix—an amalgam of honey, butter and spiced syrups. In Gaby Mlynarczyk’s version of the mix, far fewer ingredients are required, and browned butter, rather than simply softened butter, lends a slightly savory note.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce unaged blended rum, preferably Denizen
1 ounce mango brandy, preferably Rhine Hall
1 barspoon Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker. Add a few small pieces of ice and shake until it melts.
2. Pour into a Pearl Diver glass or a glass of your choice.
3. Top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a mango leaf, an edible orchid, and some freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Miyazaki Martini
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the robust, nutty flavor of Kiroku sweet potato shochu, this is Thomas Waugh’s riff on the Espresso Martini. “The [Kuroki Honten] distillery is known for their use of black koji, which gives the final product a robust, nutty, full-flavored taste,” Waugh explains. “I immediately thought coffee (cocoa, nuts), and naturally the Espresso Martini.” Using orgeat as a sweetener accentuates the richness of the shochu and results in a variation with more depth and heft than the classic. Bonus: “Espresso Martinis are way better with flavorful spirits.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  Orgeat Works Heavy Duty Toasted Almond Syrup
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Pass through a fine-mesh strainer into a small rocks glass.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: TTO + T
intro_philosophy:
“This is essentially a rum and tonic, without the tonic water,” says Orlando McCray. “Two liqueurs provide the gentian, while the soda brings bubbles, with dark rum to balance.” He encourages you to play around with the acidity level of this “mock tonic” by subtracting ingredients—like the Suze, or the lime juice—to fine-tune what you like best.

For McCray, the highball is a favorite vehicle for showcasing a spirit: Bubbles are the most effective way to open up flavors. But, he advises: “Make sure all ingredients are incorporated with a gentle stir. [Just] ‘topping’ with bubbles is a misleading technique and not effective in creating balanced drinks.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Ten To One Caribbean Dark Rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the soda water in a mixing tin with ice, and shake for approximately 10 seconds.
2. Strain into a 10-ounce Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Top with soda water and gently stir with a barspoon to incorporate ingredients.
4. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.

title: Yukimi Highball
intro_philosophy:
This marriage of two popular Japanese highballs takes inspiration from the Chūhai, the ubiquitous canned shōchū cocktails flavored with yuzu or grapefruit, and the Oolong-Hai, made with shōchū and oolong or barley tea. Vodka infused with barley tea serves as a base with a splash of Crème de Fraise des Bois, finished with a floral and bubbly pink grapefruit soda.

Order Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit Soda viaTarget.
ingredients: Barspoon of Crème de Fraise des Bois
3 ounces  Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit soda, chilled
instructions: 1. Add the vodka and Crème de Fraise des Bois to a Collins glass.
2. Fill with ice, then top off with the grapefruit soda by gently pouring down a twisted or swizzled bar spoon.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Girl From Cadiz
intro_philosophy: Ryan Maybee created this gin- and sherry-based cooler in 2007 for the Vinos de Jerez Cocktail Competition, in which he was a finalist. Since then, it’s found a permanent place on the Manifesto menu. “It’s never going away,” says Maybee.
instructions: 1. Muddle the juniper berries in mixing glass.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and shake vigorously with ice for 15 to 20 seconds.
3. Fine strain into Collins glass filled with ice.
4. Garnish with a thin spear of lemongrass.

title: “Martini Service” (Dirty Martini Riff)
intro_philosophy: At Nashville’s The Fox Bar, the zero-proof dirty Martini is built on a base of botanical Pentire Adrift mixed with housemade celery brine and rosemary oil. At the bar, it’s garnished with a lemon peel, Castelvetrano olive and a rotation of housemade pickles, which, in the past, have included cornichon, watermelon rind, turmeric gooseberry and baby corn.
instructions: 1. Chill all ingredients ahead of time.
2. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with Kold-Draft ice and gently stir, taking care to not over-dilute.
3. Strain into a chilled coupette and sidecar decanter.
4. Top the sidecar with one drop of rosemary oil and the glass with three drops.

title: Mountain Man
intro_philosophy: In this kicked up Whiskey Sour, Natasha David forgoes fresh peaches in lieu of Giffard’s Pêche de Vigne to accentuate the roundness of maple syrup and the spice of ginger.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over a large rock into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a piece of candied ginger.

title: Trail House Sour
intro_philosophy: Montana’s Trail House updates the classic whiskey sour with a walnut liqueur and a hefty dose of Angostura cordial (an original blend of citrus, spices and bitters) for a seasonal twist on the year-round staple.
ingredients: 1 ounce walnut liqueur, preferably Rapa Giovanni "Ratafia di Andorno" Liquore di Noci
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients with ice and shake.
2. Double strain into a coupe and garnish with a skewered maraschino cherry wrapped in a lemon twist.

title: Hot Penicillin
intro_philosophy: Named for its so-called healing properties, the Penicillin—bartender Sam Ross’ smoky and spicy twist on a Whiskey Sour—has become a modern classic in the cocktail canon. Victoria presents a cold-weather update by warming it up, literally, with hot apple cider sweetened with a fragrant honey syrup. The familiar Scotch whisky of the original gets a spicy kick of ginger root from Fever-Tree Ginger Beer, and added brightness from fresh lemon. “It’s warming, with a smoky spice flavor,” she says, “and perfect for transitioning into winter.”
ingredients: 1 ounce  Monkey Shoulder Blended Malt Scotch Whisky
1/4 ounce  honey syrup  (2:1 honey to water)
instructions: 1. Temper a mug with hot water to warm.
2. Discard hot water and combine Scotch, cider, lemon juice and honey syrup in the mug.
3. Top with Fever-Tree Ginger Beer.
4. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Rosemary & Elderflower White Negroni
intro_philosophy: The White Negroni—with its gentian liqueur and lighter style of aromatized wine—showcases a different side of a gin’s botanical profile from the classic version. In this take, a rosemary-infused bianco vermouth lends a piney character that brings The Botanist gin’s juniper notes to the forefront. A touch of elderflower liqueur rounds out the bitter gentian, while a dash of verjus ups the overall acidity.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  rosemary-infused bianco vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled, then strain into a double rocks glass over a large cube.
3. Garnish with a fresh elderflower.

title: Alec Bales’ 50/50 Martini
intro_philosophy: Alec Bales’ 50/50 Martini earned an honorable mention in our blind tasting of 11 different recipes. His version offers vanilla and confectionary notes, thanks to the way Fords gin lends structure to the cocktail.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass or coupe.
3. Garnish with a small green olive and a long lemon twist.

title: Pyogo Highball
intro_philosophy: A variation on the classic Horse’s Neck, this highball pairs the umami-forward flavor of shiitake mushrooms with the earthy bitterness of Suze liqueur. It all pops against a backdrop of dry, spicy Fever-Tree Ginger Ale.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  shiitake mushroom syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients and 2 to 3 ice cubes to a chilled Collins glass. Stir 10 times to chill.
2. Fill the rest of the glass with ice.
3. Top up with ginger ale.
4. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

title: Little Italy
intro_philosophy: A Manhattan variation with an extra Italian kick courtesy of the artichoke-based amaro Cynar. Audrey Saunders’ 2005 modern classic is a nod to the Little Italy neighborhood bordering the home of her influential bar Pegu Club, as well as a tribute to the combination of Italian and American ingredients in the glass.
ingredients: 2 ounces rye whiskey, such as Rittenhouse 100-proof
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Martini & Rossi Rosso
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with Luxardo cherries on a skewer.

title: Nog Nog Noggin’ on Heaven’s Door
intro_philosophy: One of the ways in which Fanny Chu reinforces the escapist atmosphere of Donna is by creating cocktails that directly evoke a particular place. Her Nog Nog Noggin’ on Heaven’s Door draws on the flavor profile of Crema Catalana (“one of my faves,” she says), a custard-like Spanish dessert that she encountered while traveling through Catalonia with her fiancée. To translate it into drink form, Chu builds on a whiskey base complemented by Cognac, Cachaça, orange liqueur, cinnamon syrup, cream and eggs and serves it from Donna’s slushy machine.
ingredients: 1 ounce bourbon, preferably Medley Brothers Bourbon
1/2 ounce Cachaça, preferably Avuá Cachaça Amburana
1/2 ounce orange liqueur, preferably Torres Magdala
instructions: 1. Blend the egg in a Vitamix until smooth and creamy.
2. Add sugar and blend until incorporated.
3. Add remaining ingredients and blend until combined.
4. If texture is not as desired, add pebble ice and blend until desired texture is reached, or freeze overnight.
5. Pour into a coupe to serve.

title: Chile Crisp Margarita
intro_philosophy: As James Park, author ofChile Crisp, explains, the spicy, crunchy condiment of the same name “belongs on everything.” Here at Punch, we took that as an invitation to try it in a Margarita, a drink that fares especially well when given thespicy treatment. As opposed to using regular chile oil, the chile crisp lends a more savory quality in addition to the expected spice. Of course, the brand of chile crisp used will determine the flavor of the finished drink—we suggest opting for something on the milder side of the heat scale so as not to throw the drink out of balance.
ingredients: 2 ounces chile crisp–infused tequila (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce agave syrup or Demerara syrup (1:1, sweetener to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a few drops of chile oil.

title: Scotty Schuder’s Missionary’s Downfall
intro_philosophy: “When we do classic tiki cocktails we stick as close as possible to the original recipe,” explains Scotty Schuder, owner of Paris’s tiki den, Dirty Dick. To update the Don the Beachcomber recipe for modern palates, Schuder simply swaps lime juice for lemon and dials back the honey mix to account for the concentrated sweetness of crème de peche.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Merlet Crème de Peche de Vigne
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend for 10 seconds and serve in a snifter glass.
3. Garnish with a pineapple wedge, mint, powdered sugar and an orchid.

title: Ohana
intro_philosophy: A variation on the Leilani Volcano—a mixture of rum, coconut, guava, pineapple and lime—the Ohana builds on a base of coconut-infused gin in place of rum. “Every time I tried to make [the Leilani Volcano] or tasted someone else’s redone version of it, it was either too creamy or it was just kind of one-note,” says Richard. When he added Plymouth Gin and contrasted its botanicals with coconut, “suddenly the guava pops more [and] the different layers of pineapple taste more like pineapple,” he explains. In a nod to another favorite cocktail, the Mai-Kai Special, which also calls on guava and coconut, Richard adds banana in the form of a cordial, something he relies on to evoke the sweet, rich banana flavor associated with, say, Bananas Foster, rather than the greener flavor favored by many bottled banana liqueurs. “I think a lot of it for me is trying to tap into people’s nostalgia and sense memory,” he says.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces coconut oil-washed gin, (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and flash blend.
2. Pour over 4 ounces of crushed ice in a swizzle glass.
3. Garnish with pineapple fronds, a pineapple wedge and an orchid.

title: Lifetime Ban
intro_philosophy: This drink was created for The Beagle, a now-closed East Village bar that was noted for its outsize love of all things sherry. While the template for this drink is a reverseMartini(1 part gin, 2 parts vermouth), it gets added character by splitting the fortified wine component between vermouth and fino sherry.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Chartreuse Toddy
intro_philosophy:
While workshopping riffs on the classic hot toddy, we wanted to create something that played close enough to the original tune, but felt a bit more tony, more deluxe, moreFrench. This combination of Cognac (French) and the herbal liqueur Chartreuse (French) plus the usual toddy trappings, is the perfect amount of French.

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine the cognac, Chartreuse, lemon juice, and honey syrup in a clear tempered mug and garnish with a star anise pod.

title: Yolanda
intro_philosophy: A deep cut fromThe Savoy Cocktail Book, the Yolanda is something of a candied Martini, building off a base of vermouth complemented by smaller proportions of gin and brandy. While Harry Craddock’s original recipe calls for sweet Italian vermouth, Portland, Maine-based bartender LyAnna Sanabria subs in the semi-sweet Comoz Blanc providing a brighter canvas for her spring-friendly rendition. Bimini Coconut Gin, from Maine’s Round Turn Distilling, and Capurro Acholado Pisco are the lighter stand-ins for the London dry gin and Cognac specified in the pages of Savoy.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanc vermouth, preferably Comoz Blanc
1 barspoon rose- and apple-infused Pineaus de Charentes (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Pink G&T Warmer
intro_philosophy: The Gin & Tonic might seem like it’s made for summer, but with its characteristic aromatics and bracing bubbles, aficionados know it actually defies seasons. Here, Victoria makes a case for a winterized take by starting with an organic Minnesota gin and Fever-Tree Indian Tonic, then putting on the proverbial snow tires with a final float of Angostura bitters, whose warming spices of cinnamon and clove marry well with the gin’s juniper and coriander notes.
