In a final nod to wintertime, the classic lime wedge steps aside for a thick slice of in-season orange. This “playful G&T,” as she calls it, is “a classic Gin & Tonic made festive.”
instructions: 1. Add the gin to a highball or large wine glass, then fill with ice cubes.
2. Top with Fever-Tree Indian Tonic Water.
3. Garnish with two dashes Angostura bitters and an orange wedge.

title: Juicebox Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Pineapple and passion fruit lend a tiki-like vibe to this cobbler riff, which is an excuse to go extra with the garnish. The drink’s name nods to the fact that, mixed together, the fruity flavors remind Dan Greenbaum of a grown-up version of a fruit punch juice box.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce passion fruit syrup (see Editor's Note)
3 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula
instructions: 1. Add the pineapple, orange, lemon and passion fruit syrup to a mixing tin and muddle.
2. Add the vermouth and swirl briefly.
3. Dump the contents of the tin into a chilled Collins glass.
4. Fill the glass 3/4 full with with pebble or crushed ice and mix briefly with a spoon or metal straw to integrate.
5. Garnish with fruit and a mint sprig.

title: Carbonara Sour
intro_philosophy: After 15 years behind the bar at the five-star luxury Hotel de Russie, Massimo D’Addezio left to open his own cocktail bar,Co.So. Cocktail & Socialin Pigneto, eastern Rome’s nightlife epicenter. With the support and skills of London-trained bartender Giorgia Crea, Co.So. does a brisk business of cocktails that are twists on the classics, with cheeky names like the Carbonara Sour. Their version is a fresh and light vodka sour with black pepper and citrus introducing a little kick and the guanciale-washed (fat-infused) vodka lending a mellow savoriness.
instructions: 1. Combine vodka, simple syrup, lemon juice and egg white in a shaker.
2. Dry shake without ice for 15 seconds.
3. Add ice to fill the shaker and shake vigorously until chilled.
4. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
5. Garnish with a lemon twist and pinch of freshly ground black pepper.

title: Daniel Webster’s Punch
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups Bordeaux, or any full-bodied red wine
instructions: 1. Peel the lemons, taking care to avoid as much of the bitter white pith as possible.
2. In a large bowl, combine the sugar with the lemon peels, then lightly muddle and let sit for 20 minutes to allow the citrus oils to infuse with the sugar.
3. Boil 2 cups of water and steep the tea bag in it for 5 minutes, and set aside to cool slightly.
4. To the bowl, add the tea, lemon juice, cognac, sherry, rum and red wine, and stir to combine.
5. Strain out the lemon peels and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
6. Fifteen minutes before serving, add the ice ring (see Editor's Note).
7. Ladle into cups and lightly top each glass with champagne.

title: Year of the Rat
intro_philosophy: In January 2017, Sugar House unveiled its “Chinese Zodiac” cocktail menu, and, with it, Kirles’s Year of the Rat, a drink he sees as a cross between two tiki classics: the Pearl Diver and theZombie. It makes use of Kirles’s take on Gardenia Mix, an obscure spiced syrup invented by tiki forefather Donn Beach that includes honey and butter. Here the mix helps contribute to a dynamic savory-sour interplay.
ingredients: 1 ounce overproof dark rum, preferably Plantation OFTD
1 ounce aquavit, preferably Long Road Aquavit
1/4 ounce raspberry liqueur, preferably St. George
1/2 ounce velvet falernum, preferably John D. Taylor's
instructions: 1. Shake ingredients over pebble ice, lightly so to avoid chilling the Gardenia Mix back to a solid state.
2. Frappe into a tiki mug, then top with more fresh pebble ice until full.
3. Garnish with an edible orchid and torched cinnamon.

title: Friesling
intro_philosophy: Though created in jest as an alternative to the ubiquitous frosé, friesling—a frozen, riesling-based drink—can nonetheless be both balanced and delicious. Here, peach-infused vodka adds a slight fruity kick to the simple recipe.
ingredients: 1 half bottle of off dry riesling, (like St. Urbans-Hof Nik Weis 2014)
instructions: 1. Freeze riesling in a pint-sized jar.
2. Once frozen, allow to thaw slightly until the texture is just slushy.
3. Stir in vodka and lemon juice until fully incorporated.
4. Garnish with fresh peach slices.

title: Bobby Heugel’s Harvey Wallbanger
intro_philosophy: Bobby Heugelcreated this version of the Harvey Wallbanger as part of a month-long campaign to raise money for victims of Hurricane Harvey. Bars around the country have put the drink on their menus and donated all or a portion of the proceeds to Houston Mayor Turner’sHurricane Harvey Relief Fund.
instructions: 1. Shake the vodka, orange and lemon juices and simple syrup with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice and float the Galliano on top.
3. Garnish with an orange slice. No fucking straw.

title: Meint Eraser
intro_philosophy: Inspiration for this updated Mind Eraser hit when fellow D.C. bartender Dimitre Darroca dropped by Service Bar one night and mentioned his time spent in the Rumple Minze cabin (named after a brand of peppermint schnapps) at Camp Runamok, an annual bartender convention. Reaching for a bottle of Rumple Minze, Christine Kim knew that the spirit’s higher proof and strong mentholated flavor would need a powerful sidekick. She landed on Jägermeister Cold Brew Coffee liqueur, combining the two spirits in equal measure, and topped them with soda.
ingredients: 1 ounce peppermint schnapps, preferably Rumple Minze
1 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Jägermeister Cold Brew Coffee liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine the first two ingredients in a Collins glass, then top with crushed ice.
2. Insert two straws into the glass, top with more crushed ice, then top with soda.

title: Humo y Oro
intro_philosophy: David Naylor, bar manager at La Ruina in San Antonio, often floats Lapsang souchong tea concentrate on top of a cocktail to add a smoky, piney dimension. The Humo y Oro, a bright and herbal drink, gets balanced by the float, which harmonizes with the agave base.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce espadín mezcal, preferably Amaras Verde Momento
3/4 ounce sotol, preferably Oro de Coyame
1/2 ounce Fresno chile honey (see Editor’s Note)
2 ounces triple-steeped Lapsang souchong tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except tea into a mixing glass and stir until chilled.
2. Pour over a large ice cube into a double rocks glass.
3. Pour tea gently over the drink so it floats on top as a separate layer.

title: Peychaud’s Roffignac
intro_philosophy: At Peychaud’s in the Hotel Maison De Ville—housed in the one-time home of Antoine Amédée Peychaud, creator of the famed bitters—Neal Bodenheimer and head bartender Nick Jarrett developed a rendition of the historic Roffignac cocktail swapping the traditional Cognac forCobrafire eau de raisin, a blanche d’Aramagnac that “brings heady notes of red berries to the table which marry perfectly with a simple raspberry shrub.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Cobrafire eau de vie de raisin
instructions: 1. In a chilled footed glass, combine eau de vie and a splash of soda water.
2. Fill with pebble ice, then add shrub. Stir to integrate.
3. Mound more pebble ice on top.
4. Garnish with raspberries and add a straw.

title: Strega Sour
intro_philosophy: The original Strega Sour recipe, first published inPlayboy’s Host & Bar Book, in 1971, was bracing and harsh, and included no sweetener. Here, Tristan Willey of Brooklyn’s Long Island Bar has updated it with a bit of honey syrup to smooth things out.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin with ice. Shake well until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Amiraali
intro_philosophy: For Peder Schweigert, the cocktail of the future will be built on spirits made with greater transparency. In the Amiraali, Schweigert and Marvel Bar head bartender Matthew Voss shake together two such spirits—Duquesne Blanc rhum agricole and Gamle Ode Dill, a locally made aquavit—along with citrus andrancio sec.
ingredients: scant 1 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Duquesne Rhum Blanc
scant 1 ounce aquavit, preferably Gamle Ode Dill Aquavit
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: By Any Means Necessary
intro_philosophy: Inspired by springtime elderflower blossoms, Tuda Grehan’s By Any Means Necessary matches the bright sweetness of St-Germain with the spice of white peppercorn-infused gin. The spirit of the French spritz, she says, “is about enjoying and savoring every moment of your creation.” The aromatic profile is rounded out with the dry herbaceous notes of sage and cucumber and topped with Champagne foam for an unexpected take on the template.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Champagne simple syrup (see Editor's Note)
2 ounces cucumber and sage-infused soda (see Editor's Note)
Top with Champagne syrup foam (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the lemon juice, Champagne syrup, St-Germain and gin, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into wine glass.
3. Top with cucumber and sage-infused soda.
4. Top with the Champagne foam, allowing it to rise above the rim of the glass.
5. Garnish with sage leaf and crushed white pepper along the rim.

title: Avocado Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: “Avocado, onion and tomato is an appetizer that my family makes before every meal,” says Demi Natoli. “I kind of wanted this slick, almost kind of oily and salinic tasting cocktail,” she says of her inspiration. Rather than using whole avocado, Natoli employs avocado oil which adds frothiness to the finished drink, a Daiquiri variation that calls for pineapple and fino sherry in addition to the expected lime juice and rum. She splits the latter into two components, Panamanian rum and agricole rum, which possesses distinctive salinic properties. In place of the usual simple syrup sweetener, Natoli adds bay leaf-infused simple syrup in a further nod to her Caribbean inspiration. “We use bay leaf in Cuban cooking all the time,” she says, “there’s not a dish that doesn’t have it in there.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Panamanian rum, preferably Caña Brava 3 Year
1 ounce rhum agricole, preferably La Favorite
3/4 ounce bay leaf simple syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with cracked pepper and bay leaf.

title: Boozeless Margarita
intro_philosophy: According to Ryan Chetiyawardana, this booze-free Margarita (which leans on Seedlip Spice in place of tequila) works well for summer parties, as it’s “always nice to have a non-alcoholic serve on hand.” For those who miss the booze, there’s no shame intopping it off with a float of blanco tequila.
instructions: 1. Chill Seedlip, juices and sweet potato puree ahead in the refrigerator.
2. Add all ingredients to a blender, add ice and blend quickly to combine.
3. Pour into a chilled rocks glass.

title: Stone’s Throw
intro_philosophy: A creamy, dessert-like cocktail, the Stone’s Throw was modeled on the tradition of Scottish nobility using milk and honey to cover up the flavor of poor Scotch distillate centuries ago, explains Mony Bunni. Incorporating tahini syrup built on sesame paste, honey, dried spices and green cardamom, the drink also draws on her Arab-American roots.
ingredients: 2 ounces Scotch, preferably Great King Street Glasgow Blend Scotch
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Happiest Hour Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: “Rum is probably the most versatile, friendly spirit ingredient there is,” says Jim Kearns. Calling on winter-friendly Spanish-style and Jamaican rums, plus rhum agricole, Kearns’ Happiest Hour Daiquiri borrows the classic tiki trick of blending base spirits to add complexity, for a twist on the timeless summer classic.
ingredients: 1 ounce lightly aged rum, preferably Santa Teresa Claro
1/2 ounce aged rum, preferably Appleton Reserve
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in shaker with ice and shake.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Coni’Seafood Cantarito
intro_philosophy: The Cantarito differs from the Paloma by virtue of its vessel; an earthenware cup known as a cántaro. At this Nayarit-style restaurant, owner Coni Cosio likes to dip the rim of the cántaro in chamoy, a condiment made from fruit, chiles and lime juice, and Tajin. The combination provides a lip-tingling counterpoint to the acidity and carbonation of the citrus juice and Squirt.
instructions: 1. If using a cántaro, fill with water and let sit for one hour to soak clay; this will prevent the tequila for absorbing. Dump water and dip rim of cántaro in chamoy, followed by Tajin and fill with ice.
2. Combine the tequila, juice of half the orange, half the grapefruit, both limes, the sea salt and Squirt in the cántaro. Mix with bar spoon and garnish with slices of citrus.

title: Sprout’s Honor
intro_philosophy:
Ranch Water, the popular Texas cooler composed of tequila, lime and bubbly mineral water, is the inspiration for Mony Bunni’s Sprout’s Honor. This spiced and summery riff offers layers of flavor with the addition of fragrant basil and aromatic bitters; to top, Bunni swaps in Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale for the mineral water. “The sweetness from the clementine is a nice balance with the spice from both the ginger and cinnamon,” she says. “And with the baking spice of the Angostura, this highball delivers a slightly savory, cream soda quality.”

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Elvelo Blanco
3 ounces  Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale, chilled
instructions: 1. Add the basil leaves to a Collins glass and gently muddle.
2. Add the tequila, lime juice and bitters, then fill the glass with ice.
3. Top off with ginger ale and stir to combine ingredients.
4. Garnish with a fresh basil sprig.

title: Three Mile Island
intro_philosophy: In a literal interpretation of Don the Beachcomber’s dictum “What one rum can’t do, three rums can,”Sam Miller’s Three Mile Island, a smoked rum Old-Fashioned variation, blends three Barbados rums as the base. “What I love about this is we’re not actually using any wood to smoke the cocktail,” explains Miller, who opts instead to char dried orange peels, drawing out citrusy notes in the rum base.
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces Barbados rum blend (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce spiced blackstrap molasses syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Prepare Old-Fashioned glass by charring a dime-sized piece of dark chocolate and 1/2 dollar-sized dried orange peel and capturing the smoke in the glass.
2. Separately, combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
3. Strain into the prepared Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

title: High Horse
intro_philosophy: This cocktail pays homage to Giuseppe González’s Horse Apple, a mix of your spirit of choice, Granny Smith apple juice and freshly grated horseradish. The version served at Club Frills calls on a horseradish hydrosol and is force carbonated, so unless you have a home bar lab, you’ll need to go to Providence to get the real thing. To make a similar drink at home, however, owner Jesse Hedberg suggests using this recipe, which calls for seltzer and, like González’s original recipe, a horseradish garnish.
ingredients: 1 ounce Granny Smith Cordial (see Editor’s Note)
4 drops saline solution (1:5, salt to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except seltzer to a tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass, then top with seltzer.
3. Grate fresh horseradish over the top of the drink.

title: Holy Ground’s Pan American Clipper
intro_philosophy: This winter-friendly Clipper “is heavy on the Angostura element,” notes Holy Ground beverage director Nathan Lithgow. “It gives a bitter spice component, and helps balance out the citrus and absinthe.” Meanwhile, Calvados is the favored brandy for the drink, as it “gives a roundness and generosity of fruit.”
ingredients: ¼ ounce absinthe, preferably La Clandestine
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express the lemon peel and discard.

title: El Amargo
intro_philosophy: Ask the city’s bartenders and serious drinkers for their favorite watering hole, and they will most likely tell you “El Ocho.” “It’s the first bar to modernize the aperitivo, and it’s also the most democratic bar in the city,” explains Buenos Aires bartender Guillermo Blumenkamp. “People of all walks of life feel comfortable here, especially with Javier [Sosa] behind the bar.” El Amargo, a riff on the Old-Fashioned, is head bartender Javier Sosa’s signature drink, and also happens to be his nickname, The Bitter One.
instructions: 1. Mix together sugar, Fernet, vodka and Punt e Mes in an Old-Fashioned glass. Stir well.
2. Add ice. Stir again to chill.
3. Garnish with grapefruit peel.

title: Winter Lady
intro_philosophy: While the name might bring to mind the famousPink Lady, this Cognac and Curaçao-based drink was actually named for the Leonard Cohen song, though bartenderMatthew Schrage suggests that the both drinks will appeal to those who want “something a bit more warming in the winter time.” A riff on a traditional flip, the spicy Winter Lady gets its frothy texture not from egg white, but from a clever beer foam topper.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce allspice dram, preferably St. Elizabeth
1/2 ounce dry Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
Hefeweizen beer foam (see Editor's Note), to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the beer in a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake and strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
3. Top with beer foam.

title: Slow Down Shirley
intro_philosophy: Jim Kearns taps into quintessential East Coast fall flavors in his Slow Down Shirley: cranberry liqueur layered onto a base of apple brandy, with lemon and ginger adding brightness.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce apple brandy, preferably Laird's 7 1/2 year
1 1/2 ounces cranberry liqueur , preferably Clear Creek
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients except for soda and shake with ice.
2. Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass and top with soda.
3. Garnish with candied ginger.

title: Tennessee Nitro Martini
intro_philosophy: A rebel take on theEspresso Martini, this recipe from Team Lyan calls on Jack Daniel’s whiskey and cold brew coffee. Though it’s put through a nitrogen rig at Super Lyan, where it’s served on tap and settles like a pint of Guinness, this version is designed to be made at home using an iSi siphon.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably Jack Daniel's Old No. 7
1/2 ounce fake lime juice (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Mix all ingredients, chill and pour into an iSi syphon and charge with one cream charger.
2. Pour into a chilled coupette.

title: Sprite Syrup
intro_philosophy: Houston’s Michael Neff created this playful riff on a low-waste stock that also happens to taste like Sprite. At The Cottonmouth Club, Neff uses the Sprite syrup in a rye whiskey-based Long Lost Pal cocktail alongside dry vermouth and Bruto Americano. “Use this concentrate as you would simple syrup for a zesty, bright and citrusy addition to cocktails,” he says. “Or, to make ‘Sprite,’ combine one part concentrate with two parts Topo Chico and enjoy over ice or in a highball.”
ingredients: 2 cups halved and juiced lime husks
2 cups halved and juiced lemon husks
instructions: 1. Combine husks and piloncillo in an 8-quart Instant Pot or pressure cooker.
2. Add about 2 quarts of water to cover completely and cook under high pressure for 5 minutes.
3. Quick-release pressure, allow to cool and strain out solids.
4. Add the lemon juice, lime juice and orange blossom water.

title: Lulu at Le Monocle
intro_philosophy: At Friends and Family in Oakland, a case of unwanted cava turned into this riff on the Death in the Afternoon. Now a mainstay on the queer bar’s menu, the Lulu at Le Monocle pays homage to the absinthe-laced Hemingway drink while also referencing one of Friends and Family’s biggest influences—the 1930s Parisian lesbian nightclub called Le Monocle.
instructions: 1. Spritz a coupe several times with absinthe and fill it with crushed ice. Allow to chill for a couple minutes.
2. Dump the ice and add both bitters.
3. Top with the sparkling wine.
4. Using a channel knife, cut a long, thin piece of lemon peel, then carefully express it and drop it into the drink.

title: Audrey Saunders’ Ginger Syrup
intro_philosophy:
This is the ginger syrup recipe that evolved into Audrey Saunders’ ginger beer, a key component of the modern classicGin-Gin Mule.

Reprinted with permission fromThe New Craft of the Cocktailby Dale DeGroff, copyright © 2020. Published by Clarkson Potter, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 1 pound fresh ginger, peeled and julienned
instructions: 1. Combine the ginger, lime juice, sugar and water in a saucepan.
2. Simmer, do not boil, until sugar is dissolved.
3. Strain, let cool, then bottle.

title: Phantom Drift
intro_philosophy: This Ramos Gin Fizz variation is part of the new fall 2017 drink menu at gin-centric Whitechapel. A couple of dashes of pink peppercorn bitters lend a refreshing, savory touch to this creamy “aperitivo fizz.”
ingredients: 2 dashes pink peppercorn bitters (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the Prosecco in a mixing tin without ice, and shake well.
2. Add ice to the mixing tin, and shake again to chill.
3. Open the tin and pour in the Prosecco.
4. Double strain into a Collins glass without ice.
5. Twist an orange peel over the drink to express the essential oils, then discard the peel.
6. Garnish with cracked pink peppercorns.

title: Daiquiri #2
intro_philosophy: Originally created at El Floridita bar in Havana, the Daiquiri #2 dates back to the 1920s and sees the addition of both orange Curaçao and orange juice in addition to lime.
instructions: 1. Pour ingredients into shaker filled with ice cubes and crushed ice and shake
2. Fine strain the mixture into a chilled glass.
3. Garnish with orange twist.

title: Nordic Honey Punch
intro_philosophy: Alex Anderson’s clarified milk punch draws upon Scandinavian flavors, incorporating herbal-inflected aquavit and an aromatic garnish of dill.
ingredients: 4 ounces bianco vermouth, such as Dolin Blanc
2 ounces honey syrup (2:1, honey to water)
8 ounces aquavit, such as O.P. Anderson
instructions: 1. Combine the vermouth, Gran Classico and honey syrup in a pitcher. Whisk until the honey is incorporated.
2. Pour the milk into a pan and bring to a boil.
3. Turn off the stove and immediately add the lemon juice and stir. Let sit for 5 minutes, then add the aquavit.
4. Strain through a nut milk bag or cheesecloth into the pitcher with the vermouth mixture, then strain the entire mixture again.
5. Double-line a large coffee filter and strain the remaining liquid again.
6. Bottle and serve in a rocks glass over ice.
7. Garnish with dill sprig.

title: Porch Jammer
intro_philosophy: In this loose interpretation of a wet Martini,Mel Tatebrings some tropical elements to the formula by splitting the gin base with an agricole-style rum and adding a small amount of banana liqueur and lime bitters. “What I look for in a Martini [is] less traditional and more playful,” he says. The name comes from a New Orleans distillery, Porch Jam, which makes the rum used in his version of the drink. If you can’t find Cheramie, however, Tate suggests using a rhum agricole that is not too funky.
ingredients: 1 ounce agricole-style rum, such as Cheramie
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass.

title: Hana
intro_philosophy: “This cocktail shares my appreciation and respect for Japanese culture and how the Japanese community blends nature and artistry together,” saysManny Hernandez, cantinero at Stokes Adobe, “creating experiences that reflect a fusion of simplicity, elegance and beauty.” Drinking the Hana, which means “flower” in Japanese, is meant to evoke nature, slowing down and savoring. It’s floral, citrusy and creamy all at once.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Niwa homemade elixir (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express lemon oil over the drink, then discard.
4. Garnish with an edible flower.

title: Wilson
intro_philosophy: When faced with the task of choosing hisdesert islanddrink, Trick Dog’s Morgan Schick takes a practical approach, building this drink directly in a coconut. With coconut water, gin, lime and soda water, this tropical refresher is designed to ease the spirits of the lone castaway.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a coconut, a mug or a rocks glass and and stir to combine.
2. Fill the glass with ice and serve.

title: Baya Baya
intro_philosophy: Because Chambord is unrepentantly sweet, you’re easily able to swap it in for any simple syrup says Mikki Kristola, who favors it with dark rum in the colder months, particularly in a straightforward sour setup like her Baya Baya, a rum sour topped with sparkling wine.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the sparkling wine, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Top with sparkling wine.
4. Garnish with a dehydrated orange chip.

title: Chris Hannah’s French 75
intro_philosophy: Chris Hannah’s take on the classic, which is served at Arnaud’s French 75 Bar, sticks with Cognac, rather than gin, and adjusts the 50-50 measure of sour and sweet for an overall drier cocktail.
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces brut Champagne, preferably Moët & Chandon Impérial
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a tulip Champagne glass.
3. Top with Champagne.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Golden Swan Martini
intro_philosophy: Inspired by a 50/50 Martini, absent gin or vodka, the Golden Swan Martini combines an ounce and a half of mezcal with an equal measure of liqueurs, split between pineapple liqueur and Ancho Reyes Verde, a green poblano liqueur. “It’s similar to a 50/50 Martini where the herbs and spices of vermouth support a London dry gin in harmony,” explains head bartender Andy May. “These highly specific ingredients build on one another in the same way.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, preferably Agave de Cortés
3/4 ounce pineapple liqueur, preferably Giffard Caribbean Pineapple
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a skewered piparra.

title: Misticollins
intro_philosophy: AtPapa San, a Nikkei izakaya, the drinks reflect a mix of influences from Japan and Latin America. The Misticollins, built on sake and mezcal, is a perfect showcase. Its star ingredient is a savory, bittersweet syrup that combines purple Peruvian olives with Japanese cucumbers, offering the cocktail its signature tang.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces nigori sake, such as Daimon Road to Osaka
1/2 ounce Peruvian olive and Japanese cucumber syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1 dash simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except for the tonic water to a shaker, and shake with ice.
2. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
3. Top with tonic water.

title: Anu Apte’s Godfather
intro_philosophy: Seattle’s Anu Apte makes the case for the Godfather as one of the most underrated classics. “It’s one of my favorite simple yet often-overlooked after-dinner drinks,” she says. This recipe can be adjusted, with more or less peat in the Scotch depending “on my mood and/or what I had for dinner,” and more or less amaretto, depending on the Scotch. Creating a “Godfather–Old-Fashioned mashup,” Apte also sometimes adds a couple dashes of Angostura bitters to the mix.
ingredients: 1/8 ounce (bar spoon) to 1/4 ounce amaretto, depending on the Scotch
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a double Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Stir for 10 seconds.

title: Alicia Perry’s Amaretto Sour
intro_philosophy: Taking second place inour ultimate Amaretto Sour blind tasting, Alicia Perry’s recipe splits the amaretto quotient between Lazzaroni and Adriatico Bianco, a drier, creamier take on the category. Woodford Reserve bourbon, simple syrup, lemon juice and egg white round out the recipe, which the judges found to be citrus-forward, almost like a creamy Italian ice.
ingredients: 1 egg white or 1 ounce liquid egg
3/4 ounce Woodford Reserve Kentucky Straight Bourbon
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry-shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass, then express a lemon twist over the drink.

title: Cheng’s Neapolitan Fizz
intro_philosophy: This over-the-top ice cream cake of a cocktail takes inspiration from the classic flavors found in the three layers of Neapolitan ice cream, with Cynar standing in for chocolate, Frangelico for vanilla and Campari for strawberry. The soda fountain stylings are complete with fresh citrus juices, strawberry syrup and rich cream, finished with a shake of birthday cake sprinkles.
instructions: 1. Combine egg white, heavy whipping cream, lemon juice, orange juice, strawberry syrup, Campari and Frangelico in a cocktail shaker.
2. Dry shake (without ice) to emulsify the ingredients, then add ice and shake vigorously until chilled.
3. Add soda water to the bottom of a chilled Collins glass, then fine-strain three-quarters of the shaken ingredients over the soda water.
4. Allow to sit for 3 minutes, then pour the Cynar into the Collins glass. (It will sink to the bottom.)
5. Top with the remaining blend in the cocktail shaker.
6. Garnish with birthday cake sprinkles.

title: Take Your Time
intro_philosophy: “My challenge…was to create a refreshing crusher, that could go on the menu atSportsman’s Club” explains Mony Bunni of the prompt given to her during the Heaven Hill Bartender of the Year regionals that lead to the creation of this spin on abuck. Built on a bourbon base, Take Your Time gets its spicy kick from Domaine de Canton ginger liqueur, while mango syrup acts as the sweetener and Topo Chico provides a sparkling finish.
ingredients: 1 ounce bourbon, preferably Elijah Craig Small Batch
1 ounce ginger liqueur, preferably Domaine de Canton
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Topo Chico, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a collins glass over ice.
3. Garnish with mint sprig and Elemakule Tiki Bitters.

title: La Quebrada Spritz
intro_philosophy: Austin Hartman’s crema de mezcal-based take on the spritz draws inspiration from Hartman’s grandfather, a cliff-diver in Acapulco—the essence of danger and finesse distilled into an at-once delicate and bracing drink.
instructions: 1. Express grapefruit twist and place at the bottom of an empty wine glass.
2. Add five ice cubes.
3. Combine mezcal, Aperol and grapefruit juice in a tin and shake.
4. Double-strain into wine glass over ice.
5. Top with sparkling wine.

title: Neon City
intro_philosophy: In this playful highball,Nine Barowners Lily Wang and Joe Briglio channel the flavors of one of their favorite summertime treats: Italian ice, albeit with some unexpected additions. Wang and Briglio describe Nine Bar as an “Asian-ish cocktail bar,” and the Neon City exemplifies their approach with its shochu base, complemented by measures of sake, Calpico and baijiu. It all comes together to form a layered foundation to which aperitivo liqueur and fresh lemon juice bring the expected tangy citrus notes of the drink’s inspiration. Wang describes it as “refreshing, a little funky and pleasantly tart.”
ingredients: 1 ounce shochu, preferably Mizu Saga barley shochu
3/4 ounce sake, preferably Joto Yuzu sake
1/2 ounce aperitivo liqueur, preferably St. Agrestis Paradiso
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Topo Chico, in a highball glass with ice.
2. Top with Topo Chico.
3. Garnish with an orange slice.

title: Salad Bar Martini
intro_philosophy: This cocktail fromCutiesis not just a tomato Martini, despite the flavor’s top billing (here, it shows up both in a clarified tomato water and an Italian tomato gin). It’s got layers, between salty manzanilla sherry and Castelvetrano olive brine. It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces vodka, such as Bully Boy Seacoast
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, such as Dolin
1/4 ounce manzanilla sherry, such as La Cigarrera
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to chill.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a cherry tomato.

title: Ribs
intro_philosophy: A cross between anOld-Fashionedand aMint Julepnamed after the smell of BBQ, this recipe is a modified version of the drink served at White Lyan. The drink is pre-diluted and can be poured straight from the rerfrigerator into a chilled glass with a lemon twist. No ribs were harmed in making of this.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a sealable container and store in the refrigerator.
2. Pour into a chilled rocks glass when ready to serve.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Anisette Frappé
intro_philosophy: “It’s a late-afternoon pick-me-up rather than a wind-down after dinner,” explains Jon Mullen of his Anisette Frappé, which is served alongside a shot of espresso and a glass of sparkling water at Bar Pisellino. As such, it clocks in at a lower ABV than a traditional Absinthe Frappé, and, though minimally garnished (“I don’t fall into tiki, it’s not overly done”), it conveys meticulous attention to detail in its presentation—a signature of Mullen’s entire output.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cordial glass filled with crushed ice.
2. Stir briefly and top with more crushed ice.
3. Serve with a straw, a side of espresso and sparkling water.

title: Dante’s Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: The flagship drink at Dante is named after Italian revolutionary Giuseppe Garibaldi, who was a central figure in the unification of Italy. Its two ingredients—Campari from the north acting as a nod to the red shirts worn by Garibaldi’s freedom fighters and bright orange representing Sicily to the south—are symbolic of its heritage.
instructions: 1. Build the Campari and orange juice in a small highball glass filled with ice.
2. Stir and garnish with the orange wedge.

title: The Bishop of Terni
intro_philosophy: Bill Brooks, beverage director at NYC’s Resto, reduces Manischewitz into a fruity syrup for this ruby-hued drink. It’s not at all sweet, but “that juicy grape flavor helps tame the green, vegetal notes of sotol,” Brooks notes.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake vigorously until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Garnish with a pea tendril.

title: Chuncho Cooler
intro_philosophy: “If you’re tapped-out on beer or cider,” proposes Michael Phillips, of Austin’s Midnight Cowboy, “this cocktail is a great alternative.” Galliano’s herbal vanilla notes complement the floral nose of Chilean pisco, its sweetness is tempered by ginger and lime. The best part? It can be built right in the glass.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients save for the soda and pour into a Collins glass. Or, build directly in the glass.
2. Top with club soda.

title: Ginger Spice
intro_philosophy: “When a guest asks for ginger, I love it,” says Sweet Liberty’s co-owner John Lermayer, “It has always been one of my favorite flavors to play with in the development of drinks.” In his Ginger Spice, Lermayer and bartender Chris Hopkins build off their current passion for all things tiki and rum-based, adding a cube of peeled ginger root to up the spice in this tropical blend of rum, yellow chartreuse, lime and sweeteners. Set over a bed of crushed ice, this so-called “vacation drink” is the perfect antidote to the South Beach climate.
ingredients: 1x1 inch cube of peeled ginger root
instructions: 1. Muddle ginger in base of mixing tin.
2. Add remaining ingredients and shake with cubed ice.
3. Fine strain into tiki mug and top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a ginger slice and lime wheel.

title: Oloroso and Cheerwine
intro_philosophy: Throughout its history, Trick Dog has always featured at least one highball on its fixed menu. This drink, which was created when, during the pandemic, the bar transformed into Quick Dog (to-go, get it?), is a great example of the team’s creativity even in a two-ingredient format. This marries savory, nutty oloroso sherry with a regional cherry soda from North Carolina called Cheerwine, whose flavor has been likened to Dr Pepper.
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a beer mug filled with ice.
2. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Whitechapel’s Ford Cocktail
intro_philosophy: In Whitechapel’s Ford Cocktail, Keli Rivers combines Old Tom gin withblanc vermouthand a splash ofBénédictinefor a cocktail that drinks like aMartini, but with more complexity and crucially, fewer preconceptions.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Old Tom gin, preferably Jensen
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Express an orange peel over the drink and discard.

title: Donna Reed
intro_philosophy: Much like the legend of theNegroni Sbagliato, Sarah Morrissey’s own spin on the Italian classic was born from a fortuitous mistake. While experimenting with Kalani coconut liqueur during service, she filled an order for aNegroniwithout rinsing the jigger, which allowed some of the coconut flavor to seep in. “Ba-zing!” recalls Morrissey. “It was delicious.” From there, she played around with the formula, ultimately calling on a quarter-ounce of coconut liqueur alongside a quarter-ounce of sweet vermouth to bolster the traditional Campari and gin base. In a nod to the original happy accident, the Donna Reed is served with asidecarof Champagne.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
Champagne, to serve as a sidecar
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the Champagne, in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.
4. Serve with a sidecar of Champagne.

title: Jamaican Mule
intro_philosophy:
With a particular interest in house-made syrups and infusions, it’s not uncommon for Jelani Johnson’s original tiki drinks to incorporate elaborate components, like quatre épices syrup, inspired by the four-spice blend often called for in French cooking, or a coconut-orgeat blend. Here he takes a decidedly more straightforward approach, calling on what he dubs his “favorite tried-and-true flavor combo.” Building off a base of Jamaican rum, he adds the ginger and lime components of a classic mule, along with a good dose of fresh pineapple juice and a finishing touch of Angostura bitters.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 2 ounces aged Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton Estate V/X
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ½ cup crushed ice and shake for about 5 seconds.
3. Pour the contents of the shaker into a pilsner glass filled with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with candied ginger on a pick, a lime wheel, and an edible orchid.

title: Nikita
intro_philosophy: On Madeira, the Nikita is commonly made with pineapple ice cream, beer and wine. The ice cream is one that’s produced especially for the drink. It’s sweet, with a subtle vanilla and a concentrated pineapple flavor. Off the island, you can make a rough substitute with vanilla ice cream and fresh pineapple. This drink is best served with a dentinho, or a small snack, such as peanuts.
ingredients: 3 ounces light lager, such as Coral
3 ounces vinho verde or any white wine
instructions: 1. In a blender or using a hand mixer, process the pineapple. Add the ice cream, then fold to mix until just combined. Return to the freezer if the mixture has melted.

2. In a small pitcher, combine the pineapple ice cream mixture, beer and white wine, stirring and mashing with a wooden spoon until well-combined. It should have the density and texture of a milkshake.
3. Pour into two small mugs with straws and serve immediately.

title: Absinthe Colada
intro_philosophy: One of bartender Maxwell Britten’s favorite pastimes is drinkingPiña Coladas. So when he joined the absinthe and oyster barMaison Premierein Brooklyn, he took the opportunity to incorporate an absinthe-infused variation. After workshopping the original drink with fellow bartender Natasha David, they came up with a version that included mint-heavy Germain-Robin absinthe from California, which wasn’t widely available enough to continue using. Britten reworked this version to include a Swiss verte-style absinthe, rhum agricole and cool crème de menthe alongside the classic base of coconut and pineapple.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce rhum agricole, such as Rhum J.M Blanc 80
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over crushed ice into a Collins or hurricane glass.
4. Garnish with a bouquet of mint.

title: Toby Cecchini’s Boulevardier
intro_philosophy: The Boulevardier has been on the menu since the opening ofThe Long Island Barin 2013. “I tried to take if off the menu after six months and people screamed bloody murder,” saysToby Cecchini. Often credited with exhuming the recipe from obscurity, Cecchini’s version calls on two full ounces ofrye, split between Rittenhouse and Old Overholt, and a split vermouth component to keep every element in balance with the Campari.
ingredients: 1 ounce Old Overholt Straight Rye Whiskey
1 ounce Long Island Bar house vermouth blend (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Javelle Taft’s 50/50 Martini
intro_philosophy: Javelle Taft’s 50/50 Martini was “dancing in all the right ways,” according to Pouring Ribbons’ Joaquín Simó inour tastingof 11 different recipes.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces navy-strength gin, such as Cadenhead’s Old Raj Dry Gin 110 proof
1 1/2 ounces dry vermouth, such as Dolin
1 dash orange bitters, such as a 1:1 blend of Regans' and Angostura orange
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a V-shaped Martini glass or a coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Pablo Moix’s Ti’ Punch
intro_philosophy: Pablo Moix of Dama in Los Angeles came in second in our recent blind tasting of Ti’ Punches. His recipe calls for a lime disk covered with a scant barspoon of Petite Canne Sugar Cane Syrup (a brand of cane syrup from Martinique) to be pressed a bit with the spoon before two-and-a-quarter ounces of La Favorite rhum agricole is added.
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces rhum agricole, preferably La Favorite blanc
1 scant bar spoon Petite Canne sugar cane syrup
instructions: 1. Drop the lime disk into an Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Add the cane syrup.
3. Using a bar spoon, press on the lime disk and mix it well with the syrup.
4. Add the rhum and serve.

title: Leña
intro_philosophy: “This cocktail is inspired by two of my favorite drinks: a spicy Margarita and a Jungle Bird,” saysRicardo Rodriguez,bar manager ofLitaandLa Otra. Here, he combines both tequila and mezcal with spicy Ancho Reyes Verde chile liqueur and the bitterness of gentian liqueur alongside pineapple and lime juices. “My kitchen background has taught me to appreciate contrasting but complementary flavors, and this cocktail achieves that balance in an approachable way,” he says.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mezcal, such as Del Maguey Vida
1/2 ounce bitter gentian liqueur, such as Luxardo Bitter Bianco
1/2 ounce agave syrup (combine equal parts agave nectar and hot water)
1/4 ounce Ancho Reyes Verde chile liqueur
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with Tajín and set aside.
2. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a pineapple half-wheel.

title: House No. 3
intro_philosophy: Vince Bright’s House No. 3 is one of a dozen so-called house cocktails that he’s been experimenting with over the years in his time off. Inspired by an unusual pairing of Scotch and salt that he encountered in a drink at Realm of the 52 Remedies, a San Diego cocktail bar, he landed on this original recipe that reads like a Rob Roy mixed with a Bamboo, by way of the tropics. To the Scotch base, he adds amontillado and manzanilla sherries, adding a note of salinity, as well as blanc and dry vermouths. But according to Bright, the key ingredient is actually the smallest one: a teaspoon of coconut water syrup. “It adds a little bit of salinity from the coconut, and just a touch of sweetness to bring everything together.”
ingredients: 1 teaspoon coconut water syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Rather Cavalier
intro_philosophy: Created while working at a neighborhood restaurant, The Sycamore, the Rather Cavalier was designed to be an approachable introduction to mezcal. “At the time, we had all of these things here [on the backbar] and none of the staff knew what any of them were for so it was sort of my excuse to play with them all and educate the staff at the same time,” says Annie Williams Pierce. Here, she combines the slightly smokey, rich profile of Mezcal Vago Elote, an espadin mezcal infused with roasted corn, withpamplemousseliqueur and dry vermouth, which, in keeping with her signature style, adds a subtle vegetal note to the minimalist stirred cocktail.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  mezcal, preferably Mezcal Vago Elote
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Ransom Dry Vermouth
1/4 ounce citric acid solution (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed grapefruit peel.

title: Champ-Ale
intro_philosophy: Ticonderoga Club is Punch’sIndustry Icon of 2025. This drink is one of the bar’s off-menu serves. Named for a somewhat maligned sparkling malt liquor, the Champ-Ale is a beer cocktail by way of thesuppressor: vermouth, lemon and cane syrup shaken and poured over sparkling wine and Genesee cream ale.
ingredients: 2 ounces light beer, such as Genesee cream ale
1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, such as Carpano Classico
1/2 ounce cane syrup (2:1, cane sugar to water)
instructions: 1. In a 12-ounce glass, pour the beer and wine, then add ice.
2. In a shaker tin, add the rest of the ingredients and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the glass.
4. Gently mix with a barspoon to incorporate the ingredients.
5. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Mezpresso Martini
intro_philosophy: Making coffee with coconut water instead of water makes a subtle difference, but according to Jay Sanders, it “changes the exhale of the drink,” and “fills in the gaps in the flavor” and texture. Together with mezcal, agave nectar and banana, a coconut water cold brew shines in Wild Child’s bestselling cocktail, this funky Espresso Martini.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces coconut water–steeped cold brew (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.

title: Coffey Pot
intro_philosophy: Time spent in Barbados inspired Orlando Franklin McCray’s take on a rum and tonic with the added splash of grapefruit liqueur. The name of the drink comes from its base ingredient of Probitas rum, which is made from a blend of Coffey still rums, from Barbados, and pot still rums, from Jamaica. “Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic features angostura bark on the nose, but not so much on the palate, and avoids the astringency which may be apparent when adding traditional aromatic bitters to tonic water,” says McCray. A final tip from McCray: “Additionally, y’all should put a straw in this so as not to get the shaved lime up your nose.”
instructions: 1. Add the Probitas rum and Bittermens Citron Sauvage to a chilled Collins glass over ice.
2. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water and lightly stir.
3. Garnish with manicured lime strings by running a zest peeler over the skin of a lime and serve with a straw.

title: PX Sweet Tea
intro_philosophy: Simply sherry, sugar and citrus, shaken, poured over crushed ice and slurped through a straw, the originalSherry Cobbleris thought to have originated sometime in the 1820s or early 1830s. But like most 19th century drinks, its origins are foggy. This black tea and PX sherry infused version is Derek Brown’s play on the original.
ingredients: 2 ounces PX sherry (preferably Gonzalez Byass Nectar)
instructions: 1. Add sherry and black tea to a highball glass.
2. Top with crushed ice and swizzle to mix.
3. Garnish with seasonal berries and mint.

title: Flatliner
intro_philosophy: Silky and frothy,Telluride, Colorado’s unofficial cocktailbears resemblance to the Espresso Martini and to the Mudslide. But to the ski town’s residents, it’s a local classic. Though bartender Steve Foster first served the drink at The Peaks Resort & Spa, the recipe—and its legacy—has spread throughout the city. Today, you’ll find Foster shaking Flatliners at New Sheridan Chop House.
ingredients: 1 shot espresso or 1 ounce cold-brew coffee
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker tin filled with ice and shake.
2. Strain into a coupe, then garnish with the coffee beans.

title: MARTINI & ROSSI® Vermuttino
intro_philosophy: The aperitivo does not need to be complicated. Consider the Vermuttino, a simple combination of MARTINI & ROSSI Ambrato Vermouth di Torino mingled with soda water over ice and garnished with caper berries or a lime slice. Dry, spicy and bittersweet in equal measure, it’s the epitome of early eveningsprezzatura.
ingredients: 1 ounce  MARTINI & ROSSI Riserva Speciale Ambrato Vermouth
instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice.
2. Combine Ambrato and soda water.
3. Stir gently.
4. Garnish with caper berry or a lime slice.

title: Dirty Spritz
intro_philosophy: This spritz variation from bartender Michael Timmons gets a welcome dose of salinity in the form of olive brine. “I wanted to create a spritz variation that was bright and refreshing but had elements of a savory texture simultaneously,” he says.
instructions: 1. Build the drink in a highball glass filled with ice.
2. Garnish with a lemon twist and olive.

title: Fiore di Francia
intro_philosophy: Ezra Star found inspiration in the food encountered along the Italian and French border, where the cuisine belong wholly to neither culture. Italian artichoke amaro, Cynar, joins forces with St-Germain in a nod to the border zone where elderflower grows freely.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Express the lemon peel and discard.

title: Mezcal Mule
intro_philosophy:
In this take on amule—a lime and ginger based drink—Jim Meehan, of New York’sPDT, was set on developing a cocktail for Richard Betts ofSombra Mezcal. “When I went about conceiving this drink, I wanted to use a lot of traditional Oaxacan flavors,” says Meehan. “Passion fruit and agave are widely available there, and the vegetal notes of the cucumber, plus the spice of the ginger are both akin to mezcal.” PDT uses a house-made ginger beer to create the spicy lime-laced backdrop for the smoky mezcal and bright fruit notes.

Reprinted with permission fromThe PDT Cocktail Book© 2011 by Jim Meehan, Sterling Epicure an imprint of Sterling Publishing Co., Inc.
ingredients: 1 ounce ginger beer, PDT's house recipe
instructions: 1. Add cucumber slices and agave nectar to a mixing glass and muddle.
2. Add all other ingredients, add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a chilled rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a slice of cucumber, a piece of candied ginger and dust gently with chili powder.

title: Saffron Freezer Martini
intro_philosophy: This recipe centers around a saffron-infused gin, paired with both dry and blanc vermouth. The latter contributes subtle perceived sweetness and body to the drink, according to bartenders who have served their own takes on the saffron Martini. With its opulent infusion, this freezer Martini makes the perfect gift for hosts or a treat to share around the holiday table.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a liter-sized bottle.
2. Shake briefly to integrate, then place in the freezer for at least 2 hours.
3. When ready to serve, pour into a chilled cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a choice of lemon, olive or caper berry.

title: Shady Grove
intro_philosophy: Jon Mullen’s Shady Grove imagines an aperitivo twist on the Paloma, with a brief layover in France—what he dubs a “Palomaperitivo.” He achieves this by mixing together silky bianco vermouth with the bitter French gentian liqueurSuzeand Calvados, though you can also sub in another clear spirit with fruity or vegetal qualities, such as tequila, gin or rhum agricole.
ingredients: 1 1/3 ounces  bianco vermouth, such as Bordiga Vermouth Bianco
3/4 ounce Calvados, such as Roger Groult 3
2 1/2 ounces grapefruit soda, such as Fever-Tree Sparkling Grapefruit (chilled)
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the grapefruit soda in a mixing tin filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled, and fine-strain into a Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Top with grapefruit soda.

title: Geb’s Reviver
ingredients: 3/4 ounce pineapple-lemon oleo saccharum (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Pour into a rocks glass over ice.

title: Piña De Mi Corazon
intro_philosophy: For this drink, Los Angeles bar manager Cari Hah turns totepache, a Mexican fermented beverage made using the rind and pulp of the pineapple, for inspiration. “I like the idea of using something that is considered waste to create a component of the cocktail,” says Hah, whose mulled punch combines homemade tepache and pineapple juice simmered with allspice, star anise, cinnamon, cloves, black pepper and cardamom. It’s then combined with El Tesoro™ Reposado Tequila. “El Tesoro™ Reposado has a beautiful balance of barrel influence while still keeping a full agave flavor,” says Hah. “The honey, vanilla and caramel notes that the light aging lends to the agave flavor melds perfectly with the spices in this cocktail.” While name of the drink means “the pineapple of my heart” it’s also a play on thepiña, the heart of the agave plant, giving it a double meaning: “The heart of my heart.” For Hah, that would be tequila.
ingredients: 4 parts  Hot Ponche Mix (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. To an Irish Coffee mug or 6-ounce tempered glass, add the El Tesoro™ Reposado Tequila.
2. Top with a ladle full of Hot Ponche Mix.
3. Garnish with freshly grated cinnamon.

title: Chink in the Armor
intro_philosophy:
Kirk Estopinal’sGunshop Fizzwas a rule-breaking cocktail for its inclusion of two full ounces—not dashes—of Peychaud’s Bitters. Here, the Chink in the Armor calls for 14 drops of Bittermens Xocolatl Mole Bitters in a cocktail that Estopinal calls “a nod to malted milk balls.”

Recipe excerpt from the new bookCure: New Orleans Drinks and How to Mix ’Emby Neal Bodenheimer and Emily Timberlake, published by Abrams. Photography © 2022 by Denny Culbert.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir to chill.
2. Strain into a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass filled with ice.
3. Garnish with a pigtailed lemon twist.

title: Branded Man
intro_philosophy: An unexpectedly tropical take on the Sazerac, Denver’s Alex Jump uses the rich warming spices in Knob Creek®Rye to play off the banana, pineapple, hazelnut and coconut notes found in the two rums and hazelnut eau de vie. It’s a drink that bounces between a brisk fall day in New Orleans and summer in the tropics, while always highlighting the versatility and complexity of the rye.
ingredients: ¼ part  Hamilton Pot Still Gold Jamaican rum
¼ part  Reisetbauer hazelnut eau de vie
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Express a lemon twist and discard.

title: Smoky Coconut-Mango Salt
intro_philosophy: Toasting mild pulla chili pepper unleashes a charred, fruity flavor that falls into perfect harmony when paired with mango, coconut and lime. Use this salt as a rim on spicy Margaritas, Daiquiris and more.
ingredients: 3 tablespoons crushed sweetened, toasted coconut chips
instructions: 1. Toast the chili in a small sauté pan over medium heat, turning occasionally until lightly charred, 3 minutes.
2. De-stem and de-seed the chili, and add to the spice grinder along with the coconut and mango.
3. Pulse to grind into a powder.
4. Stir together with the salts and lime zest.

title: Margarita Remix
intro_philosophy: “This is a fun, salty take on the classic,” says Wilson of her Tommy’s Margarita variation elevated by a salted citrus cordial. Rich simple syrup stands in for agave nectar: “I found through trial and error that a rich simple syrup was the way to go to support all the flavors I was trying to highlight,” she notes.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  salted citrus cordial  (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce  rich simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain over fresh ice into a double Old-Fashioned glass.

3. Use a match or small torch to burn one end of the cinnamon stick until fragrant. Twist a swath of grapefruit peel over the drink to express the essential oils. Cut the grapefruit swath into a narrow ribbon, and use it to tie a knot around the cinnamon stick.

title: Emoliente Piteado
intro_philosophy:
A hot herbal brew derived from 19th-century tisanes, the emoliente became “piteado” when Lima’s street vendors spiked the warming drink with aguardiente. Though the emoliente base varies, the main ingredients are toasted barley, fruit and fresh herbs. At Lima bar La Emolientería, Luis Aquije throws the emoliente with pisco, lime juice and simple syrup, serving it hot in the winter and cold in the summer.

Note: For a Hot Toddy–like drink, use just 6 ounces of emoliente and halve the amounts of pisco, simple syrup and lime juice.
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a tin.
2. Throw the cocktail between two tins a few times to mix and aerate.
3. Pour into a tall glass (with ice if the emoliente is cold).
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: MARTINI & ROSSI® Italian Spritz
intro_philosophy: A cornerstone of the aperitivo canon, the Italian Spritz is everything the occasion calls for: bittersweet, bubbly and effortless. The combination of sunset-red  MARTINI & ROSSI Bitter Liqueur swirled together with  MARTINI & ROSSI Asti Italian sparkling wine, garnished with an orange slice, sets the mood for any proper aperitivo hour.
ingredients: 3 ounces  MARTINI & ROSSI Asti Italian Sparkling Wine
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a wine glass with ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with an orange slice.

title: Fitty-Fitty Martini
intro_philosophy: TheMartinispent the better part of the ‘80s and ‘90s as a stripped-down, mostly-gin (or, gasp, vodka) version of itself. In an effort to reintroduce America to the joys of dry vermouth and orange bitters, Audrey Saunders created the sophisticated Fitty-Fitty cocktail at her New York City bar,Pegu Club.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat Extra Dry
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: The Cutter
intro_philosophy: When Ticonderoga Club guests request aPaper Plane, bartenderAlec Balesserves The Cutter, his take on the recipe that swaps house-made Campari for Aperol and house Amer Picon for Nonino, albeit in slightly modified proportions (he suggests off-the-shelf Campari and Amaro CioCiaro if making the recipe at home).
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces whiskey, preferably St. George B&E American
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Calamansi Spritz
intro_philosophy: Calamansi liqueuroffers a versatile way to incorporate the Filipino citrus, which can be difficult to source outside of its native country.“Lime [has] a dry, acrid flavor and lemon has a sweetness and florality. Adding calamansi gives you a more well-rounded picture of flavor, kind of like the lighter outlines in a painting,” says Kitty Bernardo, who uses the liqueur in theTiny Sparrow Martiniand this simple, Suze-spiked spritz.
ingredients: 4 ounces ginger beer (or 3 ounces soda plus 1 ounce tonic)
instructions: 1. Add the liqueurs to a highball glass and top with ice.
2. Stir about 10 revolutions, or until the ingredients are chilled and slightly diluted.
3. Top with the ginger beer or soda-tonic split.
4. Gently lift the ice from the bottom and stir for 2 to 3 revolutions to incorporate the ingredients without losing carbonation.
5. Garnish with fresh mint, a lime wedge and a grapefruit twist.

title: White Peach Sgroppino
intro_philosophy: In this updated take on the Sgroppino, Toby Cecchini calls for a summery white peach sorbet supplemented with peach liqueur for a fruit-forward intermezzo.
ingredients: 2 ounces white peach sorbet, roughly 2 scoops
1/2 ounce peach liqueur, preferably Giffard Créme de Pêche
instructions: 1. In a small bowl or mixing cup, gently whisk together the sorbet, vodka and peach liqueur so the sorbet does not melt.
2. Add a small amount of prosecco and stir to integrate.
3. Pour into a rocks glass.
4. Top with rest of prosecco, and gently stir to integrate.

title: Yuzu Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Legendary bartenderDale DeGroffdates this cocktail back to the late 1990s and early aughts when yuzu juice was a novelty ingredient purloined from the kitchen at the start of the culinary cocktail movement.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces dry gin, preferably Bombay white label
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and add ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with the lime wheel and shiso leaf.

title: Hibiscus Gin Sour 1.0
intro_philosophy: This twist on a classic gin sour made with hibiscus and chamomile is super refreshing and ideal for summer. Use it as a base to experiment with texture and mouthfeel by using soy lecithin in place of egg white as a modifier.
ingredients: 1 bar spoon 10 percent soy lecithin solution (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and blend with an immersion blender (or shake) until diluted.
2. Serve in a coupe.

title: Jocelyn Morin’s Manhattan
intro_philosophy: At Tern Club, a tropical bar in Knoxville, Tennessee, Jocelyn Morin uses “Herbstura” (equal parts Herbsaint and Angostura bitters) in tiki classics like the Zombie. At home, she finds the ingredient useful to add a quick hit of herbaceousness to simple drinks like a Manhattan.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Dolin Rouge
2 to 3 dashes Herbstura (1:1, Herbsaint liqueur to Angostura bitters)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Skyeway
intro_philosophy: “Pineapple and maraschino are a dream,” Lynch says of this tiki-leaning, smoky Scotch-based cocktail. A half-ounce of maraschino accentuates the pineapple: “This drink wouldn’t be the same without it,” Lynch vows.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Collins glass over pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Pink Lemonade à la Playboy
intro_philosophy:
In the 1971 edition ofPlayboy’s Host & Bar Bookby Thomas Mario, a recipe for a boozy pink lemonade peers out between a Pineapple Mint Cooler and a Pink Rum and Tonic (don’t ask). A rosé-based approximation of Playboy’s kitschy blueprint, this drink adds Giffard’s pink grapefruit liqueur for extra depth and texture. Soda water gives it that all-important sparkle.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail,with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Pour the rosé, lemon juice, orange juice, and liqueur into a Collins glass or large tumbler over ice.
2. Top with soda water and add the garnish.

title: The Herbivore
intro_philosophy: With its rich malty notes and botanical flavors, genever works well in both savory and bitter drinks. Juliet Ceballos, former General Manager at City House Nashville, plays on this idea by stirring it with cardamaro, green Chartreuse and celery bitters.
ingredients: 2 dashes celery bitters, preferably Bitter Truth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Stir, strain and serve up, in a coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Scotch Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: At the Scotch Lodge in Portland, Oregon, the Old-Fashioned is, understandably, made with Scotch. Its sweetener, meanwhile, is a sherry honey in lieu of the more classic bitters-soaked sugar cube or simple syrup. The easy-to-make ingredient brings spice and complexity to the classic.
ingredients: 2 ounces single malt Scotch, preferably Aberfeldy 12-Year
1/4 ounce sherry honey (2:1, honey to amontillado or oloroso sherry)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain over a big ice cube in a frozen glass.
3. Express a lemon peel over the drink.

title: Billy Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: At Billy Sunday, the house Old-Fashioned is the most popular cocktail on the menu. The simple variation is made with high-proof bourbon and gets the addition of smoky-sweet Zucca Rabarbaro. A well-executed Old-Fashioned is “the mark of a good bar or bartender,” according to the bar team, who suggest that the drink order acts as a litmus test.
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Muddle and stir, without ice, until sugar is dissolved.
3. Add bourbon and stir.
4. Pour into a glass over ice.
5. Express an orange peel over the cocktail, then discard.

title: Sandia Stormking
intro_philosophy: At the New Mexican restaurant Santa Fe BK in Brooklyn, the specialty Margarita program is named “The Seven,” with each Margarita corresponding to one of the geopolitical regions in George R. R. Martin’s “Game Of Thrones” series. (Martin is a New Mexico resident.) Sandia Stormking is a tribute to the book, as well as to bartender John Watterberg’s grandfather, whose weather monitoring station in Albuquerque was used to provide storm updates.
instructions: 1. Rim two glasses with red Chimayo chile salt, and add a large ice cube to each.
2. Add fruit, mint and sugar to a cocktail shaker, then muddle until ingredients are completely pulverized.
3. Add triple sec and top off with ice.
4. Add watermelon-infused tequila; it will fill the shaker to the brim.
5. Shake and strain into the prepared glasses.
6. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Silver and Sand
intro_philosophy: Blood & Sand, a private cocktail club, offers 10 variations on the classic cocktail for which it is named—and original aside, this is the most popular version. “Shake the crap out of it so you get a good froth,” advises founder and advisory board member, T.J. Vytlacil. “If you’re not sweating, you’re not doing it right.”
ingredients: 1 ounce lemon- and ginger-infused Scotch (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Cover and dry shake for 15 seconds, without ice.
3. Add ice, cover again and shake vigorously for 25 seconds.
4. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
5. Garnish with lemon twist and bitters.

title: Shoot the Moon
intro_philosophy: A key element of this Fords Gin-based riff on a Gin Old-Fashioned is that it’s made to minimize water waste. Instead of mixing with ice and then straining over fresh ice, the drink is stirred and served over the same ice. Even extra tools that would require washing—such as a mixing glass and strainer—are minimized.
ingredients: ½ ounce pear brandy, preferably Neversink Pear Brandy
¼ ounce  cinnamon syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a double Old-Fashioned glass, combine all ingredients with ice.
2. Stir until chilled and diluted.
3. Garnish with dehydrated pear and dust with cinnamon.

title: Rosa di Roma
intro_philosophy: Inspired by golden-hour aperitivo in Rome, Lucinda Sterling’s Rosa di Roma channels citrus by way of both Luxardo Bitter Bianco (which, she says, reminds her of the fragrance of oranges) and dryCuraçao. While the rich, savory notes of H by Hine Cognac shine through, it’s still floral and light on its feet.
ingredients: 1 ounce Cognac, preferably H by Hine
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Flaming Homer
intro_philosophy: The Simpsons’Flaming Homer is one of television’s greatest bar experiments. Necessity is the mother of invention, and when all the beer is gone, Homer creates his own cocktail. After mixing all the leftover spirits he can find (at least six bottles worth) into a blender, he tops it off with a bottle of Krusty’s (importantly “Non-Narkotik”) Kough Syrup. When Homer’s sister-in-law Patty accidentally ashes her cigarette into the drink it bursts into flames, and though Homer doesn’t know “the scientific explanation,” he does know that “fire made it good.” New York City bartender Matthew Belanger turned Homer’s fictional work of art into a real drink using cherry-forward Maurin Quina to (safely) mirror cough syrup and a rum-soaked lime shell to create a vessel for pre-sipping flames.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Flor de Caña 7 year rum
1/4 ounce Smith and Cross Jamaican rum
1 teaspoon Tempus Fugit Crème de Noyaux
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a tiki mug over crushed ice.
4. Invert a half lime shell and set atop the cocktail to garnish.
5. Add a sugar cube atop the lime shell and soak with a splash of overproof rum.
6. Carefully light the sugar cube and let it burn.
7. Blow out the fire before attempting to take a sip.

title: Nogave Syrup
intro_philosophy: TheTocayo cocktailat Mírate in Los Angeles is a conversation-starter in a glass. From the Mexican mole base to the garnish—a whole cricket, glossy and golden, perched on a big rock—the drink always elicits a reaction. But if there’s one ingredient bartender Max Reis hopes will spark curiosity among his guests, it’s this ingredient, his proprietary “nogave” syrup, which he calls his “sustainable answer to agave.”
ingredients: 280 milliliters (400 grams) orange blossom honey (or coconut blossom nectar, for a vegan alternative)
instructions: 1. Add the water to a blender and turn on low. Slowly add the sugar.
2. When the sugar has dissolved, add the honey and blend until smooth.
3. Test the syrup’s Brix (a measure of sweetness) and adjust recipes accordingly. (For a Tommy’s Margarita, for example, use a 50-Brix syrup). Keeps, refrigerated, for 3 months.

title: Cure’s Sazerac
intro_philosophy:
Second place inour 2024 Sazerac blind tastingwent to this version, appropriately hailing from the birth city of the drink.At New Orleans’ Cure, the evolution of the house Sazerac began well before the bar opened in 2009.

For precision and consistency, Cure relies on drops from a medicine dropper instead of dashes, which can vary based on the dasher opening and fullness of the bottle. Specifically, they landed on 23 drops, roughly the equivalent of three dashes.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce rich Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Spritz the Herbsaint from an atomizer into the interior of a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Combine the rye, Demerara syrup and bitters in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir to chill.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.
4. Garnish with the lemon peel.

title: Bentley Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Though seemingly French on paper, the Bentley is a thoroughly English cocktail. Named after the British luxury auto maker, its smart, simple makeup is remarkably modest. Served by Harry Craddock at the Savoy Hotel, the drink is closely associated with the “Bentley Boys,” a larger-than-life race team that won international fame for a series of dramatic Le Mans victories throughout the 1920s.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces calvados, preferably Roger Groult 3 Year Old
3 dashes orange bitters, preferably AZ Bitters Lab Orange Sunshine Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Adelita
intro_philosophy: At Boston’s The Hawthorne, divisive (and oft-forgotten) spirit Crème de Violette is sometimes used in small doses to “accent other flavors and contribute additional complexity to our drinks,” says bar manager Jared Sadoian. In this cocktail—inspired by the courageous women of the Mexican Revolution forever canonized in the folk ballad, “La Adelita”—the violet liqueur adds a note of soft florality to the strong combination of reposado and bittersweet Cocchi Americano.
ingredients: 1 ounce reposado tequila, preferably Siete Leguas Reposado
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients together in a mixing glass.
2. Serve up, in a coupe.

title: In Fashion
intro_philosophy: Nearly stomped out of existence by its fruity mid-20th century counterpart, the trueOld-Fashionedis as traditional as they come: a simple mix of spirits, sugar, bitters and water, which appears in 1806 as the first printed recipe for a cocktail (“cock tail”). Greg Best (formerly ofHoleman & Finchin Atlanta) fashioned a contemporary version of the cocktail’s most classic format using a 12-year-old bourbon, rich Martinique cane syrup, a healthy dose of bitters and an unexpected float of smoky mezcal.
ingredients: 2 ounces bourbon, preferably Old Medley 12 Year
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, muddle the cane syrup and lemon peel with the bitters.
2. Add bourbon and large chunk of ice.
3. Stir until chilled.
4. Using a bar spoon, float mezcal over top.
5. Garnish with an expressed lemon peel.

title: Polka Dot Negroni
intro_philosophy: Like all good stories should, the one about theNegroni‘s origin involves rakish Italian nobility. Most accounts credit the recipe to one Count Negroni, a swashbuckling proto-boho who reportedly spent time as a rodeo cowboy in the United States. Compounding his wild ways, legend has it that back at a bar in Italy in 1919, he asked for a something like anAmericano, but boozier. Swap gin for soda water, and presto, the Negroni. This version switches traditional sweet vermouth for Dolin Blanc, a sweet white vermouth, and instead of the bitter twang of Campari, Maloney uses a gentian apéritif wine and grapefruit bitters.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Express a lemon twist over top, discard and garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Agave Gracias
intro_philosophy: The inspiration for Christine Wiseman’s Agave Gracias cocktail started withpiloncillo, a rich, unrefined cane sugar from Latin America. In her Old-Fashioned variation, she adds Braulio for its “rich, refreshing, bitter backbone” and rounds out the Latin American inspiration with mezcal. “I love to work with amari because of the complexity of each one,” says Wiseman. “By simply adding a half-ounce of amaro to a cocktail, you can completely change the vibe and energy of the drink.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over one large ice cube or several smaller ice cubes.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Sailor’s Sunset
intro_philosophy: The Sailor’s Sunset is named for the saying, “Red sky at night, sailor’s delight.” In sailing lore, a crimson sunset is a harbinger of good sailing weather the following day. This tall, gingery drink follows the formula for another drink born at sea, theDark ‘n’ Stormy, except with the addition of grapefruit juice and bitter red Campari. Or you could look at it like a rum Collins, but with lime instead of lemon and ginger soda instead of plain. Either way, it’s a drinker’s delight.
instructions: 1. Add rum, Campari, lime juice, grapefruit juice and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with ginger soda and garnish with a crystallized ginger slice.

title: Chirulín
intro_philosophy: A centuries-old pisco-based cocktail, the Chirulín combines pisco, pomelo and cinnamon-spiced simple syrup, served on the rocks with a pomelo wedge and cinnamon stick. At its birthplace of El Ingenio, generations of Afro-descendant Peruvians have batched it in jarras, and sipped it from communal cups. In Lima, Tatiana Flores’ shaken version swaps pomelo for grapefruit and adds lime juice to increase acidity, which appeals to fans of sours like the Paloma, Brown Derby or Greyhound.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce cinnamon rich simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake hard until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass with ice.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit wedge and a cinnamon stick.

title: Gin Coco No. 2
intro_philosophy: At Tern Club, a tropical bar in Knoxville, Tennessee, the Gin Coco No. 2 is the ultimate crowd-pleaser. The gin-based cocktail combines tropical fruit flavors—pineapple, lime and coconut—with spiced falernum and a kick from green chile vodka. Chartreuse and a housemade syrup (which the bar also uses in itsGreen Gazoococktail) add a layer of herbaceousness.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce green herb syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce falernum, such as John D. Taylor’s Velvet Falernum
1/2 ounce St. George Spirits Green Chile Vodka
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a glass with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig and a lime wheel.

title: Vin Beurre
intro_philosophy: Hewing close to the old adage “butter makes it better,” Kathryn Olson and Zac Overman have modified a traditional Frenchvin chaud(or mulled wine) by using white wine, honey, thyme, almonds and ginger—topped with a float of whipped calvados butter. “With all the aromatics we’d chosen already, a whiff of apple on top just made sense to us, plus calvados butter just sounded fucking rad,” says Overman. He recommends using unsalted butter, saying “the drink skews pretty savory anyway with the almonds and especially the thyme. Salted butter might push it into chicken soup territory.”
ingredients: 1 750mL bottle white wine, preferably full-bodied and unoaked
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a medium saucepan.
2. Bring to a simmer and then remove from heat.
