3. Allow ingredients to infuse for 30 minutes.
4. Fine strain through a cheesecloth and discard solids.
5. Pour the mulled wine into a bottle and refrigerate until ready to use.
6. To serve, preheat an Irish Coffee glass or other hot drink glass with hot water.
7. Heat the mulled wine in a saucepan on the stove until hot.
8. Pour out the hot water from the glass and fill with hot mulled wine.
9. Top with a barspoon of calvados butter.

title: El Vato Swizzle
intro_philosophy: Slang for “pal,” “dude” or “homie” in Chicano Spanish,el vatodenotes the origin of this cocktail’s base spirit, tequila. A summery muddle of watermelon, cilantro and agave syrup, this Miami Beach-born cocktail is a near-Margarita, but in the form of an icy swizzle.
instructions: 1. Add cilantro to a pilsner glass.
2. Muddle with agave syrup.
3. Add remaining ingredients.
4. Top with crushed ice and swizzle.
5. Garnish with a slice of watermelon and several sprigs of cilantro.

title: Emerald City
intro_philosophy: Matthew Belanger ofDeath & Co.riffs on theMojitoby adding rhum agricole, creme de menthe and a squeeze of citrus directly into a lime-flavored LaCroix—lavishly topped with mint and makrut lime leaves.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon creme de menthe, preferably Giffard Menthe-Pastille
1 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Rhum JM 100 Blanc
instructions: 1. Pour out 1 1/2 ounces of the lime LaCroix.
2. Add the remaining ingredients.
3. Garnish with mint, makrut lime leaves, powdered sugar and a straw.

title: Greyhound
intro_philosophy: This highball standard is as simple as they come, with just two ingredients—grapefruit juice and vodka—served over ice and stirred. The easy template makes a solid base for a host of variations: add a salted rim for the Salty Dog, swap gin for vodka for a more herbaceous spin or pour a splash of vermouth or amaro, such as Punt e Mes or Campari for the Italian Greyhound.
instructions: 1. Build ingredients in a highball glass over ice.
2. Garnish with a grapefruit twist or a grapefruit wheel.

title: Mortimer and Mauve
intro_philosophy: “This was the last cocktail I put on Seamstress’s menu, and it’s still the number one-selling cocktail today,” says Pamela Wiznitzer of her Manhattan variation, which plays up the spiciness of the rye base with chai-infused vermouth alongside ginger liqueur.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces chai-infused sweet vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi
1/2 ounce ginger liqueur, preferably Barrow's Intense
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express the orange peel and discard.

title: Charles Dickens’s Punch
intro_philosophy: There are few things more Dickensian than a bowl of punch. A great lover of drink, Dickens wove spirits into his writing repeatedly and even conceived of his own punch: this cheek warming mix of Cognac, rum, citrus, and sugar that is “cooked” by setting it on fire.
instructions: 1. To an enameled cast-iron pot or heatproof bowl, add sugar and lemon peels. Muddle peels and sugar together to release citrus oils.

2. Add rum and Cognac to the sugar. Light a match, and, using a heatproof spoon, pick up a spoonful of the spirit mix. Carefully bring the match to the spoon to light, then bring the lit spoon back to the bowl. Let the spirits burn for about 3 minutes. The fire will melt the sugar and extract the oil from the lemon peels.
3. Extinguish the fire by covering it with a heatproof pan. Skim off lemon peels. Squeeze in the lemon juice, and add hot tea.
4. Ladle into glasses over ice. Garnish with citrus slices and grated nutmeg.

title: Andrew Volk’s Hot Toddy
intro_philosophy:
“Hot Toddies are those drinks you get when you’re cold or when you have a cold,” says Andrew Volk. “You want something strong, you want something hot, you want something a little bit spicy.”

His recipe, which he offers in both bourbon- and brandy-based iterations, ticks all the boxes.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Hunt + Alpine Cardamom-Coriander Syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Preheat a glass mug by filling it with hot water. Leave the water in for now and set it aside.

2. To prepare the drink, you'll want a heat-conducting vessel that fits into a second container. Two metal mixing tins work great: fill the first with enough hot water that the second container floats in the water when placed inside the first. Essentially. you are creating a small bain-marie to preheat the ingredients without diluting them.
3. Add the brandy or bourbon, lemon juice, cardamom-coriander syrup, and ginger syrup to your mixing tins and stir gently until heated through.
4. Empty the water from the preheated mug and immediately fill it with the heated cocktail. Top with 3 ounces hot water. Express the orange twist over the drink, and place the cinnamon stick.

title: Sorbet All Day
intro_philosophy: This take on the Detroit classic, the Hummer, replaces the usual vanilla ice cream with coconut cream sorbet, and the white rum and Kahlua with burnt cinnamon-infused aged rum.
ingredients: 2 ounces burnt cinnamon-infused Zacapa rum (see Editor's Note)
2 scoops (4 to 5 ounces) sweetened coconut cream sorbet, preferably So Delicious
1/4 vanilla bean, using just the seeds scraped from the pod
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Pour into a tiki glass, add a silly straw and top with grated nutmeg.

title: Arctic Wine Cooler
intro_philosophy:
Natasha David’s playful cooler is essentially an überprogressive sangria in slushie form. Using orange wine—a white produced in a manner similar to reds, with the grapes experiencing some skin contact—lends a punch of funkiness, while apricot liqueur suggests the chopped fruit typically found floating in a glass of sangria.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce apricot liqueur, preferably Giffard Apricot du Rousillon
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Pour into a wineglass.
4. Garnish with an orange half wheel and a straw.

title: Negroni Frappé
intro_philosophy: Naren Young’s shaken riff on the Negroni is a refreshing and lower-proof alternative to the traditional Italian cocktail. The hard shake and pour over crushed ice results in an almost-frozen combination of bitters, gin and orange juice—an ideal aperitivo for a hot afternoon.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Martini & Rossi Gran Lusso
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and shake very quickly.
2. Strain over crushed ice into a footed highball.
3. Garnish with grated orange zest.

title: Café du Maine
intro_philosophy: Once a staple at No. 9 Park, former head bartender Ted Kilpatrick’s Café du Maine is, as he described it, “a cross between a New Orleans Milk Punch and an Espresso Martini” that pays homage to the adopted home state of Allen’s Coffee Flavored Brandy.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Tahitian vanilla syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a dusting of chicory.

title: Cruise to Nowhere
intro_philosophy: Jack Schramm’s Cruise to Nowhere is a carbonated mixture of clarified guava and lime juices, blanc vermouth, pineapple rum and aquavit.
ingredients: 1 ounuce Clarified Guava Juice (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce L.N. Mattei Cap Corse Blanc Aperitif
3/4 ounce Clarified Lime Juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a carbonation bottle.
2. Chill to almost freezing.
3. Carbonate three times.
4. Serve in a highball glass over ice.

title: Eben Freeman’s Martini
intro_philosophy: Eben Freeman’s Martini calls for the Scottish Old Raj gin alongside both sweet and dry vermouth. The drink is full, round and elegant, with a slightly bitter finish.
ingredients: 2 ounces Old Raj Blue Label Dry Gin
1/2 ounce Cocchi Sweet Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir and strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a pickled onion.

title: The Bunny Mother
intro_philosophy: This retro highball was first served at The Playboy Club in San Francisco. Tart, and practically begging to be topped with a little prosecco, it drinks like a more complex, after-hours mimosa.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except Cointreau, in a shaking tin with ice. Shake well until chilled.
2. Strain into a pre-chilled Collins glass.
3. Add coarsely cracked ice to fill glass 1/2 inch from the top.
4. Add Cointreau to float on top, garnish with 1/2 an orange slice and a cherry.

title: Frozémonade
intro_philosophy: “Take frozen rosé and lemonade and smush it all together,” says Extra Fancy’s Rob Krueger, and you wind up with the immediately enjoyable and supremely crushable frozémonade.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 12-ounce Ball jelly jar and fill with crushed or pellet ice.
2. Attach the blade assembly of an Oster Beehive Blender to the jar, invert and blend until very smooth.
3. Carefully remove the blade, add a straw and garnish with a sprig of mint.

title: Da Hora
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to make a Latin-inspired Royale,” explains Ivy Mix of the effervescent inspiration behind her Da Hora cocktail. Utilizing St-Germain as a base rather than a modifier, the Da Hora is light, citrusy, and floral-forward, making for a day drink that finds itself somewhere between a Caipirinha and a simple Royale, or Champagne-topped cocktail.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients except the cava.
2. Strain into a coupe and top with the cava, then garnish with a cucumber wheel.

title: Liar’s Gambit
intro_philosophy: This nonalcoholic milk punch is made using a similar method as traditional milk punch, but uses booze-free distillate Seedlip in place of a standard spirit. Like a traditional milk punch, the dairy gives the drink unctuous texture, and the clarification process yields a nearly clear liquid that resembles water, or possibly a Martini, although its citrus and spice character quickly reveal that it belongs in a class of its own. “It almost looks like a glass of water, then the aroma pops out of the glass,” says Tyson Buhler, national beverage director for the Death & Co franchise.
instructions: 1. Combine the spiced tea, Seedlip and pineapple gum syrup in a heatproof container.
2. Scald the milk by heating it in a saucepan over medium heat until bubbles form around the edges.
3. Add the milk and lemon juice to the rest of the batched punch, and allow the punch to curdle.
4. Refrigerate the punch overnight.
5. The next day, strain the punch through coffee filters until completely clear.
6. Store, refrigerated, for up to 10 days.
7. To serve, pour 4 ounces into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Grate nutmeg over the top, if desired.

title: Painkiller
intro_philosophy: With coconut cream, pineapple juice, orange juice and a Virgin Islands birthplace sometime in the 1970s, this rum-based cocktail is a tropical drink to the core. There’s some dispute over which bartender created this twist on thePiña Colada(generally the credit goes to Daphne Henderson of the Soggy Dollar Bar), but there’s no question as to who owns it: Pusser’s Rum, who trademarked the Painkiller name in the 1990s.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Do not add ice, but shake well.
3. Pour into a snifter and top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish generously with grated nutmeg.

title: Yuzu Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Botanica Restaurant in Los Angeles features yuzu on the menu in several drinks, from this simple shaken rye cocktail to a spritz and a Mimosa. The Yuzu Cocktail is made with Yuzuco’s Super Juice, a shelf-stable product that’s accessible for stateside bartenders while still packing the tangy punch of fresh citrus.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a cherry and mint.

title: Fernetea
intro_philosophy: At the Pittsburgh restaurant Fet-Fisk, the Fernetea appears on the dessert list. A comforting mix of amaro, chilled peppermint tea, simple syrup and oat milk, the cocktail is cooling and low-ABV, a drink that beverage director Lex Haynesworth describes as “a hug any time of year.”
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients to a Collins glass over ice and stir to combine.
2. Top with oat milk.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig, if desired.

title: Salted Plum Vodka Collins
intro_philosophy: Thai cuisine aficionado Andy Ricker aims to replicate his southeastern Thai dining experiences with the Salted Plum Vodka Collins, an alcoholic twist on an existing Thai drink template. The saltiness of the plum combined with citrus results in a complex, thirst-quenching cocktail capable of holding its own when paired with food.
instructions: 1. Muddle the salted plum, lemon juice and sugar in a pint glass.
2. Add ice and vodka, then shake.
3. Strain into a Collins glass with ice and top with soda water.
4. Garnish with a lemon wedge and Amarena cherry.

title: Pink Gin
ingredients: 1 part navy strength gin, preferably Plymouth Gin Navy Strength
instructions: 1. Stir the ingredients together in a mixing glass with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
2. Garnish with the lemon twist.

title: Mujer Italiana Va a Jalisco
intro_philosophy: Translating as “An Italian Woman Goes to Jalisco,” Gina Chersevani created this mash-up of two classics to honor her Italian heritage. It melds the Tequila Sunrise with the traditional Italian Garibaldi cocktail—Campari and orange juice. Dry-shaking the mix (without ice) helps encourage the juice to froth up; showcasing the drink in a tall, thin glass helps keep that froth as long as possible.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sassafras bark-infused tequila (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the tequila and orange juice in a mixing tin and shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Double strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice.
4. Gently pour the Campari on top of the drink and allow it to drop to the bottom of the glass.
5. Garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Wimbledon
intro_philosophy: Planning Good Guy’s opening for the summer of 2024, shortly before Wimbledon, the bar team (many from Attaboy) felt that a spritz version of the Pimm’s Cup would be a perfect drink to launch with.“We wanted this to be hyperapproachable but also satisfying for any palate or point in the night; it’s a starter, an intermezzo and a finisher all in one,” says Sam Ross, the drink’s creator. Built on a base of housemade Pimm’s, the spritz is a simple, refreshing mixture layered with lemon juice, agave syrup and a topper of prosecco.
instructions: 1. Add first three ingredients to a glass with ice.
2. Top with prosecco.

title: Baboso
intro_philosophy: Here, slightly sweet Old Tom gin balances the bitter notes of gentian-basedSuzeand Bonal aperitifs, while rye whiskey, Cynar and Carpano Antica add a fall-friendly veneer to this full-bodied, stirred drink.
ingredients: 1 ounce Old Tom gin, preferably Ransom
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large cube of ice.
3. Garnish with a whole, charred habanero

title: Death & Co.’s Champagne Cocktail
intro_philosophy: A classic, straight-headChampagne Cocktail—no muss, no fuss.Death & Co.’s house recipe doesn’t divert an iota from the time-honored formula for the drink. Crisp, bright and, with that long, curly-cue lemon twist, pleasantly citrusy.
ingredients: 5 ounces Champagne, preferably Vilmart & Cie Grand Reserve
instructions: 1. Douse the sugar cube in Angostura bitters and place into a chilled flute.
2. Slowly top with Champagne.
3. Garnish with a lemon "pigtail" cut with a channel knife.

title: American Royal Zephyr
intro_philosophy: Inspired by theSeelbachcocktail, Grand Army Bar’s Damon Boelte likes to joke that the boozy American Royal Zephyr doesn’t have anything in it that isn’t alcohol: “What could be more American than that?” Boelte’s love for trains gives the bitters and bourbon-heavy drink its name, while a topping of Champagne keeps things effervescent.
ingredients: 1 ounce  bourbon, preferably Old Grand-Dad Bonded
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, combine all ingredients except champagne and stir.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Top with champagne and garnish with a cherry.

title: Valparaiso Daisy
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn’s Diamond Lil, this Chilean take on a daisy makes use of pisco from the Limari Valley for a clean yet tropical taste. A touch of dry Curaçao brings out bitterness, while sweet vermouth round outs out the drink with a subtle vanilla aroma.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce dry Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
1/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Top with soda water.

title: Smoking Bishop
intro_philosophy: Charles Dickens’s drinking knowledge was as epic as his tales, many of which include passing descriptions of the Victorian era’s drinking rituals. The Smoking Bishop happens to fall into a family of punch-style drinks named for the clerical hierarchy. The Pope involved mixing with Burgundy while Archbishop employed claret and the Cardinal, Champagne. In a final scene fromA Christmas Carol, Scrooge turns to Bob Cratchit, his belittled employee, with new eyes and invites him to be merry over a bowl of Smoking Bishop—the word “bishop” was 19th-century code for port—which referred to a roasted clove and orange-infused port punch, warmed and mulled with baking spices and further fortified with red wine.
instructions: 1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Wash and dry oranges. Pierce and stud each orange with five cloves.
3. Place oranges in a baking dish and roast until lightly browned all over, 60-90 minutes.
4. Add port, wine, water, sugar and spices to a saucepan, and simmer over low heat.
5. Slice oranges in half and squeeze juice into the wine and port mixture.
6. Serve in a punch bowl, and ladle into individual glasses.

title: Red Sangria
intro_philosophy: Donostia’s sangria riff won’t slow the party down; this low-proof version swaps out the traditional brandy for a complex, spicy vermouth, played up with fresh ginger and cardamom.
ingredients: 4 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Perruchi Gran Reserva
1 3/4 ounces Poor Man's Kitchen cardamom syrup
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients together, then pour over ice into a pitcher or similar container.
2. Garnish with candied ginger and blood orange slices.

title: Kangaroo
intro_philosophy: Truman, a wheat vodka from eau de vie whisperer Hans Reisetbauer, is “just a really, really beautiful distillate,” says William Elliott, managing partner and executive bar director at Brooklyn’s Maison Premiere. When he tried it, he knew it deserved a cocktail just as special. He turned to theKangaroo, a classic vodka Martini from the archives of cocktail history.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce bianco vermouth, such as Mauro Vergano BVB
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Express a lemon twist over the drink, then discard.

title: Angelo Azzurro
intro_philosophy: Nick Palmeri couldn’t get past the “Robitussin Jolly Rancher” taste of the original Angelo Azzurro, which was first created by Giovanni “Mammina” Pepè in Rome in 1980 using gin, triple sec and blue Curaçao. Adding Luxardo Bitter Bianco helped counter the sweetness and added a touch of bitterness, making it more “mellow and elegant,” Palmeri says. Shaking the drink helps with a quick dilution and adds a layer of ice shards on the surface of the drink, which can be served up in a classic cocktail glass, in a coupe or on the rocks.
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake until chilled, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Electric Avenue
intro_philosophy: To make this fruity Daiquiri riff, Dave Arnold freezes pineapple and pomegranate juice, then shakes the slightly slushy cubes with citrus and rum into a super-cold cocktail. Adding the “hard ice” cube is optional: Arnold prefers to include it for a “lighter”-tasting drink, “but if you want it heavier from a flavor perspective, more like a Daiquiri, than omit that cube,” he advises.
ingredients: 2 ounces pineapple juice, frozen into two 1-ounce cubes
1 ounce pomegranate juice, frozen into one 1-ounce cube
2 ounces lightly aged rum, preferably Flor de Caña
4 drops  20% saline solution (alternatively, just add a pinch of salt)
1 “hard ice” cube (one 1-ounce cube of frozen water)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients until the cubes dissolve.
2. Pour into chilled coupe glass.

title: Jazz Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the frozen Daiquiris at Havana’s famed El Floridita bar, this slushy refresher uses a couple of notable techniques. First, whole coffee beans are blended into the drink for a nuanced flavor that, mixed with crème de cacao, reads more like chocolate than coffee. Second, granulated sugar is used instead of simple syrup—it will liquefy just fine in the blender, according to Kantor. Aim for a smooth texture, without clumps of ice, so it’s icy but easy to drink without a straw: “You want it to be more liquid than a frappé.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Cacao
instructions: 1. Blend all ingredients with 10 ounces (about 1 1/4 cups) pebble ice, preferably in a Hamilton Beach 908 commercial blender.
2. Pour into a 10-ounce V-shaped Martini glass.

title: “Jacked” Clover Club
intro_philosophy: In this modified Clover Club, bartender Jason Asher calls on raspberry jacked-gin, an infusion technique inspired by historic applejack production.
ingredients: 2 ounces raspberry-jacked gin, preferably Fords (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with ice.
2. Shake vigorously until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a raspberry on a pick.

title: Urbanite
intro_philosophy: Bar manager Jesse Duré describes this drink, which was part of the winter drink menu at New York’s Chumley’s, as “a Scotch and soda variation on a Rusty Nail, a little more refreshing and sessionable.” Alongside grapefruit juice, Angostura and coffee extract, Drambuie adds sweetness and body; no extra sugar or simple syrups are added.
ingredients: 2 ounces  Scotch, preferably Singleton 12 year old Scotch whisky
4 drops  coffee extract, preferably Terra Spice Co.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a highball glass with ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Express the grapefruit peel and garnish with it.

title: Matthew Belanger’s Blinker
intro_philosophy: The Blinkerfirst appeared in Patrick Gavin Duffy’s 1934 book,The Official Mixer’s Manual, wherein the spec called for three parts grapefruit juice to two parts rye to one part grenadine, served in a footed highball glass. That version has never really taken off, but veteran bartender Matthew Belanger has been trying to figure out how to make a Blinker that appeals to the modern palate for more than a decade. The spec he’s landed on follows a traditional sour format and uses a bonded rye, acid-adjusted grapefruit juice, aperitivo liqueur and raspberry eau de vie, along with an acid-spiked raspberry syrup and additional acids. The result is a Blinker wherein the bitter grapefruit and fragrant, fruity raspberry shine.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bonded rye, preferably Wild Turkey 101
1/4 ounce raspberry eau de vie, preferably St. George or Clear Creek
3 milliliters improved citric acid solution (see Editor’s Note)
1.5 milliliters malic acid solution (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Add ice, seal and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a double rocks glass over fresh ice cubes.

title: Even Steven
intro_philosophy: Part of a new menu inspired by early ’90s TV shows and movies, this take on the New York Sour relies on Frangelico, a hazelnut liqueur, to add a pleasingly nutty scent and rich texture. Also in the mix is Tattersall Orange Crema, a bold orange liqueur made by Tattersall Distillers in Minneapolis, but orangeCuraçaocan be substituted.
ingredients: 1 ounce orange liqueur , preferably Tattersall Orange Crema
1/4 ounce St. George Spirits Bruto Americano
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Express the orange peel over the top of the drink, then garnish with orange peel.

title: Love on a Wire
intro_philosophy: At Lady Jane in Denver, bartender John Stefanski calls on a housemade blackberry-balsamic syrup to tease out the “dark fruit character” of the berries in this summery riff on a classic Gin Sour. “It’s refreshing, playful and bright, but also a serious drink full of complexity,” says Lady Jane general manager Stuart Weaver.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake (without ice).
2. Add ice, then shake again until chilled.
3. Fine-strain into a coupe.
4. Garnish with butterfly pea flower–black pepper powder, if using.

title: Rose City
intro_philosophy: Jim Meehan’s nearly two decades of tweaking his Rose spec have resulted in this, his fourth major version, which he serves at Takibi in Portland, Oregon. The local cherry eau de vie, made with Rainier cherries and matsutake mushrooms, and the red currant preserves work in concert to reflect a sense of place.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce cherry eau de vie, preferably Stone Barn Brandyworks Cherry Matsutake Brandy
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir to chill.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe and garnish with a cherry griotte on a pick.

title: The Grey Wolf
intro_philosophy:
This story is published in partnership with P(our), a symposium devoted to exploring new ideas and exchanging inspiration about the drinks industry, and beyond. The annual event promotes discussions and presentations that address issues critical to the trade; this year’s theme is “perfection.” The event is taking place in Paris on June 3rd—for more information, and for tickets,click here.

In this variation on an Old-Fashioned, Julia Momose uses plum vinegar for savory-sweet acidity and Benedictine for complex sweetness, with a dash of Angostura bitters to bring the two together. “It’s a drink that can keep opening up and opening up instead of dying after a certain point,” says Momose.
ingredients: 2 ounces Japanese whisky, preferably Hibiki Harmony
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over an ice block chipped into a gumdrop shape.
3. Express the grapefruit peel and discard.

title: Mount Olympus Collins
intro_philosophy: Using the blueprint of a basic Collins recipe, North Carolina bartender Brad Farran infused the usual gin base with fragrant Mount Olympus flower tea, added a dash of apricot liqueur and replaced simple syrup with sweet almond orgeat syrup to sweeten. Angostura bitters and lemon juice add the balance of spice and acid to complete the long, tall summer cocktail.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, infused with Mount Olympus flower tea (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce apricot liqueur (preferably Rothman and Winter)
instructions: 1. Add gin, lemon juice, orgeat, apricot liqueur and Angostura to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda water and garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: La Bandida
intro_philosophy: “I wanted something crushable with tequila and salty cucumber cordial,” says Fanny Chu of her La Bandida. To these two components she adds a splash of mezcal, a house blend of Aperol and crème de pêche and a few ounces of IPA. It’s the sort of flavor pairing that doesn’t quite add up on paper, but in practice yields interesting results: The IPA manages to highlight a grapefruit note in the Aperol that makes for a citrusy, shandy-like result. “It’s weird, but delicious,” says Chu.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
1 1/2 ounces salty cucumber cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except IPA, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Pour IPA into double rocks glass over ice.
3. Strain shaken ingredients over IPA.
4. Garnish with long cucumber slice.

title: Three Bites of the Apple
intro_philosophy: “I just wanted to celebrate fall in the Hudson Valley,” Marrero says of this autumnal riff on the Old-Fashioned. Drawing on the many farms in the area, a housemade apple cider–sherry syrup frames the fruit and cinnamon spice notes in the bourbon. A touch of bitters made by local purveyor Dutch’s “brings it all together.”
ingredients: 2 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
½ ounce  apple cider–sherry syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with apple fan.

title: Alex Anderson’s Sherry Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Taking the top spot in our blind Sherry Cobbler tasting was the archetypal recipe fromAlex Anderson. Her take builds on a three-ounce base of amontillado sherry with rich Demerara syrup, combined with muddled lemon and two orange wheels, garnished in typical cobbler fashion with a large mint sprig and seasonal fruit. “The weight is right, the flavor is right,” declared Brendan Biggins, echoing Frank Caiafa who noted after the first sip: “Thisis a sherry cobbler.”
ingredients: 3 ounces amontillado sherry, preferably Bodegas Yuste Aurora
1/2 ounce rich Demerara Syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar:water)
1 orange wheel, about a centimeter thick, cut in half
instructions: 1. In a metal cup or a glass of your choosing muddle the orange halves and lemon quarter thoroughly.
2. Add the sherry, Demerara syrup and pebble ice.
3. Use a bar spoon to mix the ingredients together.
4. Add more pebble ice on top to create a snow cone look.
5. Garnish with a large mint sprig, an orange wedge, seasonal fruit and a dusting of powdered sugar.
6. Serve with a straw.

title: Eight States
intro_philosophy: “Pretty much every drink that we do will contain some form of vermouth or sherry, or a low ABV ingredient,” says Nathan McCarley-O’Neill, “It’s kind of like a calling card.” The Eight States contains three: equal parts blanc vermouth andCocchi Americano, a measure of aloe vera liqueur and, to round things out, a hefty dose ofmezcal. “I wanted to create something a bit lower in ABV, a little more approachable, but still similar to what a Negroni is, but more so like a white Negroni.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Derrumbes San Luis Potosí
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a cucumber ribbon lining the glass.
4. Express a grapefruit twist over the drink and discard.

title: Coconut Margarita
intro_philosophy: At El Camino, thisCoconut Margaritais the best-selling drink. “People like the comfort of ordering something they know, and are pleasantly surprised when they get it and the texture is just that of a classic Margarita, since we aren’t using any coconut cream or anything,” says owner Will Wyatt. “It’s just tropical and refreshing.” At the bar, Wyatt and the team use a sous-vide method to fat-wash the base spirit, but at home, you can simply combine the oil and tequila, then freeze and strain.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce orange liqueur, such as Grand Marnier Cordon Rouge
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

title: Ramos Gin Fizz
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients, except the soda water, in a cocktail shaker.
2. Try adding a Hawthorne strainer spring to help whip the ingredients.
3. Shake vigorously for 5 minutes.
4. Add ice and shake for another minute.
5. Add the soda water to a chilled narrow highball glass and slowly strain the drink into the glass on top of the soda.
6. Keep pouring until the foam of the drink is a good inch above the glass.
7. Alternatively, a stick blender can be used to whisk the ingredients together. Then follow the other steps as above.

title: Mango Pit Syrup
intro_philosophy:
“Truly great mangoes should be enjoyed as is, eaten straight from the chopping board, or simply laid across something creamy,” wrote baker and cookbook author Nicola Lamb onher recipefor the cake that this syrup originates from. For her, a good mango should not go to waste. That includes the flesh and fiber left behind on a mango pit and its skins. This sweetener, which boils the scraps with some lime zest, water and sugar, is primarily used for cakes, but Lamb also recommends it in cocktails and zero proof drinks; she likes topping it with sparkling water and mint. It “helps us get every last drop of mango essence,” she says.

Reprinted with permission fromKitchen Projects, Nicola Lamb’s newsletter. Lamb is the author ofSIFT: The Elements of Great Baking, published by Clarkson Potter.
ingredients: 180 grams (from about 2 mangoes) mango pits and skins
instructions: 1. In a medium pot over high heat, bring everything to boil for five minutes.
2. Let cool, then strain into a sealable container.
3. Keep refrigerated for several weeks.

title: Mint & Flower
intro_philosophy: At Washington D.C.’sA Rake’s Bar, Corey Polyoka made the switch from fresh citrus to verjus as a source of acidity in his cocktails as part of their mission to strictly spotlight regional ingredients. “We use [verjus] in drinks where we need to balance other components and want a softer, more blended aspect to the sour component,” explains Polyoka of his decision to incorporate a mint verjus in this fernet-based sour.
ingredients: 1 ounce fernet, preferably Baltimore Whiskey Co. Baltamaro
3 to 4 dashes julep mint tincture (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Lola & Cola
intro_philosophy: Samuel Garcia created this cocktail as a way to make fernet more accessible to the uninitiated calling on a locally made liqueur fromRhine Hall, a small distillery located in Chicago’s Kinzie Industrial Corridor. The additions of lemon and simple syrup turn the drink into a sort of fernet Daiquiri, as he puts it, a profile many people are already comfortable with. By topping it off withFever-Tree Distillers Cola, it’s given a final, Argentine twist, a nod to the country where the Fernet & Cola is ubiquitous.
instructions: 1. Add the fernet, lemon juice and simple syrup to a shaker tin with ice, and shake.
2. Strain into a highball glass with ice.
3. Top with Fever-Tree Distillers Cola, and garnish with lemon swath and cherry.

title: Piña Verde
intro_philosophy:
Playfully dubbed the, “Greenya Colada,” by the staff at Polite Provisions, the Piña Verde was originally inspired by Erick Castro’s unorthodox addition of Green Chartreuse to his Piña Coladas years ago.

His aim was to create a drink rich with herbaceous flavor. When rum—and then later gin—didn’t cut it, Castro ditched the spirit altogether and upped the liqueur to pick up the slack. The additions of pineapple juice and lime add a fruity kick, while the Piña Colada staple, Coco Lopez, keeps it tethered to the original.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into rocks glass over pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Basilinia
intro_philosophy: Light and fragrant, this easy-sipping twist on theCaipirinhawas made for summer afternoons. Basil’s piquant clove aroma pairs particularly well with bianco vermouth’s vanilla notes, all heightened with the citrusy tang of lime.
instructions: 1. Add lime wedges and basil to a rocks glass and muddle.
2. Add vermouth and top with crushed ice.
3. Swizzle to mix.

title: White Negroni
intro_philosophy: Like all good stories should, the one about theNegroni’sorigin involves rakish Italian nobility. Most accounts credit the recipe to one Count Negroni, a swashbuckling proto-boho who reportedly spent time as a rodeo cowboy in the United States. Compounding his wild ways, legend has it that back at a bar in Italy in 1919, he asked for a something like anAmericano, but boozier. Swap gin for soda water, and presto, the Negroni. This version, adapted from London bartender Wayne Collins’ riff, turns the original on its head substituting floral Lillet for sweet vermouth and gentian-based Suze for the bitter twinge of Campari.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass if serving up, or over ice into a rocks glass if preferred.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Amaro Library’s Negroni
intro_philosophy: This equal-parts blend served at the amaro-focused bar in D.C.’s The Wharf district uses the typical Campari, but makes unusual choices otherwise, using Edinburgh gin, a London dry gin made in Scotland, and Contratto Vermouth Rosso, a heritage vermouth brand from Turin. Bullseye.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the orange twist in a rocks glass filled with one large piece of ice.
2. Stir until chilled, about 30 seconds.
3. Express an orange twist over the drink and drop it into the glass.

title: One Hot Ginger
intro_philosophy: This blend of bourbon and Grand Marnier doubles down on the heat with the addition of cayenne pepper and ginger for what Narcissa’s Simone Goldberg describes as, “a hot toddy meets a juice bar cold remedy.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon, preferably Buffalo Trace Eagle Rare
instructions: 1. Build in glass and stir.

title: Montana Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: The house Daiquiri at Montana in Hong Kong takes inspiration from two Cuban classics: the Santa Marta Daiquiri and the Boadas Daiquiri. The former is a variation from the official bar manual of the Club de Cantineros, published in 1930, and is made with a touch of kirsch. The latter was created by a former El Floridita bartender as a riff on El Floridita’sDaiquiri No. 4. The mashup has become Montana’s best-selling drink.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces white rum, such as Havana Club
1/3 ounce rich simple syrup(2:1, sugar to water)
1/6 ounce maraschino liqueur, such as Luxardo
1 barspoon framboise eau de vie, to float, such as G.E. Massenez
instructions: 1. Combine rum, lime, simple syrup and maraschino liqueur in a shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe, allowing little bits of ice to float on the surface.
4. Garnish with a maraschino cherry sunk to the bottom of the glass.

title: Midnight Marauder
intro_philosophy: InJoaquín Simó‘s spin on the classicNegroni, smokymezcalreplaces the usual piney gin, while gentian-bittered Bonal subs in for the traditional sweet vermouth and Cynar, an artichoke-driven amaro, takes the place of the expected Campari.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Karen Fu’s Bamboo
intro_philosophy: Early in a recent blind tasting, the panel floated the idea that busy recipes for the Bamboo don’t pay in the end. Nonetheless, the drink that came in second place, from Karen Fu at République in Los Angeles, was the fussiest of the bunch. It calls for eight ingredients, including three sherries, two vermouths, Angostura and orange bitters and a scant barspoon of J.M. Sirop de Canne. The judges knew upon first sip that they were tasting a cocktail that was involved, perhaps unnecessarily so. But they praised the balance, declaring the drink lovely, with a good mouthfeel—an Improved Bamboo Cocktail, as it were.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Valdespino Tio Diego
1/2 ounce palo cortado sherry, preferably Barbadillo Obispo Gascón
1 ounce fino sherry, preferably Maestro Sierra
1 scant barspoon J.M. Sirop de Canne
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a Meyer lemon peel.

title: Suppressor #21
intro_philosophy: Paul Calvert’s Suppressor #21 is a simple, low-ABV combination of fortified wines kicked up with bitter Cynar. “There’s a cool delicacy to the flavor profile of a fortified wine-based drink,” Calvert says—a mindset exemplified here by the elegant pairing of Barolo chinato and amontillado sherry.
instructions: 1. Stir and strain into a rocks glass over a large cube of ice.
2. Express and discard grapefruit peel over the top of the drink.

title: Grapefruit Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: As simple as it gets, this Grapefruit Garibaldi swaps Contratto Bitter for Campari and fresh white grapefruit juice for OJ. The result reads like a hybrid Spumoni-Garibaldi, its bittersweet, tangy combination as comfortable at brunch as it is before dinner.
instructions: 1. Pour Contratto Bitter into a Collins or highball glass.
2. Add ice and top with fresh-pressed grapefruit juice.

title: Ranch Mizu
intro_philosophy: Maiko describes her cocktail as “a very Japanese take on Ranch Water”—a Texas quencher typically made from tequila, lime juice and soda water. Her variation includes hits of shochu and rice vinegar, as well as togarashi, the savory Japanese spice mixture that features red pepper among its seven ingredients.
ingredients: Fever-Tree Sparkling Lime & Yuzu, to top
instructions: 1. Mix salt and togarashi in a shallow dish. Moisten the rim of a highball glass, then dip or roll the edge of the glass to coat with the spice-salt mixture.
2. Scoop ice into a prepared glass, and add the first three ingredients.
3. Top up with lime-yuzu soda.

title: L’Arnaud Palmer
intro_philosophy: Kitty Bernardo, former bar manager at New York’s Donna, looked to the convivial tea culture of Morocco as inspiration for L’Arnaud Palmer. As its name suggests, this tall, frosty crusher is a Cognac-based spin ona boozy Arnold Palmer—a perfect drink to cap off a round ofle golf.For the mint tea syrup, Bernardo strove for maximum authenticity, consulting a family friend from Morocco on a brewing method that would extract the most pleasing elements of gunpowder green tea and dispense with any bitter off notes. It’s involved, but worth the effort.
ingredients: 2 ounces VS Cognac, preferably Cognac VS
1 ounce Moroccan mint tea syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a shaker and whip-shake with crushed ice.
2. Pour into a tall Zombie glass and top off with fresh crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a bouquet of mint.

title: Sichuan Peppercorn Simple Syrup
intro_philosophy: Prized for their wholly unique flavor, Sichuan peppercorns embody a tingly, citrusy spice. Once crushed and infused into sugar and water, its mouth-numbing characteristics can add body to smoky mezcal, and other terroir-driven spirits like cachaça or rhum agricole.
instructions: 1. Grind the Sichuan peppercorns with a mortar and pestle. Combine the water and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat until sugar has completely dissolved. Remove from heat, add Sichuan peppercorns, and steep for 20 minutes. Strain and store in an airtight container.

title: Caribbean Heat
intro_philosophy: Paulina Konja’s rum Old-Fashioned swaps the expected simple syrup out for a “bitter blend”—a 50-50 combination of Italian amaro and French aperitif wine—that bolsters the expected aromatic bitters. It’s also meant to amplify the cinnamon and dried fruit notes that form the core of Brugal 1888.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir, then strain over a large ice cube in an Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon and orange twist.

title: The Meadowlark
intro_philosophy:
“It’s difficult putting smokiness in cocktails, especially if you’re trying to make a refreshing one,” explains Kai Parrott-Wolfe of Brooklyn’s OTB and Post Office Bar. “The flavor is so big [that] it generally doesn’t play that well with others.”

One strategy is to use a light hand, as Parrott-Wolfe does in The Meadowlark, shaking just a half ounce of heavily peated McCarthy’s Single Malt Whiskey from Oregon with an ounce and a half of gin, plus equal parts lime juice and simple syrup. The result: a subtle, refreshing response to the “something smoky” request.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce McCarthy's Oregon Single Malt Whiskey
3/4 ounce  simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Pour all ingredients into a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass.
3. Top with club soda.

title: Insanely Good Gin & Tonic
intro_philosophy: “Suze and gin are a match made in heaven,”explains Chaim Dauermann, who adds a splash of the French aperitif to up the bitter quotient in his update on the classic G&T, which also sees the addition of Angostura and housemade lime cordial.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce lime cordial (see Editor’s Note) or lime juice
instructions: 1. Add gin, Suze, lime cordial and bitters to a chilled Collins glass.
2. Top with ice and tonic.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Jalisko Flower
intro_philosophy: The Greek spirit mastiha is “a close friend to gin and blanco tequila,” according to Thanos Prunarus, owner/manager of Baba Au Rum. Agave and mastic trees are both slow-growing, hot climate plants that lend their resin to make the spirits in this sweet and vegetal sour.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake.
2. Fine strain into a coupe glass.

title: Paloma Rosa
intro_philosophy: Currently on the menu at Bar Caló, this Paloma riff “goes in a more floral direction,” says Josh Goldman, thanks to a house blend of two rose liqueurs mixed with grapefruit and a spiced elixir. The finishing touch is a spritz of rose water, which Goldman keeps in an atomizer to spray over the top of the drink.
ingredients: 1 ounce blended rose liqueur (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Place Himalayan pink salt in a shallow dish. Moisten half the rim of the Collins glass, then roll moistened rim in salt to coat.
2. Combine all ingredients, except Squirt, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Pour Squirt into tin, then strain into prepared glass over fresh ice.
4. Spritz rose water over the drink.

title: Speak of the Devil’s French Martini
intro_philosophy: In Lorain, Ohio, just outside of Cleveland, Speak of the Devilbolsters the classic components of the French Martini withlemon juice for extra acidity and simple syrup for balance. The drink belongs to a crop of newfangled French Martinis comprising the second coming of the ’tini.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Cardinal Points
intro_philosophy: This drink alludes to how both bartending and the great outdoors have given direction to Norbury’s life, with ingredients that gesture to the wild woods. Playing off of Bombay Sapphire’s mix of fruit and spice notes, the Cardinal Points combines warm flavors of orange, maple, mushroom and berries in a cocktail that has a silky stirred texture “unlike anything else I’ve made,” says Norbury.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Rubino
1/4 ounce  soured maple water (see Editor’s Note)
3 dashes Amer Kebek Wild Mushrooms bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a double-walled coffee mug containing a hand-cut clear ice cube.
3. Garnish with a blue spirulina wheel and spray with forest mist tincture.

title: Madhatter
intro_philosophy: Sam Kileydescribes her Madhatter as a “Southern-style sweet Martini,” created as an homage to North Carolina, where she went to college. Central to the drink’s makeup is vermouth made with distinctive Southeastern botanicals, including dried kudzu vine, an invasive species that runs rampant throughout the South but was kept under control at her Winston-Salem campus by packs of goats brought in twice a year for this particular task. “Although everyone told me housemade vermouth is usually not yummy, I wanted to give it a go,” she says. When mixed with Mississippi gin, the result is a slightly earthy Martini that toes the line between sweet and savory.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Double strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Green Pineapple Cordial
intro_philosophy: “People think pineapple rinds are not very usable in terms of drinks,” says Kelsey Ramage of the sustainably-minded Trash Collective, but her green pineapple cordial proves otherwise. Blended with just water, sugar and basil, the result is a bright, verdant-hued sweetener that squeezes out the last bits of life in your pineapple and adds a dose of the tropics to just about any drink.
instructions: 1. Blend sugar and water until almost dissolved.
2. Add basil stems and pineapple and blend until sugar is fully dissolved.
3. Strain through a fine strainer.
4. Bottle and refrigerate for up to 5 days.

title: Yana Volfson’s Margarita
intro_philosophy: Though Yana Volfson’s go-to Margarita calls for Casa Dragones blanco tequila, which typically retails for more than $50, this version, which took third place in our 2024 Margarita tasting, calls on the more affordable Tapatío 110 alongside a split measure of orange liqueur and lime juice for an exceptional take on the classic Marg.
instructions: 1. Prep a rocks glass with a half salt rim.
2. Add all ingredients to a shaker and hard-shake.
3. Strain over fresh ice into the prepared glass.

title: Gold Rush
intro_philosophy:
This cocktail was one of the early breakout successes atMilk & Honey, which was opened in 1999 by T.J. Siegal’s childhood friend, Sasha Petraske. Now served and enjoyed around the world, the Gold Rush is Siegal’s main claim to fame.

It’s an achievement made all the more remarkable considering that Siegal is not primarily a bartender. In fact, he came up with the idea for the Gold Rush not while standing behind the bar at Milk & Honey, but while sitting at it, sometime in 2000.
ingredients: 2 ounces bourbon, preferably Elijah Craig Kentucky Straight Bourbon
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Ferrari
intro_philosophy: No one’s sure who came up with the Ferrari, a potent 50/50 split of Fernet-Branca and Campari, butFox Liquor Barin Raleigh has welcomed it into their family of favorites nonetheless. It’s a popular industry drink, and while it’s usually taken as a shot, it has enough balance to be sipped slowly (stick it in the refrigerator first to chill it down) or used inamaro-friendly cocktails.
instructions: 1. Combine and drink as a shot.

title: Cazuela Voladora
intro_philosophy: Served in the wide-mouthed terracotta vessel from which it takes its name, the Cazuela Voladora (“flying casserole”) or Guadalajara Punch is an easy-drinking combination of tequila, citrus juice and/or soda. This traditional recipe by Karla Cuevo of La Cueva de Don Cenobio utilizes four types of citrus, but feel free to add other options such as pineapple or watermelon into the mix. The chunks of fruit are meant to be squeezed or eaten depending on your preference.
instructions: 1. Pour the tequila into a large, open-faced bowl.
2. Add the citrus juice and a can of grapefruit soda.
3. Top with ice and a generous pinch of salt, and stir to combine.
4. Top with various sliced citrus fruit.
5. Use a ladle to serve equally into four clay cazuelas, or whatever vessel you have on hand.

title: Smoochin’ Under the Clock Tower
intro_philosophy:
This contemporary punch from Chicago’s Dustin Drankiewicz was inspired by the flavors of the Middle East, particularly those of popular dessert Balal El Sham, which features of walnuts, honey and fruit. The blend of savory, cumin-scented kümmel, smoky reposado and walnut-lemon oleo is a decidedly contemporary take on punch, and one that can be served both hot and cold.

Many thanks to our friends atOne Kings Lanefor outfitting our holiday punches photoshoot, and toPrime Meatsfor allowing us to make a mess of your beautiful space.
instructions: 1. Combine the tequila, kümmel, lemon juice and pineapple juice into serving vessel.
2. Add oleo-saccharum and whisk aggressively.
3. Ladle into cups over cracked ice and serve with individual rosemary garnish.
4. To serve hot: Combine all ingredients as above into crock-pot set to medium heat. Let punch come up to temperature and serve with rosemary garnish.

title: Coqodaq’s Alaska
intro_philosophy: At Coqodaq in New York City, the food and drinks (“coqtails,” as they’re called on the menu) blend high and low. And what goes better with a chicken nugget topped with caviar than something as playful yet luxurious as a Martini spiked with Midori?
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, such as Boatyard Gin
3/4 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Lustau
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.

title: Et Moi Je Te Dis Maud
intro_philosophy:
The original drink, which earned Maud Loty first place in a 1929 celebrity cocktail competition, took its name from a revue staged the same year, penned for her byCocktails de Parisauthor Rip. It translates to, “And me, I’d tell you … Maud,” but conversationally, it can be understood as “That’s Maud for ya.” Think shrugging, mischievous resignation in response to outlandish but on-brand behavior, the “It’s Britney, bitch” of its era.

Together, Loty’s trio of ingredients yields a rich, enveloping result, with “pronounced baking spice, almond, cacao and wet-grass-on-a-summer’s-day notes,” observes Franky Marshall. This has inspired a personal flourish: a healthy dash of cinnamon-fig bitters, adding after-dinner appeal that will speak to “the brown-and-stirred contingent.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bas armagnac, preferably Marie Duffau
1 dash Mister Bitters Fig & Cinnamon bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Drunk in the August Sun
intro_philosophy: Dan Watson’s drier take on thePiña Coladaleans on Wray & Nephew and dry sherry to balance the sweetness of both pineapple juice and Coco Lopez cream of coconut. “I love how the Wray & Nephew dries out the Lopez in this drink,” explains Watson.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce cream of coconut, preferably Coco Lopez
1 ounce Wray & Nephew white overproof rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a glass of your choice over crushed ice.

title: Chip Tyndale’s Bamboo
intro_philosophy: Taking first place in our Bamboo tasting,Chip Tyndale‘s recipe hit all the marks with every judge. The formula was classical by modern standards: one and a half ounces of amontillado sherry, one and a quarter ounces of Dolin dry vermouth, a quarter-ounce of Dolin blanc vermouth, and a dash each of orange andAngostura bitters, served with a lemon twist. Tim Miner of The Long Island Bar called it a “complete cocktail,” citing the complexity of flavor, which pulled in saline, bitter and dry notes, while boasting a full body and a finish that didn’t fade.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Orgeat
intro_philosophy:
An opaque, sweet almond syrup often laced just slightly with orange blossom or rose water, or both, orgeat first started making regular appearances in bar manuals in the 1860s, but was consumed outside the realm of cocktails long before then. As early as the 1300s, orgeat was served as a delicacy—then a savory barley water, without a trace of the almonds it’s made with today. Eventually it made its way into tiki drinks in the 1940s when Trader Vic rediscovered orgeat as a sweetener.

Commercial orgeat brands vary widely from syrupy-sweet to nutty. This housemade version by Eamon Rockey of Betony in New York City is pure marzipan. He uses bitter almonds in a sous-vide preparation to capture the true essence of the nuts, which is then sweetened to become a cordial. Use it in aMai Tai, aJapanese Cocktailor any tiki drink as a sweetener with its own personality.
instructions: 1. In a pan over medium-low heat, toast the almonds until the oils begin release, and a light color has been achieved.
2. Add the almonds to a large ziplock bag containing the water.
3. Hack asous vide: Set a colander or a steaming basket inside a larger pot of water set over the lowest heat possible.
4. Drop the bag inside the colander (it should be completely submerged), and cook in the hot water bath for 4 hours.
5. Strain and discard the almonds, reserving the warm liquid.
6. Add sugar and salt, and stir to dissolve.
7. Seal in an airtight container, allow to come to room temperature and then cool in the refrigerator.
8. Add the rosewater and orange blossom water to finish.
9. Store, refrigerated, in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

title: French Connection
intro_philosophy: “I really enjoy blanc/bianco vermouth. Mixing it into a cocktail. Drinking it like water in the summer,” says Jane Danger, of Cienfuegos and Mother of Pearl in New York. Here, Danger goes tiki with it, using it in her French Connection, where the vermouth plays nicely with rum to round out an otherwise-bracing combination of bitters, grapes and citrus.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Dolin Blanc
instructions: 1. Muddle grapes in shaking tin.
2. Combine all ingredients in tin, shake and fine strain into coupe.
3. Garnish with a skewered grape wrapped with a thin orange peel, then dipped in 151, set on fire and extinguished in the drink.

title: Lazy Bird’s Hemingway Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Lazy Bird’s beverage director, Lee Zaremba, swaps out a traditionalmaraschinowith a domestic one from Leopold Brothers, made without cherry pits. While this removes its usual almond flavor, grapefruit juice and syrup add a different type of vibrancy to the drink.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with lime wheel and fermented strawberry.

title: The Mahatma
intro_philosophy: An homage to Martin “Mahatma” Lomasney, who was allegedly the recipient of the first Ward Eight cocktail in 1898, this riff modernizes the drink with hibiscus-infused grenadine and a spritz of orange oil.
instructions: 1. Pour the liquids into shaker with ice and shake hard for 10 seconds.
2. Express orange oil from an orange peel over a chilled coupe glass and discard.
3. Double strain into the coupe.

title: Jasper’s Corner Tap & Kitchen Radler
intro_philosophy: At Jasper’s Corner Tap and Kitchen, they call on chamomile syrup, lemon and mandarin vodka for a refreshingly tart, citrus-heavy variation on the radler, served in a coupe for a short take on the long drink.
ingredients: 1 ounce mandarin vodka, preferably Hangar One
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine vodka, lemon juice and chamomile syrup and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe glass and top with beer.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Cel Rey
intro_philosophy:
Fermented celery soda harmonizes with mezcal and lime juice in Danny Childs’Cel Rey, a savory stunner created for the Farm and Fisherman Tavern in New Jersey. If you don’t want to make your own soda, use a can of Dr. Brown’s Cel-Ray (which inspired Childs’ version), plus a few dashes of celery bitters to make up for the lack of fresh celery flavor in the store-bought soda. And while Childs prefers Rey Campero mezcal for its subtlety, he’s not rigid about it. The salinity and smokiness of the main ingredients will win out regardless.

Note: It is important to use organic ginger if making your own soda, as much of the ginger available in grocery stores has been irradiated, a process that kills the bacteria and yeasts necessary to produce a healthy bug.
ingredients: homemade celery tonic (see Editor’s Note) or Dr. Brown’s Cel-Ray soda, to top
3 dashes celery bitters (if using Dr. Brown’s Cel-Ray soda)
instructions: 1. Combine the first two ingredients in a Collins glass filled with ice.
2. Top with celery tonic.
3. Garnish with a celery leaf.

title: Nightmarcher
intro_philosophy: Lodged within the bowels of a Hong Kong wet market (a place to buy everything from live poultry to vegetables), 001 is one of Hong Kong’s more recent avant-garde bars defying the city’s stereotypical vertical opulence. Sky Huo, one of 001’s bartenders, can be found behind the market and through a nondescript black door making her signature cocktail, the Nightmarcher. Ariff on theLast Wordcombining Chinese mangosteen fruit, tequila, mezcal, yellow Chartreuse and celery bitters, it’s garnished with a piece of frozen smoked mangosteen served on a pineapple leaf.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, muddle the mangosteen pods.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and ice, and shake.
3. Double strain over a large ice cube into a tulip glass or a snifter.
4. Serve with a piece of mangosteen over a pineapple leaf.

title: Sarah Morrissey’s Gin & Tonic
intro_philosophy: This Spanish-style G&T features a Spanish gin, with garnishes frozen into a large ice cube. Bar director Sarah Morrissey blanches the rosemary “so it stays really green,” and freezes half of it in the ice cube, while the leafy top stays above the ice so it bobs attractively over the top of the drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, preferably Xoriguer Gin de Mahón
instructions: 1. Combine the gin and tonic in a goblet over the garnish ice cube.
2. Squeeze the lime wedge, and drop the spent wedge into the drink.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit half-moon and lime wheel.

title: Banana Shadow
intro_philosophy: The Daiquiri is one of the most called-for cocktails at the Los Angeles outpost of Broken Shaker, according to bar manager Christine Wiseman. “People come to our rooftop and immediately say, ‘I want a rum drink,’” says Wiseman, whose bar sits atop downtown’s Freehand Hotel. “That’s already their vibe.” So it’s more than logical that she riffs upon the classic rum-sugar-lime format, seeking new ways to present an old drink. For her Banana Shadow, a smart variation on the popular banana Daiquiri, Wiseman builds around Giffard Banane du Brésil, created by manually macerating bananas imported from the South American country. With other banana liqueurs, it sometimes “feels like you’re drinking candy,” she says. “But here, you’re getting delicious, subtle tropical notes that are hard to achieve on your own.” Wiseman loves the inherent banana notes present in Magdalena Rum from Guatemala, as well as the nuttiness of Lustau Palo Cortado sherry, for their ability to round out the drink, punctuated by an unexpected hit of cardamom bitters.
ingredients: ½ ounce Lustau Palo Cortado sherry
¼ ounce Giffard Banane du Brésil
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with Kold Draft ice cubes.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with dehydrated lime wheel.

title: Fin de Siecle
intro_philosophy: The House Martini at LA’s Bar Clacson, the Fin de Siecle was adapted from The Old Waldorf-Astoria Bar Book (1935) that calls for a 2:1 Martini spec, with a measured dose of both amaro and orange bitters.
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Up-To-Date Cocktail
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir.
3. Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with the lemon peel.

title: Yacht Rock
intro_philosophy: Garret Richard’s credits include founding the Brooklyn Luau, where he initially debuted this Jungle Bird variation. “It was bitter and a little bit light and had that weird orange-chocolate thing going on,” he recalls. “People loved it.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce rum, such as Smith & Cross
1/2 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Dolin Blanc
1/2 ounce crème de cacao, such as Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients except garnishes and shake with three cubes of ice.
2. Strain into a snifter over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a lime boat and an orchid.

title: Rumba Libre
intro_philosophy: At Rumba, a rum-focused bar in Seattle, this drink, a twist on theCuba Libre, was originally pre-bottled. “We had custom bottle openers made with our logo on it,” recalls general manager Jen Akin. “It was served as a kit with a block of ice, lime [to squeeze or garnish] and you got to keep the bottle opener. It was cute.” Yet, it was challenging to keep the bubbles for longer than a few days; the drink is now served on tap instead. The below is a home-friendly version of the cocktail.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Cuban rum, preferably Bacardi Quatro or Cana Brava 3 Year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Resa Mueller’s Improved Manhattan
intro_philosophy: Resa Mueller’s slight tweak on the “improved” version of the Manhattan—a label that signals the introduction of big-flavor adjuncts like absinthe and maraschino to timeless templates—swaps the expected cherry liqueur for Galliano, introducing a touch of vanilla that plays nicely with a mellowbourbon, tagging in for spicierrye.
ingredients: 2 ounces bourbon, preferably Four Roses Small Batch
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Stone Fence Riff #1
intro_philosophy: The originalStone Fence(dark rum, Angostura bitters, cider) finds its roots in colonial times; JP Fetherston’s variation kicks up the flavor with the welcome addition of peppery allspice syrup and citrus. The dry cider here tones down the sweetness of the rum, adding an “ineffable, barnyard-like quality that you unleash when you ferment apples… the ‘funk,’ if you will,” says Fetherston.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rum, Thomas Tew Single Barrel
1/4 ounce Virginia allspice simple syrup, see Editor's Note
cider, preferably Foggy Ridge Serious Cider
instructions: 1. Add rum, syrup and lemon juice to a shaking tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over a large ice rectangle.
3. Top with cider and garnish with dried apple wheel.

title: Employees Only’s Mezcal Margarita
intro_philosophy:
Steve Schneider, principal bartender at New York’s Employees Only, has a long history with Margaritas. “I love Margaritas, I always have,” he says. “The Margarita has been a progression of my career, because in my 13 years behind the bar, it’s been the drink I’ve always had to make, even if it was in a shitty dive bar, with 18 beers on tap, making disco drinks.”

Now, the mezcal-spiked version is a regular after-hours feature at EO, where the rest of the staff shares his love of the classic.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker, and add ice.
2. Shake until chilled and strain into ice-filled tumbler glass.

title: Snaquiri
intro_philosophy: In the Petraske tradition, a Daiquiri ought to be crisp and well-balanced. Double it up and you’ve got the Snaquiri. In the words of its progenitor, Karin Stanley, who now tends bar at Suffolk Arms and Little Branch, “One Daiquiri is to be consumed rapidly and immediately, the second to be sipped and savored.”
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a single cocktail shaker. Shake with one large piece of ice.
2. Strain into two cocktail coupes.
3. Garnish each coupe with a lime wheel.

title: The Odeon’s Cosmopolitan
intro_philosophy: Coming in second at a recent Cosmopolitan blind tasting, appropriately enough, was the Cosmo served today at The Odeon, where Toby Cecchini invented the cocktail. Varying slightly from theoriginal, it contained 1 ½ ounces Absolut Citron, ¾ ounce Cointreau, ½ ounce lime juice and ½ ounce Ocean Spray, garnished with a thin, twirling lime peel.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces lemon vodka, preferably Absolut Citron
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into chilled martini glass.
3. Garnish with lime twist.

title: Italian Greyhound
intro_philosophy: The original Italian Greyhound was created by John Gertsen at the now-closed Boston bar Drink. It combined equal-parts Punt e Mes and grapefruit juice. At Sunny’s in Miami, owner Will Thompson has served the cocktail off-menu, with the vermouth dialed back slightly, for a lower-proof take on the bittersweet drink.
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to a salt-rimmed glass filled with ice.
2. Garnish with a grapefruit wedge.

title: Thinking of a Place
intro_philosophy:
Elijah Craig Bourbon’s annual Old-Fashioned Week returns for its second year supporting the Restaurant Workers’ Community Foundation, October 15-24.Sign up your bar or restaurantto participate by featuring Elijah Craig Old-Fashioned riffs on your menu.

Jump’s Old-Fashioned variation celebrates the herbal and lightly fruit-forward qualities inherent in Elijah Craig by pairing it with the unexpected modifiers of yellow Chartreuse and strawberry syrup. Jump likewise finds strawberries and pistachios natural complements—infusing the latter into Cognac. The result is a bright, easy-drinking cocktail perfect for a patio session.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Giostra d’Alcol
intro_philosophy: The Giostra d’Alcol (the carousel of alcohol) was a cocktail that was created in Turin in the 1930s by painter and sculptor Enrico Prampolini as part of the Italian Futurist movement. In his bookFuturist Mixology, Fulvio Piccinino describes the drink as a shuffled version of the spritz, made with Campari, Barbera d’Asti wine and cedrata, a citron-infused sparkling soda. Naren Young’s more modern rendition, which is sweetened with a touch of honey syrup, forgoes the classic cheese and chocolate garnishes in favor of a simple orange slice.
ingredients: 2 ounces red wine, preferably Barbera d'Asti
1 ounce Baladin Cedrata soda or sparkling lemonade
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in an Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
2. Stir, top with soda and garnish with an orange slice.

title: The Local Hanky Panky
intro_philosophy: The originalHanky Panky, an equal-parts gin and sweet vermouth cocktail bolstered by two dashes of bitter Fernet-Branca, dates back to 1925 and is the most famous cocktail credited to Ada “Coley” Coleman during her time as head bartender at the American Bar at The Savoy Hotel in London. Variations abound and at Brooklyn restaurant and café Leo, Steven Reker turns to a trio of made-in New York ingredients, swapping out the typical two dashes of Fernet-Branca for a half-ounce of Brooklyn-born Arcane Fernet. “I like the classic Hanky Panky because it’s somewhere in between being a Martini or a Negroni—it’s a great winter gin drink for the indecisive,” says Fadem.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces gin, preferably Forthave Spirits Blue Gin
1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Little City
1/2 ounce fernet, preferably Arcane Distilling Fernet Herbal Amaro
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: More Supreme
intro_philosophy: The first drink Alec Bales landed on theTiconderoga Clubmenu, the More Supreme hews closely to the Daiquiri blueprint, but opts for a base of aged rhum agricole for a rich, almost savory rendition. A quarter-ounce of Camparisunkto the bottom of the cocktail offers an unexpected last sip. “The idea was, if I had to have one cocktail right before eating a meal and I couldn’t decide between a Daiquiri and a Negroni,” says Bales.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rhum agricole, preferably Rhum Clément Select Barrel
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except Campari, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Slowly pour Campari against the inside edge of the glass.
4. Garnish with freshly cracked black pepper.

title: Bay Cosmo
intro_philosophy:
The knock-out favorite from White Lyan’s first menu, this force-carbonated play on theCosmopolitanhas been subtly adapted to be easier to make at home.

For more on carbonating cocktails, Team Lyanoutlines their best practices.
ingredients: 5 1/2 ounces cranberry and bay leaf cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an iSi soda siphon (be sure that the thin interior tube is removed) and charge.
2. Shake the canister, then place it in the refrigerator for at least two hours, or preferably, overnight.
3. With the canister upright, very slowly release the pressure by pressing down the lever. (Do this a little bit at a time over the course of half an hour or so, storing in the fridge in between.)
4. Carefully open the top of the cannister and pour the drink into a coupe.
5. Garnish with a twist of grapefruit peel.

title: Picante
intro_philosophy: The originalPicante, which included cucumbers and hot sauce, was created at Soho Beach House Miami. Ata conference hosted by the brandfor its bar managers, Chris Ojeda, from the West Hollywood location, simplified the drink into a spicy Margarita, and the house cocktail was born. It rolled out to all clubs globally in 2012. But it’s only recently that the drink became a U.K. sensation, thanks to a perfect storm of pop culture moments paired with premium agave spirits finally hitting the mainstream.
ingredients: small piece (about 1/4 inch) of red chile
instructions: 1. Cut the small piece of chile and press it with a muddler in the shaking tin.
2. Hand-clap the cilantro to express the aroma, then drop it into the tin.
3. Add the rest of the ingredients and ice, shake, and double-strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
4. Cut the top end off the chile and place on the drink to garnish.

title: Electric Swizzard
intro_philosophy: The Chartreuse Swizzle, originally created in the early aughts, ushered its star ingredient into the tiki realm. This swizzle from Justin Levaughn atOtto’s High Divestars a common alternative for the herbal liqueur, Boomsma Claerkampster Cloosterbitter, bolstered by rum and combined with pineapple and lime juice, ginger falernum and a housemade vanilla honey.
ingredients: 1 ounce white rum, such as Clément Canne Bleue
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a footed pilsner glass with pebble ice and swizzle.
2. Float 3 dashes of Angostura bitters on top of the drink.

title: Tom Yum Punch
intro_philosophy: Recently, bartenders have taken to throwing everything but the proverbial kitchen sink into milk punches, then clarifying it into unrecognizable, transparent oblivion. Here, Adam Sousa and Caleb Landry create a tom yum soup-inspired drink filtered through curdled coconut milk.
ingredients: 5 cups tom yum soup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a container, combine the tom yum soup mixture with the lime juice.
2. Combine the milk and coconut milk in a separate container.
3. Stir in the lemon juice to the milk mixture, then immediately add the cocktail mix. The mixture will curdle.
4. Place in the refrigerator overnight.
5. Strain the mixture through a coffee filter.
6. To serve, pour 3 ounces into a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
7. Garnish with a chile pepper and a cilantro sprig.

title: New English Negroni
intro_philosophy: Al Culliton developed a version of this brandy-based Negroni variation before calling on Ned King to collaborate on the recipe in anticipation of its debut on the menu at Gigantic in Easthampton, MA. As Culliton explains, “it hits a lot of autumnal notes beyond apple―nuttiness, bitter citrus peel and spices.”
ingredients: 1 ounce oloroso sherry, preferably Lustau Don Nuño
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with plenty of ice.
2. Stir for 20 seconds.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Watermelon Ginger Beer
intro_philosophy:
Savoring the brilliant red hues of canned Hawaiian Punch, strawberry Fanta soda, sweetened hibiscus or an effervescent blush-colored spritz is a drinking tradition etched in Black people’s tongues. In his bookSoul Food: The Surprising Story of an American Cuisine, One Plate at a Time, food scholar Adrian Miller writes: “Red drinks were plentiful in the plantation Big House. Antebellum southern cookbooks are replete with recipes for homemade cherry, raspberry, strawberry liqueurs, syrups, and vinegars, kept on hand to color a wide range of hard and soft drinks.” In Senegal in West Africa, hibiscus flower buds or petals are steeped in water and made into a drink—bissap. From the red clays of Georgia to the town square in the French Caribbean, red drink is a celebration staple with a clear path back to Black American roots and connection to people of the African diaspora.

In celebration of the day in 1865 when more than 200,000 enslaved Texans found out they were free—two years after President Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation—ruby-colored Italian bitters or spirit-free raspberry shrubs with tonic flow freely at Juneteenth tables. InWatermelon & Red Birds: A Cookbook for Juneteenth and Black Celebrations, I offer a cooler made of ginger beer and watermelon juice that captures the flavor of the season, with a visual nod to the day’s typical red hues. The drink can easily be turned alcoholic by adding a splash of your favorite vodka. I recommend using fresh ginger to make homemade ginger beer (it adds a spicier kick than most store-bought options), which pairs with the fresh watermelon, a fruit indigenous to the African continent. Fennel fronds frozen into ice cubes offer an herbaceous undertone as the cubes melt, though dill can easily be substituted too.

On Juneteenth, at least one crimson cocktail must be consumed. Making red drinks is communion, a toast to old and new sacrifices—the future and past illuminated through the glass. A sip takes you on a rapturous journey, from where we’ve been to where we’re going. —Nicole Taylor
ingredients: 1 to 2 ounces vodka, or spirit of your choice
ginger beer, to top, preferably Barritt’s or homemade (see Editor’s Note)
2 tablespoons  coarsely chopped fresh fennel fronds, optional
instructions: 1. Divide the fennel fronds, if using, between two ice cube trays. Fill with water and freeze until solid, 4 to 8 hours.
2. In a highball or rocks glass, combine the vodka and watermelon juice, add the fennel ice or regular ice, and top with ginger beer.
3. Garnish with fennel fronds or dill, if using.

title: Livorno Punch
intro_philosophy: Italy has its very own punch:ponce alla Livornese. But unlike traditional punch, Livorno Punch swaps the tea element for coffee, specifically espresso, resulting in a bolder formula that feels right at home alongside the canon of modern coffee cocktails, fromcaffè correttotoEspresso Martinis.
instructions: 1. In a small tempered glass, add the sugar and lemon twist.
2. Top with the rum followed by the hot espresso.

title: Mauby
