intro_philosophy: Across various Caribbean cultures, you can find some version of mauby, a classic bittersweet brew served over ice. Though it is traditionally served without alcohol, the spiced, aniseed-laced amber drink has always been more of a grown-up beverage. Mauby is enjoyed year-round, but its bouquet of clove, star anise and cinnamon is reminiscent of mulled wine at Thanksgiving and Christmas fruitcake in December. Try it with rum in aMauby Mojitoor with Scotch whisky in theMoko Jumbie.
ingredients: 3/4 cup white sugar, plus more for sweetening to taste
3 cups water, plus 10 cups of water, divided
instructions: 1. Add spices, sugar and 3 cups water to a saucepan, and boil on the stovetop for 20 minutes. Allow concentrate to cool.
2. Pour the concentrate into a large bowl, then mix in 10 cups of cold water.
3. Sweeten with additional sugar to taste.
4. Strain and pour into a jug. Serve cold or with ice.

title: Margarita & Cream
intro_philosophy: The Margarita & Cream fromSchmuckin New York’s East Village is a spoonable frozen strawberry and rhubarb Margarita comes with a hefty dollop of salty whipped cream on top. It’s a drink and a snack in one.It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: 130 grams strawberry-rhubarb ice cream (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce blanco tequila, such as Patron
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a small glass, then top with whipped cream. Serve with a spoon.

title: Deke Dunne’s Widow’s Kiss
intro_philosophy: Deke Dunne makes some significant adjustments toGeorge Kappeler’s 1895 recipe, like adding Cognac to the apple brandy base and reducing the measures of Bénédictine and yellow Chartreuse. But this version, which he serves at Allegory in Washington, D.C., ultimately honors the original by enhancing its core flavors.
ingredients: 1 ounce apple brandy, preferably Republic Restoratives Chapman’s Apple Brandy
3/4 ounce VSOP Cognac, preferably Rémy Martin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir to chill.
3. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Kentucky Buck
intro_philosophy: Traditionally, abuckis made with ginger ale, but in this take on the long, summery cooler bartender Erick Castro uses homemade ginger syrup and soda water to create a bubbly cocktail with more bite. It’s named for Kentucky’s state spirit—bourbon, of course—and with the addition of a muddled strawberry and fresh lemon, it couldn’t be better suited to a long, lazy afternoon.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle strawberry with ginger syrup.
2. Add lemon juice, bourbon, bitters and ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a Collins glass over ice and top with club soda.
4. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Bywater
intro_philosophy: Chris Hannah createdthe Bywaterat Arnaud’s in 2007. The drink is essentially a distant Southern cousin to theBrooklyn. To reflect the Bywater neighborhood’s Caribbean influence, Hannah swapped out the whiskey for rum. He added falernum, a traditional Caribbean liqueur with top notes of allspice, lime and ginger. Instead of vermouth, he opted for Averna—“amaro has more body than vermouth,” Hannah notes. The amaro offered a distinct tang of orange peel, another staple of the South and a tip of the hat to the orange-heavy Amer Picon in the Brooklyn.
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients until chilled in a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe or a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express an orange twist over the surface, then discard. Garnish with a cherry.

title: Sakura Maru
intro_philosophy: To integrate the yogurt into this cocktail without it curdling or separating,Leo Robitschekcombines it with a stabilizing green tea syrup, which allows it to fully incorporate with the citrus, pisco and genever.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce aged cachaça, preferably Avua Amburana
3/4 ounce pisco, preferably Macchu Pisco Quebranta
1 ounce green tea yogurt (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain over large cubes in a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with lime zest.

title: Bar Raval’s Dunhill
intro_philosophy: The Dunhill first appeared inDrinks—Long and Short(1925) by Nina Toye and A.H. Adair, wherein the drink is credited to Hatchett’s Bar, London. One can presume that the fashionable tobacco and luxury goods brand founded by Alfred Dunhill at the turn of the 20th century is the source of the drink’s name. At Bar Raval, the bar team is repopularizing the onetime British classic with a carefully curated group of ingredients that play up the drink’s warm and cozy side.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces London dry gin, preferably Beefeater
3/4 ounce cream sherry, preferably Lustau East India
3/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Vinos Guerra
1/4 ounce dry Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass.
2. Add ice (preferably Kold-Draft cubes) and stir until chilled, adding more ice as needed.
3. Garnish with a pitted Castelvetrano olive and lemon twist on a pick.

title: Songbird
intro_philosophy: While walking through Kalustyan’s, an iconic grocery store in Midtown Manhattan, bartender Mark Tubridy came across a fig syrup that inspired this drink. A house-made pepper-fig syrup draws out the piquant Grains of Paradise notes in the gin, while the Mediterranean fruit lends depth to the red bitter liqueur. The verjus blanc and citrate syrup fold in fresh acidity to balance the sweetness, with the rich, earthy coffee notes dominating on the finish.
ingredients: 3/4 parts  Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Bitter
3/4 parts  black pepper–fig syrup (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 parts  coffee-infused verjus blanc (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and add ice.
2. Shake vigorously and fine-strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with freshly cracked black pepper and a lemon twist.

title: Calindri
intro_philosophy: Named for film actor and Cynar spokesperson Ernesto Calindri, Emanuele Broccatelli’s cocktail utilizes flavors that might appear during a Roman meal, including mint, artichoke and lemon.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mint liqueur, or lesser calamint-infused liqueur
tonic, to top, preferably AQ herbal
instructions: 1. In a highball glass, combine the Cynar, lemon juice and lesser calamint liquor.
2. Add ice and top up the glass with tonic.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel and salt crystals.

title: Queen Snake
intro_philosophy: No longer relegated to the ’tini craze of the ’90s, lychee is having a moment. “The addition of lychee brings delicate, floral high notes that tease out other floral aromatics,” says Shannon Tebay, who uses lychee liqueur in this drink, a stirred mixture of grape eau de vie and herbaceous Douglas fir eau de vie.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanche de armagnac, preferably Cobra Fire Eau de Vie de Raisin
1/2 ounce Clear Creek Douglas Fir Eau de Vie
2 teaspoons lychee liqueur, preferably Giffard Lichi Li Lychee Liqueur
1 teaspoon crème de cacao, preferably Marie Brizard
instructions: 1. Express lime, leave in bottom of a Sazerac glass.
2. Combine all ingredients and stir to integrate.
3. Top with cracked ice.

title: Jilo Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: The original Elote Old-Fashioned, created by the Casa Lumbre team, was named for the distillery in Jilotepec, Mexico, where both Nixta and Abasolo whiskey are made. Instead of the sugar used in a traditional Old-Fashioned, the drink is sweetened with Nixta liqueur.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir the whiskey, liqueur and bitters with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.
3. Garnish with orange and lemon twists.

title: Tom Macy’s French 75
ingredients: 1/4 ounce rich demerara syrup (2:1, demerara sugar:water)
2 1/2 ounces Champagne, preferably Moet & Chandon Imperial Brut
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Champagne, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Fine strain into a flute or coupe.
3. Top with Champagne.
4. Very gently dip a barspoon to the bottom of the glass once or twice to integrate the ingredients, agitating the bubbles at little as possible.
5. Express the lemon peel over the drink then gently stir with the peel to integrate. Do not discard.

title: Big Spender
intro_philosophy: Created in 2005 to celebrate the Broadway showSweet Charity, Dale DeGroff’s Big Spender nods to the musical’s hit song and appropriately calls for an extravagant rosé Champagne topper (specifically, Cristal). “We did the luxury version for the opening, but decided that beyond the opening we might need to lower the cost of sales a bit,” jokes DeGroff.
ingredients: rosé Champagne  , to top, preferably Cristal
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a flute.
3. Top with rosé Champagne.
4. Garnish with a flamed orange peel and orange horse's neck garnish.

title: Cosmonaut
intro_philosophy:
Another succinct Sasha Petraske creation, this is his sly retort to the popularity of theCosmopolitan, as the name coyly indicates. Indeed, the drink, piquant and slightly fruity, fills much the same purpose, tastewise, as that ubiquitous cocktail—only more so.

Reprinted with permission from3-Ingredient Cocktails: An Opinionated Guide to the Most Enduring Drinks in the Cocktail Canonby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2017. Published Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled, about 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Monterey Park Lychee Martini
intro_philosophy: At Kato,Han Suk Chois known to mine cherished memories and childhood flavors for inspiration. The Monterey Park Lychee Martini is modeled after almond jello, a popular Korean dessert that is usually served with canned lychee or canned mandarin. Cho notes that most people are either Team Lychee or Team Mandarin—she’s Team Lychee, as evidenced by this playful cocktail made with elderflower, a blend of rums, pisco, yogurt, citrus and of course lychee, served atop a scoop of almond jello.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce lychee purée, preferably Perfect Purée (or finely blended canned lychee)
1/4 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Père Labat 40
instructions: 1. Scoop the almond jello into the bottom of a highball glass.
2. Combine all remaining ingredients in a cocktail shaker and whip-shake with a few pieces of pebble ice until the ice melts.
3. Fill the highball glass with crushed ice, then pour the cocktail into the glass and serve with a boba straw.

title: Allies Cocktail
intro_philosophy: The improved formula—that is, a traditional recipe gussied up with a splash of this or that—informs many earlyMartinispoised for a comeback. Take for instance, the Allies Cocktail, a 50/50 Martini dressed up with several dashes of savory-spicy kümmel. (The drink’s name refers to the alliance of English gin, French vermouth and Russian kümmel).
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Pietro Collina’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Pietro Collina’s take on the Daiquiri was the top vote-getter in our blind tasting of Daiquiris in2017and2024. His formula couldn’t have been more classic: two ounces ofFlor de Caña 4-Year Extra Dry rum, one ounce of double-strained lime juice and three-quarters of an ounce of rich cane syrup (2:1) that was equal parts bold and clean.
ingredients: 2 ounces lightly aged rum, preferably Flor de Caña 4-Year Extra Dry
3/4 ounce rich cane syrup (2:1, cane sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, add ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: Sleepwalker
intro_philosophy: Building on a base of chamomile-infused Scotch, Benjamin Smith’s Sleepwalker is an ideal antidote to cold weather blues. Though it was inspired by the posset, a historic British milk drink curdled with wine or ale, this modern variation quite closely resembles an eggnog, to which a measure of Averna lends welcomed bitterness.
ingredients: 1 ounce chamomile-infused Scotch, preferably Johnnie Walker Red Label (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin with ice and roll the mixture back and forth between the tins.
2. Strain into a tea cup.

title: Americano 2.0
intro_philosophy: A direct descendent of the Milano-Torino, the Americano, the low-alcohol highball consisting of Campari, sweet vermouth and soda water, got its name due to its popularity among American expats during Prohibition, who requested a splash of soda to soften the bittersweet profile of the drink. Dante’s Naren Young reboots this classic with a few subtle tweaks.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Dolin Vermouth de Chambery Rouge
1 dash Maldon salt solution (1:1, Maldon salt:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the ginger soda, in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Top with ginger soda.
3. Garnish with an orange slice or wedge.
4. Serve with a metal straw.

title: Last Spritz
intro_philosophy: At Capri Club in Los Angeles, the Last Spritz is a cross between a Last Word and the aperitivo staple. In lieu of green Chartreuse, Bordiga Centum Herbis adds herbal flavor alongside the requisite maraschino liqueur. The whole thing is topped with soda for a spritzy finish.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce maraschino liqueur, such as Bordiga
instructions: 1. Add the first four ingredients to a shaker with two ice cubes and shake quickly.
2. Strain into a Collins glass and top with soda.
3. Garnish with a cherry.

title: Both Ways
intro_philosophy: This variation on a 1920s drink called the Cold Deck (poker slang for when the dealer has stacked the cards to the disadvantage of a player) has similarities to both the Harvard and Rob Roy—both distant relatives of the Manhattan, with the addition of white crème de menthe. The Chardonnay Cask Finished Glen Moray Single Malt adds depth and structure, with a dash of orange bitters bringing it all together in harmony. Be sure to chill your mixing glass as well as your coupe—anything colder than deathly cold is still too warm for this drink.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces  Glen Moray Speyside Classic Single Malt Scotch Whisky (Chardonnay Cask Finish)
¼ ounce  white crème de menthe
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a chilled mixing glass, then fill with ice.
2. Stir and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Plum
intro_philosophy: The inspiration for this Fizz began with the Genshu shochu, Matthew Hunter recalls: “Thismugi(barley) shochu has wonderful aromas of cacao nib and salted plum, [then] the palate moves to more savory flavors of toasted sesame and popcorn.” To accent those flavors, he created a sweet-and-savory pickled plum tahini and miso-tinged syrup. An ounce of aged rum completes the drink. “I love the balance between the Genshu and Exclusiva reserve,” he says.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  Lustau Los Arcos amontillado sherry
instructions: 1. In a mixing tin, combine all ingredients. Dry shake (no ice), until the egg white emulsifies.
2. Add ice to mixing tin, and shake again to chill.
3. Double strain into a fizz glass.
4. Garnish with black sesame seeds.

title: Oranges Etc.
intro_philosophy: “We often take one base flavor and try to insert as many applications of that flavor as possible,”says Naren Youngof his drink-making process.For this riff on theAperol Spritz, he tripled- and quadrupled-downon theiconic“orange”factor.“I think there are about six or seven applications of orange here: orange soda, Lillet, Grand Marnier, orange citrate, all these orange-y elements. It sounds like a bombshell. But the key is to apply it with a subtle hand.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce orange-flavored vodka, preferably Grey Goose L’Orange
1/2 ounce orange liqueur, preferably Grand Marnier
Italian orange soda, to top, preferably San Pellegrino Aranciata
instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice.
2. Add all ingredients except orange soda to the glass and stir to chill and combine.
3. Top with orange soda.
4. Express oils from orange peel coin over top of the drink, then discard.
5. Garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Miso Express
intro_philosophy: “When I made it the first time, it was a banger,” saysParker Luthmanof his Miso Express, a Spumoni-inspired cocktail that marries gin, Campari and grapefruit, a “very classic trio of flavors.” To make it his own, he sweetens the mixture and lends texture through a miso-ginger syrup, which pushes the flavor profile outside of the expected. “I really enjoy how it brought a really strong umami finish as well as a hint of saltiness,” he says.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce white miso ginger syrup (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce acidulated grapefruit juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the tonic water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with tonic water.
4. Garnish with grapefruit half moon.

title: Silent Night
intro_philosophy: The inspiration for this slightly herbal, large-format Martini came from the unorthodox combination of green Chartreuse and hot chocolate. “This is basically the Martini version of that,” explains Schramm, of his blend of gin, blanc vermouth, green Chartreuse and mole bitters.
ingredients: 3 3/4 ounces blanc vermouth, preferably Cap Corse
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 750ml bottle and store in the freezer.
2. When ready to serve, pour into a chilled coupe and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Mad World
intro_philosophy: Structurally simple yet satisfyingly complex, the Mad World, served at Café Mars, is an example of what makes nonalcoholic cocktails so exciting. It’s familiar but foreign, and offers enough depth to satisfy any drinker. The restaurant builds its own spice blend, but there are plenty of commercially available berbere blends that make prepping this drink at home a snap.
instructions: 1. Fill a tall glass with ice and sparkling water.
2. In a cocktail shaker, combine Ghia, berbere syrup, carrot juice and lemon juice and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.

title: Dale DeGroff’s Grasshopper
intro_philosophy: At a recent blind Grasshopper tasting, the most traditional of Grasshoppers, created by the most classic of cocktail bartenders, prevailed.Dale DeGroffwon with his blend of one ounce of Marie Brizard green Creme de Menthe, one ounce Tempus Fugit crème de cacao and 1 ½ ounces of heavy cream, served in a Nick & Nora-style coupe and garnished with shaved chocolate. The panel found it just right in appearance, texture and balance of flavor.
ingredients: 1 ounce green crème de menthe, preferably Marie Brizard
1 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with shaved chocolate.

title: Sun-Dried Lime Gimlet
intro_philosophy: This recipe, which Alba Huerta dates to 2018 or 2019, is typically pre-batched and stored in the refrigerator where it can be quickly dispatched as a half-sized welcome drink for guests at her Houston bar, Julep. The inclusion of sun-dried limes in the cordial was inspired by chef Yotam Ottolenghi, who uses them as a staple in his cooking.
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces navy-strength gin, such as Fords Officers' Reserve
3/4 ounce sun-dried lime cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Apple Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: Granny Smith is our apple of choice here, its tart qualities standing in for the expected citrus kick of the original. Splitting the liqueur quotient is a measure of manzanilla sherry and blanc vermouth, bringing a salinity and sweetness to the table, enhanced by a small boost of citrus-forward gin. We recommend storing the apples in the refrigerator prior to juicing to keep the ice from melting too quickly (or forgo ice altogether for a zippier alternative).
ingredients: 3/4 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Comoz
1/2 ounce gin, such as Future Gin
instructions: 1. Using a Breville juicer or something similar, juice Granny Smith apples until yielding 5 ounces.
2. Add the sherry, vermouth and gin to a Collins glass and add ice.
3. Top with fresh-pressed apple juice.

title: Haley Traub’s Frozen Margarita
intro_philosophy: The unanimous first-place winner inour frozen Margarita tastingwas that of Haley Traub, general manager at New York’s Attaboy. The judges found it to be the most “textbook” in the tasting, with Brian Evans describing it as the most “universally palatable” and a frozen Margarita that would never be sent back. The recipe, however, is not quite so textbook. To the expected blanco tequila (Traub favors Milagro), Cointreau, lime juice and agave nectar, Traub adds a splash of orange juice, a subtle touch that adds some necessary extra sweetness and roundness while remaining almost undetectable.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Milagro Silver
1/4 ounce agave nectar, preferably Madhava Organic Amber Agave
instructions: 1. Prepare the glass, if using the lime-salt rim. Moisten half the rim of a double rocks glass with a lime wheel, then dip gently in kosher salt.
2. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
3. Fill a 13-ounce double rocks glass with a heaping scoop of pebble ice (see Editor’s Note).
4. Add ice to the blender and blend until smooth.
5. Pour into a double rocks glass.

title: Banana Blossom
intro_philosophy: With its striking scarlet hue and manicured lemon twist studded with a mint plume, the Banana Blossom is the perfect encapsulation ofErika Flowers’ ability to blend the dramatic with the approachable. The drink features banana liqueur, lime and aged rum infused with hibiscus, an ingredient “so ingrained in me, growing up in a Caribbean household,” says Flowers. She finishes the drink with a spritz of lavender tincture on both the surface of the cocktail and the stem of the glass, so the aroma transfers to the drinker’s fingertips.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces hibiscus-infused aged Puerto Rican rum, preferably Don Q 7-year (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banane du Brésil
1/4 ounce rich Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Whip-shake with a few pebble ice cubes until diluted, then pour into a pebble ice–filled snifter.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel rose with a mint bouquet through the center.
4. Using an atomizer, spritz lavender tincture over the cocktail and on the stem of the glass.

title: Rainmaker
intro_philosophy: A spin on a pineapple Daiquiri that calls for lemon juice in place of lime, the Rainmaker also sees the unlikely addition ofBénédictine, an ingredient rarely encountered in the sour format. “Everyone knows Bénédictine from theVieux Carré, which is delicious, but it’s always associated with brown spirits—it’s not typically used in light and refreshing drinks,” explains Bales. It adds a layered spice note to the formula, complemented by the easy-to-make caramelized pineapple cordial. A dusting of locally made lime salt adds a zesty finish.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces white rum, preferably Independent Distilling
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with lime salt.

title: South Bronx
intro_philosophy: Al Sotack, currently partner at Brooklyn bar Jupiter Disco, developed this version of the classic Bronx cocktail for now-closed Philly bar Franklin Mortgage and Investment Co in 2013. “I wanted to push back on the idea that the Bronx is a shitty cocktail,” he recalls of his inspiration.
ingredients: 2 ounces Old Tom gin, preferably 1 ½ ounces Haymans and ½ ounce Ransom
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Altstadt
intro_philosophy: A tiki-fied shandy, the Altstadt (the German term for “historic city center”) combines two seemingly opposite flavor styles—German-Austrian and tropical—for a pleasantly spicy, herbaceous beer cocktail. Adam Bernbach intuitively pairs the spiced nature of both Austrian pine liqueur and falernum to warm up a crisp lager and then balances it all with a dose of tangy lime.
ingredients: 1 ounce Zirbenz Pine Liqueur (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add pine liqueur, falernum and lime juice to a Collins glass.
2. Add ice and top with lager.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel and a sprig of rosemary.

title: Gage & Tollner’s Turf
intro_philosophy: A few select, but prominent, bars have taken up the 1880s Turf Club as their own, including the reborn Brooklyn chop house Gage & Tollner. “It’s definitely time for a comeback,” says Steve Bielawski, head bartender at Gage & Tollner.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, including the orange peel, in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Brian Evans’ Pornstar Martini
intro_philosophy: The only recipe in our Pornstar Martini blind tasting to incorporate fresh passion fruit (in addition to passion fruit purée), Brian Evans’ modern take on the classic ’tini unanimously won over the judges. As Natasha Bermudez, a taster on the panel, observed, “We keep going back for more, which tells you everything you need to know.”
ingredients: 1 half of a passion fruit (reserve the other half for garnish)
1/2 ounce unsweetened passion fruit purée, preferably Boiron
1/2 ounce vanilla bean simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
3 ounces G.H. Mumm Brut Cordon Rouge Champagne
instructions: 1. Scoop out the pulp from half of a fresh passion fruit and add it to a shaker tin.
2. Add all of the remaining ingredients, except Champagne, into the shaker, and hard-shake with cubed ice until properly chilled and diluted.
3. Double-strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Float the remaining half of the passion fruit on the surface of the cocktail.
5. Pour the Champagne into a separate small flute, and serve alongside the cocktail as a palate cleanser.

title: Charbonneau Way
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to honor my French-Canadian roots with a rye drink with French influence,” says Gullo, of thisSuze– and maple-syrup-laced drink. Charbonneau Way is the name of the road that is home to Gullo’s family sugar house, where they make maple syrup. “The yard in the summertime is covered in a blanket of wild mountain thyme,” she says, explaining her decision to garnish with the evergreen herb, while the absinthe rinse is a nod to her adopted hometown, New Orleans.
instructions: 1. Rinse the cocktail glass with absinthe and set aside.
2. Combine all the remaining ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a sprig of thyme.

title: Ponche de Crème
intro_philosophy: Trinbagonian bartender Chad Lee Loy learned how to makePonche de Crème, a creamy, rum-based holiday classic, 15 years ago, from his aunt. He has been experimenting ever since, putting his own twists on it. “I’m not giving away my family recipe!” he says. “But this one comes pretty close.” Though the classic is traditionally served with ice, the beauty of this version is getting to enjoy it two ways: first, savored warm, to experience the wholeness and depth of the flavors in a new way, then later, chilled and nostalgic.
instructions: 1. In a large bowl, whisk the eggs until beaten.
2. Add the whole milk, evaporated milk and spices to a pot over low heat. Simmer for 5 minutes.
3. Slowly strain the infused milk into the beaten eggs to temper, whisking constantly.
4. Add the sweetened condensed milk and whisk until the mixture is fully blended, then add the rums, vanilla essence and bitters. Whisk the mixture until smooth, and strain again.
5. Serve warm, or store in a bottle and chill.
6. To serve chilled, pour into a glass over ice and garnish with a grating of fresh nutmeg.

title: Tom Macy’s Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Tom Macy of Clover Club in Brooklyn delivered the winning formula in our2018 Gimlet blind tastingandtook third place in our 2024 tasting. It follows a simple construction: two ounces of Tanqueray gin, three-quarters of an ounce of simple syrup and half an ounce of fresh lime juice. As one panelist observed, the resulting drink, which requires muddling two lime wedges in the syrup, before shaking with the gin and lime juice, reads like a “gin Caipirinha.”
instructions: 1. Cut a lime in half, then cut one half into quarters.
2. Muddle the limes in simple syrup.
3. Add lime juice and gin.
4. Shake and fine strain into a coupe.

title: Suppressor #4
intro_philosophy: In his Suppressor #4, Paul Calvert opts for a triple-threat of Cocchi Americano, cognac and vermouth, rounded out by pineau des Charentes—the unheralded (but delicious) aperitif wine from the Cognac region.
ingredients: 1 ounce vermouth, preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
1 ounce pineau de Charentes, preferably Prunier
instructions: 1. Stir and strain into a coupe.
2. Express and discard lemon peel over the top of the drink.

title: Adam Bernbach’s Piña Colada
intro_philosophy: Adam Bernbach, bar manager of Washington, D.C. cocktail bar 2 Birds 1 Stone, has a particular affection for Piña Coladas and serves them year round in his basement-level bar. Though he uses unsweetened coconut milk (as opposed to the traditional sweet and viscous cream of coconut) to manage the drink’s tendency toward confection, Bernbach maintains the tropical cocktail’s three-flavor pillars: rum, pineapple and coconut. His recipe takes a couple extra steps including making a pineapple syrup, but is worth the extra work. The piña mix (see Editor’s Note) can be added to a siphon to “accentuate the pins-and-needles acidity of pineapple and to lighten the coconut milk,” as Bernbach recommends.
ingredients: 3 1/2 ounces piña blend, see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. Pour rum and piña blend over crushed ice in a "coconut mug" if you're fancy enough to have one. A hurricane glass will do too.
2. Stir to combine.
3. Add more crushed ice, and garnish with a pineapple cube and a brandied cherry.

title: A Batanga
intro_philosophy: A cheeky take on Don Javier’s classic preparation of tequila, Coca-Cola and lime. The drink must be stirred with the knife used to cut the limes.
instructions: 1. Rim a highball glass with salt, and fill the glass with ice.
2. Add the tequila, lime juice and Ancho Reyes, then top with Coca-Cola.
3. Mix the drink with the knife used to cut the limes.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Key Lime Daiquiri
intro_philosophy:
Before 1926, the aromatic Key lime was America’s common lime, so if you find yourself using an early 20th century cocktail book, your lime-infused drinks may require a bit of doctoring. Today, the limes we encounter most often are called Persian limes, a variety bred to be seedless, larger and thicker-skinned than Key limes and named for the region where the lime was first grown. Ironically, what we know to be Key limes were originally were grown in Persia, but Spanish exploration in the 15thcentury prompted a global biological mash-up, and plants, animals and people were suddenly inserted into new regions around the world. When Columbus introduced the lime to the Americas, the fruit was christened according to its new, tropical locale.

When researching the difference between regular Persian limes and Key limes, bartender andSmall Hand Foodsfounder, Jennifer Colliau discovered Key limes are slightly more acidic than Persian limes, requiring an adjustment to her regular Daiquiri recipe. She also came to realize Key limes’ distinctive aroma is often perceived as sweet (in the same way aromatically “sweet” ingredients like vanilla, strawberries or bone-dry Austrian Riesling might be perceived to taste sweeter regardless of actual sugar content), meaning a balanced drink using Key lime juice actually requires less sugar.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel, if desired.

title: Harrison Ginsberg’s Martini
intro_philosophy: The winner ofour 2023 Martini tasting, Harrison Ginsberg’s recipe follows a 5:1 ratio of gin to vermouth for a classic dry, but not too dry, iteration. Served bracingly cold with the choice of an olive or a twist, the judges found the drink to possess the distinctive bite of a Martini—what one taster termed the “ultimate crunch”—that they were looking for.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir for 45 to 60 seconds, or until the Martini is properly diluted.
3. Strain into a Martini or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist or Castelvetrano olive.

title: Porchlight’s Long Island Iced Tea
intro_philosophy: Porchlight beverage director Nick Bennett admits that the Long Island Iced Tea is a mess on paper. “But if you look at the recipe as a whole,” he says, “it’s a simple sour.” In addition to the full complement of base spirits, his version is spiked with a citrus syrup (infused with a touch of ginger) and a healthy dash of Angostura bitters to create the drink’s signature ombre effect. At his Chelsea bar, the drink is served on tap, but below is a single-serving rendition.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce aged Guyanese rum, preferably El Dorado 8
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the cola and bitters in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a footed highball glass over ice.
3. Top with cola and Angostura bitters.
4. Garnish with an orange wedge.

title: Fall Monty
intro_philosophy: This cinnamon spice-infused punch from New York bartender Katie Stipe marries the nuttiness of amontillado sherry with Lairds Bonded Applejack and Spanish cider to create a her own boozy riff on fall.
ingredients: 10 ounces strong tea, preferable Tea Forte Harvest Apple or Roobis
instructions: 1. Peel the lemons, being careful to avoid the pith.
2. In a large mixing bowl add the peels of the lemons to the sugar.
3. Gently muddle to release the oils, and let sit for 15 to 20 minutes.
4. Add the tea and stir until the sugar has dissolved.
5. Add the rest of the ingredients, stir to combine, and discard lemon peels.
6. Pour into a punch bowl and add large ice cubes to chill.
7. Top with Spanish cider and ladle into individual glasses.
8. Garnish with cinnamon sticks and apple slices.

title: Yuzu Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: At Pasjoli in Santa Monica, California, yuzu plays a big part in the kitchen and bar;each year the team works with hundreds of yuzu fruit. This winter, the Yuzu Daiquiri was born when the restaurant macerated the citrus with sugar overnight, yielding a pectin-filled syrup that they discovered “whips like an egg white” and would be ideal to froth up the rum classic.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces unaged rhum agricole, preferably Rhum Barbancourt
3/4 ounce yuzu and lemon juice blend (equal parts yuzu juice and lemon juice)
3/4 ounce yuzu pectin syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce clairin, preferably Distillerie Patrick St. Surin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry-shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a coupe.

title: Salmoncito
intro_philosophy: On paper, the Salmoncito looks like the byproduct of international cocktail diplomacy. The gin is a London dry from England, the Campari from Italy. Tonic water and grapefruit, the two ingredients that finalize the recipe, are used with abandon in drinks across the globe. And yet, many consider the pink-hued highball just as Mexican in spirit as classic bedfellows like the Paloma or Margarita.
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a highball glass filled with ice.
2. Top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with a supremed grapefruit wedge; express oil from the grapefruit peel and then discard it.

title: Thrivemind
intro_philosophy: Created at Donna (where she picked up shifts prior to the opening of Llama San), Thrivemind showcases Natasha Bermudez’s penchant for low-proof, stirred cocktails in a decidedly tropical mindset. “I wanted to make something tropical, but not in-your-face tropical,” says Bermudez of her relatively restrained mixture of cachaça, manzanilla sherry, blanc vermouth and rhubarb liqueur. “It’s sort of a 50/50 Martini meets a Bamboo,” she says.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces cachaça, preferably Abelha Prata Cachaça
3/4 ounce manzanilla sherry, preferably Bodegas Yuste Aurora Manzanilla Sherry
3/4 ounce vermouth, preferably Routin Blanc Vermouth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

title: Orange Infusion Spray
intro_philosophy: This vodka-based orange infusion boosts the citrus aromatics of any drink without the actual peel. Miguel Lancha recommends it as a finishing touch to rhum agricole-based drinks to boost the inherent citrus notes or as an added garnish to tiki-style cocktails.
instructions: 1. Steep orange peels in the vodka-water mixture for several hours, or until the desired aroma is achieved.
2. Strain out orange peel, and funnel into an atomizer bottle.

title: Hop Watah Michelada
intro_philosophy: Thinking of hop water as an offshoot of beer, it’s an obvious candidate for traditional beer-based cocktails. Poi Dog Chili Peppah Water, made by Philadelphia-based, Hawai‘i-raised chef Kiki Aranita, is a vinegary blend of chile peppers and ginger often used as a condiment in Hawai‘i cuisine. In this nonalcoholic cocktail, itprovides a complex hit of gentle spice, thanks to the ginger and vinegar.The lime wedge garnish serves more than just a visual function, too, as drinkers are encouraged to squeeze it over the drink, adding an additional hit of acidity and citrus aromatics.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Poi Dog Chili Peppah Water (or equal parts mild hot sauce and rice wine vinegar)
instructions: 1. Pour the hop water into a chilled tall glass.
2. In a cocktail shaker, combine the pineapple juice and Chili Peppah Water and dry-shake for 3 to 5 seconds to combine.
3. Pour over the hop water and garnish with the lime wedge.

title: Coconut Moscow Mule
intro_philosophy: For Palomar’s take on the Moscow Mule, bar manager Jordan Valls and his team start with vodka and lime, but use ginger syrup instead of ginger beer, and add bubbles via carbonatedroasted-coconut juice. (At home, you can use astore-bought soda.) Served over crushed ice and capped with a sprinkle of toasted coconut flakes and lime zest, it’s a tropical take on the classic with a much greater depth of flavor than the original.
ingredients: 4 ounces force-carbonated coconut juice (see Editor’s Note) or toasted-coconut soda
instructions: 1. Add vodka, lime juice and ginger syrup to a snifter.
2. Top with carbonated roasted-coconut juice or toasted-coconut soda.
3. Add crushed ice and garnish with lime zest and toasted coconut flakes.

title: Honeycut’s Cosmo
intro_philosophy:
After close at L.A.’s Honeycut, shift drink often involves “baby” shots of tequila and Cosmopolitans. Bartender Mary Bartlett and bar manager Dave Fernie “will make each other Cosmos sometimes, just because it’s just quick and silly and easy to chug,” as Bartlett says.

While she sticks to the usual cranberry juice, Fernie prefers to mix his up with Honeycut’s housemade pomegranate grenadine, below.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce dry curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in mixing tin.
2. Add ice, shake and double-strain into a chilled glass.
3. Chug with your work wife (optional).

title: Pineapple Cooler
intro_philosophy: Austin Hartman’s Pineapple Cooler goes full on tropical with Plantation Pineapple Rum and falernum, made tall with a hefty dose of tonic water.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Stiggins' Fancy Plantation Pineapple Rum
3/4 ounce falernum, preferably Maggie's Farm Falernum
tonic water, to top (preferably, Fever-Tree Tonic)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Christine Wiseman’s Cosmopolitan
intro_philosophy: Taking third place at a recent Cosmopolitan blind tasting was the recipe of Christine Wiseman, of the Broken Shaker in Los Angeles. It was the most unorthodox of the top three, asking for 1 ½ ounces of Absolut Lime (not Citron), ½ ounce of Pierre Ferrand Dry Curaçao, 1 ounce Ocean Spray, ½ ounce lime juice, and ¼ ounce simple syrup. The mix was shaken with a lime peel and garnished with a grapefruit twist. While the panel thought the grapefruit flavor took over the drink a bit, they otherwise found it balanced and enjoyable.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces lime vodka, preferably Absolut Lime
1/2 ounce curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand Dry Orange Curaçao
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice and lime peel.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with grapefruit peel.

title: Kula Negroni
intro_philosophy: Julie Reiner’s Kula Negroni swaps red vermouth for blanc and calls on a strawberry-infused Campari in her fruity twist on the Negroni recipe.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a half strawberry.

title: Zirbenz Spritz
intro_philosophy: Basically a bubbly Negroni with Zirbenz Stone Pine Liqueur in place of sweet vermouth, the Zirbenz Spritz is Eric Seed’s bubbly ode to Alpine aperitivo hour.
instructions: 1. Build in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Top with soda water, and garnish with a lemon wheel and pine sprig.

title: Arvid Brown’s Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Taking second place in our 2024 Old-Fashioned blind tasting was this version from Arvid Brown, of Room for Improvement in Portland, Maine, made with a high-proof bourbon (specifically Old Grand-Dad 114), Demerara syrup and a house bitters blend. The drink is built in the glass and garnished with an expressed orange twist and a cherry, the latter being the only quibble among the judges, who thought a cherry did not belong in the drink.
ingredients: 2 dashes “Rango” orange bitters (1:1 blend of Regans’ orange bitters and Angostura orange bitters)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a rocks glass, building over a big cube.
2. Stir in the glass for 5 to 10 seconds.
3. Garnish with a Luxardo cherry and an expressed orange peel.

title: Summer Melon Marg
intro_philosophy: A first-of-the-season slice of cantaloupe sprinkled with salt served as the inspiration for Andrew Burton’s elevated take on the classic frozen Margarita. “I wanted to focus on the role the salt played in that bite of cantaloupe, which led me to using manzanilla sherry for its high salinity and acidity to help cut through the sweetness of the melon,” says Burton, “and the sherry paired well with the reposado since they both share a level of salinity and aged notes.” When selecting a fresh melon for the drink, Horse Inn chef and owner Matt Russell recommends seeking out one that is fragrant with a nice heft, advising to smell right where the stem broke off from the melon.
ingredients: 2 ounce blanco tequila, preferably Tres Agaves Blanco
3/4 ounce Manzanilla sherry, preferably Barbadillo Manzanilla
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into chilled pint glass.
3. Garnish with lime wheel.

title: Nilsson Schmillson
intro_philosophy: Bartender Jeremy Oertel has a way with crushed ice and coconut cream. He used those two tools to famous effect a few years ago in theBrancolada, the standout cocktail at Brooklyn’s Donna. Now, he’s worked his magic again at The Hidden Pearl, another Brooklyn bar, tucked behind a ramen restaurant. Here, New York Distilling Company’s Perry’s Tot Navy Strength Gin is combined with sake, lime juice and vanilla syrup.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces New York Distilling Company Perry's Tot Navy Strength Gin
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled, about 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a large rocks glass filled with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with lemon zest and toasted coconut.

title: Bon Bon Vivant
intro_philosophy: A riff on the Boulevardier, this is a summer-worthy aperitif with a French twist. Briny Scotch and manzanilla sherry evoke a salty sea breeze while letting the base of Pineau des Charentes shine. The drink is served over cubes of frozen coconut water; as a result, “the drink subtly changes while you sip, and hydrates you on those hot summer days,” Abigail Gullo explains.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  single malt Scotch, preferably Bruichladdich Classic Laddie
1 large frozen cube of coconut water, more if desired (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir first three ingredients with regular ice cubes until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over the coconut water cube(s).
3. Twist the lemon peel over the drink to express the essential oils, then discard the peel.
4. Serve with a slice of watermelon on the side, “to snack on while you sip,” Gullo suggests.

title: Second Line Season
intro_philosophy: At their forthcoming revival of New Orleans’ historic Jewel of the South, industry veterans Nick Detrich and Chris Hannah will serve elegant, understated cocktails like this brandy-based Second Line Season.
ingredients: 2 ounces apple brandy, preferably Lemorton Calvados Reserve
instructions: 1. Using a lemon wedge, coat the rim of a wine glass.
2. Using the lemon juice, run a fine layer of sugar on half the rim.
3. Fill the glass with pebble ice and then arrange 3 to 4 dried apple slices on the inside of the glass.
4. Combine the ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
5. Strain into the prepared glass.
6. Garnish with microplaned nutmeg.

title: White Cargo
intro_philosophy:
This proto-ice cream cocktail, from the 1927 bookHere’s How!, boasts a method that’s dangerously easy to commit to memory—equal parts gin and vanilla ice cream, shaken (without ice!) until incorporated. “Here’s a concoction that’s endorsed by all the ice cream manufacturers,” reads the recipe, which suggests adding a hit of white wine to the tin if your results are too thick. “And, take it from me, it’s a rare beverage!”

Originally written as simply “1/2 vanilla ice cream, 1/2 Gordon water [gin]” the below measurements are only approximations, attempt at your own risk.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice until thoroughly mixed.
2. If the consistency is too thick, add water or white wine.
3. Pour into a glass of your choice.

title: Tom and Jerry
intro_philosophy: This is a pain-in-the-ass drink to mix, but one well-worth the rosy noses it will produce. A descendent of Eggnog, the Tom and Jerry was created sometime in the early 19th century, most likely in New England. In numerous accounts, Professor Jerry Thomas claims its conception in 1847, having been quoted as naming it after himself and “two small white mice” he kept as pets called, of course, Tom and Jerry. However, reports of the warm, egg-based nog have been documented in America since the 1820s, and is sometimes even credited to English author Pierce Egan, who penned a play of the same name in 1821 (though there is no evidence to corroborate it in UK records). According to Dave Wondrich, the name does come indirectly from Egan. “To go Tom and Jerrying was to go out on the town, and a Tom and Jerry was also a low dive. And, in this case, a festive but lethal sort of drink,” says Wondrich. Though Thomas’s tale of ownership is a tall one, he became the drink’s greatest ambassador and, according to Dave Wondrich’sImbibe!,dedicated bowls were filled with batter each winter season across America until its popularity died down near the turn of the 20th century. Alongside today’s renewed sense of cocktail curiosity, comes a new wave of noggy excitement with recipes tailored to today’s palates, including this version fromAndrew Bohrerin Seattle. Butter and vanilla are modern additions, but the base remains the same: frothy, spiced egg batter mixed into dark rum and brandy, and topped with warm milk and nutmeg.
instructions: 1. Separate egg whites from yolks into two large bowls.
2. Add butter and sugar to egg yolks, and beat with an electric mixer. Mix will be slightly chunky.
3. Beat egg whites to stiff peaks (using clean beaters).
4. Using a spatula, gently fold egg whites into yolk mixture until color and consistency is the same.
5. To finish the batter, stir in allspice, cinnamon, cloves and vanilla.
6. If desired, batter can be made ahead of time and kept in the refrigerator, covered, for a few hours before assembly.
7. To assemble Tom and Jerrys, gently heat milk in a saucepan over low heat (amount depends on how many drinks you plan to serve).
8. Add 1 tablespoon of batter to a mug or small rocks glass.
9. While constantly stirring batter, add one ounce brandy and one ounce rum.
10. Fill to the top with milk (or hot water, or a 1:1 ratio), and stir until foamy.
11. Grate fresh nutmeg over top to garnish.

title: Byrrh It’s Cold Outside
intro_philosophy: In keeping with the aperitif spirit ofByrrh, Natasha David of New York’s Nitecap uses the fortified wine as a component in her spritz, playfully called Byrrh Its Cold Outside. With two sherries—amontillado and ancho chile-infused muscatel—plus cranberry shrub, it makes for an easy transition to fall.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce ancho-infused moscatel sherry (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients apart from wine and short shake (just long enough for the ingredients to blend and slightly chill).
2. Strain into Collins glass filled with crushed ice.
3. Top with sparkling wine.
4. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: The Mystical One
intro_philosophy:
This simple, holiday-ready rendition of aWhiskey Sourcombines the one-two punch of sage and cinnamon alongside lime juice in place of lemon. If you’re angling for a bit more richness, add a small egg white to the mix and shake extra vigorously to combine.

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine the 3 sage leaves and the cinnamon syrup in a cocktail shaker and use a muddler to lightly crush the sage.
2. Add the lime juice and bourbon.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Strain into a coupe and garnish with a sage leaf.

title: Lost Lake
intro_philosophy: “This was a fun drink to create and really embodies our drink philosophy at Lost Lake,” explainsPaul McGee, “tropical, complex and modern.” Riffing on Toby Maloney’s Riviera cocktail, McGee swaps gin for Jamaican rum and pineapple for passionfruit for a distinctly tropical profile.
ingredients: 2 ounces Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton Signature Blend
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with 1 cup of crushed ice.
2. Roll all ingredients into a Collins glass.
3. Top with an additional cup of crushed ice.
4. Garnish with pineapple fronds, an edible flower and a cocktail umbrella.

title: White Mezcal Negroni
intro_philosophy: Maxwell Reis, Beverage Director for Gracias Madre in Los Angeles, is a proselytizer for cocktails with a split base of gin and mezcal. “I love blowing people’s minds with the combination of gin and mezcal. Even though [they] are such extreme flavors and polarized concepts, I often find the herbaceousness of gin and the natural minerality of mezcal blend together seamlessly.” In this White Negroni riff, Reis also trades out the traditionalSuzefor the lighter Salers, putting the mezcal and gin alchemy front and center in the cocktail.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit twist or mint sprig.

title: Garibaldi Spritz
intro_philosophy: Jose Cordon’s Garibaldi Spritz marries the simplicity of the classicGaribaldiwith the refreshing familiarity of a bubbly spritz, with a focus on fresh California citrus and a custom bitter blend that allows for more control of the bitter and sweet components of the drink. “The Garibaldi is such a simple cocktail, but the fact that it really relies on the quality of the ingredients is what makes it so beautiful,” says Cordon.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Bitter Blend (1/2 ounce each of Contratto Aperitivo, Mezzodi Aperitivo and Bruto Americano)
2 1/2 ounces Orange Juice Blend (equal parts fresh Primavera tangerine juice and Murcott mandarin juice)
2 1/2 ounces prosecco, preferably a drier, sharp prosecco like Gambino Gold)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a wine glass over ice and stir to incorporate.
2. Garnish with orange slice and serve with a paper straw.

title: Two Dylans
intro_philosophy: Brian Evans knew he wanted to have a Whiskey Sour variation on the menu at the new Lobby Bar in the Hotel Chelsea. He looked to theCameron’s Kick—an Irish whiskey and Scotch Sour with lemon and orgeat—as a way of incorporating the unexpected modern flavors of tomato, macadamia nut and curry leaf.
ingredients: 2 ounces pot still Irish whiskey, preferably Powers Gold Label
generous 1/2 ounce macadamia nut orgeat (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and muddle.
2. Fill tin with cubed ice and hard-shake for 8 to 10 seconds.
3. Double-strain over cubed ice (or one large cube) into a chilled double rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a curry leaf.

title: Ava
intro_philosophy: Damon Boelte’s spin on the radler builds off a Spanish cider base with the spirited addition of white rum.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients except cider.
2. Strain over rocks in a collins glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel and raspberries.

title: Winter Paloma
intro_philosophy: The Mexican classicPaloma—essentially the love child of a Greyhound and a Margarita—gets dressed up in a winter coat, courtesy of the addition of sage. The hardy winter herb makes a cameo in the traditional formula by way of grapefruit-sage syrup and fresh sage leaves, turning the summer classic into the kind of cocktail that feels right at home beside the fire.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except the soda water to a shaking tin.
2. Add ice, and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda and garnish with a sprig of fresh sage.

title: Bitter Truth
intro_philosophy: This refined variation on the Boulevardier gets chocolatey goodness from a surprising ingredient: Cocoa Puffs cereal.
ingredients: 2 3/4 ounces Bitter Truth Batch (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a cocktail pitcher and stir to mix.
2. Strain over a large ice cube in a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a trimmed orange twist.

title: Iron Ranger
intro_philosophy: At San Diego’s Raised by Wolves, Erick Castro created this tiki-inspired cocktail for whiskey drinkers. “There’s a lot of people out there who love a refreshing tropical cocktail, however, might not necessarily be in the mood for rum,” he says. For Molly Gajdosik, a bartender based in Easthampton, Massachusetts,finding the recipe was a gatewayto the world of tropical cocktails, and bartending as a whole.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake to chill.
2. Strain into a chilled hurricane glass filled with pebble ice.
3. Garnish with grated cinnamon and fresh mint.

title: Armagnac Crusta
intro_philosophy: CJ Catalano’s Armagnac Crusta stays within the brandy family, calling on a blanche Armagnac rather than Cognac, but offers a subtle upgrade in the form of a violet-sugar rim.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanch Armagnac , preferably Château Arton Fine Blanche Armagnac
3/8 ounce orange liqueur, preferably Combie le Bleu
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Strain into a coupe with a violet-sugar rim (see Editor's Note).
3. Garnish with a lemon horseneck.

title: Gravesend Smash
intro_philosophy:
Most great American horses come from Kentucky. The same thing has long been said about American whiskey. But things are changing in both cases. New York bred racehorses, like Zivo, are among the best in the country. And another NY-bred horse, Artemis Agrotera, will be among the favorites for the Breeders’ Cup Filly and Mare sprint. It’s New York’s time to shine.

And so it is with whiskey as well. In support of Artemis, we offer this original-to-the-book cocktail, a Gravesend Smash, named for the defunct Brooklyn racetrack.
instructions: 1. Muddle half the peppercorns and grapefruit with the St. Germain in the bottom of a cocktail shaker.
2. Add the moonshine and fill the shaker with ice.
3. Shake vigorously and strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice, small cubes or crushed.
4. Garnish with the rest of the cracked pink peppercorns on top.

title: The Charleston
intro_philosophy: While it may seem heretical to use fine madeira in punches and cocktails, the Lee Brothers find it worth the splurge—the more character and flavor in the wine, the better the punch or cocktail. According to esteemed cocktail historian and writer David Wondrich, madeira was common incobblers—simple cocktails common in the early 19thcentury composed of crushed ice, fortified wine, and citrus peel—shaken vigorously and garnished with fruit. Madeira (and its fortified cousins) are excellent in cocktails because, says Wondrich, “it has the flavor intensity of brandy, but not the proof. So you can dilute it, and ice it, and still have a pleasant drink.” In some senses, this drink mimics a Manhattan with its bourbon base, fortified wine partner and a dash of bitters to bring them together.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon (preferably of the Kentuckian variety)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a 1-inch length of orange peel.

title: Cobbler Royale
intro_philosophy: With Champagne as the base for this riff on the classic cobbler riff, all that’s needed is little citrus. Dan Greenbaum says: “It’s a little more delicate, you don’t want to overpower with other flavors.” Don’t be surprised if some of the carbonation seems to deflate, he adds, yielding “a drink you drink pretty quickly.”
instructions: 1. Add the lemon, orange and simple syrup to a mixing tin and muddle.
2. Add the Champagne and swirl briefly.
3. Dump the contents of the tin into a chilled Collins glass.
4. Fill glass 3/4 full with pebble or crushed ice and mix briefly with a spoon or metal straw to integrate.
5. Garnish with fruit and a mint sprig.

title: Ojen Cocktail
intro_philosophy: “For me, the Ojen Cocktail is one of the most perfect drinks,” explains New Orleans bartender Neal Bodenheimer. “It’s so simple and dry.”With the recent return of Ojen, one of New Orleans’ favorite anise-flavored spirits, the city’s bartenders have been quick to revive its namesake cocktail. Here, Bodenheimer offers his interpretation of the NOLA favorite, a simple swizzle of Ojen and Peychaud’s, with an optional measure of orgeat or simple for richer texture. “There are still few drinks that I want to drink more,” he says, “especially during Carnival.”
ingredients: 7 dashes Peychaud's bitters (more if adding orgeat or simple)
1/2 ounce orgeat or simple (optional, for richer texture)
instructions: 1. Fill a rocks glass with crushed ice.
2. Pour Ojen over the ice and add four dashes of Peychaud's bitters, then swizzle.
3. Fill with more crushed ice and top with three more dashes of Peychaud's.
4. Swizzle until the glass frosts.

title: Moby Dick Sazerac
intro_philosophy:
This story is published in partnership with P(our), a symposium devoted to exploring new ideas and exchanging inspiration about the drinks industry, and beyond. The annual event promotes discussions and presentations that address issues critical to the trade; this year’s theme is “perfection.” The event is taking place in Paris on June 3rd—for more information, and for tickets,click here.

Often, Ryan Chetiyawardana will fixate on a unique ingredient that will then becomes the centerpiece of the drink. For his take on the classic Sazerac, that ingredient is ambergris: the organic byproduct of a sperm whale’s digestive system. He combines a small dose of ambergris with rye, simple syrup and Peychaud’s bitters, served chilled in a rocks glass and garnished with rice paper coated in absinthe.
ingredients: heavy 2 ounces rye, preferably Mr Lyan
instructions: 1. Bottle and freeze the combined ingredients, no ice.
2. Serve chilled in a frozen rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a strip of rice paper coated in absinthe.

title: Whiskey Ginger
intro_philosophy: This is not your mom’s whiskey and ginger ale. At Three Sheets, one of London’s top cocktail bars, the team hasreimaginedthis simple, long-standing highball as a study in the bold, complex flavors of pickled ginger, played against the calmer notes of an elegant Japanese whisky.
ingredients: heavy 1 ounce ginger whiskey (see Editor’s Note)
heavy 3/4 ounce pickled ginger cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the first two ingredients to a tall glass over a spear of ice.
2. Stir to combine and chill.
3. Top with cold soda water.

title: Forbidden Fruit Fizz
intro_philosophy: In this nonalcoholic offering,Sam Kileymarries grapefruit juice with orange shrub, aperitif syrup, egg white and soda for a French Caribbean spin on a Ramos Gin Fizz. As she explains, grapefruit was first cultivated in Barbados, and the aperitif captures the bitter flavors of France, uniting in the glass for what she calls “a true New Orleans drinking experience.”
instructions: 1. Combine the first 5 ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a Collins glass.
4. Gently add a splash of soda water until the froth reaches the rim of the glass.
5. Garnish with a pinch of saffron.

title: “Dirty” Negroni
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to have the dirty Martini and the Negroni get together and have a baby, and this is what came out,” says bartender Travis Tober, of Murray’s Tavern in Austin, Texas, where this hybrid is a top-seller. Bitter, briny and savory, the drink is anything but subtle.
ingredients: 1 ounce olive oil–washed gin, preferably Aviation American Gin (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi di Torino
instructions: 1. Stir the ingredients together and strain over a fat ice cube in a rocks glass.
2. Garnish with a skewered pimento-stuffed olive.

title: Five Spice Agave Nectar
intro_philosophy: The key ingredient in San Francisco bartender Duggan McDonald’s classic West Coast cocktail, the Laughing Buddha.
instructions: 1. In a medium saucepan, bring the water to a boil.
2. Add the cinnamon stick, peppercorns, star anise pods, cloves and ginger.
3. Bring back to a boil and add the salt.
4. Add agave nectar and bring to a simmer, stirring frequently.
5. Remove from the heat and let cool.
6. Cover and refrigerate overnight.
7. Strain the syrup into a glass bottle or jar and refrigerate for up to 3 weeks.

title: Dirty Dog
intro_philosophy: At Courtland Club in Providence, Rhode Island, the Dirty Dog reads like a cross between a dirty Martini and a Salty Dog. Combining the refreshing forces of grapefruit and lemon juice with the savory kick of olive brine and ancho chile liqueur, it’s a crowd-pleasing, crushable mashup.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a glass without ice.
3. Garnish with an olive and a grapefruit quarter-wheel.

title: Above Average Absinthe + Root Beer
intro_philosophy:
Canadian bartender Warren Johnston, owner of a ready-to-drink beverage company,Above Average Drinks, goes with Boylan Root Beer when topping off Vieux Pontarlier to make his Above Average Absinthe + Root Beer.

“There are still a huge number of drinkers, especially in my local community here in Alberta, that are less exposed to current trends in the cocktail world,” says Johnston. “Our team has found that simple drinks like this can often be the spark that leads them down the rabbit hole towards a lot of the products that, as bartenders, we love sharing and want to evangelize.” Root beer, after all, is not unlike a nonalcoholic amaro—a robust, complex drink layered with sarsaparilla and other botanicals.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces absinthe, such as Strathcona Spirits Absinthe Blanche or Vieux Pontarlier Absinthe
4 1/2 ounces root beer, such as Boylan's
instructions: 1. In an ice-filled highball glass, add the absinthe, then the root beer.
2. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Café Marumbi
intro_philosophy: “The Cafe Marumbi is particularly special to me,” says Kacie Lambert, head bartender at New York’s Stay Gold. The morning after her husband proposed to her, she recalls, he discovered espresso-tonics at a coffee shop in Oceanside, California. “His excitement with this revelation only briefly eclipsed the fact that he had proposed the night before.” This drink is inspired by that moment, she says. While the Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur and tonic is “a beautiful pairing” on its own, the added cinnamon and coffee notes from the barrel-aged cachaça, plus the lemon cordial, “makes for a refreshing and bright coffee cocktail.”
tags: Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
ingredients: 1 ounce barrel-aged cachaça, preferably Novo Fogo Barrel Aged
1 ounce Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the tonic water, in a mixing tin a shake with 1/8 cup of pebble ice.
2. Shake until you can no longer hear the pellet ice.
3. Pour tonic water into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Pour contents of shaker over the tonic water.

title: Bliss Point
intro_philosophy: For a summery pineapple rum-based drink at Brooklyn’sClover Club,Jelani Johnsonoffsets the rich, fruity rum with frothy egg white and citrus in multiple forms.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Stiggins' Fancy Plantation Pineapple Rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with a few drops of Peychaud's bitters.

title: Leopold’s Pimm’s Cup
intro_philosophy: The seasonally changing Pimm’s Cup at Leopold’s is one of the bar’s most popular drinks. This iteration, made for summer, incorporates strawberry, cucumber and mint. While most Pimm’s Cups call for muddled fruit, Leopold’s incorporates fruit into a syrup and garnish for a smoother finish.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce strawberry cucumber mint syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
3. Top with ginger beer.
4. Garnish with mint, lemon, strawberries and cucumber.

title: Genmaicha Bellini
intro_philosophy: In this modern take on the Bellini, Singapore’s Jigger & Pony marries genmaicha tea purée—consisting of gin, tea, sugar and agar-agar—and sparkling wine.
instructions: 1. In a mixing tin, combine the purée with half of the prosecco.
2. Lightly churn to mix, then add the remaining prosecco.
3. Pour into a chilled flute glass to serve.

title: Artemis
intro_philosophy: Coconut water is a particularly useful medium for extracting delicate fragrances from ingredients like jasmine tea, which shows up at Paris’ Bar Nouveau in this heady, floral nonalcoholic cocktail; it sometimes gets spiked with an ounce of sake or apricot eau de vie.
ingredients: 1 ounce sake or apricot eau de vie (optional)
3/4 ounce coconut water–steeped jasmine white tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Chill all ingredients, then combine in a mixing glass.
2. Carbonate usingan iSi siphonor anothercarbonating tool.
3. Serve in a tall glass.

title: Ta-Da
intro_philosophy: Karri Kiyuna’s version of a Bamboo, the Ta-Da showcases the marriage of palo cortado sherry and Bacardi Banana. “I like to do stuff like that—throw something slightly weird in,” she says. She started out with the desire to infuse a drink with the flavor of banana, expecting to land on something super rich and full-bodied like a White Russian. While tinkering, she replaced heavy cream with nutty, creamy palo cortado and ended up stumbling into the structure of a Bamboo. The end result is a playful, not-so-far-fetched twist on an old classic.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces palo cortado sherry, preferably Lustau
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass.
3. Express the lemon peel and discard.

title: Seriously Mysterious
intro_philosophy: To create this dark, smooth cocktail, Suzy Critchlow of Washington, D.C.’s Columbia Room built upon her favorite classic Scotch cocktail, the Rob Roy, by adding crème de cacao and PX sherry—plus a hit of salt and lemon oil to “make it all pop.” It’s a combination all in service of the drink’s star ingredient. “I wanted to magnify some of my favorite notes in Dewar’s: fig and chocolate,” she says.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces red vermouth, preferably Lacuesta Vermouth Rojo
1 tbsp  crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
1 tbsp  PX sherry, preferably Gonzolas Byass Nectar Pedro Ximinéz
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients into mixing glass.
2. Stir and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Sapins Swizzle
intro_philosophy: The Sapins Swizzle is based on the French pine-flavored liqueur, Sapins, which has a resinous bite that mixes curiously well with tropical tiki flavors like zesty falernum and ripe pineapple.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce overproof rum, J. Wray & Nephew
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle pineapple cubes with lime juice and cane syrup.
2. Add remaining ingredients and ice, and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain over crushed ice into a Collins glass and swizzle.
4. Garnish with freshly shaved chocolate.

title: Eve’s Pot Liquor
intro_philosophy: Collard greens are indigenous to both LaGrange, Georgia, and Monrovia, Liberia—where Keyatta Mincey-Parker’s mother and father were raised, respectively. In this cocktail meant to symbolize their love and blending of cultures, collard greens lend a hearty green base and hue. The drink’s name references the liquid left at the bottom of a pot (a staple of Southern cooking) after cooking the leafy vegetable. Apple juice adds sweetness and texture, while the saline drops and vegetal aloe vera liqueur pull all the elements together.
ingredients: 1 part  green apple juice (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 part  collard green juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a tin with ice.
2. Shake hard, and double-strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a homemade collard green chip.

title: Death in the Afternoon
intro_philosophy: The title of Hemingway’s 1932 novelDeath in the Afternoonis both a direct reference to the gruesome finale of Spanish bullfights, and a more oblique one about his meditations on mortality. The fact that he ascribed the same title to a cocktail made of a shot ofabsinthetopped with Champagne, which he submitted to a celebrity recipe book in 1935, is something to ponder. The original formula for absinthe was certainly a more powerful concoction, but the more likely explanation: In his recipe instructions he prescribed drinking three to five of these at a time.
instructions: 1. Add absinthe and and simple syrup (if using) to a flute.
2. Slowly top with chilled, sparkling wine.

title: Room for Improvement’s Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: Built on a rum base in lieu of vodka, with an unexpected banana twist and salted coconut foam,Room for Improvement’s house Espresso Martini gives the decadent drink a tropical edge. And, rather than fresh espresso, Maine’s beloved Allen’s Coffee Flavored Brandy teams up with cold-brew concentrate to bring the requisite caffeinated kick.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce aged rum, preferably Plantation Original Dark
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Top with salted coconut foam.

title: Hot Buttered Blackstrap
intro_philosophy: One part Whiskey Toddy, one part Hot Buttered Rum, the Hot Buttered Blackstrap combines the two classic wintertime cocktails conveniently in one glass. If you’re seated at Manhattan’s The Dead Rabbit, you might even sip it from an antique mustache teacup.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Lapsang Souchong-infused Old Forester Bourbon (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
2 dashes Angostura bitters or Dead Rabbit Orinoco bitters
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients, except the hot water, to a rocks glass and stir.
2. Add the hot water.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Natasha David’s Champagne Cocktail
intro_philosophy: This effervescent delight is all about theSuze. Though it contains only three-quarters of an ounce of it, the color and flavor of the sparkler scream Suze—and that’s not a bad thing.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Giffard Crème de Fruits de la Passion
instructions: 1. Combine the Suze and passion fruit liqueur in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe and top with Champagne.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Green Day
intro_philosophy: When bar staff at Portland, Oregon’s Take Two found that no single Chartreuse substitute was the perfect fit on its own, they decided to take matters into their own hands. Their house “Chartreuse” blend combines two local offerings, Elixir Ver Liqueur and Accompani Flora Green, with a high-proof expression from Italy, Enrico Toro Centerba. They use the mix in drinks like the Green Day, which is herbaceous, spicy and cooling all at once.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce ginger liqueur, preferably New Deal
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a Collins glass with a scoop of pebble ice.
2. Swizzle, then top with more pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a mint bouquet, cucumber and lime wheel.

title: Act a Fool
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to kind of give people license to act the fool,” says Owens. His cocktail blends uplifting citrusy acidity, berry brightness, floral Spanish wine and a kiss of honeysuckle sweetness, with a cava rosé float and Cajun grapefruit foam garnish lending lighthearted effervescence. “When you drink it, you feel really good, and you feel bubbly inside—like you want to dance on tables,” says Owens.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce lemon honeysuckle syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except cava rosé in a shaker and fill with ice. Shake hard until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a coupe, top with cava rosé and garnish the top of the drink with Cajun grapefruit air foam and edible flowers.

title: Je Suis Le Tigre
intro_philosophy: Dan Sabo’sSingapore Slingvariant calls for two types of Jamaican rum, alongside the modified proportions of the drink’s classic ingredients and a small dose ofBénédictine.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Wray & Nephew white overproof rum
3/4 ounce dark rum, preferably Appleton Estate 12
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and whip-shake with two ice cubes.
2. Roll into a chilled hurricane glass and top with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a mint bouquet, brandied cherries and a straw.

title: Qui Oui?
intro_philosophy: Nico de Soto’s Qui Oui? is a twist on his rendition of the Aperol Spritz, which was created for his Parisian restaurant Daroco. Rather than aquavit, an ingredient in the original recipe, this cocktail calls on St-Germain for a more fruit-forward profile.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the prosecco, in a mixing tin and shake.
2. Strain into a wine glass over ice.
3. Top with Prosecco.
4. Garnish with kiwi slice.

title: Godfather IV
intro_philosophy: “Scotch is the main event in this cocktail,” says The Spaniard head bartender Nick Brown. A riff on the amaretto-sweetenedGodfather cocktail, this drink adds on walnut liqueur for extra depth and nutty richness. As for the name of the drink? “We named it the Godfather IV because it’s a new chapter of the Godfather that hasn’t been seen before.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Scotch whisky, preferably Compass Box Glasgow Blend
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Joggling Board
intro_philosophy:
Atlanta bartender Greg Best created this drink in honor of an event withGarden & Gun, a Southern lifestyle and culture magazine. With a base of white rum, the Joggling Board is dressed up riff on theDaiquiriand named for a piece of furniture hailing from South Carolina’s Lowcountry. A joggling board is an extra-long bench grounded with rocking chair-style skiffs so it flexes and bounces, or “joggles” its sitters as they rock.

With its layers of citrus and savory seasonings, “This drink is evocative of hanging out in Charleston,” says Best. “It’s fun, but complex. Charleston can appear to be glitzy and college-y from the outside, but once you start digging, you find beautiful architecture and interesting history.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a pinch of sea salt.

title: Hotto Campari
intro_philosophy: According to Japanese American bartender Julia Momosé, who offers a variation on Hotto (“hot”) Campari in her book,The Way of the Cocktail, the drink isn’t necessarily a staple in Japan, “but if you know you know.” For a few bars in Osaka and Tokyo, as winter’s chill settles over the season, the Italian liqueur makes the jump from cocktails in rocks glasses to glass mugs adorned with orange wheels. In a nod to Japan’s beloved Shochu Oyuwari, Momosé doubles down on the drink’s citrus notes with Awa No Kaori Sudachi Chu, a fruity, bittersweet shochu distilled with sudachi citrus juice, further softening the drink’s bitter edge. Perhaps the biggest surprise comes from the accenting splash of kümmel, which adds warming caraway and cumin, “almost curry-like” spice notes to the mix, she says.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Awa No Kaori Sudachi Chu
1/2 ounce rich honey syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a teacup, combine all ingredients except for the hot water.
2. Add hot water, depending on preferred strength. Stir briefly to combine.
3. Express lemon oils over the drink.
4. Garnish with a manicured twist of lemon.

title: Queen’s Road
intro_philosophy: “It’s an overlooked classic, in my opinion,” says Llama Inn bar directorLynnette Marreroof this clean and uncluttered Donn Beach Daiquiri riff, first served at the original Don the Beachbomber location in Hollywood in the late 1930s or early 1940s. Though the original recipe called for Puerto Rican gold rum, Marrero prefers an older, more robust alternative.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged rum, preferably Zacapa or El Dorado
1/2 ounce ginger syrup (1:1 fresh ginger juice to sugar, blended)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with mint and orange peel.

title: Pepita Orgeat
intro_philosophy: At Pacific Cocktail Haven, the menu is full of tropical cocktails.
