While some use traditional orgeat, Kevin Diedrich frequently experiments with a wide variety of syrups–including salted pistachio, macadamia nuts and roasted pepitas (pumpkin seeds)—to expand the flavor profile possibilities. He typically combines this pepita syrup in a colorful drink with blanco tequila, pumpkin purée and citrus: “We found the tequila works really well with pepitas,” says Diedrich.
instructions: 1. Blend pepitas to a powder.
2. With blender on low, slowly add water.
3. Once the water is fully incorporated, slowly add sugar.
4. Strain through coffee filter.

title: Seven Seas Swizzle
intro_philosophy: Porchlight’s Nick Bennett’s love of funkyBatavia arrackis deep-seated: He first encountered it earlier in his career at a now-defunct rum bar, making the spirit permanently associated with rum in his mind. In Bennett’s Seven Seas Swizzle, Batavia plays well with bittersweet green tea syrup and bright lime, for a mashed-up riff on the Queen’s Park Swizzle (“One of my favorite cocktails,” says Bennett) and traditional punch ingredients: spirit, citrus, sweetener, spice and tea.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce green tea–infused cane syrup (see Editor's Note)
1 dash orange bitters, such as Regans’
instructions: 1. Build all the ingredients in the appropriate glass and add half the amount of necessary ice.
2. Swizzle until the glass is cool.
3. Top with ice and garnish with a mint bouquet and a dusting of nutmeg.

title: Moneyball
intro_philosophy: At Death & Co., theMoneyballis a play on the mezcal Negroni made zero-proof. To replicate the original drink’s signature smokiness, Javelle Taft calls on Lapsang souchong tea in place of the base spirit, and St. Agrestis’ Phony Negroni in place of Campari.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Lapsang tea infusion (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce passion fruit syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a large cube.
3. Garnish with an orange slice.

title: Kingston Zing
intro_philosophy:
If you have access to Ting grapefruit soda, you’re ahead of the game, and can skip the juice and syrup in this recipe. If not, Garret Richard has reverse-engineered Wray & Ting,the beloved Caribbean soft drink. “If possible, make your grapefruit punch syrup with white rather than pink fruit so as to more closely correspond to the Ting profile,” he advises. Alternatively, replace the rum with 2 ounces of blanco tequila from the freezer for a delightfully chilled Paloma.

Reprinted with permission fromTropical Standard: Cocktail Techniques & Reinvented Recipes, by Garret Richard & Ben Schaffer, copyright ©2023. Published by W.W. Norton & Co.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce grapefruit punch syrup (see Editor’s Note)
3/8 ounce strained lime juice (if 3/8 ounce breaks your brain, think of it as a light 1/2 ounce)
5 drops salt solution (4:1, water to salt)
1 1/2 ounces Wray & Nephew overproof rum, chilled in the freezer
instructions: 1. Combine the first five ingredients in a shaker tin. Whisk with a milk frother (or stir briskly until combined) and set aside.
2. Fill a chilled 12-ounce highball glass with small ice cubes. Add the soda until the glass is three-quarters full.
3. Pour the contents of the shaker into the glass while holding the glass at a 45-degree angle. Top with soda until the glass is full.
4. Agitate the mixture with a single brisk dip of a bar spoon.
5. Garnish with the channeled lime twist and a grapefruit slice.

title: Rosé Piscine
intro_philosophy:
“I got the name from a friend’s French grandmother,” says Sarah Morrissey. “She lives in the South of France and drinks rosé on ice, which she calls a pool of rosé AKA rosé piscine.” Fruity, floral pamplemousse liqueur mixes withSt-Germain, dry mineral-driven rosé, and a crisp, sharp edge of vodka.

For more on the pleasures of the French spritz, see our recently released book“How to Spritz French,”a complete guide to spritzing with St-Germain cocktails.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a wine glass over cubed ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit wheel and a lemon wheel.

title: Macunaíma
intro_philosophy: Created in 2014, theMacunaímais a cachaça, fernet and lime cocktail that spread rapidly across Brazil.The drink’s creator,  Arnaldo Hirai, believes the citrusy cocktail is light enough on its own, so he doesn’t suggest serving it over ice for added dilution. Instead, he recommends shaking to froth up the citrus before straining the drink into a chilled lowball glass without ice. While the method is simple, Hirai does say there’s one crucial element to consider: Use a good cachaça aged in balm, a widely used Brazilian wood that imparts aromas of clove and anise.
instructions: 1. Pour the cachaça, lime juice, simple syrup and Fernet-Branca into a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake with ice.
3. Strain into a chilled lowball glass without ice.

title: Kim Vo’s Gimlet
intro_philosophy: The runner-up in our recipe blind tasting, Kim Vo’s Gimlet was found to be the most “aromatically fetching” by the judges, thanks to its expressed lime twist garnish. The rest of the build is fairly straightforward, with navy-strength gin bringing the requisite backbone to the drink.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce Hayman’s Royal Dock navy-strength gin
1 ounce lime juice, freshly squeezed and fine-strained
1/2 ounce rich simple syrup (2:1 white sugar to water, by weight)
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake vigorously for 10 to 12 seconds.
2. Fine-strain into a coupe.
3. Express the oils from the manicured lime peel over the top of the cocktail and rub the peel on the rim, then rest the peel on the edge of the glass.

title: The Botanist & Tonic
intro_philosophy: This deliciously simple G&T was specifically developed for the food and cocktail stand Josh Harris concepted after he had to temporarily shutter his bar due to the pandemic. It’s similar to the streamlined highball that might have appeared on the original bar’s menu: 2 ounces of The Botanist gin, lime wedge squeezed into the drink. But the presentation is made for takeaway, built in a soda fountain–style cup, with a lid and straw to take this “tart, dry and bubbly” cocktail to sip on the go—perfect for a spring or summer’s day.
ingredients: 2 ounces  The Botanist Islay Dry Gin
Fever-Tree Premium Indian tonic water,to top
instructions: 1. Add Botanist gin to a cup with ice.
2. Fill with tonic water.
3. Squeeze a lime wedge and add to the drink.
4. Cap the cup, and serve with a compostable straw.

title: Gin-Gin Mule
intro_philosophy:
The crowning achievement, in gin terms, of early gin advocate Audrey Saunders. This is essentially a Mojito (a rum drink) crossed with a Moscow Mule (a vodka drink), but made with gin. It also illustrates the wide influence the omnipresent Mojito had on bartenders at the turn of the twentieth century. “Dale [DeGroff] showed me his recipe for a classic Mojito with a dash or two of Angostura. Having a cocktail that had a fresh herb in it—who knew? Wow, that’s amazing. For me, the Mojito base, mint and lime, was really, really enjoyable. At that point, I dove head first into gin. So sub out the rum and try the gin and see how that tastes.” Saunders found a recipe for homemade ginger beer from a Beacon kitchen staffer. “It had a lot more sugar in it, so I tightened it up,” said Saunders. “I’m adding simple syrup in cocktails anyway, so let’s make it drier. Then I can control how much sugar I can put in it. So that was it: Gin Mojito. My quest was helping people get over their phobia about gin. And I thought,Wow, this drink is really good and accomplishes just that.” She used Bombay gin at the beginning, but finally settled on Tanqueray, which had the heft she wanted.

Reprinted with permission fromAProper Drinkby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 6 sprigs of mint, some leaves reserved for garnish
instructions: 1. Combine the lime juice, syrup and mint in a mixing glass and muddle.
2. Add the gin and ginger beer and ice and shake well.
3. Strain into a highball glass filled with ice.
4. Garnish with mint leaves

title: Mommy & Daddy Time
intro_philosophy: At Saturn, a new bar in Austin, Texas, where disco cocktails and long-maligned “lowbrow” drinks are getting an elevated touch, putting a Pornstar Martini riff on the menu was a no-brainer for owner Steven Smith. “Our whole identity is fun and crazy and sexy and silly,” says Smith. “I knew we had to do a Pornstar Martini.” In theMommy & Daddy Time, the expected passion fruit elements get swapped out for pink guava liqueur.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces vodka, preferably St. George California Citrus
3/4 ounce pink guava liqueur, preferably Fruitful (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce rich vanilla bean simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all of the ingredients vigorously, then strain.
2. Serve with a sidecar of your favorite Champagne or sparkling wine.

title: Anton Kinloch’s Zombie
intro_philosophy: The winner ofour Zombie blind tasting, Anton Kinloch’s recipe was the only one of eight in which the grenadine was perceptible, thanks to the fact that Kinloch acidifies his syrup to make it pop, even when a mere tablespoon is used. For the rum, Kinloch is true to the hard-hitting nature of the original and blends one and a half ounces each of Puerto Rican and Jamaican rums, with another ounce of overproof Demerara rum. “You can taste the layers,” noted one of the panelists. Though Kinloch serves his Zombie clarified, the recipe below is for the nonclarified version that won our blind tasting.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Puerto Rican rum, preferably Havana Club Añejo Clásico
1 1/2 ounces Jamaican rum, preferably Hampden Estate 8-year
1 ounce overproof Demerara rum, preferably Hamilton 151
1/2 ounce falernum, preferably Maggie’s Farm Falernum Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a glass over crushed ice.

title: Seven Hills
intro_philosophy: Built on a base of Cocchi Americano and Amaro CioCiaro and a splash of apricot liqueur—in place of dry vermouth and Campari—Seven Hills riffs on theRome with a Viewformula.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with a half orange wheel and grated cinnamon.

title: Cherry-Flavored Spirit
intro_philosophy: “Maraschino cherries use a candying process with Marasca cherry juice for preservation. This syrup is sweet and tart with a nice richness, which translates well into cocktails,” explains Justin Ware of Houston’s Johnny’s Gold Brick. Ware suggests using theleftover syrup to make a straightforward cherry spirit, a sort of fast track to Cherry Bounce, a Colonial-era cherry-infused spirit.“The syrup adds sweetness, tartness and brings the overall ABV down. For that reason,” explains Ware, “I recommend starting with something 100 proof and adding approximately 20 percent juice to bring your ABV to about 80 proof.”
instructions: 1. Combine both ingredients and mix until the cherry syrup is fully integrated.

title: &thesea
intro_philosophy: The Mojito has rudely interrupted many a bar’s flow. One order of the classic minty drink tends to lead to another, until every patron in the place is calling for a summery highball that makes bartenders groan. Peter Altenburg found a better way: a riff on the Mojito he calls &thesea, batched with “mint-washed” rum and mint-infused Spanish vermouth. At the bar, the mix is pre-batched and force-carbonated; at home, this large-format recipe can be batched before serving with a topping of sparkling water.
ingredients: 100 milliliters malic acid solution (mix 2 grams malic acid powder with 100 milliliters water)
instructions: 1. In a container, combine the mint-washed rum, mint-infused vermouth, malic acid solution and elderflower syrup, then refrigerate until ready to serve.
2. To serve, fill a highball glass with ice, preferably an ice pillar.
3. Add 150 milliliters (approximately 5 ounces) of the cocktail to the glass and top with sparkling water. Briefly stir to incorporate.
4. Bash a small sprig of mint in your hand and then garnish the drink.

title: Beach Bod Fizz
intro_philosophy: Jelani Johnson’s tiki-fied twist on a gin-based fizz takes a classic move from the Don the Beachcomber toolkit of combining bright fruits and aromatic spices. Rather than use a combination of absinthe and Angostura bitters to achieve a complex spice blend as Don might’ve done, Johnson opts for Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic. “It has the bitterness I was looking for as well as a more complex, floral characteristic that also elongates the other flavors in the drink,” says Johnson. “For this drink, the baking spice notes and bitterness in the Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic were perfect for making the other ingredients mesh.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  passion fruit syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce  cinnamon bark syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water in a mixing tin filled with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water.
4. Garnish with an orange wedge, cinnamon stick and parasol.

title: Ohio Cocktail
intro_philosophy:
The Ohio cocktail is as far as anyone can tell, a classic cocktail of German birth. It began appearing in German cocktail books in the 1910s and, if you know where to look, you can still see it served in German cocktail bars today. There is, however, no standard recipe. Two takes on the cocktail persist—one made with Cognac, Curaçao, bitters and a float of Champagne; and the other with Western whiskey (sometimes rye, sometimes Canadian), sweet vermouth, sometimes Curaçao and, again, a topping of Champagne. The latter can be considered basically a Manhattanroyale.

Buck and Breck, a famed speakeasy in Berlin, remains faithful to the old drink, which was popular in the first half of the 20th century, but fell on hard times in recent decades. Buck prefers the whiskey version, and makes the recipe its own with a touch of China-China bitter liqueur to accent the orange notes of the Curaçao. The julep-like presentation, in a silver cup filled with ice, is unorthodox.
ingredients: 1 dash Bigallet China-China Amer Bitter Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the Champagne, in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into an ice-filled julep tin.
3. Top with Champagne.
4. Express the orange peel over the drink and discard.

title: Careful Cat
intro_philosophy: For a nondairy milk punch, Daniel Villa of Supperland in Charlotte, North Carolina, uses hispowdered methodwith coconut milk powder in this tequila- and coffee-based drink. This drink can also be made not clarified: Use 2 ounces of blanco tequila, 1 ounce each of coffee and syrup, and 3/4 ounce of lime juice. Stir and serve up.
ingredients: 8 ounces rehydrated coconut milk (see Editor’s Note)
5 ounces fennel cardamom syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Pour the rehydrated coconut milk into a Cambro or other large container.

2. In a second container, add the remaining ingredients and stir to combine. Pour this batched cocktail into the container with the rehydrated milk. Give it a gentle stir, and let it sit for about 10 minutes, during which it should curdle.

3. Pour the cocktail mixture through a fine-mesh sieve (a chinois lined with a moistened linen towel or a micron bag/Superbag will also work) into a clean container. Avoid using a Superbag with a micron rating any finer than 120, as the curds may block the filter. The resulting liquid should be slightly cloudy.
4. Pour the cocktail mixture a second time through the same sieve (including through the curds in the sieve) into a clean container. The resulting liquid should be fairly clear.
5. Funnel into a bottle and cap. Keeps, indefinitely, at room temperature.
6. To serve, pour 3 ounces over a large ice cube, and stir to chill.
7. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: The Hardy Boy
intro_philosophy: “The first time I encountered crème de cacao, it was not being used properly,” says Seth Friedus. “It was seen in drinks with sweet on sweet on sweet on vodka.” Friedus prefers to see the liqueur instead balanced with bitter or herbal contrasts to complement its concentrated chocolate flavors. In The Hardy Boy, he uses cacao white as a modifier, combining it with rye, Suze and housemade wormwood and peppermint syrup.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce wormwood and peppermint syrup (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass with ice.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Drink Your Veggies
intro_philosophy:
“Drink Your Veggies is full of unexpected flavors and combinations,” says Jacyara de Oliveira, of Chicago’s El Che Bar & La Sirena Clandestina, about this aperitif cocktail. The cachaça-based drink is distinctly vegetal, marrying earthy carrot juice with the base spirit’s grassy notes, while doses of floral St-Germain and citrus brighten it all up.

“The aperitif, to me, is the beginning,” de Oliveira says. “It is bright and light and exciting, like the beginning of a new relationship or moving into a new apartment.”
ingredients: 1 ounce cachaça, preferably Novo Fogo silver
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with crushed ice.
2. Quick shake the ingredients to incorporate.
3. Pour contents of shaker tin into a Collins glass and top with crushed ice if necessary.
4. Garnish with carrot ribbons and carrot greens.

title: Hemingway in Europe
intro_philosophy: Batavia arrack “can be a good substitute for rum in classic drinks,” says Punch Bowl Social’s beverage director, Patrick Williams. The spirit is a close relative of rhum agricole, but with a funkier, “malty” finish. Here, Williams contrasts those flavors with super-tart grapefruit syrup, fresh lime and maraschino liqueur for a riff on the Hemingway Daiquiri.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients and strain into a chilled coupe.
2. Garnish with thyme and grapefruit peel.

title: Groove is in the Heart
intro_philosophy: This technique-driven, Technicolor highball presents aBlade Runner-inspired marriage of the Garibaldi and a Screwdriver. The combination of brightly colored citrus-and-bitters flavored ice cubes and a clear cocktail of clarified orange juice, vodka and liqueurs results in a floral, refreshing and citrus-forward drink with a kick.
ingredients: 3 Blood Orange Ice Cubes (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a large Collins glass (preferably 16 ounces), add up to six flavored ice cubes (or as many as will fit in your glass), alternating colors.
2. Add club soda, then pre-batched cocktail mix, filling to the top.
3. Serve with a metal straw.

title: Erick Castro’s Michelada
intro_philosophy: Erick Castro had his first Michelada in his dad’s northern Mexico kitchen at age 14. Now 45 and considered one of San Diego’s top bartenders,Castro has perfected a Michelada recipethat maintains the simplicity of the beloved drink with a subtle riff—muddled orange slices—to elevate the otherwise casual cocktail into an elegant nod to his childhood growing up on both sides of the border. It’s bright and fizzy with a little kick, and goes down as easy as a summer afternoon.
ingredients: 1 bottle or can of Mexican lager
instructions: 1. Rim a chilled pint glass with salt or Tajín. Fill with ice.
2. In a shaker, muddle the first five ingredients then shake with ice.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.
4. Top with Mexican lager.

title: The NoMad Bar’s Mai Tai
intro_philosophy: For the NoMad’sperfected take on the Mai Tai, Leo Robitschek adds 15-year-old El Dorado Guyanese rum to a base of Appleton Jamaican rum and 100 proof rhum agricole for additional richness and weight. To impart just enough bitterness, he shakes the drink with a lime wedge, rind included. Garnished with a bouquet of mint and an umbrella, the Mai Tai doesn’t look out of the ordinary, but this particular version of the drink has proven its staying power: It’s been a menu staple for the past three years.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Clément Créole Shrubb Liqueur d’Orange
3/4 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton VX
3/4 ounce Guyanese rum, preferably El Dorado 15 Year Old Special Reserve
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the mint in a cocktail shaker.
2. Fill a Belgium glass with crushed ice.
3. Shake and strain the cocktail into the Belgium glass and top with additional crushed ice.
4. Garnish with mint bouquet and umbrella.

title: Quattro Barbie e Fragolino
intro_philosophy: Marianna Di Leo revisits Italy’s version of theLong Island Iced Tea, known as the Quattro Bianchi e Fragolina for a cocktail bar in Pagani, near Naples, where she was tasked with creating a drink inspired by Italian culture. In her take, tequila becomes the primary base, complemented by small measures of gin, triple sec and mezcal for structure, alongside a strawberry-pisto cordial (pisto is a traditional Italian spice blend). “The balance of the drink is completely different,” says Di Leo. “We wanted to serve it in a modern key, more technical but not too complex.”
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces strawberry and pisto cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: William Elliott’s Irish Coffee
intro_philosophy: This upgrade to the classic Irish was inspired by a striated riff on a White Russian, another drink that showcases the flavors of coffee and cream. William Elliott starts his version with French-pressed George Howell coffee and finishes with a collar of espresso liqueur-flavored cream.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except flavored cream, in a pre-warmed Irish Coffee mug.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with flavored cream.
4. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Bitter Orange Kvasstail
intro_philosophy: For this Collins-like pitcher cocktail,the Gefilteriawanted to highlight some of the best qualities of their kvass(a fermented and subtly alcoholic Eastern European beverage). That meant playing with its effervescence by adding seltzer, and complimenting its savoriness with gin. It’s an uncomplicated drink, too. “I think kvass is a really interesting thing to serve at home,” says Liz Alpern, one of the businesses owners. “I’ll come after work, and it’s a great thing to build on without a lot of work.” The health benefits don’t hurt, either. “One of the beautiful things about beets is they are known as liver cleansers.”
instructions: 1. In a pitcher, add kvass, gin, simple syrup and orange bitters.
2. Add ice and top with soda.
3. Stir gently to mix.
4. Pour into individual glasses and garnish with an orange peel.

title: Zoë Van Der Grinten’s “Guilty Pleasures” Rosé
intro_philosophy: The team behind White Lyan played with in-house fermentation, developing a number of mock “wines” that they then integrated into cocktails. Zoë was designed as a cross between the light elegance of Provence rosé and the hearty juiciness of South American pink wines.
ingredients: 1 quart white grape juice, without preservatives
instructions: 1. Hydrate yeast as instructed, then add all other ingredients to a mixing tub.
2. Stir thoroughly to combine all the jam and sugar.
3. Once smooth, add all the ingredients including the yeast to a clean carboy or fermenting tub.
4. Insert airlock and leave at approximately 75 degrees Fahrenheit for 21 days.
5. After three weeks, move to the refrigerator and leave overnight.
6. Siphon all but the bottom inch (the cloudy bit) into another carboy.
7. Leave cold overnight again, siphon (this is called “racking”) into bottles and store for as longs you can resist before drinking it—it will only get better with age.

title: R&D
intro_philosophy: AtBar Contra, one of ourBest New Bars of 2024, Dave Arnold continues his science- and tech-driven approach to making excellent cocktails. Clarification, liquid nitrogen infusion, acid-adjusting and force carbonation are seen throughout the menu, but this drink relies instead on a simple flavor pairing that Arnold feels is underrated: rye and damson.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Averell Damson Plum Gin Liqueur
instructions: 1. Add the ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain and serve in a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Cranberry Beret
intro_philosophy:
This is a reboot of a cocktail with a not-so-sexy name, Cranberry-Spice Cocktail, that I created forFood and Winemagazine. Cranberries, oranges, and apples are still at the heart of the drink, but I amped up the proof a bit with Laird’s apple brandy and played off the bittersweet orange notes of the Amaro CioCiaro and brightness brought on by the Aperol. It’s a great before-dinner drink to kick off a Thanksgiving gathering, a time when it’s good to keep people busy with a drink in their hand. You can also batch it up as a punch and have your guests serve themselves.

Reprinted with permission fromAmaroby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Combine the orange wedge and cranberries in a cocktail shaker and muddle until the fruit is just broken up.
2. Add the apple brandy, Amaro CioCiaro, Aperol, and bitters and fill with ice.
3. Shake until chilled and double-strain into a collins glass filled with ice.
4. Top off with the hard apple cider.
5. Garnish with the orange zest and skewered cranberries.

title: Creole Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Ben Hatch altered this recipe to fill the need for a lesser-known, spirit-forward New Orleans drink for the Elysian Bar’s menu. The result is an updated Manhattan variation that not only reads as a love letter to Hatch’s favorite Alpine producers, but also convinced him that he does, indeed, like Manhattans.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Bèrto Ross da Travaj
1/4 ounce Alpine amaro, preferably Alpe Lys
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a large orange twist.

title: Dawn Patrol
intro_philosophy: At Bar Snack in New York City, Iain Griffiths has spiced up the Arnold Palmer template with an easy-to-make turmeric syrup and nonalcoholic bitters. Griffiths named their riff Dawn Patrol, after the surfer term for catching the first waves of the morning: “It’s usually used like, ‘I’m not drinking tonight, I’m on dawn patrol.’” For those who want a full-proof cocktail, though, this drink can also be spiked with mezcal.
instructions: 1. Fill a double rocks glass with pebble ice.
2. Add all ingredients to the glass and give the mix a quick stir with a barspoon.
3. Garnish with a fresh mint bouquet.

title: Ticonderoga Club’s Sazerac
intro_philosophy: Taking top honors atour 2024 Sazerac tasting, this recipe adheres to the traditional rye (rather than Cognac) version of the drink. It’s made by filling a rocks glass halfway with crushed ice and a quarter-ounce of Herbsaint, rolling it to coat the interior of the glass, then dumping the crushed ice from the glass, ensuring a little bit of Herbsaint is left behind. The rest of the ingredients are stirred with ice in a mixing glass and strained into the prepared rocks glass, then garnished with a lemon twist.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Herbsaint, for rinsing the glass
1/4 ounce rich cane syrup (2:1, cane sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Fill a rocks glass halfway with crushed ice and add the Herbsaint.

2. Roll the glass a little to cover the whole inside of the glass with Herbsaint. Stir, then dump out the crushed ice and Herbsaint from the glass, making sure to leave just a little Herbsaint behind.
3. Add the rest of the ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
4. Strain the drink into the prepared glass and garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Pompadour
intro_philosophy: Created in 2015, this riff on a basic sour features a split base of boozy rhum agricole and Pineau des Charentes, a French fortified wine, striking what Tyson Buhler calls “a great balance between the power of rhum agricole, the juiciness of the Pineau des Charentes and the sweet roundness of vanilla.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Pineau des Charentes, preferably Pasquet
1/2 ounce vanilla lactic syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Red Velvet
intro_philosophy: The Red Velvet at New York’s iconic Bemelmans Bar combines rye, spiced plum tea, lemon and egg white—along with a dusting of bee pollen—for a sophisticated twist on a Whiskey Sour that’s as ruby-bright as the bartenders’ uniforms.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces spiced plum tea (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake vigorously.
2. Serve up in a Martini glass and sprinkle with bee pollen.

title: Miguel Lancha’s Pisco Sour (2017 version)
intro_philosophy: Cocktail director Miguel Lancha’s second version of the Pisco Sour for China Chilcano swaps out quebranta pisco for “more floral and complex” acholado pisco, adds more lime relative to sugar, and is garnished with a duo of bitters. It’s built for speed: The “lime mix” is prebatched, and egg whites are dispatched from a bottle: “We break batches of 24 eggs and break the membranes slightly with a hand blender, to be able to use them as liquid ingredients from a bottle,” Lancha notes. Finally, this version shakes the drink with ice, rather than employing the dry-shake method.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces egg white (substitute with aquafaba for a vegan version)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with 4 large Kold-Draft ice cubes.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with bitters, and swirl with a cocktail pick.

title: Caffè Tonic
intro_philosophy: In Italy,ammazzacaffè(meaning “coffee killer”) is a custom that marks the transition fromdolciandcaffèwith a small glass of amaro, to mellow out the caffeine for a spirited ending to dinner. This Averna-spiked Caffè Tonic is a modern way to have the best of both worlds.
instructions: 1. Add Averna and cold brew coffee to a chilled Collins glass filled with crushed ice.
2. Stir or swizzle to combine.
3. Top with chilled tonic water, adding more crushed ice if needed.
4. Garnish with fresh mint.

title: Papaya Salad Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the papaya salads regularly served in her Thai Town neighborhood, Christine Wiseman brings the brightness of the dish into a classicDaiquiriformula by way of a cordial comprised of Thai chilies, fish sauce, tomato water, sugar, lime juice, papaya and more. “This one took awhile for me to get right,” she admits, “but I needed to get the fish sauce just right because it is such a bold flavor, I didn’t want it to dominate the drink.”
ingredients: 2 ounces white Guatemalan rum, preferably Magdalena
1 ounce papaya salad cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with nopales and edible glitter.

title: Dante’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy: During the summer of 2020, the Greenwich Village bar Dante introduced its first “aperitiki” menu. This drink, a tropical take onthe bar’s signature Garibaldimade with Campari, Zucca Rabarbaro amaro, “fluffy” pineapple juice and lime, served as inspiration for the whole concept.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce rum, such as Planteray Stiggins’ Fancy Pineapple Rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a small water glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with an orange wedge, Luxardo cherry and pineapple frond.

title: Alec Bales’ Last Word
intro_philosophy: Though the Last Word is classically made with green Chartreuse, this recipe calls for something with a lighter touch: Boomsma Claerkampster Cloosterbitter. ForAlec BalesofTiconderoga Club, the more affordable herbal liqueur is a welcome, milder and lower-ABV addition to a range of other drinks that typically call for the liqueur, from this one to the Bijou to the Tipperary.
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to a shaker tin with ice and shake.
2. Double-strain into a Nick & Nora glass.

title: Spumoni
intro_philosophy: The cult drink among Japanese bartenders made with Campari, grapefruit and tonic gets a Garibaldi-inspired makeover by Bar Pisellino’s Jon Mullen. Spiked with an apple-distillate-based gin and a sweet-and-savory pink peppercorn syrup, the real star is the layer of frothy Ruby Red grapefruit juice courtesy of a Breville juicer. “People are triggered by that thick layer of foam,” says Mullen. “They see a server walking the drink across the room and every time we get a few more orders.”
ingredients: 1 teaspoon Pink Peppercorn Syrup (see Editor's Note)
1 1/2 ounces chilled tonic water, preferably Fever-Tree Indian Tonic
1 1/2 to 2 ounces fresh Ruby Red grapefruit juice
instructions: 1. Combine pink peppercorn syrup, gin and Campari in a juice glass over four ice cubes and stir until chilled.
2. Top with tonic water and fresh grapefruit juice.
3. Stir to incorporate.
4. Garnish with cracked pink peppercorns.

title: Hello Motherf*cker
intro_philosophy: At this Austin-based cocktail pop-up, founders Caer Maiko Ferugson and Sharon Yeung and a rotating cast of Asian bartenders from across the country serve up drinks highlighting their native foods and spirits. This riff on the Adios Motherfucker uses two types of Japanese gin: Roku, and jasmine green tea-infused Nikka Coffey. Combined with Batavia arrack, shochu and a blend of Asian citrus and blue Curaçao, the drink is served over crushed ice in a Hello Kitty glass. It’s a playful melding of herbal, floral and citrus flavors that don’t mess around.
ingredients: 1 ounce Asian citrus blend (lemon, pomelo, mandarin, yuzu; whatever is fresh at market)
1/2 ounce jasmine green tea-infused Nikka Coffey Gin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the blue curaçao, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a tall Hello Kitty glass over crushed ice.
3. Top with blue curaçao.
4. Garnish with skewered candy bow.

title: The Ruffian
intro_philosophy: This winter sipper is named after Brooklyn bar owner Alla Lapushchik’s friend’s dog. Lapushchik—who owns the horse racing themedOTB(off-track betting)—later learned that the dog was named after Ruffian, a champion American racehorse from the 1970s. Now an ode to two four-legged beasts, this cocktail is an all-American sour mix of rye whiskey, Applejack, lemon, thyme-infused syrup and a splash of absinthe.
instructions: 1. Add a dash of absinthe to a rocks glass, and roll around to coat. Discard and set aside.
2. Add remaining ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
5. Garnish with a sprig of thyme.

title: The Pollinator
intro_philosophy: The Pollinator, a floral twist on the Prohibition-era gin Bee’s Knees, features a shaken mix of The Botanist gin, aromatic pisco, fresh lemon juice, lavender-honey syrup and cardamom bitters. Though layered, this sour keeps the gin’s subtle notes of juniper, meadowsweet, heather and elderflower at the fore. An altogether elegant palate cleanser.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.
2. Strain into a coupette, then garnish with a sprig of lavender.

title: Night Tripper
intro_philosophy: This built-in-flask drink pays tribute to New Orleans music legend Dr. John (the Night Tripper is one of his nicknames). Here, two Italian liqueurs,Stregaand Averna, add bitterness and complexity to the whiskey base, which is pre-chilled before serving. Should you happen to visit New Orleans when it’s not Mardi Gras, you can order this drink from bartender Chris Hannah (served in a glass, over ice) at Arnaud’s French 75 Bar.
instructions: 1. Funnel all of the ingredients into a flask, cap tightly and chill.
2. Serve directly from the flask, or pour over ice.

title: Honey-Berry Lemonade
intro_philosophy: Created by Eric Prum and Josh Williams, of food and drink design firmW & P, this near cobbler-style cocktail underscores summer’s prime farmer’s market pull—berries. A hallmark of the season, lemonade in a tall icy glass could not get better. That is, unless you add booze and some berries. Fresh-squeezed lemon juice is complimented by farmer’s market honey and summer berries, all muddled up and dumped over a pile of ice. The vodka is optional, of course, but it’s strongly recommended.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle the honey and berries together until crushed.
2. Add vodka (optional), water, lemon juice and ice, and shake until well chilled.
3. Double-strain into a Collins glass over ice.
4. Garnish with berries and a lemon wheel.

title: Meaghan Dorman’s Gibson
intro_philosophy: While some Gibson onions are boiled to a soft consistency, Dorman deliberately removes the onions from the brine directly after a one-minute boil, “so the onions stay crunchy,” she explains. “It’s a nice little snack too.” After making the onions, be sure to retain some of the brine to add to the finished drink.
ingredients: 1 ounce bianco vermouth, such as Carpano
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a pickled onion.

title: The Bee Durham
intro_philosophy: The Bee Durham is Kingfisher’s signature and most popular cocktail. The nuanced riff on the Bee’s Knees calls for wax-washing gin as the base spirit, a simple and inventive technique for added texture.
ingredients: 2 ounces beeswax-infused gin, preferably Bombay Sapphire (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a ceramic cup or rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel or lemon wheel.

title: The Dead Rabbit’s Bishop
intro_philosophy: While The Dead Rabbit defines this port-based drink as an Archbishop, we adhere to William Terrington’s 1869 definition, which classifies this mixture as a Bishop. Part of the larger ecclesiastic family of punches that run the gamut from the decidedly more regal, Pope, built on a base of Burgundy, to the lowly Church Warden, typically made with inexpensive ginger wine and thinned with tea, this recipe revives the popular yuletide drink of the 18th and 19th centuries.
instructions: 1. Warm the Bishop mix in a small saucepan and pour into a wine glass.
2. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.
3. Express the lemon peel and orange peel over the surface of the drink and discard.

title: U Drop Inn Flip
intro_philosophy: Swapping French brandy for a mixture of rich Brandy de Jerez coupled with malty genever, alongsidecrème de cacao and a cocoa powder, Demario Wallace’s U Drop Inn Flip is a more robust take on the originalBrandy Flip.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Lustau Solera Gran Reserva Brandy de Jerez
3/4 ounce dark crème de cacao, preferably Tempest Fugit
1/4 ounce palo cortado sherry, preferably Lustau Peninsula
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in shaking tin without ice and dry shake.
2. Add ice and shake.
3. Fine strain into fizz glass and garnish.

title: Blueberry Spritz
intro_philosophy: “Blueberries in Maine—I know, I know,” saysHayley Wilson, “but there’s a reason we put them in everything.” Here, a straightforward blueberry syrup with a splash of apple cider vinegar stars alongside alpine amaro Pasubio and elderflower liqueur, a pairing that Wilson describes as a “natural couple.” The spritz format was, for her, a no-brainer. “I’m a sucker for a spritz,” says Wilson. “It’s how I’m going to start almost every time I go out.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce elderflower liqueur, preferably St. Elder Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a wine glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with blueberries.

title: Lawless
intro_philosophy: In an effort to recreate the time-honored ritual of smoking and drinking, Stephanie Teslar of Phoenix’sBlue Houndbegan ingeniously smoking cocktail glasses with tobacco.Settling onvanilla pipe tobacco, Teslarlights it on a skillet, allows it to start smoking, cups it with a chilled double rocks glass and lets the smoke diffuse for five to ten seconds. Caught in a cold environment, the smoke cools and disperses slowly, almost clinging to the glass.Teslar dubbed the accompanying cocktail “Lawless” in tribute to local Phoenix business,Lawless Denim. With the name as an inspiration, she wanted the drink to capture a “fugitive on the run” sort of feeling, a sense of transgression in the ingredients and in the overall flavor impact. So she wondered,what plays well with tobacco? Bourbon.What other flavor conjures the illicit? Wormwood, the primary botanical in absinthe, long-alleged to have psychotropic effects, which she expresses withBäska Snaps Malört. Finally, she blended the flavors together using her “truck stop bitters,” which incorporate everything one might pick up at a rest stop: coffee, tobacco and a candy bar (which is represented with cocoa). The finishing component is, of course, genuine tobacco smoke.
ingredients: 2 ounces bourbon (preferably St. George Breaking & Entering)
4 dashes truck stop bitters (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Chill a rocks glass in the freezer, at least 15 minutes ahead of time.
2. Add bourbon, demerara syrup, Malört and bitters to a mixing glass.
3. Add ice and stir.
4. On a skillet, carefully light pipe tobacco.
5. Once heated and burning, cup a chilled rocks glass over the tobacco to trap smoke.
6. Once smoke fills the glass, release. (Extinguish pipe tobacco.)
7. Strain bourbon mixture into smoked glass.

title: Hanamizaké Martini
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

“The Hanamizaké cocktail is named after the nihonshu (Japanese sake) that we drink while sitting beneath the sakura forhanami(flower viewing),” Julia Momosé explains. “There is a belief that if a sakura blossom falls into your sake cup during hanami, that you will have good fortune.”

Here, spicy ginger shochu and woodsy Japanese gin are rounded out with a vermouth made with Japanese botanicals. The finishing touch: a pickled sakura garnish that signifies “a gentle wish for the good fortune of those who join us at the bar.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  Hizo Otokoyama Tokubetsu Junmai sake
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain over shiozakura in a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Bay Leaf and Douglas Fir Essential Oil Spray
intro_philosophy: Bay leaf and Douglas fir provide an earthy note, especially when spritzed on a napkin holding a drink with a particular baking spice-forward profile, like The Man About Town.
ingredients: 10 drops Douglas fir essential oils, preferably Aftelier Perfumes
instructions: 1. Steep the bay leaves in the vodka for two weeks, agitating occasionally.
2. Strain and discard the bay leaves.
3. Pour one ounce of the infused vodka into a small spray bottle.
4. Add 10 drops of Douglas fir essential oils.
5. To use, spritz on a napkin for extra aromatics, then set the drink on the napkin.

title: Mushroom
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to find a method that would recreate some of the yeasty, mushroom-y flavors you get with vintage Champagne,” explains Ezra Star of the inspiration for using mushroom dashi syrup as the sweetener in her recipe. A dehydrated, candied mushroom tops off this modern spin on theChampagne cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce huckleberry verjus reduction (see Editor's Note)
3/4 ounce mushroom dashi sugar (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients and chill before serving.
2. When ready to serve, pour the mixture into a flute and top with Champagne.
3. Garnish with a candied mushroom.

title: Delores Royale
intro_philosophy: The Delores Royale, a clear wink at the seasonal change from summer to fall, adds weight to its smoky mezcal base by way of apricot liqueur and amontillado sherry—then is brightened by citrus (in the form of mandarin vodka and lime) and topped with sparkling wine, in a refreshing nod to late summer spritzes.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Lustau "Los Arcos"
1/2 ounce mandarin vodka, preferably Hangar One
1/4 ounce apricot liqueur, preferably Rothman & Winter
instructions: 1. Shake and strain into a coupe glass.
2. Top with cava and garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Josh Ibañez’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: This recipe was among the judges’ favorites in our2024 Daiquiri blindtasting. Collectively termed the “rum nerd’s Daiquiri” by the tasters, this version calls on a blend of four rums alongside a similarly considered sugar blend and the requisite lime juice. Though it is perhaps not for everyone, the judges praised its pronounced—but not overbearing—rum profile, which had the distinctive ester-y aroma of Jamaican rum as well as the layered complexity that comes with a four-rum blend spanning ages, styles and countries of origin. “The rum is in the forefront,” said Ray Sakover, co-owner of New York’s Paradise Lost, “but the lime and sugar are still there playing supporting roles.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Ten to One White rum
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
2. Shake like hell. (The resulting Daiquiri should have some solid froth to it; it is not the same without that texture.)
3. Fine-strain into a coupe.

title: Seafire Colada
intro_philosophy:
At Ave in Grand Cayman, the Escape is essentially a Piña Colada Royale with a cloud-like head of tropical foam. This drink takes inspiration from that cocktail, but is easy to shake up at home and serve as a mini cocktail; sometimes, bold and rich flavors are best enjoyed in tiny doses. This recipe can be easily scaled up for a crowd, simply multiply each measurement by your number of servings.

Reprinted with permission fromTiny Cocktails, by Tyler Zielinski, copyright © 2025. Published by Clarkson Potter.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce lightly aged rum, such as Probitas
instructions: 1. Combine the rum, coconut cream and juices in a cocktail shaker filled with three cubes of ice.
2. Briefly, yet vigorously, shake to chill.
3. Strain into a tiny snifter glass and slowly top with Champagne by pouring in one stream in the center of the cocktail to create the drink’s signature fluffy head.

title: Pedro Suckerpunch
intro_philosophy: Pedro Ximenéz sherrybrings the sweet kick of anOld-Fashionedto this shaken blend of bourbon, lemon juice and Amaro Nonino. Coffee liqueur, which is dashed on top of the finished drink as a garnish, bolsters the raisinated flavors in the sherry.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Pedro Ximenéz sherry, preferably Lustau San Emilio
2 dashes espresso liqueur, preferably Caffe Borghetti
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaking tin and shake well.
2. Strain into a bucket glass with ice.
3. Garnish with two dashes of espresso liqueur.

title: The Black Pearl’s Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy:
Originally called The Pharmaceutical Stimulant, the Espresso Martini was created by Dick Bradsell at Fred’s Club in the late 1980s, when a young model, who Bradsell claims is now world famous, sidled up to the bar and asked for something to wake her up—and then fuck her up. The solution was a combination of vodka, fresh espresso, coffee liqueur and sugar, shaken into a frothy glass of bittersweet addiction. (Some speculate the model was Kate Moss, others Naomi Campbell, but Bradsell has never revealed her identity.)

Bartending apocrypha aside, the drinks has legs. The natural oils in the espresso, which give a shot that beautiful crema on top, turn into a thick, stable layer of froth when you shake it. The dark liquid beneath, when the drink’s made right, is a perfect balance of boozy, bitter and sweet. It’s like drinking a Guinness in a cocktail glass.

This version comes courtesy of Melbourne’s The Black Pearl, where the drink outsells all other cocktails at the bar by a ratio of four to one.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker, add ice and shake.
2. Fine strain into a cocktail glass, and garnish with three espresso beans.

title: Avocado Paloma
intro_philosophy: Despite the name of the drink, “it’s not incredibly green,” warns Josh Goldman of Bar Caló, since it’s mostly infused with avocado oil while the flesh is strained out. For those seeking a bolder hue, he suggests using white grapefruit juice instead of pink and adding a couple of drops of liquid chlorophyll.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce agave syrup (2:1, agave nectar to hot water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except avocado soda in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Add the avocado soda to the tin, then strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.
3. Express the grapefruit peel and discard.
4. Garnish with a fresh avocado leaf.

title: Mrs. Rabbit’s Bedtime Toddy
intro_philosophy: The traditional toddy template kicked up withSuzeand peated Scotch. Stephen Bielawski’s former coworker, Al Culliton, calls this toddy a, “smoky, floral, bitter delight.” Bielawski, for his part, describes it as “equal parts fragrant, calming and inebriating.”
ingredients: 1 ounce blended Scotch or Irish whisky
1/2 ounce single malt Scotch, preferably Laphroaig
3/4 ounce honey syrup (1:1 honey to water)
instructions: 1. Muddle ginger and orange slice in a steaming pitcher.
2. Combine remaining ingredients and steam until hot.
3. Strain into a pint glass and top with hot water.
4. Add a chamomile tea bag and garnish with lemon wheel, orange peel and freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Grissini With Salami, Prosciutto and Pickled Radicchio
intro_philosophy: With a bit of polishing, aperitivoessenzialeis transformed from elemental snack into elevated grazing. Wrapgrissiniwith tangy marinated radicchio and prosciutto and lay out oil-preserved anchovies for a bit of extra visual flair.
instructions: 1. In a saucepan, bring the white wine, white wine vinegar, and juniper berries to a boil over medium heat.
2. When the liquid is bubbling, submerge the radicchio leaves and let boil for 5 minutes.
3. Meanwhile, pour the olive oil into an airtight container.
4. Take the white wine mixture off of the heat, remove the radicchio with tongs, and gently shake off any excess liquid.
5. Place the pickled leaves in the olive oil and store in the refrigerator until ready to use so that they retain their color and flavor.
6. Drain the leaves of any excess oil before using.
7. Starting at the top of each grissini, wrap with a piece of salami or prosciutto, and then wrap with a radicchio leaf.
8. Repeat for all remaining bread sticks.

title: Sobacha Chu-Hai
intro_philosophy: A take on Japan’schu-hai, this cocktail brings together buckwheat tea (“soba cha” in Japanese), which “has a refreshing yet nutty and earthy flavor that pairs well with this complex barley shochu,” saysTom Liu, with lemon cordial for acidity and body, and saline solution for a savory hit. The drink typically incorporates force carbonation, a technique common at Los Angeles bar Thunderbolt, where Liu is head bartender. At home, try this version, which calls on concentrated buckwheat tea and soda water instead.
ingredients: 3 ounces buckwheat tea concentrate (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the buckwheat tea concentrate, shochu, lemon cordial and saline solution to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass with an ice spear.
3. Top with soda water.

title: Bramble (Fresh)
intro_philosophy: The Bramble, invented in 1984 by bartender Dick Bradsell, is one of the few drinks that falls into the category of “modern classics.” One of the founding fathers of London’s cocktail scene, Bradsell created this cross between aCobblerand a Gin Sour while working at Fred’s Club in SoHo. He considers it a sentimental play on aSingapore Slingusing entirely of British products—the blackberries lending a flavor “reminiscent of his childhood on the Isle of Wight.” Bartender and writer Toby Cecchini sums up its contemporary importance well calling it, “the riesling of the cocktail world, known by drinks weenies since seemingly forever.” This seasonal version calls for fresh blackberries.
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, muddle the blackberries with simple syrup.
2. Add gin and lemon juice, and top with crushed ice.
3. Swizzle to mix.
4. Top with more crushed ice, and garnish with a blackberry and a lemon wheel.

title: Rockwell Place’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy:
Workshopped by the bar team at Brooklyn’s Rockwell Place, this Jungle Bird was the winning recipe in our2024 tastingof the drink. The judges praised the texture and body of the drink, and the balance among the three central pillars of the cocktail: rum, red bitter and pineapple. As Talia Baiocchi, Punch editor-in-chief, noted, it was the “most archetypal” of the bunch.

Editor’s note: At Rockwell Place, the bar team makes the Jungle Bird with a house stout syrup and acid-adjusted pineapple juice, but this is a home bartender–friendly version and the same version submitted to our tasting.
ingredients: 1 ounce Appleton Estate 12-Year-Old Rare Casks rum
2 teaspoons rich Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaking tin. Add one large ice cube and two smaller ice cubes.
2. Shake for 30 seconds or until the smaller ice cubes have dissolved.
3. Strain into a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish as you see fit.

title: Warm Regards
intro_philosophy: Being from the South, Tiffanie Barriere has always found tea cocktails, and tea in general, a most welcoming drink. The notes of baking spices and pepper in the Glen Moray Chardonnay expression put her in the mind of tea. The addition of a homemade Chai Spice Syrup carries this warmth throughout the drink, finished with the fresh pop of aromatic winter citrus.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces  Glen Moray Speyside Classic Single Malt Scotch Whisky (Chardonnay Cask Finish)
½ ounce  Chai Spice Syrup (see Editor’s Note)
½ ounce  freshly squeezed blood orange juice
½ ounce  freshly squeezed lemon juice
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a teacup over ice.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Angostura Colada 3.0
intro_philosophy: TheAngostura Colada, created by Zac Overman, has gone through several iterations and is now in its 3.0 version, the goal of which, according to Sunken Harbor Club’s Garret Richard, is to “put more ‘colada’ in the Angostura Colada.” To that end, the cocktail is prepared in a blender using pineapple chunks and xanthan gum to help stabilize the blend, keeping the ice and liquid better incorporated. The fresh fruit flavor and the slushy-machine texture are two quintessential markers that bring to mind the classic beach bar colada.
ingredients: 60 grams pineapple chunks, preferably frozen and defrosted with excess water strained off
1/2 ounce acid-adjusted pineapple juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the crushed ice in a blender and briefly blend to integrate.
2. Add the crushed ice and blend again.
3. Pour into a skull mug or another glass and garnish with a pineapple wedge, pineapple leaves and an edible orchid.

title: Green Swizzle
intro_philosophy: According toImbibe!, the Green Swizzle reigned supreme in the Caribbean from the late 1890s through the 1930s, before being dethroned by the Daiquiri #2. A Rum Swizzle made green by the addition of wormwood bitters (or crème de menthe, by some accounts), the recipe cited here originally appeared in a 1908 edition of theNew York Herald.
instructions: 1. In a tall glass, combine all ingredients.
2. Half fill glass with shaved ice.
3. Swizzle the drink until the ice is melted and the drink almost frappé.
4. Strain into a cocktail glass.

title: Amaretto Sour
intro_philosophy: The Amaretto Sour implies pre-bottled mix and university bar crowds of a certain variety. Until we came across Portland bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s higher proof, but feathery-light egg whiteversion, we’d written off the headaches of days gone by. His version relies on the backbone of strong bourbon (an unusual addition) to round out the fruit of a high-quality amaretto, a liqueur made from almonds and apricot pits. Egg white blends and buoys the stronger ingredients creating a more sophisticated cocktail than most of the amaretto sours to come before it.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce bourbon, cask proof (Booker's is a good bet)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry shake.
2. Add ice and shake well.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel and a brandied cherry.
5. Serve and grin like an idiot as your friends freak out (as Mr. Morgenthaler recommends).

title: Crème de Cacao
intro_philosophy:
The crème de cacaos of the mid-19th century were meant to be consumed on their own, and despite their sweetness (their sugary viscosity, not the addition of dairy, is what earned them the “crème” moniker) balance was paramount. But as 20th-century cocktail culture swaggered in, the spotlight shifted to base spirits (whiskey, gin, etc.) and liqueurs went from stand-alone sippers to mere mixers. Thus, producers of liqueurs like crème allowed standards to wane—favoring higher levels sugar over nuance and relying on artificial coloring and oil extracts instead of actual cacao.

But now, crème de cacao is seeing revival thanks to bars and bartenders making their own housemade versions that balance nuanced sweetness with the bitter beauty of chocolate. This rum-based recipe comes from Teardrop Lounge in Portland, Oregon.
instructions: 1. Add sugar and water to a saucepan and set over medium heat.
2. Bring to a low simmer and stir to dissolve sugar.
3. Add cacao nibs, stirring constantly. The sugar will re-granulate and smoke a bit, until it begins to slowly caramelize and coat the cacao nibs. This process should take no more than 15 minutes.
4. Remove from heat, and pour the cacao nibs onto a parchment-lined baking sheet. Let cool, then break up with a spoon.
5. Reserve half of the nibs for your next batch, and place the remainder into an airtight container.
6. Top off with the rum.
7. Let steep for one week, then strain through cheesecloth.
8. Measure remaining amount and mix with equal parts distilled water to bring to proof.
9. Funnel into a bottle to serve.

title: Wait For It
intro_philosophy: Created at the Speed Rack Season 6 National Finals, where she took first place, Bunni’s Wait For It answered judge Alba Huerta’s call for a low-proof stirred drink with St-Germain. “I immediately thought of the floral sweetness of St-Germain and knew it would work well with a dry sherry,” she says. Keeping in mind not only the taste but the appearance, Bunni added a measure of Salers: “I wanted to add a bitterness, but keep the beautiful pale yellow color.” Finished with an expressed lemon peel, Wait For It makes for a bright aperitif cocktail and a welcome addition to category ofsession cocktails.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce manzanilla sherry, preferably Lustau Manzanilla Papirusa
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon swath.

title: Letter of Marque
intro_philosophy: Named for the document that gave individuals permission to capture and raid “enemy” vessels on the high seas, the Letter of Marque is an ode to what were, essentially, pirates-for-hire. Ryan Liloia’s potent mixture of rums and sweet-tart juices all shaken up and dumped over ice, might provide the state of mind necessary to privateer one’s own vessel—preferably a tiki mug full of something strong.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle ginger syrup with pineapple slices.
2. Add the remaining ingredients (except soda water), add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Add soda water and strain over crushed ice into a pilsner glass.
4. Garnish with a pineapple wedge and a mint sprig.

title: Avocado Pit Orgeat
intro_philosophy: While this recipe yields “a lovely warm toasted flavor” on its own, sometimes Kelsey Ramage uses almond extract or a little orange flower water to “bump up the flavor.” She also uses this syrup as a base for making falernum, adding spices (cinnamon, allspice, clove, anise) to the pan to toast with the pits, and then tossing in a leftover orange and lime husk to the overnight infusion.
instructions: 1. Make sure avocado pits are clean and dry. Scrub off any of the green stuff still left on them and leave to thoroughly dry out either under heat or overnight.
2. Blend the pits in a Vitamix or blender until the shreds are fine and consistently sized. Alternatively, use a microplane to grate the pits.
3. Over medium-high heat in a dry pan, give them a medium toast, constantly moving the shredded pits around in the pan. They should turn bright orange pretty quickly.
4. In a bowl or saucepan, stir together the toasted pits, sugar and water. Add your toasted pits to the sugar and water and stir. If you want a richer syrup, use only half of the water.
5. Allow to infuse overnight.
6. The next day, return the mix to the Vitamix or blender, and blitz one more time to combine. Strain through a superbag or similar.

title: Pisco Punch
intro_philosophy: A pisco cocktail that rose to fame in San Francisco in the late 1800s, the Pisco Punch is now served at bars across Lima. At Museo del Pisco, the house version of the drink combines torontel pisco, lime juice and a trio of pineapple-centric ingredients: syrup, water and juice. Enrique Hermoza serves it on the rocks with a dehydrated orange half-wheel and a pineapple leaf, which introduces fans of sweet and sour cocktails to the subtle notes of aromatic pisco.
ingredients: 3 ounces agua de piña (see Editor’s Note)
2 ounces pineapple and molle syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with 5 ice cubes and shake hard for 30 seconds.
2. Strain into a 14-ounce glass with 4 ice cubes.
3. Garnish with the dehydrated orange and pineapple leaf.

title: Ballin’ is a Habit
intro_philosophy: McLain Hedges of Denver’s RiNo Yacht Club takes a Japanese highball, built on Suntory Toki whisky, and diverts it through France; his Ballin’ is a Habitsees three unorthodox additions, namely a full ounce of Dolin dry vermouth, a splash of St-Germain and a few drops of saline.
ingredients: 1 ounce Japanese whiskey, preferably Suntory Toki
soda water, to top (preferably Fever Tree)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Avena Alexandra
intro_philosophy: The notes of caramel, vanilla, orange, dried fruits and nuts in Bacardi Ocho Sherry Cask Finish Rum had Fanny Chu (a brand ambassador for Bacardi) thinking of morning oatmeal in the tropics and an Alexander riff that played off the complementary flavors of oat milk and bananas. To achieve the perfect level of chill, dilution and foam, Chu shakes up the drink using one large ice cube. She highly recommends you serve this in the sexiest coupe in your collection.
ingredients: 1 ounce rum, preferably Bacardi Ocho Sherry Cask Finish
1 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane
1 ounce oat milk, preferably Chobani Extra Creamy Oatmilk
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
2. Shake for approximately 10 seconds, then fine-strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express an orange twist over the surface of the drink and discard. Sprinkle cocoa powder over the surface of the drink.

title: Pé de Cabra
intro_philosophy:
On the Portuguese island of Madeira, Pé de Cabra is a typical offering at many bars. This recipe is adapted from the drink Carlos Freitas serves at his bar, Pé-de-Cabra, which originated the drink.

Freitas didn’t want to share the brand of cocoa powder he uses, which includes chocolate powder, sugar and malt extract; in the U.S., Ovaltine is a close approximation. Alternatively, many bars on Madeira use bottled chocolate milk.

Coral stout, a 5.1 percent ABV beer that’s the gold standard for Pé de Cabra, is difficult to find outside of Portugal. But many bars on Madeira, including Freitas’, serve a premium take on the drink made with Guinness, although at 7.5 percent ABV, you’re getting a bit more booze.

For the wine element, Freitas uses vinho tratado, a homemade, fortified, unaged Madeira wine; sweet Madeira wine works as a substitute. Many bars on the island simply use red boxed wine, boosting the amount of sugar to compensate.And don’t forget Carlos’ advice for enjoying a Pé de Cabra: “You should drink it quickly, otherwise the foam will disappear.”
ingredients: 150 milliliters (5 ounces)  sweet Madeira wine, chilled
1/2 teaspoon malted cocoa powder, such as Ovaltine
2 swaths of lemon peel (around 3 grams total)
instructions: 1. To each of two porter- or tulip-style beer glasses, add a swath of lemon peel and an ice cube.
2. To a small pitcher (or blender), add malted cocoa powder, sugar, stout and sweet Madeira wine.
3. Process with an immersion blender (or blend) until frothy, around 15 seconds.
4. Pour over ice and serve immediately, ideally with a dentinho, or small snack, such as peanuts.

title: Wild Amargo
intro_philosophy: In this frothy sour,Lou Bernard, beverage director atMita, layers herbaceous, slightly savory and tropical flavors by marrying equal parts gin, Salers and fino sherry, complemented by pineapple liqueur, lemon and an easy gooseberry syrup. As a bartender working within a restaurant, Bernard always tries to work with the kitchen to reduce waste; here he subs aquafaba in lieu of egg white to create the requisite froth.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Strain out the ice and shake again, then pour into a coupe.
3. Garnish with edible flowers.

title: Rum Swizzle
intro_philosophy: Synonymous with the Caribbean, the original Rum Swizzle, with its base of rum, lime juice and bitters, has spurred countless variations. Here, Trader Vic’s ode to the original.
instructions: 1. Pour over 2 scoops shaved ice in a glass pitcher.
2. Churn vigorously with a swizzle stick until the drink foams and pitcher frosts.
3. Pour into chilled highball glass and garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Sherry Flip
intro_philosophy:
The term “flip” is said to have been used as far back as the late 1600s to describe a mixture of beer, rum and sugar cooked at high heat, resulting in what is essentially the 17th-century version of the worst hangover instigator imaginable. By the 19th century, the flip had evolved into a fully upright drink defined as a combination of a spirit or fortified wine, sugar and egg—shaken with ice, and served up with nutmeg grated over the top.

While there are a number of spirits that make for a fine flip, the deep, walnuty character of dry oloroso sherry—and its higher level of glycerol—combined with the creaminess of an entire egg results in what Jerry Thomas, in his 1887 version ofHow To Mix Drinks,aptly describes as a “very delicious drink” that “gives strength to delicate people.” Sure does. A cold weather fortifier, the Sherry Flip does well during the holidays as a less polarizing—and less boozy—stand in for eggnog.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker without ice.
2. Shake vigorously for 30 seconds.
3. Add ice and shake for another 30 seconds.
4. Strain into a copita or small wine glass.
5. Grate fresh nutmeg over the top.

title: Parish Hall Punch
ingredients: 1⁄2 cup  gin (preferably Greenhook Ginsmiths’ Old Tom Gin or Hayman's Old Tom)
1/2 cup Basque cider (preferably Isastegi or Sarasola)
instructions: 1. Peel the grapefruits, taking care to avoid as much of the bitter white pith as possible.
2. In a large bowl, combine the sugar with the grapefruit peels, then lightly muddle and let sit for 20 minutes to allow the citrus oils to infuse with the sugar.
3. After 20 minutes, add the gin, sherry, cider, ginger beer and seltzer. Stir to combine.
4. Add the ginger and the grapefruit peels to the bowl to garnish.
5. To serve, ladle into punch cups over ice.

title: Alpine Pass
intro_philosophy: For bartender Max Green, amaro has become a bona fide staple. “I can’t imagine a world where bitters aren’t part of a cocktail,” says Green. “Amaro is invaluable.” The name of Green’s bitter highball-spritz combination is a nod to Valtellina, the Northern Italian valley where Braulio is made, and a key travel route between Italy and Germany. The pronounced bitterness and complex flavors of Braulio are rounded out with a “subtle sweetness” from vermouth; meanwhile, “the menthol and woody notes evolve, and the essential oils of citrus add a bright undertone,” he says.
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients, except for the soda water, in a highball glass filled with ice and stir to lightly chill.
2. Top with soda, and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: La Danza
intro_philosophy: Brother Wolf uses Lurisia’s Chinotto soda, made from the fruit of myrtle-leaf orange trees, in the refreshing La Danza, complementing the bubbly drink with Cocchi Americano Rosa, fresh citrus juices and orange oil. Chinotto “offers an almost root beer or cola flavor [to cocktails], with natural coloring, lots of effervescence and a touch of pulp,” says King.
ingredients: 2 dashes orange oil (Brother Wolf uses NOW Foods essential oil )
2 to 3 ounces chinotto soda, preferably Lurisia, to top
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients in a mixing tin and add ice.
2. Shake and strain into an ice-filled Collins glass.
3. Top with chinotto soda and a pinch of Maldon flakes.

title: Polynesian Pearl Diver
intro_philosophy: In Quentin Tarantino’s 2012 antebellum film,Django Unchained,a variation of a standard tiki drink appears in the cooly vicious hands of plantation owner Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio)—never mind the fact that tiki, though created in Hollywood, was not invented until the 1930s.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Pearl Diver's Mix, (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender.
2. Blend on high until the consistency is uniform.
3. Pour into a tiki mug (or a coconut shell) and garnish with an orchid.

title: Gage & Tollner’s Stinger
intro_philosophy: St. John Frizell never developed a taste for theStingerbut, in an effort to revive the historical bar program at Gage & Tollner, he set about developing one with Jelani Johnson. Working off of Zac Overman’s rum-based version from Frizell’s bar Fort Defiance, in Red Hook, Brooklyn, the pair developed a spec that serves up mint three ways: the cooling, candied mint of the crème de menthe, the bitter mint of Branca Menta, and grassy notes from the fresh mint leaves that are shaken with the cocktail. A rum float adds a bit of funkiness.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce white crème de menthe, preferably Giffard
1 teaspoon rich Demerara syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
1/4 ounce rum, preferably Smith & Cross rum, for float
instructions: 1. Combine all but rum in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake to chill.
3. Strain into a brandy snifter over crushed ice.
4. Float rum on top.
5. Garnish with a mint bouquet and serve with a straw.

title: Fancy 79
intro_philosophy: This distant relative of theFrench 75cuts down on waste by utilizing the entirety of the citrus—in this case, clementine.
instructions: 1. Combine the first five ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass and top with Champagne.

title: In The Pines
intro_philosophy: Ryan Maybee mixes herbal, pine-scented génépy with housemade chamomile-infused rye, vanilla syrup and Champagne in his In The Pines, which is at once bracing and refreshing and thoroughly cold-weather appropriate.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy des Alpes
1/2 ounce  vanilla syrup (1:1, sugar:water, with 2 Madagascar vanilla beans infused for every liter)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except sparkling wine in a shaking tin and shake well with ice.
2. Strain into a champagne flute with no ice.
3. Top with sparkling wine.  Garnish with lemon zest.

title: Hemingway Hi Ball
intro_philosophy: Fanny Chu’s riff on a Hemingway Daiquiri starts with a small-batch Panamanian white rum, which Chu likes for its “banana-y” notes, and swaps out the standard dose of maraschino liqueur for a splash of Luxardo cherry syrup, which helps balance the sour component from fresh lime. The standard grapefruit juice is replaced with a full three ounces of Fever-Tree grapefruit soda, resulting in a refreshing, bittersweet long drink.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce  white rum,  preferably Pedro Mandinga Silver
instructions: 1. Combine the rum, lime juice and cherry syrup in a mixing tin.
2. Add 3 ice cubes and briefly shake to incorporate ingredients and slightly chill.
3. Strain into a Collins glass filled with ice.
4. Top off with Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit soda and give it a quick stir.
5. Garnish with a lime wheel, grapefruit and cherry.

title: Peach Buzz
intro_philosophy: Kelsey Ramage loves peaches, and inspiration for this cocktail struck right at the end of the season, when the fruit reaches peak, juicy ripeness. On top of the rich stone fruit infusions, a sweet fern tincture gently pulls out the botanicals in the Bombay Sapphire gin, highlighting cassia bark and licorice.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce peach-infused Bombay Sapphire gin (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce peach-infused dry vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
2 dashes sweet fern tincture (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a small cocktail tin, add ice, and stir until well chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupette glass, and garnish with a peach ball.

title: Bijou Blanc
intro_philosophy: When developing the French-focused bar program at Le Rock, Bossy attempted to make the 1890s classic Bijou—previously not a favorite of hers—into a drink she loved. Her version relies on navy-strength gin and the expected green Chartreuse, but switches out sweet vermouth in favor of Italian bianco and extra-dry vermouths in equal measure. Bossy also ditches the orange bitters and cherry (or olive!) garnish of the original and adds a quarter-ounce of Salers for added backbone.
ingredients: 1 ounce navy-strength gin, such as Four Pillars
1/2 ounce extra-dry vermouth, such as Bordiga
1/2 ounce bianco vermouth, such as Bordiga
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel “flag.”

title: Green T
intro_philosophy: Atthe pioneering cocktail bar White Lyan(which closed in April 2017), they used tannins in different forms (powdered, by way of teas, etc.) to create texture and astringency in cocktails. In their Green T, they combine gin with a strong green tea syrup, “fake lime juice” and soda for a wholly unique highball.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces green tea syrup, (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce  fake lime juice, (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a highball glass.
2. Add ice, and top with soda water.

title: Music That Stays On for Extra Days
intro_philosophy: This low-ABV Zombie riff presents what Lost Lake’s Shelby Allison and Paul McGee call a “sessionable take on a notoriously non-sessionable tiki cocktail.”
ingredients: 1 dash absinthe, preferably Letherbee Barrel Aged Absinthe
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients in a shaker tin with one cup of crushed ice
2. Using a spindle blender, buzz for three seconds.
3. Pour into a ceramic mug and top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with mint bouquet, cinnamon stick, grapefruit peel, orchid and other tropical accoutrements.

title: Banana Snaquiri
intro_philosophy: You won’t find this non-traditional Daiquiri on the cocktail list at Brooklyn’s Kings County Imperial, but bartender Richard Murphy will occasionally pull it out for VIPs. He uses demerara sugar in the simple syrup for a bigger, bolder flavor that can hold up next to robust ingredients like banana and spiced falernum.
ingredients: 2 ounces white rum, preferably Denizen Aged White Rum
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients and one cup of ice to a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Pour into shot glasses, or a tiki mug for a full-sized drink.
4. Garnish each shot with a banana slice and a grating of nutmeg.

title: Suppressor #1
intro_philosophy:
As Ticonderoga Club partner Paul Calvert says about drinking suppressors, “You’re between two places, and you just want to hold the line… That feeling could last all night.”

To achieve that, Greg Best’s O.G. Suppressor #1 draws on the most basic building block of low-proof cocktails: fortified wines. Vermouth mixes with the savoriness of sherry and citrus notes, achieving compelling layers of flavor sans the booze.

Special thanks to our friends atW&P Designfor this bad-ass pineapple tumbler. More over atthepineapple.co.
ingredients: 1 ounce PX sherry, preferably Alvear PX sherry 2008
instructions: 1. Build ingredients over crushed ice in a julep cup.
2. Garnish with a swath of orange peel and a sprig of mint.

title: Champaxne Cocktail
intro_philosophy: At Swan Bar, this zero-proof riff on the Champagne Cocktail relies on a nonalcoholic sparkling wine, a sugar cube infused with orange flower water and spirit-free bitters.
ingredients: 1 orange blossom sugar cube (see Editor’s Note)
10 drops All the Bitter New Orleans bitters
nonalcoholic sparkling wine, preferably French Bloom Blanc, to top
instructions: 1. Place the sugar cube in a flute. Add bitters, then top with nonalcoholic wine, without ice.
2. Stir to combine.
3. Garnish with a long orange twist.

title: Rule of Thirds
intro_philosophy: With this New Orleans–inspired cocktail, bartender Maggie Morgan decided to riff off the “holy trinity” of Cajun cooking: onion, bell pepper and celery. The clean, herbal notes of the gin and the bright citrus kick of lemon juice help bond the vegetal and Southern spice elements into a balance of sweet, sour and savory, recalling the “rule of thirds” principle in artistic composition.
ingredients: 3/4 parts  bell pepper syrup  (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add gin, bell pepper syrup, lemon juice and celery bitters to a shaker tin.
2. Add ice and shake.
3. Double-strain into a coupe half-rimmed with andouille seasoning.
4. Garnish with a cocktail onion.

title: Umami Tea Service
intro_philosophy: CJ Catalano created this nonalcoholic cocktail recipe for a pop-up with chef Dominique Crenn at MILA Omakase. He combines Lapsang souchong with a warm shiitake mushroom base, then brightens it all with a touch of calamansi vinegar.
instructions: 1. Pour Umami Tea into a teacup and finish with the calamansi vinegar.
2. Garnish with a honeysuckle flower.

title: Banana Bread Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: In this Old-Fashioned, reminiscent of chocolate-studded banana bread, the secret ingredient is “Banana Bread Bitters,” made with equal partsFee Brothers Walnut Bitters and Fee Brothers Aztec Chocolate Bitters. Bar manager Bill Brillinger recommends Old Forester for this drink, “because I get chocolate notes from the bourbon.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crème de banane, preferably Tempus Fugit
1/4 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Giffard
