2. Put apples in a baking dish, and spoon brown sugar into the core of each. Add 1/4 inch water to the bottom of the dish, and place in the oven until softened, about 45 minutes.
3. In a large sauce pot, add cider, ale and sherry. Place over low heat, and do not boil.
4. In a square of cheesecloth, add cinnamon stick, cloves and allspice. Tie securely and drop into the warming pot with nutmeg and ginger.
5. If adding eggs, skip to the next step. If not, let mixture simmer for 30 minutes and skip to step 11.
6. Separate egg yolks from whites into two separate medium-sized bowls.
7. With an electric mixer, beat egg yolks until frothy. Then beat egg whites until stiff peaks form.
8. Beat egg whites into yolks until just combined.
9. Slowly add 1/2 a cup of the warm cider mixture into the eggs while whisking the entire time.
10. Whisk this mixture back into the cider pot.
11. Add apples and baking liquid to the pot.
12. Ladle into individual glasses, and garnish with an apple slice and a cinnamon stick.

title: Pinkies Out
intro_philosophy: Natasha David has a penchant for things that sparkle, namely spritz drinks. The Pinkies Out is one such bubbling cocktail born of a love for weird wine and infused Dolin Blanc. At Nitecap, David mixes oxidized orange wine with chamomile-infused Dolin Blanc. Balanced with Cocchi Americano, bright verjus blanc (unfermented grape juice) and dry apple cider, this cocktail is surprisingly taught, fizzy formula. Though it may be ladylike, it’s an addictive drink that pops nearly every pinkie finger holding it.
ingredients: 1 ounce Dolin Blanc, chamomile-infused (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add orange wine, Dolin, Cocchi and verjus to a wine glass.
2. Add ice and top with sparkling cider.
3. Garnish with a half an orange wheel.

title: Ivory Towers
intro_philosophy: This nonalcoholic cocktail fromTiny Championstakes inspiration from Italian Chinotto, abitter Italian soda. Bartender Alphonso Quinones infuses Lucano’s N/A amaro with dried cascara, the berry that grows outside of a coffee bean. Quinones describes the fruit as having a “dried plum and raisin smell, with a flavor of hibiscus and jammy red fruits.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces cascara-infused N/A Amaro (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce turbinado syrup (2:1, turbinado sugar to water)
3 to 4 ounces hop water, such as Lagunitas Hoppy Refresher, to top
instructions: 1. Add the amaro, juice and syrup to a shaker tin and whip shake with a couple of ice cubes.
2. Strain into a glass over ice.
3. Top with hop water.
4. Garnish with an orange half moon.

title: Bonnie’s Long Island Iced Tea
intro_philosophy: Traditionally, the Long Island Iced Tea does not contain any actual tea, but Bonnie’s in Brooklyn serves its version with an orange pekoe tea concentrate. Channing Centeno, who designed the cocktail menu at Bonnie’s, preserves the integrity of the original recipe but spices it up with Cognac and Mexican Coca-Cola. “It’s a super crushable cocktail,” he says.
ingredients: 2 ounces spiced honey syrup (see Editor’s Note)
6 ounces orange pekoe concentrate (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake the ingredients, except for the cola, in a large mixing tin filled with ice, then strain into a large teapot. Top with cola.
2. When ready to serve, pour into a mug over a large rock.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Horsefeather
intro_philosophy: Built on a whiskey base and topped with ginger beer and a squeeze of lemon, the Horsefeather reads like southern take on theMoscow Mule. “I just assumed it was a classic cocktail,” says Ryan Maybee of this Kansas City staple, “but…I started to realize that nobody outside of the Kansas City area knew what I was talking about when I would ask for a Horsefeather.” Refreshing, approachable and native to his hometown, the Horsefeather has become a mainstay of Maybee’s repertoire.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably Rieger’s Kansas City Whiskey
instructions: 1. Build over ice in a Collins glass.

title: It’s So Easy
intro_philosophy: Using winter clementines, Aaron Polsky of New York City’sMulberry Projectcreated this orange cobbler whose citrusy edges are rounded out with Bittermens Orange Cream Citrate, a throwback to the soda fountain counters of yore.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle clementine segments with lemon juice and simple syrup.
2. Add gin and Orange Cream Citrate.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Dump into a rocks glass and top with crushed ice.
5. Garnish with a clementine wheel.

title: Spanish Monk
intro_philosophy: First published in 1951 in Charles H. Baker Jr.’sThe South American Gentleman’s Companion, theSpanish Monkcombines gin, lemon, green Chartreuse, simple syrup and an egg white. Nick Flower learned the recipe at New York’s Little Branch, and he now serves the classic at his bar Too Soon in Portland, Oregon.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry-shake.
2. Add ice, then shake again.
3. Strain into a coupe.

title: IMO
intro_philosophy: The name of this drink,imo, means “potato” in Japanese. Here, mellow, earthy potatoshochuis given additional complexity thanks to two liqueurs: subtly bitter Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur and smoky crema de mezcal.
tags: Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces potato shochu, preferably Shiranami Genshu
3/4 ounce Del Maguey Crema de Mezcal
2 teaspoons Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a snifter.

title: Ichor and Glass
intro_philosophy: An elevated play on the classic Blood and Sand cocktail, Ryan Casey borrows from Greek mythology:Ichoris, according to legend, the blood-like fluid that flows through the veins of the gods. The “glass” in the drink is the spherical ice, representing a polished version of sand.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Scotch, preferably Compass Box Great King Street
1/2 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably preferably Mancino
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice sphere.
4. Twist orange peel over the top of the drink to express the oils, then discard the peel.

title: Moonraker
intro_philosophy: Shannon Tebay created her take on Joe Gilmore’s late-1960s Moonwalk cocktail for a menu she launched in October 2021, when she was head bartender at the Savoy’s American Bar. She opted to push the mimosa–Champagne Cocktail hybrid into French 75 territory with the addition of Irish whiskey—a nod to Gilmore’s heritage—while retaining the floral and citrus notes of the original.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces (45 milliliters) Irish whiskey, preferably Powers
1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon (20 milliliters) chamomile syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon (20 milliliters) lemon juice
instructions: 1. Prepare the glass: Using an atomizer, spray a swath of the side of a Champagne flute with vodka. Sprinkle the chamomile sugar onto the glass through a sieve or sugar duster. Shake off any loose particles by gently tapping the base of the flute on a solid surface. Set aside.
2. In a cocktail shaker, combine all ingredients but the Champagne.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Strain into prepared glass.
5. Top with Champagne.

intro_philosophy: Nick Bennett of New York’s Porchlight updates the classic ’70s call drink with a five-whiskey blend and 7Up syrup.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce rye whiskey, preferably Old Overholt Rye
1/2 ounce rye whiskey, preferably Canadian Club Rye
1/4 ounce peated single malt whiskey, preferably Corsair Triple Smoke
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in an iSi whipper and carbonate.
2. Serve in a footed highball glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Spicy Boi
intro_philosophy: Olsen believes the key to modifying a classic like the Old-Fashioned lies in tweaking the syrup first. Here, she makes what she calls a “summer syrup”—it has tropical infusions like cinnamon and makrut lime—because, of course, it’s always summer in Miami. Thus, this is a year-round drink for Olsen and her customers. She ups the spice notes by opting for cardamom bitters and cardamom ice. Since the Knob Creek®Rye is already so spicy, the name befits this drink.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Strain over a cardamom ice cube (see Editor’s Note) in a double Old-Fashioned glass.

title: Abigail Gullo’s Boulevardier
intro_philosophy: In a recent Boulevardier tasting, Abigail Gullo’s rye-based rendition took top honors. The judges termed it a near-perfect example of the cocktail.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rye whiskey, preferably Rittenhouse Rye
3/4 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably La Quintinye Vermouth Rouge
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over cracked ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with orange peel.

title: Dunkin’ Delight
intro_philosophy: Despite being a self-proclaimed coffee snob, Iain Townsend Griffiths admits that thisEspresso Martini riffwas inspired by a blueberry-spiked coffee from Dunkin’. Here, the fruit flavor comes courtesy of beloved flavored vodka,Stoli Blueberry. The rest of the recipe is fairly straightforward, calling on fresh espresso in combination withcoffee liqueur, simple syrup and a pinch of salt all topped with a fresh grating of nutmeg.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blueberry vodka, preferably Stoli Blueberry
3/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Mr. Black
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Sitting Pretty
intro_philosophy: Demi Natoli’s Sitting Pretty is a tropical highball, bursting with bright citrus flavor from Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit soda along with fresh lime, mint and coconut. Natoli thinks of it as a Mojito meets a Paloma by way of a Saoco, a Cuban cocktail made with local rum, lime, ice, sugar and coconut water. You want a coconut water with around 20 grams of sugar per serving, like Iberia or Goya, both of which can be found in the Hispanic products section of most grocery stores.
instructions: 1. In the bottom half of a mixing tin, add the mint and simple syrup and muddle to combine.
2. Add rum, coconut water and lime. Fill with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Add the grapefruit soda to a Collins glass and fill the glass with fresh ice.
4. Strain the contents of the shaker into the glass and give it a quick stir.
5. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Glogg
intro_philosophy: If glogg (or glögg, if you’re feeling Scandinavian) does not immediately conjure Vikings or some later breed of burly, bearded Nordic men, nothing will. While the process of “mulling” wine with spices dates back to Roman times, the word glogg—which once described a mixture of wine (dry red and port together, generally), a spirit (cognac) and spices, heated up—first appears in print in 1870 as the shortened version of “glödgad vin” or “glowing wine.” By the 1890s glogg had firmly rooted itself with the canon of American (and European) holiday drinks. While our version toes a line between modern and classic, many contemporary American versions can include everything from sherry to brandy to vodka. So, by all means, get weird.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a large sauce pot.
2. Bring to a simmer and then reduce heat to low.
3. Let simmer over low heat for 30 minutes.
4. Sweeten to taste with additional brown sugar.
5. Strain Glögg and serve into individual glasses.
6. Garnish each glass with a tablespoon of raisins and a tablespoon of sliced almonds.

title: Jeremy Oertel’s Manhattan
intro_philosophy: Jeremy Oertel’s take on the Manhattan was the top vote-getter at ourtasting of 17 Manhattan recipesin 2016. His formula couldn’t be more classic: two-and-a-half ounces of Rittenhouse rye, one ounce of Carpano Antica Formula sweet vermouth and two dashes of Angostura bitters. The panel found the cocktail rich and full-bodied, with notes of cocoa nibs on the finish.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a coupe.

title: Capputivo
intro_philosophy: This is a drink for new beginnings: Edward Hansel developed it as a smoother gateway for those curious but unaccustomed to Fernet shots. The trio of coffee liqueur, amaro and Luxardo Bitter Bianco in the Capputivo is delicate, but still revving—that’s why Hansel suggests drinking it to start your day or evening—“at 7 a.m. or p.m., with rad sunglasses on.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Firelit Spirits Coffee Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the egg white in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain the liquid into one half of the mixing tin to remove the ice.
3. Add the egg white and dry shake.
4. Double strain into a coffee cup or coupe.
5. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: The Bar’s Tuxedo Cocktail
intro_philosophy: For the revamp of New York’s iconic Four Seasons bar, head of bar operations for Major Food Group, Thomas Waugh, developed this version of the sherry-spiked Martini riff, which is pre-batched, pre-chilled and poured from a crystal decanter.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 1 liter bottle and place in the freezer for 24 hours.
2. Pour into a coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with skewered Tomolives.

title: Macadamia Nut Chi Chi
intro_philosophy: A blended mess of vodka, pineapple, coconut cream and rich, nutty macadamia liqueur, this frozen cocktail is a tiki original with versions attributed to Polynesian forebears Don the Beachcomber and Trader Vic. Modern tiki expert Jeff “Beachbum” Berry rejiggered this version in his 2002Intoxica!
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Pour into two tiki mugs.
4. Garnish with an umbrella.

title: Brockton Navy
intro_philosophy: “Old Tom is a beautiful thing,” says Danny Shapiro. “I enjoy its versatility—it plays so well with so many things.” Here, he positions the slightly sweet gin against bittersweet Amargo-Vallet liqueur, then bolsters those flavors with lemon andorgeat, for a touch of sweetness.
ingredients: 1 ounce Old Tom gin, preferably Scofflaw
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon wedge.

title: Ronnie Buders
intro_philosophy: A sour triple threat, the Ronnie Buders includes a sour beer gastrique alongside sour mash and sourdough tincture.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sour beer gastrique (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with Sour Patch Kids.

title: Giuseppe Gonzalez’s Pornstar Martini
intro_philosophy: This ostentatious, two-vessel assemblage—vodka, passion fruit, lime and vanilla in one glass, a shot of sparkling rosé Champagne on the side—was a sensation at London’s Townhouse and its sister bar, LAB, in the early 2000s. Its fame was doubtless spurred along by its provocative name. Though once widely drunk in the U.K., its inclusion on the cocktail list at Suffolk Arms may well be its New York debut.
instructions: 1. Put all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake.
2. Strain into a coupe and serve with fresh passion fruit and a shot of sparkling rosé.

title: Hojoko’s Ward Eight
intro_philosophy: A classic Ward Eight set through the lens of an anything-but-classic izakaya, this drink gets some umami from a tamari-laced lime cordial and acidity from a rice wine vinegar-infused grenadine. Bartender Darren Swisher says that bourbon will lead to a drink that’s “sweeter, rounded and fuller bodied,” while the rye will offer something “drier and more linear.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon, preferably Larceny or Weller 107
OR 1 1/2 ounces rye whiskey, preferably Rittenhouse
1/4 ounce Hojoko lime cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

title: Moulin Rouge #2
intro_philosophy: Francois Vera’s Moulin Rouge #2 counts on Suze to balance the sweetness of strawberries and vanilla, for a drier rendition of Vera’s original recipe. “It brings balance to a cocktail without hurting the palate of those who don’t enjoy much bitterness,” he explains.
ingredients: sparkling rosé, preferably d'Alsace rosé brut, to top
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients, except for brut rosé, with ice.
2. Strain into a flute and top with brut rosé.

title: Lazarus
intro_philosophy: Echoing the famously resurrected Biblical character, this cocktail finds a second life for ingredients scavenged from the kitchen, transforming upcycled elements into a savory-sweet cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce corn silk tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a shaker, fill with ice, and shake.
2. Double-strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish by wrapping the corn husk around the glass from the base to the rim, attaching with a small clip or clothespin.

title: Old Hickory
intro_philosophy: “I like to pay homage to the lesser known New Orleans cocktails,” says Maxwell Britten, head bartender of Brooklyn cocktail bar Maison Premiere. Britten adapted his Old Hickory—a reference to President Andrew Jackson’s nickname—from Stanley Clisby Arthur’s 1937FamousNew Orleans Drinks and How to Mix ‘Em. His version includes the addition of Peychaud’s bitters, another nod to its New Orleans roots. Because the drink is a vermouth-based, low-proof cocktail Britten likes to suggest it as an unorthodox, but compatible companion to oysters (Maison’s culinary specialty).
tags: Famous New Orleans Drinks and How to Mix 'Em
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: The Roosevelt Room’s Amaretto Sour
intro_philosophy: Taking the third spot inour Amaretto Sour blind tasting, this recipe, on paper, was the most finicky of the bunch. It calls for one and a quarter ounces of Lazzaroni amaretto, half an ounce of Wild Turkey 101 bourbon, a quarter-ounce of amontillado sherry, plus both lemon and lime juices, Demerara syrup, hazelnut oil, salt tincture and an egg white. The finishing touch was a spray of black walnut bitters over the surface of the drink. That last flourish was the judges’ only quibble. “Even though there’s something that is atypical, it still tastes like the drink,” said bartender Max Green.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce egg white (or 1 small egg white)
1/4 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, Demerara sugar to water)
4 drops salt tincture (1:10, salt to water)
instructions: 1. Add the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry-shake without ice.
2. Add cubed ice and short-shake for 5 seconds.
3. Double-strain into a large rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Use an atomizer to spray 4 spritzes of Fee Brothers Black Walnut bitters over the surface of the drink, then top with a cherry and an orange twist “flag.”

title: Americano
intro_philosophy: Don’t let the name fool you: the Americano’s heritage is distinctly Italian. Born from the Milano-Torino (equal parts Campari from Milan and red vermouth from Torino over ice) in the 19thcentury, this cocktail—topped up with soda water and garnished with an orange twist—is believed by some to have been the favored beverage for American tourists seeking “la dolce vita” in Italy during Prohibition. Though its heavyweight cousin, theNegroni, may have more currency in today’s cocktail world, the Americano isn’t far behind.
instructions: 1. Add Campari and sweet vermouth to a Collins or rocks glass.
2. Add ice and top with soda.
3. Garnish with an orange slice or orange peel.

title: ViceVersa’s MiTo
intro_philosophy: At Miami’sViceVersa, one of ourBest New Bars of 2024, the Milano-Torino (or Mi-To for short) serves as the base for the entire Negroni Family section of the menu. The mixture, typically equal parts Campari and sweet vermouth, is turned into an elaborate cocktail unto itself, made here with banana-infused Campari and descending quantities of Torino vermouth, osmanthus water, two types of sherry and coffee amaro. It’s used to add dimension to everything from the bar’s force-carbonated Americano to the house Negroni, but shines equally bright on its own.
ingredients: 400 milliliters Thai banana–infused Campari (see Editor’s Note)
50 milliliters palo cortado sherry, preferably González Byass
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a container, then mix and close tightly or put into a sealable bottle. Keeps, refrigerated, for up to 2 weeks.

title: Copa Nog
intro_philosophy: This cheeky riff on eggnog from the Little Copa pop up in New Orleans has a “Christmas in July” feel to it, with coconut, lime and Angostura bitters offsetting the velvety sweetness of the Coco Lopez and eggs. It’s refreshing on the rocks, with some grated nutmeg to round it out and warm it up.
ingredients: 13 ounces rum, preferably Flor de Caña
instructions: 1. In a large mixing bowl, beat the eggs and lime zest on medium-high until frothy. Add the evaporated milk, sweetened condensed milk and Coco Lopez, and beat carefully until fully incorporated. Add the rum, bitters and nutmeg.

2. Pass the nog through a fine-mesh sieve to discard the zest. To serve, pour it in a tall glass over ice and grate fresh nutmeg on top. Leftovers can be refrigerated or frozen in an airtight container. If frozen, thaw in the fridge or on the counter—because of all the rum, it won’t take long to defrost.

title: Part Time Friend
intro_philosophy: This equal-parts shaken drink puts four bold flavors together. “We have loved Alma Tepec and used it on most of our menus since we opened two and half years ago,” says Bar Tobalá bartender Anthony Jayasekera of the pasilla mixe chile liqueur. He pairs it with Amaro Lucano, sweetened ginger juice and lime in this crowd-pleasing cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweetened ginger juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a bouquet of mint.

title: Last Night by the Jetty
intro_philosophy: Justin Brody, head bartender at Mystic, Connecticut’s The Port of Call, describes this tequila cocktail as “the love child of a Margarita and an Old-Fashioned, conceived in a cave by the sea.” Tequila and celery syrup offer earthy, savory tones, which are grounded by a rinse of absinthe and lemon juice. For a brackish finishing touch, he garnishes the drink with brined kombu. “If you hold it to your ear,” jokes Brody about the drink, “you can hear the ocean.”
ingredients: absinthe, preferably Pernod Ricard, to rinse
5 dashes of Scrappy’s Black Lemon bitters
instructions: 1. Rinse the inside of a rocks glass with an atomizer spritz of absinthe.
2. Place a large lump of clear ice in the glass.
3. Combine the tequila, celery syrup, lemon juice and bitters in a mixing glass, then top with ice and stir until well-chilled, about 20 seconds.
4. Strain into the glass over ice, then garnish with a piece of brined kombu, partially covering the cube.

title: Coffee With Giuseppe
intro_philosophy: Coffee With Giuseppe takes inspiration from Chicago bartender Stephen Cole’s Bitter Giuseppe, a modern amaro classic made with Cynar, sweet vermouth, lemon and orange bitters. When stirring the drink, Williams Pierce recommends keeping your nonstirring hand on the mixing glass and stirring until you feel the chill of the glass. “You’re looking for chill as well as dilution here, but since the drink is also going over ice, you don’t want it to be too diluted,” she says.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Du Nord Café Frieda Coffee Liqueur
4 drops  drops saline solution  (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir for 10 to 15 seconds to chill, then strain into a chilled rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a super long orange twist.

title: Post Melon
intro_philosophy: At Pennyroyal in Cardiff, Wales, Tom Parham swaps out the Dry Daiquiri’s signature Campari and passion fruit syrup for other herbal and sweet elements. “The idea was to create an unusual flavor pairing by matching the bitter aloe notes in Fernet with the watermelon, while the amaro’s saffron adds a warmth that lifts the rum,” says Alexander Taylor, the bar’s owner.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rum, preferably Chairman’s Reserve Gold Rum
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
2. Shake vigorously to chill and dilute.
3. Strain into a frozen coupette glass and serve.

title: Haifa Vice
intro_philosophy: At New York’s Chez Zou, theHaifa Vice was designed to play with the layered element of the Miami Vice.Servedin a jarra pitcher, each component with its own spout, the vessel allows guests to control the amount of each drink that they pour into their glasses. Chez Zou clarifies the drink using pectinase and other enzymes, but this version relies, instead, on a more classic milk punch approach.
ingredients: 5 ounces Mango Colada Milk Punch (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Pour Mango Colada Milk Punch into a glass with ice.
2. Combine pomegranate juice and Aperol in a mixing glass with ice, and float the mixture on top of the milk punch.

title: Aviation
intro_philosophy: After being lost for almost a half-century, this sky blue concoction was refurbished to its original glory only within the last decade. This original version first appears in Hugo Ensslin’s 1916Recipes for Mixed Drinks, citing a combination of gin, maraschino liqueur, crème de violette and lemon. The reasons it fell out of favor? A double whammy: first, the recipe bible of the era, theSavoy Cocktail Book, dropped crème de violette from the recipe in the 1930s, leaving a predominately sour mixed drink, then, crème de violette was discontinued altogether in the 1960s. Rothman & Winter recreated the liqueur in 2007, making the original recipe possible again, to the delight of a new generation of bartenders who have since championed this forgotten drink.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce crème de violette (or 1/4 ounce simple syrup)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Fill shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: New Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: In the canon of classic drinks, theOld-Fashionedis as traditional as they come: a simple mix of spirits, sugar, bitters and water, which appears in 1806 as the first printed recipe for a cocktail (“cock tail”). Other alcohols were permitted, but the whiskey or rye version of this over ice is what we now know as the Old-Fashioned, thought to be named later that century after more elaborate new-fangled cocktails entered the canon. During Prohibition, new versions appeared adding fruit and cherries to distract from the available crude spirits. After repeal, this version stuck as the most common interpretation until the recent cocktail revival brought the original recipe back from the brink of extinction. Instead of layering muddled fruit with spirits and topping with soda and/or shaking, the PUNCH version sticks to tradition via the (light) muddle, stir and strain method.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, muddle sugar cube with cherry, orange wheel and bitters.
2. Add whiskey and ice and stir well.
3. Double straininto a chilled rocks glass over ice (preferably an oversized cube).
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Bring June Flowers
intro_philosophy: “Suze and othergentian liqueursdeliver [bitterness] in abundance, while at the same time being light, crisp and almost floral,” says Chaim Dauermann, beverage director of New York’s The Up & Up. “This brings bitter drinks out of the dark realm of theNegroniand into [the] taste profile that easily appeals to many.” The aptly named Bring June Flowers highlights these characteristics in Suze by way of a jasmine syrup, meant to pump up the liqueur’s inherent floral notes, and muddled cucumber, which plays on the liqueur’s more vegetal tones.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Dump into a chilled double rocks glass.
3. Top with pebble ice.
4. Garnish with a cucumber ruffle.

title: Melon-Lime Soda
intro_philosophy: This is a layered take on the usually straightforward highball—“a little touch of Japan,” says Masa Urushido of Katana Kitten. To balance the sweetness of Midori liqueur, he typically uses a mix of juice from Japanese sudachi, a super-sour Japanese citrus fruit, and regular (Persian) limes; if sudachi is not used, dial the lime component back to a half-ounce.
ingredients: 1 ounce lime vodka, such as Absolut Lime
instructions: 1. Place an ice spear or a stack of ice cubes in a frozen highball glass or handled beer stein.
2. Add the vodka, Midori, matcha-lime cordial, sudachi juice and lime juice.
3. Top with chilled soda water and gently stir.
4. Garnish with a lime leaf, and serve.

title: Richard Boccato’s Manhattan
intro_philosophy: The winner ofour Manhattan tasting, this archetypal recipe sticks with a 2:1 ratio of whiskey—specifically, Michter’s rye—to sweet vermouth, in this case Cocchi di Torino. Two dashes of Angostura bitters complete the drink, which is garnished with a marasca cherry. As one expects from any good Manhattan, the drink is comforting: “It feels like a salve,” remarked one judge.
ingredients: 1 ounce Cocchi di Torino sweet vermouth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cold mixing glass straight out of the freezer.
2. Stir with cold shards of crystal-clear block ice, preferably stored at –4°C.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.

title: Silver Service 50/50 Martini
intro_philosophy: Amidst Silver Lyan’s menu of party drinks—Appletinis, Jell-O shots and more—the Martini service is, by comparison, restrained. But even though it’s not as Technicolor as the rest of the menu, and it isn’t garnishedwith a balloon, the drink’s sleek Martini glass and selection of garnishes still make for an indulgent serve. This recipe is for the 50/50, one of four Martini styles available on the menu.
ingredients: 1 ounce house vermouth blend (1:1, Dolin dry vermouth to Cocchi Americano)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Serve with a dish of pickled cocktail onions, olives, a lemon peel and an oyster.

title: Alpine Apple
intro_philosophy: Claire Sprouse zeroes in on Braulio’s “woody aromatics” for her warming Martini variation, the Alpine Apple. The abundant apple orchards prevalent in the northern regions of Italy near the Swiss border inspired her to reach for Pommeau, a French aperitif made from fresh apple juice and apple brandy. Yet Braulio’s prominent alpine aromatics still act as its cornerstone. Braulio is an amaro that can transition from day to night in cocktails,” says Sprouse. “From crisp sours to more belly-warming drinks.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with an apple slice and a mint sprig.

title: Life of Peach
intro_philosophy: In Gowanus, Brooklyn, at Public Records—a sprawling music-driven community space that’s equal parts bar, restaurant, café and performance space—founding partner Francis Harris introduced a fresh spin on a frozen Margarita that “since day one” has been their most popular drink. A Calabrian chili-infused blanco tequila is bolstered by blood peach purée complemented by a lime juice and an agave blend along with an unexpected note of dry, earthy bitterness courtesy of Zucca Rabarbaro Amaro. Harris says the name is a nod to the past year and a half of pandemic living and the struggles endured, much like the title character Pi in Yann Martel’s bestselling novel and philosophical allegoryLife of Pi.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Calabrian chile-infused tequila (see Editor's Note)
3/4 ounce blood peach fruit purée, preferably Boiron brand
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until cold and smooth.
2. Pour into a chilled rocks glass.
3. Garnish with peach slice.

title: Joe Campanale’s Negroni Sbagliato
intro_philosophy: In his take on the Negroni Sbagliato, Joe Campanale goes for a double dose of bitters, using one ounce each of the Brooklyn-made Forthave Red and Cappelletti from Italy. The judges inour blind Negroni Sbagliato tastingfound the drink the most beguiling of the 10, with endless layers of piquant, spicy, herbal and savory flavors.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Dolin Red
instructions: 1. Combine first three ingredients in a wine glass.
2. Fill glass with ice.
3. Add sparkling water and prosecco.
4. Stir once or twice very gently to integrate, so as not to dissipate the bubbles.
5. Garnish with an orange slice.

title: Kagano
intro_philosophy: An homage to his grandmother’s cocktail bar, Kagano, which Christian Suzuki aims to re-open in the U.S., this rich, stirred drink blends aged rum with Scotch and banana liqueur. A measure of Japanese plum wine, known as umeshu, ties the drink together and harkens back to Suzuki’s youth: “My grandma used to put it in milk and give it to me as a child,” he recalls.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged Puerto Rican rum, preferably Bacardi 8
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Express an orange peel over the surface of the drink, then discard the peel
4. Garnish with an edible orchid and banana leaf.

title: Pineapple Express
intro_philosophy: Caitlin Patterson’s Pineapple Express gets a double-dose of amaro, calling on both Averna and Cynar. She equal measures of both to a rosemary-infused mezcal base and incorporates her tropical flair by way of fresh pineapple and lime juices. “The Averna and Cynar… really bring something to the table to round out the drink and keep it from becoming overly sweet,” she says.
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing tin filled with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over one large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

title: Stygian Mojito
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, except soda, to a mixing tin.
2. Add ice, and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda and garnish with mint.

title: Garibaldi Granita
intro_philosophy: One of the simplestgranita recipes, the Garibaldi Granita combines the aperitivo’s expected orange juice and Campari with an ounce of vodka in order to raise the proof and achieve the right slushy texture. According to creator Jelani Johnson, this simple granita is “my biggest slam dunk.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an 8- or 16-ounce deli container and stir to combine.
2. Cover with a lid and freeze overnight.
3. After 24 hours, use a fork to scrape and whip the mixture until it reaches a slushy texture.
4. Serve in a chilled glass with an orange slice.

title: Garden View
intro_philosophy: Julia Momose’s Garden View is a wintery take on Fields of Green, a non-alcoholic menu staple at Kumiko, her Chicago cocktail bar. Inspired by theengawa, an outdoor hallway in Japanese homes that runs between garden and kitchen, Momose, who was born and raised in Japan, says that the drink has a “sunny red profile” lent by the spiced shichimi-lemon syrup, which pairs with the green flavors of Seedlip Garden 108 and the subtle shades of passion fruit from sencha tea. Like pulling back the curtain onyukimi shoji(windows in Japanese architecture built specifically to view snow), Momose’s drink evokes coziness: “It has a deep hay quality and warming tones—all very comforting.”
ingredients: ½ ounce  shichimi-lemon syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Steep tea for 1 and a half minutes. While steeping, measure shichimi-lemon syrup and Seedlip Garden 108 into a pre-warmed mug or tea cup.
2. Strain the freshly steeped green tea over the mixture and serve. This can also be prebatched and stored chilled, and sipped from a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Enigma de Muerte
intro_philosophy: At San Francisco’s False Idol, lead bartender Anthony Schmidt pairs passion fruit andmaraschinowith high-octane tequila in this morbidly baptized frozen drink. With a sidecar shot of mezcal and a plastic eyeball garnish, the drink is evocative of the tiki bar’s whole “impending danger and peril” mood.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  high proof blanco tequila, preferably Siemba Valles High Proof
1 1/2 ounces passion fruit syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce mezcal, preferably Vago reserved in a shot glass as an accompaniment
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the mezcal in a drink tin.
2. Add the pebble ice.
3. Using a drink mixer on medium speed setting, mix for 2 to 4 seconds.
4. Empty contents into a 14 1/2-ounce double rocks glass.
5. Serve the drink along with the shot of mezcal and instruct guests to sip the mezcal and follow with a taste of the cocktail.

title: The Grasshopper Lies Heavy
intro_philosophy: “While working on the drink, I couldn’t help but think of the Grasshopper,” says Kinsey. “At that point, it was tweaking spirit ratios to still keep the cocktail a Brandy Alexander, but with just the right amount of mint flavor in there for an added snap.” Kinsey thinks the shaken version of his drink has a “refined, shirt-and-tie holiday party feel to it,” but isn’t against letting loose and tossing it in a blender with ice or even a scoop of ice cream, to fully lean into the milkshake possibilities of this cocktail. “It’s been a long year,” he says, “and it’s the holiday season, so treat yourself.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mint liqueur, preferably Giffard Menthe-Pastille
1/2 ounce Crème de Cacao, preferably Giffard
3/4 ounce oat milk, preferably Oatly Full Fat Oatmilk
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker and dry shake without ice to incorporate the ingredients.
2. Add ice and continue shaking until chilled.
3. Fine-strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with shavings from an Abuelita hot chocolate disc

title: Best of Both Worlds, Pt. 2
intro_philosophy: A shandy in a punch bowl, the Best of Both Worlds, Pt. 2 isTeardrop Lounge‘s rum-infused ode to summer. Without the addition of Miller High Life, the drink would be a semi-tropical marriage of golden rum with lime and sweet-tart raspberry gomme (a raspberry syrup), but the beer topper turns the drink into a marriage of high-low, which is just Portland, Oregon’s drinking style.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, except High Life, to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake with a few ice cubes.
3. Strain over crushed ice into a punch bowl.
4. Pour High Life bottles over top (be sure to wedge bottles in the ice, inverted when serving).
5. Garnish with a mint bouquet.

title: Good Enough Gatsby
intro_philosophy:
In the style of Trader Vic, Sean Quinn demonstrates whiskey’s ability to be just as much of a summer go-to as it is a winter standby. The spiciness of rye is backed up by cinnamon syrup, while unaged pear eau de vie and pineapple juice bring a brightness that keeps the drink in balance. To round out the cocktail, Quinn calls on a teaspoon of Fernet Branca for a bracing, cooling flourish.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce pear eau de vie, preferably Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
3. Strain into a large rocks glass filled with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with pineapple fronds and grated cinnamon.

title: Trou Normand
intro_philosophy: At the French bistro Le Veau d’Or, Sarah Morrissey serves this spin on the French tradition of Trou Normand, or “Norman hole.” Typically consisting of a chilled shot of the French apple brandy Calvados—or sometimes Calvados-soaked apple sorbet—the tradition is designed to make space, or a “hole,” for more courses, toeing the line between excessive and epicurean. Morrissey opts, instead, for blanche Armagnac, an unaged grape spirit—kept in the freezer for a rich texture—in place of Calvados, paired with fresh-pressed Granny Smith apple juice.
ingredients: 1 ounce Granny Smith apple juice (pressed just before serving, otherwise the juice will brown)
1 ounce blanche Armagnac, such as Pellehaut, kept in the freezer
instructions: 1. Combine the ingredients in a shot glass and serve.

title: Hi Falutin’
intro_philosophy: Tooker Alley’s Del Pedro likens Swedish punsch to a less herbal, more spice-forward kind of Chartreuse, noting that his Hi Falutin’ takes a full ounce of the stuff, stirred together with whiskey and Byrrh.
instructions: 1. Combine whiskey, punsch and Byrrh in a mixing glass.
2. Express each lemon peel into the drink and drop them into the glass.
3. Stir drink over cracked ice, strain into a rocks glass and serve.

title: Keystone Highball
intro_philosophy: “This cocktail is like the keystone in a bridge,” explains Julia Momose, who likens an evening of drinking to a bridge spanning from the aperitif to the nightcap, with the keystone falling right in the middle, with dinner. Like any thoughtful pairing, Momose’s take on the dinner cocktail can be adjusted to suit the meal at hand: “When it comes to the garnish, this should never be an afterthought…rosemary, mint, thyme, oxalis, lavender…all of these may be beautiful accents to a special meal,” she says.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably Rieger's Kansas City
4 ounces soda water, plus more to top
instructions: 1. Fill a highball or Collins glass two-thirds full with ice.
2. Stir to chill the glass, then drain off any water.
3. Pour the tea, St-Germain and whiskey into the glass and stir gently to combine.
4. Pour soda water down the side of the glass so as to retain carbonation.
5. Add ice and top with a final splash of soda water.
6. Express the lemon peel, then discard.
7. Garnish with fresh bay leaf.

title: Sitting Pretty
intro_philosophy: Demi Natoli’s Sitting Pretty is a tropical highball, bursting with bright citrus flavor from Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit soda along with fresh lime, mint and coconut. Natoli thinks of it as a Mojito meets a Paloma by way of a Saoco, a Cuban cocktail made with local rum, lime, ice, sugar and coconut water. You want a coconut water with around 20 grams of sugar per serving, like Iberia or Goya, both of which can be found in the Hispanic products section of most grocery stores.
instructions: 1. In the bottom half of a mixing tin, add the mint and simple syrup and muddle to combine.
2. Add rum, coconut water and lime. Fill with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Add the grapefruit soda to a Collins glass and fill the glass with fresh ice.
4. Strain the contents of the shaker into the glass and give it a quick stir.
5. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Oxford Comma
intro_philosophy:
When searching for a gin cocktail to round out Brooklyn cocktail barDram’smenu, Jeremy Oertel looked to one of his favorite drinks from the New York tequila bar,Mayahuel. “I wanted to find a way to combine the flavors of a shaken cocktail—called the Loop Tonic—into a stirred cocktail,” says Oertel. “I like the way that celery and green Chartreuse go together, so I maintained those flavors and added maraschino for hint of sweetness.”

He didn’t have a name for it, so he turned it over to Dram’s owner Tom Chadwick who went back to his office to print menus. “My guess is, Tom was probably listing the ingredients and used an oxford comma to separate the final components. He’s a funny guy like that,” he says. “He definitely didn’t name it for the Vampire Weekend song.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Rattlesnake
intro_philosophy: “In all honesty, I don’t drink cocktails often, am not a huge fan of egg whites in my drinks, and am not a lover of absinthe,” says cocktail expert Natasha David. Yet, she says, the frothy, absinthe-spiked Rattlesnake is unexpectedly balanced. As David puts it: “It just goes to show that ingredients in the right proportions create harmony, even if they aren’t always up your alley.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry shake, without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Fine-strain into a coupe glass.
4. Garnish with an Angostura bitters swirl.

title: Gaz Regan’s Negroni
intro_philosophy: Gaz Regan’s “Ultimate Negroni” recipe, which he submitted for our tasting ofmore than 20 takes on the cocktail, calls for Jägermeister used in place of Campari.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: BB Highball
intro_philosophy: “It’s a Bitters & Soda, basically,” says Jon Mullen of his BB Highball, a drink that he created during his time helming the bar program at Mettā. To a Braulio base, he adds a full teaspoon of Angostura bitters as well as dehydrated citrus juice—what he calls “citrus caramel”—for acidity in place of fresh lemon. It’s a prime example of the ways in which Mullen collaborates with the kitchen to repurpose ingredients that would otherwise be wasted. A soda water topper adds carbonation to the highball, which channels all the complexity and flavors of the Italian Alps.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces navy strength gin, preferably Perry's Tot
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with mint, purple shisho and lemon zest.

title: Mango-Ango-Lambro
intro_philosophy: The drink world’s frozen wine fixation might’ve started withfrosé, but that’s not to say it can’t expand to other corners of thewine rainbow. Here, Claire Sprouse calls on Lambrusco in her Mango-Ango-Lambro, a low-proof interpretation of a New Orleans-style frozen mango Daiquiri.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Elote Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Leanne Favredescribes her Elote Cobbler as “savory and indulgent,” an apt description for a drink that is spirit-forward and richly textured. A base of corn-forward bourbon is complemented by the baking spice and earthy notes of reposado tequila, paired with unsalted oat milk, orgeat and a splash of lemon juice. The signature savory element comes courtesy of a salted corn syrup that lends body to the finished drink.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces salted corn syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a beer glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a corn husk leaf.

title: El Presidente 2.0
intro_philosophy: Served on tap at New York’s Dante, this riff improves on the rum-vermouth-orange liqueur classic with a sumac tincture that both echoes the grenadine’s tart, earthy flavors and recalls the pomegranate’s connection to the Middle East.
ingredients: 1 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi
1/2 ounce Pierre Ferrand dry orange Curacao
1 teaspoon house grenadine (see recipe for Dante's grenadine )
instructions: 1. Fill a mixing glass with ice and add all ingredients.
2. Stir until very well chilled.
3. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Donna Brutta
intro_philosophy: This super-simple, low-proof punch from Barnacle in Seattle is built on a base of amontillado sherry with the added fall flavors of cranberry liqueur, spicyByrrhand a splash of soda.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce cranberry liqueur, preferably Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Build in a collins glass over ice and garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Twilight Treasure Fizz
intro_philosophy: Austin bartender Caer Maiko Ferguson’s agave-centric take on a classic New York Sour, the Twilight Treasure Fizz, features a mulled wine syrup that finds a second use for that two-day-old bottle of red. “The great thing about mulling wine is the variety of spices you can use,” says Ferguson. “This particular mix is inspired by the ingredients in many of the delicious mole sauces I’ve tried when visiting Mexico.” Ferguson combines the sweet and spice of the mole-inspired wine syrup with the savory vanilla notes of El Tesoro™Reposado Tequila in this avant-garde take on mulled wine.
ingredients: 3/4 part Mulled Mole Wine Syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add 1/4 part of Mulled Mole Wine Syrup to the bottom of a chilled Collins glass.
2. Add the El Tesoro™ Reposado Tequila, lemon juice, egg white and the remaining 1/2 part of the Mulled Mole Wine Syrup to a cocktail shaker.
3. Dry shake without ice to combine the ingredients. After dry shaking, fill your shaker with ice and short shake to slightly chill without diluting.
4. Slowly strain into the chilled Collins glass over ice, and top with soda water.
5. Express and discard the oils of one orange peel and garnish with chocolate shavings.
6. Serve with a reusable straw.

title: Quando e Dove
intro_philosophy: Named for the Italian phrase that means “when and where,” Lauren Corriveau’s Quando e Dove conjures up the dreamy experience that a spritz so often provides. “Just say the time and place, and I’ll be there,” says Corriveau. “There’s something so romantic about a spritz. I always like thinking of it as a great escape.” The recipe is a mashup between a classic spritz and a Collins, using lemon to highlight the bright citrus profile of L’Aperitivo Nonino, and saline fino sherry to bring out its subtle vegetal notes.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  fino sherry  (preferably Lustau Fino Jarana)
1/4 ounce  Rothman & Winter Orchard Apricot liqueur
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except club soda to a mixing glass over ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a wine glass over ice, and top with club soda.
3. Garnish with a thyme sprig, lemon wheel and Castelvetrano olive.

title: Dope Ass Midori Sour
intro_philosophy: “The Midori Sour and the Lychee Martini are probably the only ‘Asian’ drinks the average consumer can think of,” saysCaer Maiko, adding, “We have to acknowledge the history we are coming from, but we wanted to elevate the experience and flavors.” She achieves this by leaning on fresh melon and cucumber purée alongside gin, Midori melon liqueur and, to boost the traditional Asian flavors, a barspoon of baijiu and a few dashes of yuzu extract.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with crushed ice.
2. Pour into a Chinese-style to-go box.
3. Top with more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a paper straw and maraschino cherry.

title: Bergamot Sour
intro_philosophy: Created for a customer who was on his way to a sushi dinner and wanted something Japanese to prime his palate, Toby Cecchini’s Bergamot Sour is essentially a gin sour with housemade bergamot cordial and fresh ginger syrup deployed as sweeteners, all garnished, appropriately, with a shiso leaf.
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients and shake.
2. Strain into a rocks glass and garnish with a grapefruit twist and a shiso leaf.

title: Chile Fino Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy:
Sotol is like the grown-up sibling of tequila and mezcal: the two morerowdy distilled spirits from Mexico.Añejomeans “aged,” and Añejo Sotolis matured in French oak barrels for two years. There’s a distinct familyresemblance between tequila and sotol—they both have a gentle, fruitysweetness—but the sotol is a bit more gentle and nuanced than themore lip-smacking tequila can be. The sotol needs infusing for at least24 hours to get the heat of the chile.

With thanks to Georgie Thorp forcreating this.

Reprinted with permission fromNOPI: The Cookbookby Yotam Ottolenghi and Ramael Scully, copyright © 2015. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounce chile-infused Añejo Sotol (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Fill up a mixing glass with ice cubes and add all the ingredients, apart from the julienned lemon zest and chile.
2. Stir for about 30 seconds, then strain through a Hawthorne strainer into two rocks glasses filled with ice.
3. Garnish with the lemon zest and chile and serve at once.

title: Margarita Verde
intro_philosophy: In her aptly-named Margarita Verde, Stacey Swenson turbo-charges the grassy notes of blanco tequila with a house-made “garden cordial.” Consisting of fresh green bell pepper, snap peas, parsley, celery and agave nectar, it brightens the classic sour formula while a touch of salt draws out extra nuance. “It still feels like a cocktail not a smoothie,” assures Swenson.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces tequila, preferably El Tesoro Blanco
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel and parsley sprig.

title: The Lonesome Hero
intro_philosophy: More than just a digestif, Becherovka acts as a bridge ingredient in this drink. The herbal notes complement the spicy characteristic of rye whiskey while the ginger and cinnamon notes of the liqueur are bolstered by bright notes of cherry.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rye whiskey, preferably Ragtime Rye
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Bill Brooks’ Godfather
intro_philosophy: The drinks menu at The Cannibal Liquor House changes frequently, but there’s usually an updated “disco drink” lurking somewhere along theHarvey Wallbangermainstay. This revival of the classic Godfather keeps the Scotch component intake, but keeps the drink from becoming too sweet by tempering the amaretto with sherry and a bitter hint of amaro. A sprinkle of bee pollen on the top reads almost like crumbly brown sugar and adds textural interest; it can be omitted if preferred.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Monkey Shoulder
1/4 ounce palo cortado sherry, preferably Lustau
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an orange peel and a sprinkle of bee pollen.

title: Black Scottish Cyclops
intro_philosophy:
Sometimes coming up with a name for an original cocktail is a challenge, and other times it just comes to you when you’re watching a YouTube clip from the multiplayer game Team Fortress 2 and you encounter the character Tavish “The Demoman” Degroot, who calls himself “a black Scottish cyclops.” That’s what happened to my bartending friend Rocky Yeh. Amused, Rocky thought that this character deserved a drink. Rocky describes the Black Scottish Cyclops thus: “The Ramazzotti and bitters add contrasting notes to the peat and roundness without really making it any less of an in-your-face sort of thing, like the character that it’s named for.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
ingredients: 4 dashes Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel–Aged Bitters
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir well.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over two ice cubes.

title: Piedra
intro_philosophy: ThePiedragained traction in Mexico in the mid-19th century. Popularized in cantinas, the mix of fernet, anis and tequila is seen as a hangover cure. It’s often made withFernet-Vallet, a Mexican amaro that’s less viscous and minty than Fernet-Branca, which lends a pronounced cardamom note to the cocktail.
ingredients: 1 ounce anise liqueur (aka anis or anisette)
instructions: 1. In a Cognac glass, combine all three spirits, then swirl to mix until homogenous.
2. Serve with a glass of water with ice, as a back.

title: White Monkey
intro_philosophy: When inventing the White Monkey, bartender Tom Richter began by thinking about the grape-forward pisco base. “I cook a lot of white gazpacho, which includes fresh grapes, almonds and milk,” he says. Beginning with the same sort of structure, Richter added almond-based orgeat and milk to his grape-based spirit. He then balanced it with the brightness of citrus and dry vermouth for a nutty, foamy cocktail with an funky cereal-like aroma.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Kopiko Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: Taking its name from the Indonesian coffee candy Kopiko, this spin on the Espresso Martini, from one of ourBest New Bars of 2024, gets a boost in richness from a small measure ofFrangelico, a hazelnut-flavored liqueur.Cobra’siteration also triples down on the coffee flavor, using both espresso and cold-brew concentrate, plus Kahlúa coffee liqueur to deliver the requisite coffee flavor.
ingredients: heavy 1/4 ounce rich turbinado syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a vegan wafer.

title: Sugar Rim
intro_philosophy: A sugar-crusted rim is essential to the Crusta family of cocktails and a necessary accoutrement of the classic Cognac-basedSidecar. The key to a beautifully structured sugar rim is prepping glassware well ahead of cocktail hour.
ingredients: 1 lemon or orange (depending on  the desired flavor)
instructions: 1. Pour sugar onto a small plate.
2. To cut a wheel of citrus, cut a lemon or orange in half horizontally (not from pole to pole, but right down the middle).
3. Cut a 1/4 inch wheel from one half of the cut piece of citrus, and then halve to create a half-wheel.
4. Holding a coupe or rocks glass upside down to avoid juice running down the glass, run the citrus slice carefully around half of the glass's outside rim to moisten.
5. Instead of dropping the the glass straight into the sugar, press the moistened outside rim into the plate of sugar.
6. Gently shake off any excess.
7. Let harden at room temperature, and when set, place in the freezer to chill until cocktail hour.

title: Moloko Plus
intro_philosophy: In Anthony Burgess’s 1962 novel (and Stanley Kubrick’s 1971 film),A Clockwork Orange,the Korova Milk Bar dispenses drinks—namely the Moloko Plus—to make one shiver. According the main character, Alex, a glass of Moloko Plus “would sharpen you up and make you ready for a bit of the old ultra-violence.” It’s the illicit additives— vellocet (opiate), sythemesc (mescaline), drencrom (adrenochrome) “or one or two other veshches [drugs]”—that put the “plus” in Moloko Plus. San Francisco bartender Morgan Schick interpreted this creepy cocktail with rum, mezcal (to sharpen one up, presumably) and aromatic cardamom milk.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Del Maguey Crema de Mezcal
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients (except sparkling wine) to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a highball glass.
4. Add 2 ounces chilled sparkling wine.

title: Edge of Seventeen
intro_philosophy: AtCure, there’s always at least one shrub cocktail on the menu, and Alex Anderson is the de facto shrub queen. “At Cane & Table, the first thing they taught me was to make an orange shrub,” recalls Anderson. “From there, the shrubs I could come up with in my head just got more and more insane.” For the Edge of Seventeen, Anderson incorporates a relatively tame shrub consisting of orange and carrot juices, dill vinegar and turmeric. “The turmeric really brought it all together and made it have that earthy kind of quality that I was hoping for.”
instructions: 1. Pour the carrot shrub into a chilled coupe.
2. Top with sparkling wine.

title: Yellow
intro_philosophy: This equal-parts drink appears on the menu at Cravan, a classics-focused cocktail bar in Paris with a penchant for French contributions to the canon. It also appears in owner Franck Audoux’s book,French Moderne, where he explains that the combination of gin, Suze and yellow Chartreuse was a popular mixed drink enjoyed along France’s Côte d’Azur, and takes its name from the color of its star ingredients. Here, Audoux adds another yellow element—lemon juice—to bring the drink into sour territory, for a cocktail that reads like a more-mellow Last Word.
instructions: 1. Combine the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Express the lemon twists over the surface of the drink and discard.

title: Prince
intro_philosophy: A member of theStingerfamily, the Prince is a rye-based version of its more famous cousin that originated at the Waldorf-Astoria before Prohibition. It reads like a cross between a Fancy Whiskey Cocktail from the late 19th century and, because of the unfussy stir-in-the-glass process, a relative of the bachelor drinks of the ’70s, like the Godfather and Rusty Nail.
ingredients: 2 ounces rye, preferably New York Distilling Ragtime Rye
2 teaspoons white crème de menthe, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in an Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Add a large ice cube or sphere and stir briefly.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: James Bolt’s Dirty Martini
intro_philosophy: Tying for second place in our blind dirty Martini tasting, James Bolt’s recipe calls for two types of gin: Four Pillars Olive Leaf gin, which counts olive leaf tea and olive oil among its distinctive botanicals, and a half ounce of navy strength gin. To that combination, Bolt adds dry vermouth, Cerignola olive brine and, to round out the savory notes, two dashes each of saline solution and The Bitter Truth olive bitters. Perhaps more than any other it had a true-to-life olive flavor that Punch editor-in-chief Talia Baiocchi described as “meaty, almost like drinking a Castelvetrano olive.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Four Pillars Olive Leaf Gin
1/2 ounce navy strength gin, preferably Four Pillars
2 dashes The Bitter Truth olive bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir for 12 to 15 seconds.
3. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
4. Garnish with a Cerignola olive.

title: Honeysuckle Julep
intro_philosophy: Georgia’s version of the julep often includes a touch of peach brandy in an ode to the state’s abundant stone fruit. Bartender Damon Boelte borrowed this ingredient for his summery, flower-adorned cocktail using muddled peaches alongside sweet yellow Chartreuse, golden honey syrup and Old Tom Gin. Topped with a flower blossom and a lemon wheel (PUNCH’s own addition), the Honeysuckle Julep is frosty, aromatic drink made for hot afternoons.
instructions: 1. In a julep tin or rocks glass, muddle peaches with honey syrup.
2. Add Chartreuse, Old Tom gin and crushed ice, and stir.
3. Add more crushed ice to mound over top.
4. Garnish with a honeysuckle or other sweet, fragrant flower and a thin slice of lemon.

title: Prima Vera
intro_philosophy: Pink, citrus-forward drinks aren’t solely the dominion of summer. In this amalgam of biting Aperol, tangy hibiscus-infused Pisco and autumnal thyme syrup, Raphael Chavez from Freemans creates a bitter-sour refresher that surpasses seasonal labels and looks damn good, to boot.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce thyme simple syrup (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, add ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with a sprig of thyme.

title: Last Word
intro_philosophy: One of the few surviving Prohibition-era drinks, the Last Word originated at the Detroit Athletic Club, where it was most likely mixed with bathtub gin during America’s dark days of temperance. Ted Saucier, author of 1951 cocktail manualBottoms Up!attributes the invention to vaudeville monologist Frank Fogarty, whose wit often earned him the last laugh. The cocktail was revived in the early aughts when bartender Murray Stenson, formerly of Seattle’sZig Zag Café, came across the recipe while researching old bar manuals. It quickly became a staple at the Zig Zag and a beloved revival within the cocktail world.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s Mint Julep
intro_philosophy: Jeffrey Morgenthalerfavors simplicity, of both ingredients and execution, in his julep recipe. Morgenthaler’s rendition, which took first place in our recent blind tasting, calls on ten muddled mint leaves, rich simple syrup and Woodford Reserve bourbon. The judges found the drink perfectly balanced with one taster deeming it highly “re-orderable.”
instructions: 1. Muddle mint leaves and simple syrup in a julep cup.
2. Add bourbon and stir.
3. Add crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet.

title: Ce Soir
intro_philosophy: A mix of two ounces of Cognac, with touches of yellow Chartreuse and Cynar, and two types of bitters, Nicole Lebedevitch’s Ce Soir is simple, potent and elegant—and, according to Robert Simonson, who chose it as one of his top cocktails of 2017, it deserves to be better-known.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Express the lemon peel and discard.

title: Leanne Favre’s Oaxaca Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: In her take on the modern classic, Leanne Favre hews closely to Phil Ward’s original recipe, simply splitting the tequila quotient between two brands and adding a dash each of mole bitters and saline solution. At ablind tasting of Oaxaca Old-Fashioneds, Ward complemented the drink as “the best representation of the original.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces reposado tequila, preferably equal parts Siete Leguas and Calle 23
3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Chichicapa
scant teaspoon amber blue agave nectar
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Express oil from an orange twist over the drink, then flame the twist and use to garnish.

title: Belvoir Boulevard
intro_philosophy: Pamela Wiznitzer loves low-proof, easy-drinking cocktails and anything with Campari. In an elongated riff on theNegroni(named for a street in her hometown of Cleveland, Ohio), she swaps gin for vodka, ups the vermouth with Martini & Rossi Ambrato and reduces the dose of the classic red bitter liqueur. A few drops of brisk saline solution bring everything together, while bubbles render it Sbagliato-esque.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, apart from the sparkling wine, in a Collins glass over crushed ice.
2. Top with sparkling wine.
3. Garnish with orange slices.

title: Yazoo Street Scandal
intro_philosophy: In the Yazoo Street Scandal, Damon Boelte adds strength and richness with a hit of bourbon and a dose of both hibiscus and ginger syrups. With the addition of black tea, this drink is aspringtime take on the Collins that “tastes like a cross between the best sweet tea you’ve ever had and a high-rollingMojito.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce hibiscus syrup (1 tea bag steeped with a cup of 1:1 simple syrup)
instructions: 1. Muddle the mint in a Collins glass and add in all remaining ingredients, save for the bitters.
2. Fill the glass with crushed ice and swizzle.
3. Top with the bitters and garnish with a mint sprig and a lemon wheel.

title: The Seamstress
intro_philosophy: Abigail Gullo’s dark, stirred Seamstress cocktail gets a lift from sparkling wine and bright, citrusy L’Aperitivo Nonino, whose botanical flavors balance the rich, spicy notes of Armagnac. The yin to L’Aperitivo’s yang, Amaro Nonino lends a rounded, honeyed quality. The Seamstress takes its inspiration from the employees of Seattle madame Lou Graham, whose brothel workers’ occupations were listed officially as “seamstresses.”
instructions: 1. Add first four ingredients to a mixing glass over ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe, top with sparkling wine, and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Florodora
intro_philosophy: This classic is an homage to the “Florodora Sextette,” six scandalously beautiful young ladies who danced in the 1900 musicalFlorodoraat New York’s Casino Theater. Just like the dancers who went on to marry millionaires—as David Wondrich recounts inImbibe!—the Florodora cocktail swerves beautifully in pink thanks to a mess of muddled raspberries swirled with lime, gin and ginger soda. It was most definitely drunk by the well-heeled crowds who sidled up to its likely barroom of origin, the Waldorf-Astoria.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle raspberries with simple syrup.
2. Add lime juice, gin and ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a Collins glass over ice.
4. Garnish with an orange wheel, lime wheel and a raspberry.

title: (Lou’s) Army Navy
intro_philosophy: The Army Navy, also known as the Army & Navy, dates to at least the 1930s. A cousin of contemporary orgeat sours like theCameron’s Kickand Coo-ee Special, it’s evidence of an orgeat boom that predates tropical drinks like the Mai Tai. At Dutch Kills, the house Army & Navy spec honors longtime regular and retired FDNY firefighter Lou, who prefers hers with a cocktail cherry sunk to the bottom of the coupe and Angostura bitters dashed on top.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Sink a cocktail cherry to the bottom and float the bitters on top.

title: Tigre’s Airmail
intro_philosophy: At New York’s Tigre, bar director William Elliott pays tribute to the 1930s classic, but brings it both deeper into the tropical realm by layering different rum expressions, and firmly into the celebratory royale canon by using a flute, rather than the traditional highball glass. Below, we’ve included both a single-serving spec and one scaled up for entertaining. Simply batch the base and top it with Champagne to order.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce agricole rum, preferably Rhum J.M Terroir Volcanique agricole rum
1/2 ounce aged rum, preferably Santa Teresa 1796 rum
1/2 ounce lightly aged rum, preferably Probitas rum
scant 1/2 ounce cane syrup (1:1, cane sugar to water)
1/8 ounce (3/4 teaspoon) lime cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except the Champagne to a tin.
2. Add ice, and shake until chilled.
3. Fine-strain into a chilled flute, and top with Champagne.
4. Express a lime peel over the top, and discard.

title: The Vacation
intro_philosophy: This recipe appears in the bookMinimalist Tiki, by Matt Pietrek and Carrie Smith. One of the first drinks workshopped for the tiki bar before it opened in January 2019, Parks accents this tropical drink with a dash of housemade vanilla Angostura, which helps “connect all those flavors and make them one new flavor.”
ingredients: 1 ounce lightly aged or filtered rum, preferably Real McCoy 3
1 ounce unaged agricole rum, preferably Rhum J.M Blanc
1/4 ounce falernum, preferably John D Taylor’s Velvet Falernum
1 dash vanilla-Infused Angostura bitters (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin andflash blendor shake with crushed ice.
2. Pour into a squall or hurricane glass, then top with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with pineapple fronds, orchid and a paper umbrella.

title: Gallery Gimlet
intro_philosophy:
I created the Gallery Gimlet for the new Gallery Bars onboard Holland America Line ships. Founded in 1872, Holland America today is owned by Carnival Corporation. They remain the “adult” cruising brand, focused on fine food and drink served in elegant surroundings.

Reprinted with permission fromThe New Craft of the Cocktailby Dale DeGroff, copyright © 2020. Photo by Daniel Krieger © 2020. Published by Clarkson Potter, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Frost the rim of the glass with black Hawaiian sea salt and chill.
2. Assemble all the remaining ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake well.
3. Strain into the salted and chilled cocktail glass and garnish with the lime wheel.

title: Pink Peppercorn Cane Syrup
intro_philosophy: Lost Lake bartenderVince Brightinfuses them in syrup, as seen in thePequeño Boxing Club. Here, the pink peppercorn’s kick builds upon a more obviously spiced poblano-infused tequila in thisTi’ Punchvariation. “The pink peppercorn enhances the poblano, which is contrasted with the smoke of the mezcal,” he mentions. “The layers all circulate.” Given its fruit-forward characteristics, pink peppercorn syrups are highly versatile—making appearances alongside similarly herbaceous ingredients like ginger and citrus. Enter aperitivo drinks such as the Bar Pisellino’s grapefruit-heavySpumonior Dan Sabo’s modern, Aperol-adjusted take on theMoscow Mule.
instructions: 1. Combine the water and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat and stir until sugar has dissolved. Remove from heat, add the pink peppercorns and let sit for 30 minutes. Strain into a sealable container and refrigerate until ready to use. Will keep up to one month.

title: Roman Holiday
intro_philosophy: This Jungle Bird omits rum altogether, putting the focus on amari as well as cold-brew coffee. Says Spirit Guide (yep, that’s her title) Nandini Khaund, “In designing a menu for a hotel filled with travelers, escapism and wanderlust is always an inspiration. This riff on the Jungle Bird would ideally be drunk in the afternoon on the Italian Riviera, but looking out towards Chicago’s lakefront in the sun feels pretty good, too.”
ingredients: 1 ounce cold-brew coffee, such as La Colombe Pure Black
1/4 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. In a shaking tin, combine all ingredients and shake with ice.
2. Strain onto a mound of crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a cinnamon stick inserted between the ice and side of the glass.

title: Mai Tai
intro_philosophy: The credit for this iconic 1940s drink—whose name is a nod to the Tahitian, “Maita’i,” which means “good”—is usually given to venerable Los Angeles tiki bar Trader Vic’s. Buoyed by the rise of tiki culture and some big celebrity endorsements (think Elvis inBlue Hawaii), this rum-based umbrella drink became cemented in the public imagination as a tropical must-have. The classic components of tiki are all here: lots of rum, a citrus component and a hint of exotica via the addition of orgeat, a syrup made from almonds. But don’t look to this drink for kitsch factor alone: when done up right—no orange juice or syrupy prefab Mai Tai mix—this is one of the greats. This version—a recipe interpreted by tiki bartender Brian Miller—is based on Trader Vic’s 1944 original. (It’s pictured in a Mai Tai glass from Alan Smart’s Los Angeles home tiki bar, HaleKahiki.)
ingredients: 1/2 ounce white rum, agricole (preferably Neisson L’Esprit rhum)
1/2 ounce gold rum (preferably Hamilton Jamaican gold)
1/2 ounce aged rum (preferably El Dorado 15 year)
1/2 ounce aged rum (preferably Appleton 12yr rum or Plantation Jamaica 2001)
1/2 ounce Clement Creole Shrubb (or an orange curaçao like Pierre Ferrand Dry Curaçao)
3/4 ounce orgeat (preferably Orgeat Works or Small Hand Foods)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over crushed ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an umbrella, a lime wheel or spent lime shell and a sprig of mint (optional).

title: Hearty Handshake
intro_philosophy: A Manhattan with the fireside appeal turned up to 11, Jack Schramm’s Hearty Handshake sees the traditional rye and sweet vermouth combo kicked up with an easy-to-make treacle flavored with cold brew concentrate and chai. A few dashes of absinthe counterbalances the sweetness. Serve up in a coupe with an orange twist.
ingredients: 5 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
1 1/4 ounce Chai Coffee Treacle (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a sealable 750ml bottle and store in the freezer.
2. When ready to serve, pour into a chilled coupe and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Cortado
intro_philosophy:
On Portugal’s Madeira island, “cortado” doesn’t refer to an espresso topped up with hot milk. Rather, in the colder, inland, mountainous parts of the island, it’s a mix of coffee and barley “coffee” sweetened with sugar, cut (“cortado,” in Portuguese) with sweet Madeira wine, and served with a swath of lemon peel.

Barley coffee is known here simply as “cevada” (Portuguese for “barley”) or “café de cevada.” Often, barley is just one component—along with chicory and/or rye and coffee—in something called “mistura Ibérica” (“Iberian mix”). To make a Madeiran-style cortado, barley coffee is mixed with traditional coffee, usually at a ratio of three to one. Cevada is available at Portuguese online retailers such asPortugalia Marketplace(or at Spanish retailers, where it’s known as “café de cebada,” or Italian ones, where it’s called “caffè d’orzo”). Nowadays, barley coffee and its variants are most commonly available in instant form, which will work just fine in this recipe.

Da Silva and other vendors on Madeira use bottles of Madeira wine labeled simply “sweet”; there’s no need to break out the good stuff here.
instructions: 1. Make the coffee: In a French press, combine the barley “coffee,” coffee and 2 cups of water. Steep for 4 minutes and strain into an urn or Thermos. Add the sugar and shake to combine.
2. Make the cortado: In a tumbler or coffee cup, combine 1/2 cup of the coffee mixture with 1 ounce of the sweet Madeira (or to taste).
3. Garnish with a lemon peel and serve hot. Repeat with remaining ingredients.

title: Maverick
intro_philosophy: This drink, by Mike McCollum of Attaboy’s Nashville outpost, is a fresh and herbaceous riff on Sam Ross’Mosquito. They both follow the winning template of four key ingredients in equal proportion—an Attaboy signature move—a spirit, lemon juice, sweetened ginger juice and something bitter. McCollum applies a light touch here, going with Aperol as the bitter element and gin as the base spirit (the Mosquito uses Campari and mezcal, respectively).
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweetened ginger juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain through a tightly gated Hawthorne strainer (or else double-strain) into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with candied ginger.

title: Red Light
intro_philosophy: This ombre drink changes from pink blush to deeper ruby at the bottom of the drink thanks to a “sink” of Campari. This is accomplished by pouring the shaken cocktail over a strategically-placed ice cube so the liquid cascades like a fountain, settling gently over the red bitter.
ingredients: 1 ounce lightly aged rum, preferably Flor de Caña 4 year
1/4 ounce falernum, preferably John D. Taylor's Velvet Falernum
instructions: 1. Pour the Campari into a double rocks glass then add a 2-inch ice cube.
2. Combine the remaining ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Slowly strain the cocktail over the ice cube so that it does not disturb the Campari.

title: Rhubarb & Grape
