intro_philosophy: In this pisco-based batched cocktail, Max Venning combines a Chilean pisco with a cordial made from rhubarb and citric acid. “Some things are worth waiting for, and the fermented rhubarb cordial in this recipe is definitely one of them,” says Venning. “Once you’ve stabilized the fermented rhubarb with sugar and citric acid, it’ll last for a few months in the fridge. Meaning you can enjoy that flavor for much longer than just the season,” he explains.
ingredients: 6 ounces fermented rhubarb cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a 30-ounce sterilized bottle.
2. Store in the refrigerator, where it will keep up to 2 months.
3. For an individual drink, pour 3 ounces of bottled pisco-rhubarb cordial into a glass.
4. Top up with soda water.
5. Garnish with a long peel of rhubarb stalk.

title: Mushroom
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to find a method that would recreate some of the yeasty, mushroom-y flavors you get with vintage Champagne,” explains Star of the inspiration for using mushroom dashi syrup as the sweetener in her recipe. A dehydrated, candied mushroom tops off this modern spin on theChampagne cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce huckleberry verjus reduction (see Editor's Note)
3/4 ounce mushroom dashi sugar (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients and chill before serving.
2. When ready to serve, pour the mixture into a flute and top with Champagne.
3. Garnish with a candied mushroom.

title: Gin Sonic
intro_philosophy: TheGin Sonic, a Gin & Tonic in which the tonic water gets cut with soda, was an idea born of necessity in the 1990s. But since then, “the function of ‘Sonic’ has changed,” says Yasuhiro Kawakubo, who runs Bulgari Ginza Bar in Tokyo. “Now we have more tonics, but we have new craft gins too. If you want to showcase the real taste of these gins, Sonic style is best.” To best highlight the spirits, he says, use evenmoresoda, compared to tonic.
instructions: 1. Add gin to a Collins glass with ice.
2. Top with soda water and tonic water.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Blacktail’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy: Second place in our2024 Jungle Bird blind tastingwent to this recipe from Will Pasternak of Blacktail (currently operating as a pop-up in New York’s Backbar at Hotel Eventi). Blackstrap features prominently in this version, with three-quarters of an ounce complemented by a half-ounce each of Appleton 8-year and Smith & Cross Jamaican rum. The drink is otherwise identical toGiuseppe González’s take, with the addition of one dash of Angostura bitters and white sugar in lieu of simple syrup. The judges found it a natural evolution from González’s blackstrap-forward spec, and a drink that only improves as it sits.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Appleton Estate 8 Year Old Reserve Jamaican rum
instructions: 1. Add the juices, sugar and bitters to a tin, then stir briefly until the sugar is dissolved.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and ice, and shake.
3. Fine-strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Cana’s Caju Amigo
intro_philosophy: The Caju Amigo at Cana is more of a tribute tothe Brazilian classicthan an exact replica. “Instead of relying solely on the caju fruit, we drew inspiration from tiki-style layering and created a cashew orgeat,” made with bottled caju juice and roasted cashew nuts, explains co-founder Marko Bogdanovic. Still, the simple idea behind the drink is the same as for its cousin in Brazil. Caju has the power to “naturally lift and enhance the flavor of cachaça,” Bogdanovic says, “as if they were always meant to share the same glass.”
ingredients: 1 ounce prata cachaça, such as Magnífica Prata
1 ounce amburana cachaça, such as Nossa Amburana
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
2. Shake well until thoroughly chilled.
3. Fine strain into a chilled Martini glass.
4. Garnish with a generous dusting of freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Grand Army’s Amaretto Sour
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the Amaretto Sour served at New York’s now-closed NoMad Bar, a small measure of Campari finds its way into the classic served at Brooklyn’s Grand Army. It might sound unorthodox on paper, but the tweak is designed to be almost imperceptible, offering just enough bitterness to cut the inherent sweetness of amaretto.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker and dry-shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass.
4. Express an orange twist over the drink, then discard.

title: The Ace Hotel’s Sangria
intro_philosophy: A traditional sangria, lightened up with crisp rosé and pisco, finds a new balance while maintaining its dangerous chuggability.
instructions: 1. Soak peach and strawberries overnight in rosé, discarding fruit before use.
2. Combine all ingredients in a pitcher and stir.
3. Add ice and fresh slices of peach and strawberry.

title: Baltimore Southside
intro_philosophy: As a bartender and entrepreneur of African American descent, Aaron Joseph sees more than just a drinking tradition in the Southside; he sees the legacy of Black bartenders in Baltimore’s country clubs, namely George Lee and Andrew Ervin. His recipe honors that legacy while mixing in his craft cocktail perspective, yielding a refreshing single-serving punch perfect for hot Baltimore summers.
ingredients: 2 ounces white rum, such as Don Q Cristal or El Dorado 3-year
instructions: 1. Combine the rum, lemon juice, simple syrup and mint in a shaker with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a double rocks glass over 1.25-inch ice cubes.
4. Top with about 1 1/2 ounces of club soda.
5. Garnish with mint and a lemon wheel.

title: Our Swords
intro_philosophy: “I love working with amaro because of the immense variety within the category,” says bartender Dan Sabo, “and how much you can change a drink by subbing a small amount of one amaro for another to create something entirely different.” Named after the Band of Horses song, Our Swords is a bittersweet julep that is built on a base of Cynar. “This drink grew out of my love of the pairing of artichokes and peaches; they’re a delicious duo,” says Sabo. “I built off this like I would a culinary dish, and added some nuttiness with the sherry, some tart sweetness with Cherry Heering and fresh green flavor from mint.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Giffard Crème de Peche de Vigne
instructions: 1. Place mint leaves in a julep cup and lightly muddle to release the oils.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and fill the cup three-quarters of the way with crushed ice.
3. Swizzle the ingredients together with a bar spoon.
4. Top with more crushed ice to create a mound.
5. Garnish with a large mint bouquet and a handful of seasonal berries, such as blueberries, blackberries or raspberries.
6. Finish with a dusting of powdered sugar and serve with a metal straw.

title: Chris Hannah’s Hot Buttered Rum
intro_philosophy: At his NOLA bar, Jewel of the South, Chris Hannah relies on a number of flavored batters to kick upthe bar’s Hot Buttered Rum. Below is his base-base, which can be doctored with everything from cocoa to galangal and hibiscus.
instructions: 1. To a tempered mug, add 2 tablespoons of batter.
2. Top with hot water and stir in the spirit to incorporate.
3. Garnish with a cinnamon stick.

title: El Presidente
intro_philosophy:
Gerardo Machado ruled Cuba from 1925 to 1933, a time when Americans made Havana’s many rum-soaked watering holes their haven away from Prohibition. Though the dictator was nicknamed ”the butcher”—most likely for the missing ring finger on his right hand suffered while working at a butcher shop as a child—the bartender responsible for this Machado-inspired cocktail simply called it, El Presidente. Or so the stories go.

Many tip their hats to Eddie Woelke, an American bartender at the Jockey Club in Havana for the creation of this and the Mary Pickford. However, the drink found popularity upon the repeal of Prohibition at El Chico, a Greenwich Village joint run by Spanish immigrant Benito Collada. Like so many cocktails of that era, the El Presidente fell into obscurity as rum lost its footing in the American spirits market.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with an orange or lemon peel.

title: Harvey Wallbanger Frappé
intro_philosophy: It was only a matter of time before disco drinks got the frappé treatment. InPaul McGee’s Harvey Wallbanger Frappé, the popular 1970s mixture ofvodka, Galliano and orange juice gets a frozen reboot that sees OJ swapped fordry Curaçaowhile a touch of lime juice adds extra acidity.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a blender and blend for 10 seconds on a medium speed.
2. Pour into a coupe and garnish with orange zest.

title: Contraband Picnic
intro_philosophy: Though it’s most often paired with clear spirits, watermelon can play well with brown spirits, too, says Chad Hauge. Here, whiskey, manzanilla sherry and grapefruit juice counter the fruit’s inherent sweetness, resulting in a light, balanced and complex summer cocktail.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces manzanilla sherry, preferably La Guita
instructions: 1. Shake vigorously and double strain into a highball glass over ice.
2. Garnish with fresh, pickled or booze-soaked watermelon.

title: Flannel Shirt
intro_philosophy: Bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler created the Flannel Shirt for an autumnal event. Using classic fall flavors—apple, earth, spice and smoke—he whipped up this fleecy, bone-warming drink with the bold backbone of Scotch and a supporting cast of apple cider, St. Elizabeth Allspice Dram and super-bold Averna. Morgenthaler says, “It reminds me of a hot drink that you’d have on Thanksgiving morning—only served cold.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Pineapple Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: This simple, slightly fruity Daiquiri riff incorporates fresh pineapple juice into the classic build.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Bamboo
intro_philosophy: One of Japan’s originals, the Bamboo was created in the 1890s at the Grand Hotel In Yokohama, Japan by German bartender Louis Eppinger. The hotel was partly owned by a group of Americans in the military stationed in Japan at the time, and, in hopes of bringing a bit of their homeland to the island, they enlisted Eppinger as their man for the job. Having worked in San Francisco around the same time that Jerry Thomas assumed celebrity behind the bar, Eppinger became a fixture at the establishment for a decade and a half until his death, in 1907. According to David Wondrich, the Bamboo traveled quickly across the ocean and, by 1901, was a regular item on menus throughout America, finding enough fame that it was eventually sold in pre-mixed in bottles across the country. The Bamboo is currently enjoying a revival with renewed interest in the category of sherry cocktails. Joaquín Simó’s version adds a small dose of cane syrup to help balance the dryness of the drink and give it a bit more texture.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Banana Hammock
intro_philosophy: This tropics-inspired Margarita from Coral Wig in Baltimore plays up the banana flavor two ways: a four-day infusion of fruit in the tequila, andTempus Fugit Crème de Banane liqueur. Honey syrup provides a touch of sweetness while yuzu juice brightens the entire cocktail. The icing on the cake, though, is two dashes of MSG solution, which gives the Margarita a pleasing roundness and umami notes even as the ice melts. The housemade Himalayan salt rim is optional if you’re making it at home, but it sure looks good on the glass.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane
1/4 ounce rich raw honey syrup (2:1, honey to water)
2 dashes diluted MSG solution (2 parts water to 1 part MSG)
instructions: 1. Rim half the glass with the Himalayan salt blend.
2. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Red Queen
intro_philosophy:
Inspired by a number of early twentieth-century recipes for long drinks that rely on a base of red wine, the Red Queen gets extra fortification from the addition of both bourbon and Amaro Braulio, an alpine amaro that adds a cooling, herbal freshness to the drink. As for the name, it’s a reference to a line in the Jefferson Airplane song “White Rabbit.”

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine the wine, bourbon, lemon juice, simple syrup, and amaro in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice, shake, and strain over crushed ice into a tall collins glass.
3. Garnish with lemon wheels, fresh thyme, sage, and rosemary.

title: Bobby Heugel’s Freezer Martini
intro_philosophy: Top honors in our tasting of freezerMartiniswent toBobby Heugel, the Houston-based cocktail bar owner and a known Martini obsessive. The panel recognized this drink’s classic London-dry profile and embraced it right off. (Heugel has been known to sell this rendition as a 750-milliliter “Bobby’s Martini” at Anvil Bar & Refuge.)
ingredients: 7 1/2 ounces Noilly Prat Extra Dry vermouth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 1-liter bottle.
2. Store the bottle in the freezer for several hours, or overnight.
3. When ready to serve, pour into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Bijou
instructions: 1. Stir the ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and strain into a chilled coupette or cocktail glass.
2. Garnish with the lemon twist and maraschino cherry.

title: Old Flame
intro_philosophy: The immortal Old-Fashioned serves as the spark for the Old Flame, whose modern touch comes in the form of a smoky-sweet grilled pineapple syrup with an accent of herbal absinthe to complement the classic bitters. “The rye spice of Du Nord Mixed Blood Whiskey is accentuated by the blend of absinthe and bitters, creating a bracing backbone,” says Johnson. “The bourbon’s top notes of light smoke, stone fruit and vanilla are rounded out by charred pineapple and brown sugar, making a complex and delicious sipping cocktail.” If you don’t have bar-quality ice molds at home, Johnson recommends filling a deli container with filtered water and then, once frozen, smacking it with a sturdy metal spoon to create uniquely shaped cubes for your favorite cocktail.
ingredients: 2 ounces Du Nord Mixed Blood Whiskey
1 teaspoon  grilled pineapple rich Demerara sugar syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice.
2. Stir until chilled and strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Tall Boxes
intro_philosophy: This was one of the signature drinks of Jim Meehan’sambitious but short-lived Frank Lloyd Wright-inspired Chicago bar. A take on the brandy Old-Fashioned, it leans on superior Sacred Bond, a 100-proof spirit from Kentucky’s Heaven Hill distillery. He muddles and then fine-strains out the orange and cherry “garbage,” creating a silky and deceptively simple drink that bridges the “old” and “new” styles.
ingredients: 2 ounces Christian Brothers Sacred Bond brandy
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, muddle the orange wheel and cherry with the Angostura bitters and simple syrup.
2. Add the brandy and ice, and stir until chilled.
3. Fine strain into a chilled rocks glass over one large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a triangle orange peel and a cherry on a pick.

title: Ibizan Herbal Liqueur (Hierbas Ibicencas)
intro_philosophy: Upward of 20 herbs can go into hierbas ibicencas, Ibiza’s iconic liqueur. Listed below are the standard ones. Add others—lavender, rue, juniper bark—as desired. Use the thin end of a wooden spoon or something similar to push the sprigs, leaves and peels down through the neck of the bottle. A ratio of three parts sweet anisette to one part dry anisette is fairly standard, though adjust to personal taste and the anisette’s sweetness.
ingredients: piece of lemon and/or orange peel
24 ounces (about 750 ml)  sweet anisette, or to taste
8 ounces (about 250 ml)  dry anisette, or to taste
instructions: 1. Sterilize a 1-liter glass bottle. Trim the herbs so that they will fit beneath the neck of the bottle.
2. Feed the herbs into the bottle, using the thin end of a wooden spoon to push them down.

3. Add the sweet anisette to a jug, and blend in the dry anisette to get the desired taste. Use a funnel to pour the mixture into the bottle over the herbs. Cork and label. Store in a dry, cool place for at least 3 months. Serve chilled.

title: Bemelmans’ Vesper
intro_philosophy: The spirit-forward, gin-and-vodka–drenched Vesper was first made famous by Ian Fleming’sCasino Royale, but it is a drink worth of affection in its own right. At Bemelmans Bar in New York City, the classic sees equal parts vodka and gin—plus a splash of Lillet—shaken, not stirred.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake.
2. Pour into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Ojen Piña Colada
intro_philosophy: “Ojen is near and dear to us New Orleaneans,” explains Compère Lapin’s Abigail Gullo, who incorporates the local anise-flavored spirit into her spin on the Piña Colada, which alsofeatures brandy, pimento dram and lemongrass, all blended with tropical staples: pineapple and coconut.
instructions: 1. Put all ingredients in a blender with ice and blend until smooth.
2. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Koji-San
intro_philosophy:
Kenta Goto’s etherealSakura Martiniisunequivocally the most iconic cocktail on the menu at his eponymous bar on New York’s Lower East Side. But while the cherry blossom–inspired drink represents the epitome of elegance, for umami hounds there’s a sleeper hit lying in wait that’s equally deserving of the spotlight:the Koji-San.

The key to the Koji-San’s allure is how two seemingly different spirits—barley-based shochu from Japan and smoke-laced mezcal from Mexico—meet with conviction in the glass, ultimately revealing that even though they don’t share origin stories,their similarities outweigh their differences. Both are earthy, terroir-driven spirits, and whentethered together via the bright, cooling qualities of celery juice (which, incidentally, also ups the savory factor), the result is a refreshing sour bearing multitudes of intrigue.
ingredients: 1 ounce plus 5 teaspoons shochu, preferably Iichiko Saiten
3/4 ounce citrus blend (equal parts lemon and lime juice)
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with a blend of sea salt and dashi powder (use 3 parts sea salt to 2 parts dashi).
2. Add all ingredients except celery juice to a shaker with ice and shake.
3. Strain into the prepared glass over ice.
4. Float celery juice on top.

title: Mamajuana Manhattan
intro_philosophy: At Jalao, a Washington Heights, New York, branch of the iconic Santo Domingo restaurant, housemade mamajuana—a mix of rum, wine, honey and botanicals—stars in the bar’s Mamajuana Manhattan. The making of the mamajuana itself requires steeping a proprietary blend of bark and spices for three months “to eliminate some of the bitterness of the wood,” according to bartender Jordy Castillo. That bitter liquid is disposed of and replaced with a fresh round of ingredients added to a 1-liter bottle, including a touch more honey, wine and white rum that then rests for another three weeks before being put to use in this Manhattan variation, which also calls on a small measure of Frangelico and amaretto to bolster the spiced notes. The seasoned wood can be reused several times, according to Castillo.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Serve in a frosted coupe.
3. Garnish with a cherry.

title: Non-Morto
intro_philosophy: Translating from Italian as “Not Dead,” this Zombie variation gets a bittersweet kick from Campari in place of the usualgrenadine. Absinthe provides a drying hint in lieu of Angostura bitters, which are muted by the Campari.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the prosecco, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a tiki glass over ice.
3. Top with prosecco.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Coconut Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: Building off the simplicity of Dick Bradsell’s originalEspresso Martini, or “Vodka Espresso” as he preferred to call it, this drink relies on only three ingredients: espresso, cane sugar andcoconut rum, which takes the place of the expected vodka. The result is an easy yet decadent spin on the template, with a pronounced tropical edge.
ingredients: 2 ounces coconut rum, preferably Planteray Cut & Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Rye Whiskey Syrup
intro_philosophy:
Equal parts rye and sugar, this strong play on simple syrup is a necessary component of bartender Andrew Bohrer’sBitter Handshake, and a recipe from Brad Thomas Parsons’ book,Bitters.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. In a medium saucepan, bring the sugar and rye to a simmer, stirring occasionally to dissolve the sugar.
2. At the first crack of a boil, remove from the heat.
3. Let cool completely, then store the syrup in a glass jar for up to four months.

title: Jules Rimet
intro_philosophy: While not native to Argentina, Argentines love bittersweet Fernet Branca and drink more of it than any other nation in the world. So popular is the Milanese amaro that there is now a distillery in Buenos Aries. Created by illustrator John Perry Yates for the 2014 World Cup match final between Argentina and Germany, this mano-a-mano recipe is nothing more than a picon-bière in which hearty, chocolatey Doppelbock stands up to Fernet’s bitter kick. “The Jules Rimet Cup” was the name of the original World Cup trophy—it was stolen in Brazil in 1983 and has never been found.
instructions: 1. Add Fernet and beer to a chilled tulip glass or beer mug.
2. Stir gently to combine.

title: Mezcal Sun-Risa
intro_philosophy: At Ghost Donkey, a Mexican-inspired bar in lower Manhattan, head bartender Ignacio “Nacho” Jimenez offers a play on the oft-maligned Tequila Sunrise. His version, built on a split base of tequila and mezcal, is lengthened with bitter orange juice and topped with spicy hibiscus-habanero syrup in place of the more traditional grenadine.
instructions: 1. Combine the tequila, mezcal and bitter orange juice in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Carefully pour the hibiscus-habanero syrup over the top, to float.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Café La Trova’s Banana Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Just two coffee beans in the blender—a technique learned from late bartender John Lermayer—adds balance and a hint of coffee flavor to this banana Daiquiri.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane
instructions: 1. Blend all ingredients with crushed ice for 15 seconds.
2. Pour into an 8 1/2-ounce coupe glass.
3. Serve with two straws.

title: Road Less Traveled
intro_philosophy: The Road Less Traveled is a bittersweet, tangy and herbaceous play on a mule with nonalcoholic amaro. While the flavors of the base spirit, an N/A amaro from Pathfinder, are complex, it’s the syrup that really provides the cocktail with a proper backbone. According to Pink Flamingo bar manager Nick Pikounis, the spiced honey has tons of other applications, too, includingsubbing for agave in a Margarita, or invigorating a white rum punch.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce blood orange–Calabrian chile honey (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake the first three ingredients with cube ice and strain into a rocks glass.
2. Top with ginger beer and garnish with a dehydrated orange half-wheel.

title: Brandy Alexander
intro_philosophy: The Brandy Alexander, also known as the Alexander No. 2 is a mix of equal parts brandy, crème de cacao and cream dusted with freshly grated nutmeg. The first edition, which employs gin as its primary spirit, was born of necessity; Prohibition required a heavy hand in sweet ingredients to conceal poor-quality spirits produced illegally. Eventually the Alexander No. 1 evolved with the taste of the times, and gin was replaced by cognac or brandy.
ingredients: 1 ounce crème de cacao, Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe or a small rocks glass.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Blood and Sanguinello
intro_philosophy: This Blood and Sand riff is named for the Sanguinello, a Sicilian blood orange. Unlike the original cocktail, this version doesn’t include orange juice, but it does showcase Solerno, a blood orange liqueur.
ingredients: 1 ounce Scotch, preferably Glenfiddich 15 Year Old
instructions: 1. Muddle cherries in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add remaining ingredients to the cocktail shaker.
3. Add ice and shake very well.
4. Double strain into a coupe glass
5. Twist the orange peel over the top to express essential oils, then use the peel to garnish.

title: Spice Adams
intro_philosophy: “This drink is pretty weird,” Devin Kennedy admits, noting that it falls somewhere between aCorn ’n’ Oiland aMojito, though it reads like something else entirely. The most abundant ingredient is the falernum, which does double duty as a sweetener and a flavoring agent, bringing a pronounced clove and allspice note to the mixture. An ounce of agricole rum lends a grassy, acidic base note, which is offset by the more confectionary aroma of the pineapple rum that is floated on top of the finished drink. In Kennedy’s candid take, “It’s kind of like a mindfuck.”
ingredients: 1 ounce agricole rhum, preferably Rhum J.M Blanc 100 proof
1 1/4 ounce John D. Taylor's Velvet Falernum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the pineapple rum, in a mixing tin and shake with crushed ice until ice dissolves.
2. Strain into a Collins glass.
3. Use a straw to press the mint down into the bottom of the glass and top with crushed ice.
4. Top with a float of Plantation Pineapple Rum.
5. Garnish with a mint bouquet.

title: London x Tokyo
intro_philosophy: Created for the Bombay Sapphire competition in 2017, thisMartinivariation is inspired by Japanese flavors incorporated with techniques like fat-washing and infusions that might be more at home in the London cocktail scene. “My husband and I took our honeymoon in Japan and just fell in love… we love the food, we love the process of it, we love the delicacy behind it… but they crush beer during their meal,” says Annie Williams Pierce, “I was like ‘Your girl needs a Martini!’” Here, Persian limeolive oil-washedgin is complemented with sugar snap pea-infused blanc vermouth andverjusfor a delicate, vegetal spin on the timeless classic. The resulting vermouth-infused peas act as a bonus snack.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces Persian lime olive oil-washed gin, preferably Bombay Sapphire (see Editor's Note)
1 1/3 ounces  sugar snap pea infused-blanc vermouth, preferably Dolin Blanc
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a few drops of the olive oil saved from the wash.

title: Julep’s Prescription Julep
intro_philosophy: In Julep’s riff on the 19th century Prescription Julep, Armagnac replaces Cognac, for a more rustic flavor, while the herbal spice of Bénédictine complements the rye and brings a savory element to the mix.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a julep cup.
2. Add crushed ice and swirl until frost forms on the cup then top with more ice.
3. Garnish with fresh mint, powdered sugar and a straw.

title: Pink Chihuahua
intro_philosophy: Named for the drink’s pink color, this highball from Sips in Barcelona draws inspiration from both Sherry Cobblers and sangria. The wine, the interplay of citrus and sugar, and lengthener—here a blood orange soda—pays homage to similar components in the classics.
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a highball glass over ice.
2. Garnish with grated lime zest.

title: Bitter Handshake
intro_philosophy:
The Bitter Handshake was the very first drink Andrew Bohrer ever served me. He had been making a name for himself around Seattle as an inventive bartender, and he lived up to his reputation when I met him at Mistral Kitchen, where he used to hold court, and gave me a drink that I still think about often.

While Andrew was experimenting with a Fernet Branca–based cocktail, one of the sous chefs presented him with some reduced blood orange juice to play around with behind the bar. From this, Andrew developed an after-dinner Fernet old-fashioned digestif of sorts, with an ingeniousrye whiskey syrupsubbing in for the standard simple syrup and the rich blood orange reduction serving as an improvement over the muddled oranges from poorly made and overly sweet old-fashioneds. Andrew is fanatical about his ice and he serves this over a hand-carved ice sphere. If you don’t feel like hand carving your own ice sphere and don’t have the right mold, you can swap in a large hunk of ice or a large ice cube. The orange zest wrapped around the ice won’t look as elegant, but the drink will still be delicious.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over an ice sphere.
4. Garnish with the orange zest atop the ice sphere.

title: Griffin Keys’s Boulevardier
intro_philosophy: Second place in our recent Boulevardier blind tasting went to Griffin Keys, of (appropriately enough) the Boulevardier bar in Dallas. He reached for WhistlePig rye and Carpano Antica vermouth, and served the drink up, with an orange twist.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with orange zest.

title: Bon Voyage! Singapore Sling
intro_philosophy: This fall, the team behindTrick Dogwill debut their latest venture, Bon Voyage! Their Singapore Sling is a complex twist on the original, calling on house-made pineapple-ginger soda and “sherry heering”—oloroso infused with a medley of dried herbs and cherries.
ingredients: pineapple ginger soda, to top (see Editor's note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda.
4. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

title: Samson Swizzle
intro_philosophy: While working at Zombie Village, where he created this drink,Sam Millernotes that he gained an appreciation for “the amazing ability to blend flavors through a swizzle.” Here, he takes theQueen’s Park Swizzleas a jumping-off point, but gives it “a tropical vibe” simply by swapping traditional simple syrup with a spiced passionfruit syrup. “It’s a pretty simple switch, but it gave the drink a whole new depth.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Rum Bar Gold
1 ounce Barbados rum, preferably Real McCoy 3 Year
1/3 ounce passion fruit syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a zombie glass, add crushed ice, and swizzle.
2. Garnish with a heavy float of Angostura bitters and a mint bouquet.

title: Be Trippin
intro_philosophy: In this Pendennis riff, Phoenix bartender Jason Asher deploys a pineapple-jacked gin, a rapid infusion technique inspired by historic applejack production that simply requires frozen fruit to come to temperature in the spirit or liqueur of choice.
ingredients: 2 ounces pineapple-jacked gin, preferably St. George Terroir (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Andy Bixby’s Rob Roy
intro_philosophy: In a recent blind tasting of Rob Roys, Andy Bixby’s version tied for second. He called for two ounces of Glenmorangie 10-year, a highland single malt, one ounce of Cocchi di Torino vermouth, two dashes of Regan’s orange bitters and one dash of Angostura bitters. An orange twist was expressed over the surface of the drink and discarded, while a cherry garnish completed the picture. The orange scent and flavor came through strongly in the cocktail (the choice of Glenmorangie, which often offers orange notes on the nose, doubtless helped in this), which the judges found rich, with marzipan notes.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi Di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over 1 cracked cube of ice and 5 whole cubes and stir until chilled.
2. Add “finishing cube” and stir 10 more times.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Express orange peel and discard. Garnish with cherry.

title: Gin and Juice
intro_philosophy: Created for the Tanqueray Gin challenge in the 2018 World Class bartender competition, this recipe employs a blender to create “fluffy” grapefruit juice with ease. The texture also helps intensify the grapefruit aroma and flavor, says Pavel Pamukchiev.
ingredients: 3 ounces improved grapefruit juice (see Editor's Note)
1 ounce gin, preferably Tanqueray No. Ten
instructions: 1. In a blender, pulse the grapefruit juice several times, for a couple of seconds each time.
2. In a chilled highball glass with ice, add the gin and yellow Chartreuse and stir.
3. Top with grapefruit juice and stir to integrate.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit slice.

title: Ryan Maybee’s Sazerac
intro_philosophy: “The Sazerac was the cocktail that opened my eyes to how technique and preparation can really make the difference between a horrible cocktail and a beautiful one,” says Maybee. A self-professed “classicist,” it’s no surprise that the Sazerac is one of the drinks he considers representative of his bartending style.
instructions: 1. Coat the inside of a chilled rocks glass with absinthe, discarding the excess. Set aside.
2. In a separate mixing glass, add the sugar cube, Peychaud’s bitters and splash of soda water.
3. Muddle the mixture into a thick paste.
4. Add the rye to the mixing glass, then add ice.
5. Stir for 30 to 45 seconds until sugar is completely dissolved and the drink is thoroughly chilled.
6. Strain contents from the mixing glass into the rocks glass.
7. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Perá Fortuna
intro_philosophy: Created for a local cocktail competition, the Perá Fortuna builds from a classicGimletstructure, adding spiced pear liqueur, absinthe and celery bitters. “A drink I used to make all the time was a gin, lime, absinthe Collins,” recalls Richard Beltzer of the inspiration. Turning the drink into a shorter format allowed the flavors to stand out in stronger concentration, but the finishing touch came from introducing absinthe back into the equation. “I realized the drink needed more body,” explains Beltzer, “and absinthe is like a cheat code.”
ingredients: 3 dashes celery bitters, preferably Fee Brothers
1/2 ounce pear liqueur, preferably St. George Spiced Pear
1 1/2 ounces London dry gin, preferably London No.3
instructions: 1. Rinse coupe with absinthe and discard.
2. Combine all remaining ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with pear wheel.

title: Sarah Morrissey’s Gin and Tonic
intro_philosophy: Sarah Morrisseytakes a Spanish-style approach to her Gin and Tonic, building the recipe in a Burgundy glass over “lots of ice” and garnishing the mixture of Spanish gin and Fever-Tree tonic with a medley of citrus and juniper berries.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, preferably Xoriguer Gin de Mahon
tonic water, preferably Fever-Tree, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Burgundy glass over plenty of ice.
2. Garnish with spent lime and lemon wedges, a mint sprig, juniper berries, and a grapefruit slice.

title: Après Ski Julep
intro_philosophy: Named after the leisurely lifestyle she imagines to be endemic to the Italian Alps, Stacey Swenson created her Après Ski Julep to spotlight “Braulio’s fresh minty alpine brightness and warming spices.” While many bartenders use amaro as a modifier in cocktails, Swenson prefers to use Braulio in place of the base spirit, swapping in a high-proof bourbon as a modifier. “It’s a way to cut back on the alcohol without sacrificing flavor,” she says. “Amaro was my gateway into my love for spirits and cocktails. It’s so complex, but so comforting and soothing at the same time.” The result is a spirited, cold-weather julep rounded out with a slightly salty, nutty warmth.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce bourbon, such as Wild Turkey 101
instructions: 1. Add the fresh mint leaves and blackberry shrub to a julep cup and gently muddle together.
2. Add the Braulio, bourbon, nocino and saline and fill with crushed or pebble ice.
3. Swizzle with a bar spoon to incorporate ingredients.
4. Top with more ice and garnish with fresh mint and blackberry halves.

title: Kingsland Gimlet
intro_philosophy: A dash of curry bitters adds nuanced spice to the comforting familiarity of watermelon. The drink pays homage to watermelon curry, a traditional dish from northwestern India, and in particular a version once served by the late chef Floyd Cardoz at New York’s Tabla.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce overproof Jamaican rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
1 dash The Bitter End Curry Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Hug-Tight
intro_philosophy: “Sfumato is brooding, smoky, woody, and all things dark,” says Matt Piacentini of Up & Up, New York. “It’s like what would be in an Italian witch’s cauldron. Piacentini’s Hug-Tight is a smoky variation of the Champagne cocktail with equal parts Sfumato and mezcal. The sparkling wine topper “grabs all those aromatics from the amaro and mezcal and brings them up to the surface where they make little aromatic explosions for your nose,” he says.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in chilled rocks glass.
2. Add ice and stir to cool, but not dilute.
3. Top with dry sparkling wine, like a brut or extra brut Champagne or prosecco.
4. Garnish with lime wheel.

title: Suze in Paradise
intro_philosophy:
Tucked in a corner on the rue Paradis is the “headquarters” of the Fédération Française de l’Apéritif (FFA), presided over by cofounder Quentin Chapuis. Theapérobar features food and drinks, everything proudly (and officially) made in France. To prove that point, two long rows of Suze bottles crowd shelves stocked with everything from French whiskey to Macvin du Jura. This fizzy drink is their version of a spritz, sticking to their mission, with French spirits as their base.

And because aperitif always taste better when there’s something to snack on, there are also jars of red pepper-spiked Basque pâté, socca chips from Nice (be careful with these; once you open the bag, you’ll have a hard time not finishing them all), and even driedinsectes pour l’apéritif. These beetle larvae seasoned with garlic andfines herbesmay, indeed, be tasty (the are French after all…), but I’ll stick with the FFA’s well-curated selection of French charcuterie and cheeses,merci.

Reprinted with permission fromDrinking French: The Iconic Cocktails, Aperitifs, and Café Traditions of France, with 100 Recipes, by David Lebovitz, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Ed Anderson.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crème de framboise or crème de cassis
3 ounces freshly squeezed pink grapefruit juice
instructions: 1. Mix the Suze, crème de framboise and grapefruit juice in a large footed goblet or wine glass.
2. Add the tonic water and fill the glass with ice.
3. Stir briefly, and garnish with the citrus twist.

title: Daiquiri Clasico
intro_philosophy: This is Julio Cabrera’s ideal classic Daiquiri, made with white sugar—not simple syrup, which can add a “caramelized” flavor—and shaken to icy (but not overdiluted) perfection. It was a top vote-getter at our2024 Daiquiri tasting.
ingredients: 2 ounces white rum, preferably Planteray 3 Stars
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice for 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a 5 1/2-ounce coupe glass.

title: AJ Johnson’s Gin Rickey
intro_philosophy: Andra “AJ” Johnson created this juicy, aromatic Gin Rickey while consulting for a Mediterranean restaurant. The basil adds a “savory, saline element” to D.C.’s Green Hat Original Batch Gin, while a simple syrup made from Buddha’s hand, basil and makrut lime lends the drink bright, floral and earthy notes. Johnson strays from tradition by giving the cocktail a light shake to incorporate the syrup, which gives the cocktail a silky, yet clean, mouthfeel. You can find dried makrut lime leavesonline, or substitute lemon syrup for the leaves and Buddha’s hand.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, such as Green Hat
club soda, such as Q, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Top with club soda.
4. Garnish with straw, lemon and lime ribbons and fresh basil.

title: Mendo Sidecar
intro_philosophy:
First created during World War I in either London or Paris, this Cognac-based cocktail traditionally had only two other ingredients, Cointreau and lemon juice. I’ve discovered that Germain-Robin XO brandy, made with a high percentage of Pinot Noir grapes, is a fantastic base for a sidecar, but you can also use VSOP Cognac or another well-aged brandy. The maraschino liqueur adds a lovely floral high note. Spraying the drink with orange oil gives you a fresh citrus aroma as you start to take a sip. Most sidecars are served in a sugar-rimmed glass, but I don’t feel that this version needs it.

Reprinted with permission fromArtisanal Cocktailsby Scott Beattie. Copyright (c) 2008 by Scott Beattie. Photo (c) 2008 Sara Remington. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Cosmojito
intro_philosophy: The concept of the cocktail mash-up shows no sign of slowing. In fact, it’s evolved to the point where two discrete genres—tiki and aperitivo—have formed an entirely new mashup entity:aperitiki. It’s into this category that drinks like theWhite Negroni Piña Coladaand theZombie Spritzreside. Adding to the growing canon of cocktail mashups, the bar team at Dante NYC has introduced both the Cosmojito and the Cosmo Spritz to the spring lineup. Here, the Cosmo and Mojito join forces to create a fruity, vibrant drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces orange vodka, preferably Grey Goose L’Orange
sparkling water, preferably San Pellegrino, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a spritz glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with orange wheels and mint sprigs.

title: Blue Hotel
intro_philosophy: This riff on the Pornstar Martini from Tern Club in Knoxville, Tennessee, escorts the modern classic further into tiki territory by fortifying it with Giffard Blue Curaçao and housemade orgeat. At home, store-bought orgeat works, too.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce passion fruit liqueur, preferably Giffard
instructions: 1. Shake ingredients and double-strain into a chilled coupe.
2. Serve with a sidecar of chilled cava.

title: Weathered Axe
intro_philosophy: Though it may seem like a breezy summer cocktail with the inclusion of citrusy Combier and herbal-sweet Cocchi Americano, the Weathered Axe easily transitions into a cold weather drink with the swap of a garnish. This staple at Chicago’sScofflawis traditionally served with a bouquet of fresh, cooling mint and a spritz of absinthe, but come January the evergreen aromatics of rosemary transform the Axe into a savory winter drink.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a bouquet of mint or a sprig of rosemary.

title: Discolo’s Pornstar Martini
intro_philosophy: At Discolo, an ’80s-inspired cocktail club in New York City’s Chelsea neighborhood, beverage director Matthew Reysen takes a high-concept approach to the Pornstar Martini, uniting the bubbles and the cocktail into a single clarified drink. “I wanted to make the drink more about the bubbles and give you a cocktail that was like you were drinking a glass of Champagne, but also tasted like a Pornstar Martini,” says Reysen, who was inspired by London bartender Chris Moore’s signature Champagne Piña Colada, a more sophisticated take on the classic boat drink that includes coconut sorbet and Champagne.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Pornstar Milk Punch (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Build the drink in a flute.
2. To garnish, rest a quarter of a fresh passion fruit atop the flute.

title: Fairbanks Loan No. 2
intro_philosophy: This loose interpretation of the Douglas Fairbanks, a Prohibition-era cocktail poured at Sloppy Joe’s in Havana, is “reminiscent of a Daiquiri on steroids,” says Brian Kane. Originally made with gin, apricot brandy and egg white, the drink is named after the influential silent film actor who became one of Hollywood’s earliest megastars.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Stiggins' Fancy Plantation Pineapple Rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: World’s Best Bonsai Margarita Riff
intro_philosophy: At Truce, co-owner David Mor offers this playful riff on theBonsai Margarita, a drink that likely dates back to the 1980s when it was simply called a Melon Margarita or a Midori Margarita, after its star ingredient. In this version, Midori is swapped out for fresh cantaloupe juice and a French melon liqueur.
ingredients: 2 ounces chamomile and chrysanthemum tea–infused tequila (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce melon liqueur, preferably Aelred’s Melon aperitif
instructions: 1. Line the rim of a rocks glass with salt and set aside.
2. Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared rocks glass over fresh ice and garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Round and Around
intro_philosophy: This spritz variation is “an anytime cocktail,” says Proprietors lead developer  Lauren Corriveau, meaning it’s “appropriate for any season and super sessionable.” While Lillet Blanc provides the wine element, the Jin Jiji provides structure and an herbaceous complexity that helps to ground the apricot and provide a foil for the bitterness of the tonic.
ingredients: 1 ounce  Jin Jiji India Dry Gin
2 teaspoons  apricot marmalade,  preferably Bonne Maman
instructions: 1. Shake first four ingredients with ice.
2. Fine-strain into a wine glass over fresh ice.
3. Top with tonic.
4. Lightly tap the basil bouquet to release fragrance, then insert the bouquet with a lemon peel to garnish.

title: Mahogany Hall Gimlet
intro_philosophy: “I made this one for the Gallery Bars aboard Holland America Line,” recallsDale DeGroff. An otherwise straightforward Gimlet is heightened by a trio of sweeteners in DeGroff’s so-called “triple syrup.”
ingredients: 2 dashes Dale DeGroff’s Pimento Aromatic Bitters
instructions: 1. Shake all the ingredients with ice.
2. Fine strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with lime wheel.

title: Guava Spritz
intro_philosophy: “I wanna make something for the people that just want to drink an Aperol Spritz,” says Paige Walwyn of her Guava Spritz. In lieu of Aperol, she calls on Select Aperitivo in equal measure with aloe liqueur, a splash of lemon juice and, as the name suggests, guava syrup. To top it off, prosecco rosé adds the requisite bubbles.
ingredients: 2 ounces prosecco rosé, preferably Tenuta Santomè Prosecco Rosé, to top
instructions: 1. Add the first four ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into an all-purpose wine glass and top with prosecco.
3. Garnish with a cucumber wheel.

title: The Varnish’s Vesper
intro_philosophy: Served at the Varnish in Los Angeles, Eric Alperin’s Vesper took third place in our blind tasting of Vesper recipes. Made with both vodka and gin, like the classic, this version also incorporates Cocchi Americano.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce vodka, preferably Nat Kidder Navy Strength Vodka or Haku Vodka
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: White Negroni Highball
intro_philosophy: As the name implies,Orlando Franklin McCray’s hybrid cocktail takes the traditional build of thefairer Negroni, opting for Salers instead ofSuzeand blanc vermouth in place of Lillet, and tops the whole thing with tonic water and a lemon wedge.
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with cracked ice until chilled and diluted.
2. Strain into a Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Insert a bar spoon into the glass and pour the tonic water down the coil of the spoon to integrate all ingredients.
4. Garnish with a manicured lemon wedge.

title: Oops Not Berry’s
intro_philosophy: This cereal cocktail is a dyed-in-the-wool Wisconsin original, complete with a syrup made from the state’s own Jolly Good fruit punch soda. For the backbone of the drink, Lost Whale uses its proprietary blend of three different bourbons, which bartender Tripper Duval says is tuned for a Wisconsinite’s palate (wheated mashbill; on the sweeter side), but at home the 100-proof Old Forester works well.
ingredients: 1 ounce Oops All Berries–infused coconut milk (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce bourbon, preferably Old Forester 100 Bourbon
3/4 ounce fruit punch syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce rye, preferably Old Forester 100 Rye
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin. Shake well until chilled and diluted.
2. Strain over crushed ice into an emptied soda can or a cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with mint and a gummy whale.

title: Tonic Blend
intro_philosophy: A housemade sachet can be used to infuse both hot and cold drinks. Here, Maxime Belfand, bar director for AvroKO, offers his Tonic Blend, a combination of citrus peels, chamomile and juniper. Mimicking the flavor of tonic, this works especially well in vodka-based drinks. To use it, dip one Tonic Blend sachet in hot water briefly, squeeze out excess hot water, then steep in two ounces vodka for three to five minutes.
instructions: 1. Place all ingredients in a tea bag or square of cheesecloth and close.

title: Felices Los 4
intro_philosophy: Named after a song by Colombian singer Maluma, this spirit-forward mixture combines bourbon, aged rum, Pedro Ximénez sherry and a splash of peated whisky. Despite its spirituous construction,Michael Aredesdescribes the drink as “crushable and delicious.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Pedro Ximénez sherry, preferably Lustau
1 scant bar spoon Scotch whisky, preferably Laphroaig 10 Year
instructions: 1. Insert a banana leaf into the glass and trim so that it is flush with the rim.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir until chilled.
3. Strain over a large cube into a rocks glass.
4. Express the orange peel over the drink, then insert into the glass.

title: Laura Maddox’s Tequila Daisy
intro_philosophy: “When I was introduced to the Tequila Daisy, it was eye-opening,” saysLaura Maddox, who credits the simple sour as the drink that got her into bartending. She cites the combination of lemon and tequila (rather than the more common lime-tequila pairing) as particularly captivating, especially in the land of Margaritas. It sent her down a rabbit hole of classic drinks that continue to inform the core of the work she and her team carry out at Small Victory. Her version departs from the original only in fine-tuning the ratios.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Cascahuín Tahona
instructions: 1. To prepare a coupe or cocktail glass, rim the edge with sugar.
2. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with 3 drops of orange flower water.

title: William Elliott’s Martini Variation
intro_philosophy: William Elliott tweaks the classic Martini recipe with a few additions. Gentian-basedAvèze, less harsh than its other golden counterparts like Suze and Salers, works together with a blackcurrant cassis to mellow out the drink for a fruity, floral finish.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounce gin, preferably Xoriguer Gin de Mahon
3/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably La Quintinye Vermouth Royal Extra Dry
1/4 ounce cassis, preferably Jacoulot Crème de Cassis de Dijon
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Garuda
intro_philosophy: Matthew Belanger’s Garuda reads like the Loaded Tecate by way of Japan. Rather than splashing hot sauce over the surface of the can, he dips it inshichimi togarashi, a piquant Japanese spice blend. The execution is simple enough: dip, open, sip. Once there’s enough space, Belanger recommends pouring in one ounce (“or more if you’re brave”) of Japanese single malt.
ingredients: 1 can watermelon beer, preferably 21st Amendment Hell or High Watermelon
1 ounce Japanese single malt, preferably Hakushu 12 year
instructions: 1. Rub the rim of the beer can with the lime wedge.
2. Dip the can into the shichimi, open and sip.
3. Pour in Japanese whiskey.

title: The Brave
intro_philosophy: Bobby Heugel worked on The Brave cocktail for a full year before openingAnvil Bar & Refugein Houston in 2009, andit remainstheonly drink that has been on nearly every Anvil menu since opening day. Not unlike Anvil itself, the Brave is a bit of an oddball considering it doesn’t get shaken or stirred with ice—just swirled around in a wine glass and then misted over with aromatic Angostura bitters and garnished with a flamed orange peel. Perfectly delicious and balanced in its own right, the Brave changes the idea what a traditional cocktail can mean. In a tongue-in-cheek nod to the cocktail’s constancy, staff will often answer Anvil’s phone with,“Anvil, home ofTheBrave. How may I help you?”
instructions: 1. Build ingredients in a wine glass.
2. Swirl to combine.
3. Mist sides of glass evenly with Angostura (in a mister bottle) and garnish with a flamed orange peel.

title: Newark
intro_philosophy: “John Deragon and I created this cocktail for the PDT menu in the fall of 2007,” explains Jim Meehan in his book,Meehan’s Bartender Manual.Brooklyn cocktail variationswere all the rage at the time, he recalls, and rye whiskey supplies were dwindling thanks to overwhelming demand for classic whiskey cocktails in New York. “As Manhattanites are forced to do, we looked across the river for inspiration, and came up with this New Jersey apple brandy-based twist, which substituted Fernet-Branca for Amer Picon.” The bitter and boozy end result, they decided, was “worthy enough to be Newark’s namesake.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Laird's Apple Brandy, preferably 100 Proof
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir to chill.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

title: Café Royal’s Matador
intro_philosophy: One of two historic Matador cocktails that have inspired a number of modern riffs, Café Royal’s equal-parts mixture of tequila, orange Curaçao and dry vermouth was first recorded in 1937. TheTequila Matador, meanwhile, is Trader Vic’s tropical spin on the drink.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.

title: Gulf Coast Martini
intro_philosophy: A spoonful of Guinness stout “essence” adds a robust bitter note to this drink, created for a Martini-and-oyster pairing event where it matched up with briny Gulf Coast oysters. A rotovap (rotary evaporator) was employed for the original version, but a stovetop reduction method works, too.
ingredients: 5 drops saline solution  (1 part salt: 4 parts water)
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with radish slice.

title: Chad Arnholt’s Ward Eight
intro_philosophy: After tinkering around with the Ward Eight while working at Boston’s Citizen Public House, Chad Arnholt settled on a version with a quarter-ounce of orange juice. “The balance of my own recipe depends on what the oranges I am getting taste like,” he says. If the orange juice—squeeze your own!—is sweeter, back off on the grenadine.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce to 3/4 ounce pomegranate grenadine (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

title: Banshee
intro_philosophy: The Banshee is one in a triumvirate of dairy-driven drinks invented in the middle decades of the 20th century at Bryant’s Cocktail Lounge in Milwaukee. Garret Richard’s take on the banana-and-chocolate tropical dessert drink calls on a homemade liqueur made with banana schnapps, layers of chocolate, a small measure of rum and a nutmeg garnish. The whole thing gets flash-blended and served over crushed ice, which Richard says lightens the texture while also lengthening the drink’s life.
ingredients: 1 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
1 ounce Banana Bunch liqueur (see Editor’s Note)
1 dash Dave Arnold’s Chocolate Bitters (see Editor’s Note) or store-bought chocolate bitters
5 drops salt solution (4:1, water to salt)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin with 8 ounces of crushed ice.
2. Flash-blend for 5 seconds and pour, unstrained, into a double Old-Fashioned glass with 4 ounces of crushed ice.
3. Grate fresh nutmeg on top and serve with a straw and an optional plantain chip.

title: Lion’s Tail
intro_philosophy: This recipe is adapted fromCafé Royal Cocktail Book, first published in London in 1937. It remains a subject of fascination: a whiskey-based cocktail that seems to have all the trappings of a tiki drink.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Nobody Ever Dies
intro_philosophy: Part of Chantal Tseng’s “Literary Cocktails” series, Nobody Ever Dies is inspired by the Hemingway short story, in which two lovers, Maria and Enrique, briefly reunite while on the run in Cuba. “The drink is one of many riffs on theZombiea laDon the Beachcomber,” explains Tseng. “I adore passionfruit in tropical rum cocktails and like [it as an] ingredient to compliment the suspense in Maria’s situation.”
ingredients: 1 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Neisson Rhum Agricole Blanc
1 ounce dark rum, preferably St. Lucian
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a tall tiki mug over crushed ice.
2. Swizzle to incorporate.
3. Top with more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a lime shell filled with overproof rum and nutmeg, set on fire.

title: Coriander Seed Gimlet
intro_philosophy: At London’s Seed Library, this simple Gimlet calls on a coriander seed cordial—a nod to the original Gimlet’s prescribed Rose’s lime juice. “The wonderful musty citrus flavor from the seeds creates a complex but intuitive profile with the gin,” says Alex Lawrence, brand director for the Mr Lyan group of bars, which opened Seed Library in spring 2022.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce coriander seed cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the gin and cordial in a mixing glass with ice, and stir like you would a Martini. (If the drink is underdiluted, it can become sticky because of the cordial’s sugar.)
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass, and garnish with a fresh green grape.

title: Multiverse
intro_philosophy: The Universeis a disco-era cocktail invented by Bobby Batugo in 1978. He entered it in the U.S. Bartenders’ Guild competition that year and won. At the time, the Japanese melon liqueur Midori was new to the U.S. Batugo’s original was a shaken drink with Midori, vodka, pistachio liqueur, and pineapple and lime juices. At Sunken Harbor Club, Shannan Lynch accidentally created a drink that bears a striking resemblance to the Universe, but hers uses the bar’s cutting-edge techniques to create a house melon liqueur (adapted from YouTuber Kevin Kos) and acid-adjusted pineapple and orange juices to give the cocktail a brightness that didn’t exist in the original. She also chose to ditch the vodka in favor of white rum and aged aquavit. Store-bought Midori can be used in place of the DIY melon liqueur; the resulting drink will be much sweeter.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce white rum, preferably Hamilton White ’Stache
3/8 ounce acid-adjusted orange juice (see Editor’s Note)
3/8 ounce acid-adjusted pineapple juice (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce pistachio orgeat, preferably Orgeat Works
5 drops saline solution (4:1, water to salt)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Add ice (preferably one large shaking cube and two Kold-Draft cubes), seal, and shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
4. Garnish with a disco ball keychain.

title: Daiquiri Frappé
intro_philosophy:
“Our version of the classic frappé is inspired by theDaiquirisserved in Havana bars like El Floridita,” explains Paul McGee.

After returning from a trip to the Cuban capital he set to work tweaking the classic for Lost Lake. “It took a long time to get everything right—the flavor, texture and dilution,” he recalls. “I actually used Rick Bayless’ ’90s Margarita recipe to solve the problem of too much liquid, and [I] use lots of lime zest and less actual lime juice.”
ingredients: 2 ounces white rum, preferably Caña Brava
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend for 15 seconds on a medium speed.
3. Pour into a coupe.
4. Garnish with two neon swizzle sticks and additional lime zest.

title: Cloud 9
intro_philosophy: “I remember Toby Maloney [of theViolet HourandPouring Ribbons], coming into my bar and asking for a White Negroni,” says Jeremy Oertel, a bartender and bar consultant in New York City. “He was very particular about it.” Mayahuel, where Oertel worked early on in his career, specializes in tequila and mezcal, so playing on Maloney’s request, he switched the Negroni’s traditional gin base for tequila. He then added Lillet Blanc for fruity roundness, as well as Salers, a gentian-flavored liqueur to give the drink its requisite bitter kick.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass (or a Nick & Nora if you're fancy enough to have one).
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Sailor’s Paradise
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the Sturgill Simpson albumA Sailor’s Guide to Earth, Denver-based bartender Alex Jump set out to create a cocktail that exemplified the virtue of balance while working with ingredients that evoked oceanic, Asian and tropical flavor profiles. A delicate, mineral, low-ABV variation of the Martini, it incorporates sherry infused with exotic fruit and umami notes into a stirred gin cocktail. A splash of pickled melon brine and pinot gris lend the drink a sweet-and-sour mellowness. Jump says, “For me, that album is very much a representation of the fact that the pursuit of greatness does not have to exist without balance in life.”
ingredients: 3/4 parts  sherry infused with kombu and pineapple (See Editor’s Note)
1 teaspoon  pickled melon brine (See Editor’s Note)
1 teaspoon  cane syrup (2 parts cane sugar:1 part water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Serve alongside garnish options of: pickled hami melon, pickled cucumbers, oyster shell and pineapple scrap tincture and kombu and citrus oil.

title: Phố Cổ | Old Quarter
intro_philosophy: “Sticky rice and pandan are popular ingredients in Vietnamese street food, known for their distinctive flavors and aromas,” explainsThi Nguyen, who uses both in this twist on the Old-Fashioned. The base consists of toasted rice–infused rye, sweetened by a simple pandan syrup and finished with two dashes of Angostura bitters. “The toasted rice adds a delightful nutty and toasty flavor,” says Nguyen, “while the pandan syrup brings a vanilla-coconut essence.”
ingredients: 2 ounces toasted rice–infused rye (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to chill.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with pandan leaves.

title: Suit and Tie
intro_philosophy: Lychee Martinis hit peak popularity when Kristina Magro, now chief cocktail evangelist at the craft beer–focused Lone Wolf Tavern in Chicago, worked behind the bar of a big-box steakhouse back in 2010. Lychee in its natural form is quite sweet, but Giffad’s Lichi-Li “is not cloying or viscous—less syrupy than bright and floral,” she says. A longtime fan of “50-50” Martinis, Magro combines the liqueur with an equal portion of manzanilla sherry, introducing a savory element to one half of the mix. For the opposing half, she goes with Germany’s Monkey 47 gin, whose complex botanical mash, far from “a juniper bomb,” provides an appealing backbone.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce manzanilla sherry, preferably Lustau Manzanilla Papirusa
3/4 ounce lychee liqueur, preferably Giffard Lichi-Li
instructions: 1. Rinse a chilled cocktail glass with absinthe and set aside.
2. Combine remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into prepared cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with fresh lychee.

title: Kobra
intro_philosophy:
If you think port doesn’t get its proper due here in the States, it’s doubly true of white port. “Some people are like, ‘I heard of that once in a song my grandma listened to,’” jokesMorgan Schick, the creative director behind Trick Dog. In an attempt to assuage such ageism, Schick used the classicBambooas a launch point for the Kobra. “I just think the structure works really well,” he says of the template, which combines white port with manzanilla sherry, enhanced with spice from the falernum and bitterness from the quinquina wine.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces manzanilla sherry, preferably Hidalgo la Gitana
1/2 ounce Tempus Fugit Kina l’Avion d’Or quinquina
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Express the grapefruit peel and discard.

title: Terra Firma
intro_philosophy: While developing the drinks menu for Pacific Standard at Portland’s KEX hotel, “we didn’t really have a classic spirit-forward drink on our very fanciful lobby bar menu,” says Jeffrey Morgenthaler, the bar’s owner. This Vieux Carré variation fills that role, “grounding” the drinks list. “We named it, aptly, Terra Firma, or ‘solid ground’ in Latin,” explains Morgenthaler. The Terra Firma, made with Japanese whisky in place of rye and apple brandy in place of Cognac, puts a modern spin on the classic.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Japanese whisky, such as Suntory Toki
3/4 ounce apple brandy, such as Laird’s Bonded Apple Brandy
3/4 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Dolin
instructions: 1. Stir with ice cubes and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
2. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Electro Lit
intro_philosophy: “This is a cocktail where I get to poke a bit of fun at my most amazing city and its juice and wellness craze,” says Christine Wiseman of the coconut water and curry-turmeric-infused cocktail. Tequila forms the base of the crushed-ice drink, complemented by passion fruit liqueur and lime juice. “People go crazy over it.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce passion fruit liqueur, preferably Chinola
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with dehydrated coconut flakes.

title: Korean Paloma
intro_philosophy: For the house Paloma at Mr. Susan in Berlin, the star of the drink is gochujang, a fermented pepper paste. The funky, smoky notes of the ingredient complement bittersweet grapefruit soda, which the bar makes in-house, as well as earthy tequila, tart lime juice and mandarin liqueur.
ingredients: heavy 1/2 ounce gochujang syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce mandarin liqueur, such as Mandarine Napoléon
homemade grapefruit soda, to top (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except grapefruit soda to a highball glass with ice and stir.
2. Top with grapefruit soda and garnish with a grapefruit wedge.

title: Will Pasternak’s Mai Tai
intro_philosophy: Taking third place at our 2025 Mai Tai tasting, this recipe combines two rums—Appleton Estate 12-year and Rhum J.M Blanc—alongside two orange liqueurs, Orgeat Works toasted almond syrup, lime juice, rich cane syrup and a few dashes of saline solution. The judges appreciated the inclusion of a bolder, agricole-style rum: “It’s a balanced Mai Tai where you can taste the rum,” one said. In other words, it ticked all the boxes.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Orgeat Works toasted almond syrup
1/2 ounce rich cane syrup (2:1, cane sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and briefly shake.
2. Fine-strain into a highball glass three-quarters full of crushed ice.
3. Add a straw, and garnish with mint bouquets and an etched lime wedge.
4. Pack the rest of the glass full of crushed ice.

title: The Wolseley
intro_philosophy: William Elliott’s drink follows the blueprint of theThe Savoy Cocktail Book’sBentley Cocktail—originally a basic mix of Calvados, Dubonnet and bitters—with a few important tweaks. Cheekily named for a different iconically British carmaker, Elliott’s version uses two varieties of Calvados for complexity, and enlists Suze, Hamilton pimento dram and Germain-Robin to add layers of vegetal and herbal aromatics. “Despite the depth of aged Calvados, allspice and gentian, the wine-based Dubonnet adds layered length and complexity,” says Elliott. “[It lifts] an otherwise quite-heated concoction.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Montreuil Selection Calvados (or other 3 year or younger bottle)
3/4 ounce Adrien Camut 6 year (or other 6 year Calvados)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Obituary (c. 2011)
intro_philosophy: This “wetter” version of the stylized New Orleans Martini reflects Maison Premiere’s palate and the reigning Martini aesthetic of the early 2010s. It appeared on the bar’s opening menu during this period; this version is featured in the forthcomingMaison Premiere Almanac(Clarkson Potter, spring 2023).
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces London dry gin, preferably Hayman’s
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir to chill.
3. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
4. Express and discard the lemon twist.

title: Charaillon
intro_philosophy: The name of this drink is a mashup of a type of French melon—Charentais—and the name of the town where it grows, Cavaillon. Since Charentais is difficult to obtain in the United States, “I chose to use the reliable cantaloupe, which is easy to find,” franky marshall explains. The drink also features a young Pineau des Charentes White, which adds complementary ripe fruit notes and a touch of acidity to balance the remaining ingredients.
instructions: 1. In a mixing tin, stir cantaloupe juice and yogurt.
2. Add remaining ingredients and ice. Shake briefly; do not overshake.
3. Fine-strain into a fancy rocks glass over a 2-inch-by-2-inch ice cube.
4. Garnish with ground cardamom (or cinnamon, if using), directly in the center of the cube.

title: Fair Play
intro_philosophy: “Tequila and orange is always a nice combination,” says Julia McKinley. She pumps up the combo with aquavit and a touch of Campari, which, she says, bolsters the subtle orange notes of the Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale.
ingredients: 1 ounce reposado tequila, preferably Siembra Valles Reposado
half a lemon, juice and hull
Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale, to top
instructions: 1. Cut a lemon in half, trimming off the excess peel from the end. Juice the lemon half and add the spent hull into a chilled Collins glass.
2. Add the remaining ingredients except the ginger ale to the glass. Add ice and stir a few times.
3. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale.

title: Brown Sugar and Beyond
intro_philosophy: “My inspiration for this cocktail was the idea of bringing together East and West,” Dev Johnson says. “Yes, teas historically come from the East, but cultures of the West are familiar with their flavors, especially English breakfast tea.” The tannins in the black tea enhance some of the plum and pear notes found in the brown sugar shochu, he adds, which has a mellow aroma similar to whiskey.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce simple syrup (1:1 ratio of sugar to water)
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, pour the shochu over the tea bag and allow to infuse for 2 to 3 minutes, then remove the tea bag. (It can be used again to make 3 to 4 other drinks, Johnson says.)
2. Add simple syrup and ice, and stir.
3. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass.
4. Garnish with orange twist.

title: Sommer Schatzi
intro_philosophy: Fitzgerald’s recipe calls for a specific riesling: a 2016Leitz QbAwith notes of honey, apple, pear and chamomile. “It’s really juicy and slightly sweet, with a good, tart backbone,” he says. As such, his friesling additions—chamomile-flavored honey and lemon juice—work to both emphasize and balance the wine. Definitely don’t skip the garnish: “The mint sprig magically pulls out those apple flavors and makes the whole thing super summery and refreshing,” says Fitzgerald.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients and transfer to plastic containers to freeze.
2. Pour into a glass of your choosing and garnish with a mint sprig.

title: The Slope
intro_philosophy: Julie ReinerdevelopedThe Slopeas the house Manhattan at her Brooklyn bar, Clover Club. The recipe calls for Punt e Mes cut with a quarter-ounce of apricot liqueur, a signature ingredient in several of Reiner’s modern classics, including theGin Blossom.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce apricot liqueur, preferably Rothman & Winter Orchard Apricot
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.

title: Kahuna Barrel
intro_philosophy: “The Kahuna Barrel was me trying to figure out what my Rum Barrel would be,” says Richard of the countless variations of the tiki classic, sometimes known as a Rum Keg, typically consisting of tropical juices, sweetener and, of course, rum. “I think theMai-Kai’s Rum Barrel is the best,” he says. “They have all sorts of weird little idiosyncrasies about how they make drinks; they have very specific Florida orange juice, a very specific rum blend and a lot of building this drink was trying to emulate those flavors,” he says. Calamansi and orange juice replicate the specific tang of Florida orange, while the rums (Appleton Reserve, Coruba Dark, Hamilton 151) are blended to mimicthe extinct Kohala Bay.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce honey syrup (3:1, orange blossom honey:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and flash blend.
2. Pour into a tiki mug over 4 ounces of crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge shell.

title: Chris McMillian’s Mint Julep
intro_philosophy:
“The beauty of the Mint Julep is its simplicity,” says longtime New Orleans bartender Chris McMillian. “It’s about making each element the best that you can, and understanding that your idea of the best may change over time.” McMillian has been perfecting his recipe for over two decades and he’s famous for serving his take on the iconic cocktail with a side of performance art, reciting by memory an ode to the drink penned in the 1890s by J. Soule Smith.

At Revel, McMillian keeps 18 silver-plated julep tins of various sizes on-hand and adjusts the amount of bourbon and simple syrup accordingly.
ingredients: 2 to 4 ounces bourbon, preferably Maker's Mark
instructions: 1. In a julep tin, add the mint and gently muddle.
2. Fill the cup with hand-crushed ice until there is a small mound above the the top rim of the cup.
3. Pour the bourbon over the ice followed by the simple syrup.
4. Top with additional crushed ice.
5. Garnish with 1 to 2 mint sprigs.
6. Serve with a straw.

title: Dale DeGroff’s Martini
intro_philosophy: Dale DeGroff’s take on the dry gin-based classic was the victor at our Martini tasting. DeGroff’s simple and strong 7:1 concoction of Beefeater Gin and Martini Reserva Speciale Ambrato vermouth impressed with its straightforward, purist style.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir and strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Jane Danger’s Margaladaoma
intro_philosophy: Jane Danger’sMargaladaomauses soy sauce as an ode to the umami of theMichelada, and tequila and lime, to the timeless combination of theMargarita; yuzu ale represents the citrus of aPaloma. The wildcard additions of sesame oil and pomegranate molasses hint at Danger’s tiki roots and round out the flavors, while a hit of Sriracha adds some heat.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce honey syrup or cane syrup (1:1, honey or cane sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Rim a Collins glass with salt.
2. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients except for ale and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the glass and top with yuzu ale.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Surfer on Acid
intro_philosophy: Jägermeister has gotten a bad rap. In recent years, however, the bro-ey party shot has gotten a second look from bartenders who call on its herbal, bittersweet flavor in everything fromMargaritastoOld-Fashioneds. AtBespokein Wilmington, North Carolina, Robby Dow features the spirit in this shaken tropical drink.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces white rum, such as Don Q Cristal
1/2 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water, by weight)
1/4 ounce Jamaican rum, such as Smith & Cross
1/4 ounce coconut rum, such as Malibu
1 dash saline solution (1:4, salt to water, by weight)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a double rocks glass over a large block of ice.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Smokie & Alice
intro_philosophy: The Smokie & Alice has been on the cocktail list at Georgia James since it opened in 2018 and exemplifies the creative spirit behind the bar. Named for an obscure song—“Living Next Door to Alice,” by the ’70s English rock band Smokie—the drink tastes like a kicked-up Penicillin made with Japanese whisky, peated Scotch and a housemade black tea syrup.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce High Wire Southern Amaro (or Amaro Nonino or Amaro Meletti)
1/2 ounce black tea syrup (see Editor's Note)
