1/4 ounce Scotch, preferably Compass Box Glasgow Blend
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel and a cinnamon stick.

title: Oh, My Word!
intro_philosophy: There’s no citrus in this stirred riff on the classic Last Word created by Sother Teague at New York’sAmor y Amargo. In keeping with the bar’s aesthetic (and policy against using citrus in its drinks), it’s a deliberately spirit-forward cocktail with a bitter edge that subs lime bitters and Amaro Montenegro in place of fresh citrus.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir.
3. Strain into a coupe glass.
4. Twist a lemon peel over the top of the drink to express the essential oils, then garnish the drink with the peel.

title: Mexican Tricycle
intro_philosophy: The Mexican Tricycle was born as “a distant cousin to my old coworker Jeff Morgenthaler’s Broken Bike,” a drink that is itself a riff on the classic Bicicletta (Campari, dry white wine, soda water). Smoky mezcal acts as the backbone of the drink, standing up to the sweetness of the cider with an added kick of bitter Cynar—making for a simple, refreshing and low-proof cocktail.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
instructions: 1. Add mezcal and Cynar to a ten-ounce Collins glass.
2. Fill with ice and top with cider.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Zirconia
intro_philosophy: Designed to be non-alcoholic, the Zirconia can also be ordered with alcohol. The base of the drink is a house-made seasonal shrub made with fruits and vegetables like cucumbers and persimmon, fresh citrus and a dash of water-soluble CBD, all topped with tonic or soda water.
ingredients: 2 ounces tonic or soda water, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the tonic or soda water in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a highball glass filled with ice and top with tonic or soda water.
3. Garnish with seasonal fruit or herbs of your choosing.

title: Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Though the name “daiquiri” may be inexorably linked to the frozen drink menu at strip mall chain restaurants these days, the true recipe is a classic that can stand toe-to-toe with the best. Essentially a rum sour, the credit for the recipe usually goes to a U.S. engineer living in Cuba during the Spanish-American war, though it’s more likely that Cuban residents had been drinking something similar for some time. Famously associated with author Ernest Hemingway and the jet-set glamour of pre-embargo Cuba in the 1930s, the Daiquiri would rise in popularity in the United States during World War II, as Caribbean rum became much easier to procure than foreignwhiskey.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Dry Tongue Therapy
intro_philosophy: This drink, which features a “police line-up of ingredients,” says Guillermo Bravo, was created for Brooklyn bar Featherweight’s Tiki Tuesdays. While each ingredient manages to shine through individually, Wray & Nephew’s funk “stands tallest with a cocky smirk.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Wray & Nephew white overproof rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and whip shake with pebble ice.
2. Pour into a super thistle glass or a tulip glass.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit half wheel, mint and a charred cinnamon stick.

title: Classic Champagne Punch
intro_philosophy: For his take on Champagne punch, Dale DeGroff adapted a popular 20th-century recipe, which he used to serve during his tenure at New York’s iconic Rainbow Room. To a base of Cognac, DeGroff works in a slew of fresh fruit (pineapple, orange, grapefruit and lemon), plusBénédictineand maraschino liqueur.
ingredients: 1  pineapple, peeled and cut into cubes
6 oranges, cut into six pieces each
2  grapefruits, peeled and cut into cubes
2  lemons, peeled and cut into quarters
instructions: 1. Muddle the fruit and sugar with a cup of water.
2. Pour the maraschino liqueur, Bénédictine and Cognac over the crushed fruit and mix well.
3. Cover and allow the mixture to sit in the refrigerator for several hours.
4. Remove the punch from the refrigerator and stir.
5. Strain the punch into a large punch bowl and add the chilled Champagne and club soda along with ice.
6. Serve in wine glasses over ice and garnish with orange slices and pineapple wedges.

title: Bay Ridge
intro_philosophy: Bénédictine has a knack for playing well with others, making it a reliable modifier in many cocktails that need a little extra depth and sweetness. Clover Club’s Tom Macy prefers pairing the liqueur with brown spirits, though, which he feels go so well with “Beni’s” dark and earthy flavors—like in this rye- and prune brandy-spiked Manhattan riff by way of Brooklyn, a menu mainstay from the Carroll Gardens bar.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir.
2. Pour into a Nick & Nora glass and garnish with an orange twist.

title: The Lawn Boy
intro_philosophy: The Lawn Boy, made with gin, passion fruit liqueur, papaya purée and Casamara Club’s Como, is Canon’s most popular cocktail. The fruit-forward drink is a crowd-pleaser, but owner Jamie Boudreau has another theory as to why it’s so beloved. “The Lawn Boy is served in a bathtub,” he says of the drink, which gets topped with “Peach Bubble Bath” (peach juice, simple syrup andFoam Magic). “Pretty much anything we put in a bathtub becomes a Top Three drink.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Casamara Club Como amaro soda, to top
instructions: 1. Add the first four ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a bathtub-shaped glass (or other cocktail glass) half-filled with crushed ice.
3. Top with amaro soda.
4. Top with Peach Bubble Bath and dried rose petals.

title: Ma Cherie
intro_philosophy:
It might not look it, butLeo Robitschek’s Ma Cherie, which appears in the “Apéritifs” section of the NoMad’s drink list, is yet another session cocktail inspired by the classic sherry cobbler. Savory elements, from the muddled celery down to the serpentine cucumber garnish, draw the drink away from its source material, while additions like velvet falernum and pineapple syrup thickened with gum arabic offer a swift turn toward the tropical.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Put the celery in a cocktail shaker and use a muddler to lightly crush it.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and ice and short-shake, just long enough to combine and chill the ingredients.
3. Fine strain into a highball glass filled with crushed ice and garnish with the cucumber ribbon.

title: Bold Rob Roy
intro_philosophy: Among the first decisions to make when constructing a Rob Roy is deciding which spirit to use, as the choice between a smoky Islay or a fruitier Highland Scotch can have a drastic effect on the cocktail’s flavor profile. The Bold Rob Roy lives up to its name with two ounces of Laphroaig 10 Years Old Single Islay Malt Scotch Whisky, a full-bodied, peated example, alongside an ounce of Carpano Antica Formula Sweet Vermouth, a rich Italian bottling with strong vanilla and orange peel notes, and two dashes ofAngostura bitters.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a maraschino cherry.

title: Nick Jarrett’s Ramos Gin Fizz
intro_philosophy: In a blind-tasting of 10 Ramos Gin Fizzes from some of America’s best bartenders, this version of the classic from Peychaud’s in New Orleans relied on the unorthodox use of a blender to edge into the top three.
ingredients: 3 ounces Hayman's Royal Dock navy-strength gin
2 ounces simple syrup, (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the seltzer, cream and club soda in a shaking tin and set aside.
2. Add 120 grams (a small scoop) of cobble/Scotsman ice to a second tin and set aside.
3. Prepare two 14-ounce zombie glasses and add 1 ounce fresh, cold seltzer to each glass.
4. Pulse the contents of the first tin in a blender. Add the cream, and pulse again. Add the ice, and blend on high for about 12 seconds.

5. Pour the contents of the blender into each glass until half-full, and then to just below the lip. Let sit for a couple seconds, then tap the bottom of the glasses on the bar mat to force the CO2 up.
6. Top each glass with club soda while rotating until you have a 3/4-inch foam collar above the lip. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Time Flies
intro_philosophy: Created for a special menu offered during Tales of the Cocktail, this bracing drink amps up the tropical component with banana liqueur and 23 drops—about 3 generous dashes—of tiki bitters.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces pisco, preferably Campo de Encanto Quebranta Pisco
1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass over five Kold-Draft ice cubes.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Express the lemon peel and use as garnish.

title: La Playa Cubana
intro_philosophy: AtDonnain Brooklyn, poblano pepper offsets earthy rum, bittersweet Italian amaro, and Scandinavian fernet in this rich, herbaceous drink. “It’s meant to evoke a Cuba Libre in stirred form,” says bartender Patrick Gartner. “We recreated the sharp bite of a carbonated soda and squeeze of lime, which adds so much to the classic,” he notes.
ingredients: 1 ounce aged Barbados rum, preferably Real McCoy 5 Year
1/2 ounce Ancho Reyes Ancho Chile liqueur
1/2 ounce unaged overproof rum, preferably Rum Fire
1/2 ounce rich cane sugar syrup (2:1, cane sugar:water))
1 dash key lime citric solution (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass over KD ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with lime twist and mint sprig.

title: Vespa
intro_philosophy: “This is our Italian spin on the Vesper,” says Mike Trow. In addition to mixing vodka and gin, it also mixes rich ambrato vermouth with bracing dry vermouth.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces gin, preferably Garnish Island gin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a basil leaf.

title: Amaretto Sour Frappé
intro_philosophy: It was only a matter of time before disco drinks got the frappé treatment. Here, Konrad Kantor of New Orleans’ Manolito adds an unexpected splash of pineapple juice to his blended Amaretto Sour Frappé for a bittersweet kick.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients, except the amaretto, into a blender.
2. Blend on a slow setting then pour the amaretto into the blender.
3. Blend for 30 more seconds.
4. Pour into a V-shaped Martini glass or a coupe and garnish with pineapple fronds.

title: Joe Stinchcomb’s Last Word
intro_philosophy: Taking second place in our 2025 Last Word tasting was this recipe from Joe Stinchcomb of Bar Muse in Oxford, Mississippi. On paper, it’s a bit of a departure from the classic. The equal-parts formula is abandoned in favor of an ounce each of navy-strength gin and Chartreuse (or Boomsma, although we stuck with Chartreuse for this tasting), three-quarters of an ounce of lime juice and a mere half-ounce of Luxardo maraschino. The judges found it on the dry side, but ultimately liked the dialed-down maraschino.
ingredients: 1 ounce green Chartreuse or Boomsma Claerkampster Cloosterbitter
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Shake until chilled, then strain into a cocktail glass.

title: McIntosh
intro_philosophy: “I like poaching apples versus juicing because it gives a more intense flavor,” says Christiaan Röllich, who set out to create the liquid equivalent of apple pie in his McIntosh. A combination of malty genever, apple purée and sweet pecan-brandy syrup, the drink also alludes to the longstanding Dutch beer-and-genever-shot ritual,kopstootje(literally, “little headbutt”) when it gets shaken with IPA.
ingredients: 1 ounce poached apple purée (see Editor's Note)
1 1/2 ounces IPA, preferably Pizza Port Swami's
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in cocktail shaker without ice and dry shake.
2. Add ice, shake and strain into Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Garnish with apple slices.

title: Hope You Find Your Dad!
intro_philosophy: A variation on the classicSouthside,Daniel Miller’sElf-inspired seasonal drink invites Strega to commingle with District-made Green Hat gin, lime and mint. The Italian liqueur brings a bounty of festive botanicals that complement the mint simple syrup for a cooling finish reminiscent of a candy cane.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Pulque de Guayaba
intro_philosophy: This tall, silky, rose-colored cocktail offers a long, multilayered fruity finish, fronted by the pulque’s notes of freshly cut grass and lychee. Alex Valencia used to use a canned product for this bestselling drink, but the availability of high-quality distilled pulques, like Tlaxcala’s Juerte Destilado de Pulque, has been a game changer for this particular drink, as well as other Mexican bar programs in the United States.
ingredients: 2 ounces rum, preferably Santa Teresa 1796 Solera Rum
1 ounce guava purée, preferably The Perfect Purée of Napa Valley
3 to 5 drops vanilla essence (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker tin filled with ice and shake for 7 seconds.
2. Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass.
3. Squeeze lemon peel over drink to disperse oil, then add as garnish.

title: Nine Dragons
intro_philosophy: At Kingfisher in San Diego, the Nine Dragons pairs Malahat Spirits’ Mekong River Gin with blood orange liqueur, Cynar and a vanilla syrup. The Malahat gin can be hard to find, so another lemongrass- and citrus-forward gin would be a fine substitute.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce black sugar vanilla bean syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce Matchbook Distilling Co. Elsewhere Blood Orange Aperitivo
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with cubed ice and shake vigorously.
2. Double-strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass, then garnish with a blood orange half-moon.

title: Francerre
intro_philosophy: While the sauvignon blanc grape can shape shift depending on where it is grown, its archetypal expression hails from the Loire Valley’s Sancerre region. Here the grape tends to exhibit both minerality and a green aspect, sometimes likened to green pepper. For this white wine-based answer to frosé we honed in that green aspect of the grape, calling on St. George Spirits’ Green Chile Vodka, alongside simple syrup and lime juice, to turn its flavors up to 10.
ingredients: 1 ounce St. George Spirits Green Chile Vodka
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Pour into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a jalapeño slice.

title: Braggadocio
intro_philosophy: Wild Childis known for its high-concept low- and no-alcohol cocktails, but the Braggadocio is one of the bar’s alcohol-bearing offerings. For this spicy Tequila Sour, five types of chiles go into the base spirit infusion, complemented by the bittersweet botanicals of Amaro Averna and maple-tamarind syrup, all culminating in a layered take on the simple template.
ingredients: 1 ounce five pepper–infused tequila (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: EXpresso Martini
intro_philosophy: While many nonalcoholic cocktail recipes call fora growing number of N/A spirits, some bars opt to create their own. Garden Bar PHX, for example, makes its own Averna-inspired “amaro” out of chicory, gentian root, Mexican Coke and more. Here, it’s used as the base of the bar’s zero-proof take on the Espresso Martini.
ingredients: 3 ounces cold-brew coffee, brewed as a concentrate
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with coffee beans.

title: Nuked Negroni
intro_philosophy: This is London modernist bartenderRyan Chetiyawardana’s favorite recipe from his first book and, he says, “the one people seem to make and tag me in the most.” This batched version of the classic cocktail takes an unexpected turn by way of a quick infusion in the microwave (yes, the microwave).
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a closable microwave container.
2. Add to the microwave and blast at 600 watts for 3 minutes.
3. Allow to cool and filter.
4. Serve over ice in a rocks glass.

title: Flamenco Cooler
intro_philosophy: “For years, Ojen was just one of those things that you heard about but never really saw,” explains The Bywater bartender Chad Arnholt. “Like crème de rose or Sasquatch.” Though the anise-flavored liqueur is still largely unavailable outside Louisiana, as bottles make their way across the country in the form of personal gifts from NOLA locals, Arnholt has had opportunity to incorporate the New Orleans favorite in his Flamenco Cooler, which shakes Ojen with dry vermouth, fresh watermelon and lemon for a seasonal refresher.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Lofi or Dolin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker, add a fistful of pebble ice and shake.
2. Pour into a footed pilsner, zombie or hurricane glass and top with more pebble ice.
3. Garnish with a thin lemon wheel.

title: Shark’s Tooth
intro_philosophy: A Don the Beachcomber classic, the Shark’s Tooth is a fruit punch sour of sorts with a base of rum, the essential tiki juices—lime and pineapple—and a dose of two cherry liqueurs to tie it all together.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake with three small ice cubes.
3. Strain into a port or small wine glass.
4. Garnish with a 1 ounce shot glass of Appleton 12 year rum or Plantation Jamaica 2001 rum.

title: Johnny Blaze
intro_philosophy: It is hard to deny that thespicy Margaritais the drink of our times. Made with tequila or mezcal, and spiced with everything from muddled jalepeños to habanero tincture or via chile powder rim, the piquant mixture is, as Punch contributor Scott Hocker declares, “simultaneously safe, extreme, cultured and milquetoast.” In other words, it’s the ultimate anytime, anywhere drink. At Grand Army in Brooklyn, the Johnny Blaze, named for the anti-hero from the comic and film,Ghostrider, pairs tequila with fiery habanero shrub and lime with an extra kick courtesy of ginger.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco tequila, such as Arette Blanco
1/4 ounce "Some Good Stuff Biz" (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over Kold Draft ice.
3. Garnish with lime wheel.

title: Amarguinha
intro_philosophy: At his Lisbon kiosk, Quiosque de São Paulo, André Magalhães balances fragrant, sweetAmarguinha, a Portuguese bitter-almond liqueur, with equal parts fresh-squeezed lemon juice, serving the drink over ice, with lemon peel for an additional hit of aroma. This recipe calls for one and a half ounces each of Amarguinha and lemon juice, but you should be generous with your pours—Magalhães certainly is. Portugal’s iconic brand of bitter-almond liqueur, Amarguinha, is available ata handful of shops in the United States.
instructions: 1. Combine the lemon juice and Amarguinha in a rocks glass just short of filled with ice cubes, and stir until chilled.
2. Rub the edge of the glass with the lemon peel, then add to the drink.

title: Loaded Tecate
intro_philosophy: When TJ Lynch bought the space that would become Mother’s Ruin over a decade ago, he discovered a case of Tecate left behind in the refrigerator by the previous owners. Recalling a trend started by Toby Maloney years prior that consisted of putting salt and lime on top of a beer can—a nod to Maloney’s years spent in Texas—Lynch ran to the corner bodega to pick up some Cholula (“my all-time favorite hot sauce,” says Lynch), and from then on, the Loaded Tecate has been a signature of Mother’s Ruin.
instructions: 1. Squeeze a lime wedge and sprinkle some salt over an open can of Tecate.
2. Add Cholula to taste and serve.

title: Yayo
intro_philosophy:
Without Casa Camacho’s custom gin, gaseosa and sweet vermouth, it will be difficult to get the exact balance of flavors and aromas as the Yayo served at its bar of origin in Madrid. But the drink is forgiving (Ambrosio and his employees never measure the ingredients), and even outside of Spain, it’s possible to get close.

Casa Camacho uses Larris dry London-style gin, which is 30 percent ABV, but opt for the lowest-proof gin you can find, and try to source a sweet vermouth from Spain. The hardest ingredient to find in the United States is undoubtedly gaseosa, essentially sweetened soda water without any additional aromatics or flavoring. It’s common in Spain and Portugal, where it’s an obligatory ingredient inTinto de Veranoand other wine-based drinks. In the U.S., La Casera, the brand used at Casa Camacho, might be available at a Spanish grocer; otherwise, Sprite or 7UP will do in a pinch. The Yayo is best served with salty or pickled snacks, such as olives, potato chips or a slice of bread topped with chorizo or smeared with Gorgonzola.
instructions: 1. Add one or two ice cubes to a small footed glass.
2. Add the gin and slice of lemon.
3. Top with gaseosa and sweet vermouth.

title: Gangster’s Paradise
intro_philosophy: What’s the hallmark of a Vengroff cocktail? “Passionfruit and/or cinnamon,” she says. This tiki-inspired drink has both, providing a striking yellow glow and enticingly spiced aroma. The elaborate garnishes, including a tangle of thin carrot peelings that Vengroff calls “carrot spaghetti,” also nod to her tiki proclivities.
ingredients: ¾ ounce  cinnamon syrup (See Editor’s Note)
1 small drop  turmeric oil (diluted down to 1 part turmeric oil : 1 part water)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Dump contents of shaker (including ice) into a hurricane glass.
3. Top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with pineapple leaves, orchid blossom and carrot spaghetti, and serve with green and white paper straw.

title: Drinkin’ with Stiggins
intro_philosophy: A blend of pineapple rum,Swedish punschand green Chartreuse, the Drinkin’ with Stiggins calls on mint to complement the drink’s inherent herbal flavors and contrast its notes of baking spice, which come from a bar spoon of star anise-infused gomme syrup.
ingredients: bar spoon star anise gomme (see Editor's Note)
6 to 8 drops tiki bitters, preferably Bittermens 'Elemakule Tiki Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker over ice.
2. Shake and strain into a whiskey glass, such as Glencairn.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig and a star anise pod.

title: Jack Rose’s Kümmel Trident
intro_philosophy: In D.C., Trevor Frye riffs on the modern-classicTrident—equal parts aquavit, sherry and Cynar—by replacing the traditional Scandinavian spirit with kümmel liqueur and amontillado in place of fino, pumping up the drink’s savory notes.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice, stir and strain in to a chilled coupe.
2. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Meghan Royale
intro_philosophy: Foregoing the blender, The Luminary’s take on frosé starts with a Aperol-based mix that is frozen ahead to make a granita, which is then piled into a coupe and topped with a floater of pink wine. “We wanted something a little more visually striking,” says owner Jeremy Iles of this drink, which is named for one of the restaurant’s close friends named, yes, Meghan.
instructions: 1. With an ice cream scoop, collect one well-packed, rounded scoop of granita and place in a coupe.
2. Top with sparkling rosé to within 1/2 inch of the rim.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: That’s Probably Him
intro_philosophy: Fresh flavors of apricot and lemon mingle in harmony to take this sparkling cocktail from Jimmy Hibbard far and above its gin Martini roots. Serve in a Champagne flute for ultimate feelings of fancy.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir all ingredients with ice until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Champagne flute.

title: Aki Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy:
Elijah Craig Bourbon’s annual Old-Fashioned Week returns for its second year supporting the Restaurant Workers’ Community Foundation, October 15-24.Sign up your bar or restaurantto participate by featuring Elijah Craig Old-Fashioned riffs on your menu.

Japanese for “autumn”—“I’m bad at naming cocktails!” laments Natasha Bermudez—the drink was created  as a fall menu pairing at New York’s Llama San, the Nikkei (Japanese food as practiced in Peru) restaurant where Bermudez is head bartender. She makes it food-friendly by thinning out the body, using a smaller dose of syrup than she would with a stand-alone cocktail, and with barley shōchū, which she finds nutty and woody like a good sherry. She enhances the “fresh” notes she finds in Elijah Craig Small Batch with lightly muddled shiso leaf, a Japanese staple.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
1/2 ounce  white sesame cane syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. In a rocks glass, lightly muddle shiso leaf to release aromatics, then add a large ice cube.
3. Strain cocktail into rocks glass.
4. Express grapefruit peel over cocktail, and discard.

title: Art Through Time
intro_philosophy: This citrusy drink is relatively straightforward, but is presented with maximum drama. For cocktail competition, presentation included a “floating box,” a mirrored coaster, a garnish 3D-printed with a clock face, and a stirring stick 3D-printed with a minute hand.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
1 drop  Scrappy’s Firewater bitters (using an eyedropper)
instructions: 1. Stir first four ingredients with ice for 20 to 30 seconds.
2. Strain into a white wine glass, over a 1.5-inch-by-1.5-inch ice cube.
3. Twist lemon peel over the drink to express essential oils, then discard.
4. Garnish with zigzag-cut lemon peel and edible flowers.

title: The Bamboozled Angel
intro_philosophy: Toby Maloney’s citrus-driven cocktail, formerly found on the menu of the “vaguely Latin” Lorenzo’s in Bushwick, Brooklyn, is layered with bourbon and and housemade cinnamon syrup, which provides the heat and spice necessary for a cocktail both refreshing and fortifying.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in shaker over ice and shake.
2. Strain into rocks glass over large draft cube.
3. Top with angostura bitters; express grapefruit peel over drink and garnish.

title: Dos Gardenias
intro_philosophy: In developing the Dos Gardenias, Collina set out to make a drinkable parallel to the NoMad’s signature dessert, “Milk and Honey,” a combination of milk ice cream, oat shortbread and dehydrated-milk foam. What he ultimately created was in presentation and profile akin to a Sherry Cobbler (acidic, with notes of raisin and nuts), but with an added richness owing to the inclusion of honey-and-butter–based Gardenia Mix.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon walnut liqueur, preferably Nux Alpina Nocino
instructions: 1. Shake ingredients over ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass filled with crushed ice.

title: Blood and Sand
intro_philosophy: This recipe first popped up in theSavoy Cocktail Bookin 1930, with the title thought to be a nod to Rudolf Valentino’s 1922 silent film of the same name (itself, an adaption of a 1909 Spanish novel) about the rise and fall of a bullfighter. This mix of equal parts Scotch, sweet vermouth, cherry liqueur and orange juice, shaken and strained into a coupe, makes for one of the rare cocktails based on Scotch.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: “Root Beer Float”
intro_philosophy: There is no ice cream or root beer in this drink, but a mix of cream, amari, sarsaparilla bitters and stout certainly do a fine job of pretending. This bittersweet, fluffy mixture—which takes its inspiration from the Italian Futurist approach to mixology—is somewhere in between aRamos Gin Fizzand the soda fountain classic.
instructions: 1. Add Branca Menta, Ramazzotti, cream, simple syrup and egg white to a mixing glass or tin and dry shake.
2. Add stout and ice and shake quickly.
3. Pour over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda and two dashes of sasparilla bitters.

title: Autumn Sweater
intro_philosophy:
The bittersweet lyrics of “Autumn Sweater,” from Yo La Tengo’s 1997, I Can Hear the Heart Beating As One, serve as the source material for this melancholy change-of-season shoegazer. Serve it over a large block of ice, or over an ice sphere—even better to evoke a fat harvest moon hanging in the nighttime sky.

Made in Sicily since 1868, Averna is a syrupy, bitter herbal liqueur. It isn’t overpowering, though, and is a great gateway amaro if you’re interested in exploring potable bitters. Amaro Nonino is another mild Italian digestif whose caramel color and warm, spicy burnt orange notes round out the full fall flavors here. Wrap yourself in an Autumn Sweater and embrace what the season has in store for you.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Photos by Ed Anderson© 2011.Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the garnish in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Add a large sphere of ice to a chilled rocks glass and strain the drink into the glass.
3. For the garnish, use a paring knife to slice a thick strip of zest from an orange.
4. Twist it over the drink to release the essential oils and rub along the rim of the glass.
5. Stud the orange zest with two whole cloves and drape it over the ice sphere.

title: Bar Muse’s Last Word
intro_philosophy: Like many bars across the country, Oxford, Mississippi’s Bar Muse has been impacted by the Chartreuse shortage. According to owner Joseph Stinchcomb, it can be difficult to “capture the depth of flavor that Chartreuse has,” but the bar, which typically has at least one Chartreuse cocktail on each of its revolving menus, has made some pivots. This riff on the Last Word, for example, swaps the usual liqueur forBénédictine.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: The Edsel
intro_philosophy: Named for the Ford model that was only in production for two years in the 1950’s, this cocktail is Shannon Ponche’s (of New York’s Clover Club and Leyenda) riff on a Negroni Sbagliato. This “fall-spiced, low ABV cocktail” gains some nuttiness from savory oloroso and heat from Ancho Reyes, while sweet vermouth and Campari pay homage to its muse.
instructions: 1. Pour all ingredients into a rocks glass and stir briefly.
2. Top with sparkling wine and garnish with an orange half-wheel.

title: Royal Pimm’s Cup
intro_philosophy: The traditional flavors and familiar redcoat-bold color of Pimm’s No. 1 lie at the heart of the Pimm’s Cup. But the Slanted Door’s Erik Adkins wantonly tosses all that tradition to the wind in his Royal Pimm’s Cup, which is built upon a boozy Pimm’s Mix of his own making. It’s all topped lavishly with sparkling wine—because you can “add Champagne to anything and call it ‘royal'”—and many a garish garnish, creating a new tradition all its own.
instructions: 1. In 14-ounce glass, combine Pimm's Mix, sparkling wine, ginger ale, and lemon juice.
2. Add ice and gently stir.
3. Use mandoline or sharp knife to thinly cut a long, broad slice of cucumber and wrap around the inside of the top of the glass.
4. Use a channel knife to cut a slice of lemon peel and add to glass along with bruised mint.
5. Decorate garishly with seasonal berries.

title: Cicatriz’s Carajillo
intro_philosophy: This take on the carajillo is designed to provide a jolt of energy, a start to one’s night rather than the luxurious (and languid) sips synonymous with drinking the traditional version, which is often served in an oversized snifter so jam-packed with ice that drinking it becomes the activity in and of itself. The tequila brings out spicy, peppery notes in the cocktail; the end result is a drier, more complex take on the classic.
ingredients: 3 drops saline solution (1:4, salt to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express an orange peel over the top of the drink, then discard.

title: Kingston Negroni
intro_philosophy: “I can’t explain what possessed me,” explains New York City bartender Joaquín Simó, “but within five minutes of spirits importer Eric Seed handing me a bottle of Smith & Cross, I had created this drink.” He began with the blueprint for a classicNegroni, wanting to avoid muddying the flavors with too many other ingredients. “It strikes me as strange that the first thought I had when smelling and tasting this funky, estery, hogo-reeking, grilled banana bread, smoking allspice, brute of an overproof Jamaican rum was, ‘How do I work this into a stirred apertivo?’” Simó usually avoids using Carpano Antica in Negronis—he thinks it can be a bit of a bully—but in the case of a Smith & Cross base, he thought it could stand up to the vermouth’s bombastic chocolate and bitter orange notes, while tempering Campari’s bitterness.
ingredients: 1 ounce Jamaican rum, such as Smith & Cross
1 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into over ice (preferably a large cube) into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a long, trimmed orange peel.

title: Cane & Table’s Miami Vice
intro_philosophy: At Cane & Table in New Orleans, where proprietor Kirk Estopinal is currently offering a made-from-scratch Miami Vice as a pandemic-era special, the drink represents a welcome familiarity. “In these weird times I’m inspired by things that are brainless enjoyment,” he says. “Right now we just want to comfort our guests with pleasures.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces unaged rum, preferably Don Q
1 1/2 ounces aged rum, preferably Brugal Extra Viejo
instructions: 1. In a blender, combine the unaged rum, coconut cream, pineapple juice and 1/2 ounce of lime juice and blend.
2. Add 1 1/2 cups of pebble ice and blend again until smooth.
3. Pour into a Hurricane glass.
4. In the blender, combine the aged rum, 3/4 ounce of lime juice and the strawberry and blend.
5. Add 1 1/2 cups of pebble ice and blend again until smooth.
6. Pour into the Hurricane glass.
7. Garnish with a strawberry and mint sprig.

title: Filibuster
intro_philosophy: San Francisco bartender Erik Adkins uses the basicWhiskey Sourblueprint for this autumn-inspired drink. Instead of simple syrup, Adkins substitutes Grade B maple syrup to create a deep, frothy cocktail topped with spicy Angostura bitters. The Filibuster throws a bit of heat thanks to its strong rye backbone; Adkins recommends using a lower proof rye in order to preserve the egg white’s foam.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce egg white or 1 small egg white
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry shake.
2. Add ice and shake well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. To garnish, dash Angostura bitters decoratively over top cocktail.

title: Angostura Colada 2.0
intro_philosophy: The Angostura Colada, created by Zac Overman, made its public debut at a weekly pop-up tiki night called Sunken Harbor Club at Brooklyn’s now-closed Fort Defiance. When Fort Defiance owner St. John Frizell opened a brick-and-mortar location of Sunken Harbor Club above his celebrated steakhouse Gage & Tollner, he put the drink back on the menu with the help of bartender Garret Richard. This 2.0 version incorporates acid-adjusted pineapple juice, highlighting that flavor while dialing back the drink’s perceived sweetness, and allowing the lime from the original recipe to be left out. Now, Sunken Harbor Club has devised a3.0 version, which tilts the drink back toward its colada roots.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce overproof rum preferably Smith & Cross
1/2 ounce acid-adjusted pineapple juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and flash-blend until incorporated.
2. Pour into a mug over 8 ounces of crushed ice and 3 small ice cubes.
3. Garnish with nutmeg, a pineapple wedge and pineapple leaves.

title: La Pícara
intro_philosophy: “La Pícara was born out of a deep dive into the flavors of Mexico, inspired by a taco truck crawl I took while traveling there,” saysCapucine Prager, bartender atBar Goto, of this tequila sour. “Every day brought a new explosion of savory, spicy and herbaceous combinations,” she says, which she channeled here with cilantro, peppers, the salinity of manzanilla sherry and a tart hit of lime juice.
ingredients: 1 ounce shochu, such as The SG Kome Shochu
2 drops Ms. Better’s Bitters Miraculous Foamer
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.

title: Three Dots and a Dash’s Missionary’s Downfall
intro_philosophy: At Chicago’s Three Dots and a Dash, Julian Cox puts a modern spin on the classic tiki drink, the Missionary’s Downfall, with. “I love the combination of bone-dry rum and sweeter flavors like peach and honey,” he says of the combination of rum, créme de pêche, mint and pineapple. Though the mint is nitro-muddled at the bar for a modernist spin, a classic muddle works just as well when making the drink at home.
ingredients: 1 ounce rum, preferably Ron Barrilito 2 star
instructions: 1. Muddle the mint in a shaker tin.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and shake with ice.
3. Double strain into a coupe glass.
4. Garnish with a pineapple crescent and mint.

title: 5th Amendment
intro_philosophy:
The onslaught of tourism to Honolulu in the post-War years rapidly diminished the quality of well-wrought cocktails, as bars, in an effort to keep up with all that demand, turned to canned juices and cheap rum. The role of the city as tropical oasis slinging saccharine drinks in hollowed-out coconuts has persisted since. But over the past few years, a legitimate craft cocktail scene has been percolating just beyond the beach.

This drink, the handiwork of Dave Newman, owner of the welcoming gastropub-meets-craft cocktail hangout Pint + Jigger, is the perfect example of the tropical-classic mashup that has come to define some of the city’s most unique drinks.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir until well diluted.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large cube.
3. Express a lemon peel over the glass and drop it in to garnish.

title: Purity of the Turf
intro_philosophy: A lighter, rhubarb-tinged spin on the Martinez from The Up & Up’s Matt Piacentini adds layers of bitter complexity and keeps the sweetness in check. Piacentini created this drink as part of PUNCH’s House Cocktail Hack column, spring edition.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir all ingredients with ice until chilled.
2. Strain over ice into double old-fashioned glass, and garnish with an orange peel.

title: Tomato Jam–Infused Campari
intro_philosophy: At Thyme Bar in New York, the Solanum Negroni is made with Campari that has been cooked sous vide with tomato jam at 70°C, for 45 minutes. This at-home method is a simpler infusion technique, which similarly lends the red bitter a savory edge and can be used in an array of aperitivo drinks.
ingredients: 15 grams tomato jam or tomato chermoula
instructions: 1. Heat Campari to around 158°F.
2. Add tomato jam, and blend ingredients together.
3. Cool, then filter through a cheesecloth into a container and refrigerate until use.

title: Rites of Spring
intro_philosophy: “Rites of Spring is a delicateManhattanvariation, inspired by the idea of having this solo, introspective walk through a beautiful crisp forest,” says Lauren Corriveau of her spring-inspired cocktail. Clear Creek’s Douglas Fir Eau de Vie, made by infusing clear brandy with Douglas fir buds, adds forest-like aromatics alongside the citrusy flavors of orange marmalade and lemon verbena-infused vermouth.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces whiskey, preferably Wild Turkey 101 Rye
1 ounce lemon verbena-infused bianco vermouth, preferably Carpano vermouth
1/4 ounce Clear Creek Douglas Fir Eau de Vie
1 barspoon orange marmalade, preferably Bon Maman
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.

title: Moscow Mule
intro_philosophy: Born from a long lineage of ginger beer-based buck cocktails, this mixed drink featuring vodka, ginger beer and lime juice was created in the early 1940s. There is some dispute about the exact origins of the recipe, but most accounts credit an alcohol-fueled meeting between John G. Martin, an executive at the company that bottled the then-unknown Smirnoff, and Jack Morgan, owner of the Cock ‘n’ Bull bar in Hollywood and ginger beer producer. Together, the pair dreamed up an easy-to-make drink using their underperforming products and gave it a funny name (“Moscow” is a nod to vodka’s Russian roots) for catchy marketing. After a lull during World War II, growing popularity in Hollywood and ads for “Mule Parties” featuring celebrities such as Woody Allen helped raise the profile of this drink in the United States—as well as that of vodka, which would go on to supplant gin and whiskey as the country’s most popular spirit. Tradition dictates this drink should be served in a copper mug (some origin myths account for a third friend who needed to offload said mugs) though highballs or Collins glasses are suitable replacements.
ingredients: 4 ounces ginger beer (preferably Fever Tree of Fentimans)
instructions: 1. Add vodka and lime juice to a Collins, highball or copper mule mug (if you're fancy enough to own one).
2. Top with crushed or cracked ice.
3. Top with ginger beer and swizzle gently to mix.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Bliss
intro_philosophy: This riff on a classic Daiquiri features vermouth “to show how it can brighten and lighten up a familiar drink,” says Wildhawk’s Karri Kiyuna. Here, she chose bianco vermouth to support “the funk of the Banks rum, while filling in some brighter botanicals,” making for a complex cold-weather cocktail that lives up to its name.
ingredients: 1 ounce rum, preferably Banks 5 Island Rum
1 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi Bianco Vermouth
1/2 ounce vanilla syrup (1:1, sugar: water, with 1 whole scraped vanilla bean per quart)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to cocktail shaker, then add ice and shake vigorously.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express the oil of a lemon peel and discard.
4. Garnish with dehydrated blood orange wheel.

title: Yesterday, Today and Amaro
intro_philosophy: “The name Yesterday, Today and Amaro pays homage to the history of passing down recipes for amari production from one generation to the next,” says Brian Kane, who created the drink in May 2015 when he was the beverage director at the now-shuttered Philadelphia restaurant Abe Fisher. The amaro-kissed Manhattan riff builds on a base of rye with Cynar, Averna and herbaceous Bénédictine. “There are very few ingredients behind the bar that provide as much character in such small doses as amari,” says Kane. “This drink seeks to introduce the exotic by showcasing it in a familiar setting.”
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until chilled, then strain into a chilled coupe or Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express the lemon zest over the surface of the drink and discard.

title: Hand-Cut Potato Chips
intro_philosophy: The best basic aperitivo spreads are a trifecta of olives, nuts and potato chips. Hand-frying chips helps transform aperitivoessenzialefrom basic snack into elevated grazing.
ingredients: 4 Russet potatoes, washed, scrubbed and dried
4 cups canola or safflower oil, for frying
instructions: 1. Fill a large bowl with cold water.
2. Using a mandoline, thinly slice the potatoes and drop them into the bowl to keep them from browning.
3. Strain the potato slices and layer them between paper towel sheets, pressing to soak up the water.
4. Keep between paper towels until ready to fry.
5. Keep between paper towels until ready to fry.
6. Prepare a plate with dry paper towel sheets for the potato chips to rest on after frying.
7. Place oil in a heavy-bottomed skillet, and heat to 350 degrees on a deep-fry thermometer.
8. Using a metal slotted spoon and working in small batches, carefully place the potato slices into the oil, frying until golden, 1 to 2 minutes for each batch.
9. Scoop the finished chips out of the oil with a slotted spoon and place onto the paper towel–lined plate.
10. Sprinkle with sea salt, and serve in a paper bag alongside olives and nuts.

title: Don’s Special Daiquiri
intro_philosophy:
A 1970s updateon the 1930s variant known as the Mona Daiquiri, Don’s Special might more accurately be described as a Daiquiri twice removed. When Donn Beach first created the Mona, in 1934, he called on a base of 30-year-old Meyer’s Mona rum—for which the drink is named— and further amended the formula with the addition of both passionfruit and honey syrups. Following the discontinuation of Mona rum in 1946, Beach—true to his personal mantra that what one rum can’t do, several can—altered the recipe by calling on a blend of gold Jamaican and light Puerto Rican rums, resulting in Don’s Special Daiquiri.

In this version, Daniele Dalla Pola swaps honey syrup for agave nectar and makes the unorthodox addition of spiced rum for an extra kick.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Purple Jesus
intro_philosophy: This playful drink, a riff on an infamously strong party punch, is one of the top sellers at New Orleans–inspired restaurant Holywater. About half of a pony of Miller High Life is gently floated over the top to create a two-tone appearance; the remainder of the drink is served on the side, as a chaser.
ingredients: 1 ounce purple Kool-Aid syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1 7-ounce pony Miller High Life, to top
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, combine the vodka, lime juice and Kool-Aid syrup with Kold-Draft ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over fresh Kold-Draft ice.
3. Top the drink by pouring about half of the Miller High Life over the back of a spoon, so it floats on top of the drink.
4. Garnish with a paper umbrella and/or a gummy shark. Serve with the remaining Miller High Life on the side.

title: Caipirinha
intro_philosophy: Similar to theDaiquiri, this strong sweet-sour drink calls forcachaça, a Brazilian take on rum distilled from fermented sugarcane juice. Wildly popular in Brazil, the combination of lime juice, sugar and cachaça was thought to have originated to mask the taste of crudely-produced caçhaca, which, until recently, was widely considered a peasants’ spirit. As production techniques have improved, so has the cocktail. Riding theMojito’srecent wave of popularity, the Caipirinha has been gaining traction in the United States, no doubt on account of a new wave of quality cachaça imports finally making their way stateside.
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, add lime pieces and sugar, and muddle until well juiced.
2. Add cachaça and ice.
3. Stir to mix and garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Butter Martini
intro_philosophy:
Think of this drink as a Martini-plus: It’s “very simple and straightforward, but at the same time there’s more than meets the eye,” says Berg, who is noted for using boundary-pushing techniques that trick the palate. (A note: “Simple” is definitely in the eye of the beholder. The core ingredient list is indeed streamlined, but you need at least four days, and maybe more, to get those ingredients prepared.)

Berg is partial to the butter from Fannremsgården (Fannrem Farm), which she considers the “real star” of the drink. “It is made in a very traditional way, using sour cream as the starting point. This gives it richness but also lots of acidity and depth of flavor.” It doesn’t hurt that Berg’s own calf—Ramos, as in the dairy-based fizz—lives at Fannremsgården. But if Fannremsgården is not available, and you have no such allegiances, any good butter will do.
ingredients: 2 ounces Fannremsgården Butter–-washed Bombay Sapphire gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with lacto-fermented gooseberry.

title: Bay Leaf Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: At Bar Kabawa, one of ourBest New Bars of 2025, creative bartender Kathryn “Pepper” Stashek and chef Paul Carmichael have turned to archival recipe manuals to bring Caribbean cocktail culture to New York. While some of the drinks are direct callbacks to that history (like theGolden Glove), others are fresh and brand-new, like the Bay Leaf Daiquiri, which is made with the help of liquid nitrogen for muddling and echoes the use of the herbs in some of the kitchen’s snacks. “I don’t even wanna know how many pounds of bay leaves we go through between the kitchen and the bar here,” says Stashek.
ingredients: 2 ounces lightly aged blended rum, such as Chairman’s Reserve White
3/4 ounce lime juice blend (1:3, key lime juice to Persian lime juice)
3/4 ounce bay leaf syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add bay leaves to a shaker. Pour a bit of liquid nitrogen into the shaker to muddle the herbs.
2. Add the rest of the ingredients to the shaker and shake.
3. Fine-strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Fluttershy Highball
intro_philosophy:
Annie Williams Pierce goes full-on summer in her Fluttershy Highball, infusing semi-sweet French vermouth with farmers market strawberries, then pairing it with mezcal and fino sherry. The bitter orange, citrus oil and dominant quinine flavor of the Fever-Tree Indian Tonic Water brings on a bright bitterness that’s enhanced with a few drops of saline water, which Pierce calls the unsung hero of the home bar. As for the leftover vermouth-soaked strawberries, “You can make ice cream, bake them in a tart, or put them in milkshakes,” Pierce says. “And keep in mind you can always add these to the drink itself for a boost of flavor.”

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces  Strawberry Blanc Vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
¾ ounce  mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
4 drops  saline solution (4:1 water to salt)
3 ounces  Fever-Tree Indian Tonic Water, chilled
instructions: 1. Add the vermouth, mezcal, sherry and saline solution to Collins glass.
2. Fill the glass with ice and give it a quick stir.
3. Top off with the tonic water.
4. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Bocce Ball
intro_philosophy: At The Bronze Owl, bar director Max Green stays relatively true tothis ’70s-era drink’sthree-ingredient origins but adds dashes of orange and Peychaud’s bitters. This version also benefits from “fluffy” orange juice extracted using a centrifugal juicer.
ingredients: 2 ounces amaretto liqueur, preferably Adriatico Amaretto
2 ounces “fluffy” orange juice, extracted via a centrifugal juicer, or hand-squeezed and aerated with a milk frother or blender
instructions: 1. In a highball glass with ice, layer the ingredients in the following order: amaretto, then bitters, then sparkling water, then orange juice.
2. Garnish with a small piece of biscotti on the rim of the glass.

title: Diamond Noir
intro_philosophy: Key to the success of the Diamond Noir is the fat-washing process that lends the drink its unexpected velvety texture.Eric Simmonstakes a milk punch–inspired approach by filtering the entire cocktail—bourbon, yuzu juice, lemon juice and Demerara syrup—through heavy cream. The final product is then topped with a cabernet float, yielding a New York Sour–adjacent cocktail that feels right at home against a menu of pasta and Italian wine. As Simmons explains, “It has all the [elements of] the restaurant tied into one drink.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce burnt Demerara syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the wine, and freeze for 1 hour.
2. Strain the mixture through a coffee filter until clarified.
3. In a mixing glass, stir the clarified mixture with ice until properly diluted.
4. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
5. Gently pour the cabernet float over the top of the drink.

title: A Bird in the Shrub Is Worth Two in the Bush
intro_philosophy: Carla Rivera is obsessed with calculating the ABV of cocktails. This one, a deceitfully low-proof take on a Silver Sour, comes out to 13.3125% ABV, or 26.625 proof. Slightly nutty (re: sherry) and sour (re: shrub), with lift from the egg white, this drink has a balance of light complexity and extreme drinkability.
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, preferably Bombay Sapphire East
3/4 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Osborne Medium Sherry
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to shaker without ice and dry-shake.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Double-strain into glass and garnish with bitters.

title: Cosmogroni
intro_philosophy: “We love cocktail mash-ups,” explains J.P. Fetherston of this Cosmo-Negroni riff, which keeps the Absolut Citron, orange liqueur and cranberry aspects of the original Cosmopolitan, but shakes them up with Aperol. The Columbia Room’s other drink mash-ups include the Daquirac (Daiquiriand theSazerac), the Last Cup (Last WordandPimm’s Cup) and the forthcoming Ramos Gin Swizzle.
ingredients: 1 ounce citron vodka, preferably Absolut Citron
1 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Mancino Bianco Ambrato
1 dropper cranberry bitters, preferably Fee Brothers
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir together all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Flame an expressed orange peel over top of the drink, then discard the peel.

title: Adam and Eve
intro_philosophy: Xavier Herit’s biblically named drink is a nod to the forbidden fruit Adam and Eve couldn’t keep their curious paws off of. The apple-based ingredients—calvados, cranberry and apple shrub and spiced cider—are balanced with bright, acidic verjus (the unfermented juice of unripened grapes), dry amontillado sherry and sparkling wine, all of which happen to be grape-based ingredients. Herit bottles this cocktail for easy service at his New York City barWallflower, but you can serve it up in a coupe glass at home if you prefer.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce cranberry and apple shrub (see Editor's Note)
2 dashes Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas bitters
instructions: 1. Add calvados, sherry, shrub, verjus cider and bitters to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass (or a bottle).

title: Mojito Granita
intro_philosophy: The cooling Mojito is an ideal candidate for a frosty makeover. Jelani Johnson’s recipe hinges on a homemade mint syrup, which muddles two full mint sprigs into an ounce of sweetener for an extra-herbaceous kick. Note: Depending on how cold your freezer is, you may want to include more water, up to 2 1/2 ounces; colder freezers require less water.
ingredients: 1 ounce mint simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an 8- or 16-ounce deli container and stir to combine.
2. Cover with a lid and freeze overnight.
3. After 24 hours, use a fork to scrape and whip the mixture until it reaches a slushy texture.
4. Serve in a chilled glass with a mint leaf.

title: Frozen Vodka Espresso
intro_philosophy: From London, the home of the original Vodka Espresso, this frozen version was developed to showcase a light-roasted Ethiopian coffee on offer from Ace’s Bulldog Edition coffee shop. Demerara sugar helps coax out delicate floral notes from the coffee, McIntyre says, to keep the drink “light and delicate.”
instructions: 1. In a blender, combine all ingredients with 2 scoops of crushed ice.
2. Pulse on high speed until mixed into frozen consistency.
3. Pour into chilled espresso or cappuccino cup and serve with a straw.

title: Don Lockwood
intro_philosophy: “The Don Lockwood exemplifies the Dutch Kills cocktail ethos,” says Richard Boccato, owner of the Queens, New York, bar. “It has been in heavy rotation here almost from the day that we first swung open our doors to the public 16 years ago.” The Old-Fashioned variation is made with bourbon, Scotch, maple syrup and chocolate bitters and is served on Dutch Kills’ signature crystal-clear block ice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Windowsill Thief
intro_philosophy: Drawing on her upbringing in Richmond, Virginia,Kat Fosteris flexing a repertoire of passed-down Appalachian kitchen techniques—including pickling, canning and fermentation—to execute complex culinary cocktails at Margot in Brooklyn. The Windowsill Thief, whose name alludes to pilfered pie, is one such example. Central to the recipe is a lacto-fermented cherry syrup—the fermentation process, Foster says, lends the cherries a savory, meaty quality—paired with brown butter–washed rye.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces brown butter–washed rye (or whiskey of your choice, see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce palo cortado sherry (or amontillado or oloroso)
1/4 ounce lacto-fermented cherry syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce thyme liqueur, preferably G.E. Massenez Garden Party
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, then stir until chilled.
2. Strain over a large rock in a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a fermented cherry.

title: Canchánchara
intro_philosophy: TheCancháncharawas created by guerilla fighters of the Cuban Wars of Independence. Originally made with aguardiente de caña (the first distillation of sugar cane) honey, and limón crillo (also known as Mexican lime or Key lime), the drink was originally a restorative for enslaved people working the plantations.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass (or a clay cup) over ice.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Tribute to Mermaids
intro_philosophy: While the combination of Tecate, salt and lime is, to Toby Maloney, “just perfect,” he’s not averse to stretching the format of the original beer can cocktail. Here, he builds on the big citrus notes of saison with added lemon and rum, plus honey syrup and Peychaud’s bitters. The result: a pleasingly high-low hybrid of aFrench 75and aDaiquiri, with the yeast notes of the saison replicating the flavor profile of Champagne.
ingredients: 1 can saison, preferably Six Point Harbinger
1 1/2 ounces white rum, preferably Plantation 3 Star
instructions: 1. Pour out four ounces of beer in a glass and set aside.
2. Combine the rum, lemon juice, honey and bitters in a mixing glass with ice and briefly stir.
3. Slowly pour into the beer can.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.
5. Continue to add beer from the glass as the volume in the can goes down.

title: Exotic Citrus Sangria
intro_philosophy: Created for a private event in Augusta, Georgia, this sangria features a blend of citrus and bubbles for a fragrant, nontraditional take on Spain’s famous wine cocktail.
ingredients: 5 ounces exotic citrus syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a pitcher and stir gently to mix.
2. To serve, divide among 8 rocks glasses over large ice cubes.
3. Garnish each glass with a piece of lemongrass inserted like a straw.

title: Perfect Manhattan
intro_philosophy: One of the heavyweights in the cocktail world, theManhattanis something of a twist on the Old Fashioned, most likely spurred by sweet vermouth’s arrival and ensuing popularity in the United States during the latter part of the 19th century. The too-good-to-be-true story surrounding this drink’s origins—that it was invented at the Manhattan Club for an event with Winston Churchill’s mother—is just that: a tall tale. There’s still some debate among cocktail historians, but current theories for the original recipe favor either the Manhattan Club (sans Churchill), or a waiter named “Black,” who worked in lower Manhattan in the 1870s. There are other cocktails named for each of New York’s boroughs, but none as enduring or popular as the Manhattan. The “perfect” modifier indicates a combination of dry and sweet vermouth in equal parts as opposed to the original Manhattan’s full measure of sweet vermouth.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry or a lemon twist.

title: Tahini Cardamaro
intro_philosophy: A central ingredient in Clemente Bar’sThree Boxes, this tahini-infused Cardamaro comes together quickly. Try it swapped into aNegroniin place of Campari or in aPaper Planein lieu of Amaro Nonino, or better yet, sip it on its own after dinner for a savory spin on digestivo.
instructions: 1. Whisk together the Cardamaro and tahini paste and let rest for 10 minutes. Strain through a coffee filter. Will keep, refrigerated, for up to a month.

title: A La Mode
intro_philosophy: This combination of fresh apple cider, bourbon and Licor 43 (a citrus and vanilla-tinged Spanish liqueur) is just one pie short of, well, pie. But New York bartender Karin Stanley’s (of Dutch Kills) spicy, creamy ode to apple piea la mode—represented with lightly whipped brown sugar cream—is almost better than the thing itself. Because, well, bourbon.
instructions: 1. Add heavy cream and brown sugar cube to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add the coil of a hawthorne strainer and dry shake, without ice, for ten seconds or more, to aerate but not whip into stiffness. It must be light but still pourable.
3. In a saucepan, heat bourbon, Licor 43 and cider over low heat until steaming, about 10 minutes.
4. Pour into a tempered mug.
5. Holding a slotted spoon closely over the surface of the drink, float a finger's worth of cream on top of the drink.
6. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: The Lambeth Walk Fizz
intro_philosophy: With a base of mango brandy, paired with pineapple juice and banana cordial, The Lambeth Walk Fizz from William Elliott at Maison Premiere reads like a Ramos by way of the tropics.
ingredients: 2 ounces mango brandy, preferably Rhine Hall Mango Brandy
1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake vigorously with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass.
3. Put the glass in the freezer for a few minutes.
4. Using a straw, make a small hole in the top of the drink.
5. Pour a small amount of soda water through the hole until the surface of the drink rises above the edge of the glass.
6. Garnish with a channel-peeled orange zest.

title: Hemingway Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: With his prodigious constitution for drinking (and then writing about it), Ernest Hemingway shows up frequently in cocktail mythology, and none perhaps more famously than in this drink’s. La Floridita, a Havana bar frequented by the author in the 1920s, served Hemingway these doctored upDaiquiris, made unique by maraschino liqueur and notable for the lack of simple syrup (thought to be because Hemingway was diabetic). He reportedly could pack away tens of these at a time, ordering doubles—or what would come to be known as the “Papa Doble,” in deference. Another interesting fact: the bartenders would blend the drink with ice, then strain it out into a glass, foreshadowing the (mostly terrible) rise of the frozen Daiquiri.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Season of Strangers
intro_philosophy: In an uncommon partnership, Katie Weismann mixes fennel-infused light-aroma baijiu with mezcal for an earthy and smoky base, which is then balanced out by a sweet syrup and tangy acid-adjusted watermelon juice. At Spoke Wine Bar, the drink gets an added herbal boost from fennel seed syrup, but a simple syrup works well for the home bar.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces fennel-infused light-aroma baijiu (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce acid-adjusted watermelon juice (5 grams citric acid to 500 grams strained juice)
1/4 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing tin and dry shake (without ice).
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a glass.

title: Two Island Gin & Tonic
intro_philosophy: As the name suggests, this G&T riff nods to the influence of two islands: Scotland’s Islay, where The Botanist Islay Dry Gin is made, and Julia Momosé’s beloved Japan, represented by yuzu sake. A pinch of salt suggests sea air and helps amplify citrusy notes found in both the gin and sake.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  The Botanist Islay Dry Gin
1/2 ounce Tsukasabotan Yamayuzu Shibori (yuzu-shu, or yuzu sake)
Top Note Indian Tonic, to top
instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice, and stir to chill. Strain off the melted water.
2. Pour gin and yuzu-shu over the ice.
3. Stir to chill, then top with the tonic water.
4. Finish with a pinch of salt.
5. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Guillotine
intro_philosophy: A dry mezcal Manhattan with a hefty dose of Cynar, this three-ingredient cocktail exemplifies Yanni Kehagiaras’ approach to cocktails. Across the board at Stoa, his San Francisco cocktail bar, drinks top out at four ingredients or fewer, and he eschews added sugar unless specifically called for in a classic recipe. At a time when maximalism reigns supreme in the cocktail world, Kehagiaras is leading the minimalist charge with drinks like the Guillotine, which is, in turn, smoky, earthy and herbal.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled and diluted.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Brooklyn Cosmo
intro_philosophy: “[It] enabled us to showcase the flavors of the Meyer lemon in a way we couldn’t have achieved by simply adding lemon juice,” says chef and owner Jake Novick-Finder of the sous-vide technique used in this drink. If you’re not up for the sous-vide experience, infusing the vodka works, too, but it takes a couple of days to achieve the desired effect.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sous-vide citrus vodka (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce pineapple gomme or simple syrup (1:1, sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and shake vigorously with ice until frothy.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. If desired, garnish with lime wheel.

title: The F.A.F. Martini
intro_philosophy: Short for “Fancy as Fuck,” the star of this pricey ($30) high-endMartiniis a “barrel-rested” small-batch gin from London, which adds a gentle golden tinge to the drink.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, combine all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with Castelvetrano olive and lemon twist.

title: Johann Goes to Mexico
intro_philosophy: This mezcal spin on the Trinidad Sour calls for a full half-ounce of Angostura bitters. A cocktail-geek special if there ever was one, it’s dense and grainy, the smoke of the mezcal sneaking through cracks in the formidable wall of Angostura spice.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Distant Lover
intro_philosophy: This summery tequila sour fromMel Tate, bartender atDovetail, is named after a Marvin Gaye song. In it, strawberry syrup comes together with bright citrus, rich orgeat and Amaro Sfumato Rabarbaro, which lends a subtly smoky flavor and added depth to the cocktail. The result is a drink that channels the classic flavor combo of strawberry and rhubarb in an unexpected, yet refreshing way.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated citrus wheel or a small decorative heart pinned to the glass.

title: Tropical Fluff
intro_philosophy: Bartender Fanny Chu’s low-proof mashup of aJungle Birdand aGaribaldicalls on the bittersweet and tropical in equal measure. “I wanted a low-ABV Jungle Bird variation with fresh fruit juices,” she says. “Reminds me of when I was in Hawai‘i.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, such as Doctor Bird
instructions: 1. Combine the pineapple, orange and grapefruit juices in a cocktail shaker or high-speed blender.
2. Add 3 to 4 cubes of ice and shake or blend until you no longer hear the ice.
3. Add Aperol, rum and banana liqueur to a glass, then top with the fluffy juices.
4. Garnish with a half-wheel of orange and torched sugar.

title: Emerald City
intro_philosophy: The driving idea behind the Emerald City was to create an elevated Appletini. Rather than the expected vodka base, Shannon Tebay opts for Reisetbauer blue gin, “an assertive gin that’s still a good platform for other flavors to shine.” And for the all-important apple element, Tebay looks to Cyril Zangs apple cider eau de vie, a coveted expression made from over 30 varieties of apple. But the ingredient that ties the drink together is a half-ounce of Absentroux, a fortified wine aromatized with a botanical blend typically found in absinthe. “The Absentroux is really the seasoning here,” she says. “It ties everything together.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce apple eau de vie, preferably Double Zero Cyril Zangs Cider Eau De Vie
1/2 ounce blanc vermouth, preferably La Quintinye
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
3. Garnish with an apple fan.

title: Dolores Way
intro_philosophy:
“A vermouth cocktail is great in the afternoon, as an aperitif or whenever really,” says Wildhawk’s Karri Kiyuna, who likes to serve this drink as an introduction to the ambrato style of vermouth.

The drink is named after Kiyuna’s grandmother. “She liked to do things her way, and though she was not a big alcohol drinker, I think she would have enjoyed the bright flavors in this low-ABV, floral cocktail.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

title: Crown Chelsea
intro_philosophy: An easy-drinking cocktail—it’s Dorman’s favorite shift drink—the Crown Chelsea uses a base of bourbon mixed with just a hint of rum. It also employs orgeat syrup as a sweetener, adding a nutty richness that complements the barrel notes of the bourbon. The allspice dram, meanwhile, amps up the baking spice notes of the other ingredients, while keeping the sweetness in balance.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a double Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Add one large ice cube and stir approximately 20 times.
3. Express an orange peel over the drink and discard.
4. Garnish with another orange peel, spiked with cloves.

title: Mantra-Rock
intro_philosophy: “Rather than throwing out our day-old juice, we process it into flavorful, more shelf-stable cordials,” explainsLauren Corriveau, who deploys a number of house-made cordials in original cocktails and non-alcoholic drinks as part ofNitecap’s sustainability program. In her Mantra-Rock, a grapefruit cordial built from the scraps of the daily garnish prep, complements blanco tequila, Cocchi Americano Rosa, lime and rhubarb. “The flesh from the grapefruit adds a fresh burst of brightness, while the zest and pith contribute to a pleasantly bitter element,” explains Corriveau.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce pink peppercorn-infused Pueblo Viejo Blanco Tequila  (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the seltzer, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit crescent and lime wheel.

title: Sloe Moon’s Rose
intro_philosophy: A modern take on the swizzle, the Sloe Moon’s Rose at Sauvage swaps the traditional rum base for gin, Contratto and framboise.
instructions: 1. Build in the glass with crushed ice.
2. Garnish with microplaned lime zest, then top with powdered sugar and a dash of Peychaud's around the rim.

title: Freezer Saz
intro_philosophy: This Sazerac can be made as a single serving (stir 2 ounces of rye and 1/4 ounce Demerara syrup with ice before straining and skip the water, if you go that route). But at Poison Heart in Philadelphia, the take on the New Orleans classic shines as a pre-batched and chilled drink. You can replicate it at home with any large glass container, which is ideal for holiday entertaining or gifting.
ingredients: 3 ounces Demerara syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
4 spritzes pastis, preferably Ricard Pastis, from an atomizer (per serving)
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients to an empty pitcher, swing-top bottle or other glass container.
2. Place in the freezer for about 3 hours.
3. To serve, add the bitters to a frozen rocks glass, then pour 2 1/2 ounces of the prepared Sazerac.
4. Finish with spritzes of pastis from an atomizer, then express a lemon peel over the drink and discard it.

title: The Thirsty Monk
intro_philosophy: For this twist on aWhiskey Sour, Andrew King balances whiskey with citrus and herbal flavors (lemon,génépyandBénédictine), but it’s a hefty 12 drops of Peychaud’s bitters that allow this drink to double as an aperitif. “Shaking versus stirring yields a drink that is lighter on the palate,” says King, who suggests that the aromatic cocktail is perfect “before a meal: The herbs settle your belly and the rest gets your palate excited to eat.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon, such as Buffalo Trace
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain over ice in a Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Little Deuce Coupe
intro_philosophy: “Watermelon is incredibly refreshing, but tends to bring a lot of sweetness to a drink,” explains Xavier Herit, co-owner of the Wallflower. To balance this sweetness, Herit adds a measure of acidity in the form of lime juice, using the two contrasting flavors as foils for each other in this refreshing summer cocktail.
ingredients: 1 dash Thai chili bitters (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients together and strain into a coupe.

title: Room for Improvement’s Aviation
intro_philosophy: In Arvid Brown’s reworked Aviation, rose petal–infused gin is matched with the expected maraschino liqueur and lemon juice, though Brown omits the crème de violette and instead opts for a little Campari, some génépy, and a house-spiced grenadine flavored with toasted cardamom, cinnamon and star anise. Though he has taken liberties with the recipe, he still titles the drink an Aviation on his bar’s menu. “We find the right drinks make it into the right hands more often when people are familiar with the title,” says Brown of his decision to stick with the classic moniker.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rose petal–infused gin (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce house spiced grenadine (see Editor’s Note)
2 barspoons génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy Le Chamois
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a tall, footed glass.
3. Add crushed ice.
4. Garnish with lemon twist and cherry.

title: Carajillo
intro_philosophy: Mexico City’s party drink—a combination of fresh espresso and the Spanish liqueur Licor 43—can be found throughout the city in cantinas, coffeeshops and cocktail bars. At Cicatriz, an all-day café in the capital city, Scarlett and Jake Lindeman serve one of the best versions in town. “Frothy, caffeinated, and sweet—it’s like an adult milkshake,” says Lindeman.
ingredients: 1 ounce freshly pulled espresso (Cicatriz uses a blend of Chiapas and Veracruz beans from local Mexican roasters)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake hard with ice until chilled.
2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass with a large ice cube.

title: Manhattan
intro_philosophy:
One of the enduring heavyweights in the cocktail world, the Manhattan is something of a twist on theOld-Fashioned, most likely spurred by sweet vermouth’s arrival and ensuing popularity in the United States during the latter part of the 19thcentury. The too-good-to-be-true story surrounding this drink’s origins—that it was invented at the Manhattan Club for an event with Winston Churchill’s mother—is just that: a tall tale. There’s still some debate among cocktail historians, but current theories for the original recipe favor either the Manhattan Club (sans Churchill), or a waiter named “Black,” who worked in lower Manhattan in the 1870s. There are other cocktails named for each of New York’s boroughs, but none as popular as the Manhattan.

Photo originally published inBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Photo by Ed Anderson © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry or a lemon twist.

title: Sidecar 75
intro_philosophy: Created by Jonas Andersen of Strøm Bar in Denmark for a Merlet Cognac competition, this drink is a play on the classic Cognac-based cocktails theFrench 75and theSidecar. Like the Sidecar, it uses an orange liqueur and lemon for its citrusy zing and Andersen’s own Champagne syrup to play on the bubbly, yeasty notes of a French 75. Andersen has begun experimenting using fresh grape juice and Champagne yeast to create the syrup, but his original version uses flat Champagne (it would be heresy to use the live stuff, according to him) and sugar to create a simpler, home bar–friendly version.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce triple sec, preferably Merlet Trois Citrus
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel and a slice of pickled pear (optional).

title: Siam Park Swizzle
intro_philosophy: In creating the Siam Park Swizzle, Ran Duan drew inspiration from his round-the-world travels. A riff on the Queen’s Park Swizzle, it’s named for Thailand’s previous designation as Siam. “The drink is essentially a Mojito with fresh mint, lime and rum, elevated with the flavors of nutty almond, sweet milk and vanilla from the pandan,” says Duan. Butterfly pea flower, a blue-purple blossom, adds color, replacing the crimson lent from Angostura in the Queen’s Park Swizzle. The flavor of pandan, a Southern Asian herb, is added in tincture form, which should be made a day ahead.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over crushed ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with butterfly pea flower tincture, mint, orchid.

title: Spurt of the Moment
