intro_philosophy: The most popular cocktail at Grand Prize Bar is the Spurt of the Moment, a crushable cocktail made with mezcal, guava and a housemade spiced hibiscus syrup. “It’s lighthearted and beachy and doesn’t take itself too seriously, which I think resonates with our clientele,” says creator Daniel Jircik.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce spiced hibiscus syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Fine-strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Hop Over
intro_philosophy: At the now-closed New York bar The Beagle, Tom Richter built on the classic radler template by adding genever, falernum and orange flower water to the mix.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a pint glass over cracked ice and top with beer.
2. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Angostura Sour
intro_philosophy: A riff on a Charles H. Baker cocktail, Kirk Estopinal’s Angostura Sour is unorthodox in its use of Angostura bitters as a base spirit. Because bitters are high-proof by nature, the Ango Sour is strong as any cocktail with a typical spirit base, but aromatically astringent and curiously pleasant when smoothed together with a citrus-sugar-egg white backbone. Deep, dark crimson the Angostura Sour is truly a cocktail whose sum is much greater than its parts.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Ambrato Sour
intro_philosophy: This ‘local’ take on a gin sour substitutes lemon for green apple juice as the drink’s source of acidity.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sour apple juice (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce apple pulp syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

title: I’m on Fire
intro_philosophy: “My answer to a spicy Margarita,” Sarah Morrissey says, of the aptly named I’m On Fire.Mezcalin place oftequilaprovides a smoky profile, while Cholula hot sauce kicks up the heat. Rather than just reaching for the expected measure of lime, Morrissey uses fresh pineapple juice for both acidity and extra sweetness.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with ancho chili powder and a pineapple leaf.

title: Obituary
intro_philosophy: New Orleans has its very own Martini riff. Typical of the city of its birth, which has absinthe practically running through its veins, the Obituary differentiates itself from other dry Martinis through its inclusion of the French wormwood spirit where there might otherwise be bitters. William Elliott, of Brooklyn’s Maison Premiere, characterizes the drink as a “stylized New Orleans Martini” that, he notes, makes a perfect pairing for the bar’s renowned oyster program.
ingredients: 2 3/4 ounces gin, such as Hayman’s London dry or Thomas Dakin Red Cole
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, such as Bordiga Extra Dry
6 dashes absinthe, such as La Muse Verte
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir to chill.
3. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
4. Express and discard the lemon twist.

title: Broth Back
intro_philosophy: At Cobra, in Columbus, Ohio, the Broth Back is the most popular boilermaker on the menu. Consisting of a shot of whisky and a side of hot broth inspired by Maruchan Ramen packets, it’s a surprising, yet nostalgic pairing. “Our kitchen is the last fresh-food option open in Columbus most nights, so naturally we are the last stop for people having a night out and industry folk,” according to Alex Chien, Kayla LeRoy and David Yee, who make up the bar team. Late nights plus an industry-heavy crowd mean lots of boilermakers. Here is the recipe for the broth; Cobra pairs it with Dewar’s White Label Scotch.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in an appropriately sized stockpot. Add the cold water and slowly bring up to a bare simmer over medium heat.
2. Reduce to the lowest possible heat and allow the broth to steep for 3 hours. Let cool, then strain and serve.

title: Through The Woods
intro_philosophy: James Bolt, owner of Charleston’s The Gin Joint, crafts a straightforward but flavor-packed apple cider syrup, offering support to the the Leopold Bros. New York apple whiskey in this liberties-taking Appletini update. The additions of Pineau des Charentes, oloroso sherry and cardamom bitters build depth and dry out the end result.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Leopold Bros. New York Apple Whiskey
1 ounce apple cider syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Suffering Bastard
intro_philosophy: Made with both brandy and gin (and not a lick of rum), this drink dates from tiki’s Golden Era, says Martin Cate, proprietor of San Francisco’sSmuggler’s Cove: “Created at the Shepheard Hotel in Cairo circa 1942 by legendary globetrotting barman Joe Scialom, this was the drink that fortified Montgomery’s boys during the Second World War as they pushed back against Rommel in North Africa.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce demerara syrup , see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. Add the ginger beer to a Collins or highball glass.
2. Add the remaining ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
3. Fill with cracked or cubed ice. Shake and strain the contents into the glass.
4. Gently fill with cubed or cracked ice.
5. Garnish with a mint sprig and swizzle stick.

title: Passion Fruit Down River
intro_philosophy: This Paper Plane variation plays up tropical passion fruit and grapefruit. Meanwhile, the drink name riffs on “Mango Pickle Down River”—a song from the same M.I.A. album that includes “Paper Planes,” the track that inspired Sam Ross to name his original cocktail.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Double-strain into a coupe glass.
3. Twist the orange peel over top of the drink to express the essential oils, then discard the peel.

title: BeyBey’s Mama
intro_philosophy:
Staring at the contents of her refrigerator inspired Fanny Chu to make this “summer salad” of a low-ABV cocktail. The combination of juicy watermelon and salty-sweet bread-and-butter pickle brine gets a kick from Campari and mezcal. (Chu finds that the vegetal notes of the clean, crisp Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water play particularly well with agave spirits.) Chu has also mixed up a spirits-free take she calls Hey, BeyBey!; it’s practically made to be a poolside go-to.

Sweetness among watermelons varies, so Chu advises tasting and adjusting with sugar or another sweetener if needed; adding a splash of an agave syrup will extend the fresh juice’s shelf-life.

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: ½ ounce  mezcal, preferably Agave de Cortes Joven
¾ ounce  bread-and-butter pickle brine, preferably Grillo’s
3 ounces  Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water, chilled
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients except the tonic water to a shaker filled with ice.
2. Short-shake and strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with tonic water and stir.
4. Garnish with a cucumber slice.

title: Peanut Butter Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: This peanut butter and jelly-like cocktail illustrates how to use the enfleurage method of fat-washing to infuse bourbon with the oil that sits on top of peanut butter. Although a recipe for making strawberry whey syrup is included below, a commercial strawberry syrup orfraise de boisliqueur (strawberry liqueur) can be substituted.
ingredients: 2 ounces peanut butter fat-washed bourbon, preferably Buffalo Trace (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce strawberry whey syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a fresh strawberry.

title: Julia Momosé’s Highball
intro_philosophy: At her Chicago bar, Kumiko, Julia Momosé brings her detail-oriented approach to a dealer’s choice–style menu. Guests can expect thoughtful, ingredient-driven recipes, like this updated Japanese whisky highball.
ingredients: 1/4 teaspoon mango vinegar, preferably Huilerie Beaujolaise Mango Vinegar
1/4 ounce mango brandy, preferably Rhine Hall
1/4 ounce black cardamom Sauternes, see Editors note
1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably Nikka Taketsuru Pure Malt Whisky
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for soda water, in a Collins glass over cracked ice.
2. Top with soda water.
3. Garnish with a manicured orange twist.

title: Maison Premiere’s Sazerac
intro_philosophy: Known as St. Tammany on the Maison Premiere menu, this drink’s distinctive flavor comes from three non-traditional twists: the use of Bitter Truth Creole Bitters in addition to the usual Peychaud’s; the strongly flavored absinthe Jade 1901, the work of absinthe expert Ted Breaux; and green-anise-infused demerara syrup.
ingredients: 2 ounces rye, preferably Russell's Reserve Single Barrel
1 teaspoon green anise demerara syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In an ice-filled rocks glass, add a small measure of absinthe and set aside.
2. Combine all remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain the absinthe from the rocks glass into a sidecar to serve alongside the finished drink, and dump the ice.
4. Strain the contents of the mixing glass into the prepared rocks glass.
5. Garnish with an expressed lemon peel.

title: Low Key
intro_philosophy: Colin Carroll and Alex “Goose” Gesler came up with the Low Key shortly after signing their lease for 5 & Dime. Their philosophy centers around simply made drinks with a touch of complexity, in this case a bourbon highball sees the addition of a house-made herb-lemon syrup.
ingredients: 2 ounces bonded bourbon, preferably Early Times
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in an ice-filled Collins glass.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with soda water.

title: Portfolio
intro_philosophy: The Portfolio sits in the bold, brash, boozy end of the cocktail spectrum with drinks like Phil Ward’sOaxaca Old-Fashioned. Shaking this combination of spirits with lemon juice and simple syrup, as opposed to clarified lemon cordial, would collapse the rich architecture of the drink, ruining the very quality that makes it so fascinating—it would be just another sour.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
3/8 ounce Clarified Lemon Cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe

title: Sother Teague’s White Negroni
intro_philosophy: Sother Teague’s White Negroni was a notable entry in our blind tasting of 10 White Negronis. The most bitter of the bunch (unsurprising from a bartender whose tagline is “I♡bitters”), the recipe calls for an ounce and a half of gin, three-quarters of an ounce of Suze and an equal measure of dry vermouth, finished with a few dashes of chamomile bitters and a lemon twist. Brad Thomas Parsons, himself a bitters aficionado, thought it might read as “aggressively bitter for the average drinker,” but it did not put off the judges.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir briefly just to chill without adding much dilution.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express a lemon twist over the surface then insert into the glass.

title: Hey, BeyBey!
intro_philosophy:
Staring at the contents of her refrigerator inspired Fanny Chu to make this “summer salad” of a low-ABV cocktail. This version—a spirits-free take on her Campari and mezcal-laced BeyBey’s Mama—is practically made to be a poolside go-to.

Sweetness among watermelons varies, so Chu advises tasting and adjusting with sugar or another sweetener if needed.

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: ¾ ounce  bread-and-butter pickle brine,  preferably Grillo’s
3 ounces  Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water, chilled
instructions: 1. Add the watermelon juice, pickle brine and lime juice to a shaker filled with ice.
2. Short-shake and strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with tonic water and stir.
4. Garnish with a cucumber slice.

title: Jaffa Bar’s Godfather
intro_philosophy: “This is a two ingredient drink,” explains Sean Byrne of the classic Godfather blueprint, “I was like,How do I drag this into modern times?” For Byrne, the answer was to combine the requisite Scotch and amaretto with Lucano syrup, made by combining sugar, water, Amaro Lucano and cinnamon sticks. “It’s only two barspoons in there, but it really makes a lot of difference,” he says. Outside of this cocktail, Byrne says the Lucano syrup would work nicely in any Old-Fashioned-style drink, particularly alongside Scotch or rye.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended Scotch, such as Famous Grouse
1/2 ounce peated Scotch, such as Laphroaig
1/4 ounce amaretto, such as Lazzaroni Amaretto
2 barspoons Amaro Lucano syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until properly chilled and diluted.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Super Drunk Uncle
intro_philosophy: This playful drink gets a double dose of Scotch: The two main components are Scotch andDrambuie, a honey- and spice-flavored liqueur made with a Scotch whisky base. Pour whatever whisky is on hand for this versatile cocktail, since either a smooth blended Scotch or a peat-forward version works beautifully.
ingredients: 1 ounce Scotch whisky, preferably The Macallan 12
instructions: 1. Combine the first five ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into Collins glass over cubed ice.
3. Top with IPA.
4. Garnish with lemon wedge.

title: Shady Grove
intro_philosophy:
“My favorite kind of holiday drink is something spirituous and spice-driven,” says Alec Bales, and his Shady Grove, which takes inspiration from the classic Dark ’n’ Stormy, delivers. In his riff, the traditional dark rum sits out, replaced by American apple brandy and the artichoke-based Italian amaro Cynar. It’s rounded out with a splash of cane syrup and a dash of aromatic bitters and finished with a spiced ginger ale, redolent of bright orange peel, cinnamon and coriander.

Order Fever-Tree Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale viaKegWorks.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce  cane syrup (2:1 ratio of cane sugar to water)
1 1/2 ounces Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients except the ginger ale to a shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over ice and top with the ginger ale.
4. Express an orange twist over the drink and discard.

title: Kingston Club
intro_philosophy: Jeffrey Morgenthalercreated this drink circa 2011; it also appears in hisThe Bar Booktome. Why does Drambuie get top billing in this tiki-style drink? “Many herbal liqueurs do well in tropical drinks,” Morgenthaler notes. “Drambuie is certainly in the same family asBénédictine, yellow Chartreuse, Galliano, etc.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with orange twist.

title: Christmas in July
intro_philosophy: “You think that you can’t have a winter tiki drink, but you totally totally can,” says Jelani Johnson. “It doesn’t always have to be a fruity drink on cobbled ice.” Here, Johnson plays on the his own recipe for Hot Buttered Rum, the first drink of his to make it on theClover Clubmenu, but offers a cold version built on brown butter-washed rum. Bolstered by housemade coconut-coffee ice cream and cinnamon bark syrup, the drink is shaken until frothy for a creamy,flip-likedrink.
ingredients: 2 ounces brown butter-fat-washed Diplomatico Exclusiva Reserva rum (see Editor's Note)
1 ounce coconut-coffee ice cream (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce cinnamon bark syrup (see Editor's Note)
1 dash Swabbie's Dashes #2 (1:1 Dale DeGroff's Pimento Aromatic Bitters:cinnamon bark tincture), see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake vigorously with ice.
2. Strain into a flip glass.
3. Garnish with a cocktail umbrella.

title: The Inferno Room’s Zombie
intro_philosophy: Taking second place in our Zombie blind tasting, ChrisCoy’s recipe stood out for its rich, velvety mouthfeel, an exceedingly difficult quality to achieve in a drink prepared via spindle blender, which can easily overdilute a drink and make it feel thin. To thank for that is a rich honey syrup that complements the requisite cinnamon syrup and falernum. “It’s so hard to get the texture right with this drink, and this one nailed it,” said Garret Richard, a judge on the tasting panel.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce overproof aged rum, preferably Plantation O.F.T.D.
3/4 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Worthy Park 109
3/4 ounce overproof Demerara rum, preferably Hamilton 151
1/4 ounce falernum, preferably John D. Taylor’s Velvet Falernum Liqueur
3 drops absinthe, preferably La Fée Parisienne Absinthe Supérieure
instructions: 1. Combine the ingredients in a large shaker tin, then flash-blend using a spindle mixer for about 2 seconds.
2. Strain into a glass over fresh pellet or crushed ice.
3. Garnish with mint, dehydrated lime and nutmeg.

title: Godfather No. II
intro_philosophy: Old-school bar Tosca likely served the classic Godfather, a cocktail consisting of equal parts amaretto and Scotch, during the drink’s 1970s heyday. Today, their updated variation adds complexity by way of maraschino liqueur, plus a splash of smoky Lagavulin, which is added to a milder, blended-Scotch base. “Basically, we took the world’s simplest drink and managed to make it a reasonably taxing pickup,” quips Chad Arnholt, who created the drink with partner Claire Sprouse.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Cutty Sark Prohibition blended Scotch
1/4 ounce maraschino liqueur, preferably Leopold Bros.
2 dashes Scotch, preferably Lagavulin 16 Year Old
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Express the orange peel and discard.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: American Tiki
intro_philosophy: An all-American homage to the tiki genre, this drink includes an overproof white blackstrap rum for a hint of molasses and spice. While Robert Rugg-Hinds typically uses a house-made “Kentucky Falernum,” which mixes spice-infused bourbon with lemon juice and pecan syrup, home bartenders can “save the hassle and use John D. Taylor Velvet Falernum,” he advises.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces white rum, preferably Prichard's Crystal Rum
1/4 ounce white blackstrap rum, preferably Thomas TewWidows Walk Overproof Blackstrap Rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a tall glass mug or tiki mug.
2. Add crushed ice and mix with a swizzle stick or spoon to combine.
3. Top with more crushed ice to fill the glass.
4. Garnish with cloves and a few dashes of orange bitters.

title: Drifter
intro_philosophy: At ABV in San Francisco, the concept is simple: The menu is built around the spirits that the owners want to drink, and the drinks they want to make from them. This cocktail, the Drifter, is a straightforward mixture of Japanese whisky, blanc vermouth, Amaro Nonino and Peychaud’s bitters, garnished with a grapefruit twist.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce Japanese whisky, preferably Suntory Toki Japanese Whisky
3/4 ounce blanc vermouth, preferably Dolin Blanc Vermouth
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir gently.
2. Strain into a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Peach Me How to Dougie
intro_philosophy: No stranger to frozen drinks,T.J. LynchofMother’s Ruincreates a thoroughly modern and dead simple recipe in his playfully named Peach Me How to Dougie, a blended mix of bourbon, lemon, honey syrup and fresh peach.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend until smooth and serve in a glass of your choosing.

title: Argentina’s Cynar Julep
intro_philosophy: TheCynar Julepis a time stamp of Argentina’s cocktail—and sociopolitical—history. The mix of Cynar, mint, lemon and grapefruit is a vestige of the stiff, homegrown concoctions of the country’s old-school drinking culture (like the Clarito, an extra-dry Martini or the fernet- and vermouth-based Ferroviario), while also being ahead of its time, a precursor to today’s amaro revival and explosion of craft vermouth and bitters.
instructions: 1. Add the mint leaves, lemon juice and simple syrup to a highball glass and use a muddler to gently crush the leaves.
2. Add crushed ice and the Cynar, then swizzle to mix.
3. Top with the fresh grapefruit juice and garnish with a mint sprig.

title: A Coy Decoy
intro_philosophy:
As offerings in the American gin category expand by the day, the botanical profile of the spirit has branched out well beyond the juniper-forward expressions typical of the London dry style. Here, Chris Coy deploys cucumber-heavy Uncle Val’s gin alongside a more traditional expression from Fords, blending the two in a manner akin to how Don the Beachcomber married different styles of rum within a single drink. Combined with grapefruit liqueur and pineapple and lime juices, the Coy Decoy is bright, refreshing and uniquely modern.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1 ounce London dry gin, preferably Fords
1/2 ounce cucumber-forward gin, preferably Uncle Val's
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake vigorously, about 30 seconds.
3. Pour into a Zombie glass and garnish with mint, an edible orchid and a lime wheel.

title: High Line Fizz
intro_philosophy: A orange-tinged spin on a classic gin fizz from Pamela Wiznitzer of Seamstress in NYC, created for the spring edition of our House Cocktail Hack column.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients (except the soda) in a shaker and shake without ice.
2. Add ice to the shaker and shake vigorously until well chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass without ice and top with soda.
4. Zest lemon over the top of the drink to garnish.

title: Death Flip
intro_philosophy:
When this cocktail first appeared on the menu at the Black Pearl in Melbourne, in 2010, no ingredients were listed. And if you asked what was in the drink, the bartender would not tell you. The only thing offering the customer a hint as to what they were getting into was the ominous description: “You don’t wanna meet this cocktail in a dark alley.”

Of course, plenty of people stepped up to take the bait, and many ended up liking the cocktail—something that likely wouldn’t have happened if the ingredients were listed: tequila, yellow Chartreuse, Jägermeister and a whole egg. To date, it is the only flip to become a modern classic.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a sour glass.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Basque Bamboo
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn’s Bar Vinazo, the Basque Bamboo is a cross between the sherry classic and a spritz. The cocktail gets its name from two ingredients, a Basque blanco vermouth and a Basque cider, which put an acidic, briny, bubbly spin on the template. This Bamboo can easily be batched for a crowd; simply combine all ingredients, minus the cider, and top à la minute.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco vermouth, preferably Tximista Vermouth Blanco
1 ounce fino-style sherry, preferably Gómez Nevado Pálido Sierra Morena Seco
1 ounce Basque cider, preferably Isastegi or Órdago Iberiko
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a cider glass filled with ice. Gently stir to combine.
2. Garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Eel Bar’s Marianito
intro_philosophy: TheEel Bar versionof thisBasque classicrelies on Atxa Rojo vermouth, a Spanish bottling that the bar serves on tap, as the base. To this, they add dry Curaçao, which brings some body and citrus notes to the equation, and a small dose of rum—not the expected gin—and a few dashes of Angostura bitters. The bar uses Holmes Cay Réunion, which, like many agricole-style rhums, has a pronounced olive note that brings a welcome briny flavor to the drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Atxa Rojo
1/2 ounce agricole rhum, preferably Holmes Cay Réunion Island
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, then garnish with an olive on a pick and an orange twist.

title: Improved Genever Cocktail
intro_philosophy: “This really is one of my favorite cocktails,” Sidle says. “It’s maybe right behind aSazeracin my book.” As a riff on Jerry Thomas’s Improved Holland Gin Cocktail, technically this is a cocktail that’s beentwice“improved”: while the original is made with dashes of absinthe and orangeCuraçao, Sidle subs in more substantial amounts of green Chartreuse and maraschino liqueur. “The amount of maraschino is minimal, but crucial,” he cautions; the drink feels too heavy without the “higher notes” of the cherry liqueur.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Rosé Colored Glasses
intro_philosophy: In stirred drinks, sushi rice “softens the heat of the spirit and makes the flavors more cohesive,” according to Leanne Favre, who developed this cocktail for the Brooklyn restaurant Winona’s. Smoothing the rougher edges of Japanese whisky with an à la minute rice wash helps the spirit adhere to and amplify the drink’s other ingredients, aromatic rosé vermouth and Cappelletti aperitivo liqueur.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled and diluted.
3. Fine-strain into a rocks glass with a large rock.
4. Garnish with an expressed orange twist and a pansy.

title: Coast to Coast
intro_philosophy: In her Cape Codder riff, Lauren Corriveau of New York’sNitecapbuilds on a base of St. George California Citrus Vodka, plus cranberry shrub, tonic water and a few drops of saline solution.
ingredients: 2 ounces St. George California Citrus Vodka
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over ice and stir.
2. Top with tonic.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Rosita
intro_philosophy: Popularized by Gary “Gaz” Regan, the Rosita, which reads like a tequila Negroni, calls for reposado tequila at its base and cuts the typical sweet vermouth portion with a half-ounce of dry vermouth.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an Old-Fashioned glass with crushed ice and stir briefly.
2. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Hail Caesar
intro_philosophy: At The Tusk Bar in Manhattan, bar manager Tristan Brunel describes the base of his Bloody Mary riff, the Hail Caesar, as “almost like a dashi,” an intense umami blend of soy sauce, fermented chiles, horseradish, fresh garlic and cilantro, strained, cut with Clamato and the spirit of your choice, and served in a distinctly nighttime sour glass. It can be made with any spirit, but, says Brunel, “peated Scotch whisky is a secret menu item here at Tusk, and for the more adventurous bloody drinker, it elevates the savory components to a whole new level.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces spirit, such as gin, tequila, mezcal or peated Scotch
1 ounce Caesar spice mix (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Prepare a sour glass with a Tajín-salt rim.
2. Build the ingredients in a mixing glass, then add ice and “roll” the cocktail four times before serving.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.

title: Equal-Parts Martini
intro_philosophy: Just because it’s not a bowlful of gin, doesn’t mean a Martini can’t still have a bone-dry flavor profile. This 50/50 version of the classic relies on Miró Extra Seco, an extremely dry, wormwood-forward, Spanish vermouth alongside Perry’s Tot Navy Strength gin. A whisper of absinthe ties the ingredients together.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces ounces navy strength gin, preferably Perry’s Tot
1 1/2 ounces dry vermouth, preferably Miro Extra Seco
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with lemon twist and olive.

title: Gochujang
intro_philosophy: At Jeong in Chicago, chef and drink developer Dave Park wanted to create a cocktail that “utilize[d] a Korean ingredient and showcase[d] it as the star.” The Gochujang, named after its star ingredient,brings the Korean fermented red chile pastetogether with the bright flavors of raspberry, calamansi and lime juice for a sweet and spicy sour.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and top with ice.
2. Shake vigorously.
3. Strain into a coupe glass and express an orange peel over the cocktail.
4. Garnish with a fresh orange peel and serve.

title: Abigail Gullo’s Ramos Gin Fizz
intro_philosophy: In a blind-tasting of 10 Ramos Gin Fizzes from some of America’s best bartenders, this version of the classic from Abigail Gullo made the cut thanks to its stiff meringue, which held its structure better, and longer, than any other in the field.
ingredients: 1 ounce simple syrup, (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Place a Collins glass in the freezer.
2. Add all ingredients except club soda to a mixing tin and dry shake.
3. Add three Kold-Draft cubes to the tin, then shake until the cubes are dissolved.
4. Remove the Collins glass from the freezer and add two fingers (approximately 2 ounces) of fresh club soda to the glass.

5. Pour the cocktail high and slow in a thin, solid stream into the glass. Let the meringue settle, then slowly add more mixture until the head pops over the lip of the glass without spilling. A final rinse of the tin with a splash of soda water to top is allowed if there is room and the structure is stable.
6. Gently express an orange peel over the glass and discard the peel. Serve with a straw.

title: Las Reinas Margarita
intro_philosophy:
With a split base of tequila andL’Aperitivo Nonino, Las Reinas Margarita is an Italian take on a classic cocktail. L’Aperitivo Nonino is a vegan-friendly, versatile aperitivo liqueur that comes from the legendaryFriulian distillery. Las Reinas Margarita, which translates to the Queen’s Margarita, embodies the ethos of the women-run and -owned Nonino brand, while the imagery on the aperitivo bottle pays homage to the three generations of women master distillers.

L’Aperitivo Nonino plays particularly well in this rendition of the margarita, replacing the traditional orange essence with notes of citrus, rich grape, and a slight bitterness. Combined with a squeeze of fresh lime juice, this pared-back approach allows for a nuanced and refreshing margarita.
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with salt.
2. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
3. Shake until chilled.
4. Strain into the rimmed rocks glass over ice.
5. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Spiced Sazerac
intro_philosophy: Working at a Hugh Acheson restaurant inspires Atlanta’s Kellie Thorn to tweak the culinary parts of any cocktail, in order to make it her own. Though it’s thought of more often as a gin botanical, Thorn believes juniper works particularly well with the spicy character of Knob Creek®Rye, especially its baked apple and anise notes. Thorn advocates for the Sazerac as the perfect drink for at-home bartenders to get creative and choose their own spices to add; she suggests cardamom, caraway or star anise. Because of the higher-proof whiskey, she recommends stirring for a while to aid in dilution.
ingredients: ¼ part  juniper-rich gum syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Rinse a frozen rocks glass with absinthe and discard the liquid.
2. Combine remaining ingredients in a frozen mixing glass over ice and stir.
3. Strain into frozen rocks glass.
4. Express a lemon twist and serve on the side.

title: Fay Wray
intro_philosophy: Banana isn’t the easiest flavor to work into a cocktail. In fact, it can often backfire, resulting in something reminiscent of regretful tropically-tinged hangovers. However, Matthew Belanger’s Fay Wray is the opposite of overly sweet summer drinks. Strong, but balanced and fruity, it mixes the classic flavors of beach drinks—rum, lime and demerara syrup—with the toasted notes of Cognac and banana. Poured over crushed ice and garnished with mint, it’s an unexpectedly fresh take on tiki.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce gold rum (preferably Barbancourt 4 Star Rum)
3/4 ounce banana liqueur, Giffard Banane du Bresil
instructions: 1. Squeeze lime wedge into a cocktail shaker and add the wedge to the shaker too.
2. Add all other ingredients and a small amount of crushed ice.
3. Pour, without straining, into a rocks glass.
4. Add more crushed ice, and garnish with a dried banana slice and a mint bouquet.

title: Gibson
intro_philosophy: A good example of how powerful a garnish can be, with this cocktail the onion transforms a bitters-lessMartiniinto an entirely new drink: the Gibson. The usual historical squabbles exist about the drink’s origins (in short: at San Francisco’s Bohemian Club in the 1890s for Walter D.K. Gibson, or for the illustrator, Charles Dana Gibson, among many others), but no one can seem to pinpoint when or why a pickled onion made it into the recipe, as the earliest versions did not call for it. By the mid-20thcentury though, the Gibson—with onion intact—appeared to represent a challenge to the Martini in terms of cultural caché, though its status has dwindled in recent years.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a cocktail onion.

title: Sound & Fury
intro_philosophy: Unlike some of the other nonalcoholic offerings from Shawnee, Kansas’ Wild Child, the Sound & Fury does not require home-distilling equipment to make. Carrot, mango and tomatillo juices come together to form the base, while lime and habanero vinegar (“a shrub that doesn’t taste like a vinaigrette,” according to owner Jay Sanders) bring an acidic kick.
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Pour the contents of the shaker, including the ice, into a footed glass and top with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a piece of spiced candied mango.

title: Piña Colada Milk Punch
ingredients: 14 ounces aged rum, such as Planteray 5-Year
1 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Pour the rum, coconut water, Velvet Falernum, pineapple juice, lime juice and Demerara syrup into a heat-safe mixing bowl.
2. Over medium-low heat, heat the milk in a saucepan, stirring continuously until the milk begins to bubble around the edges (taking care not to let it boil).
3. Add the milk to the mixing bowl, stir until it begins to coagulate, and let the mixture sit for 15 minutes.
4. Strain through a cheesecloth or coffee filter until the mixture is clarified.
5. Ladle into cups over ice, and garnish with a cherry, pineapple slice, or both.

title: Santiago’s Luck
intro_philosophy: Inspired by Cuban coffee and sweet plantains—“one of my favorite after-dinner traditions,” Jake Powell says—the name of this Old-Fashioned variation comes from a character in Ernest Hemingway’sThe Old Man and The Sea, which tells the story of a Cuban fisherman. The cocktail is intended to be pre-batched and stored in the freezer, so you can pour it over ice and serve right away without having to stir and then dump the ice, wasting water.
ingredients: 15 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
1 1/2 ounces  cinnamon-infused banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 750 ml bottle, then store in the freezer.
2. When ready to serve, pour 2 1/2 ounces into a rocks glass, over a large piece of ice.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Nekokaburi
intro_philosophy: Nekokaburi, or “a wolf in sheep’s clothing,” borrows Christian Suzuki’s childhood nickname. “[My mother] would always joke that I always showed this sweet, shy, innocent side … but really I was loud like a dragon, striking like a scorpion and slick like a snake,” he says. Combining mango cream liqueur, lemon juice, egg white, amazake (a sweet sake) and mezcal, this frothy dessert-like drink masks its boozy bite beneath its fruit-forward top notes.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces kinako-infused mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Strain into a Glencairn glass.
4. Garnish with kinako powder.

title: Campo Cooler
intro_philosophy: This recipe appears inThe Nomad Cocktail Bookby Leo Robitschek. Flash-infusing bitters with golden raisins adds dried-fruit richness that echoes similar notes found in amontillado sherry and honey syrup.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces pisco, preferably Campo de Encanto
1/2 ounce unaged blended rum, preferably Banks 5 Island
1/2 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Lustau Dry Amontillado Los Arcos
1 teaspoon raisin-Infused Angostura bitters (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and whip shake with three Kold-Draft  ice cubes.
2. Strain into a highball glass filled over crushed ice.

title: Frank Caiafa’s Corpse Reviver No. 1
intro_philosophy: A sibling to the much more popular No. 2, the Corpse Reviver No. 1’s name is a bit of a misnomer; the spirit-heavy cocktail is much more suited to be a nightcap than a hangover remedy. To the original recipe’s Cognac, Calvados and sweet vermouth, Frank Caiafa adds orange bitters and an orange twist garnish in his revived recipe.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Calvados, preferably Boulard Grand Solage VSOP
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir for 30 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Cucumber
intro_philosophy: Created for the opening menu at The Pool Lounge,Thomas Waugh‘sGimletriff combines cucumber-infused absinthe, lime and cane syrup for a refreshing take on the classic.
instructions: 1. Muddle the cucumber wheels in a shaker tin.
2. Add remaining ingredients and shake with ice.
3. Strain into a coupe glass over a small amount of crushed ice.
4. Garnish with thinly sliced baby cucumbers.

title: Hot Pants
intro_philosophy: The 1974 edition of theOld Mr. Boston Official Bartender’s Guideis responsible for introducing the Hot Pants cocktail—a perplexing combination of tequila, peppermint schnapps, grapefruit juice and powdered sugar, shaken and poured into a salt-rimmed glass. It sounds like it shouldn’t work—and it really doesn’t, at least as originally constituted. But something about the Hot Pants intrigued Tammy Bouma, inspiring her to update the oddball sour for modern tastes. Her version omits peppermint schnapps in favor of a fresh mint tea syrup.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mint tea simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

title: Under The Mistletoe
intro_philosophy: This cocktail is a riff on the Vieux Carre. Built on a base of mezcal, the drink from Demi Natoli atWhite Limozeenspotlights pear in two expressions: first, in a brandy, and second, in a spiced liqueur. Natoli praises the latter for its “pure, fresh flavor of pears on the palate” and its gentle cinnamon and clove notes. “Especially during the holidays, when spice can easily dominate, this liqueur stands out for its restraint and harmony between fruit and spice,” she says.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, such as Del Maguey Vida
1 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Mariol Alta Blanco Vermut
1/2 ounce pear brandy, such as Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients (including the lemon peels) to a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

title: Pumpkin Buttered Tequila
intro_philosophy: Enrique Sanchez’s iteration of hot buttered rum calls on a pumpkin butter made by simmering pumpkin puree with evaporated milk, agave, spices and unsalted butter. He mixes this with oaky añejo tequila, but only an ounce of it. “Because it’s a warm drink, you really have to keep an eye on how much booze you’re adding,” says Sanchez. “It’s easy to add too much and then you really feel it.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the hot water, in an Irish Coffee mug.
2. Fill the mug with hot water and stir until well-incorporated.
3. Top with whipped cream and toasted pumpkin seeds.

title: Creamy Limoncello
intro_philosophy: Though not centuries-old or handed down from generation to generation, this limoncello recipe is an authentic product of Italian tradition. Angela Pugliese, an Italian immigrant by way of Uruguay, recreated the Southern Italian liqueur in her South Philadelphia kitchen after visiting family in Milan. It has since become her finest culinary wampum, traded for favors done by neighbors up and down the block. The structure is simple resulting in a sweet and creamy digestif thanks to a spare combination of lemons, sugar, whole milk and high-proof grain alcohol.
instructions: 1. Using a microplane, zest all the lemons, careful to not remove any of the bitter white pith.
2. Add lemon zest to grain alcohol and let steep in a cool, dark place for two weeks.
3. In a large pot, combine the milk and sugar and bring to a boil.
4. Remove from heat, cover and store somewhere cool overnight.
5. When the milk-and-sugar mixture has cooled, add the vanilla powder and infused alcohol. Stir and let sit for one hour.
6. Strain the limoncello into four clean 750 ml bottles. Store in the fridge or freezer.

title: Commodore
intro_philosophy: While both white and dark Crème de Cacao are chocolate-flavored, the dark gets its signature hue from caramel coloring, which some bartenders find to have an artificial taste. But others have found success with the deeply dark-chocolate-y, not-too-sweet version produced by Tempus Fugit. At Canon in Seattle, Jamie Boudreau contrasts the liqueur’s richness with acidity from fresh lemon and spice from bourbon, plus a dash of grenadine, in his Commodore.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit dark
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin with ice and shake.
2. Strain into a coupe and serve up.

title: Missing In Action
intro_philosophy: This “soft and crushable” cocktail from Samuel Miller is a tropical riff on the classic Paper Plane. The drink name pays homage, too; it’s a nod to artist M.I.A., whose single “Paper Planes” inspired Sam Ross to name the original drink.
instructions: 1. Whip shake (shake vigorously with a small amount of pellet ice) all ingredients or briefly blend all ingredients with a Hamilton Beach spindle blender.
2. Pour into Zombie (or Collins) glass, and top with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with lemon twist and mint bouquet.

title: Renai Revolution
intro_philosophy: This playful highball was inspired byChristian Suzuki’s family vacations to Japan’s Lake Kawaguchi, where soft-serve grape ice cream is a popular snack. The flavor ofUnited Sodas of AmericaWhite Grape reminded Suzuki of this beloved childhood treat, so he built on that by combining it with shochu and pandan-vanilla syrup. The silky texture and body of the shochu combined with the flavors of the soda and syrup render what Suzuki calls, “an adult take on a childhood sensory memory.”
ingredients: 2 ounces United Sodas of America White Grape
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda.
4. Garnish with pandan leaf.

title: Electric Feel
intro_philosophy: In thisTi’ Punchspinoff, Shannon Tebay ups the citrus kick from the traditional lime coin with the addition of yuzu liqueur. A measure of green chili vodka, meanwhile, adds an unexpected spicy note, tempered by a teaspoon of coconut liqueur for a complex spin on the tropical stalwart.
ingredients: 1 ounce rhum agricole, preferably La Favorite Blanc Agricole Rhum
1/2 ounce St. George Green Chile Vodka
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass over cracked ice.
2. Stir to integrate.

title: Coco Pandan Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Known for crafting tiki-inspired cocktails influenced by his Filipino roots, Gelo Honrade infuses bourbon with pandan, a herb popular in Southeast Asian cooking and baking, which lends an earthy, coconut flavor to the traditional Old-Fashioned blueprint.
ingredients: 2 ounces pandan-infused Angel's Envy bourbon (see Editor's Note)
2 barspoons demerara syrup (1:1 demerara sugar dissolved in hot water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with banana brûlée.

title: Fever! Til You Swizzle
intro_philosophy:
Featuring aged rum and warming ginger and allspice, Sam Miller’s modern highball is “refreshing but bold, and gives you the feeling of the holidays,” he says. A measure of banana liqueur rounds out the drink with some sweetness and adds a tropical finish, as do the spiced candied orange wheels. (Miller recommends reserving the simmering liquid left over from making the wheels. “Use it to experiment with cocktails or drizzle over your ice cream,” he says. “I like to use it in my Daiquiris and Old-Fashioneds.”)

As for the drink’s name? “It’s an ode to the Peggy Lee song ‘Fever,’” one of my partners, Didi’s, favorite songs to sing.”
ingredients: 1 ounce  Appleton Estate 8 Year Reserve Jamaica rum
1/2 ounce  Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur
instructions: 1. Build the first four ingredients in a Collins glass.
2. Fill the glass three-quarters full with crushed ice. Swizzle, using a barspoon or swizzle stick, to mix.
3. Top with ginger beer and more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a spiced candied orange wheel.

title: (And Her Name Was) Cassandra
intro_philosophy: At the newly opened Bar Beau in Williamsburg, beverage director Grant Wheeler leans on Japanese ingredients when it comes to the cocktails. Here, Japanese whisky appears as part of a split base with bourbon and bonded whiskey for a complex take on a whiskey sour.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Japanese whisky, preferably Akashi Ume
1/2 ounce bonded whiskey, preferably Old Overholt
1/2 ounce salted honey syrup (2:1, honey: water, salt to taste)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the bitters, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Fine strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Top with bitters and a fresh hyssop leaf.

title: Tart Gin & Tonic
intro_philosophy: Most Spanish Gin & Tonics are presented with a jumble of garnishes. This version takes a more streamlined approach, accenting a drink made with Japanese gin and yuzu bitters solely with shiso leaves.
ingredients: 4 dashes The Japanese Bitters yuzu bitters
6 ounces Thomas Henry Bitter Lemon tonic
instructions: 1. Add gin, Suze and bitters to a goblet filled with ice.
2. Pour tonic into goblet. (Valerie typically leaves the remainder of the small bottle for guests to sample, if desired.)
3. Garnish with shiso leaves.

title: Old-Fashioned Appetizer
intro_philosophy: Even at the turn of the 20th century, bartenders couldn’t resist dressing up the pared-down Old-Fashioned. In 1917, New York bartender Hugo Ensslin decided to split the whiskey base with Dubonnet, relying on a bar spoon of Curaçao to serve as the sweetener. A cornucopia of garnishes, including an orange slice, a pineapple slice and a lemon twist, likely contributed to the drink’s name: The Old-Fashioned Appetizer.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, plus a large ice cube, into a rocks glass.
2. Garnish with a lemon twist, orange slice and pineapple slice.
3. Serve with a small bar spoon.

title: Marie’s Cure
intro_philosophy: Jilbert El-Zmetr, co-owner of Brooklyn’sLaziza, created this drink, aPenicillin riff, as an ode to his mother. “I was raised in a Lebanese household and kitchen surrounded by good food, drinks, music and company,” he says. “A home-cooked meal and the love a mother brings is indisputable and is the ‘penicillin’ we all need in our lives. Mum always liked a combination of sour and ginger-forward flavors, so the Marie’s Cure was born.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker without ice and shake well.
2. Add ice to the shaker and shake briefly for 5 seconds.
3. Double-strain into a coupe.
4. Spray the top of the drink with peated Scotch, then garnish with a lemon twist or apple slices on a pick.

title: Teacup Toddy
intro_philosophy: From this intimate basement bar comes general manager Lindze Letherman’s favorite toddy, which she created to “welcome the shift from the fall shoulder season to winter ski season.”
instructions: 1. Fill your favorite teacup with boiling water to warm it.
2. Pour out water and add bourbon, lemon juice and calvados syrup to preheated cup.
3. Top with fresh boiling water, and garnish with apple chips or lemon wheel.

title: Haywire Highball
intro_philosophy: Hayley Wilson describes this unusual, yellow-tinged highball as “savory” and “malty,” thanks to the complexity of California-made shochu, Fever-Tree’s Light Tonic and a salted saffron syrup. For those who would prefer a store-bought option, Wilson suggests the saffron simple syrup from Maine producer Royal Rose, boosted with a sprinkle of sea salt.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  salted saffron syrup (see Editor’s Note)
Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Premium Indian Tonic Water,to top
instructions: 1. Shake the first three ingredients with ice.
2. Fine-strain into a Collins glass, and top with fresh ice.
3. Top with tonic water.
4. Garnish with the dehydrated lemon wheel, and serve with a compostable straw.

title: Three-Ingredient Midori Sour
intro_philosophy: “Despite its otherworldly hue, Midori is surprisingly legit,” explains John deBary of his decision to rework the much-maligned Midori Sour into a dead simple,three-ingredient recipe.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Stars & Satellites
intro_philosophy: What began as a riff on the Trident, an equal-parts mixture of aquavit, fino sherry and Cynar, soon evolved into its own drink entirely.Hayley Wilsonstill leans on an equal-parts build, but layers Cynar with floral, citrusy liqueur Italicus, amontillado sherry, a teaspoon of grapefruit oleo saccharum and a dash of orange bitters. Named after a line from Wilson’s favorite Death Cab for Cutie song, she notes that Stars & Satellites is designed as a nightcap for winding down after a long evening. “I want to be by my record player at the end of the night, playing some old, early 2000s music and drink this.”
ingredients: 1 teaspoon grapefruit oleo saccharum (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass.
3. Express the lemon swath and use as garnish.

title: High Altitude Highball
intro_philosophy:
In San Francisco, the bartenders at ABV are such big fans of génépy that they like to drink it ice-cold, three dashes of Angostura on top. In terms of cocktails, though, Ryan Fitzgerald likes to sneak it into a riff on a Scotch and soda, this one with Japanese whisky.

“Both Hakushu and génépy come from mountain areas—and both are influenced by the region they come from,” he says. “They work great together in this simple cocktail.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy des Alpes
instructions: 1. Combine whisky and génépy in Collins glass.
2. Top with seltzer and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Elusive Dreams
intro_philosophy:
The Elusive Dreams,Demi Natoli’s spin on Cuba’s Hotel Nacional cocktail—rum, pineapple, lime, apricot—takes a decidedly tropical turn as she swaps out the apricot in favor of banana liqueur. Natoli then doubles down on the pineapple, using fresh pineapple juice and splitting the rum component between the traditional white rum and Plantation pineapple rum, which is infused with both the rind and fruit of Victoria pineapples. Cinnamon syrup provides a baking spice note for added depth and a nod to Don the Beachcomber’s secret weapon.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1 ounce Plantation Stiggins’ Fancy pineapple rum
1 ounce blended unaged rum, preferably Plantation 3 Stars
1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banane du Brésil
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker. Add 1 large ice cube and shake until chilled, about 30 seconds.
2. Strain through a fine-mesh strainer into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a pineapple crescent and an edible orchid.

title: Chelsea Sidecar
intro_philosophy:
Basically a Sidecar with gin swapped for the Cognac, the Chelsea Sidecar is rarely, and perhaps unfairly, absent on most menus in the United States. “It sort of falls in the middle,” says Harrison Ginsberg, “It’s too simple to appeal to most cocktail enthusiasts and at the same time, most gin lovers will opt for a Martini or a Gimlet.”

To remedy this, Ginsberg has made some key adjustments. “Though the original calls for a traditional London dry, we opted for Roku, a Japanese gin with bright citrus notes of coriander, sancho peppercorn, green tea and yuzu,” he explains. To buttress the lemon juice and the orange-flavored Cointreau, the team at Overstory also make a mandarin oleo saccharum. “The original recipe can be too lean and too taut so the syrup rounds out the drink,” says Ginsberg.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Express a lemon twist over the surface of the drink and garnish with a drop of lemon, lime and orange oils.

title: Ani Varela’s Clarito
intro_philosophy: At La Favorita, bartender Ani Varela puts her own spin the Argentine Martini riff by adding a few drops of orange bitters to the classic construction.
ingredients: 1/3 ounce (2 teaspoons) dry vermouth, plus more to prepare the glass
instructions: 1. To a mixing glass, add ice and a splash of vermouth. Stir until ice has begun to melt. Pour the mixture, including melted ice, into a chilled coupe.
2. Add remaining ingredients to the mixing glass with more ice and stir until combined.
3. Pour cold water and ice out of the coupe glass.
4. Express the lemon peel over the drink, then use as garnish.

title: El Taco Rojo
intro_philosophy:
This story is published in partnership with P(our), a symposium devoted to exploring new ideas and exchanging inspiration about the drinks industry, and beyond. The annual event promotes discussions and presentations that address issues critical to the trade; this year’s theme is “perfection.” The event is taking place in Paris on June 3rd—for more information, and for tickets,click here.

In this cocktail, Jennifer Le Nechet uses ingredients that mimic those of a freshly made Mexican taco. Blanco tequila is infused with grilled corn, then paired with it a red bell pepper shrub made from cider vinegar and white balsamic cream. It’s all finished off with a squeeze of lime juice and a dash of chipotle tabasco, just like the food that inspired it.
ingredients: heavy 2 ounces Grilled Corn Infused Don Julio Blanco
heavy 1 ounce red bell pepper shrub
instructions: 1. Rim rocks glass with salted grilled corn, dry lime slice, and coriander sprig.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into glass over ice.

title: Big Chief
intro_philosophy: According to Abigail Deirdre Gullo, formerly of NoLa’s SoBou and now at Compère Lapin, this strong and stirred cocktail is “named after the Big Chief Indians down here in New Orleans that lead their tribes in the St. Joseph’s Day parade.” The drink is derived from a lineage of New York-named drinks, most immeditately a variation on the Longshoreman, which is based on the Red Hook, which is based on the Brooklyn, which is based on the Manhattan. “It’s kind of the journey I made from Manhattan to Fort Defiance in Brooklyn and now to New Orleans and SoBou,” she says. “I wanted to use Averna because the Sicilian influence is very strong here in New Orleans. It’s also what I like to imagine my great-great grandfather doing a shot of (along with some espresso) before he left Palermo for the New World.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a Nick and Nora glass or coupe.
4. Holding the peel of an orange in your fingers, warm the peel side with a lit match over the drink.
5. Squeeze the peel to express the oils over the match and drop the peel into the glass.

title: Lowtide Lifesaver
intro_philosophy: “I needed more of my coffee and tea knowledge than my cocktail knowledge to make this drink,” says Vince Bright, of his non-alcoholic Lowtide Lifesaver that features onLost Lake’s most recent menu. Moroccan mint tea syrup pairs with grenadine as the sweetening agents, complementing the Seedlip Spice 94 base, a clove-forward distillate, and the ginger beer topper. A squeeze of lemon juice offers a hit of acid, all served over crushed ice for a layered, complex refreshment. “I have some friends who don’t drink, so it was always important to me that when they come in, they have a drink that isn’t just kind of pushed to the side,” says Bright.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mint tea syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the ginger beer, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with ginger beer.
4. Garnish with mint.

title: Old Etonian
intro_philosophy: TheOld Etonianis a lesser-known Martini cousin fromThe Savoy Cocktail Book. It’s recently been revived by Leishla Maldonado atLomain Providence. She put it on the menu with the very specific goal of highlighting a special gin from Normandy—Le Gin de Christian Drouin—which employs an unaged apple brandy and an unusual botanical blend including ginger, almond, rose and citron. When combined with Lillet Blanc, crème de noyaux and orange bitters, the resulting cocktail is gentle, sophisticated with an almost marzipan warmth and complex layers of flavor.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces apple eau-de-vie-based gin, such as Le Gin de Christian Drouin
1 barspoon créme de noyaux, such as Tempus Fugit
2 dashes orange bitters, such as Fee Brothers
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until well chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Frozen Angelo Azzurro
intro_philosophy: The Frozen Angelo Azzurro joins a growing cast of aperitivo cocktails that have hit the deep freeze, including the Garibaldi, Negroni, and, naturally, theAperol Spritz.
instructions: 1. Pour all liquids in a Vitamix and top with the bag of crushed ice.
2. Blend on high until smooth.
3. Pour into a Collins glass.
4. Garnish with orange half moon.
5. Serve with straw.

title: Hightail Out
intro_philosophy: In this tall drink, mole bitters brighten and enhance, adding an aromatic element to the combination of rum and blanc vermouth, while complementing the cinnamon and spiced notes of Don’s mix.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Don's mix (1:2, cinnamon syrup:grapefruit juice)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients apart from soda water.
2. Strain into a Collins glass and top with soda.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel and a mint sprig.

title: GUSTU Julep
intro_philosophy: Though singani, a clear brandy native to Bolivia, is often enjoyed on its own, it can also can be used to fortify a cocktail, adding its signature muscat grape flavor into the mix. At Restaurant GUSTU in La Paz, bartenders combine it with vodka, mint and chocolate bitters in a decidedly Bolivian variation on the Julep.
instructions: 1. In a Julep glass, muddle the orange, lemon and mint with the soda.
2. Add the sugar and the bitters and stir.
3. Add the vodka and aged singani. Stir.
4. Fill the glass with crushed ice and decorate with all the fruits you have.

title: Tommy’s Margarita
intro_philosophy: TheMargarita—a blend of fresh lime juice, tequila and orange liqueur with an optional sweetener—is a potent, well-built entry in the cocktail canon. Plenty claim credit for its invention: a restaurateur based south of Tijuana in the 1930s, a socialite in Acapulco in the 1940s. Others believe it evolved as a south-of-the-border twist on the then-popular Daisy (the Spanish word for “daisy” is margarita, after all), dreamed up during Prohibition when Americans would travel abroad to drink. This version of the Margarita was created in the early ’90s by Julio Bermejo of Tommy’s Mexican Restaurant in San Francisco. Bermejo omitted orange liqueur in favor of the natural honeyed flavor of agave nectar helping to create the West Coast style of bartending using fresh, seasonal ingredients. It’s no mistake that agave nectar finds a natural harmony with an agave-based spirit.
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass with asalted rimif desired.
2. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
3. Add ice and shake.
4. Strain over ice into prepared rocks glass.
5. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Antique Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: This herbaceous, earthy cocktail created by former bartender Natalie Mauser-Carter uses new oak-aged gin, which plays off mesquite’s rich, spicy, dark chocolate and coffee notes. Chamomile-honey syrup, orange bitters and Angostura bitters add depth and complexity, while finishing spritzes of mesquite extract and liquid smoke balance the gin’s floral elements.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, preferably Waterloo Antique Gin
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients, except for the mesquite extract and liquid smoke, in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over one large ice cube.
3. Finish with 2 sprays of mesquite extract and 1 spray of liquid smoke.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: The Buddy System
intro_philosophy: In a playful high-low juxtaposition, the team at Montana’s Trail House brought techniques from the kitchen to the bar in the development of their Budweiser syrup, which is deployed here alongside fino sherry and Brennavín, all served in a smoked wine glass.
instructions: 1. Smoke the wine glass and set aside (see Editor's Note).
2. Shake all ingredients with ice.
3. Strain into a wine glass over ice.

title: Deijī
intro_philosophy: A WSET-certified sake educator,Shaun Williamsis often inspired by Japanese techniques and ingredients. The Deijī, which means “daisy” in Japanese, is Williams’ take on a Margarita made with Japanese ingredients, like Roku gin and sake in place of tequila, and a homemade yuzu Curaçao. Williams channels the tang of a salt rim with a homemade shio solution incorporated directly into the drink.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce simple syrup(1:1, sugar to water)
2 to 3 dashes shio solution (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake to chill.
2. Strain into a large coupe, then garnish with an edible flower.

title: Cold Brew Negroni
intro_philosophy: A self-described “Negroni obsessive,” Lunetta beverage director Kristine Bocchino uses Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur to support the bittersweet components in this variation on the classic. “I was introduced to Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur by a close friend who is a bartender in New York,” she recalls. “I fell in love with it because it is the most pure tasting coffee liqueur I have come across.”
tags: Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Hole in the Fence
intro_philosophy: The Mojito heads to tiki-town in this rhubarb-spiked mint-and-rum refresher from NYC bartender Matt Piacentini.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, including the mint to a shaker, and shake vigorously until chilled.
2. Strain over ice into a highball glass, allowing some of the mint bits into the glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Green Eyes
intro_philosophy: At Portland Hunt + Alpine Club, the Green Eyes has been the best seller since Day One. This riff on theLast Wordis a straightforward combination of gin, green Chartreuse, lime, simple syrup and an egg white, resulting in a frothy, herbaceous drink and “a true representation of Hunt + Alpine,” according to co-owner Brianna Volk.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce rich simple syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Fine-strain, remove ice and shake again.
3. Pour into a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel and cherry on a pick.

title: Jocelyn Morin’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Jocelyn Morin, owner of Tern Club in Knoxville, Tennessee, adds complexity to her take on the Daiquiri with a few modifiers. In lieu of simple syrup, she uses a richer Demerara syrup, and balances it out with a couple dashes each of saline solution and “Herbstura,” an equal-parts blend of Herbsaint liqueur and Angostura bitters.
ingredients: 2 ounces Jamaican rum, preferably Plantation Xaymaca
1/2 ounce Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar to water)
2 dashes Herbstura (1:1, Herbsaint liqueur to Angostura bitters)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Toby Cecchini’s Cosmopolitan
intro_philosophy: Before the “Cosmo” became the must-have liquid accessory of Sarah Jessica Parker acolytes, there was the Cosmopolitan, created by bartender Toby Cecchini at theOdeonin New York City, in 1988. Adapted from a pink-hued mock-Martini recipe that had been floating around Florida and San Francisco, Cecchini retooled the ingredient list with higher-quality mixers, choosing Citron vodka, lime juice, Cointreau and cranberry juice. Renowned in the Miami and New York club scene, the drink gained national exposure viaSex and the City, and, in the late 1990s, would go onto become the go-to order for upwardly mobile urban women. Strip away all the silly cultural associations, however, and what you’re left with is a doctored-up Cape Cod—a little sweet, not too alcoholic and pink.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce cranberry cocktail, such as Ocean Spray
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: The Franklin’s Rosita
intro_philosophy: At The Franklin, Evan Wolf, Matt LoFink and Jason Sorbet have implemented a few subtle tweaks to the classic Rosita Cocktail. Their softer take still has plenty of character made with smoky tequila and Aperol in place of Campari.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces smoked tequila, preferably Lunazul El Humoso
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Dolin Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice.
3. Express orange twist and discard.
4. Garnish with a dehydrated orange wheel.

title: Huelo’s Japanese Slipper
intro_philosophy: Huelo’s Japanese Slipper variation, labeled as a Midori Sour on their menu, brightens the original formula and adds complexity by cutting the melon liqueur with savory gin and replacing the Cointreau with aloe vera syrup, garnished with Champagne air in truly hedonistic ’80s style.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce aloe vera syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.
2. Strain into a cocktail coupe.
3. Using a julep strainer, scoop the Champagne air onto the top of the drink.

title: Yuzu-Calpico Fizz
intro_philosophy: Westerners might describe the Calpico Fizz as a “Tom Collins with yuzu and Calpico.” In Japan, it might be classified as an updated version of “Chu-hi,” which is essentially a shochu highball. Chu-hi is a common drink found in manyizakayaaround Japan, coming in different varieties such as Calpico Chu-hi, Oolong Tea Chu-hi and many more.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except for club soda in a shaker.
2. Use a hand mixer to dissolve yuzu preserves thoroughly.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Strain into a highball glass.
5. Top with club soda, and garnish with a calpico marshmallow.

title: Trash Tiki Citrus Stock
intro_philosophy:
This formula for citrus stock, which extends the life of fresh citrus and helps to eliminate waste, was created with plenty of wiggle room in mind, and Iain Griffiths, who founded the pop up and online forum, Trash Tiki, with Kelsey Ramage, suggests adjusting your recipe based on the type of citrus you are using, as well as the drink you hope to make.

In certain recipes, this stock can be used on its own as an ingredient or in place of fresh juice; it can also be combined with fresh citrus juice in a 1:1 ratio for use in highballs and frozen cocktails.
ingredients: 1 kilogram citrus husks (split in half and juiced)
instructions: 1. Bring the water to a boil and add the citrus husks. Allow the mixture to boil for five minutes.
2. Using tongs, remove the husks, then remove the liquid from the heat.
3. Allow the liquid to cool, and measure it by volume (it should be about 1,300 milliliters)
4. Transfer the liquid back to the stockpot and place it over high heat.
5. Bring to a boil, and reduce the liquid by half.
6. Add in white sugar (see Editor's Note) to stabilize, and adjust with citric and malic acids (see Editor's Note).

title: Between Two Trees
intro_philosophy:
In honor of Angel’s Envy’s#toastthetrees—in which the brand is pledging to plant 20,000 new oak trees this spring, along with adapting cocktail recipes to generate less waste—we’ve created a mashup of two essential whiskey classics.

Our Between Two Trees can be thought of two ways: a New York Sour in an Old-Fashioned build, with the port finish on the Angel’s Envy bourbon replacing the red wine float and our house lemon cordial replacing lemon juice; or a low-waste homage to the muddled fruit Old-Fashioned, with Angel’s Envy contributing a cherry note and orange bitters standing in for a fresh orange wheel.

However you view it, our intent was to remove fresh ingredients from the drink without sacrificing bite and freshness. We did so by creating a lemon cordial comprised of leftover lemon husks, sugar, water and citric acid. It not only employs an ingredient that would normally be tossed out, but it gives the drink both sweetness and a kick of acidity to brighten it.
ingredients: 2 ounces Angel's Envy Bourbon Port Finish
1 dash Dr Adam Elmegirab's Dandelion & Burdock Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice, and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large cube.

title: Tropical Thunder
intro_philosophy: In this frothy, tropical-leaning riff on the Daiquiri, milk-washed rum lends a rich mouthfeel to the fruitier notes of pineapple and orange juice. Created during this barback days at Booker & Dax, this was Jack Schramm’s first cocktail to ever make it on a menu.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce acid-adjusted orange juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Andrew Volk’s Hot Buttered Rum
intro_philosophy: Andrew Volksticks to his East Coast roots by adding vanilla ice cream to his spiced batter, which also relies on a dose of cardamom.
ingredients: 2 Hot Buttered Rum mix (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Preheat a glass mug by filling it with hot water. Let sit until the cup heats through, then dump the water.
2. Add the hot buttered rum mix into the preheated mug and add a small amount (about an ounce) of hot water. Stir with a small whisk until the mix is incorporated into the water.
3. Add the rum and fill the mug with the remaining hot water. Stir with the whisk to fully incorporate.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Gimlet
ingredients: 2 parts navy strength gin, preferably Plymouth Gin Navy Strength
instructions: 1. Combine the liquid ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Serve in a lowball glass over cubed or hand-cut ice.
3. Garnish with the lime wheel.

title: French Lemonade
intro_philosophy: Houston-based bar owner Pasha Morshedi wanted to create a drink that channeled sunshine and a leisurely French lifestyle. Floral St-Germain, grassy rhum agricole, tarragon and an edible flower garnish represent a plant, from stem to leaves to blossom. This drink, he says, “is complex and full of an array of flavors, but is still a bit light and as carefree as a glass of lemonade.”
ingredients: 1 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Dolin Vermouth de Chambery Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a 10-ounce wine glass over ice.
3. Top with lemon tonic.
4. Garnish with fresh tarragon and edible flowers.

title: Pimm’s Cup #37
intro_philosophy: While it’s not completely classic, this gin-based Pimm’s Cup variation created for the summer 2021 menu, “is a fairly straightforward drink,” says Maison Premiere’s head bartender Steven Rhea. “Given that Pimm’s is such a neutral product, I choose to use products to accentuate its flavors: orange, lemon, bitters, ginger, juniper.”
ingredients: 1/2 teaspoon saline solution (1 part salt: 2 parts water)
instructions: 1. Slap mint bouquet against palm, then rub on inside of Collins glass to release aromatic oils. Set mint aside.
2. Combine all ingredients, except ginger ale, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into prepared Collins glass over fresh ice.
4. Top with ginger ale.
5. Garnish with mint bouquet, cucumber wheel, orange flag with cherry. Serve with a straw.

title: Julie Reiner’s Freezer Martini
intro_philosophy: Second place in our freezer Martini tasting was won byJulie Reiner, co-owner of the Brooklyn bars Clover Club and Leyenda. The tasters found it well-integrated and delicate, with none of the drink’s flavors dominating. “It makes me want more with each sip,” said PUNCH senior editor Chloe Frechette. “A very good before-dinner Martini,” noted bartenderMeaghan Dorman. (Don’t look for this drink among the to-go offerings at Clover Club—it is Reiner’s at-home go-to.)
ingredients: 3 ounces vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Ambrato
3 ounces dry vermouth, preferably Dolin Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 750 milliliter bottle.
2. Store the bottle in the freezer for several hours, or overnight.
3. When ready to serve, pour into a chilled cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with lemon twist and tomolive.

title: Chantal Tseng’s Jungle Cocktail
intro_philosophy: “The Jungle is not a well-known sherry cocktail, but should be,” says Chantal Tseng of the close sibling of the Trinity cocktail (equal parts dry gin, dry vermouth and sweet vermouth, with an orange peel). “Around the time I started realizing that the classic repertoire vermouth drinks were brilliant once you figured out how not to let the vermouth go bad,” she continues, “it became an obsession to explore this retro-vintage world.”  If aMartiniorNegroniseems too daunting, Tseng recommends the Jungle to “break you in.”
ingredients: 1 ounce London dry gin, preferably Jensen's
1 ounce fino sherry, preferably Valespino Inocente
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed orange peel and a sprig of fresh thyme.

title: Lemon Ice
intro_philosophy: In a nod to the “organic architecture” philosophy of Frank Lloyd Wright, from which Prairie School draws its name, Jim Meehan’s Lemon Ice calls on ingredients from the surrounding area, including an Illinois sparkling wine and a vodka distilled in Chicago.
ingredients: 1 ounce dry sparkling wine, preferably Illinois Brut Sparkling Wine
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass.
2. Top with a mound of shaved ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Mall Grab
intro_philosophy: At Jaffa Bar, Sean Byrne has created several amaro syrups, including Cynar syrup, to add a bittersweet kick to his cocktails. “With this one, I’m essentially making vermouth,” he says. By blending Cynar with sour cherry juice, sugar, vanilla extract and cardamom, he developed a less-sweet alternative to the fortified wine. The result is something akin to Punt e Mes, he says, with “a more herbal taste.” He shakes this in equal parts with rye and Cognac, plus two barspoons of Bonal for a spirit-forward drink with layers of bittersweet complexity.
instructions: 1. Rinse a rocks glass with arak, then set aside.
2. Combine remaining ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until properly chilled and diluted.
3. Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice.
4. Garnish with an orange twist expressed over the surface of the drink, then discard.

title: Everything Nice
intro_philosophy: It’s perhaps no surprise that the best-selling cocktail at Alison Hillard’s Washington, D.C., bar is an Old-Fashioned—the bar is world-renowned for its whiskey selection. Customers may be surprised, however, by just how elevated this take on it is, with the call for oleo saccharum, an old-timey ingredient mostly used in punches, that really ups the citrus aromas. It manages to be extremely complex while never overshadowing the Knob Creek®Rye in the process. Hillard notes that though it’s a minor ingredient, the oleo saccharum makes a big impact, and thus the effort it takes to make it is well-rewarded.
ingredients: ¼ part  green Chartreuse oleo saccharum (see Editor’s Note)
⅛ part  fresh ginger juice  (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Strain over a big cube in a double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed lemon twist.

title: Jungle Bird’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy: Third place in ourJungle Bird 2024 blind tastingwent to New York’s aptly named Jungle Bird. The bar’s house recipe eschews blackstrap altogether in favor of a blend of Don Q pineapple rum and Smith & Cross Jamaican rum. To that is added the expected Campari, lime and pineapple juices, as well as the unorthodox pineapple liqueur. Juicy and refreshing without a pronounced rummy punch, the drink was deemed “a great gateway Jungle Bird,” by Brooklyn bartender Evan Major, and “the friendly Jungle Bird,” by rum expert Austin Hartman.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.
2. Strain into a glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a pineapple slice and pineapple frond.

title: Dr. Diablo
