2 cups ginger liqueur, preferably Domaine de Canton
1 bottle Champagne, preferably Moët & Chandon Brut Imperial
instructions: 1. In a punch bowl, combine all ingredients over a large block of ice.
2. Garnish with Granny Smith apple balls, thin lemon coins or rings and sliced habaneros, to taste.

title: Golden Handcuffs
intro_philosophy: At Houston’s The Pass & Provisions, head bartender Stuart Humphries takes a thoroughly modern approach to his Golden Handcuffs cocktail, pairing Swedish punsch with Aperol and pineapple rum for a bittersweet spirituous drink.
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Strain over a large ice cube in a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with Aleppo dusted orange wheel.

title: La Chunga
intro_philosophy: Llama Inn beverage directors Lynnette Marrero and Jessica Gonzalez have created a Peruvian version of the classic Rum Buck, minus the bubbles. Ginger syrup pairs with the rich and complex chicha morada—a blend of boiled maize infused with pineapple rinds, cinnamon, cloves and apples—with a rum base and the requisite dose of lime for an update on the classic.
ingredients: 1 ounce white rum, preferably Plantation 3 Star
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients and shake.
2. Strain into a rocks glass with ice.

title: Capitol Park
intro_philosophy: “Rye and amaro is a combination that rivals peanut butter and jelly in my book,” says Dorothy Elizabeth, who once spent a summer attempting to try every whiskey and amaro combination before landing on her favorite: Woodford Reserve rye and Cardamaro. “Simply love at first sight,” she says. Here, the mixture is complemented by a measure of herbal liqueur and three types of bitters.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Bitter Truth EXR Bitter Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated orange wheel.

title: Dreams of Alebrijes
intro_philosophy: “This one is…in my style of kind of weird but good,” says Annie Williams Pierce, “I wanted to create this kind of green prickly sort of cocktail… but it’s also frothy and floral.” Tequila provides a charred, grassy backbone while almost a near ounce ofSuzeand Cardamaro bring a green, bitter herbaceousness to the mix;rosé syrupadds brightness, and texture comes courtesy ofaquafaba. Williams Pierce adds the finishing touches with ground fennel pollen and dehydrated raspberry dust sprinkled over the top.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  malic acid solution (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake without ice.
2. Add ice, and shake again quickly.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with fennel pollen and raspberry dust.

title: Monkey Fizz
intro_philosophy: Monkey Fizz will trick you with its texture—it’s clear and fizzy but the mouthfeel is heavier than you’d expect. The coconut oil- and cacao butter-infused gin give it heaps of richness while makrut lime provides a spicy and zesty kick.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces coconut and cacao gin (see Editor's Note)
1 1/2 ounces makrut lime syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Stir to combine.

title: Emotional Rescue
intro_philosophy: “The Emotional Rescue is easily defined as a Manhattan variation in its basic anatomy,” explains Karen Fu of Brooklyn’s Donna, “but it’s more about the Kina d’or, a French quinquina.” Part of an ever-expanding family of Manhattan spin-offs, the Emotional Rescue was originally dubbed the Emotionally Exhausted by the drink’s creator, Brian Miller, who took inspiration from Chad Solomon’sBensonhurst.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce quinquina, preferably Kina L’Avion d’Or
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: It’s Not Easy
intro_philosophy: The Green Swizzle emerged in the Caribbean hotel bars of the late 19th century, and the drink became exceedingly popular in the decades that followed. But unlike many iconic drinks of that period (like close cousin theQueen’s Park Swizzle), Green Swizzle recipes vary widely. Some are rum-based, others are made with gin, some contain crème de menthe, Angostura bitters, and/or falernum; the only real constants are lots of crushed ice and the now-forgotten ingredient: wormwood bitters. At Choy in Nashville, beverage director Abe Vucekovich has created an überpopular riff on the Green Swizzle called the It’s Not Easy, which combines tequila,génépy, pineapple, lime, green tea syrup and mint, with hints ofgreen Chartreuseand Peychaud’s bitters.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce green tea syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. In a footed pilsner glass, combine the mint leaves, tequila, syrup and génépy.
2. Let the mixture sit for 30 seconds or up to 5 minutes.
3. Add the lime and pineapple juices.
4. Add crushed ice in increments, swizzling after each addition.
5. Mound more ice atop the drink, and add a straw and mint bouquet.
6. Dash Peychaud’s bitters on top and, using an atomizer, spritz the mint with green Chartreuse.

title: Reverb
intro_philosophy: “This is a lighter take on an Old-Fashioned,” ideal for transitioning between seasons, explains Devin Kennedy, head bartender at Pouring Ribbons. He adds nutty, fruity cream sherry to amplify the baked apple and fig notes in the small-batch bourbon. Meanwhile, a housemade spiced oleo saccharum echoes the whiskey’s spice tones while providing a sustainable use for spent citrus peels.
ingredients: 2 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
1 teaspoon  Spiced Oleo Saccharum (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into rocks glass over a large cube of ice.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Leeward Negroni
intro_philosophy: Kevin Diedrich is a pandan enthusiast, using it in three different forms on Pacific Cocktail Haven’s menu: in a milk punch, as salted pandan syrup and in this Negroni riff whose name is derived from the term used for the side of an island sheltered from the wind. In this drink, pandan is incorporated via cordial, adding a nutty, tropical flavor to the traditionally bitter base, boosted with a wash of tiki bitters.
instructions: 1. Dash tiki bitters into a rocks glass. Gently rotate the glass to coat the inside with the bitters, then spill out any excess.
2. Combine the remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a fresh pandan leaf.

title: Death Valley
intro_philosophy: A riff on Death in the Afternoon, the deceptively simple build yields a nuanced, “beautifully balanced, incredibly refreshing” drink, says co-owner Justin Lavenue. The bar uses Kübler absinthe because it’s slightly sweeter than other brands, and tempers the citric acid in the lime juice and carbonic acid in the Topo Chico. The inherent salinity of the mineral water elevates the anise and fennel notes of the spirit.
ingredients: 1 bottle ice-cold Topo Chico with “a big swig taken from it”
instructions: 1. Open Topo Chico and pour off a big swig.
2. Pour the absinthe and lime juice into the Topo Chico bottle and insert a 12-inch stainless-steel straw.
3. Garnish with lime wedge, halved if necessary to fit next to the straw, and pin it in place.

title: Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: Third place in our recent Espresso Martini tastingwent toJeffrey Morgenthalerof Clyde Common in Portland, Oregon. The only victor to ask for cold brew—albeit in the form of a concentrate—the drink was otherwise standard, mixing in a three-quarter ounce each of Stoli 100 Proof vodka and Kahlua, while eschewing simple syrup. In a clandestine touch, Morgenthaler instructed a lemon peel be expressed into the mixing tin before shaking.
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a mixing tin with ice.
2. Express the lemon peel into the mixing tin, discard, then shake.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with three coffee beans.

title: Bruja Smash
intro_philosophy: “I had read in some cooking manual or been told by a chef that anise paired well with red fruits,” says Seattle bartender Andrew Bohrer on how he first started using Strega. “I first began using it in a drink with gin and fresh raspberries.” His Bruja Smash doesn’t stray too far from that early attempt and pairs Strega with tequila, lemon, mint and raspberries for a savory-fruity riff on a classic smash.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaking tin, then add ice and shake.
2. Strain over crushed ice.
3. Top with additional crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Flowers & You
intro_philosophy: “The crisp, refreshing flavor of cucumber plays well with a multitude of profiles—from vegetal and herbaceous drinks to those with more fruity and floral character,” says Lauren Corriveau. Her brandy and blanc vermouth spritz-inspired Flowers & You incorporates Fever-Tree Cucumber Tonic with a homemade grapefruit cordial and rosewater.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanc vermouth, preferably La Quintinye Blanc Vermouth Royal
2 ounces Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a wine glass filled with ice.
2. Lightly stir and garnish with a half-wheel slice of grapefruit.

title: Jacque Rose
intro_philosophy: This play on the classic Jack Rose subs in Campari for the traditional grenadine syrup. To lean even harder into the French aspect of this riff, Gina Chersevani suggests using Calvados for the brandy component.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  brandy, preferably Copper and Kings Apple Brandy
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Farmer’s Armagnac
intro_philosophy: A pun on theFarmer’s Almanac, the most ubiquitous bedside book apart from the Bible, says Boelte, in his home state of Oklahoma, the Farmer’s Armagnac builds on the classicSidecarformula, simply swapping out Cognac for Armagnac and Cointreau forBénédictine.
instructions: 1. Prepare a coupe or cocktail glass with a half sugar rim and set aside.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Lemon Simple Syrup
instructions: 1. Combine sugar, water and the zest of one lemon in small saucepan over low heat, and simmer until sugar is dissolved.
2. Let cool, stir in 1/3 cup lemon juice and fine strain into a jar or bottle.
3. Will last up to a month in the fridge.

title: Café de Olla Martini
intro_philosophy: Michael Aredesdescribes this cocktail as an “Espresso Martini with purpose and intention.” The combination of Oaxacan rum complements coffee liqueur, cold-brew coffee and “olla syrup,” a homemade cinnamon-orange sweetener that nods to Mexico’s signature café de olla.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing tin, then add 3 standard ice cubes.
2. Shake vigorously for about 10 seconds, then fine-strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a flamed orange peel, then sprinkle ground espresso over the top.

title: Guardian Deity
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

At its heart, this is a straightforward Gimlet variation, explains Takuma Watanabe, yet it’s also one that lends itself to riffing, depending on what ingredients may be readily at hand. He chose to focus on yuzu, in the form of both fresh juice and jam. The benevolent name nods to that key ingredient as well: “Yuzu, which is in season in winter, has a strong scent, and there is a popular belief that it can exterminate evil spirits,” he says.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a shiso leaf.

title: DC Summer Cobbler
intro_philosophy: “I like the salty apple tang that a splash of Manzanilla offers in addition to it also translating to chamomile in Spanish,” says Chantal Tseng of her Sherry Cobbler variation. “This version plays with my geographic location as well, with the D in Diego and the C in Cigarrera.”
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces amontillado sherry, preferably Tío Diego
1/2 ounce manzanilla sherry, preferably La Cigarrera
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients in a shaker with a few cubes of cracked ice and shake for 5 seconds.
2. Double-strain contents into a chilled rocks or highball glass and fill with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a large bunch of fresh mint, seasonal berries and grated orange zest.
4. Serve with a straw.

title: Holland Gin Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Erik Adkins is well versed in Curaçao’s versatility, showcasing the orange liqueur in the classic cocktail list alongside spirits both dark and light. Here, a small measure of Curaçao complements the juniper-heavy genever and the dash of orange bitters in his streamlined riff on Jerry Thomas’s Improved Holland Gin Cocktail, served, nontraditionally, on the rocks.
ingredients: 1 barspoon gum syrup, preferably Small Hands Food
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garish with a grapefruit peel.

title: Ta-Ke Martini
intro_philosophy:
Sweet potato shochu gives backbone to a riff on the classic Bamboo. It’s made with Tenshi no Yuwaku, a shochu aged in sherry barrels for more than seven years; the process gives it a character that some liken to a cross between a sherry and a brandy. (The name Tenshi no Yuwaku, which translates to “angel’s temptation,” is a reference to the “angel’s share”—the measure of wine or whiskey that evaporates during aging, which is said to be taken by angels.)

“It has a very oxidative sherry note that you typically get from an amontillado or oloroso, without the sweet raisin notes typically found in whiskeys that have been aged in sherry barrels,” Don Lee observes.
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Walking Papers
intro_philosophy: In this drink, New Orleans-based bartender Scott Hicks looks to Tra Kal made with Patagonian crabapple for an unexpected bitter burst alongside cranberry and citrus. “Their sharp, almost bitter taste is a welcome change to the cocktail world, where most apple-based spirits trend more towards sweet,” explains Hicks. “The concept of such a bold eau de vie with original flavors drew me in right away.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce cranberry brandy, preferably Clear Creek Cranberry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: ‘Spicy With Tequila’
intro_philosophy:
At The Pastry War, Bobby Heugel turns this drink when a guest asks for something spicy with an agave spirit. “I assume they want something more intriguing than the habanero Margarita that is on our menu,” says Heugel, “So, typically, [I] offer this little number.”

A mix of tequila, green Chartreuse, lime juice, agave nectar, mint and a house-made habanero tincture, The Pastry War’s response to a “spicy, with tequila” request is undoubtedly more challenging than a spicy Margarita, with the cool sensation of mint contrasting sharply with the heat of the chile, and the unexpected herbaceousness of Chartreuse.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Shake and strain into a Collins glass with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with Tajin dusted on top, a lime and two mint sprigs.

title: Link Ray
intro_philosophy: “Suze is a beautiful, bitter modifier,” explainsJim Kearns, who highlights the versatility of the liqueur in his Link Ray—which can be built on a base of a handful of spirits while allowing the earthy aroma of Suze to play off the vegetal notes of celery juice.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces tequila, agricole rhum, gin or vodka
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients and strain into a highball over ice.
2. Top with soda and garnish with a celery frond, celery salt and a pinch of medium-ground black pepper.

title: Improved Shochu Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Kenta Goto’s (of the Japanese-style cocktail bar, Bar Goto) distant riff on theImproved Whiskey Cocktailthat combines barley shochu, aged gin and hop liqueur.
ingredients: 2 ounces barley shochu, preferably Mizu no Mai
2 teaspoons  aged gin, preferably Berkshire Ethereal Gin
instructions: 1. All all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice, and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a Sake Masu (wooden sake box).

title: Cool Aunt Pimm
intro_philosophy: Annie Williams Pierce’s take on a Pimm’s Cup pairs blanco tequila and amontillado sherry, with a stop in the kitchen pantry for raspberry preserves. The drink gets an extra bit of levity courtesy of sea salt and fresh mint; the requisite cucumber comes from Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce blanco tequila, preferably Tequila Cabeza
Heaping spoonful raspberry jam or preserves
1 1/2 ounces Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water in a mixing tin filled with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
3. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist and fresh mint (or a combination of fresh herbs like mint, cilantro and basil)

title: Songs About Keri
intro_philosophy: To make this spicy, Midori-spiked tequila highball, Poison Heart owner and general manager Andrea Ulsh took inspiration from her friend Keri Smith, who served a similar cocktail at Bar Blondeau and now works at Xanadu, both in Brooklyn, New York. Poison Heart makes its own poblano liqueur to give the cocktail a smoky kick, but at home, you can sub in Ancho Reyes Verde.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce poblano liqueur, such as Ancho Reyes Verde
sparkling mineral water, such as Topo Chico, to top
instructions: 1. Add the first five ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass with ice, then top with sparkling water.
3. Garnish with a Tajín-coated cucumber slice.

title: Coronation No. 1
intro_philosophy: There are several old cocktails that are called Coronation, but this one dates to 1903, when a Newark, New Jersey, bartender named Joseph Rose won thePolice GazetteBartender’s Contest with it. A low-ABV mix of French vermouth, sherry, maraschino liqueur and orange bitters, the drink has lived on in the world of mixology because of its inclusion in theHoffman House Bartender’s Guide(1905) andThe Savoy Cocktail Book(1930). At Fedora in New York, Ben Finkelstein carefully chooses each ingredient to create a cocktail that he says “drinks like a little curated glass of wine.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces dry vermouth, such as Mauro Vergano Sec
3/4 ounce fino sherry, such as Lustau Jarana
1 barspoon maraschino liqueur, such as Luxardo
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until well chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: L’Alligator C’est Vert
intro_philosophy:
This story is published in partnership with P(our), a symposium devoted to exploring new ideas and exchanging inspiration about the drinks industry, and beyond. The annual event promotes discussions and presentations that address issues critical to the trade; this year’s theme is “perfection.” The event is taking place in Paris on June 3rd—for more information, and for tickets,click here.

Nico de Soto knows that “the perfect drink would be perfect for everyone”—and a drink like that does not exist. Rather, he looks for perfection within his own personal favorite ingredients, such as the nutty pandan herb, which he has here developed into a syrup. Coconut milk adds texture and tropical vibes, tempered by a full ounce of a quintessential Parisian ingredient, absinthe.
ingredients: 1 ounce Pandan Syrup, see Editor's note
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake for 12 seconds.
3. Double-strain into a flip glass.
4. Garnish with nutmeg.

title: Jägerita
intro_philosophy: The Jägerita is essentially a standard Margarita with tequila swapped out in favor of the aughts’ most bro-tastic party shot, Jägermeister. Despite how it may sound on paper, the drink has gone on to win over the bar world, becoming a modern classic along the way.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe and garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Post Modern
intro_philosophy: At Manhattan’s Dear Irving, Tom Richter bases his Post Modern on a spirited combination of oft-overlooked sloe gin and Scotch, rinsed with absinthe. “Sloe gin has been around for a long time,” says Richter, “and is just itching to start being used as a more common modifier.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker, and add ice.
2. Shake until chilled and strain into an absinthe-rinsed coupe.

title: Blessed Thistle
intro_philosophy: Based on the classic framework of aNegroni—equal parts strong, bitter and sweet—A16 Rockridge’s Blessed Thistle replaces sweet vermouth with CioCiaro and Cardamaro. CioCiaro’s earthiness pairs well with gin’s herbaceous backbone and Campari’s bittersweet tang, while Cardamaro provides a wine-like quality maintaining the aromatic and dry qualities of sweet vermouth. The name is a nod to blessed thistle, a plant believed to have medicinal properties often used in amaro production.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain over a large rock into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Latin Trifecta
intro_philosophy: Drawing on ingredients from romance language-speaking countries, the Latin Trifecta honors Spain, Italy and Mexico with the strong and savory trio of tequila, sherry and Cynar. Seattle bartender Jamie Boudreau says, “Tequila and sherry have always been great friends, and adding the bittersweet complexity of an amaro elevates the pairing.” Indeed, the three form a perfect trio.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a flamed orange twist.

title: Kapri Robinson’s Adonis
intro_philosophy: Kapri Robinson favors the Adonis so much that she pulled it out for an elimination challenge on Netflix’sDrink Masters. Not only does she prize the complementary relationship between the amontillado sherry and sweet vermouth in her spec, she also appreciates the drink’s low-ABV profile, which appeals to more than a few modern drinkers.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces amontillado sherry, preferably Lustau Los Arcos
1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with an expressed orange peel.

title: Negroni Shakerato
intro_philosophy: Not quite a riff on the Negroni, the Shakerato is simply a different treatment of the Negroni. Where the three-ingredient drink is a stirred cocktail, without exception, this version takes Campari, sweet vermouth and gin, and shakes them into an icy, pink froth. It’s then further turned on its head with the addition of a Castelvetrano olive garnish—a nod tothe Italian Futurist art movement, which was often less about ingredients and more about expectations—or rather, the unexpected.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and shake vigorously until ice begins to break into very small pieces.
2. Strain into a rocks glass and garnish with three Castelvetrano olives on a cocktail skewer.

title: French 75
intro_philosophy: Named after a French gun used in World War I—a not-so-subtle nod to the drink’s lethalness—this Champagne cocktail was made famous at Harry’s New York Bar in Paris in the early 1900s. Some historical records cite Cognac as the original base spirit, which would make sense on account of the drink’s Gallic origins. Somewhere in translation, however, gin became a common base, though many bars, includingFrench 75bar in New Orleans, still use Cognac as the base.
instructions: 1. Add first three ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe or a flute and top with sparkling wine.
4. Garnish with a long curling peel of lemon.

title: Sobacha Fizz
intro_philosophy: AtFirstbornin Los Angeles,Kenzo Hanputs their tea expertise into practice across the cocktail menu: Deeply fermented green pu-erh tea stars in a Kingston Negroni riff; toasty hojicha drives the nonalcoholic milk punch. Here, earthy sobacha (toasted buckwheat) flavors a bourbon fizz. Han describes this drink as “essentially a Gold Rush made into a fizz,” with Amaro Ramazzotti bringing some bitter citrus notes to the drink. The finishing touch is a grating of buckwheat over the top of the drink. “It functions as the bitters on top of a Whiskey Sour,” says Han, “and provides a delicious toasty aroma.”
ingredients: 2/3 ounce honey syrup (2:1, honey to water)
instructions: 1. Combine the first five ingredients in a cocktail shaker without ice and dry-shake.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a fizz glass, then top with soda.
4. Garnish with grated sobacha on top.

title: The Dead Rabbit Irish Coffee No. 2
intro_philosophy: This “workshopped” version of The Dead Rabbit’s Irish Coffee varies only slightly from theoriginal versionserved at the bar, showcasing a light-bodied whiskey and slightly richer sugar syrup than previously used. The glassware is key: Dead Rabbit uses a six-ounce tulip-shaped glass to showcase the drink.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces blended Irish whiskey, preferably Clontarf
scant 1/2 ounce rich demerara syrup, (2:1, sugar:water)
instructions: 1. In a six-ounce glass, stir together the whiskey, demerara syrup and hot coffee.
2. In a bowl, whisk the cream until the bubbles disappear and the consistency thickens a bit.
3. Pour the cream over the top of the drink.

title: For the Good Times
intro_philosophy: New Orleans bartender Alex Anderson was inspired to complement the natural flavor and bright carbonation of Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit with a fragrant honeydew melon syrup. A serrano pepper is added to the cocktail shaker to mix and mingle with tequila, vermouth and lime, resulting in a sweet and slightly vegetal highball with a spicy kick.
ingredients: 1 ounce  Montanaro Vermouth di Torino Rosso
instructions: 1. Place the serrano pepper slices in a mixing tin, then pour in the tequila, vermouth, honeydew syrup and lime juice.
2. Fill the mixing tin with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Add the grapefruit soda to a Collins glass, and fill the glass with fresh ice.
4. Fine-strain the contents of the shaker into the glass.
5. Garnish with a serrano pepper.

title: The Simple Sussex
intro_philosophy: Created for Liberty in Seattle, where it was a top seller: “It’s basically a Martini on the rocks with a twist,” he says, describing it as “simple, clean, gin-forward,” with ingredients that “lift each other up.” This is emblematic of his drink-making style, he says, describing that as “effortless and approachable—nothing too complicated.”
ingredients: ¾ ounce  Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir together all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass, over a large ice cube
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Cafecito
intro_philosophy: Ginsberg and Figueroa’s Cafecito—named after the classic Cuban coffee serve, which consists of espresso and sugar whipped together to yield a distinctive layer of crema—highlights the natural affinity between Cognac and coffee in an unexpected way. They recommend using larger ice cubes or chunks of ice to shake the drink to better stand up to the fresh shot of hot espresso and minimize the risk of overdilution. The final flourish, a dusting of dark cocoa powder, is intended to evoke the experience of an espresso-soaked tiramisu.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  almond orgeat (see Editor’s Note), or use high-quality commercial orgeat
1 ounce  fresh espresso, preferably Ethiopian coffee
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with dark cocoa powder sifted through a powdered sugar shaker.

title: Hawaiian Cocktail
intro_philosophy: The apple brandyHawaiian Cocktailis (probably) a long-lost pineapple-and-Chartreuse sour that’s dear to Thad Vogler’s heart. He first revived it for the opening of the French brandy–focused bar Trou Normand (which has since shuttered) and is bringing it back once again for his Bar Agricole pop-up at Quince. It’s a favorite of both Vogler and his guests, all of whom appreciate the drink’s velvety, lush texture and continental-meets-tropical flavor profile. He has used both green Chartreuse and Chartreuse’s limited-release Tau Tarragona—a blend of roughly 70 percent yellow Chartreuse to 30 percent green—but this recipe calls for yellow.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce pineapple gum syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Vesper
ingredients: 1 part vodka, preferably Absolut Elyx Vodka
instructions: 1. Stir the liquid ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
2. Garnish with the lemon twist.

title: Ritz-Carlton Tokyo Martini
intro_philosophy: Inspired byo-toso, an infused sake typically enjoyed in Japan around the new year, this Martini from the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo blends cherry blossom vermouth, mirin and two types of bitters to replicate the herbal, medicinal flavor.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces London dry gin, preferably No.3
heavy 3/4 ounce gin, preferably Bobby’s Schiedam Dry Gin
5 milliliters (1 teaspoon) mirin, preferably Saijo Shiro Mirin
1 dash The Japanese Bitters shiso bitters
1 dash The Japanese Bitters yuzu bitters
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.

title: Christine Wiseman’s White Claw Cocktail
intro_philosophy: In what she calls a “weird variation on a Negroni,”Christine Wiseman‘s White Claw cocktail of choice combines a split base of gin and Campari with sweet vermouth over crushed ice, and finishes it off with an ounce each of both tangerine- (in lieu of orange zest) and watermelon-flavored White Claw.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the White Claw, in a glass over crushed ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with watermelon and tangerine White Claw.

title: Vesper
intro_philosophy:
A true Bond-style cocktail, the Vesper was first mentioned by writer Ian Fleming in his 1953 novel,Casino Royale, as a drink order detailed by Bond himself. He specifies a strong formula of vodka, gin and Kina Lillet, “shaken, not stirred,” of course. Some historians have speculated that Bond slipped up in specifying Kina Lillet—a quinine-flavored white wine aperitif whose distillery also produced vermouth—intending for vermouth all along. The formula for Lillet has since changed, circa mid-1980s, making way for a new lighter, sweeter version with a lower dosage of quinine. As such, the classic Vesper specs may drown out the delicacy of Lillet’s contemporary recipe. To remedy, PUNCH suggests upping the proportion of Lillet. However, Cocchi Americano, a bittersweet Italian aperitivo, is probably the most accurate substitute for the Kina Lillet of days gone by. And though Bond said “shake,” we most definitely say, “stir.”

ingredients: 1/2 - 3/4 ounce Lillet Blanc (or 1/2 ounce Cocchi Americano)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Pandora
intro_philosophy: A.O.C.’s Christiaan Röllich looks to the kitchen for the inspiration behind his Pandora, which builds on a base of housemade cherry compote (which had been mistakenly placed on his back bar) and finishes with blonde ale and pisco.
ingredients: 1 ounce pisco, preferably Campo de Encanto
3/4 ounce A.O.C. cherry compote (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients and dry shake.
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Fine strain into a coupe glass.
4. Garnish with brandied cherries.

title: Frozen Margarita
intro_philosophy: The ideal consistency for a frozen Margarita should be that of “barely melted soft-serve ice cream,” says Travis Tober, co-owner of Nickel City in Austin, Texas. He recommends using a Vitamix or three-speed Hamilton Beach commercial bar blender, but ice, he believes, is the most critical ingredient. Rather than plain ice, Tober uses cubes of frozen orange pekoe tea to complement the Cointreau and add a touch of tannin to the mix.
ingredients: 1 ounce lime juice blend (3:1, Persian lime juice:Key lime juice)
1/2 ounce rich simple syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
1/2 cup Iced Tea cubes (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. If using, rim a glass with salt or Tajín.
2. Combine the tequila, lime juice, Cointreau and simple syrup in a blender with Iced Tea cubes.
3. Blend for 5 seconds on the lowest speed, then blend at high speed for 10 seconds.
4. Pour into the prepared glass, and garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.

title: White Mezcal Negroni
intro_philosophy: Thewine-based gentian liqueurused in this recipe in lieu of Suze adds an extra-bitter element that complements the base spirit and blanc vermouth for a drink that has far more depth than its three ingredients would suggest: It’s minerally, herbal and bitter, but not all at once, creating layers of flavor that evolve with each sip.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Alessio Vermouth Bianco
1/2 ounce Domaine La Bohème Gentiane Extra Bitter Aperitif
instructions: 1. Combine in a mixing glass with ice and stir briefly for five seconds.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube or whatever ice you have.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist expressed over the drink, then discarded.

title: Cooper’s Nightcap
intro_philosophy: Jamie Boudreau’s nightcap is meant to resolve a complex meal. The drink is versatile, “replicating an amaro for those times when one has a big dinner but the restaurant does not stock amari,” explains Boudreau. “Most restaurants will have the three ingredients listed, and [thus] a happy stomach can now be had in most places.”
instructions: 1. Layer the ingredients in a shot glass in the order listed.

title: Boulevardier
intro_philosophy: Erskine Gwynne was an individual of epic reputation across Paris in the 1920s. A true man-about-town andboulevardierin the literal sense of the word, Gwynne ran a magazine of the same name for American ex-pats living in Paris. Mention of this literary-influenced cocktail appears in Harry MacElhone’s (owner of Harry’s New York Bar in Paris) 1927 bookBarflies and Cocktails, crediting Gwynne as the drink’s creator. Depending on its permutation, the Boulevardier can be seen as a bittersweetManhattanvariation or a whiskeyNegroni. The true beauty of the Boulevardier is its adaptability to bitter and sweet, so depending on the base spirit, an array of amari andvermouthcan be used to play to the chosen whiskey’s strengths.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass, or strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Tokyo Iced Tea
intro_philosophy: True, it’s not consumed at the frequency of the Long Island Iced Tea, nor even the frequency of the blue Curaçao variant—theAdios, Motherfucker, which remains popular on the West Coast—but the Tokyo Iced Tea was still present enough in the mid-aughts that California restaurateur Guy Fieri whipped up a batch on a Season 2 episode ofGuy’s Big Bitein 2007, pairing it with spicy tangerine beef for a “Far East” dinner. “That’ll be a party favorite!” Fieri exclaims, as he pops several novelty straws into a fish-shaped punch bowl.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce unaged or lightly aged rum
instructions: 1. Combine the first seven ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Top with lemon-lime soda.
4. Garnish with a lemon wheel and a cherry.

title: Chutni Gimlet
intro_philosophy: “When thinking about the history of the Gimlet, I always think about the creation of lime cordial,” says Maiko, Daijoubu’s co-operator. So for this Gimlet variation, she built a lime chutney cordial featuring ginger, raisin and—more unusually—garlic to echo some of the rich, savory notes found in the finish of the Jin Jiji gin.
ingredients: 2 ounces  Jin Jiji India Dry Gin
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into coupe glass.
3. Garnish with cilantro sprig.

title: Spritz Olympia
intro_philosophy: This bubbly, garnet-hued drink featuring a housemade sorrel soda pays homage to two Jamaican artists: painter-sculptor Christopher González and reggae star Bob Marley. The “three little birds” that garnish the drink refer to the title of the popular Marley song.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
3 ounces  chamomile sorrel soda (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into an 8-ounce wine glass over fresh ice.
3. Twist a thick swath of lemon peel over the glass to express essential oils.
4. Trim the lemon peel to resemble three little birds. Secure with a cocktail pick, and use to garnish the drink.
5. Drop allspice berries into cocktail.

title: Morning Glory Fizz
intro_philosophy: From the name, it can be assumed this drink by late-1800s bartender Harry Johnson belongs in the canon of classic hair-of-the-dog hangover remedies. A potent blend of Scotch and absinthe, the Morning Glory Fizz’s rough edges are smoothed over with silky egg white and a splash of soda to quell the pangs of a hangover headache. An orange garnish brightens the boozy aroma and calls one to face the day with renewed vigor.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake until well-chilled, and top up with soda.
4. Garnish with an orange peel or orange wheel.

title: Joaquín Simó’s Manhattan
intro_philosophy: Landing on the podium at both our2016and2023Manhattan blind tastings, Joaquín Simó’s recipe fractures each component in half—splitting the whiskey between Rittenhouse rye and Russell’s Reserve 10-year bourbon, the sweet vermouth between Cinzano 1757 and Martelletti Classico, and the bitters between the traditional Angostura and Dale DeGroff’s pimento bitters. That final flourish adds noticeable baking spice to the equation, resulting in a drink that is rich, robust and soothing in a way only a Manhattan can be.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: Show Me State
intro_philosophy:
Robert Sachse’s Show Me State started as a riff on the Jungle Bird before getting transformed almost entirely: orange juice replaced pineapple juice, Campari was exchanged for mezcal and dry curacao replaced the blackstrap rum, turning the Show Me State into a citrus-driven, smoky cocktail all its own.

“Guests will always look around and get lost in how many bottles in the bar they don’t recognize, or how many ingredients in the cocktail list they’ve never heard of before,” says Sachse. “That doesn’t happen with frozen drinks. They’ll see the slushy machine, the malt mixer, the blender and point and say to give them ‘whatever comes out of that.’”

Special thanks to our friends atWest Elmfor outfitting ourfrozen drinks photoshoot.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender, and add ice (about 5-6 regular-sized cubes, cracked).
2. Blend until smooth and pour into a glass.
3. Garnish with a floating lime wheel with an American flag standing ceremoniously on top.

title: Negroni Absinthe
intro_philosophy: “I’m obsessed with cacao and mezcal together,” says Sarah Morrissey of this nuanced riff on the mezcal Negroni, which calls for a quarter-ounce splash of crème de cacao. In addition to the smoky mezcal, Atamán vermouth, a sherry-based vermouth from Spain, is a featured player in the drink. “It’s a really special vermouth, a little sweet, with bitter herb notes and dark chocolate on the back end.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, preferably Agave de Cortés
1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Atamán vermouth rosso
1/4 ounce crème de cacao blanc, preferably Giffard
instructions: 1. Coat the interior of a cocktail glass with 3 spritzes of absinthe.
2. In a mixing glass, add the remaining ingredients and ice, then stir until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Una Vita da Signori
intro_philosophy: At his cocktail bar near the Vatican, Massimo D’Addezio combines mezcal and Martini Gran Lusso with bitter flavors and an amaro infused with quinine and bitter orange.
ingredients: 1 1/3 ounces mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
1 1/3 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Martini Gran Lusso
4 dashes amaro, preferably Petrus Boonekamp Amaro
instructions: 1. In an Old-Fashioned glass, combine the mezcal, vermouth, China Clementi and amaro.
2. Add ice cubes and stir until chilled.
3. Garnish with licorice root.

title: Bee Is for Bourbon
intro_philosophy: Casey finds Elijah Craig such a pleasant-drinking neat pour that his Old-Fashioned remains bourbon-heavy, at a ratio of nearly 10-to-1. He complements his favorite notes in the bourbon with three matching liqueurs: one honey-based, one banana, and the final, cocoa bean. But they’re used in such small proportions that the drink never gets too sweet—this is a true bourbon lover’s cocktail.
ingredients: ¼ ounce  Giffard Banane du Brésil
1 barspoon  Tempus Fugit Crème de Cacao
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Artichoke Hold
intro_philosophy: It may seem like an odd coupling, but St-Germain (an elderflower liqueur) and Cynar (a bitter artichoke amaro) play surprisingly well together, especially in tiki-style drinks. It’s a combination that New York bartender Jeremy Oertel uses in his playfully-titled Artichoke Hold at Brooklyn cocktail barDonna. “This cocktail is actually a play on a play,” he says. “I did a cocktail called theBitter Mai Tai, and this is its relative.” The warm funk of Smith & Cross creates a heavy base for the bittersweet commingling of amaro and elderflower.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add a small amount of ice and shake lightly.
3. Strain over crushed ice into a rocks glass.
4. Top with more crushed ice and garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Gin Fizz
intro_philosophy: The gin iteration of the classic 19th-century fizz template may be the most famous, but rightly so, especially when it comes to warm-weather drinking. The herbal, citrusy character of the base spirit shows well alongside the sweet-sour combo of citrus and simple syrup, all lightened by soda water and egg white. Note, the fizz is not served over ice—it’s meant to be slurped quickly and efficiently without the addition of extra dilution.
instructions: 1. Add gin, lemon juice, simple syrup and an egg white to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a fizz or highball glass.
4. Top with soda water.

title: Soil Expedition
intro_philosophy: At True Laurel in San Francisco, bartender Nicolas Torres has experimented with a fair number of ambitious non-alcoholic cocktails. For the Soil Expedition, he wanted to recreate the flavors of root beer, using kefir grains as a fermentable base. He blends the resulting mixture with Seedlip Spice and Grove to create a naturally acidic, herbaceous cocktail that Torres says “tastes like A&W, but with a lengthier ride of roots and kombucha tang.”
ingredients: ½ teaspoon  caramel coloring (see Editor’s Note)
2 ½ grams  dried kefir grains, bloomed into kefir water cultures (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for Seedlip Spice 94, Seedlip Grove 42 and kefir water cultures in a pot and bring to a simmer, stirring frequently to dissolve sugar. Let simmer for 5 minutes, remove from heat and cover. Leave to sit overnight to fully absorb all the botanical flavors.
2. The next day, fine-strain the mixture into a Mason jar and compost the spent roots. Add both Seedlips to the sweet root tea and stir generously.

3. Strain the kefir water cultures and discard the water. Add the strained cultures to your mixture, gently stir, and let sit for at least 30 minutes. Strain cultures from the mixture (you can use them again).
4. Optionally, you can force-carbonate the mixture at this point. Store in refrigerator for up to two weeks.
5. To serve, pour over ice in a highball glass and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Hot Buttered Rhum Cider
intro_philosophy:
This drink appears on our list every winter. You can smell the mulled cider being heated when you approach the bar. This strong, hot, rich drink is shelter from a cold San Francisco night.

Reprinted with permission fromThe Slanted Doorby Charles Phan © 2014. Published by Ten Speed Press. Photography © 2014 by Ed Anderson.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce aged Haitian rum (preferably Barbancourt 8 year)
1 tablespoon spiced compound butter (see Editor's Note)
6 ounces mulled apple cider (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add rum, mulled cider and compound butter into a sauce pan and heat until the butter has dissolved and the liquid is steaming.
2. Pour into a heat proof mug.
3. Garnish with a cinnamon stick, star anise and a disc of orange peel studded with a clove.

title: Dale DeGroff’s Whiskey Smash
intro_philosophy: The smash, as a category of drink, had been lost to time whenDale DeGroffput out this fresh-fruit answer to theMint Julepin 1988.
instructions: 1. Muddle syrup, water, lemon and mint in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add bourbon. Shake with ice until chilled.
3. Strain into rocks glass over crushed ice.
4. Garnish with mint sprig.

title: Jack Rose
intro_philosophy: According to David Embury’sThe Fine Art of Mixing Drinks, the Jack Rose was, during the mid-20thcentury, a pillar of basic cocktail-mixing knowledge. The origin of its name is disputed: some credit it to an early 20th-century hit man called “Bald Jack Rose,” while others connect it to Jersey City bartender Frank J. May, who was also known as Jack Rose. What is certain is that the Jack Rose isa New Jersey cocktail through and through. Its American apple brandy base, applejack (a.k.a. “Jersey Lightning”), is one of the country’s oldest continuously-produced spirits and Laird’s in New Jersey remains its largest producer to this day.
tags: The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Natoma St.
intro_philosophy: “My manager at a not-to-be-named restaurant I worked at four years ago asked for something Negroni-like that wouldn’t knock him on his ass, something he could continue to drink all shift long,” says Trick Dog’s Caitlin Laman. Her answer: a low-proof Negroni riff consisting of sherry and bitter-yet-rich Gran Classico, balanced out with dry vermouth that Laman describes as a “refreshing, herbal, bitter, sherry-driven cocktail that you can drink all night long.” Amen.
ingredients: 1 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Hidalgo Napoleon
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass with one large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: The Violet Hour’s Grenadine
intro_philosophy: Reducing some–but not all–of the pomegranate juice helps retain its natural acidity, resulting in a vibrant, lively grenadine that contributes tartness as well as sweetness to a cocktail, with orange peel further brightening its fresh fruit flavor.
ingredients: 6 cups pomegranate juice, divided into 4 cups and 2 cups
instructions: 1. Heat 4 cups of pomegranate juice in a saucepan over medium heat.
2. Bring to a boil, then reduce and simmer until the volume is reduced by half.
3. Add the remaining 2 cups of fresh pomegranate juice and the sugar and continue to simmer, stirring, until sugar has dissolved.
4. Remove from heat and add salt and orange peels, expressing peels into the liquid before adding.
5. Cool completely and remove peels before using.
6. Stored in the refrigerator, this grenadine will keep at least two weeks.

title: Negroni Alla Fiama
intro_philosophy: ANegronimade breakfast-ready, the Alla Fiama pulls back the classic’s proportions to be slightly lower proof and adds freshly-squeezed peach juice to mimic the a.m. style of a Bellini. Instead of Campari, bartender Douglas Derrick uses Cappelletti Vino Aperitivo, another historic bitter Italian ingredient made from a wine-base and produced in the Alto Adige region. Sweet vermouth is replaced with Oregon’sImbue Petal & Thorn vermouth, an amaro-inspired herbal ingredient made from a base of Oregon-grown pinot gris.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a wine glass.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig and toasted almond dust (optional).

title: Capri Sour
intro_philosophy: The eponymous sour at Los Angeles’ Capri Club varies by the season. The bright, bittersweet cocktail is always made with mezcal and Amaro Meletti as the base, but the bar uses different “house red bitter blends” that mix options like Contratto Bitter, Bordiga Bitter, Tuvè Bitter and more. This ingredient is used across multiple drinks, from the Capri Sour to the bar’s boilermaker, in which the red blend subs in for Campari in a 50/50 Ferrari shot. At home, Campari oryour own red bitter blendworks just as well.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, preferably Agua del Sol
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a Luxardo cherry and a lemon peel.

title: Use Your Illusion II
intro_philosophy: Noticing Mikkeller Subway Mosaic’s blueberry notes, The Rockwell Place bartender Alex Kveton incorporated the IPA into a cocktail syrup paired with blackberry liqueur in this shaken mezcal cocktail.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce blackberry liqueur, preferably Giffard Crème de Mûre
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake until chilled, then strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a blackberry on a pick.

title: Road Runner
intro_philosophy: A more baroque take on the classic Whiskey & Cola (that leans ever-so-closely to Ramos Fizz territory), Alex Jump’s inspiration was to make an easy-drinking cocktail fit for both a “high-falutin’” Southern cocktail bar or the back porch after dinner. The drink is built on a base ofNew York Distilling Co.’sRagtime Rye, which is made in Brooklyn and was one of the first spirits to garner the designation of “Empire Rye”— a class of rye that must be produced in-state, using at least 75 percent New York–grown grain. Peanut-infused amontillado sherry provides some heft and depth, while lemon juice and theFever-Tree Distillers Colacut the richness.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  peanut-infused Lustau amontillado sherry (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the soda, and dry shake.
2. Add ice, then shake vigorously.
3. Strain into a chilled fizz glass, and top with Fever-Tree Distillers Cola.

title: Absinthe Frappé New Orleans
intro_philosophy: “Be sure to shake this cocktail extra long and extra hard,” Scott Baird advises. “It needs the dilution. It makes the drink shine.” In fact, don’t worry about over-shaking it, he adds: “You can beat it up and it still tastes great.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sweetened condensed milk syrup (1:1 water to condensed milk, stirred together)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a frappe glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with mint floret and powdered sugar.

title: Coley Negroni
intro_philosophy: Infusing Campari with coffee beans can extract their roasted, chocolatey flavor and their oiliness, which helps round out a cocktail. Erik Eastman’s Coley Negroni utilizes the complex ingredient, pairing it with bittersweet Amaro Averna in this simple riff on the classic.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces London dry gin, such as Beefeater
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with plenty of ice and stir thoroughly to combine and dilute.
2. Strain into a chilled lowball glass over a large ice cube, and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: The Mess-cal
intro_philosophy: “A guy came into my bar and, without any prompting, asked me to make him a drink that was a mockup of a rabid polar bear wrestling a naked clown,” says Toby Cecchini, who, unsurprisingly, cites it asthe strangest drink request he’s ever gotten. The resulting cocktail, The Mess-cal, is a mega-sized take on the unorthodox prompt. Says Cecchini, “I can’t account for the drink’s balance or subtlety, but he said I nailed it dead.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces white rum, preferably Plantation White 3 Stars
1/2 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Rhum J.M. Blanc
1/2 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Minero
1/2 ounce Bigallet Viriana China China Amer
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients over ice in a mixing glass and stir.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over one large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a large grapefruit peel.

title: Cold in the Shadows
intro_philosophy:
An ode to Northern California, the Cold in the Shadows hints at San Francisco’s chilly umbra, even in the warmest of months. Each ingredient is connected to the region—the IPA from the Anderson Valley, Campari, whose headquarters are housed in San Francisco, and St. George from Alameda—and blended together in what drinks like a bitter shandy.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail, with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce raspberry liqueur, preferably St. George
instructions: 1. Combine the Campari, raspberry liqueur, honey syrup and lime juice in a shaker.
2. Shake quickly with a couple of ice cubes, then add the IPA.
3. Strain into a highball glass over crushed ice and garnish.

title: In Bokeh
intro_philosophy: Riffing on the photographic technique of bokeh—employing a shallow depth of field while the subject remains sharp—bartender Emilio Salehi starts by putting the gin in focus. Candew melon, a cantaloupe-honeydew hybrid, is employed for its soft sweetness, representing a “dreamy background.” Floral and herbal notes from the pink rose bitters and Thai lime complement the fruit, while a shisho falernum highlights nutty, green, peppery flavor profiles in the gin.
ingredients: 1/2 parts  candew melon–infused bianco vermouth  (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 parts  red shiso falernum  (see Editor’s Note)
4 dashes  pink rose bitters  (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients into a mixing glass and stir well with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass with a large cube.
3. Express a grapefruit twist over the cocktail. Discard.
4. Garnish with makrut lime leaf–compressed melon cube and micro shiso leaf.

title: Jake Powell’s Oaxaca Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Jake Powell’s take on the modern classic simply adds mole bitters to the equation, a move that the drink’s creator, Phil Ward, found to be a successful one. “It’s a good direction to go in,” noted Ward ata blind tasting of Oaxaca Old-Fashioneds, in which Powell’s recipe was among the top vote-getters.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces reposado tequila, preferably Tequila Ocho
1/2 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Chichicapa
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Express an orange twist over the drink, then use to garnish.

title: Dutch Kills’ Last Word
intro_philosophy: The unanimous winner of our recentLast Word tasting, this recipe manages to balance the hard-hitting ingredients with ease. Upon the drink’s arrival, one judge, Tom Wolfson, observed: “Even just visually, this looks like what a Last Word should look like.” Lizzie Munro, Punch’s art director, found it to be “sweet in the right way, tart in the right way,” almost like a limesicle. By splitting the Maraska with simple syrup, Boccato avoided the tendency for the liqueur to dry out the drink too much, and the lime twist gave it a welcome aromatic pop. “If I go to a bar and I order a Last Word and I get that,” said Wolfson, “I’m happy.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Maraska maraschino syrup (equal parts Maraska liqueur and simple syrup)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker with a single Hundredweight or similar large-format ice cube.
2. Shake vigorously and strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express a lime twist over the surface of the drink and discard.
4. Sink a maraschino cherry into the cocktail and serve.

title: Polar Bear
intro_philosophy: A cool and smoky riff on a Stinger, Trick Dog’s Polar Bear cocktail is simple, yet highly effective. Instead of gin, there is toasty mezcal mixed with a measure of sweet white vermouth and a splash of crème de menthe layered with the herbal aromatics of angelica all shaken up Stinger-style. Cool, white, warming and stealthy—just like a polar bear.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crème de menthe (preferably Tempus Fugit)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass or coupe.

title: Bee Keeper
intro_philosophy: Rachel Sergi, head bartender at The Next Whiskey Bar at The Watergate Hotel, is a regular Dewar’s drinker. “It plays really well with pineapple,” she says, a pairing that inspired this riff on aWhiskey Sour: “I wanted to do a whiskey sour with bite.” Pineapple comes into play as part of a white-pepper cordial, and the drink gets a dramatic flourish thanks to the lemon-honey espuma floating on top.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Scotch, preferably Dewar's White Label
3/4 ounce white pepper-pineapple cordial (see Editor's Note)
lemon-honey espuma, to top (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the espuma in a rocks glass over ice.
2. Top with espuma and grate lemon zest.

title: Tiger Biz
intro_philosophy:
This biz is used to add some sweetness and body to the Tiger Lily, a mezcal and coriander-infused blanco tequila cobbler.

Try it in aVenus Fly Trap,Take Your TimeorMargarita.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bottle, seal and store refrigerated for up to two weeks.

title: Ajax Punch
intro_philosophy:
Gary Hayward’s Embers Ski Lodge delivers a little mountain charm to Nashville, and the Ajax Punch, named after a patio bar at the base of the gondola on Aspen Mountain, features white rum with refreshing muddled cucumber and watermelon, topped decadently with sparkling wine.

“The Ajax has been really popular this summer… It’s nice for the bartenders to be able to whip up several drinks at a time,” says Hayward. “And when you’re at home, punches are perfect for entertaining a large group.”
instructions: 1. Put a palm full of cubed watermelon and cucumber pieces in a tall glass, and muddle until juiced.
2. Squeeze one lime half into glass, discard rind.
3. Fill glass with ice, add rum and simple syrup.
4. Top with sparkling wine.
5. Stir gently and garnish with basil leaves and watermelon spear.

title: Night Or Day Vesper
intro_philosophy: At the Denver’s Cooper Lounge, guests can customize their Vesper selection by choosing between either Smogóry Forest or Lake Bartężek from Belvedere Vodka’s Single Estate Rye series. “People get to compare and contrast,” says Brittany Barbery, Assistant General Manager. The gameplan for the classic drink, inspired by James Bond’s drink order inCasino Royale, is simple: Let the base spirit shine. In this instance, the terroir of either vodka selection becomes the focus, with Smogóry Forest lending savoriness and Lake Bartężek offering a fresher, peppery drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces Belvedere Smogóry Forest or Lake Bartężek vodka
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Edgewater Beach
intro_philosophy: In the pages of Ted Saucier’s 1951 bookBottoms Up,Paul McGeehappened upon the Edgewater Beach, a mixture of Jamaican rum, sweet vermouth, lemon, sugar and orange bitters—along with one quarter of a preserved peach. Here, he reworks the recipe with a split base of overproof and gold rums, and swaps the original lemon for lime. But the muddled canned peaches remain.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce overproof rum, preferably Hampden Estate
3/4 ounce gold rum, preferably Rum-Bar Gold
1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi di Torino
3/4 ounce lime juice, plus the spent hull
instructions: 1. Combine peaches, sugar, lime juice and lime hull in a mixing tin and muddle.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and shake with ice.
3. Double strain into a chilled coupe glass.

title: Speyside Sunset
intro_philosophy: You don’t often think “spritz” when you think of Scotch, but the subtle notes of apple and pear in addition to warming notes of cinnamon and vanilla found in Glen Moray’s Classic Chardonnay Cask Finish set it up as the perfect base for a refreshing wintertime spritz. The delicate, semisweet blanc vermouth gets an added herbal kick with a brief infusion of fresh thyme. You can mix up the serve here by using a classic Collins glass with a long, clear ice spear or a more spritz-friendly wine glass filled with cracked ice.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces  Glen Moray Speyside Classic Single Malt Scotch Whisky (Chardonnay Cask Finish)
1 ounce  Thyme-Infused Blanc Vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the Scotch, infused vermouth and bitters to a chilled Collins glass or wine glass filled with cracked ice.
2. Top with sparkling wine.
3. Garnish with fresh thyme and lemon zest.

title: Dante’s Bicicletta
intro_philosophy: The Bicicletta is a bitter spritz-like drink of mid-1930s origin made with Campari, dry white Italian wine and club soda. Dante’s version gets a lemon wheel and slightly reduced measure of Campari.
instructions: 1. Add the Campari and dry white wine in a footed highball glass filled with ice.
2. Top with soda water, and garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: T Stagg Slide
intro_philosophy: The T Stagg Slide takes inspiration from a classic Mudslide, combining bourbon, coffee liqueur, date syrup and cream, all buzzed in a stand-up drink mixer with crushed ice and finished with a dusting of cinnamon and espresso. “As a greener bartender, I was fixated on what would be the most unique on paper,” explains Alicia Perry, “but as a neighborhood bar, it was really important for us to be creating a space where people feel comfortable.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably St. George Nola
5 ounces crushed ice (only if using a stand-up drink mixer)
1 pinch salt (only if using a cocktail shaker)
instructions: 1. If using a stand-up drink mixer, combine all ingredients in the tin and buzz for about 5 seconds.
2. If using a cocktail shaker, combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with a single standard ice cube until the cube melts and the drink takes on a milkshake-like texture.
3. Pour into a fizz glass.
4. Garnish with a a dusting of cinnamon and espresso and a mint sprig.

title: Pegu Club
intro_philosophy: As the British colonized their way across continental Asia in the 19thcentury, they set up outposts for their empire’s wayward explorers in an effort to provide a civilized gathering place after a long day of conquering. Each of these boys’ clubs had their own rituals and drinking rites, and the Pegu Club, located in Yangon, Myanmar, found itself at the center of British social life in 1920s. Its members, citizens of a bygone political era, knew the city as Rangoon, Burma, and this drink was their house cocktail. The Pegu Club eventually found its way into Harry’s New York Bar owner Harry MacElhone’sBarflies and Cocktailsin 1927 and was further immortalized by Audrey Saunders’ New York Citybar of the same name.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lime peel.

title: Old Figgy
intro_philosophy: Volk sees Elijah Craig as the ultimate fall spirit, evoking the flavors of the season. For his autumnal take on the Old-Fashioned, he swaps in homemade maple-fig syrup for regular sugar to amplify the fruity warmth already present in the bourbon. He feels it’s perfect for sipping outside, perhaps around a campfire.
ingredients: ½ ounce  maple-fig syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a double Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Add one large ice cube and stir 30 to 40 times.
3. Express an orange peel over the drink and discard.
4. Garnish with a skewered fresh fig half.

title: Rose Tinted Glass
intro_philosophy: In this fragrant sour, Kirk Estopinal maintains a light flavor profile by using fennel tea syrup and rose water over a Cognac base. The floral notes of rose and bright anise transform this winter classic into a springtime staple.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce fennel tea syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake and strain the drink into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a mint leaf.

title: Stone Fence
intro_philosophy:
Before raiding Fort Ticonderoga at the beginning of the Revolutionary War in 1775, Ethan Allen and the Green Mountain Boys went drinking at the Remington Tavern in Castleton, where they knocked back a mixture of rum and hard cider. Finding only a dozing guards, Allen stormed the officers’ quarters and demanded they surrender “in the name of the Great Jehovah and the Continental Congress.” The English didn’t offer Allen much resistance and Fort Ticonderoga was successfully seized, thanks in part—we like to think—to the blood-warming Stone Fence.

In Allen’s day, rum and hard cider surely were the backbone of this drink, but as time went on, whiskey production outpaced rum. This version can be tweaked to include rum, brandy or whiskey, while the addition of mint and Angostura bitters are a tip from our friends at Southern Efficiency in Washington, D.C.
ingredients: 2 ounces dark rum, brandy or bourbon/rye
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a rocks glass over ice.
2. Garnish with a mint sprig, a lemon peel or freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Hot Penicillin
intro_philosophy: Named for its so-called healing properties, the Penicillin—bartender Sam Ross’ smoky and spicy twist on a Whiskey Sour—has become a modern classic in the cocktail canon. Amanda Victoria presents a cold-weather update by warming it up, literally, with hot apple cider sweetened with a fragrant honey syrup. The familiar Scotch whisky of the original gets a spicy kick of ginger root from Fever-Tree Ginger Beer, and added brightness from fresh lemon. “It’s warming, with a smoky spice flavor,” she says, “and perfect for transitioning into winter.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Scotch, preferably Monkey Shoulder Blended Malt Scotch Whisky
1/4 ounce honey syrup  (2:1 honey to water)
instructions: 1. Temper a mug with hot water to warm.
2. Discard hot water and combine Scotch, cider, lemon juice and honey syrup in the mug.
3. Top with Fever-Tree Ginger Beer.
4. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Bitter Giuseppe
intro_philosophy: A cult favorite within the modern classic amaro cocktail canon, Stephen Cole’s Bitter Giuseppe, created at Chicago’s Violet Hour, uses Cynar as the foundation. The cocktail can be enjoyed as an aperitivo or an after-dinner digestivo and is one of several rule-breaking modern cocktails that gets stirred, rather than shaken, despite the inclusion of fresh lemon juice.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Alligator Arms
intro_philosophy: Claire Sprouse’s vermouth-based cocktail from the menu of her bar Hunky Dory, calls on a housemade celery syrup for vegetal tones, combined with lime juice and a dash of absinthe.
ingredients: 3 ounces vermouth, preferably Cinzano Extra Dry
instructions: 1. Prepare a 14oz hurricane or goblet with a salted rim.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into prepared glass over ice.

title: Blonde Redhead
intro_philosophy: A whisky-fied Negroni, the Blonde Redhead is two parts Italian (Carpano Antica sweet vermouth and barolo chinato) and one part Japanese (Yamazaki 12 year whisky)—just like the ’90s rock band it’s named for (a set of Italian twins and a Japanese singer-songwriter). Creator Douglas Derrick of Portland, OR replaced gin with Japanese whisky and Campari with barolo chinato to transform the classic formula into a digestif/late-evening riff. Served up in a coupe rimmed with Campari-infused orange peels, the drink is modeled after Japanese technique in which a single ice cube from its mixing glass is added to the cocktail to slowly melt with the drinker’s progression.
instructions: 1. Rim a coupe glass with orange dust (see Editor's Note).
2. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
3. Add ice and stir until chilled.
4. Strain into rimmed coupe glass and add one ice cube from mixing glass to the drink.
5. Express and orange peel over top and discard.

title: Bling Melon
intro_philosophy: Bookmakers beverage director Ryan Sparks doesn’t mix traditional crushes, but he does take requests for them as an opportunity to experiment. This variation cuts the natural sweetness of watermelon with spicy elements: St. George Spirits’ green chile–infused vodka and Ancho Reyes, an ancho chile–based liqueur from Puebla, Mexico.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces St. George green chile vodka
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients and serve over crushed ice.
2. Garnish with a watermelon radish slice.

title: Samgyetang Ju
intro_philosophy: Inspired by a Korean chicken soup that’s made with ginseng and other medicinal herbs, this infused soju shot is complex in flavor, yet easy to make. With notes of jujube, chestnut and licorice root, the shot—which is served at Brooklyn’sOrion Bar—is woodsy and comforting, perfect for the holiday season. Recipe from Irene Yoo’sSoju Party: How to Drink (And Eat!) Like a Korean, forthcoming from Alfred A. Knopf in fall 2025.
ingredients: 1 serving pack (25 to 30 grams) samgyetang herbs , or an equivalent mix by weight of dried ginseng, jujube, chestnut, licorice root, cinnamon, milk vetch, mulberry bark and/or angelica root
instructions: 1. In a wide-mouthed jar or glass bottle with a tight-fitting lid, combine all the ingredients.
2. Infuse for at least 3 days, or longer to your liking (a longer infusion will be richer and more syrupy), then strain.
3. Serve at room temperature.

title: Tinto de Verano
intro_philosophy:
Perhaps the Tinto de Verano (literally “summer red wine”) is Spain’s equivalent of a basic spritz. There it’s cut withgaseosa, a lemon-flavored soda, and can be found already mixed and bottled at the grocery store. Simpler than Sangria and lower in alcohol than the country’s other national obsession, the “Gin-Tonic” as they call it, this version freshens up the typical formula with red wine, homemade lemon syrup, and a long pour of soda water for a surprisingly light and poppy Spanish spritz.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail, with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Add wine and lemon syrup to a shaker.
2. Add ice and shake gently until chilled.
3. Pour over ice into a tumbler or wine glass.
4. Top with soda and garnish.

title: Mood Ring
intro_philosophy: Prepared tableside at New York’s Mission Chinese, this drink sees blue tea topped with an acidic mixture—in this case, a tropical blend of pineapple, lime, rum and orange liqueur—that causes it to change color.When beverage director Sam Anderson realized that he’d need to light the drink consistently to make the effect visible in a dark dining room, he found the solution in the form of LED coasters he sourced on a rave site. This approachmakes the resulting cocktail literally glow, a visual display not unlike that of a lava lamp.
ingredients: 2 ounces aged rum, preferably Cana Brava
3/4 ounce orange liqueur, preferably Combier L'Orange
1/2 ounce coconut syrup (1:1, sugar:coconut milk + drop orange blossom water)
1 ounce butterfly pea tea (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Pour butterfly pea tea into glass on a large rock of ice, all sitting on LED coaster, illuminating the deep blue of the tea.
2. Combine remaining ingredients in shaker, dry shake and transfer to a glass carafe.
3. Pour mixture over ice and blue tea. Tea color will quickly change from blue to magenta.

title: The Dead Rabbit’s Lion’s Tail
intro_philosophy: “We added [the Lion’s Tail] to our Vol.1 as it was a historical classic,” recalls McGarry. “We wanted to breathe new life into it.” And he does, revamping every aspect of the classic version except the lime juice and the allspice dram.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a punch glass over a fresh ice cube.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Citrus and Smoke
intro_philosophy: In this play on the Gin & Tonic, gin is replaced with savory mezcal and paired with citrusy, full-bodied Boylan Heritage Tonic. A honey-salt rim and flamed orange peel complete the drink’s proto-Margaritaflare.
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass with asalted rimusing the honey.
2. Fill prepared glass with crushed ice.
3. Add mezcal and tonic to the rocks glass.
4. Flame grapefruit peel over top of the cocktail and garnish with flamed peel.

title: Austin Hennelly’s Boulevardier
intro_philosophy: Banana-infused Japanese whisky is the secret ingredient in this drink, made using the same Bananas Justino technique pioneered in Dave Arnold’s bookLiquid Intelligence.Typically, Hennelly makes the drink in large quantities and predilutes it by 12 percent water by volume. The prebatched drink then is chilled in the refrigerator, ready to be poured over a cube of ice stamped with the Momofuku peach logo. The proportions below, however, are for a single serving.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi Storico Vermouth di Torino
1 1/2 ounces Bananas Justino Suntory Toki (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Black Velvet
intro_philosophy: The Brooks’s Club in London was founded as an aristocratic order for London’s most distinguished mess of lords, barons and dukes. The Black Velvet is said to have originated amidst these men in 1861. Upon the death of Queen Victoria’s husband, Prince Albert, champagne did not seem an appropriate sympathy cocktail, so it can be surmised that a dark beer was somber enough to foil the celebratory implication of bubbles. While it does seem like a travesty to mix champagne with anything but a plate of oysters, it must be said that stout (another worthy bivalve companion), plays remarkably well with its unsuspecting spouse.
instructions: 1. In a flute or a Collins glass, add Guinness.
2. Top gently with champagne.

title: Kryptonite Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: This seasonal take on theDaiquiriuses fresh rhubarb juice in place of lime to cut down the drink’s carbon footprint.
ingredients: 1 ounce white rum, preferably Bacardi Carta Blanca
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupette.

title: First Salute
intro_philosophy:
Early in Gullo’s career,Toby Cecchinichallenged her to create a good drink with three ingredients or less. “I had recently become fascinated with Tiki and all things Beachbum Berry and was reading about Don’s Mix,” Gullo says of the inspiration behind herDaiquiririff. In addition to the expected rum and lime, Gullo adds her house-made grapefruit oleo saccharum, which is spiked with cinnamon and star anise.

“Toby thinks I cheated by putting more ingredients in the syrup,” Gullo recalls. Nonetheless, the drink was a hit with St. John Frizell and landed a spot on theFort Defiancemenu during her tenure there.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Campari Radler
intro_philosophy: The housemade radler cocktails at 151 double down on the citrus, thanks to a combination of a Austrian grapefruit-flavored radler and lemon juice. This one in particular is laced with bittersweet Campari, yielding a kind of sudsy Americano.
instructions: 1. Add the Campari and lemon juice to a chilled pint glass, and top with beer.
2. garnish with a quarter wheel or grapefruit or orange.

title: Frozen Batidas
intro_philosophy: These Brazilian milkshakes are made in many flavors; choose your favorite fruit puree or nectar. This recipe appears in both the 2002 and 2020 of Dale DeGroff’s cocktail guide.
ingredients: 2 ounces tropical fruit puree or nectar
instructions: 1. Blend all ingredients with ice.
2. Pour into a stemmed glass.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Ryleigh’s Sagamore Crush
intro_philosophy: This whiskey-based Crush variation uses Sagamore Spirit Rye, which is produced with spring water from Sagamore Farm, a thoroughbred horse breeding and training facility in Baltimore County.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rye whiskey, preferably Sagamore Spirit
instructions: 1. Combine rye and triple sec in a pint glass with ice.
2. Squeeze fresh orange juice directly into glass and top with a splash of ginger ale.
3. Garnish with an orange slice and drink immediately.

title: A Moment of Silence
intro_philosophy: Maks Pazuniak used the New Orleans classic La Louisiane as a jumping off point for this rye drink. However, he kept only the rye, throwing out all the other usual ingredients. The oddball result makes for an enjoyably bitter little glass of fruit punch. The recipe was published by Pazuniak and Kirk Estopinal in the influentialBeta Drinks(the sequel to the even more influentialRogue Drinks) in 2011.
ingredients: 1 ounce apricot liqueur, preferably Marie Brizard Apry
1/4 ounce apple brandy, preferably Laird's Bonded
instructions: 1. Fill a rocks glass with ice. Rinse ice in glass with Campari.
2. Combine remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into rocks glass.
4. Garnish with orange twist.

title: Julio Cabrera’s El Presidente
