Schick likes to add a bit of booze to his cobbler to give the drink a bit more backbone, and he decided to go with genever, a Dutch-style gin whose distinct maltiness, Schick knew, would comingle nicely with the nuttiness of amontillado. The addition of curaçao might seem unorthodox in the world of sherry cobblers, but there’s historical precedent: toward the latter part of the 19th century the cobbler started to embrace a number of embellishments, like pineapple gum syrup, orange curaçao, and port. Where things get weird here is with Schick’s menthol tincture, a relatively simple mix of menthol crystals dissolved in vodka—which he came up while reading soap-maker forums. While the drink certainly benefits from the cooling menthol sensation, if you can’t get your hands on menthol crystals at your local soap store, the drink is plenty delicious without it.

Reprinted with permission fromSherryby Talia Baiocchi, copyright © 2014. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Pierre Ferrand dry orange curaçao
instructions: 1. Add of the ingredients but the garnish to a mixing glass, add ice, and shake.
2. Strain over crushed ice into a double rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a spring of mint and the half orange wheel.

title: Project Manhattan (Duck and Cover Edition)
intro_philosophy: The name is a tongue-in-cheek reference to the “nuking” methodology in this update of the boozy classic. Microwaving lends itself best to batched cocktails with softer flavor profiles; here,Ryan Chetiyawardanaselected Westward Whiskey for its bold “cacao, red berry, herbal and piney notes.” Applejack, a blend of vermouths (Chetiyawardana uses equal parts Cocchi di Torino and Martini Rosso) blackcurrant cordial “lift the sides of the drink, while still allowing the whiskey to shine.”
ingredients: 8 1/2 ounces apple brandy, such as Laird’s Straight Apple Brandy Bottled in Bond
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a vacuum-sealable, microwave-proof bag and microwave for 3 minutes on high power. Allow to cool, then strain and bottle.
2. To serve, add 2 1/3 ounces in a mixing glass over ice, and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with Luxardo or Amarena cherry.

title: Winter in Miami
intro_philosophy: For all but a few days each year, winter does not exist in Miami, Florida. For this reason, bartender Valentino Longo, of Le Sirenuse, created this spicy aperitivo to evoke the season’s traditional flavors. “It’s light in alcohol, refreshing. Coffee plays an important role in incorporating all those botanicals and spices together,” he says. With L’Aperitivo Nonino as its base spirit, the Winter in Miami is an interlude of tropical (lent from banana) and cozy (all those baking spices), underlined by Nonino’s gentian and chamomile notes to keep the whole thing in balance.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  cold-brew coffee  (not concentrate, or concentrate that’s been diluted)
¼ ounce  spiced banana syrup  (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except the soda and tonic to a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain over ice into a highball glass prepared with a rim of banana salt, and top with soda and tonic.

title: The Royal Palmer
intro_philosophy: Chicago café and bar Truce has two Arnold Palmers on the menu: a pared-back daytime version and a more layered, nuanced evening take. The Royal Palmer is the latter, and it incorporates two nonalcoholic spirits, sweeteners made from Earl Grey tea and persimmons, and a homemade ginger lemonade.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces iced black tea, such as Rare Tea Cellar 3 Estate Iced Black Tea
1/2 ounce Crema Earl Grey syrup (1:1, cane sugar to brewed Rare Tea Cellar Crema Earl Grey, by weight)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker over ice, and shake vigorously for 5 seconds.
2. Fine-strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel and mint.

title: Single Village Fix
intro_philosophy: This modern classic was first made at Beretta in San Francisco in 2008. Its creator, bartender Thad Vogler, simply combines mezcal and lime juice with pineapple gum syrup, which brings richness and acidity to the three-ingredient drink.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce pineapple gum syrup, such as Small Hand Foods
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice, shake and strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Calvados & Tonic
intro_philosophy: The simple combination of Calvados and tonic may not be as popular stateside as it is in France, but Sarah Morrissey hopes to change that, pointing out how refreshing, bitter, sweet and boozy it can be. “I especially like using the Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic in this drink for its notes of ginger and vanilla,” says Morrissey. “It enhances the apple flavor of the Calvados—plus, it’s pink.”
ingredients: 2 ounces ounces  Roger Groult 3 Year Calvados Pays d’Auge
instructions: 1. Build the ingredients except the garnish in a chilled Collins glass or Burgundy wine glass over ice.
2. Lightly stir, and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Maria Mole
intro_philosophy: For Diogo Sevilio, a bartender at Pindura Bar in São Paulo, theMaria Moleis “the kind of drink that’s adaptable and easily fits into any menu.” Popularized in the 1980s by a viral advertising campaign, the two-ingredient drink takes inspiration from a traditional Brazilian dessert of the same name; made from gelatin and sugar, it’s known for its light, spongy texture. The term “Maria mole” can also refer to something soft or without structure, which likely influenced the cocktail’s name, reflecting its smooth and velvety texture.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces bianco vermouth, preferably Martini Bianco
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass with ice, stir both ingredients to chill and dilute the mixture.
2. Strain into your desired glass. If using a cocktail glass, chill it beforehand; if serving in a lowball glass, add one large ice cube.
3. Finish with an orange twist.

title: Quilty
intro_philosophy: Powered by Laphroaig, a notably peaty Scotch, this spirit-forward drink was developed for Slowly Shirley’s film noir-themed menu, which debuted in the fall of 2018. A pairing of smoky whisky, mezcal, nutty amontillado sherry and bittersweet coffee liqueur, this drink is, according to beverage director Jim Kearns, “a big, bold drink that tastes like coffee and smoke.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with lemon peel.

title: Daytime Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: As seasonless as the Old-Fashioned might be, it still inspires seasonal tinkering. “The idea behind the Daytime Old-Fashioned was to have a sessionable take on [the] classic,” says Victoria. While her update on the OG OF features the familiar bourbon base, it crosses over into long-drink mule territory with a healthy pour of spicy, aromatic ginger ale—which stands in for the usual bitters while bringing on the required sweetness. “It may be lighter than a classic version, but it really packs flavor … and is easy to drink from day to night,” she says.
instructions: 1. Add bourbon to a Collins glass, then fill the glass with ice cubes.
2. Top with Fever-Tree Ginger Ale.
3. Garnish with a cocktail cherry and lemon wheel.

title: Barrelhouse Flat’s Whiskey Smash
intro_philosophy: The layman’s Mint Julep, the Whiskey Smash comes with all of the flavor of its more famous relative but without the associated frippery (tin cups, Derby hats, et al.). Jerry Thomas called it, “The Julep on a small plan.” A few slices of muddled lemon and a fistful of mint helps lift and brighten the flavors, making this potent number dangerously easy to toss back. This is the Chicago bar Barrelhouse Flat’s subtle riff on the classic.
ingredients: 2 ounces bourbon, preferably Old Grand Dad
instructions: 1. Add mint leaves, lemon wedges and demerara syrup to a mixing tin or glass, and muddle together.
2. Add the rest of the ingredients and ice, and shake briefly.
3. Double strain into a rocks glass over ice and garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Nonalcoholic Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Barbuto’s simple spirit-free take on the Old-Fashioned is built on a base of Kentucky 74, a nonalcoholic alternative to bourbon. Maple syrup imparts richness and a round texture. Bar manager John Dillon suggests using room-temperature syrup, which is easier to incorporate into the drink.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice or a large cube.
3. Garnish with an orange twist and a sprig of burnt rosemary.

title: Three Scots and a Dash
intro_philosophy: A play on the tiki classicThree Dots and a Dash, this whiskey-based rendition was created by Zac Overman at the launch of Sunken Harbor Club, a weekly tiki celebration at Red Hook’sFort Defiance.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce passionfruit syrup (1:1, passionfruit puree:simple syrup)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Pour all contents into a tall tiki mug.
3. Garnish with three cherries pinned to a pineapple spear.

title: Trick Dog’s White Negroni
intro_philosophy: This White Negroni variation from Trick Dog in San Francisco skips the Suze to preserve a crystal-clear appearance. Bar founder Josh Harris “feels strongly” that the liqueur’s sunny hue and distinct gentian bitterness don’t belong in the modern classic, and opts for Luxardo Bitter Bianco instead. While Harris favors an “old-school London dry” for this drink, he notes that a wide range of gins will work, though the end result “can be significantly different based on the gin you choose.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into an Old-Fashioned glass (or into a coupe, if preferred, without ice).
4. Twist the grapefruit peel over the top of the drink to express essential oils, then use the peel to garnish.

title: Blackberry-Lime Syrup
intro_philosophy:
Sweet-tart and deep, dark purple, this summer simple syrup accompanies theShady Lanecocktail from Brad Thomas Parsons’ book,Bitters.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. In a medium saucepan, combine the sugar, water, blackberries, and lime zest.
2. Bring to a simmer, stirring occasionally to dissolve the sugar and pressing the blackberries against the side of the pan with the back of a wooden spoon.
3. At the first crack of a boil, remove from the heat. Once cooled, pour the syrup through a strainer, discard the solids, and store in a glass jar.

title: Miami Rice
intro_philosophy: Developed for a weekend pop-up with a Japanese-tropical mashup theme, this Miami Vice riff starts with a riff on a frozen Piña Colada featuring Beniotome Sesame Shochu, a barley shochu distilled with sesame seeds, and sake kasu (a byproduct of making sake) from Brooklyn Kura brewed into a syrup “that emulates the viscosity and richness of a Coco Lopez.” It’s then swirled with strawberry purée blended with overproof rum.
ingredients: 1 ounce Sake Kasu Syrup (see Editor's Note)
2 ounces Strawberry Daiquiri Purée (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except Strawberry Daiquiri Purée with 6 ounces crushed ice, and blend on high for approximately 1 minute.
2. Pour into a 10-ounce glass.
3. Float 2 ounces of Strawberry Daiquiri Purée on top. Present the cocktail with a layered look, but stir before drinking to integrate flavors properly.

title: False Start
intro_philosophy: Westlight’s False Start is a stirred drink garnished with cucumber that balances reposado tequila with bitter, nutty Cardamaro, sweet vermouth and Cynar, for a drink that’s rich but surprisingly light on its feet.
instructions: 1. Gently muddle cucumbers, stir all ingredients and fine strain into a coupe.
2. Garnish with a cucumber wheel.

title: Jasmine
intro_philosophy:
Paul Harrington named this drink after Matt Jasmin, a friend with whom he went to architectural school. He was working at Townhouse when Jasmin said, “Make me something you’ve never made before.”

“The Pegu Club was really the drink I used to push on people,” remembered Harrington. “I loved the Pegu. I literally thought about it for twenty seconds. I decided to use Campari instead of Angostura bitters, and use lemon juice instead of lime juice. I made it once, put a twist of lemon on it. It was a beautiful pink color. I handed it to him. He said, ‘Wow, that’s good. You just invented grapefruit juice.’”

The Jasmine gained wider fame when Harrington included it in his 1998 bookCocktails. Bartenders across the nation, and the world, who were looking for instruction, made it alongside the other, older drinks in the book.

Years after inventing the drink, Harrington realized he’d been spelling his friend’s last name wrong all along; there is no “e” at the end. But by then, it was too late.

Reprinted with permission fromA Proper Drink, copyright 2016 by Robert Simonson. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the lemon twist in a cocktail shaker three-quarters filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with the lemon twist.

title: A Thousand Ships
intro_philosophy: Bartender James Socci has long been inspired by the Greek myth of Helen of Troy, so she decided to craft a cocktail in tribute to the legendary beauty. Using primarily ingredients that would have been available in the ancient world, she accents the base spirit of gin with soft spice and floral flavors provided by cardamom honey and rose water. Rhubarb jam adds earthy, tart depth, while an egg white and soda water gives the drink a frothy texture.
instructions: 1. Dry shake first six ingredients.
2. Add one ice cube and shake until dissolved.
3. Fill shaker with ice and shake.
4. Double-strain into footed highball glass.
5. Top with soda water, and express lemon peel over top.
6. Garnish with a rose petal.

title: Génépy Suisse
intro_philosophy:
In the Génépy Suisse, Ryan Maybee doubles down on winter drinking, incorporating pine-scented herbal liqueur génépy into a riff on the classic Absinthe Suisse cocktail. “The sweeter qualities of the cacao and coffee blend beautifully with absinthe, and work equally well with génépy,” he says.

Génépy Suisse sees the original Suisse’s crème de menthe swapped for crème de cacao, plus the addition of coffee liqueur, heavy cream and a garnish of grated nutmeg—all which results in essentially an elevated, adult mocha.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy des Alpes
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin and shake well with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Creamy Martini
intro_philosophy: Atthe pioneering cocktail bar White Lyan(which closed in April 2017), they used lactic acid—perhaps best known as the agent that gives yogurt or kefir its tang—when looking to enhance savory flavors and round off the edges of a drink; as a milder acid, it actually helps add a fuller, creamy mouthfeel to cocktails, as has a slightly higher pH than citric or malic acid. It’s used in the recipe for the Creamy Martini to, well, give it creaminess.
ingredients: 2 drops 5% lactic acid solution, (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.

title: Tiramisu
intro_philosophy: Credited to London’s since-shuttered LAB bar, this drink nods to the custardy Italian dessert, which layers creamy mascarpone with ladyfingers soaked in espresso and booze. “Any kind of cheese in a cocktail, normally I’d run for the hills,” jokes Naren Young, proprietor of New York’s Dante. But here, a mere teaspoon adds a luscious touch. Meanwhile, Mr. Black’s Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur adds the appropriately caffeinated punch. “I liked that this one had some coffee beans used in its production,” compared to other liqueurs that are merely coffee-flavored sweeteners. A grating of dark Valrhona chocolate on top lends the finishing dessert-like touch to the drink.
tags: Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with shaved chocolate.

title: Means of Preservation
intro_philosophy: The Martini-esque Means of Preservation is a John Gertsen—formerly of No. 9 Park and Drink, and now of SF’s ABV—original made of gin, St-Germain, dry vermouth and celery bitters.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a expressed grapefruit peel.

title: Meshugenah Margarita
intro_philosophy: Served at Joe & Misses Doe, Jill Dobias uses Manischewitz to add vibrant color and fruity sweetness to a Margarita, while balancing out the tartness of lime juice.
instructions: 1. Pour kosher salt into a dish. Moisten the edge of the glass, and gently roll the edge of the glass in the salt to create a generously salted rim.
2. Pour tequila, lime and simple syrup into a cocktail shaker.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Pour contents, including ice, into prepared glass.
5. Hold a spoon, rounded side up, directly above the drink. Gently pour the Manischewitz over the bowl of the spoon to “float” the wine on top of the drink.

title: Session Manhattan
intro_philosophy:
In this low-proof spin on theManhattan, sweet vermouth and rye switch places; the former acting as the base spirit and the latter as the modifier. Small measures of amontillado sherry and dry vermouth add complexity and balance.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe, then garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Toronto
intro_philosophy: Similar in construction to the earlier “Fernet Cocktail” appearing in Robert Vermier’s 1922 book,Cocktails: How to Mix Them, the Toronto is a spirit-forward Fernet-laced drink pulled from the pages of David A. Embury’s 1948 titleThe Fine Art of Mixing Drinks.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Charente-16
intro_philosophy: When using young Pineau des Charentes, Brian Means likes to pair it with spirits that have complementary fruit or spice notes, such as apple or pear brandy, bourbon or tequila. In the Charente-16, named for the train station in Cognac, France, he stirs tequila with Pineau, dry Curaçao and banana liqueur. “The black pepper in the tequila works nicely with the red fruit and baking spices in the [Pineau],” he says, “and is rounded out by dried orange peel and roasted banana.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounces Pineau des Charentes, preferably Chateau Montifaud Rosso
1/2 ounce dry Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
1/4 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banana du Brasil
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients together in a mixing glass and add ice.
2. Stir for about 10 to 15 seconds, then strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express an orange peel over the glass and drop it into the drink.

title: Midnight Stinger
intro_philosophy: At Attaboy in New York City, guests generally give the bar team a few basic descriptors, and the bartenders then pull from an ever-changing repertoire of drinks. This fernet-laced riff on the classic Whiskey Sour formula is co-owner Sam Ross’ go-to drink for “whiskey/citrus/bitter” requests.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, add ice and shake.
2. Strain over crushed ice into a rocks glass, and garnish with a mint sprig.

title: White Negroni Fizz
intro_philosophy: Increasingly, modern classic cocktails have spawned a bevy of offshoots that might just pave the way for a new chapter in the modern classic canon—modern classics, remixed. Orlando Franklin McCray’s White Negroni Fizz, for instance, transforms the fairer Negroni with the addition of soda water, a splash of lemon juice and a store-bought vegan foamer into a tall frothy, well, fizz.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces navy strength gin, preferably Hayman’s Royal Dock
1 1/4 ounce blanc vermouth, preferably Cap Corse Blanc
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice for 30 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled highball glass over ice at the same time as soda water.

title: Greta Garbo
intro_philosophy: Just a couple of dashes of anise-accented absinthe distinguishes this Daiquiri variation. It was created in Cuba, where it was named for the star of the silver screen. While the drink isn’t nearly as famous as the Hemingway Daiquiri, perhaps it ought to be: “It’s really good,” says Julio Cabrera. “It’s even better than the Clásico.”
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice for 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a 5 1/2-ounce coupe glass.

title: Champan’s Haven
intro_philosophy: Champan’s Haven, a direct English translation of Copenhagen, reads like a Gimlet variation in which aquavit drives the vegetal character of the drink, highlighted by muddled cucumber and celery bitters.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a floating cucumber wheel.

title: Bourbon and Tepache
intro_philosophy: Using the framework of a Whiskey Sour, Bryan Eichhorst’s Bourbon and Tepache combines the funky aromatics of pineapple-basedtepache(a fermented Mexican beverage) and pineapple white wine vinegar with a backbone of bonded bourbon, sweet vermouth and housemade velvet falernum. Served over crushed ice, it’s equal parts sour, sweet and strong—like any good Whiskey Sour should be.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sweet vermouth (preferably Punt e Mes)
1/4 ounce pineapple macerated white wine vinegar (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Dry shake (shake without ice).
3. Pour over crushed ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel and a mist of Angostura bitters.

title: Strong Start
intro_philosophy: “One of my favorite uses for génépy is as a sweetener for heavy cream,” says Troy Sidle, former bartender at New York’s Pouring Ribbons. In this riff on the classic Irish coffee, Sidle contrasts the herbaceous aromatics of génépy cream with warming, rum-spiked coffee.
ingredients: génépy cream, to top (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the coffee, rum and syrup in a clear coffee mug.
2. Top with the génépy cream. Express the orange peel over the drink.

title: Seven Years Cycle
intro_philosophy: Conceived for the menu at Banzarbar in 2018, Seven Years Cycle was built outward from one central ingredient: Clear Creek cranberry liqueur. Natasha Bermudez set out to make a savory cocktail, pairing the cranberry with rosemary, before taking a different tack by calling on the citrus-forward Edinburgh Christmas Gin, which is also infused with frankincense and myrrh. Ancho Reyes chile liqueur adds a smoky note to the shaken cocktail, while the finishing touch comes by way of half a teaspoon of Vicario’s Monk’s Secret liqueur, an herbal, vegetal elixir that, in Bermudez’s words, “is the one thing that made the drink finally work.”
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce oloroso sherry, preferably Lustau Oloroso Sherry
1 ounce gin, preferably Edinburgh Christmas Gin
3/4 ounce cranberry liqueur, preferably Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: El Quijote’s Kalimotxo
intro_philosophy: Brian Evans describes this rum-spiked Kalimotxo riff that’s served at El Quijote in New York as “a traditional red wine-and-cola meets a Cuba Libre.” He recommends using a wine on the lighter, fruitier side, such as a garnacha or a pinot noir.
ingredients: 1 ounce Plantation Stiggins’ Fancy Pineapple Rum
1/2 ounce Spanish red vermouth, preferably Destilerías Atxa Rojo Vermut
1/2 ounce cinnamon simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
Casamara Club Alta sparkling amaro, to top
instructions: 1. Build the first six ingredients in a shaker and short-shake with three ice cubes for approximately six seconds.
2. Strain over cubed ice in a Collins glass and top with nonalcoholic sparkling amaro.
3. Garnish with a small mint bouquet, orange slice and a small cluster of red grapes.

title: Sippin’ the Tea
intro_philosophy: Though not explicitly an Espresso Martini riff, Fred Beebe’s Sippin’ the Tea answers the call for anyone athis hyperlocal Philadelphia bar, which sources ingredients exclusively from east of the Mississippi. In this recipe, black tea–infused vodka is shaken with two types of amari and condensed oat milk flavored with pandan leaves grown right on the bar’s front window.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces black tea–infused local vodka (see Editor’s Note)
1 1/2 ounces condensed oat milk (see Editor’s Note)
2 dashes Fee Brothers black walnut bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a two-piece cocktail shaker with one large ice cube and shake for 12 seconds.
2. Throw the cocktail five times by passing the liquid back and forth between the shaking tins at a distance, using a julep strainer to hold the large cube in one of the tins.
3. Fine-strain into a coupe glass.
4. Garnish with 3 nigella seeds.

title: The Boardwalk
intro_philosophy: With yeasty, sourdough notes combined with hints of almond, apple and dried citrus, the mineral character of dry sherry often reads as perceived acidity in cocktails. Here,Chantal Tsengcalls on manzanilla to cut the sweet, viscous character of rum and vermouth and ties the whole thing together with a bright twist of citrus.
ingredients: 1 ounce aged rum, preferably Barbancourt 5 Star
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Dolin Rouge
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed orange peel and grated nutmeg.

title: Moon Watcher
intro_philosophy: “I’ve always enjoyed the way Scotch plays with fortified wines, spiced and fruit flavors,” says head bartender Evans of this drink, which channels the essence of baked goods from banana bread to spice cake. Named after the moon-watcher ape from the introduction of Stanley Kubrick’s2001: A Space Odyssey, head bartender Evans describes this drink as “a sort of a Rob Roy for the holiday season.”
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Black Bottle
3 dashes Bittermens New England Spiced Cranberry Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir for 15 to 20 seconds.
2. Strain into chilled Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with skewered cranberry and lime peel, then mist with pimento dram.

title: Amar-garita
intro_philosophy: An “amaro margarita,” this low-alcohol riff on the classic Marg uses a split base of lightly bitter gentian amaro and dry vermouth. “Vermouth is usually used as a modifier only,” Lucas Garcia says, but here, it’s “the main character of a cocktail.”
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass with a half salted rim.
2. Shake all ingredients with ice.
3. Strain into a prepared rocks glass over fresh ice.
4. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.

title: 50/50 Margarita
intro_philosophy: While experimenting with introducing sherry into the50/50 Martiniformat,Natasha Bermudezrealized that the fortified wine works well inMargaritas, too. Her 50/50 Margarita splits the base of the drink between mezcal and manzanilla sherry to introduce a touch of salinity and acidity, mirroring the classic cocktail’s already citrusy-salty flavor profile.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, preferably Mezcal Verde Amarás Espadín
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with worm salt or smoked chile salt.
2. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the rimmed rocks glass over ice.

title: Mandarin Cinnamon Snaps
intro_philosophy: Åhus-based Per Hermansson, Absolut’s Director for Sensory Design, infuses his own snaps for the holidays and serves it alongside classic Scandinavian dishes. This simple recipe features two quintessential Christmas flavors—citrus and cinnamon—in one festive shot.
instructions: 1. Wash the fruits thoroughly in lukewarm water. Peel, avoiding the inner white pith.
2. Place the peels in a clean container or bottle and add the cinnamon stick.
3. Pour in the vodka and let stand in the fridge for about 2 days.

title: The Gentleman
intro_philosophy: At Stoa in San Francisco, owner Yanni Kehagiaras creates cocktails that showcase the complexity of simplicity. All the drinks on the menu have four ingredients or fewer, and none use added sugar (apart from classics that specifically call for simple syrup), relying instead on Kehagiaras’ studied expertise and deep understanding of his backbar to find perfect balance. The Gentleman is made up of just three ingredients: Bonal, tequila and gentian liqueur, which come together to form an infinity loop of green, softly bitter, herbal flavors.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce gentian liqueur, preferably Antica Torino Liquore di Genziana
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Anthony Schmidt’s Negroni Sbagliato
intro_philosophy: Bringing up third place in our blind Negroni Sbagliato tasting was the highball-bound drink prescribed by Anthony Schmidt of J & Tony’s in San Diego. Schmidt’s very careful instructions begin with one ounce each of chilled Campari and Cocchi Vermouth di Torino. To that he adds, while tilting a Collins glass, three ounces of chilled prosecco and one and a half ounces of chilled seltzer, namely, Topo Chico. The ice is added to the drink afterward—“This lets gravity fold the beverage for you, while keeping as much carbonation as you can trapped in the drink,” Schmidt notes—and the drink is garnished by a lemon twist (discarded) and an orange twist in the glass. The panel found the drink bright and juicy; light, but not watered down.
ingredients: 1 ounce vermouth, preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine the Campari and vermouth in a highball glass without ice.
2. Add lemon juice.
3. Tilt the glass while adding prosecco.
4. Gently add ice, using a barspoon to ease into glass. (This lets gravity fold the beverage for you, while keeping as much carbonation as you can trapped in the drink.)
5. Express a lemon peel and discard. Garnish with orange peel.

title: Singchelada
intro_philosophy: “It was definitely a conscious decision to swap out the ingredients with Thai and Southeast Asian ingredients,” notes bartender Bobby Leonardo of New York’s Wayla, who took inspiration for the Singchelada from both the Michelada andcha ma nao, a Thai-style tangy lime iced tea. The drink is “full of that savory umami flavor” and “sharp and aggressive spicy flavor” with the addition of green papaya sauce, chile paste and soy sauce.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce green papaya sauce (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Squeeze lime and combine remaining ingredients, except beer, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Pour into a beer glass.
3. Top with beer.
4. Garnish with cherry plum sea salt rim.

title: Alexander the Peacemaker
intro_philosophy: This Russia-meets-Midwest cocktail from Portland’sKachkablends vanilla ice cream with San Francisco’s unpasteurized Nash Kvass (a fermented and subtly alcoholic Eastern European beverage) and cocoa nib-infused overproof rum. The kvass’s savoriness balances the sweet cream and rum, while the cocoa powder and grated nutmeg garnish add a dessert-y element of complexity.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rum, overproof and infused with cocoa-nibs
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender.
2. Blend quickly until smooth.
3. Serve in a small rocks glass.
4. Garnish with cocoa powder and freshly grated nutmeg.

title: The Jetport
intro_philosophy: “I’m just kind of a simp for chamomile,” says Arvid Brown, especially when it’s paired with grapefruit, which is where his spin on thePaper Planecomes from.Handshake Digestif Bitters, a unique Persian American amaro from Maine that isn’t as sweet as the standard Amaro Nonino, brings the chamomile along with dozens of other botanicals, from saffron to spruce tips. The result, named for the Portland International Jetport and served at Brown’s bar,Room for Improvement, is “a super punchy and juicy rendition of the classic with a distinct herbal backbone.”
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit peel.

title: Spirit of ’76
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg, an orange and apple slice, a brandied cherry and a Bicentennial flag toothpick.

title: Fast Canoe
intro_philosophy: Named for a Polvo song from the mid-‘90s, whose vibe Paul McGee felt fit this refreshing drink, the Fast Canoe is a straightforward whiskey-ginger highball, given a Southeast Asian twist withpandan syrup, which adds a coconut-like note. Opt for a whiskey that’s not too smoky; McGee recommends Glenlivet, a Speyside single malt.
ingredients: 4 ounces ginger beer, preferably Fever-Tree Ginger Beer
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except ginger beer in a Collins glass over five large ice cubes.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with ginger beer.
4. Garnish with pandan leaf.

title: American Beauty
intro_philosophy: InThe Stork Club Bar Book, Lucius Beebe recommends drinking this little cocktail at noon, to “abate the grief of a stormy morning.” While it’s likely to wake you up, it may cause grief in some drinkers due to the fact that, in its original form, it tastes a lot like drinking fruit punch after brushing your teeth. See recommendations on bringing the drink into 2015 in the Editor’s Note.
instructions: 1. Add crème de menthe, orange juice, grenadine, French vermouth and brandy to a shaking tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass and top with port.

title: Pinetop Perker
intro_philosophy: Chad Solomon plays on genever’s distinct botanical flavors by blending it with malted aquavit, pine liqueur and pine extract in the Pinetop Perker, a sort of Egg Sour by way of northern Europe. At the bar, the drink is finished with a spritz of housemade “Alpine Woodland Essence” built on aromas of cedar, fir and bergamot. Here, in lieu of that, he recommends expressing a lemon twist over the top of the drink to mask the egg white aroma.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry-shake.
2. Add ice and shake well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or footed whiskey sour glass.
4. Express the lemon twist over the top of the drink and discard.
5. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon peel.

title: Surf Club
intro_philosophy: A fan of sherry, bartender Valentino Longo uses the fortified wine instead of vermouth in his take on the Turf Club, but first infuses it with maraschino cherries. Also in the mix is a bit of housemade pickle liqueur. Guests can choose gin or vodka as their base spirit, and select a garnish from a caddy that includes an olive, lemon peel and pickled onions.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce cherry-infused fino sherry (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with an olive, lemon twist or pickled onion.

title: Wibble
intro_philosophy: Neither a global phenomenon nor an obscurity, the Wibble is not without a certain stature. Invented in the 1990s by Dick Bradsell, the godfather of the London cocktail revival, it’s a mixture of gin, sloe gin, grapefruit and lemon juices, simple syrup and crème de mure. In London, it’s considered by many to be a modern classic. Yet, it’s rarely consumed outside of Great Britain.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Seelbach
intro_philosophy:
At the turn of the 20th century a pair of Bavarian brothers, the Seelbachs, opened a posh hotel in downtown Louisville catering to upper-crust travelers. Its lavish interior evoked the Old World and attracted characters—like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Al Capone—who knew they could always get a stiff drink at theSeelbach Bar, even throughout Prohibition. The grand, saloon-style counter specialized in bourbon and, as Brad Thomas Parsons writes in his book,Bitters, its signature cocktail was apparently created when a bartender used aManhattanto catch the overflow from an uncorked Champagne bottle. Or so the story went. The Seelbach’s narrative has since been proven to be nothing more than afabrication by the hotel’s bartender, Adam Seger, in the 1990s.

Though the ingredients don’t quite reflect the architecture of a Manhattan the liberal addition of Peychaud’s and Angostura bitters do counter the bourbon’s sweetness with a Manhattan-esque bite.
instructions: 1. Add bourbon, Cointreau and bitters to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled flute or coupe glass.
4. Top with Champagne or sparkling wine.
5. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Wagtail Sings
intro_philosophy: Created for Shaker & Spoon, a cocktail subscription service, Wagtail Sings was born out of self-imposed restraints. “When working on a cocktail kit there are lots of limitations, but limitations breed creativity,” saysCaer Maiko. Destined for a Japanese whisky themed box, Maiko’s recipe naturally intended to nod to Japanese culture, but having recently prepared a Daijoubu cocktail box for the same company she was wary of creating another “Super Asian Cocktail.” Instead, the stirred combination of Japanese whisky, spiced pear syrup with a barspoon of Underburg channels one of the Japanese autumn microseasons known as “Wagtail Sings.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce spiced pear syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with lemon oils and cinnamon smoke.

title: Alec Bales’ Bijou
intro_philosophy: Born in the 1890s, the original Bijou recipe combines equal parts gin, sweet vermouth and green Chartreuse. Here,Alec BalesofTiconderoga Clubin Atlanta swaps the herbal liqueur for Boomsma Claerkampster Cloosterbitter, a lighter, lower-ABV alternative.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces London dry gin, such as Fords or Gin Lane
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Carpano Classico
1 dash orange bitters, such as Regans’
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Pour into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a cherry.

title: Southern Comfort
intro_philosophy:
This force-carbonated cocktail takes inspiration from both theMint Julepand the combination of bourbon and iced tea. The subtle, smoky heat from the chipotle-infused tea syrup adds a layer of richness to an otherwise vibrant summer drink.

For more on carbonating cocktails, Team Lyanoutlines their best practices.
ingredients: 1/5 ounce citric acid 10% solution (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an iSi soda siphon (be sure that the thin interior tube is removed) and charge.
2. Shake the canister, then place it in the refrigerator for at least two hours, or preferably, overnight.
3. With the canister upright, very slowly release the pressure by pressing down the lever. (Do this a little bit at a time over the course of half an hour or so, storing in the fridge in between.)
4. Carefully open the top of the cannister and pour the drink into a highball glass over crushed ice.
5. Garnish with two lemon wheels.

title: The Long Island Bar’s Dirty Martini
intro_philosophy:
This recipe starts with The Long Island Bar’s basic Martini spec: 12:1 gin to vermouth. “Depending on how ‘dirty’ the guest is requesting it, we could add anything between a quarter-ounce to an ounce or more of the olive brine,” Cecchini explains. “Some people just get borderline irrational with this dirty thing, but it’s not ours to question; you order it, you pay for it, we’re happy to make it for you.”

And while some insist on an odd number of olives in their martini, Cecchini is staunch on two olives as garnish: “Wetake our cue from Sinatra, who maintained that the correct number of olives in the drink was ‘one for me and one for my baby.’”
ingredients: 3 ounces London dry gin, preferably Fords or Hayman’s
1/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Dolin Dry
1/4 ounce (or more) dirty Martini olive brine (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice, until well-chilled and diluted.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail coupe.
3. Garnish with 2 olives on a pick.

title: Eremita
intro_philosophy: At Ofélia, a cocktail bar in Brazil’s Belo Horizonte, guests can order by selecting one of 22 tarot cards, each representing a signature drink. If the Eremita card is selected, the corresponding drink is a high-end version of Xeque Mate, a popular Brazilian drink that features rum, iced yerba mate tea and guaraná soda. “It has already become the city’s flagship libation, and we decided to pay homage to it in our own way,” explains Bruce Moreira, the bar’s creative director. This is Ofélia’s contemporary spin on the democratic drink.
ingredients: a splash (about 1/4 ounce) of guaraná juice or soda
instructions: 1. Add the rum and lemon juice to a mug.
2. Fill the mug with ice.
3. Add the yerba mate tea and top with a splash of guaraná.
4. To serve as it’s presented at Ofélia, place the mug on a saucer, with a lemon leaf and sugar cubes on the side.

title: Mamma Guidara’s Godfather
intro_philosophy: This cheeky variation on the classic Godfather cocktail was created for Mamma Guidara’s, a series of Italian-themed Sunday suppers at The Nomad named after owner Will Guidara’s mother and a nod to Mamma Leone’s, a beloved restaurant that formerly resided in Theater District. This drink keeps “the spirit and soul” of the original, but strays from the original formula (equal parts amaretto and Scotch). Instead, Pietro Collina dials back the amaretto and focuses on the fruit and spice notes present in Irish whiskey, rounding them out with just a half-ounce of smoky Scotch.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Irish whiskey, preferably Jameson Black Barrel
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Rosie Martini
intro_philosophy: The Rosie Martini served atPitt’sis named after a cat  Ben Hopkins-Prager and their partner fostered. It’s a delicate but savory meeting of onion brine spiked with chile powder and the rich weight of off-dry vermouth. A little bitterness from a trace of gentian rounds the whole thing out. It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: 1 ounce dry vermouth, such as Method Dry Vermouth
3/4 teaspoon cocktail onion brine (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except for the onion brine to a mixing glass with ice and stir to dilute.
2. Strain into a glass, then add onion brine and lightly stir to incorporate.
3. Express a lemon twist over the glass, then discard it. Garnish with a cocktail onion.

title: Clarified Corn ‘n’ Oil
intro_philosophy: Paul McGee’s Clarified Corn ’n’ Oil transforms the tropical mixture of aged rum, falernum and lime juice from its typical petroleum color to a crystal-clear amber for a drink that has a softer touch than the original.
ingredients: 375 milliliters  (½ bottle) rhum agricole, preferably Clement Select Barrel
375 milliliters (½ bottle)  rum, preferably Real McCoy 5 Year Barbados Rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the half and half, in an 8 quart container.
2. In a separate 8 quart container, add half and half.

3. Pour the cocktail mixture (the first container) over the half and half and let sit for 30 minutes. You should see the punch curdle, this is a good thing. Line a fine mesh strainer with a damp cloth napkin or cheese cloth and place strainer over a deli container and slowly pour about 8 ounces of the mixture through the cloth. The first liquid coming through will be a bit hazy so move the strainer to another container and continue to let the mixture slowly collect into the container. Continue to pour more of the mixture through the strainer. It will yield around 2 deli containers.
4. Place punch in refrigerator and pour 3 to 4 ounces over a big ice cube whenever you like.

title: The Tropic of Cancer
intro_philosophy: This tiki-style drink takes its name from the circle of latitude that wraps around part of the earth’s southern hemisphere, hitting many of the areas where ingredients in the drink are sourced: Mexico (mezcal), Asia (ube, a purple yam indigenous to the Philippines), and the Caribbean (falernum). Bee propolis, which can be purchased in health food stores, is used to add a trace of bitterness to balance the drink.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with spiced ube powder.

title: Samarian Sunset
intro_philosophy: Star Trek, the eponymous, multi-generational television and movie series, offers some of the most elegant and interesting contributions to sci-fi cocktail culture. The Samarian Sunset, which first appeared inStar Trek: The New Generation, is a mystery that seems more technology than cocktail: Served clear in a clear glass, the drink comes into its own when, after the glass is tapped, the transparent liquid begins to swirl with color. Reinterpreted for mere humans, Natasha David’s Tequila Sunrise variation gets its color from a splash of bottom-floating Campari.
instructions: 1. Add 1/2 ounce Campari to a chilled rocks glass.
2. Sit a large rock of ice on top of the Campari.
3. Shake remaining ingredients with ice in a cocktail shaker.
4. Gently strain over the rock of ice so the drink floats over the Campari.
5. Garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Izzy Tulloch’s Gimlet
intro_philosophy: The winning recipe from our2024 Gimlet tasting, this drink represents the cordial-less approach to the drink, relying instead on fresh lime juice and simple syrup. Setting this cocktail apart, a lime wheel gets shaken with the rest of the ingredients to release the oils from the skin.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients, including the lime wheel, to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.

title: Parlour Room Punch
intro_philosophy: Historically built on anarrackbase, today’spunchesincorporate a variety of spirits from bourbon to brandy, or in the case of Erin Ashford’s recipe—both. To this double dose of spirit, Ashford addsdry Curaçaoand Amaro CioCiaro before topping the whole thing with sparkling rosé.
ingredients: 1 1/4 cups bourbon, preferably Old Grand-Dad Bonded
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a punch bowl.
2. Serve individually over crushed ice in four-ounce glasses.
3. Garnish with skewered cherries.

title: Strawberry Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Asked which cocktail he’d choose to porrón, Matthew Belanger chose a “crushable” Daiquiri, made with the addition of muddled strawberries. But this pink-hued drink, with its split rum base, is just as refreshing and summer-ready served up. For a Daiquiri with a richer color and more robust fruit flavor, let the muddled fruit sit in the tin with the other ingredients for two minutes before shaking.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
1 ounce white rum, such as El Dorado 3-Year, Caña Brava or Plantation 3 Stars
1 ounce Wray & Nephew White Overproof Jamaican Rum
instructions: 1. In the base of a mixing tin, muddle together the simple syrup and strawberry.
2. Add all remaining ingredients to the mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Fine-strain into a coupe.

title: Applesmoke
intro_philosophy: At the core ofBritt Fox’s Applesmoke cocktail, a Baltimore-made pechuga-style apple brandy informs the entire composition of the drink. Though it only contributes a half-ounce to the recipe, the spirit—distilled with country ham, persimmons, pawpaws and black walnuts—stars alongside rye, maple syrup and apple butter in a funky mid-Atlantic take on a whiskey sour.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce lemon juice (adjust up to 3/4 oz if apple butter is extra sweet)
1/2 ounce Asimina Pumila pechuga-style apple brandy, or any pechuga mezcal
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a persimmon round.

title: Mott and Mulberry
intro_philosophy: Named for an intersection on the border of Little Italy and Chinatown in New York City, the Mott and Mulberry is bartender Leo Robitschek’s autumnalWhiskey Sourriff. His mix of spicy rye, bittersweet Amaro Abano and tart apple cider layered over demerara syrup and fresh lemon combine to make a bone-warming comfort cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce apple cider or tart apple juice
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with thinly sliced apple wedges.

title: Hakumai Highball
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

“To me, spirits made from Japanese rice are special,” says Kenta Goto of his choice to spotlight rice shochu. He describes the spirit as having a sake-like aroma, alongside a stronger rice-based vodka in this drink. “They are truly smooth, and that is the beauty of it.”

Goto’s straightforward highball is topped up with soda water and garnished with pickled ginger for visual interest and a piquant accent. “I wanted to showcase that simple is the best,” he explains. “Using simple, great ingredients that harmonize together and elevate each other, you get a spectacular result. “
ingredients: 1 ounce  rice shochu (such as Hakutake Shiro)
3/4 ounce  rice vodka (such as Suntory Haku)
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a highball glass over ice, and stir gently to combine.
2. Garnish with pickled ginger.

title: Harvest Smash
intro_philosophy: “This was actually the first drink I ever came up,” Tyndale says of thisWhiskey Smashvariation. Here, he opts for anapplejackbase (“a brown liquor that would be appealing to everyone”) in the classic smash template, alongside muddled blueberries.
ingredients: 2 ounces applejack, preferably Laird's Bonded Applejack
instructions: 1. Muddle the lemons, blueberries and mint in a mixing tin.
2. Add apple brandy and demerara syrup and shake with ice.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over cracked or Kold Draft ice.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig and three blueberries on a pick.

title: The Dead Rabbit’s Amaretto Sour
intro_philosophy: “This is a full guilty-pleasure drink for me,” says Ian Alexander, a veteran New York bartender. “I absolutely love it.” He developed this recipe for The Dead Rabbit, in homage to the signature Amaretto Sour served at the now-shuttered NoMad Bar. On paper, its inclusion of Campari seems like a detour from the platonic composition of an Amaretto Sour, but it cuts and balances the inherent sweetness of the amaretto, much like high-proof bourbon does inJeffrey Morgenthaler’s acclaimed spin on the classic.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce overproof bourbon, preferably Old Forester overproof bourbon
instructions: 1. Dry-shake ingredients.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a lowball glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with an orange half-wheel and a skewered brandied cherry.

title: The Braveheart
intro_philosophy: Devon Espinosa created this deliberately non-smoky Penicillin variation during his tenure at The Tasting Kitchen. Although he’s since moved on to another position, the drink remains a popular off-menu option.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, combine all ingredients with ice.
2. Shake well, then strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.

title: Tom Macy’s Eggnog
intro_philosophy: Coming in third in our blind eggnog tasting was the nog of Tom Macy, partner at Brooklyn’s Clover Club. His recipe called on a duo of vanilla and cinnamon syrups, which lent a Christmas-spice undercurrent to the expected milk, cream and trio of spirits (Cognac, rum and bourbon). The judges found the texture to be silky and satisfying, while the drink cloaked a surprising fruit flavor that made you want to go back for another sip. As Cecchini summarized, “It takes you straight sideways the second you taste it.”
ingredients: 3 egg yolks (or whole eggs, if preferred)
1/2 cup aged rum, preferably El Dorado 12 Year
instructions: 1. In a mixing bowl or serving pitcher, thoroughly whisk (or blend with a hand mixer) the eggs, cream, milk and syrups together.
2. Add the spirits while stirring continuously and grate in a whole bunch of nutmeg, to taste.
3. Refrigerate for at least 3 hours or put in the freezer for 1 hour.
4. To serve, stir one more time, then pour into small wine glasses or punch cups and grate fresh nutmeg over the top.

title: Peanut Punch
intro_philosophy: Baidawi Assing, Trini food expert and director ofEat Ah Food, makes his version of Peanut Punch, a Caribbean staple, with Guinness. He says the beer adds a “punch” to the punch, and also injects some bitterness that contrasts with the drink’s sweetness while emboldening its warm and woody flavors. Texturally, the foamy beer thins and smooths out the thick punch.
instructions: 1. Add ice and milk to the blender, then the rest of the ingredients.
2. Blend until smooth, then pour into a glass.
3. Top with granola and wheat germ.

title: Sanctity of The Gods
intro_philosophy: Abigail Gullo’s Sanctity of The Gods, served at Loa Bar in New Orleans, celebrates the unique flora and fauna of the Mississippi River Delta. Hendrick’s limited-edition Neptunia gin gives the cocktail a distinct herbal character that complements a briny manzanilla sherry. A tincture of Vietnamese fish sauce and Sicilian olive oil provides an extra kick of umami.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, preferably Hendrick’s Neptunia gin
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist and Sicilian olives served on the side in a spent oyster shell.

title: No New Friends
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to make it something that felt like a cocktail, not something that was juicy and has club soda,” says Julia McKinley of her approach to non-alcoholic drinks. Rather than work from an existing cocktail template and simply remove the alcohol, McKinley starts from scratch to build something that feels complete unto itself. Here, turmeric tonic and hibiscus teas form the base of No New Friends, while lime and CBD-infused agave add sweet and sour components and aquafaba lends texture. The result is “something that has a little bitterness, a little spice and beautiful texture.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Organic Kilogram Turmeric Tea, steeped overnight
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a Nick and Nora glass.
3. Express the lemon peel and discard.

title: Blended Grasshopper
intro_philosophy: This mint-green cream-based drink was reportedly invented pre-Prohibition in a 1919 New York City cocktail contest in which Philbert Guichet, owner ofTujagque’sin New Orleans, took home second place for this recipe. A combination of equal parts crème de menthe, crème de cacao, and heavy cream, shaken with ice and strained into a cocktail glass falls into the category of sweet after-dinner drinks. This frothy concoction gained traction mid-century, especially in the American South. The core ingredients allow for a host of variations: swap cream for vodka to get the “Vodka” or “Flying Grasshopper,” or add coffee for the “Brown” version. Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s version is based on the Wisconsin tradition of swapping cream for ice cream and throwing it in a blender. He adds a bit of Fernet Branca for a bittersweet bite.
ingredients: 8 ounces crushed ice, prepared with a Lewis bag and mallet or a food processor
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender pitcher.
2. Blend on low speed until smooth.
3. Pour into an old-fashioned soda glass or a tall mug.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig and serve with a straw.

title: Austin Hartman’s Mojito
intro_philosophy: A runner up in our recent blind tasting of Mojitos, Austin Harman’s recipe calls on a blend of three rums.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Rhum J.M Sirop de Canne
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for soda water in a Collins glass and muddle heavily.
2. Add soda water and pack the glass with crushed or cracked ice.
3. Insert the straw and gently agitate the ingredients.
4. Garnish with mint.

title: Sauvage Martini
intro_philosophy: At Sauvage, the presentation of this bracingMartiniis lean and spare: pre-batched in bottles, chilled in the freezer and poured when ordered, inspired by similar presentation at London hotel bars and in Japan. Here’s a version to make a generous single-serve version at home, as well as the instructions for batching (and freezing) ahead.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir together all ingredients with ice.
2. Stir and strain into a coupe.
3. Serve with a sidecar of ice, caper berry, nasturtium blossom, fresh juniper sprig and lemon peel.

title: Winter Leaf Fizz
intro_philosophy: During a period of experimentation with tea, Kelsey Ramage built this cocktail around the flavor of Seedlip’s Spice 94 paired with vibrant, fruity rooibos from Sloane Fine Tea Merchants. Whereas it might have been easy to fall back on baking spice elements, Ramage challenged herself to expand the palette she was working with; instead, she reached for house-fermented cranberry wine (whose residual alcohol is cooked off) and mandarin-infused oleo saccharum. The result is a refreshing, almost spring-y drink with floral notes and unexpected viscosity and subtle spice.
ingredients: 10 milliliters  mandarin oleo saccharum (see Editor’s Note)
40 milliliters brewed rooibos tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Build ingredients in a highball glass over ice.
2. Using a barspoon, lift all the ingredients together without agitating to maintain carbonation.

title: Sakura Colada
intro_philosophy: Inspired by a cherry blossom tree, Corriveau’s Sakura Colada marries the botanicals of gin and kirsch with coconut milk, vanilla syrup and a small measure of red bean paste. “The gin is…the blossom or petals, the coconut and vanilla are sort of like the sap of that flower and the red bean is the stalk,” explains Corriveau. “It’s bright and refreshing, just as much as it is decadent.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces gin, preferably Tanqueray No. Ten
1/2 ounce brandy, preferably Clear Creek Kirschwasser
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a pilsner glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a lime peel flower and mint sprig.

title: Ford Cocktail
intro_philosophy: The improved formula—that is, the traditional recipe gussied up with a splash of this or that—informs many early Martinis poised for a comeback, including the Ford Cocktail, which addsBénédictineinto the mix alongside several dashes of orange bitters.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stirred until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Crown of Castile
ingredients: 1/2 part Giffard Sirop aux Fruits de la Passion
1/4 part Ancho Reyes Verde Chile Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients, except for sparkling wine, in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Pour into a wineglass and top with the sparkling wine.

title: The Saturn
intro_philosophy: While the Singapore Sling is perhaps the best-known gin cocktail in the tiki genre, “the Saturn deserves the mantle of the perfect gin tiki cocktail,” says Garret Richard, who put the drink on the menu for the Exotica night he hosts monthly at New York’sSlowly Shirley. The original drink, which was discovered by Jeff  “Beachbum” Berry, is credited to California bartender J. “Popo” Galsini, who won the International Bartender’s Association World Championship in 1967 with the cocktail.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender with the crushed ice.
2. Flash-blend and pour into a rocks glass filled with ice.
3. Garnish with a lime twist wrapped around a cherry, secured with a toothpick.

title: PSG&T (Pumpkin Spice Gin & Tonic)
intro_philosophy: Perhaps no one cocktail captures Richard Beltzer’s style as aptly as his PSG&T, or Pumpkin Spice Gin & Tonic, a seasonal spin that calls on squash syrup and cinnamon-infused gin. It marries the familiar highball template with a sustainable bent (the syrup extends the life of the squash), while cheekily nodding to the ubiquity—and yes, deliciousness—of the Pumpkin Spice Latte. “I want the people who look at the Pumpkin Spice Latte at Starbucks and want it, to order this drink,” explains Beltzer—“but without the insecurity.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounces manzanilla sherry, preferably La Guita
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Topo Chico and tonic water, in a snifter over crushed ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with Topo Chico and tonic water.
4. Garnish with orange wheel, torched cinnamon, grated nutmeg.

title: Jerk Batanga
intro_philosophy: A simple mix of tequila, Coca-Cola, lime and the occasional salted rim, the Batanga is a refreshing drink, and it’s easy to see why it recently became so viral. Riffs on the drink abound, likethe version served at Cicatrizin Mexico City, which introduces Ancho Reyes chile liqueur to the template, and this version served at New York’s Dolores, which adds a blend of spices and banana to the mix.
ingredients: 1 ounce jerk-infused reposado tequila (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce amontillado sherry, such as Lustau
3/4 ounce banana liqueur blend (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Rim a glass with salt, then fill it with ice.
2. Add all ingredients to the glass and gently stir to incorporate.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Brennan’s Brandy Milk Punch
intro_philosophy: “Breakfast at Brennan’s” started as an answer toDinner at Antoine’s, the 1947 Frances Parkinson Keyes murder mystery that bookends its drama with dinner parties at Antoine’s restaurant in New Orleans. Opened by legendary NoLa restaurateur, Ella Brennan,Brennan’sinvented brunch. Yes, it’s true. And along with its conception came a host of eye-opener cocktails including classics like Brandy Milk Punch, a mouth-coating mix of French brandy, sugared-up cream and fresh nutmeg.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Jabberwocky
intro_philosophy: “Manzanilla is great in stirred drinks because it is lean and dry, which adds a mouth-watering quality to cocktails,” explains Andrew Meltzer, Bar Manager at San Francisco’s sherry-centric 15 Romolo. In his Jabberwocky—adapted from the Jabberwock, which originally appeared in the 1930Savoy Cocktail Book—manzanilla, gin and Lillet Blanc combine in equal parts for a delicate, floral drink.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a chilled mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Averna Stout Flip
intro_philosophy: Beer cocktail guru Jacob Grier, author ofCocktails on Tap, calls the Averna Stout Flip one of his favorite creations. Working with the idea that dark beer likes dark spirits, Grier developed the drink while guest bartending at a Prohibition-themed spot in Portland. This boozy milkshake-like concoction works best with heavier stouts (think something like Young’s Double Chocolate Stout).
ingredients: 1 ounce stout (like Young's Double Chocolate Stout or Samuel Smith's Oatmeal Stout)
instructions: 1. Crack the egg into a shaker.
2. Add the Averna, stout, bitters and ice then shake hard until cold and frothy.
3. Strain into a wine glass.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Billy Ray Valentine
intro_philosophy: In this spin on thePiña Colada, Devin Kennedy uses just a half-ounce of Trinidadian rum, letting Madeira contribute most of the body to the cocktail. To the expected coconut and pineapple juice, he also adds a half-ounce of amontillado sherry, for a slight nutty note, and a teaspoon each of cinnamon syrup and banana liqueur as “the salt and pepper.” It is, in Kennedy’s words, “the perfect Piña Colada.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce amontillado sherry , preferably Lustau "Los Arcos"
1 ounce coco biz (1/2 ounce coconut milk, 1/2 ounce coconut cream)
1 teaspoon banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banane du Bresil
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin with crushed ice and 3 standard ice cubes.
2. Flash blend with a drink mixer.
3. Strain into Pilsner glass over crushed ice.
4. Garnish with trimmed Piña fronds and shaved cinnamon.

title: Beach Plum Whiskey Sour
intro_philosophy: Robert Simonson made several beach-to-glass cocktails with his homemade beach plum syrup, but his favorite was a Whiskey Sour variation: 2 ounces bourbon, ¾ ounce lemon juice, ¾ ounce beach plum syrup. “Sometimes making do does just fine,” he notes.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce beach plum syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain up into a coupe or over the rocks in an Old-Fashioned glass.

title: Vulture’s Gimlet
intro_philosophy: At Vulture in San Diego, the Gimlet calls on lime juice and a few wedges thrown directly into the shaker.“This unlocks the bright citrus oils from the peels as well as some angular, bitter flavors from the pith,” says Lucas Ryden, the bar’s cocktail and spirits manager. “I call it ‘3D lime flavor.’” For a savory undertone, a quarter-ounce of fino sherry and a pinch of celery salt round out the drink.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce gin, such as Oka Japanese Gin
1/2 ounce overproof gin, such as Bimini
instructions: 1. Cut the lime in half. Juice one half (about 1/2 ounce of juice) into a shaker. Cut the other half into three wedges, then squeeze and drop the wedges into the shaker.
2. Add the rest of the ingredients to the shaker with ice and shake hard.
3. Double strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Mediterránea
intro_philosophy: For years, bartender Keith Mrotek, of Flora Room in Minneapolis, has been mixing drinks with Primitivizia, a bottled mugolio byEleonora Cunaccia, a forager who canvasses the Dolomites for the choicest cones. The Mediterránea features mugolio alongside alpine gin and alpine liqueur, ginger syrup and citrus. “Categorically, I’ve used [mugolio] in gin-based cocktails because I feel like it can—magically—remove some of the ‘pine’ taste that gin cocktails have and mellow it out a little bit,” Mrotek explains. “It adds complexity in a way that you can’t wrap your head around. It’s like MSG or shio koji.”
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces tonic water, preferably Fever-Tree, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except tonic water in a cocktail shaker with ice and briefly shake.
2. Strain into a highball glass with ice and top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with a pine cone and three buzz buttons.

title: Negroni Bianco
intro_philosophy: The Negroni Bianco served at Dante’s two New York locations—a mixture of gin, both blanc and dry vermouths, Tempus Fugit’s Kina L’Aéro d’Or, a dash of verjus and lemon bitters served up in a Nick & Nora glass—was  well-liked in our blind tasting of 10 White Negronis for its “gentle” approach to the drink and its pleasing roundness.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat Extra Dry
1 ounce Tempus Fugit Kina l’Aéro D’or
2 dashes lemon bitters, preferably Bitter Truth
1 dash of verjus, preferably Fusion Napa Valley Verjus Blanc
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with an expressed and discarded lemon twist and baby’s breath flowers

title: Jen Akin’s Ti’ Punch
intro_philosophy: The winning drink in our recent blind Ti’ Punch tasting came from Jen Akin of Rumba. Her version consists of half a barspoon of Sirop J.M (a brand of bottled cane syrup from Martinique), a small lime coin and two ounces of Rhum J.M Blanc 100-proof. The judges loved the body and strong flavors of the drink. “This tastes correct,” said Kate Perry, a former Rumba bartender and the US market manager for La Maison & Velier.
ingredients: 2 ounces rhum agricole, preferably Rhum J.M Blanc 100-proof
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, add the lime, then syrup, then the rhum.
2. Swizzle and serve.

title: Jamie Boudreau’s Absinthe Frappé
intro_philosophy: Jamie Boudreau’s take on the Absinthe Frappé uses a touch of Dimmi, a modern Italian aperitivo liqueur, to sweeten and complement the classic combination of absinthe, mint and sugar served over ice. “Dimmi works as it’s not an overtly powerful spirit,” explains Boudreau, “and the licorice notes tie in with the absinthe, with the citrus and vanilla playing along as well.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce créme de menthe , preferably Giffard
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients.
2. Strain into a cobbler glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a mint leaf.

title: Batida de Coco
intro_philosophy:
In the Batida,one of Brazil’s most beloved drinks, sweetness is an essential, unapologetic component, which is why bartender Igor Renovato incorporated a hint of condensed milk—a contentious ingredient among local bartenders—in his coconut-spiked version.

Nestled on the iconic Rua da Lapa in downtown Rio, Surubar serves liters upon liters of Renovato’s Batida de Coco. The bartender attributes its popularity to the meticulously balanced blend of flavors, which change over time. “The Batida is essentially a pre-batched cocktail, which matures and enhances its flavor after a few days in the fridge, gaining body and intensifying its flavor profile,” he says. “I recommend letting it sit for seven days. But at Surubar, it always disappears much sooner.”
ingredients: 7 ounces fresh coconut meat, cut into chunks
instructions: 1. Blend everything except for the cachaça in a high-speed blender until the coconut pieces are finely chopped and integrated.
2. Add the cachaça and mix well.
3. Bottle the mixture and refrigerate for 7 days before serving.
4. To serve, pour into a cup.

title: Gin Daisy (Old and New)
intro_philosophy: As with many of the classics, there are actually two genres of Gin Daisy, with a historical dividing line somewhere around the turn of the twentieth century. The basic daisy formula, as designed in the 1870s, is more or less a sour kicked up with a few dashes of orange liqueur. Later, the daisy got a makeover: the gin ratio was knocked down, simple syrup was added for texture, and grenadine was swapped in for the orange liqueur. Both renditions are simple, quaffable drinks that deserve more play. Follow this recipe for the true old-school version, or try her fruitier sister, below.
instructions: 1. Add gin, orange liqueur, and lemon juice to a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until chilled.  Strain over ice into a rocks or Collins glass and top up with soda water. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

2. To make the new-school Gin Daisy, add 1½ ounces gin, ½ ounce lemon juice, ¼ ounce grenadine, and ¼ ounce simple syrup to a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until chilled. Strain over ice into a Collins or rocks glass and top with soda water. Garnish with an orange slice.

title: Dante’s House Manhattan for Two
intro_philosophy: This drink for two is bottled, chilled in the freezer and served with dramatic flourish: a tray arrives bearing the drink, along with a candle, a small bowl of smoked almonds and a choice of brandied cherries and orange knots, for the guest to garnish their drink as they see fit. “A whisper” of two nut-based liqueurs, Frangelico and walnut-y Nocino, add nuanced sweetness.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bottle.
2. Shake to combine, then store the bottle in the freezer.
3. To serve, divide the contents of the bottle between two Nick & Nora glasses.
4. Garnish each drink with a brandied cherry and orange peel knot.

title: Better Luck Tomorrow’s Gibson
intro_philosophy: Some young mixologists have lately found in blanc vermouth the key to balancing aGibson. Such is the case with this lovely version by Alex Negranza, of the Houston bar Better Luck Tomorrow. A touch of pear liqueur further softens the mixture, while a playful triple garnish of two onions and garlic add bite and a visual flourish.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces London dry gin, preferably Beefeater
1/2 ounce red onion-infused gin (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce pear liqueur, preferably Rothman & Winter
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with pickled red onion, pearl cocktail onion and pickled green garlic.

title: Fumata Bianca
intro_philosophy:
This is a soft, yet edgy mixture of sweet, herbal and smoky that goes down easy, despite the challenging flavors involved.

Reprinted with permission from3-Ingredient Cocktails: An Opinionated Guide to the Most Enduring Drinks in the Cocktail Canonby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2017. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a Collins glass.
2. Add ice and top with club soda.
3. Express a grapefruit twist over the drink and drop into the glass.

title: Swamp Thing
intro_philosophy: At Los Angeles bar Night on Earth, the Swamp Thing takes the Swampwater—a slushy cocktailinvented by Chartreusein the 1970s—and makes it modern. Their take on the party drink, using a method learned from fellow L.A. bartender Austin Hennelly, clarifies it in coconut milk, which involves straining with a slotted hotel pan, a vessel that increases surface area to speed up the clarification process.
ingredients: 1 1/2 liters (51 ounces) sencha tea concentrate (see Editor’s Note)
750 milliliters (25 ounces) clairin, such as Saint Benevolence
500 milliliters (17 ounces) lime cordial (see Editor’s Note)
375 milliliters (12 1/2 ounces) Planteray Stiggins’ Fancy Pineapple Rum
instructions: 1. Cover a slotted hotel pan with a dye-free piece of cloth and set it over a large, clear container.
2. In a separate, nonreactive container, combine all ingredients except the coconut milk.
3. In a third container, measure the coconut milk, then slowly pour the cocktail mixture into the coconut milk. Stir gently until solids form.
4. After the mixture separates, pour it over the cloth-lined hotel pan to start the straining process.

5. If the milk punch doesn’t fully clarify after the first pass, pour the mixture back over the solids until the strained liquid comes out clear. (The milk solids are doing the work of clarification, not the cloth.)
6. Refrigerate the collected clarified liquid until ready to serve.
7. To serve, pour 4 1/2 ounces of the mixture over a large ice cube in a rocks glass.

title: Daq Attack
intro_philosophy: The Let’s Go Disco & Cocktail Club in Los Angeles, a new bar from Lee Zaremba and the team behind De La Nonna’s Pizza, channels a late 1970s and ’80s Italian discoteca with drinks like the Garibaldi Spritz and theFizz Italiano, served in a dusty rose-colored stucco space that will houses a DJ booth, vinyl-filled shelves, a 24-foot green marble bar and Mario Bellini–style sofas. Alongside the expected Italian-inspired drinks are a few twists on classics, like this bright, kiwi-tinged take on the Daiquiri built on two types of rum.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with freshly grated black lime or a lime twist.

title: Beachfire Margarita
intro_philosophy:
I call this a Beachfire Margarita because the smoky nuances of mezcal remind me of a driftwood bonfire on the beach. My favorite mezcals are San Luis del Rio, Minero, and Chichicapa, all made under the auspices of Del Maguey. Fans of peaty Islay single-malts will probably enjoy this margarita, too.

Reprinted with permission fromArtisanal Cocktailsby Scott Beattie. Copyright (c) 2008 by Scott Beattie. Photo (c) 2008 Sara Remington.Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Rub a slice of lime around the rim of a Collins glass.  Press lip of the glass into a plate of coarse salt. Shake off any excess and set aside.
2. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker, add ice and shake.
3. Strain over ice into prepared Collins glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: St. John Frizell’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: In our blind tasting of 20 Daiquiris from America’s top bartenders, St. John Frizell’s recipe came in second. In his rendition, he relies on two ounces of Denizen Aged White Rum, three-quarters of an ounce of lime juice and three-quarters of an ounce of simple syrup (1:1) for a Daiquiri that had a surprising amount of depth and fruit character, which one panelist described as, “like that perfect piece of grapefruit that you spoon out and pop into your mouth.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, add ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: River Tam Martini
intro_philosophy: At Amor y Amargo, where all ten menu items are batched or prepared, Sother Teague explains that not only does this technique ensure consistency (“you’re getting soup from the same pot”) it enables a higher level of precision in a single drink. A minuscule amount of one ingredient, such as Japanese chili and lime bitters, diffused into a 750ml bottle, as in this slightly spicy Martini riff, creates an effect impossible to recreate in a single pour.
ingredients: 1/8 ounce Japanese chili bitters, preferably 18.21 Bitters
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a 720 or 750ml bottle.
2. Seal and store in the refrigerator.

title: Neal Bodenheimer’s Porron Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Asked which cocktail he’d choose to porron, Neal Bodenheimer created this “inverted Martini” at PUNCH HQ. Made with (mostly) chilled ingredients, the large format drink builds onPineau des Charentes, gin and orange bitters, plus filtered water for dilution, for a refreshing, low proof variation on the classic that can be built directly in the vessel—no stirring required.
ingredients: 3 ounces  Pineau des Charentes, preferably Jean-Luc Pasquet, chilled
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients directly in the porron.
2. Garnish with lemon twists.

title: Solid Gold Cadillac
intro_philosophy:
All the drinks at midcentury-themed Bottle Club Pub reference classic American songs; this Golden Cadillac riff is named for a 1956 Pearl Bailey ballad.
