A word of advice from Jayson Wilde: Don’t try to hurry the melting process on the stovetop or microwave. “It changes the structure of the ice cream,” he says. Wilde cuts a 3-gallon tub of ice cream in half, peels off the cardboard, sets it in a large Cambro container and allows it to melt overnight.
ingredients: 1 ounce Giffard white crème de cacao
1 1/2 ounces French vanilla cream (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Flash-blend all ingredients in a Hamilton Beach blender (or other stand-up mixer).
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Amaris
intro_philosophy: “This drink was truly a labor of love,” says New York bartender Aaron Polsky. The Amaris is named for a woman he wanted to win back and combines her favorite ingredients: bittersweet Gran Classico and Fernet Branca. “I struggled with it, and finally it came together when I added Strega,” he says. Built entirely from herbal liqueurs, it’s a super-layered drink with no reference-point within a specific cocktail family. “I look at this cocktail as an aggressive combination: It’s about finding harmony within oppression,” he says.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled rocks glass.

title: The Mexican Gentleman
intro_philosophy: Simply sherry, sugar and citrus, shaken, poured over crushed ice and slurped through a straw, the originalSherry Cobbleris thought to have originated sometime in the 1820s or early 1830s. But like most 19th century drinks, its origins are foggy. Denver bartender Sean Kenyon’s take layers two sherries with tequila, mezcal and a mess of seasonal berries.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, lightly muddle berries and orange wheel.
2. Add all other ingredients, add ice and shake.
3. Strain half into a Collins glass over crushed ice and stir.
4. Add more crushed ice and strain the remaining half over top.
5. Stir to frost the glass and top with berries for garnish.

title: 2020 Visions
intro_philosophy: Chris Elford spent time behind the bar at New York’sAmor y Amargo, so it’s no surprise to find him embracing the use of amaro in classic tiki and tropical drink templates. Elford calls this drink, which features the versatile artichoke-based amaro Cynar, “one of the most crushable drinks we’ve ever created.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Navy Stength Grenadine (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with a small amount of crushed ice.
2. Pour into a double Old-Fashioned glass and top with more crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a fresh mint bouquet, freshly grated cinnamon and nutmeg.

title: They Can’t Kill Us All
intro_philosophy: This is a simplified version of the drink made at Allegory, where the purple cocktail is playfully illuminated by a light-up coaster. An alternate presentation: “Carefully use the flashlight of your phone,” Dunne suggests. “You won’t be disappointed!”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit
3/4 ounce yuzu juice (or equal parts lemon and lime juice)
instructions: 1. Combine first five ingredients in a container.
2. Heat the kefir on the stovetop or in the microwave. Bring it to a simmer, but do not boil. Simmering will cause the kefir to curdle, which is good.

3. Add the warm kefir to the container with the cocktail, and let sit for at least 30 minutes. The acid from the citrus juice and sherry will cause the kefir to curdle further. The longer the mixture is allowed to sit, the better the final clarity will be.

4. Strain cocktail through a coffee filter; the filtered cocktail should be clear, with a yellowish hue. For a clearer drink, filter it again through the curds, using the same filter. This can be repeated as desired.
5. Add ube syrup, and stir to incorporate.
6. To serve, pour the cocktail into a rocks glass, over a large ice cube and stir to chill.

title: Bananas Is My Business
intro_philosophy: Adam Bernbach plays off of the fruit and spice character found in Ayinger Bräu Weisse, an unfiltered Bavarian wheat beer, in the bar’s famous Bananas Is My Business. “It’s conceptualized around the various types of banana flavors in Hefeweizen,” says Bernbach. Rounded out with banana soda, white whiskey and a touch of bitter amaro, the drink recalls the flavors of fresh, roasted and candied banana.
ingredients: 2 ounces Hefeweizen beer, preferably Ayinger Bräu Weisse
1 ounce white whiskey, preferably High West Silver Oat Whiskey
instructions: 1. Build the drink in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Gambol and Snap
intro_philosophy: A refreshing springtime drink featuring Dimmi alongside tequila, the Gambol and Snap conjures notes of stone fruit, melon and marmalade. “The acidity from the lime cordial and effervescence from the beer are both far too subtle to bring the drink into shandy territory,” says Chaim Dauermann, but together they lend the drink a subdued sweetness.
instructions: 1. Muddle the cucumbers in a mixing glass.
2. Add all ingredients except saison.
3. Stir with ice.
4. Add the saison and stir again.
5. Double strain into a double rocks glass over block ice.
6. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Frozen Fitzgerald
intro_philosophy: A frozenGin Sourthat manages to be crisp and aromatic at the same time. Team White Lyan suggests an additional splash of absinthe or celery bitters to up the herbaceous quality, if desired.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a sealable container, such as a freezer bag or tupperware, with as little air as possible.
2. Freeze overnight.
3. Blend all ingredients until smooth or agitate with a spoon and pour into a cocktail glass.

title: Viva Alberti
intro_philosophy: The base ingredient in Will Elliott’s complex spritz is the idiosyncratic saffron-infused Strega, a brilliant-yellow bitter liqueur whose name means “witch” in Italian. Named for the memory of Giuseppe Alberti, who founded the Strega distillery in 1860 in Benevento, Italy, this herbal, savory spritz boldly carries his name forth.
instructions: 1. Add the Strega, Cognac, Cappelletti Aperitivo, lemon juice, and bitters to a wine glass.
2. Add cracked ice, and stir until chilled.
3. Top with sparkling wine and add the garnish.

title: Whey Punch
intro_philosophy: Ryan Chetiyawardanaopts for yogurt whey (the result of straining full-fat yogurt for half an hour) to add richness to his wintry Whey Punch. Chetiyawardana notes that the cocktail—mixed with Scotch, maple syrup and rooibos tea—maintains the spirit of a clarified milk punch with a fast-tracked method. “It still manages to get the silkiness you want to drink,” he says.
ingredients: scant 1 3/4 ounces yogurt whey (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a highball glass over large ice cubes.
3. Garnish with an orange horse's neck and a discarded lemon coin.

title: Floradora
intro_philosophy: Originally named in honor of a Broadway musical from 1900,this gin buck with raspberry and limewas included in Jacques Straub’s 1913 bookManual of Mixed Drinks. Alba Huerta, of Julep in Houston, originally encountered it on a trip to New York 15 years ago and brought it back to Texas with her. There, she’s championed it for a long time, first with a frozen version at Grand Prize Bar, followed by a more straightforward take at Julep, where it’s been on the classics menu for years.
ingredients: 2 ounces dry gin, such as Condesa
1/2 ounce raspberry syrup, such as Zergut
ginger beer, such as Q Mixers, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all but the ginger beer in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass and top with ginger beer.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel and raspberry on a pick.

title: Tre Sorelle
intro_philosophy: Alicia Perry qualifies her Tre Sorelle as a “delicate yet revitalizing variation on the Pisco Sour.” To complement the grappa at the heart of L’Aperitivo Nonino, Perry combined it with a moscatel pisco, whose notes of pear, orange blossom and cardamom pair with Nonino’s own floral flavor profile. Its name, “Tre Sorelle,” means “three sisters” in Italian and is a nod to Nonino’s current team of distillers: sisters Cristina, Antonella and Elisabetta. “I wanted to create a cocktail that highlighted the soft citrus and floral notes of the product,” says Perry, “whilst also paying homage to the story behind it.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except grapes to a shaker tin and dry shake.
2. Add grapes and ice, then shake firmly to ensure proper dilution and muddling of grapes.
3. Fine-strain into a coupe and garnish with a sprig of lavender.

title: Crusta Alcala
intro_philosophy: At Jewel of the South in New Orleans, Chris Hannah and Nick Detrich have dedicated an entire concept to Joseph Santini, the inventor of theBrandy Crusta, where, naturally, the Crusta is king. The Crusta Alcala is their mixture of tequila, mezcal, lime juice, yellow Chartreuse and a small measure of crème de cacao served in a glass coated with a coffee-sugar rim, garnished with an orange peel.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass rimmed with a coffee-sugar mixture (see Editor's Note) and garnish with an orange peel.

title: Gin Daisy (New School)
intro_philosophy: This drink is a variation on the basic Daisy formula: a sour kicked up with the addition of seltzer or soda water. Like any of the classics, the Gin Daisy is divided into two distinct genres: the Old School and the New School. The former relies on orange liqueur for its citrusy backbone while the latter knocks down the gin ratio and substitutesgrenadinefor a fruitier flavor.
instructions: 1. Add gin, lemon juice, grenadine and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Garnish with a slice of orange.

title: Paper Plane
intro_philosophy:
Sam Ross, the longtime bartender at Milk & Honey (now Attaboy), created this simple, equal-parts drink for the opening menu at The Violet Hour in Chicago, a bar where he never worked. “It’s my second most well-traveled drink,” after the Penicillin, said Ross. It is particularly popular in Toronto, for reasons that remain mysterious to Ross. “It is essentially the official drink of Toronto,” he said. “It is on every cocktail menu in Toronto.” It is made with the Italian bitter Aperol and the Italian amaro Nonino Quintessentia, two ingredients whose stars rose with the cocktail movement. (The original recipe contained Campari, but that was quickly supplanted with Aperol, which became the norm.) The drink was named after a song by the British rapper M.I.A. that Ross was listening to while he tried to come up with the recipe.

Reprinted with permission fromAProper Drinkby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker three-quarters filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: Why Not
intro_philosophy: “When we started brunch five years ago,” explains T.J. Lynch, “we had this silly idea to buy a slushy machine to do a frozen signature brunch cocktail.” What began as a one-off experiment became a marker of Lynch’s fast-casual approach to drinks, and a prime example of the thoughtfulness and culinary sensibility that goes into nearly every drink, no matter how short-lived (at Mother’s Ruin, slushy recipes change daily, and never repeat). This frozen Paloma-style slushy topped with a five-chile molasses swirl “began our 400-plus recipe love story with our slushy machine,” explains Lynch.
instructions: 1. Blend all ingredients with ice.
2. Swirl a rocks glass with five-chile molasses before filling.
3. Pour the mixture into the prepared glass and top with more molasses.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Eponine Collins
intro_philosophy: A French-inflected Collins served at New York City’s Frenchette builds on a base of gin, complemented by Suze and Amaro Montenegro alongside both grapefruit and lemon juice.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice and top with soda.
3. Garnish with 2 cucumber slices and 2 basil leaves.

title: Golden Hour
intro_philosophy: This citrusy cocktail is clarified using strawberry yogurt, then carbonated to spritz-ready effervescence. Stilmann pre-batches and bottles the drink, and serves it in a balloon glass decorated with edible paint, post-graffiti-style.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
1/2 bar spoon  Salers gentian liqueur (in an atomizer)
1/2 bar spoon  strawberry mist (in an atomizer) (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Place yogurt in a container, then slowly pour in ITALICUS and vinho verde. Stir gently to combine. Let curdle, then strain through a coffee filter to clarify.
2. Add citric acid, then force-carbonate and bottle at a PSI of 50. (At this point the drink can be bottled in individual portions.)
3. Tag the outside of a balloon glass with edible spray paint.
4. Spray the inside of the glass with Salers.
5. Pour the clarified cocktail into the prepared glass over large pieces of cracked ice.
6. Spray strawberry mist over the top of the drink.

title: Alco’hall & Oates
intro_philosophy:
The inspiration for this drink was “an impulse for nostalgia,” says Aneka Saxon, director of beverage development at Chicago’s Machine. She wants guests to recognize at first sip that “this is chocolate milk, through and through, with alcohol in it, that I get to enjoy as a grown-up, with no shame.”

At the restaurant, the cocktail is presented in a ceramic milk vessel for guests to “pour into the bowl,” aka a rocks glass half-filled with Cocoa Puffs. Alternatively, the drink can be enjoyed on its own.
ingredients: 5 ounces Cocoa Puffs-infused oat milk (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except Cocoa Puffs in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass filled with Cocoa Puffs.

title: Jerez Tonic
intro_philosophy: In a bold spin on the G&T,Leanne Favrepairs the requisite gin with slightly saline manzanilla sherry and a small measure of banana liqueur, all topped with housemade lemongrass tonic. “By [creating] my own tonic water, I can manipulate the sugar [and] bitter elements of the soda,” she explains. The result is a low-ABV highball with hints of the tropics.
ingredients: Top with lemongrass tonic (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine first three ingredients in a highball glass over ice.
2. Top with lemongrass tonic.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Beuser & Angus Special
intro_philosophy: A Chartreuse sour from Berlin, the Beuser & Angus Special takes inspiration from the Last Word and the Ramos Gin Fizz. Created in 2007 by Gonçalo de Sousa Monteiro for fellow bartenders Bastian Heuser and Angus Winchester, the drink has gone on to become a modern classic.
instructions: 1. Combine the first five ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake hard with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice.
3. Top with orange flower water.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Caitlin Laman’s Manhattan
intro_philosophy: Caitlin Laman’s (formerly ofTrick Dog) bourbon Manhattan came in third in our tasting of 17 different Manhattans from America’s top bartenders. Her two-parts whiskey to one-part vermouth, plus Angostura, formula was classic, but her liquor choices unusual. The bourbon was the oft-overlooked Johnny Drum 101, and the vermouth was the California-conceived, Italian-made Tempus Fugit Alessio Vermouth di Torino.
ingredients: 2 ounces Johnny Drum Bourbon Private Stock 101
1 ounce Tempus Fugit Alessio Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass, and garnish with a brandied cherry (See Editor's Note).

title: Banana Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: In her classicDaiquiririff,Julie Reinerplays up the ripe flavors of fresh banana with Giffard Banane du Brésil and a two-rum blend, plus lime juice and Demerara syrup.
ingredients: 1 ounce Jamaican rum, such as Planteray
1 ounce white rum, such as Planteray 3 Stars
1 ounce banana liqueur, such as Giffard Banane du Brésil
1/2 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel and cocktail umbrella.

title: Ryan Lotz’s Rum-Old Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Honorable mention at our blind rum Old-Fashioned tasting went to Ryan Lotz of Shore Leave in Boston, whose recipe one panelist called “zippy” with a “bracing quality,” a key attribute to the Old-Fashioned format. It was considered by the judges to represent the ideal rum Old-Fashioned for rye drinkers. As bar owner Paul McGee observed, “this is how you convert whiskey drinkers.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces unces Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton Estate Signature Blend
1/2 ounce agricole rhum, preferably Rhum J.M VSOP
Scant ¼ ounce  Demerara syrup (1:1, Demerara sugar: water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass with one large ice cube and stir briefly.
2. Garnish with an orange and a lemon twist.

title: No Say
intro_philosophy: “I wanted a cocktail that I could drink on the beach in the tropics,” says Pamela Wiznitzer of her mezcal-based No Say, which sees Aperol, coconut liqueur and lemongrass syrup brightened by fresh lime and pineapple juice.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass with ice.
3. Garnish with a makrut lime leaf.

title: Tonique
intro_philosophy: At Libertine in New York City, the Tonique merges the French classicCalvados & Tonicwith refreshing, vegetal cucumber tones via bitters and a cucumber-flavored tonic water. An apple-based aperitif underscores the flavor of the brandy, while Empirical Spirits’ Plum, I Suppose offers more fruit flavor and Salers provides bittersweet balance.
ingredients: 1 ounce Calvados, preferably Montreuil Sélection or Avallen
1/2 ounce Neversink Apple Apéritif or pommeau
1/4 ounce Empirical Spirits Plum, I Suppose
1 dash fleur de sel saline solution (1:5, fleur de sel to water)
cucumber tonic water, preferably Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic
instructions: 1. Mix the first six ingredients and pour over a large spear ice in a Collins or highball glass.
2. Carefully pour the tonic water into the glass, using a bar spoon to fully incorporate while minimizing loss of carbonation.

title: Fire Island
intro_philosophy: This spicy Margarita variation contains complexity in myriad forms: herbal Strega and a housemadeblood orange–Calabrian chile honey.According to Pink Flamingo bar manager Nick Pikounis, the spiced honey has tons of other applications, too, adding depth toan N/A amaro mule, or invigorating a white rum punch. This is best enjoyed in a spicy, salt-rimmed glass.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanco tequila, such as Arette
1 ounce blood orange–Calabrian chile honey (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Salt the rim of a rocks glass and set aside.
2. Shake ingredients with cube ice.
3. Strain into the prepared rocks glass over cube ice.
4. Garnish with the dehydrated orange half-wheel.

title: Banana Spider
intro_philosophy: Though hardly a new flavor in the history of cocktails—banana liqueur has existed since the late 19th century—banana has been making its way into a growing number of recipes in every form imaginable: fermented, roasted, macerated. In New Orleans, Kirk Estopinal ofCane & Tabledeploys a macerated banana liqueur in the Banana Spider to amplify what is essentially aPisco Sourriff.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banane du Brésil
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and whip shake.
2. Add ice and shake.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with Angostura bitters.

title: Frozen Sherry Margarita
intro_philosophy: For Paul Taylor, Beverage Director of Washington D.C.’s Columbia Room, tequila and sherry go together like “peas and carrots.” Tequila’s affinity for salt finds the perfect match with amontillado sherry, whose production region’s proximity to the ocean introduces a distinct minerality to the fortified wine and acts as a vital bridge between the spirits and the acid from the fresh-squeezed lime.
ingredients: 2 ounces reposado tequila, preferably Altos Reposado
1 ounce Amontillado sherry, preferably Hidalgo "Napoleon" Amontillado
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into chilled snifter glass.
3. Garnish with lime wheel.

title: Satan’s Whiskers
intro_philosophy: The Satan’s Whiskers first appears in print in Harry Craddock’sSavoy Cocktail Bookfrom 1930, but many attribute the drink to the Embassy Club inProhibition-era Hollywood. The speakeasy was opened by restaurateur-cum-playboy Adolph “Eddie” Brandstatter, and played host to his personal entourage of starlets and high rollers. Satan’s Whiskers isa variation on the Bronx, and can be made one of two ways—either “straight” with Grand Marnier, or “curled” with orange curaçao.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Grand Marnier or orange curaçao
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Champagne Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Simply sherry, sugar and citrus, shaken, poured over crushed ice and slurped through a straw, the originalSherry Cobbleris thought to have originated sometime in the 1820s or early 1830s. But like most 19th-century drinks, its origins are foggy. Its simplicity and popularity, however, spawned countless riffs—including the Champagne Cobbler, which gets an effervescent element by swapping the sherry base for bubbles.
instructions: 1. In a highball glass, combine simple syrup and citrus and gently muddle at the bottom of the glass.
2. Fill the glass with crushed ice and top with Champagne.
3. Ornament in a tasty manner with berries in season.

title: Earl Grey MarTEAni
intro_philosophy: “With the opening of Pegu [Club],” explains Dale DeGroff, “Audrey’s singular mission was to get people used to drinking gin again.” Like the use of orange marmalade in the Breakfast Martini or pomegranate syrup in the Juniperotivo, Audrey Saunders introduced the unexpected element of tea by way of Earl Grey-infused gin in her classic sour, helping pave the way for the gin Martini’s return.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce Earl Grey tea-infused gin (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Measure all the ingredients into a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and shake hard to a ten-second count. Strain into a chilled Martini glass, 1/2 rimmed with sugar.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Rocky Mountain Cooler
intro_philosophy: This low-ABV cocktail hails fromThe Stork Club Bar Book, where it was served as an easy-drinking evening cocktail. Tom Richter of Manhattan’s Dear Irving has adapted it (see Editor’s Note) for the modern palate with the addition of cinnamon syrup, turning it into an unorthodox (but no less delicious) winter cocktail.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaking tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass and dust with nutmeg.

title: Hop Skip Jump
intro_philosophy: “Herbal and earthy elements can really complement the flavors found in your beer,” says Zac Sorensen, who uses Cynar and Punt e Mes to accent the hoppy aromas of American Pale Ale. An ode to the bitter purls of yore, the Hop Skip Jump is served in a punch mug and garnished with half an orange wheel.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the beer in a cocktail shaker and shake.
2. Add ice to a punch mug and fill halfway with beer.
3. Strain the shaken ingredients into the mug and garnish with half an orange wheel.

title: Tunnel
intro_philosophy: First appearing in the 1929 bookCocktails de Paris Présentés par RIP, the Tunnel was originally made with gin, dry vermouth, Campari and Vermouth Cora. Franck Audoux’s modernized take, served at his Paris bar Cravan, reads like a French Negroni, which he describes as “drier, bitter, better.”
ingredients: 1/3 ounce Italian vermouth, preferably Punt e Mes
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients until chilled in a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.

title: Cooper’s Regard
intro_philosophy: Bartender Caitlin Pfeiffer highlights Cherry Heering alongside both sweet and savory flavors, calling onfalernumand manzanilla sherry in her rye whiskey-based cocktail. “[The drink] is about demonstrating how Cherry Heering can bring about its own bold flavor,” she explains, “while simultaneously enhancing the spice notes of [the] other ingredients.”
instructions: 1. Build contents in an Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Stir with ice and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Saudade
intro_philosophy: Brazilian native Carolina Malta features flavors of her homeland—cachaça and yerba maté tea—in this delicately spiced drink. The drink’s name—Saudade—is a Portuguese word that describes “the infinite feeling of deeply missing someone,” she explains; a half-ounce of port pays homage to her late Portuguese father.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
1 ounce  clove- and cinnamon-infused aged cachaça (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce  concentrated yerba maté herbal tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice for 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a digestive glass over a single ice cube.
3. Garnish with a sugared banana slice; use a flame to caramelize it.

title: Chartreuse Élixir Végétal & Soda
intro_philosophy: Chartreuse’s typical green and yellow expressions are darlings of the cocktail world. The Élixir Végétal, a concentrated, higher-ABV bottling, however, is less well-known; it has only been available in the U.S. for a few years. The herbal spirit is best used in small doses:spritzed on top of an Alaska, for example, or in place of bitters. Here, it’s simply combined with soda water for an aromatic, low-proof drink.
instructions: 1. Add soda water and Chartreuse Élixir Végétal to a glass over ice, adjusting the ratio to your liking.

title: Veintiuno
intro_philosophy: When people come into Llama San looking for an agave cocktail, this is what Natasha Bermudez steers them toward (the restaurant does not currently keep mezcal on their backbar). Though the ingredients bear little resemblance to the agave spirit, Bermudez entices drinkers with the sour bite of sudachi, which, when paired with shochu, sherry and toasted white sesame syrup is akin to the tangy, slightly saline profile of aMargarita. “It’s obscure, even for this menu, but people love it,” says Bermudez.
ingredients: 1 ounce shochu, preferably Kintaro Mugi Shochu
3/4 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Lustau Amontillado Sherry
1/2 ounce walnut liqueur, preferably Rapa Giovanni Ratafia di Andorno
1/2 ounce toasted white sesame syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with lime zest.

title: Brant Cocktail
intro_philosophy: When he was writingThe Waldorf Astoria Bar Book, Frank Caiafa dove into not just theStingerbut its lesser-known variations, including a rye-based version called the Prince, and the Brant Cocktail, which adds Angostura bitters to the original formula. The Brant originally appeared in George Kappeler’s 1895 book,Modern American Drinks. Though Caiafa likes the way this family of cocktails tastes when the ratio is weighted more toward the base spirit, he believes they are at their best after dinner and, thus, keeps the ratio truer to the original spec.
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces VSOP Cognac, preferably Rémy Martin VSOP
3/4 ounce white crème de menthe, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe, and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Rustic Pimm’s Cup
intro_philosophy: This mash-up of sophisticated Wimbledon cocktail and gap-year-friendly shandy blends high and low sensibilities into one summer-ready drink. Chantal Tseng first learned how to make a Pimm’s Cup from the back of a Pimm’s bottle at the Tabard Inn; this version brings together her love of the classic drink (and tennis) with memories of back-packing through Europe drinking shandygaffs. Cucumber syrup references the traditional garnish and makes it easier to batch. “If Pimm’s Cups were drinks for the sophisticated tennis fans and shandygaffs were for the less-than-mature, learning-how-to-drink kids, then a combination is the Rustic Pimm’s Cup,” says Tseng.
instructions: 1. Mix Pimm's, lemon and lime juices, cucumber syrup and seltzer
2. Add cracked ice, ginger ale and beer.
3. Garnish with cucumber and lemon.

title: Salty Godfather
intro_philosophy: This’70s-era drinkis brought into the modern era by way of an amaretto that’s kicked up with sea salt. Whilethis leaner amarettoallows the drink shine in its original equal-parts formula, we like dialing it back just a bit so it still reads like a whisky-forward drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Monkey Shoulder
instructions: 1. Add the Scotch, amaretto and bitters to a mixing glass, add ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large cube.
3. Express an orange peel over the top of the glass, and discard.

title: Larkin G&T
intro_philosophy: Beginning in the late 19th century, Gin & Tonic became a staple of British gymkhana clubs across the British Raj, exclusive clubs built so colonial officers could play sports and drink, and which often explicitly excluded Indians. Today, the Gin & Tonic hasseen a revivaloutside of the gymkhana club, and is growing out of its colonial associations. Over the past few years, Indian bartenders have put their own spins on the drink, often made with local gins and infused with spices and produce that are native to India and Southeast Asia. At Sidecar in New Delhi, the Larkin G&T is made with a roasted pineapple honey shrub and mace tincture.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce roasted pineapple honey shrub (see Editor’s Note)
scant 1/2 ounce Fake Lime (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the first four ingredients to a goblet or all-purpose wine glass, then top with tonic water.

title: Las Croabas
intro_philosophy: Bolo, whereAntonio Jimenezis head bartender, is a Latin American restaurant in Philadelphia. Working with Bolo’s chef, Yun Fuentes, Jimenez created a ceviche dirty Martini inspired by the Peruvian dish. To the expected base of gin, he adds a chile oil–washed vermouth for spice along with a ceviche brine, a tangy, savory mix that includes ingredients like lime juice, fish stock, passion fruit and ginger. “This drink, with its umami fresh fish notes, reminded me of a beach town on the east coast of Puerto Rico, famous for its fishing community, called Las Croabas,” says Jimenez.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce chile oil–washed dry vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a rolled-up anchovy, cocktail onion and small hot pepper on a skewer.

title: Coco En Rama
intro_philosophy: “When myself and Leo [Robitschek] were in Miami a couple of years ago we fell in love with fresh coconuts with rum in them,” says Nathan McCarley-O’Neill, who channels the spirit of that drink, but puts a decidedly high-brow spin on it. Fino sherry replaces rum and is paired with tarragon-infused blanc vermouth, Cocchi Americano,falernumand un-pasteurized coconut water, which adds a richer mouthfeel without departing too far from the uncomplicated nature of the original inspiration. “It’s super easy drinking.”
ingredients: 1 ounce tarragon-infused blanc vermouth, preferably Dolin (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce coconut water, preferably Harmless Harvest
1 teaspoon pear brandy, preferably Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Raining on 110th St.
intro_philosophy: “The ‘big boy,’ in-your-face nature of Punt e Mes always hits a soft spot for me,” explains Carlton Dunlap, who uses the vermouth in this unconventional take on theManhattan. Appearing alongside the softer Cocchi di Torino, Punt e Mes plays against other surprising additions, such as coffee tincture and Licor 43, in a wetter spin on the classic cocktail.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended vermouth (3 parts Cocchi di Torino to 1 part Punt e Mes)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a Nick and Nora glass and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Melanie’s Moto
intro_philosophy: ThisMojitoriff is named for a bartender that Seth Raymond worked with in Seattle, Melanie Ohlenkant, also a motorcycle enthusiast. “She did cool things with [cocktail] presentation behind the bar,” he recalls. “I think I learned the most from her about presentation.” The over-the-top garnish is an homage to her.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. To garnish, squeeze a lime half over the top of the drink so that pulpy beads fall out.
5. Slap the Thai basil sprigs to activate aroma, then insert into the drink.
6. Place a straw in the drink, then dash bitters over the top.

title: Gema Rosa
intro_philosophy: This floral, Southern-inspired cocktail is a paean to a few of the places around the world that have influenced Cruz’s cocktails and art. The horchata syrup, hibiscus infusion and lime are a nod to his native Mexico, while fino sherry conjures time spent in Spain; Peychaud’s bitters provide a dash of New Orleans flavor.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces hibiscus-infused Bombay Sapphire gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake hard for 10 seconds, then double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
2. Garnish with an edible flower, and use an atomizer to mist the top with Peychaud’s bitters.

title: Amami Island Colada
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

As the name alludes, this tropical-leaning drink is inspired by the Amami Islands, an archipelago in the Kagoshima Prefecture in southern Japan, where Jougo shochu is made. Inspired by the subtropical, high-humidity climate, “I thought a spin on a colada would work perfectly here,” Chris Bostick notes. Since apricots grow well in the region, he added a touch of apricot liqueur, which “really brought this cocktail together.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  matcha brown sugar coconut cream (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with several nuggets of crushed ice.
2. Pour into a frozen double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Fill with crushed ice and pack down, creating a dome of ice above the surface of the drink.
4. Garnish with a matcha-dusted dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Austin Hartman’s Ti’ Punch
intro_philosophy: Coming in third in our recent blind Ti’ Punch tasting, Austin Hartman’s version comprises a mixof one-and-a-half ounces Rhum J.M 110-proof (the highest proof spirit in the tasting), a half-ounce of Sirop J.M and a lime disk.
instructions: 1. Add the lime disk, skin-side facing down, into a rocks glass, then add the syrup and rhum.
2. Place a swizzle stick atop the lime disk and swizzle the punch until the oils, rhum and syrup have blended (about 6 to 8 seconds).

title: Singapore Sling
intro_philosophy: As one of the oldest drink formulas in existence, theSlingwas originally composed simply of spirits, water and a sweetener. The Singapore Sling (more a tikified punch than a sling) is one of the great thirst-quenchers of the 20th century, was created at the Raffles Hotel in 1915 in balmy Singapore. At that time, it was most likely nothing more than gin, citrus, soda and cherry brandy. Over the years, though, it went through a number of hyperbolically sweet phases, some including pre-bottled mixers and canned juices. Today, the Singapore Sling has been dialed back to its drier incarnation using fresh lime juice and cherry brandy.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except for soda to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda.
5. Garnish with a brandied cherry, a pineapple wedge and a mint sprig.

title: Old Frenchie
intro_philosophy: Sebastian Cañas of Yvonne’s in Boston plays on the Old Cuban cocktail in his aperitif, the Old Frenchie. “It’s a refreshing cocktail, with some citrus behind it that will get your palate clean and ready for dinner,” as an aperitif should, he says. White rum and mint, plus a dose of St-Germain and a topper of sparkling wine, makes for a drink that is “floral and elegant,” and ideal for an early evening cocktail.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in cocktail shaker over ice and shake.
2. Double-strain over crushed ice into a tall glass.
3. Top with Champagne. Garnish with mint sprig and a few dashes of bitters.

title: Madeira Park’s Tuxedo
intro_philosophy: The Tuxedo is a classic cocktail from the 19th century. Originally made with gin, fino sherry and bitters, it’s one of the most well-known Martini riffs. AtMadeira Parkin Atlanta, the recipe goes maximalist, with two gins, two vermouths and a tiny bit of Chartreuse Élixir Végétal, which adds herbal flavor to the drink.
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, such as Procera Blue Dot
3/4 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Lustau Blanco
1/2 ounce high-proof gin, such as Martin Miller’s Westbourne
1/2 ounce fino sherry, such as PM Spirits Project Fino Sherry
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, such as Bordiga extra dry
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir for around 40 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express a large lemon peel over the drink, then use as a garnish.

title: Flame of Love
intro_philosophy: The Flame of Love was created by bartender Pepe Ruiz in 1970 for Dean Martin at West Hollywood’s former celebrity hangout, Chasen’s. A variation of the ValenciaMartini, Ruiz’s spin adds flamboyant flair by expressing orange oil through a match flame for a dramatic finish. We’ve adapted ours with bit more sherry and some orange bitters, but just as much showmanship.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until well chilled and strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with aflamed orange peel.

title: Baby, You’re Driving
intro_philosophy:
True to Extra Fancy’s none-too-fancy philosophy, Baby, You’re Driving is simple and refreshing in equal measure. And it’s an easy-to-remember recipe of equal parts, to boot: slightly spicy bison grass vodka, Lillet, grapefruit liqueur and lime.

“The name of course implies that this drink is too good to put down,” explains Krueger. “But, in fact, it’s relatively light, so you can safely have a couple without melting away on a hot day.”
ingredients: 1 ounce bison grass vodka, preferably Żubrówka
1 ounce grapefruit liqueur, preferably Combier Pamplemousse
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish.

title: Amaro Kalimotxo
intro_philosophy: At Quattro Teste in Lisbon, Basque native Alf del Portillo updates the classic Kalimotxo with Amaro Lucano and Branca Menta, a nod to his wife and co-owner Marta’s Italian roots. A lacto-fermented raspberry cordial adds dark fruit and acidity; he likens the effect to the fruity sourness of a lambic beer.
ingredients: heavy 1 ounce Rioja Crianza, preferably Robatie
2 teaspoons lacto-fermented raspberry cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to build over ice in a highball glass.
2. Garnish with a mint crown.

title: Blood Orange Gin Tonica
intro_philosophy: Themodern Gin & Tonicis “not this super high-octane beverage that we were drinking 10 years ago out of a soda gun,” says Matt Reysen, bar director at New York restaurant Mel’s. There, the house Gin Tonica takes a lighter aperitivo approach and changes seasonally. In its late-winter edition, blood orange gin combines with blood orange tonic water, complemented by bright citric acid solution and bittersweet Cappelletti aperitivo liqueur. Crucial to the drink is using the right amount of tonic water; a G&T should have 4 to 5 ounces, according to Reysen.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces blood orange gin, preferably Malfy Blood Orange Gin
3 dashes citric acid solution (see Editor’s Note)
London Essence Blood Orange and Elderflower Tonic, to top
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients to a goblet or stemless glass and stir to incorporate.
2. Top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with a blood orange wheel, pomelo half moon and lemon wheel.

title: Ancho Problem
intro_philosophy: At Boston’s Drink, a menu-less bar that specialized in on-the-fly bartender’s choice drinks, one of the most common refrains heard from guests was: “I’d like something spicy with tequila.” Ezra Star’s go-to cocktail was this chile-spiked Ancho Problem, which gets its heat from Ancho Reyes chile liqueur and astringent blanco tequila.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.

title: One Night in Bangkok
intro_philosophy: “It embodies the things I love in drinks these days,” explains Liz Pearce of her loose spin on a Gimlet. “There’s a kick from the plum sake…and an exotic spice flavor from the syrup, which I made using ingredients leftover from cooking Thai food.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Crème de Banane
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with Thai long pepper and kaffir lime leaf.

title: Dunhill
ingredients: 1 ounce Lustau East India Solera Sherry
1/4 ounce orange Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
instructions: 1. Fill a rocks glass with ice, add the absinthe, and set aside.
2. In a mixing glass add the gin, sherry, vermouth and curaçao, fill with ice, and stir.
3. Empty the rocks glass, coating the sides with the absinthe.
4. Add a large ice cube to the rocks glass and strain the stirred ingredients into the glass.
5. Garnish with the lemon peel.

title: Vermouth and Tonic
intro_philosophy: In Spain, vermouth is traditionally consumed on the rocks in a copa glass, garnished with an orange and a lime. But Greta Inglis, co-owner of London’s El Vermut, also encourages guests to explore her 30-plus vermouth selection with the aid of tonic. Albarino-derived St. Petroni Vermu Vermello, from Galicia; and Montseta Blanco, produced in Valls, are her sweet and dry picks for this simple highball.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces vermouth, preferably St. Petroni Vermu Vermello or Montseta Blanco
instructions: 1. Combine vermouth and tonic in a copa glass over ice.
2. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Red Clay Bamboo
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu running through March 31st, 2022—learn more and find a bar near you.

A Japanese shochu-based riff on the classic Bamboo, this drink is designed with flavors that complement but don’t overpower the spirit, such as tropical fruit and almond. Thinking of the sweet potato that the Red Satan shochu is derived from, Dead Rabbit’s Aidan Bowie uses coconut water, sherry and saline solution to “season” the drink’s star ingredient. Note: If sushi rice is unavailable, cooked long white rice is a fine substitute.
ingredients: 2 dashes  saline solution(4 parts water to 1 part salt)
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, gently muddle shochu and sushi rice.
2. Add remaining ingredients to mixing glass, and stir to chill.
3. Fine-strain into a chilled clay pot.
4. Garnish with a disc of fresh banana, speared on a cocktail pick.

title: Fanny Chu’s Paloma
intro_philosophy: The most unusual Paloma to chart at our blind tasting came from Fanny Chu, most recently of Brooklyn’sDonna. She combined 1 1/2 ounces Espolón tequila with 3/4 ounce each of Ruby Red grapefruit and lime juices, 1/2 ounce of Giffard Pamplemousse liqueur, 1/4 ounce of simple syrup and 1/4 ounce of the Italian aperitivo liqueur Aperol, which gave the drink a remarkably deep pink hue. This was all topped with Fever-Tree club soda. Despite the surfeit of components, the judges thought the drink balanced, equally tart and sweet.
ingredients: soda water, preferably Fever-Tree, to top
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients, except for the soda water, into a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Pour into a Collins glass over ice.
4. Top with soda water and garnish with a lime wedge and grapefruit slice.

title: Flaming Heart
intro_philosophy: Toby Maloney describes this drink as “one of my favorite The Violet Hour classics, a great call for anyone asking for a spicy Margarita.” Because making a syrup using jalapeños or any dried pepper can yield inconsistent results, Maloney turned instead to green Tabasco. The green pepper notes of the hot sauce draw out similar ones in the tequila, while the vanilla of the Licor 43 bridges the gap between the heat and the sweet pineapple juice, he adds.
ingredients: 9 drops Fee Brothers Old Fashion Aromatic Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add 5 ice cubes and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over fresh ice into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Mystery Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Garret Richard recommends using a stand-up drink mixer, rather than a blender or a cocktail shaker, to make this drink, as it better aerates the honey-butter mixture known asGardenia Mixand effortlessly incorporates it into the rest of the drink, which builds on gin, Cognac andPamplemousse liqueur. In a pinch, you can shake it in a cocktail tin, but “it can be a bit of a chore,” Richard warns.
ingredients: 3/4 ounces  Cognac, preferably Pierre Ferrand 1840 Cognac
instructions: 1. Flash blend all ingredients in a drink mixer with 8 ounces crushed ice.
2. Pour the mixture into a Pearl Diver glass over 4 ounces of crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit slice, a lime twist and an orchid.

title: Salty Duncan
intro_philosophy: For his Salty Duncan, Jim Kearns calls on that all-important combination of sweet, sour and bitter. A mix of two types of citrus, blanc vermouth, cane syrup,Suzeand Luxardo Bitter Bianco, served on the rocks with a salt rim, the cocktail drinks like summer appropriate riff on the Negroni Bianco.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a half salt rim and a lime wedge.

title: Yankee Notions
intro_philosophy: In this aperitif cocktail, Ulysses Vidal relies on the subtlety of rainwater Madeira to bring added complexity and balance to a mixture of bourbon, chamomile cordial and Angostura bitters.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express a lemon peel over the surface of the drink, then discard.

title: Passion & Poise
intro_philosophy: This drink was developed for Jesse Hubbard’s forthcoming book project,Punk Rock & Cocktails II(Biblio Publishing, August 2022). The finished drink should have a consistency “somewhere between a milkshake and a sundae,” he says.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces extra-virgin olive oil–washed gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Muddle strawberries in a cocktail tin. Add gin, lemon juice and ice. Shake well.
2. Scoop ice cream into a coupe glass. Strain the contents of the shaker tin over the ice cream, which should induce the ice cream to start melting into the gin mix.
3. Drizzle fernet syrup over the top.
4. Garnish with star anise, dehydrated lemon wheel, and strawberry slices. Serve with a straw.

title: Legends of the Fall
intro_philosophy: As the name suggests, this autumnal drink captures plenty of nuttiness and spice in the glass. The base spirit is split between a generous pour of applejack and a smaller dose ofrye whiskey.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with orange and lemon peels.

title: Pass the Kvassier
intro_philosophy:
At Portland’s traditional Russian zakuski (Russian small plates) restaurant, Kachka, Israel Morales mixes together brandy and rye kvass (asubtly alcoholic Eastern European beverage), which he calls a “natural marriage.”

For this three-ingredient cocktail, he uses Russian-brewed Ochakovskiy, a commercial kvass that tastes of molasses, and keeps it simple with a orange peel garnish. Think of it as the Russian sophisticate’s brandy and Coke.
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to a rocks glass.
2. Add ice and stir to mix.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: James Bolt’s 50/50 Martini
intro_philosophy: Taking third place in our blind tasting of 50/50 Martinis, James Bolt’s recipe was the only one to split both the gin and vermouth. (Due to a shortage of the Mancino, Dolin was substituted as a standalone vermouth; all the panelists agreed that the split vermouth would’ve only improved the drink.) “You get a progression of flavors,” said Simo, “which is what I want to see in a 50/50 Martini.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Scottish gin, preferably The Botanist
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir for 30 to 45 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express a lemon peel over the surface of the drink and discard.

title: Le Rock’s Stinger
intro_philosophy: Estelle Bossy toyed with the idea of putting an absinthe or crème de menthe frappé on the after-dinner list at French restaurant Le Rock, but ultimately settled on aStinger. Having just developed her menu of freezer Martinis, she decided to try that with a Stinger, serving it over pebble ice for a frappé effect. Notably, she chose to use Armagnac over Cognac, citing the freezer method’s tendency to flatten more “delicate aromatic structures.” Armagnac, Bossy says, “brings an oily, beefy meatiness that flavors cling to.”
ingredients: 3 1/2 ounces Armagnac, preferably Domaine d’Espérance Bas-Armagnac 5 Year
1 1/4 ounces crème de menthe, preferably Tempus Fugit
1/4 ounce vanilla liqueur, preferably Giffard Madagascar Vanilla
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bottle.
2. Store the bottle in the freezer for several hours, ideally overnight.
3. To serve, pour into two juice glasses and top with pebble ice.
4. Garnish with a pineapple frond and serve with a short straw.

title: Maritime Martini
intro_philosophy: This gin-based Martini is a play on the traditional dirty version, substituting the brine from pickled kelp for olive juice. The result is a cocktail that delicately suggests the ocean.
ingredients: 1 ounce wine-pickled stipe brine (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with pickled stipe.

title: French Pearl
intro_philosophy: In 2006, few people in the United States understood the appeal of gin or pastis. Audrey Saunders’ rather counterintuitive solution to this problem was to put both the gin and the pastis in the same shaken drink—along with lime juice, simple syrup and mint leaves. She called it the French Pearl.
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, add the lime juice, simple syrup and mint, then muddle.
2. Add the gin, pastis and ice and shake until chilled.
3. Fine-strain into a coupe.

title: Almazara
intro_philosophy: In dimly litTarde.O, a bar nestled inside a 19th-century palace-turned-hotel, the Almazara cocktail appears in a paper-thin rocks glass over a large ice cube, bright green manzanilla olive perched on top. On the menu, the Madrid bar lists an intriguing ingredient for the drink: limonada de aceituna, or olive lemonade, which transforms the simple cocktail into a briny-tart-sweet mix that’s oddly reminiscent of a pickleback shot, layered with Mediterranean ingredients.
ingredients: Le Tribute Olive Lemonade, to top
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a highball glass.
2. Garnish with a manzanilla olive.

title: USS Bomber
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn’s celebrated absinthe and oyster barMaison Premiere, Maxwell Britten enjoys every occasion to create a fantastical cocktail—especially the 4th of July. This red-white-and-blue layered cocktail is a refreshingly bitter, yet subtly sweet mix of absinthe, gentian-flavored Suze, kitschy-classic blue Curaçao and aromatic Peychaud’s bitters. The addition of house coconut syrup adds a tropical element, much like that of standing on the deck of a United States ship in some exotic harbor. Well-crushed ice is the key to achieving a distinctly layered effect.
instructions: 1. Add absinthe, lemon juice, coconut syrup and Suze to a tall pilsner glass.
2. Fill glass half way with crushed ice and swizzle.
3. Pack glass almost full with crushed ice.
4. Top with blue curaçao.
5. Pack all the way to the top and mound with crushed ice.
6. Dash Peychaud's generously over top.
7. Garnish with a mint bouquet or a three pineapple leaves.

title: Graceful Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: The OF as dessert, this was inspired by Havican’s love of baking, a hobby she acquired from her grandmother, Grace—thus, the drink’s name. The inherent baking spice notes in the Knob Creek®Rye (think cinnamon, clove, nutmeg) combine with the house-made vanilla syrup and tart Burlesque Bitters—which have strong notes of hibiscus and sour berries—to create a cocktail that is straight cherry pie. Still, it is never too sweet or cloying, and is kept in check by the expected Ango.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Strain over a big cube in a double Old-Fashioned glass.

title: Angel’s Tit
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled small cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with cherry.

title: Spritz Tussaud
intro_philosophy: Coming in third place at a recent blind spritz tasting was Chantal Tseng of D.C.’s Petworth Citizen and Reading Room. Her recipe calls for Cappelletti Aperitivo Americano, a popular option with bartenders in place of Campari or Aperol; two ounces of Perrier; and three ounces of rosé Champagne.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except rosé Champagne in a wine glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with rosé Champagne.
4. Garnish with half a blood orange slice.

title: Suit and Tie
intro_philosophy: Lychee Martinis hit peak popularity when Kristina Magro, now chief cocktail evangelist at the craft beer–focused Lone Wolf Tavern in Chicago, worked behind the bar of a big-box steakhouse back in 2010. Once armed with Giffard Lichi-Li, “I was really excited to get another crack at it,” she says. Lychee in its natural form is quite sweet, but Lichi-Li “is really quite delicate,” says Magro. “It’s not cloying or viscous—less syrupy than bright and floral.” A longtime fan of “50-50” Martinis, Magro combines the liqueur with an equal portion of manzanilla sherry, introducing a savory element to one half of the mix. For the opposing half, she goes with Germany’s Monkey 47 gin, whose complex botanical mash, far from “a juniper bomb,” provides an appealing backbone.
instructions: 1. Rinse a chilled martini glass with absinthe and set aside.
2. Combine all remaining ingredients in a mixing glass and add ice.
3. Stir to combine.
4. Strain into Martini glass
5. Garnish with fresh lychee.

title: Piper’s Kilt
intro_philosophy: In Seattle, Abigail Gullo, a New Orleans transplant, offers the Piper’s Kilt at her bar, Ben Paris. Calling on the abundance of berries native to the Pacific Northwest, Gullo pulverizes dehydrated blackberries, marionberries and raspberries and mixes the fruit powder with sugar for the rim, while gin, local honey and raspberry liqueur round it out for a Crusta as true to her adopted city as the original is to NOLA.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce pink peppercorn honey (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a berry sugar-rimmed cocktail glass (see Editor's Note) and garnish with a wide swatch of lemon peel tucked into the rim of the glass.

title: Inverno Luce
intro_philosophy: “Like its name, this drink is a harmonious glint of warm sunshine in the dead of winter,” says Dan Zeiders, whose Inverno Luce translates to “winter light” in Italian. A base of herbaceous Amaro Sibona is married with a malty and smoky 12-year Scotch and finished with the addition of laurel, evergreen and juniper notes from gin resulting in a winter cocktail that’s a perfect balance of sweet and bitter.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce single malt scotch whisky, preferably Glenlivet 12-Year
1/2 ounce gin, preferably St. George Terroir
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: 320 Main’s Planter’s Punch
intro_philosophy: This classic West Indies staple is traditionally made with a dark rum, but Schiffer prefers Wray & Nephew, an overproof white rum from Jamaica, which offers a strong backbone and a heavy dose of funk.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Wray & Nephew white overproof rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with crushed ice.
2. Roll into a Collins glass.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Frangelico Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Ideal to satisfy a thirsty crowd at a holiday gathering, this quick, build-in-the-glass Old-Fashioned tweak substitutes the required sugar forFrangelico. “I try to think of it as a sweetener, more than a spirit,” says Amor y Amargo’sSother Teague. Already cold weather-friendly, the Italian liqueur’s hazelnut flavor goes nicely with the cinnamon and cocoa notes found in Angostura and mole bitters, respectively.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, brandy or aged rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in an Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
2. Gently stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with a dried cranberry and an orange twist

title: Tepache Collins
intro_philosophy: At Qui in Austin, bartender Justin Elliott crafts his owntepache, a traditional Mexican beverage made from fermented pineapple and exotic spices. He combines the semi-bubbly pineapple base with rum—white or golden, your choice—lemon, honey and fresh aromatic Thai basil. Thetepachetakes the place of soda as it would in a regular Collins while the other elements support and highlight its complexity.
instructions: 1. Add rum, lemon juice, honey syrup and Thai basil to a Collins glass.
2. Muddle basil lightly to release oils.
3. Add tepache and top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a straw, mint sprig and Thai basil leaf.

title: June n Juice
intro_philosophy: The June n Juice is bartender Anthony Bates’ ode to Juneteenth. His pear- and gin-laced riff on the Piña Colada is his way of honoring the path—from the Caribbean up through the South—that many African-Americans took when they came to America. The Caribbean influence comes by way of coconut and pineapple, while Bittermens Burlesque bitters add a touch of New Orleans spice to the mix.
ingredients: 1 ounce London dry gin, preferably Oxley
1 ounce pear brandy, preferably Purkhart Pear Williams Brand
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with pebble or crushed ice.
2. Shake until chilled and pour into a Collins glass.
3. Top with more pebble or crushed ice.
4. Garnish with mint.

title: Bar Goto’s Whisky Highball
intro_philosophy: “A highball seems simple, but to make a really good one is calculated,” says Kenta Goto, owner of New York’s Bar Goto and Bar Goto Niban. His preferred recipe for theJapanese classiccalls for a slightly dialed-back amount of whisky, and he specifies that measuring the 4 ounces of soda, rather than eyeballing, is important to pair with a whisky between 40 and 44 percent ABV. “ If a customer requests a highball made with a whisky with higher ABV, we tweak the ratio to 1 ounce to 4 ounces to keep the right balance in the drink,” he says.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces Japanese whisky, preferably Toki, chilled in the freezer
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a highball glass over ice.

title: Midnight, the Stars and You
intro_philosophy: ThoughCureis often considered a whiskey bar, whiskey makes up only about 10 percent of the backbar. Still, it’s put to good use in drinks like Alex Anderson’s Midnight, the Stars and You. ABoulevardiervariation, the drink is named after the closing song fromThe Shiningand features protagonist Jack Torrance’s favorite whiskey: Jack Daniels (albeit a limited release from their Master Distiller series). “I wanted to do a dark, stirred cocktail that could transition either to spring or fall,” explains Anderson, who adds floral complexity with chamomile liqueur, balanced by the bitter notes of Varnelli Sibilla, “a really intense amaro.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably Jack Daniels Master Distiller
1/4 ounce Marolo Milla Grappa and Chamomile Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: North Country
intro_philosophy: Jared Sadoian often turns to “upside-down” drinks—where the base and modifier ratios are flipped—for a way to pair strong flavors in a way that won’t, as he says, “put you under the table.” His Manhattan variation marries fall in New England with the warm spices of the iconic alpine amaro, Braulio. He combines heirloom ice cider from northern Vermont, bonded apple brandy and an aromatic dash of bitters to bring it all together in the glass. “This is a full-flavored drink that remains light on its feet,” says Sadoian. “It’s versatile as an aperitif or a lingering after-dinner sip.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Eden Heirloom Blend Ice Cider
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Nuclear Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Spawned in the late aughts at LAB—London’s influential high-energy, high-volume bar—thisspin on a classic has hada cult followingsince its creation in 2005. More recently, the drink has united online cocktail enthusiasts who are in search of the best substitute for green Chartreuse, the drink’s key ingredient, which has become increasingly scarce.
ingredients: 1 ounce overproof unaged Jamaican rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Nova Scotia
intro_philosophy: In this cocktail, Tom Walker claims “a Scotch Old-Fashioned meets an Alaska.” Building on a base of Highland single malt Scotch whisky, Walker combines yellow Chartreuse with orange bitters for a light flavor profile suitable for summer.
ingredients: 2 ounces Scotch, preferably Highland single malt
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
2. Stir five to six times to integrate.
3. Garnish with a lemon and an orange twist.

title: New Yorker in LA Sour
intro_philosophy: Aaron Polsky, bar manager atHarvard & Stone, uses Lillet Rouge alongside pineapple-based Tepache liqueurin his play on theNew York Sour. Together, the two subtly spiced ingredients stand in for the more traditional addition of red wine to draw out the whiskey’s subtle oak flavors.
ingredients: 2 ounces rye whiskey, preferably Wild Turkey 81
1/3 ounce Tepache pineapple liqueur, preferably Bittermens
instructions: 1. Shake with three freezer tray ice cubes vigorously until the shaking sounds light and airy.
2. Strain over ice in a large rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a clove.

title: Alex Day’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Alex Day’s Daiquiri rounded out the top three vote-getters in our blind tasting of 20 Daiquiri recipes. His formula relied on a combination of Neisson Blanc Rhum Agricole split with Diplomático White Rum, alongside one ounce of lime juice and three-quarters of an ounce of simple syrup (1:1), for a measured Daiquiri that incorporates just enough grassy agricole funk.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces  lightly aged rum, preferably Diplomático
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, add a large cube of ice (preferably 2.5" x 2.5") and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: Tour Le Carbet
intro_philosophy:
The Royal Bermuda Yacht Club cocktail is closely associated with Trader Vic, as it appeared in his 1947 bartender’s guide, but it was actually first published in Crosby Gaige’sCocktail Guide and Ladies’ Companionin 1941. Shannon Mustipher’s Tour Le Carbet is a variation on the drink that swaps out the aged Barbados rum in favor of rhum agricole blanc and ditches the Curaçao for earthy Suze. The result is a bittersweet Daiquiri riff fit for the 21st century.

Photo reprinted fromTiki: Modern Tropical Cocktailsby Shannon Mustipher, published by Rizzoli New York.
ingredients: 2 ounces rhum agricole blanc, such as Neisson or Père Labat 59
3/4 ounce falernum, such as John D. Taylor
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice.
2. Shake and double-strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Bruxa Irmã Seis Batida
intro_philosophy: “Strega is a diplomatic Italian liqueur,” explains Seattle’s Andrew Bohrer. “It just whispers herbal notes rather than proclaiming them.” Bohrer’s Bruxa Irmã Seis Batida combines Strega with cachaça, oloroso sherry and coconut milk for a herbaceous twist on typical tiki flavors.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin.
2. Shake and strain over crushed ice into a Collins glass.
3. Garnish with nutmeg.

title: Apple Martini
intro_philosophy: “I’m taking you back to the 1990s,” saysRamsey Muskof his Apple Martini. But unlike the cloying construction prevalent in the drink’s heyday, this version calls on a clarified Granny Smith cordial, paired with pear eau de vie and a split base of vodka and gin. “It’s crystal-clear,” says Musk, “but it tastes like you’re biting into a fresh Granny Smith.”
ingredients: 1 ounce clarified sour apple cordial (see Editor’s Note)
1 teaspoon pear eau de vie, preferably Clear Creek or St. George pear brandy
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to one half of a two-piece cocktail shaker containing ice.
2. Throw the mixture by pouring it from the tin with ice into the second tin to aerate the drink.
3. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
4. Garnish with a cherry directly in the glass.

title: Poppa’s Pride
intro_philosophy: This ginger-laced bourbon smash was a signature at Ba’sik, the now-closed Brooklyn bar with a beloved following. Instead of muddling the lemon wedges and mint leaves, Jay Zimmerman shakes the hell out of them, along with a mix of bourbon and ginger juice, and tops the drink with soda and Angostura bitters. If you don’t have access to fresh ginger juice, you can muddle several pieces of ginger with simple syrup to achieve a spicy bite. Just adjust the ginger ratio to taste.
ingredients: 1 ounce ginger juice, sweetened (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add bourbon, ginger juice, lemon wedges and mint to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a highball or Collins glass over fresh ice.
4. Top with soda water and Angostura bitters.
5. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Baransu
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the prime winter scenario of “cuddling near a fire,” Carlie Steiner of D.C.’s Himitsu stirs Dewar’s with heavily-peated Scotch, oloroso sherry and a few dashes of bitters. It’s an ideal after-hours cocktail: “This drink is meant to help you wind down,” she says.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Canelli Spritz
intro_philosophy: This “kitchen sink” spritz from Natasha David is an adult version of the only soda her mother allowed her to drink growing up, a DIY concoction made with berry concentrate from the health food store mixed with sparkling water. “The spritz should be an easy, effortless cocktail, something you throw together from what you have so that you can entertain your friends,” says David, noting that fresh raspberries can stand in for the liqueur, and another amaro can be substituted for Ramazzotti. “The whole idea behind the spritz, even before the ingredients, is the culture. Engaging with friends and having a lively conversation… to me that’s the most important ingredient of a spritz.”
instructions: 1. Add 3 hand-cracked ice cubes to a large white wine glass then fill the glass with regular ice cubes.
2. Combine all ingredients, except the prosecco, in a white wine glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Top with sparkling wine.
4. Garnish with grapefruit crescent.

title: Gage & Tollner’s Dirty Vodka Martini
intro_philosophy: At Gage & Tollner, a house brine gives the bar’s dirty Martinis their olive-like tang. The dirty Martini can be made with gin or vodka; this variation uses Tito’s vodka.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces vodka, such as Tito’s vodka
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an olive.

title: Microdose
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the concept of “salty watermelon on the patio,” this low-alcohol drink from Brian Catapang ofMagnus on Wateris made with local sea salt and dulse, a seaweed with a purple-red hue, which he forages from a nearby beach.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces fino sherry, preferably Tio Pepe Fino Sherry
1/2 ounce moscatel pisco, preferably Capurro Moscatel Pisco
3/4 ounce sea salt syrup (see Editor’s Note)
12 drops habanero and dulse seaweed tincture (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a deep coupe glass (about 7 ounces) or small Pearl Diver glass.

title: Jalapeño Diablo
intro_philosophy: At New York’s Porchlight, the Jalapeño Diablo is “hands down” the top-selling cocktail, according to beverage director Nicholas Bennett. A straightforward, effervescent mix of chile pepper-infused tequila, lime juice, soda water and crème de cassis, the riff on the classic Diablo also includes three-quarters of an ounce of housemade ginger syrup, a variation on a version first created by Sasha Petraske.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce crème de cassis, preferably Lejay Lagoute
instructions: 1. Combine first three ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into an ice filled Collins glass.
3. Top with soda water and crème de cassis.
4. Garnish with candied ginger.

title: Queen Charlotte Punch
intro_philosophy: Thad Vogler of Bar Agricole leans on a base of red wine to maintain low ABV in this seasonal punch, to which he adds a double dose of citrus, housemade raspberry syrup and sparkling water.
ingredients: 5 ounces raspberry gomme syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add red wine to a punch bowl over ice.
2. Separately, shake orange juice, lemon juice and raspberry gomme syrup and pour into the punch bowl.
3. Top with soda water and stir.

title: Brandied Cherries
intro_philosophy: Leo Robitschek, vice president of food and beverage for Sydell Group (the parent company of NoMad and Eleven Madison Park), started brandying cherries during his time at EMP. It was one of many collaborations between the bar and the kitchen that would come to set the restaurant’s bar apart. Pitted cherries are bathed in a sugar syrup flavored with vanilla, orange peel and spices, then preserved in Germain-Robin brandy, for a garnish well worth fishing out of a Manhattan variation.
ingredients: Peel of 2 navel oranges, excess pith removed
900 g (about 2 pounds) Bing cherries, washed and pitted
instructions: 1. Combine the sugar, water, orange peel, lemon juice, cinnamon, star anise and vanilla beans in a large saucepan. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to a simmer. Add the cherries and simmer until heated through.

2. Remove the saucepan from the heat and stir in the brandy. Store the cherries and the liquid in an airtight container in the fridge for at least 4 to 5 days before using; the cherries will continue to macerate and are optimal after around 2 weeks. They will keep for 6 months.

title: La Chancleta
intro_philosophy: Created bymambises(guerrilla fighters) during the Cuban Wars of Independence as a morning toddy, the Canchánchara combinesaguardiente de caña, honey, lime juice and water. It originated in the main sugar cane-growing region outside the colonial city of Trinidad, and became a popular restorative for enslaved people working the plantations. The modern iteration is served on the rocks, in a traditional clay cup called ajícara. Julio Cabrera’s riff, from the Spanish word for “flip-flops,” uses Yaguara Cachaça Ouro for its similarity to Cuban aguardiente in addition to a ginger-infused honey syrup and Persian lime, which is less acidic than Key lime. Curiously, many American versions of the Canchánchara use añejo, rather than plata rum, but skip it, says Cabrera. “If you’re using añejo, then it isn’t a true Canchánchara.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce cachaça, preferably Yaguara Cachaça Ouro (alternatively, Cabrera suggests Clément Premiére Canne Rhum Blanc Agricole)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass (or a clay cup) over ice.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Long Island Iced Tea
intro_philosophy:
“The original Long Island Iced Tea, from my memory, was this very homogeneous thing that tasted of ethyl alcohol and bad decisions,” recalls bartender Paul Taylor, who recently set about rescuing the oft-maligned gut-punch of a cocktail for his current menu at Washington D.C.’sColumbia Room.

His refined version calls on a house-made cola alongside house-made sour mix, pepper-infused rum, California gin,sherry-based vermouthand amaro.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Fresh Sour Mix (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce Vermouth La Copa González Byass
1/2 ounce Green Pepper Rum (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except soda water, in a Reidel Coca Cola Glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Top with soda water.
3. Stir to incorporate.
4. Garnish with a comically large lemon wedge.

title: Twentieth Century
intro_philosophy: At a time when rail travel was still the preferred and most decent mode of transportation, the Twentieth Century Limited enjoyed a 65-year run between Chicago and New York. During its track tenure, which began in 1902, the rail line provided passengers with a library, a barbershop, in-house maids and private sleeping berths. Ticket holders would tread across a crimson carpet to board the train, introducing the phrase “red carpet treatment” to the American lexicon. The line was such an institution that a Brit, not an American, dreamed up a cocktail to honor its name. It first appeared in theCafé Royal Cocktail Bookin 1937 and is similar to aCorpse Reviver #2, with crème de cacao subbing in for orange liqueur.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Dove Dispatch
intro_philosophy: In the Dove Dispatch, Meaghan Dorman mixes Campari, tequila and a splash of grapefruit juice, plus bell pepper simple syrup for earthiness, then tops it all with housemade chile salt for a touch of heat. “Green, vegetal flavors combined with a hint of spice accomplishes this well,” she says, referring to the “savory and strong” call. “[These drinks] should still be bright and enjoyable, but with that extra subtle layer.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce red bell pepper simple syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the soda water in a shaking tin.
2. Shake and strain over ice into a Collins glass rimmed with chile salt.
3. Top with soda water.

title: Cloister
intro_philosophy: Though it has the air of a pre-Prohibition cocktail, the Cloister actually originates with thePlayboy Bartender’s Guide, published in 1971. A gin sour that relies on two types of citrus, its monastic name is a nod to its inclusion of yellow Chartreuse, the complex herbal liqueur produced by the Carthusian monks of southeastern France. For New Orleans bartender Christina Rando, It’s the ideal “gateway” drink capable of converting skeptics into avowed Chartreuse fans. She prefers this variation fromJim Meehan’s 2011PDT Cocktail Book, which introduces a touch of simple syrup to counterbalance the fresh grapefruit and lemon.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

title: Fireside Cheer
intro_philosophy: Mole bitters “are just so versatile,” says Sean Umstead, co-owner of Kingfisher in Durham, North Carolina. While typically seen alongside agave spirits, here, the bitters accent the caramel notes of Scotch and rich crème de cacao in a celebratory, sparkling wine–topped drink.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce blended Scotch, preferably Famous Grouse
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir very lightly to chill.
2. Strain into a flute, then top with sparkling wine.

title: Margarita Soda
intro_philosophy: The key to the Margarita Soda is simplicity. The ingenious highball mashup from Ridgewood’s Hellbender starts with a base of aTommy’s Margarita, topped with club soda, which opens up the earthy tequila notes and the sharp lime, offering balanced, layered complexity.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces tequila, preferably Pueblo Viejo Blanco
instructions: 1. Rim a Collins glass with sea salt.
2. Add the first three ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Pour into the prepared Collins glass, top with club soda and stir.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Revolver
intro_philosophy: Many bartenders were excited by the arrival of Bulleit Bourbon on the market, Jon Santer included. He created this simplespin on a Manhattanin 2004 when working at Bruno’s in San Francisco, and later took the drink to Bourbon & Branch. There, the theatrics of the flamed orange twist caused customers to order it again and again, making the drink famous in quick order.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a flamed orange twist.

title: Tarocco Spritz
intro_philosophy:
