Inspired by a cocktail from New York City bartender Natasha David, the crimson-colored Tarocco Spritz is a variation on the Sicilian Tarocco Orange, often referred to as the “half-blood orange.” A mixed-heritage cocktail, this drink has a bumped-up base of gin to match the vibrant bitter aperitivo liqueur Cappelletti. The drink’s acidity comes courtesy of blood orange, lemon juice, and prosecco, bound together by the unlikely addition of vanilla, which complements Cappelletti’s notes of spice and oxidation.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail,with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Add the gin, Cappelletti, orange juice, lemon juice, and vanilla syrup to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over fresh ice, top with the prosecco, and add the garnish.

title: Gin and Grapefruit Radler
intro_philosophy: Typically, a radler (the German word for “cyclist”) is known for being light in alcohol, but the addition of a shot of juniper-driven German gin ups the gear ratio. The Radler’s Haus Helles, made by Flesk Brewing, is available exclusively at the restaurant, so unless you have the hookup, Stiegl Pilsner will do nicely in its place.
ingredients: 8 ounces Radler Haus Helles,  or substitute Stiegl Pilsner
instructions: 1. Add the ingredients to a chilled pint glass, starting with the beer.
2. Briefly stir to combine, and garnish with a slice of grapefruit.

title: The Last Petal
intro_philosophy: “The Last Petal speaks to my love of low-ABV cocktails,” says Mony Bunni, who was inspired to make the drink when she first tasted Imbue Petal and Thorn vermouth, which she describes as being the color of rosé, with “notes of chamomile, cinnamon, roses and orange peel.” Here, she combines it with fino sherry, rhum agricole and cava for a drink that’s at once briny, floral and refreshing.
ingredients: 1 ounce Imbue Petal and Thorn vermouth
1/2 ounce fino sherry, preferably Lustau de Jarana
1/2 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Clement Canne Bleue Rhum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the cava, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Top with cava and garnish with a pinch of crushed, dried rose buds.

title: Matt Lee’s Five O’Clock Pick-Me-Up
intro_philosophy: If you’re comfortable classifying wine as fruit syrup, this drink qualifies as a shrub, since it comprises grapes, sugar and vinegar. But it’s closer in spirit to a cocktail, because it’s designed for quick mixing and immediate drinking. Matt Lee warns against overthinking it: The only goal here is to salvage wine that isn’t quite up to your standards.
ingredients: 1/2 cup boring white or rosé wine
1/4 teaspoon spicy pickle brine, plus more to taste
instructions: 1. Pour wine into a wine glass.
2. Add the brine.
3. Garnish with a pepper slice.

title: The Rorschach Test
intro_philosophy: This cocktail balances savory aquavit with sweet-tart fruit elements—Amer Picon, lemon and The Violet Hour’s house grenadine—all made effervescent by a healthy measure of pale ale.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce housemade grenadine (see recipe for The Violet Hour's grenadine )
2-3 ounces light pale ale, preferably Brooklyn Summer Ale
instructions: 1. Fill a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Add all ingredients, except beer.
3. Shake lightly and pour, ice included, into a hurricane glass.
4. Top with beer.
5. Garnish with rolled up, skewered orange peel.

title: Coltivare Julep
intro_philosophy: Morgan Weber’s modern interpretation of the classic Mint Julep gets a tangy sweetness in the form of sorghum vinegar. To allow the drink to evolve in the glass, Weber suggests not stirring the Julep; instead, let the ice melt, and sip accordingly.
instructions: 1. In a Julep cup, add all leaves and half of the sorghum vinegar.
2. With a muddler, lightly express leaves around the entire interior of cup.
3. Pack to the brim with crushed ice then add 2 ounces of bourbon.
4. Add more ice, snow cone-style, on top of cup.
5. Disperse remaining vinegar evenly over the top then add remaining bourbon.
6. Garnish with a straw, two bunches of mint tops and a dusting of powdered sugar.

title: Puritan
intro_philosophy: The Puritan emerged at the turn of the 20th century as a mixture of gin, French vermouth, yellow Chartreuse and orange bitters. Will Thompson first encountered it when he was working at Drink in Boston and has brought it all the way to his Miami bar, Sunny’s, where it’s featured on a menu of Martini variations. The understated counterpart to its sibling, the Alaska, the Puritan gets herbal, honeyed complexity from the yellow Chartreuse while still remaining firmly in Martini territory.
ingredients: 2 ounces London dry gin, such as Hayman’s
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, such as Dolin
2 dashes orange bitters, such as Angostura
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a Martini glass and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Bebbo
intro_philosophy: The Bebbois a lesser-known cousin of the Bee’s Knees that adds a touch of orange juice to the Prohibition-era sour. For Michael Madrusan, of Melbourne, Australia’s craft cocktail institution The Everleigh, it’s been a favorite since he discovered it among the thousands of recipes inJones’ Complete Barguideyears ago. Madrusan’s version uses Australian gin and honey, plus the addition of an Angostura bitters garnish, which come together to create a spiced, big-citrus version of the Bebbo that’s a real crowd-pleaser at the bar.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, such as Four Pillars Rare Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe and garnish with a stripe of Angostura bitters.

title: Rabo de Galo
intro_philosophy: Rabo de Galofirst became popular in the mid-1950s when the Italian vermouth producer Cinzano opened a factory in bustling São Paulo. To compete with the ubiquitous consumption of cachaça, the native spirit, in local bars, the company introduced a foreign concept to Brazil: mixing two alcoholic bases in the same glass and calling it a “cocktail.” However, the practice took off only after they decided to translate the word. In Portuguese,galomeans “rooster” (or “cock”), andrabomeans “tail.”
ingredients: Scant 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Vermouth Carpano Classico
instructions: 1. Pour the cachaça, vermouth and Cynar into a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass with ice.
3. Garnish with a lime twist.

title: John deBary’s Amaretto Sour
intro_philosophy: “The Amaretto Sour is quite possiblythearchetypal bad drink,” says John deBary. For his personal update, deBary pares the recipe down to its essentials, offering a low-proof version built on Luxardo’s bitter and pungent Amaretto di Saschira.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, or a rocks glass over ice.

title: The Inward Turn
intro_philosophy: Inspired by bartender Marta Ess’ passion for dance, this drink “is about reminding yourself to take time for self-reflection and self-care,” she says. A variation on the classic gin Martini, it’s meant to be sipped slowly and conscientiously. Tomato water, reflecting the need for nourishment, adds vegetal complexity; fortified wines lend a silky texture, while a touch of saline solution recalls the healing properties of saltwater. The garnish is meant to evoke the leg of a dancer standingen pointe.
ingredients: 1/2 parts  juniper- and basil-infused bianco vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until very well-chilled (about 40 turns).
3. Fine-strain into chilled Nick & Nora glass.
4. Express and discard lemon peel.
5. Garnish with lemon thyme sprig inserted into cherry tomato, wrapped in lace of dehydrated lemon.

title: Daiquiri Menta
intro_philosophy: With a roster of drinks inspired by personal experiences at Havana’s Floridita, Manolito pays homage to Cuba’s rich cocktail history as interpreted by two of the New Orleans’ most prominent bar figures,Chris Hannahand Nick Detrich. Their blended mint Daiquiri, a straightforward mixture of rum, lime, sugar and mint, is equally at home in New Orleans as it is in Havana where Detrich first served it.
ingredients: 2 ounces  white rum, preferably Bacardi Superior
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the rum, in a blender.
2. Blend on a low setting until the contents begin to circulate.
3. Add the rum and blend until the contents move in a smooth and uniform fashion.
4. Pour into a large Martini glass, or go-cup.

title: Betty Carter
intro_philosophy: Just across from theBrooklyn Academy of Musicis a sweet little space calledBerlyn, the apt home of this mellow whiskey drink. New York bartender Jeremy Oertel began with the idea of Betty Carter, legendary jazz singer who once lived in Berlyn’s neighborhood, Fort Greene. “I wanted ingredients that were rich and soulful, like port or sherry,” says Oertel. Eventually he came up with a sherry-infused whiskey sour of sorts whose “flavors made me think of Carter’s kind of music,” with bourbon, Amaro Nonino and rich PX sherry.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce PX sherry (preferably Hidalgo-La Gitana Triana)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Don’s Mix
intro_philosophy: A classic tiki ingredient,key to drinks including the Zombie and Donga Punch. Jeff “Beachbum” Berry, who decoded the recipe from Don the Beachcomber’s original, notes that white grapefruit juice is essential for its bitterness and acidity.
instructions: 1. Crush the cinnamon sticks and place them in a saucepan with sugar and one cup water.
2. Bring to a boil, stirring until the sugar is dissolved.
3. Lower the heat and cover cover the saucepan. Simmer for two minutes.
4. Remove the saucepan from heat and, keeping it covered, let sit at least two hours.
5. Strain. Cinnamon syrup will keep up to one month refrigerated.
6. To make Don’s Mix, combine two parts white grapefruit juice with one part cinnamon syrup.

title: Chocolate Martini
intro_philosophy: At some cocktail bars, a request for this kitschy dessert cocktail might raise an eyebrow, but with the return of decent crème de cacao to the market, the right bartender knows a chocolate Martini can be pure digestif manna. In New York City, Eamon Rockey mixescrème de cacaowith vodka and nutty amontillado sherry. The unorthodox addition of the dry Spanish wine to a base of vodka balances the crème de cacao’s bittersweet flavor profile and velvety texture.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: N/A Spaghett
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the Spaghett and the Camparty, this take on the beer spritz combines the bitter Italian soda Stappi with a nonalcoholic light lager. This is a drink that is less a recipe and more an idea that can be adjusted to your preferences. Add citrus if you like (grapefruit and it’s a bitter shandy, lemon and you stay within the bounds of the original), or leave it out and adjust the ratio of Stappi to pilsner, and go forth with confidence.
ingredients: 1 can nonalcoholic lager, preferably Untitled Art Italian Pilsner or Athletic Lite
instructions: 1. Combine the Stappi and lager in your desired ratio, either directly in the can or over ice.
2. Finish with a squeeze of lemon or grapefruit, if desired.
3. Garnish with a lemon or grapefruit half-wheel, if you’re feeling fancy.

title: Hey High Hello
intro_philosophy: In this Collins-style cocktail, Julia McKinley builds on a base ofPineau des Charentesand fino sherry, supplemented by a small measure ofJapanese gin, all topped with lemon tonic. Like Madeira, Pineau des Charentes offers both sweetness and an inherent drying effect, while the gin, Nikka Coffey gin, adds a brightening effect. “You can use a very small amount of it and it adds really beautiful lift,” says McKinley of the Japanese gin, “and then if you pair it with any kind of citrus it just explodes.” The end result is, in McKinley’s words, “super crushable, but it has enough complexity to make it something interesting.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Japanese gin, preferably Nikka Coffey
1 barspoon Petite Canne Sugar Cane Syrup
Fever Tree Sicilian Lemon Tonic, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the lime coin, in a Collins glass.
2. Squeeze the lime coin into the drink to express the oils and drop it into the glass.
3. Add ice and stir.
4. Top with the tonic water.

title: Averna Smash
intro_philosophy: Nestled in the tiny space next to Seattle chef Jason Stratton’s acclaimed Spinasse, Artusi has become a hub for the city’s expanding love affair with amaro. This bittersweet concoction of Knob Creek bourbon, Amaro Averna, walnut oil, a muddled Amarena cherry and orange wheel and Fever-Tree Bitter Lemon soda is one of the aperitivi bar’s most popular drinks.
ingredients: 2 ounces bourbon, such as Knob Creek
Fever-Tree Bitter Lemon soda, to top
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle together the orange wheel, brandied cherry and walnut oil.
2. Add bourbon, Averna and ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a Collins glass over ice and top with lemon soda.

title: A Stone’s Throw
intro_philosophy: In A Stone’s Throw, whatBritt Foxdescribes as “fiddly” amounts of Bénédictine, dry Curaçao and stone fruit–infused Lillet Blanc work in tandem to bolster the spirituous backbone of the drink: VSOP Cognac. “I care the most about spirits,” explains Fox. “It’s always where my passion has been, and so, if I’m being honest, it all still starts with a spirit that I’m super excited about.”
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces VSOP Cognac, preferably H by Hine
3/4 ounce cherry- and plum-infused Lillet Blanc (see Editor’s Note)
2 dashes aromatic bitters, preferably Jack Rudy
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a tin or mixing pitcher. Add ample ice and stir until cold.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass and garnish with a halved fig.

title: Cornucopia Punch
intro_philosophy: “If you’re expecting a crowd for the holidays, larger format is the way to go,” advises Eben Freeman. Here, he mixes together citrus juices, tea, Applejack and sparkling cider to feed the thirsty hordes before dinner.
ingredients: 8 ounces citrus juice, combined from 1 orange, 1 lemon and 1 lime
24 ounces black tea, brewed and still hot
instructions: 1. Add sugar and citrus peels to large punch bowl and muddle, then let sit for 30 minutes to one hour.
2. Add hot tea and stir to dissolve sugar.
3. Strain out citrus peels and add liquid back to bowl. Add citrus juice, rum and Applejack.
4. Add ice cubes; two-iinch cubes are preferred so it doesn't melt as fast, but whatever you have will work.
5. When ready to serve, top with cider, grated cinnamon, grated nutmeg and garnish with citrus slices and pomegranate seeds sprinkled throughout.

title: For Rex
intro_philosophy: Neal Bodenheimer’s For Rex pays tribute to his home city of New Orleans and its particular affinity for anise-flavored spirits. Dedicated to the carnival krewe of the same name, For Rex riffs on the classic Ojen cocktail, a Mardi Gras favorite comprising Ojen, bitters, sugar, and water, with an added level of complexity by way of St-Germain. The combination of elderflower and anise-based Ojen recalls the original recipe for another anise-flavored liqueur, Sambuca, which incorporated elderflower as a major component.
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a rocks glass over crushed ice.
2. Swizzle to combine then garnish with a dash of Peychaud’s.

title: Golden Phone
intro_philosophy: A stirred riff on the 21st Century (Jim Meehan’s tequila-based update of the classic 20th Century), the Golden Phone calls for half an ounce of yellow Chartreuse as an herbal bridge between tequila, Lillet and crème de cacao.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist and two Luxardo cherries.

title: The Night Shining
intro_philosophy:
Though the kümmel-spiked Silver Bullet (gin, kümmel, lemon juice) is alleged to be Prince Philip’s favorite cocktail, bartender Ali Reynolds likes to use the savory spirit—whose taste he describes as ranging from white chocolate to pink peppercorn to olive tapenade to walnut—in his The Night Shining.

“I wanted to create a more robust, stirred, down drink,” he explains, in contrast to kümmel’s usual appearance in shaken, citrusy drinks. Here, he –where “the olive flavors I pick up from Ron Zacapa 23 work well with the caraway and chocolate notes.”
ingredients: 2 dashes bitters, preferably Adam Elmegirab's Boker's Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients with ice in a mixing glass and stir.
2. Strain into rocks glass with one rock and garnish with lemon twist.

title: Whiskey Sour
intro_philosophy: This iconic sour—whiskey, lemon juice and sugar, shaken over ice—forms the building block for many cocktails due to its structural simplicity prime for riffing. Add an egg white and it becomes the “Boston Sour” (PUNCH’s preferred whiskey sour recipe). Add a red wine float and it becomes theNew York Souror Continental Sour, a variation that popped up in the late 1800s.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker, and dry shake.
2. Add ice to the shaker and shake well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass or over ice into a rocks glass.

title: Jon Mullen’s Aperol Spritz
intro_philosophy: Jon Mullen of Bar Pisellino won second place at a recent blind spritz tasting. Subtle upgrades to the expected formula—by way of citric acid solution, saline solution and quality prosecco—make for a standout rendition.
ingredients: 1 dash citric acid solution (1:10 citric acid powder:water, by weight)
1 ounce chilled soda water, preferably Boylan's or Fever-Tree
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except soda water and prosecco in a wine glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Add soda water, nearly fill the glass with hand cracked ice cubes, then gently top with prosecco.
4. Stir to integrate.
5. Serve with a plate of orange wedges and Castelvetrano olives.

title: Noche Triste
intro_philosophy: Inspired by theRemember the Maine, a drink whose various elements tell the story of the USS Maine, which sunk off the coast of Havana in 1898, Orestes Cruz set out to create a similarly narrative cocktail. In his Noche Triste, he creates an abstract interpretation of the Mexican War of Independence, in which sherry represents Spain, Tequila stands in for Mexico, and the Gran Classic represents “the bitterness of the battle,” explains Cruz. Finished with a dash of chocolate bitters, the spiced nuttiness of the drink calls to mind Mexican hot chocolate.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces Ceylon black tea-infused tequila reposado (see Editor’s Note)
1 dash chocolate bitters, preferably Fee Brothers Aztec Chocolate Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express the orange peel and use as garnish.

title: Sunset Spritz
intro_philosophy: “I love vinegar-based shrubs in spritzes,” bar director Stacey Swenson explains. “It lightens and brightens them up, brings the flavors forward. I’m a big fan of both shrubs and watermelon.” This variation, brightened with watermelon shrub and a spicy tincture based on Italy’s Calabrian peppers, Swenson describes as a “hyperseasonal summer drink.” She adds that the “bold but not overwhelming” flavors allow Italicus’ nuanced citrus notes to shine through.
ingredients: 5 drops  Calabrian chile tincture (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce  salted watermelon shrub (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. In a large wine glass, combine all ingredients over ice.
2. Garnish with watermelon slice placed inside glass.

title: Almost Forgotten
intro_philosophy: Since leaving Baltimore, where she worked at The Bluebird and NiHao, to join Happy Accidents in Albuquerque, New Mexico,Tammy Boumahas been putting her penchant for tinkering to good use, expanding the bar’s menu with playful cocktails built around a roster of ingredients unique to the Southwest. In this flip,champurrado—a hot Mexican chocolate drink—nods to time-honored regional flavors and is paired with rum distilled in-house and a porter reduction, plus passion fruit liqueur and a whole egg.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce passion fruit liqueur, preferably Chinola
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and dry-shake (without ice).
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Double-strain into a brandy snifter or a flip glass.
4. Garnish with freshly grated cinnamon.

title: Rob Roy
intro_philosophy: The first-known mentions of the Rob Roy credit New York’s Waldorf Astoria Hotel for the 1897 recipe, which is essentially aManhattanmade with Scotch whisky. Cocktail historians figure the name was a nod to a play about the great Scotsman, which premiered three years earlier in Manhattan (hence the Scotch whisky). The drink skews a touch leaner than its bourbon and rye counterparts, and since the Scotch gets doctored up with sweet vermouth and bitters, a blended whisky will more than suffice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry or a lemon twist.

title: The Greenpoint
intro_philosophy: This Chartreuse-infused drink, named for Brooklyn’s Greenpoint neighborhood, is a relative of the 1909 classic, the Brooklyn. It may indeed have a slightly greenish tint in the glass. But to be clear, it’s made with yellow Chartreuse, not the more anise-forward green Chartreuse.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: BBT
intro_philosophy: The BBT (bourbon, bitters and tonic) is essentially an Old-Fashioned lengthened and lifted thanks to a topper of tonic water. Think of it as the Old-Fashioned of summer.
instructions: 1. Add bourbon and tonic to a rocks glass over a large rock of ice.
2. Top with aromatic bitters and garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Bitter Almond Negroni
intro_philosophy: On paper, the three building blocks of a classic Negroni—gin, sweet vermouth, Campari—are nowhere to be found, but in their place a myriad of flavors combine for a winterized rendition of the bitter original. Here, a stirred mix of grappa and bitter Cocchi Rosa is bolstered by spicyBecherovka, citrusy China-China and a small measure of Suze.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces grappa, preferably Nardini Grappa alla Mandorla
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Walnut Orgeat
intro_philosophy: This alt-orgeat was created for The Eddy, now closed, where it filled out a tiki-style drink made with a split base of Cachaça and aged rum, plus a dose of cold brew coffee. Those are some pretty robust flavors, and needed an equally assertive sweetener. Roasting the walnuts created a bolder, darker profile that fit the bill.
instructions: 1. Preheat oven to 425°. Spread walnuts on a baking sheet and roast for about 15 to 20 minutes. Remove from oven and allow to cool.
2. Toast spices in a heavy-bottomed pan over low heat, until lightly smoky.
3. Add water and sugar and stir to dissolve. Remove from heat.
4. While still hot, add orange zest and cane syrup.
5. When cool, strain mixture into blender. Add walnuts and blend on high. Strain into a bottle and cover. Store in refrigerator; keeps for about two weeks.

title: Reverse Manhattan
intro_philosophy: An “upside-down” version of the classic, utilizing Miró Rojo, a very dry, Italian-style vermouth, with Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel Rye, to provide extra backbone. Both Angostura and Bogart’s bitters are used, in an effort to recreate the original Boker’s Bitters, called for in the earliest recipes, says Jim Kearns.
ingredients: 1 ounce rye whiskey, preferably Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel Rye
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with orange twist and brandied cherries.

title: Jalisco Hot Chocolate
intro_philosophy:
A match ordained by the gods, this Mexican hot chocolate (your standard-issue hot chocolate upgraded with cinnamon and chile pepper) spiked with tequila is the very definition of a winter cocktail: transporting, fortifying, and still gluggable.

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine the milk, chocolate chips, brown sugar, cayenne, chile powder, cinnamon, and vanilla in a saucepan over medium heat, whisking continually until the chocolate is dissolved, about 7 minutes.
2. Divide the tequila among four mugs (2 ounces in each) and pour the hot chocolate mix into each.
3. Garnish each mug with a cinnamon stick or whole dried ancho chile.

title: Pomegranate Shrub
intro_philosophy: I first had pomegranate in a Greek mythology course in college. We were reading the story of Persephone, daughter of Zeus and queen of the underworld, who is often depicted in Greek art holding a pomegranate. I was a Midwestern boy, and this was the 1980s, and so pomegranate was exotic and mystifying. I was immediately hooked. Fresh pomegranate juice is best in this drink, but honestly, juicing pomegranate is tedious and messy work. No one will judge you for using a commercial juice—just make sure it’s 100-percent pomegranate.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a large bottle, and shake to combine.

title: Rivington Punch
intro_philosophy: The Rivington Punch marries two of the most classic spritzers—the wine spritzer and theAperol Spritz—and dresses is it up in bright pink. A base of rosé wine combines with lightly bitter Aperol and the sweet fruit companions of elderflower and raspberry liqueurs to create this fuchsia summer bubbler. No punch or spritz would be complete without a fistful of fruit; in this case, it’s grapefruit to compliment the Aperol and strawberries for the liqueurs.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a wine glass.
2. Add ice and garnish with a grapefruit slice and strawberry slices.

title: Chesapeake Junction
intro_philosophy: Shae Minnillo describes his Chesapeake Junction as a”grapefruit bomb.” Featuring the bitter citrus three ways, this beefed-up sour, built on absinthe and brandy, highlights the ability of Pamplemousse to enhance similar flavors.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients until chilled then strain into a cocktail glass.

title: Vintage Coco
intro_philosophy: Lynnette Marrero, co-founder of Speed Rack and the bar director for New York’s Llama Inn and Llama San, created her own spin on the classic Caribbean combination of Scotch and coconut water for women’s history month.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Scotch, preferably Johnnie Walker Black or Jane Walker
instructions: 1. Add the coconut water, pineapple juice and Scotch to a highball glass.
2. Fill glass with ice cubes or a Collins spear.
3. Add Fever-Tree, and gently stir to mix.
4. Garnish with a shiso leaf or mint sprigs.

title: Cola Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: AtLucky Charlie, the late-night coal-oven pizzeria in Bushwick, Brooklyn, beverage director Rob Hoffman makes use of the bar’s robust amari collection in a lineup of creative cocktails. In a city that’s crowded with countless Espresso Martini variations, Hoffman’s Coca-Cola Espresso Martini was a breakout hit as soon as it made its debut on the menu. Beyond the drink’s namesake not-so-secret ingredient, Hoffman’s use of Santa Maria Al Monte Caffè Ligure, a Calabrian coffee liqueur, is a key component. This easy-to-batch blend can also be adjusted by swapping out the vodka for an aged rum.
ingredients: 2 ounces vodka, preferably Fort Hamilton Fortress Vodka
3/4 ounce Santa Maria al Monte Caffè Ligure
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake hard until well-chilled to ensure a proper frothy head.
2. Double-strain into a coupe glass and sprinkle ground espresso beans over the surface of the drink.

title: French Connection
intro_philosophy: As something of an entry level gentian liqueur, less bitter than its cousins, Salers and Suze, Avèze is easy to swap in and out of classic cocktail templates in place of other, bitter ingredients. In this riff on theBoulevardier, bartender Tommy Klus calls on the liqueur in place of Campari, and uses lightly peated, single malt Scotch in place of American whiskey.
ingredients: 1 ounce peated Scotch, preferably Highland Park 12 Year Old
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica or Cocchi Vermouth Di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an expressed orange peel.

title: Hundo Pea
intro_philosophy: At Cuties in Portland, Maine, this is “the surprising sleeper hit” of the menu. “To us, it reads as more of an oddball or adventurous cocktail but has been consistently embraced, enjoyed and reordered by folks who appreciate how bright and vegetal it is,” says bartender Bryce Summers. “It nicely checks the boxes of being refreshing and sessionable, acting as a bridge between our wine and cocktail lists.” The snap pea syrup in the drink is also used in an N/A cocktail, thePea & T.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces dry riesling, such as Günther Steinmetz
1/2 ounce snap pea syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/8 ounce pear eau de vie, such as Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a wide (13-ounce) Collins glass.
3. Add crushed ice until heaping, and garnish generously with mint and a snap pea.

title: 4 Day Weekend
intro_philosophy: Stephanie Andrews’ Old-Fashioned riff is inspired by her father. “My mom would bring home peaches from the market, nice and ripe,” Andrews recalls. “He’d slice them up and start muddling them into whiskey, and we’d sit out on the front porch with a glass half-full of bourbon, peaches, lemons and things, just talking… I took that memory and condensed it down into an Old-Fashioned.” Her summer-ready take also captures other iconic flavors of the season, including mustard (in the form of bitters) and a BBQ-infused bourbon that gets spritzed over the finished cocktail.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  grilled peach gomme syrup (see Editor’s Note)
4 dashes  Lapsang souchong tea–honey mustard bitters (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir the first three ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
2. Finish by misting BBQ Spritz over the top of the drink.
3. Garnish with a grilled peach. Use a Microplane to zest some lemon peel on top of the drink.

title: The Bar’s Jack Rose
intro_philosophy: Like many of the classic cocktails on the menu at New York’s swanky revamp of the iconic Four Seasons Bar, bar director Thomas Waugh’s Jack Rose takes a standard recipe and supercharges it with multiple layers of flavor, in this case by using both applejack and Calvados. According to PUNCH Contributing Editor Robert Simonson, “It would be fair to call it the best Jack Rose in town.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, add ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass and garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Frosé Y’all
intro_philosophy: Frosé finds its spiritual home in New Orleans, a place where you’re never more than a few blocks from a frozen Daiquiri. It’s there that, to the veritable bounty of frozen drinks, Kelly Fields has added her Frosé Y’all. The most simplistic of the frosé recipes we’ve found to date, Fields’ recipe consists of nothing more than rosé, ice and simple syrup, blended until smooth. “It got way too hot too quickly in New Orleans,” explains Fields. “We knew we needed something summery and deliciousright away.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a glass of your choosing and serve with a straw.

title: Al Fresco Spritz
intro_philosophy: Though the aperitif comesin many forms, the Al Fresco Spritz keeps close to the classic interpretation—not too sweet, alcoholic, or heavy, and, most importantly, effervescent. Naren Young bumps up the botanicals with a measure of gin, which complements the floral notes of St-Germain, all balanced with a dose of acidity by way of lime. Young, a self-professed sucker for beautiful garnishes, elevates the drink with an impressive array of fruit, from green grapes to kiwi wheels to starfruit, which turns this batchable cocktail into a party unto itself. Note: For a single serving, divide all of the ingredients by four.
ingredients: 6 ounces bianco vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi
sparkling water, preferably Perrier, to top
instructions: 1. Combine the vermouth, St-Germain, gin and lime juice in a pitcher over ice and stir.
2. Top with equal parts Perrier and prosecco.
3. To serve, place a cucumber wheel in each glass and pour in the spritz.

title: Mexi-Gin Martini
intro_philosophy: Residing somewhere between a Martini and a Margarita, Phil Ward’s Mexi-Gin Martinicombines the sweeter, lower proof crema de mezcal with the expected gin and dry vermouth. Ward recommends either leaving the drink ungarnished or adding a not-too-spicy pickled pepper.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

title: Fountain Inn’s Syllabub
intro_philosophy: The Syllabub from D.C.’s Fountain Inn showcases the bar’s commitment to employing modern bar techniques and eliminating waste while interpreting old American drinks. Though the bar’s version uses force carbonation and an iSi cream whipper, Hines has adapted this recipe for home use.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Cognac, preferably Pierre Ferrand 1er Cru de Cognac
3 3/4 ounces German wheat ale, preferably Franziskaner
instructions: 1. Combine the first five ingredients and half an ounce of lemon juice.
2. Dry shake until frothy.
3. In a large coupe, combine the remaining ingredients and stir to incorporate.
4. Pour frothed mixture on top.
5. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: The Glorious Fourth
intro_philosophy: Though it shares its name with a song written to commemorate the American Bicentennial in 1976, this cocktail is much older, appearing inThe Flowing Bowl, an 1892 cocktail book written by the German-born, New York-based bartender William Schmidt. It doesn’t read particularly American ingredients-wise despite the patriotic moniker, either: the juice of one lime, brandy, a dash of Jamaican rum and a large tablespoon of ice cream, shaken “exceedingly well” and strained into “a fancy glass.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a glass of your choice.

title: White Negroni & Tonic
intro_philosophy: This herbaceous highball from Rolo’s in Queens, New York’s Ridgewood neighborhood starts with a base of a White Negroni. Because Luxardo Bitter Bianco swaps in for Suze, it’s crystal clear, which beverage director Leo Bayless-Hall says makes it “so sexy and fun.” Topping with tonic opens up the drink’s botanical notes, offering a refreshing and complex cocktail.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce gin, such as Forthave Spirits Blue
instructions: 1. Add ice to a Collins glass.
2. Add the first three ingredients to the glass, then top with tonic and stir.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: St. Lucian
intro_philosophy: Showcasing the versatility of Creole Shrubb, Brad Smith pairs the orange liqueur with dark rum, amaro and chocolate bitters in this off-menu item at New Orleans’ tiki paradise,Latitude 29. “In the world of tiki cocktails,” explains Smith, “Creole Shrubb can take the place in any recipe that calls forCuraçao.”
ingredients: 2 ounces dark rum, preferably Hamilton St. Lucia 5 Year Old
1 ounce creole shrub, preferably Rhum Clément
1/4 ounce Latitude 29 cinnamon syrup (see Editor's Note)
1 dash chocolate bitters, preferably Fee Brothers Aztec
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with one large ice cube.
2. Stir for 47 revolutions and strain into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Glueh Kriek
intro_philosophy: In Portland, Oregon,Cascade Brewingoffers its interpretation of the European market–inspired glühkriek, a type of warm, spiced beer. “Glueh Kriek [another spelling of glühkriek] is often people’s first encounter with a hot beer, and it offers a really unique, memorable experience for them,” says Kevin Martin, director of brewery operations. The brewery’s recipe builds off their own kriek-style beer, but it can work with a variety of styles.“I would suggest anything that isn’t too bitter or astringent, with a malty, slightly sweet character, such as a barleywine, low-hop amber or red ale, brown ale, porter or sweet stout. I would avoid hoppy styles like IPA, or sulfury beers like lagers,” says Martin says. “The beauty is that there is no set recipe, so you can get really creative and try lots of different beer and spice combinations.”
instructions: 1. Pour the beer into a saucepan over medium-low heat.
2. Gradually heat the beer to 150˚F, stirring every few minutes.
3. Add the spices (alternatively, place the spices in a tea infuser or spice bag before adding), then add the honey.
4. Allow the spices to steep for 5 to 10 minutes.
5. If more sweetness is desired, add additional honey.
6. Remove the tea infuser or spice bag (or strain if using neither), and pour the mixture into a tempered glass or mug.
7. Garnish with an orange wedge.

title: Strawberry Letter
intro_philosophy:
Created for his grandmother’s birthday, Brian Hawthorne’s Strawberry Letter began life as a convenient way to serve drinks to a crowd. “A punch is much better than individual cocktails at this kind of gathering,” explains Hawthorne, “because no one is stuck making drinks, but everyone’s glass is full.”

Hawthorne’s crimson-colored punch is a summery, sophisticated combination of gin, Lillet Rouge and strawberries, turned effervescent with sparkling wine.
instructions: 1. Muddle strawberry with simple syrup.
2. Shake and double strain over ice in a collins glass.
3. Top half and half with dry sparkling wine and club soda.

title: Sanguinello Spritz
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, except prosecco, to a mixing tin.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass and top with prosecco.
4. Garnish with a blood orange half-wheel.

title: The Drunken Pharaoh
intro_philosophy: A measure of bourbon and lemon counteracts this otherwise cloying concoction while crushed matzo and Manischewitz bring this cocktail as close to kosher as you can get this passover.
ingredients: sugared matzo, for rimming glass (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Coat rim of glass with simple syrup, then dip in the matzo mix so that the matzo adheres to the edge.
2. In a cocktail shaker, combine the bourbon, Manishewitz and lemon juice with ice and shake.
3. Strain into the glass over ice and top with club soda.

title: Grievous Angel
intro_philosophy: “On a sunny patio, bourbon needs embellishment, by way of citrus, bright fruit, or perhaps a floral element,” explains Big Star’s Laurent Lebec. The bourbon-based Grievous Angel softens the hit of whiskey with a touch of St-Germain’s floral sweetness alongside strawberry syrup, and kicks everything up with the addition of bitters and citrus for refreshing brunch-ready fruit sour.
instructions: 1. Shake all of the ingredients well.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass.
3. Express the lemon peel, then discard and garnish with the sliced strawberry.

title: Digestivi
intro_philosophy: In this play on a classic digestivo, the combination of the natural rosé with the tannins from the teas and the fruitiness of strawberry and hibiscus are accentuated and intensified with oaky, vanilla notes, which come from the cocktail’s Cognac base.
ingredients: 8 ounces  rosé, preferably biodynamic or natural
6 ounces hibiscus and oolong tea (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Dissolve the jam in the tea whilst still hot, then filter through tea strainer.
2. Add all remaining ingredients and stir to combine, then transfer to glass bottles or into a small, well-used barrel, to age for one month or more.
3. Chill the finished cocktail, then pour into frozen sherry glasses.
4. Garnish with a a fresh-cut strawberry.

title: Third Base
intro_philosophy: “Swedish Punsch has a zippy, zesty and funky flavor with enough oomph to show up in a drink even in small amounts,” explain the minds behind Extra Fancy’s Third Base cocktail, a gin-based drink that plays on the subtle sweetness of punsch to complement lemon, honey and peach puree.
ingredients: 1 ounce navy strength gin, preferably Perry's Tot
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with cracked ice.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with a sprig of mint.

title: Army & Navy
intro_philosophy: In this updated 1930s-era recipe, orgeat and Angostura bitters bring a rich mouthfeel and aromatic spice notes that tilt the axis of this sour toward the tropical realm. The simplicity of its build is reflected in several more modern tropical cocktails featuring gin, including theSleeping LotusandRoyal Hawaiian.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Pen Pal
intro_philosophy: A play on theOld Pal, a bracing mix of rye whiskey, Campari and dry vermouth, the Pen Pal is the original’s mellowed-out, but beefed-up cousin. This drink switches out the bitter twang of Campari for the citrus-pop of Aperol, while letting the rye whiskey take the lead with a spicy, whiskey-forward resolve.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Emeralds on the Pavement
intro_philosophy: This is essentially a modified Bobby Burns, using a combination of dry vermouth and honey in place of sweet vermouth, and swapping in Grand Marnier for Bénédictine. The Elgin’s beautiful balance of bright fruit and silky, toasty cocoa notes is offset nicely by the floral notes and slight brininess of a good dry vermouth. The honey syrup is a nod to the honeyed heather and citrus notes often found in Speyside whiskies. A nice, big cube will mitigate quick dilution, but for a change of pace, try this served up in a chilled coupe.
ingredients: 2 ounces  Glen Moray Speyside 12-Year-Old Single-Malt Scotch Whisky (Elgin Heritage)
1/4 ounce honey syrup (1:1 ratio of honey to water)
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with an expressed lemon twist placed on the rim of the glass.

title: Elote Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: At Licorería Limantour, the Elote Old-Fashioned is made with Nixta corn liqueur, corn whiskey and mezcal fat-washed with a buttery base. It’s batched ahead of time, and stirred at the last minute with a mix of bitters to accent the flavors in the drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces Elote Old-Fashioned mix (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with nutmeg.

title: Up in Smoke
intro_philosophy: Turning the idea of aWhiskey Souron its head, the bar team at The Freehand Hotel in Miami first takes a batch of fresh, ripe strawberries, smokes them in a meat smoker and turns them into a hazy, pink syrup.  They then mix it into a heady formula of rye whiskey and Ramazzotti amaro resulting in an elusively fruity, yet savory sour.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce smoked strawberry syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a dehydrated orange wheel.

title: Paperback Romance
intro_philosophy: At DrinkWell in Austin, a few ingredients that are less common stateside—pisco and sloe gin—form the base of the Paperback Romance, the most popular drink at the moment. Paired with grapefruit juice, peach bitters and bergamot liqueur, the cocktail is a no-brainer for this time of year; it “just screams spring,” says DrinkWell’s Caer Maiko.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Garnish with an orange twist and a blackberry.

title: Thunder Gun Espresso
intro_philosophy: “My style is clean and boozy, but more than anything, I love getting people to try new things,” says Columbus, Ohio, bartender Annie Williams, “and I love this drink because it’s a little outside of my comfort zone.” She calls for Averna in her amaro-forward Thunder Gun Espresso cocktail for its “beautiful coffee, citrus, cinnamon and bitter chocolate notes.” Williams also loves “the complexity that amaro inherently brings to a cocktail.” Here, the familiar notes of coffee from the cold-brew and aromatic spicy chocolate bitters help make this a great “intro to amaro” cocktail.
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients except for the tonic water in a cocktail tin.
2. Add one ice cube and whip-shake to quickly aerate and dilute until the ice cube is melted.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
4. Top with tonic water.
5. Garnish with a long lemon twist.

title: Vieux Carré
intro_philosophy:
New Orleans does strong and stirred better than most American cities. From theHurricaneto theSazerac, Pat O’Brien’s to the Napoleon House, much of the Big Easy’s cocktail history insists upon specific coordinates of conception. Stanley Clisby Arthur, author ofFamous New OrleansDrinks and How to Mix ‘Em, attributed this drink’s original recipe to theHotel Monteleone, located in the Vieux Carré (French Quarter). Today, the cocktail remains a New Orleans classic, and can be experienced at its original post at the Monteleone’s Carousel Bar, which turns slowly around as life in the peculiar precinct passes by on Royal Street.

Photo original published inBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Photo by Ed Anderson © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
tags: Famous New Orleans Drinks and How to Mix 'Em
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an orange or lemon peel.

title: Punch House Spritz
intro_philosophy:
Everyone should have a house spritz—a seasonal standard whose proportions are known by heart and ingredients are stocked easily. This is ours. A simple riff on the classic spritz formula originally built to highlight Lini’s fruity, irresistible lambrusco rosato, this has become a spring-summer staple for both of us. Gentian-tinged Cocchi Americano plays the bitter role, while sour grapefruit acts as a foil to is sweetness, simultaneously pumping up the volume on the lambrusco. Built in a pitcher or portioned out in a wine glass, it’s a drink that embodies the spritz philosophy of being both beautiful and simple.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail, with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC. Photography credit: Dylan + Jeni © 2016
instructions: 1. Build the ingredients in a rocks or wine glass over ice and garnish.

title: Pancho Villa
intro_philosophy: This easy-drinking, semi-tropical cocktail, which originates in Charles H. Baker’s 1939 bookA Gentleman’s Companion, is the Philippines’ answer to aSingapore Sling. Named after Francisco Villaruel Guilledo, a Filipino flyweight boxing champ who went by the name “Pancho Villa,”  the original drink went heavy on the gin and fruit liqueurs. Manila nativeMarlo Gamora’s version, which he developed for the East Village Filipino restaurant Jeepney, is a more rum-centric endeavor, with dialed-in proportions to better calibrate the sour and the sweet.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged rum, preferably Santa Teresa 1796
1/2 ounce cherry liqueur, preferably Cherry Heering
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled highball glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with pineapple leaf, lime zest and lime wheels.

title: Joaquín Simó’s Perfect Manhattan
intro_philosophy: For Joaquín Simó,splitting the vermouth portion of the Manhattan, i.e., turning it “perfect,” yields an infinitely variable cocktail tailor-made for any season. Here, his go-to formula that’s just right as-is and equally adaptable to the vermouths of your choosing.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Antica Torino Rosso
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice and stir briskly until very cold.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Express a lemon peel over the cocktail, then notch in onto the side of the glass.

title: U.S.S. Wondrich
intro_philosophy: Jeff Beachbum Berry conceived of this recipe as an “intermission drink”—a light refresher intended to be consumed in between full-strength cocktails. The name pays tribute toDavid Wondrich, a proponent of this practice, and incidentally, the first guest to request a sherry drink at Berry’s famed New Orleans tiki bar, Latitude 29.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Sabra liqueur, or 1/2 ounce allspice liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

title: Black Lime and Strawberry Salt
intro_philosophy: Freeze-dried strawberries lend sweetness and color to this salt, but much of its flavor comes from small, wrinkly Persian black limes, which are soaked in brine and dried in the sun for a uniquely floral, funky and sour punch.
ingredients: 1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon crushed freeze-dried strawberries
instructions: 1. Separately grind the freeze-dried strawberries and black lime in a spice grinder, wiping the machine clean after each use.
2. Stir together with the salt and sugar in a small bowl.

title: Whirlybird
intro_philosophy: When Brendan Dorr opened tropical-inspired tavern The Pink Flamingo in Baltimore, he had to have one thing on the menu: a stirred Jungle Bird. This particular aged rum—with notes of overripe bananas, caramel and baking spice—is balanced nicely with a bitter Italian aperitif and acidic pineapple syrup.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Jamaican rum, such as Hamilton Jamaican Pot Still black rum
3/4 ounce St. George Spirits Bruto Americano
3/4 ounce pineapple gum syrup, such as Liber & Co.
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with cube ice.
2. Strain into a ribbed glass or coupe with cube ice.
3. Garnish with the dehydrated pineapple half-wheel.

title: Fourth Degree Cocktail
intro_philosophy: By 1922, the Martini formula was veering more towards dry—or at least semi-sweet—with the creation of the Fourth Degree, a London-born mixture of gin, both sweet and dry vermouths and several dashes of absinthe. Think of it as a Perfect Martini, improved.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Ian Kearney’s White Claw Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Spirits specialist Ian Kearney takes his White Claw in the spritz direction, opting for a simple formula of one part tequila and half part Aperol topped with grapefruit White Claw.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except White Claw, in a double rocks glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with grapefruit White Claw.

title: Giuseppe González’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy: The winning drink in our 2019 Jungle Bird tasting, is appropriately by the bartender who helped popularize it:Giuseppe González, who ran Suffolk Arms in New York City and is now based in Las Vegas. His mix was the full-bodied, bitter-boozy-juicy package the judges recognized instantly as a Jungle Bird.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a large rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with orange slice.

title: Julie Reiner’s Clover Club
intro_philosophy: The Bellevue-Stratford in Philadelphia was the fashionable, see-and-be-seen hotel of the late 1800s. Like the Friars’ Club or the Algonquin Round Table of its era, the establishment hosted The Clover Club, an all-male salon of lawyers and writers—including the likes of William Butler Yeats—until World War I. The cocktail didn’t appear until later in the Club’s history and eventually fell out of fashion, most likely due to the use of egg white and feminine associations with raspberry. But like many of the pre-Prohibition stalwarts, it was rediscovered as part of the classic arsenal, and made immortal by Julie Reiner’s Brooklyn cocktail bar of the same name.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake until chilled and strain.
3. Add the drink back to the tin and shake again, without ice.
4. Pour the drink into a chilled cocktail glass.
5. Garnish with skewered raspberries.

title: Beni Shoga Mule
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

This tart and spicy mule incorporatesbeni shoga, a Japanese ginger pickle often served on the side of fried rice or curry, Caer Maiko explains. “It’s dyed red with red shiso leaves,” she explains. The drink’s bright red hue also evokes the bottle of Kaido, she notes, a shochu made from sweet potatoes and rice.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  beni shoga shrub (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce  citrus juice blend (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake first three ingredients with ice until chilled, approximately 10 seconds.
2. Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass or copper cup.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel on top of the ice. On the lime wheel, add a small pile of beni shoga pickles.

title: Wry Smile
intro_philosophy: Abigail Gullo, bar manager of restaurant Compère Lapin in New Orleans, invokes a dry sense of humor with her Manhattan riff, the Wry Smile. Using rye whiskey as a base, she blends in two amaros, a vermouth and cream sherry for a sweet-bitter balance. Cappelletti Amaro Sfumato adds both “bitter and juicy notes,” she says.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi di Torino
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Marianito
intro_philosophy: A vermouth-based cocktail ubiquitous to northern Spain, the Marianito combines sweet vermouth, gin, Campari and bitters, served up or over ice. At La Mula de Moscú, Fernández Marchante serves a fairly classic rendition of the Basque Country staple, which reads like a lighter, summery Negroni.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, such as Cinzano
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing tin with ice andthrow itfor 25 to 30 seconds.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist and a green olive.

title: Brandy Crusta
intro_philosophy:
Invented by an Italian bartender named Joseph Santini in New Orleans, the Brandy Crusta was one of the city’s first true calling-card cocktails; originally mixed in the 1850s, it predates even therye whiskey-based Sazerac. Though it all but disappeared in the early 20th century, today, the Crusta is experiencing a revival of sorts, thanks to bartenders like Chris Hannah, who, in 2004, was the first to bring the drink back to its home city.

“It was not on any menu in the entire city,” explains Hannah. “It’d fallen off the radar.” His version, shaken and strained into asugar-rimmedglass, has been balanced to suit the modern palate, but otherwise stays true to the original in its spirit-forward template. Like many of today’s Crustas, too, it includes a small dose of maraschino liqueur, an addition made popular near the close of the 19th century.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker over ice.
2. Shake and strain into asugar-rimmedcocktail glass.
3. Garnish with the peel of half a lemon.

title: Ol’ Poet’s Smoke
intro_philosophy: The Ol’ Poet’s Smoke—a mix of Glenlivet Founder’s Reserve, honey, lemon and Amaro Montenegro—is one of several drink’s in the Scotch highballs section of the cocktail menu at therevamp of Chumley’s. According to critic Robert Simonson, “It’s what aPenicillincocktail would be if it was a highball.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a highball glass.
2. Add ice, and top with soda.

title: Arnold Palmer Milk Punch
intro_philosophy: In this take on the Arnold Palmer, Kyle Davidson, beverage director of BLVD Steakhouse in Chicago (and formerly of The Violet Hour), turns to the classic milk punch technique—in which the acids of citrus curdle milk to filter out any particulates in the mixture, without adding heat—to round out the combination of Earl Grey tea, citrus and bergamot liqueur for a silky, crystal-clear spin on the summer classic.
ingredients: 200 grams (a heavy 3/4 cup) Earl Grey tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. In a large container, combine the orange peels and sugar and muddle briefly. Let sit for at least 15 minutes to allow the sugar to absorb the orange peel oils.
2. Add the Earl Grey tea, followed by the rest of the ingredients. Once combined, let sit overnight in the refrigerator.
3. Using a coffee filter or similar, strain the batch into a large container. The first pass will be cloudy.  Once all the liquid has passed through the strainer, filter through a second time.
4. After around 20 minutes, it should start to strain slower and clear. Once that happens, transfer the filter to a new, clean container and allow it to collect the clear milk punch.

title: Pimm’s Italiano
intro_philosophy:
Dale DeGroff’s Italianate take on the classic Pimm’s Cup.

Reprinted with permission fromThe New Craft of the Cocktailby Dale DeGroff, copyright © 2020. Photo by Daniel Krieger © 2020. Published by Clarkson Potter, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Muddle the cucumber wheel and the Cynar in the bottom of a highball glass.
2. Add ice cubes and build the drink in the glass and stir.
3. Then add the cucumber spear and the lemon wedge.

title: Elephant Flip
intro_philosophy: A bittersweet take on the colonial flip, the Elephant Flip—created by longtime bartender Christina Rando—builds on a base of Ramazzotti, Jamaican rum and bourbon, adds flavors of chocolate and pomegranate and tops it all with bitter IPA. “It’s rich, ‘dessert-y’ and filling, but still balanced,” says Franklin Mortgage & Investment Co.’s Sara Justice. “It’s really the best of both worlds.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and dry shake.
2. Fill the cocktail shaker with ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a fizz glass and top with IPA.
4. Garnish with a line of aromatic bitters, such as Bitter Truth.

title: Baldwin’s (Easy) Sherry Colada
intro_philosophy:
At Baldwin Bar, located above Boston’s Sichuan Garden restaurant, bartender Ran Duan serves his Sherry Colada, a mixture of palo cortado, manzanilla, and amontillado sherries, plus pineapple juice, house-made coconut cream, and lemon juice. Here he offers this “easy” version, which requires only one sherry—amontillado— cutting the ingredient list down to four without sacrificing craveability.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
2. Pour into a Zombie or highball glass. Add crushed ice to fill the glass.
3. Garnish with a pineapple wedge, pineapple fronds, and Angostura bitters (if desired).

title: Getaway Car
intro_philosophy: At Raines Law Room and her other venues, Meaghan Dorman has developed a reputation for streamlined cocktails and elegant presentation. Her take on the Jungle Bird, which swaps in Ancho Reyes for Campari—alongside a kick of ancho chili powder—fits right in.
instructions: 1. Fill a shaker tin half-full with pebble ice.
2. Add all ingredients and shake.
3. Fill a Zombie mug half-full with pebble ice.
4. Strain into the mug, and garnish with a lime wheel and a sprinkle of ancho powder.

title: Chartreuse Daisy
intro_philosophy: Like many of Squable’s drinks, the Chartreuse Daisy is a simple riff on a classic formula. Taking the blueprint of a daisy (a sour with added seltzer or soda water), Terry Williams and Anna Wilkins opt for a base of yellow Chartreuse, making it less gin-forward, plus a raspberry syrup for balance.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a skinny Collins glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with firestix flowers, raspberries and a lemon wheel.

title: Margaladaoma
intro_philosophy: What do you get when you cross aMargarita, aPalomaand aMichelada? AMargaladaoma, naturally. For a richer, umami-forward drink, go Negra Modelo, but if you’re looking for something lighter on its feet, Modelo Especial is a fine substitute.
ingredients: 1 ounce grapefruit and chile de árbol shrub (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. To shaking tin, add mezcal, grapefruit shrub and grapefruit juice. Add ice, and shake.
2. Strain over ice into a Collins glass rimmed with salt.
3. Top with Negro Modelo, and garnish with a half grapefruit wheel.

title: Tim Miner’s French 75
intro_philosophy: The winner in our recent blind French 75 tasting, the panel found Tim Miner’s rendition bewitching and beautifully integrated, with lots of body and lushness. “That push/pull between the brandy and the citrus is doing all the work there,” said Joaquín Simó, an expert on the panel. “This could go four seasons,” added St. John Frizell. “It’s got enough summertime flavors. It’s so complete.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Cognac, preferably H by Hine
Champagne, to top (preferably Louis Roederer Brut Premier)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Champagne, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a flute.
3. Top with Champagne.
4. Express the lemon peel and discard.

title: Southside
intro_philosophy: Depending on how you look at the glass, the Southside lands somewhere between a ginMojitosans soda water or aGimletwith mint. Though New York’s 21 Club lays claim to the recipe as part of its Prohibition-era menu, some cocktail historians place the conception some 40 years earlier at the Southside Sportsmen’s Club in Long Island, a private establishment where tony Manhattanites went to hunt, fish and drinkMint Juleps—the latter of which probably evolved into this iteration. The clubby association stuck, and the drink became standard issue for the pearl and nine-iron set, but one would be remiss in passing this over on principle—it’s as delicious as it is simple.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, gently muddle mint leaves with simple syrup.
2. Add all other ingredients, add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double straininto a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Spank a mint sprig against your hand to release the oils and garnish.

title: Scout’s Blackberry and Pine Wine
intro_philosophy: A dry berry ferment from London bar Scout, this wine combines the late British summer burst of blackberries, seen scattered over the hedgerows across the country, with the more autumnal flavor of pine sprigs. Invented to make use of bruised or otherwise unsellable blackberries by Scout’s owner Matt Whiley, this wine harnesses the fruit’s natural yeasts, making it vital to keep the liquid at a constant temperature when fermenting. You can scale the yield of the recipe up or down as desired.
instructions: 1. Add 1 liter of water to your ferment bucket along with all the sugar and dissolve.
2. Blend or crush blackberries and pine and add to your ferment bucket.
3. Add the remaining 3 of liters water and stir.
4. Cover the ferment bucket tightly with muslin cloth and leave for 3 days or until small bubbles appear on the surface.

5. Now place the lid with an airlock and ferment for a further 10 to 20 days depending on the temperature of the environment. Scout likes to ferment all the sugar creating a dry ferment but less time will result in a sweeter liquid.

6. Once you are happy with the ferment pour off liquid being careful to leave as much excess fruit and sediment at the bottom; repeat this process over the course of 3 to 4 days to clarify the liquid.
7. Bottle and keep until you are ready to drink.

title: Real Charmer’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: This signature drink from Real Charmer in Los Angeles is a souped-up take on theNuclear Daiquiri. In lieu of falernum, it calls on an easy-to-make coconut syrup for extra tropical flavor. It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients in a shaker and hard shake with ice.
2. Double-strain into Nick and Nora glass.

title: Glasgow Mule
intro_philosophy: The classicmule or buckis composed of a base spirit, citrus and ginger ale. Damon Boelte of Brooklyn’sPrime Meatsused this simple formula to build his Glasgow Mule, named for its Scotch foundation. Boelte builds upon this with fresh lemon, the versatile elderflower liqueur St-Germain, spicy Fever Tree ginger beer plus a dash of aromatic Angostura bitters over crushed ice to complete this tart and spicy cocktail.
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a large mule mug (if you're fancy enough to own one) or a Collins glass.
2. Add crushed ice and stir.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel and candied ginger.

title: Off Piste
intro_philosophy: Noel Martin’s thoroughly French spritz calls on a short-list of the country’s most beloved spirits. St-Germain offers a floral sweetness that rounds out the anise flavors from the pastis, giving the cocktail a balance between citrusy and herbaceous and allowing the subtle complexities and botanicals of the other spirits to come through. The name, Off Piste, was inspired by La Grave, a small ski resort in the French Alps, and refers to how a spritz can be “the perfect platform to deviate from what is conventional, usual or expected.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce pastis, preferably Henri Broudin Pastis
1/2 ounce génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy des Alpes
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except Perrier, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain over ice into a large wine glass.
3. Top with Perrier.
4. Garnish with fresh dill, a lemon twist and an edible flower.

title: Padua Paloma
intro_philosophy: This Paloma-meets-spritz mashup introduces Italian bitter Aperol into the mix. Since Aperol adds some sweetness, Josh Goldman of Bar Calo lengthens the drink with sparkling water instead of citrus-flavored soda.
instructions: 1. Combine first four ingredients in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Top with sparkling water, and stir with a straw.
3. Garnish with dehydrated grapefruit wheel and black salt.

title: One Thousand Cranes
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

This crushable, citrusy highball is poetically named after a Japanese children’s novel, in which 1,000 cranes are used to make a wish. “The cocktail itself is a riff off a classic Collins,” Kevin Diedrich explains, “but using fresh lemon verbena, which paired so well with the savory melon notes of the Saiten shochu.”
ingredients: 2 ounces  cucumber- and melon-infused iichiko Saiten shochu (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce  lemon verbena syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake first four ingredients with ice.
2. Double strain into an ice-filled Collins glass.
3. Top with yuzu soda.
4. Garnish with the cucumber ribbon and lemon verbena.

title: Fond de Culotte
intro_philosophy: Also known as Suze-cass, the Fond de Culotte is a 20th-century French aperitif that simply combines Suze and crème de cassis. Today, it’s rarely seen on menus and is more commonly an off-menu serve. Modern bars, like Le Syndicat, often lengthen the drink with club soda, force-carbonation or sparkling wine. Here, Le Syndicat uses a technique called “jacking” to quickly infuse Suze with blackberry flavor.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crème de cassis, preferably Marie Brizard
1 teaspoon quinquina rouge, such as Cap Corse Rouge Aperitif or Byrrh
instructions: 1. Add Suze, crème de cassis and quinquina to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Top with club soda.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: The Modern Prometheus
intro_philosophy: A cocktail made with four and half ounces of booze—plus a couple of dashes of absinthe—certainly does deserve to be named for the mythic being that gave humans fire. For this drink, Martin Cate reimagines theZombieto include three different types of gin, absinthe, citrus juices and falernum.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Navy strength gin, preferably Royal Dock
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to shaker tin with ice and shake.
2. Transfer the contents of the shaker tin to a tall Zombie glass.
3. Top with crushed ice and garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Russian Coffee
intro_philosophy: Although kvass (a fermented and subtly alcoholic Eastern European beverage) is traditionally drunk cold, Kachka’s Israel Morales felt that its comforting flavor worked well in a hot winter cocktail. At his Portland, Oregon, Russian restaurant he toyed with the idea of warming up the kvass for a hot toddy, but landed instead on this spiked coffee riff, which he says is a throwback to midcentury America’s fascination with the style. The result is a cocktail that is bittersweet and reminiscent of an Irish Coffee with its lightly-whipped chicory cream garnish.
instructions: 1. In a tempered mug, add all ingredients and stir to mix.
2. Top with an inch of whipped chicory cream (see Editor's Note) and garnish with an orange peel.

title: Nonalcoholic Negroni
intro_philosophy: Much like the Negroni Sbagliato’s origin story, thisnonalcoholic Negroniwas created when bartender Leanne Favre mistakenly grabbed a bottle of Wilfred’s nonalcoholic aperitif in lieu of a similarly-labeled gin substitute. The resulting drink was our favorite in a blind tasting of 10 nonalcoholic Negronis, favored for its bracing and bitter qualities. “The bitterness helps me come back for another sip rather than want to throw it back,” said Tom Macy, a judge at the tasting.
instructions: 1. Chill all ingredients before use.
2. Combine the ingredients in a glass over a large ice cube, and give a quick stir to incorporate.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Imaginary Folklore
intro_philosophy: Bartender Christian Suzuki wanted to create a dirty Martini variation that would employ only a few ingredients, each one packing a punch while still playing off the delicate flavors of the gin. Drawing inspiration from the flavors and memories of his grandparents’ restaurants in Tokyo, he uses sherry fat-washed with sesame oil alongside a nori-infused brine to lend a sharp, savory kick. St-Germain adds a touch of sweetness and body, and the rice puff garnish recalls the scent of toasting rice at the city’s outdoor food markets.
ingredients: 3/4 parts  sesame oil fat-washed manzanilla sherry (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir until diluted.
2. Pour into a large rocks glass. Serve in a bowl over crushed ice to keep the cocktail cold.
3. Serve “otsumami” (snack) style with the rice puff garnish on side.

title: Red Beet and Peppercorn Shrub
intro_philosophy:
For this recipe, I used a mix of apple cider vinegar and distilled white vinegar. I don’t normally like distilled white vinegar in shrubs, as it can overwhelm delicate berries and stone fruits. But beets are gutsy, and they can handle the stronger flavor.

If you have a favorite recipe for pickled beets, try adding spices from that recipe to this one. For example, if you like bay leaves and mustard seeds in your pickled beets, they’ll work well in this shrub, too. Add them along with—or instead of—the peppercorns and kosher salt.
instructions: 1. Add beets and both vinegars to blender. Blend until pureed.
2. Press puree through a fine-mesh strainer into a medium bowl. You should have about 2-3 cups beet juice and vinegar.
3. Add beet juice and vinegar mixture, sugar, peppercorns, and kosher salt to a nonreactive container. Cover and allow to steep for one day. Taste. If it’s not peppery enough, give it another day.
4. Place a fine-mesh strainer over a small bowl and pour mixture through to remove solids.
5. Bottle and store in refrigerator.

title: Dan Greenbaum’s Sherry Cobbler
intro_philosophy: With just enough citrus to give acidic lift, “a raspberry cobbler is delicious with amontillado sherry,” says Dan Greenbaum. This is a close copy of the cobbler previously served at The Beagle, a now-closed East Village bar that helped launch the sherry-cocktail revolution, and where Greenbaum manned the bar.
instructions: 1. Add lemon, raspberries and simple syrup to a mixing tin and muddle.
2. Add the sherry and swirl briefly.
3. Dump the contents of the tin into a chilled Collins glass.
4. Fill the glass 3/4 full with pebble or crushed ice and mix briefly with a spoon or metal straw to integrate.
5. Garnish with fruit and a mint sprig.

title: Mosquito
intro_philosophy: Invented by Sam Ross at Attaboy in 2017, the Mosquito revisits a template Ross explored with his iconicPaper Plane10 years prior. It features four ingredients in equal measure, creating a harmony of smoky, sweet, spicy, sour and bitter elements. It’s the progenitor ofa whole brood of Attaboy drinks, known as the Bug Cocktails, which follow a common formula of a spirit, plus lemon (or lime) and housemade ginger juice, all rounded out with a bitter liqueur.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweetened ginger juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with candied ginger.

title: Astoria
intro_philosophy:
Essentially aMartiniwith inverted proportions, the Astoria, named after the New York City hotel where it was created, is one of many vermouth-heavy Martini variations that were popular from the late 18th century on through the first half of the 20th century. Our version, which was adapted fromThe Old Waldorf-Astoria Bar Book, swaps out Old Tom gin for London dry, and ups the vermouth for a slightly drier take on the original.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe and garnish with the olive.

title: Stop-and-Go Light
intro_philosophy: “The purpose of this drink was to showcase some of the unique flavors that are enjoyed in the Upper Midwest while still being a very classic-feeling daisy-style cocktail,” saysJackson Mercier, head bartender at Bryant’s Cocktail Lounge in Milwaukee. Crème de noyaux—which also stars in thePink Squirrel, an iconic ice cream cocktail originating at Bryant’s—teams up with Trinidadian rum and brandy, the state spirit of Wisconsin. (For the latter, Mercier suggests using Korbel, if you’re not feeling fancy.) “The split base between a dry Trinidadian rum blend and a sweeter American-style brandy provides a sort of high-low [quality],” says Mercier.Lime juice, vanilla syrup and a dash of peach bitters complete the drink, which takes its name from the Milwaukee term for a traffic light.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Trinidadian rum, preferably Scarlet Ibis
3/4 ounce brandy, preferably Wollersheim Press House (or Korbel)
3/4 ounce crème de noyaux, preferably Tempus Fugit
1/4 ounce to 1/2 ounce vanilla syrup, preferably Torani (the amount will vary by the styles of noyaux and vanilla syrup)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a dark cherry.

title: El Quijote’s Red Sangria
intro_philosophy: The red sangria at El Quijote starts with an “affordable, youthful” garnacha and cava, plus a 10-year-old brandy de Jerez and Bonanto, a grape-based aperitivo that Brian Evans likens to Aperol, but with more bitterness and a distinct cherry characteristic. Pineapple and lemon juices and cinnamon syrup add complexity, as does a balsamic vinegar reduction, for “an element of intrigue and an element of acid.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Bodegas Lustau Brandy de Jerez Solera Reserva
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a large wine glass over cubed ice, ending with cava.
2. Stir lightly to combine.
3. Garnish with sliced fruit.

title: Garden Mule
intro_philosophy: This herbaceous twist on the Gin-Gin Mule replicates the uplifting greenness of summer, with the hue to match. The Botanist gin is infused with tannic green tea, then paired with a textural “garden syrup” made from toasted fennel seeds, mint and basil stems—all of which complement the gin’s elegant botanicals. In true mule fashion, it’s topped with ginger beer, which adds effervescence and lifts the drink’s complex aromatics to the nose.
ingredients: 2 ounces  green tea–infused The Botanist gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients except for the ginger beer to a shaker with ice, then shake.
2. Strain into a Collins glass and add spear or cubed ice. Top with ginger beer.
3. Garnish with fresh herbs and serve with a straw.

title: El Pepe
intro_philosophy: Built with a structure similar to aMargarita—except with mezcal and herbaceous Dolin Génépy in place of tequila and Cointreau—El Pepe wields an unexpected layered complexity.
ingredients: 1 ounce mezcal, such as Del Maguey Vida
1/4 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over a large rock into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a basil leaf.

title: San Francisco Treat
intro_philosophy: Sam Levy, owner of the Fern Bar in Sebastopol, California, created this drink as the ultimate nightcap when he was the bar manager at the Michelin three-starred Restaurant at Meadowood in St. Helena, California. Combine and stir one ounce each of Fernet-Branca, Averna and Dolin Blanc vermouth over ice and serve neat in a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass. Garnish with a flamed orange zest if you’re feeling ambitious.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and briefly stir.
