2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with a flamed orange twist.

title: Butter-Infused Rum
intro_philosophy: Originally created by bartender Don Lee during his tenure at New York City cocktail barPDT, this buttered rum is used as the base of his Cinema Highball. Bartender John deBary also incorporated it into his blue drink for PDT, theShark.
instructions: 1. Melt butter over medium heat, but be careful not to brown.
2. Pour rum into a large container or bowl and add melted butter. Stir to mix.
3. Cover and let sit for 24 hours at room temperature, then place in the freezer for two hours.
4. Fine strain and bottle.

title: El Duque
intro_philosophy: Taking the classic template of the Manhattan, the bar team at The Freehand Hotel on Miami Beach substitutes rum for bourbon and sherry for sweet vermouth. They then add a bit of cold brew coffee and chocolate bitters for complexity creating a postprandial digestif with a kick—just in case you want to hit the club when you’re finished.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Siete
intro_philosophy: AsRanch Waterhas grown beyond its native West Texas, bars across the country continue to make their own spins on the drink. At Holy Ghost in Portland, Oregon, the Siete is the most popular of nine Ranch Water riffs on the menu. “We think of the Siete as a tequila Piña Colada soda,” says bar manager Sid Chi.
instructions: 1. Salt the rim of a Collins glass.
2. Add all ingredients with ice.
3. Top with soda water, and stir to incorporate.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Sorrenity
intro_philosophy: On New York’s Lower East Side, the Caribbean bar Las’ Lap has served different rum-based sorrel cocktails over the years. This December, the bar has created the Sorrenity, which combines aged rum and St-Germain with citrus, sweetness and an ounce of sorrel for a punchy, floral drink. Las’ Lap makes its own tea for the cocktail, but as with all thingssorrel, the exact mix is up to you. Make it however you enjoy it best.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel and dried sorrel.

title: Necromancer
intro_philosophy: “I really just love Corpse Revivers,” says Vince Bright of the inspiration behind his Necromancer. Working from that classic blueprint, Bright swaps rhum agricole for gin as the base spirit, then adds grapefruit juice as the sour citrus element and velvet falernum for that tropical spice. “I don’t think there’s anything wrong with the classic one, I just wanted to spice it up a little bit.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Neisson Blanc
1/2 ounce falernum, preferably John D. Taylor's Velvet Falernum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: The Pompadour
intro_philosophy: A fan of Pineau des Charentes both by itself as an aperitif and in cocktails, Dan Greenbaum likes to use it in place of sweet vermouth in drinks: “It gives a slightly drier, more floral aspect,” he explains. The Pompadour, adaptedfrom the 1936 edition of cocktail maestro Frank Meier’s guide,The Artistry of Mixing Drinks, is a bright, puckery mix of Pineau, aged rum and lemon juice.
instructions: 1. Pour all ingredients into a mixing glass and shake.
2. Strain into a coupe and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Gold Dust Woman
intro_philosophy:
Alex Jump inherited a love of her father’s favorite summertime drink, the Rum & Tonic. She uses that here as the launching pad for a Collins riff, with distinctive grassy notes of rhum agricole and an earthy bite from a syrup made with turmeric and coconut water. (One of Jump’s favorite moves is making syrups with a base liquid other than plain water.) Lengthening the drink with Fever-Tree Club Soda delivers clean effervescence to finish.

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces  white rhum agricole, preferably Rhum J.M. 100 Proof
¾ ounce  Coconut Water & Turmeric Cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add the rhum, Campari, lime juice and cordial to a mixing tin filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled, and strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Brandy Fix
intro_philosophy: No one celebrates the fix—simply a sour served over crushed ice—more prominently than Richard Boccato’s Fresh Kills in Williamsburg. Robert Simonson chose this off-menu version as one of his top cocktails of 2017.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Pour into a chilled double rocks glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon wedge.

title: St. John Frizell’s Hemingway Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: The winning cocktail in our recent blind Hemingway Daiquiri tasting came, somewhat unexpectedly, fromFort Defiancein Brooklyn, not a bar known for the drink. Perhaps a key to ownerSt. John Frizell’s victory was his habit of including a small piece of grapefruit peel in the mixing tin when shaking, the so-called“regal shake.”The judges found the drink tart, bright and light-bodied, with just a hint of vanilla lurking in the background.
ingredients: 2 ounces white rum, preferably Denizen Aged White Rum
1 small piece grapefruit peel, approximately ½ inch x 2 inches
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice for 15 to 20 seconds. (If it's Kold Draft or other 1x1 cubes, add a handful of pellet ice.)
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a very thin lime wheel.

title: Room for Improvement’s Manhattan
intro_philosophy: “I’ve always preferred the dryness and spice of a higher proof rye in my Manhattans,” says Arvid Brown of Portland, Maine’s Room for Improvement, who uses a split base of Rittenhouse and Old Overholt ryes. “The keystone ingredient that really sets [our Manhattan] apart is a small measure of Luxardo Amaretto that works to lend depth, complexity and a little extra body.” At the bar, the drink is pre-diluted, batched and frozen, but this recipe is for a single serving.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Dolin Rouge
2 barspoons amaretto, such as Luxardo Amaretto
1 dash house orange bitters blend (1:1, Angostura orange to Regans’ orange bitters)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a Luxardo cherry.

title: The Streamliner’s Moscow Mule
intro_philosophy: This unassuming Moscow Mule from Eric Alperin’s forthcoming The Streamliner in downtown Los Angeles, gets garnished with a scoop of house-made citrus sorbet, which is meant to be stirred into the drink as its consumed.
ingredients: ginger beer, to top (see Editor's Note)
1 small scoop citrus sorbet (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add vodka to a 10-ounce chilled Collins glass over an ice spear.
2. Top with ginger beer.
3. Garnish with a small scoop of citrus sorbet and a straw.

title: TJ Vytlacil’s Blood & Sand
intro_philosophy: Fresh-squeezed orange juice and vigorous shaking for maximum froth are the keys to acing this classic equal-parts drink. Creator TJ Vytlacil admonishes: “You should definitely break a sweat making a Blood & Sand. If you’re not sweating, you’re not doing it right.”
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Dolin Vermouth de Chambéry Rouge
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and vigorously shake.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a flamed orange coin.

title: Dark Materials
intro_philosophy: Chantal Tseng is a dedicated tea drinker who finds toddies “delightful,” as well as ritualistic. “Hot drinks are made to be sipped slowly,” she says. “The way you hold the mug to warm your hands, blowing on the hot liquid to temper it, getting a good whiff of the steamy elixir…it’s comforting and relaxing.” This Sherry-based version incorporates fernet, absinthe and traditionally warming ingredients like turmeric and ginger juice with dandelion root tea for an earthy, botanically complex cocktail.
ingredients: 2 ounces oloroso sherry, preferably Emilio Hidalgo Gobernador
1/2 ounce fernet, preferably Tempus Fugit Fernet del Frate Angelico
1/2 ounce honey syrup (1:1, honey to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except dandelion root tea, in mug.
2. Top with dandelion root tea.
3. Garnish with lemon peel, cinnamon stick and freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Alex Jump’s 50/50 Martini
intro_philosophy: Taking second place in our blind tasting of 11 50/50 Martini recipes, Alex Jump’s recipe was described as having a “beautiful finish.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce London dry gin, preferably Tanquerary 10
1 1/2 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat Extra Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a green olive and a lemon twist.

title: Elderflower Collins
intro_philosophy: Ever since Ideveloped a tapioca pearl cocktail, I’ve been obsessed with finding ways to incorporate them into cocktails. This drink is a bit of a mashup of traditional milk boba teas and a classic Tom Collins, with the hop water and elderflower providing some of the same botanical elements that a gin might.The light florality is an intriguing counterpart to the dairy and tapioca elements here. If you’d prefer to use an alcoholic elderflower liqueur such as St-Germain, just note that those products bring a bit more acidity to the table in contrast to the nonalcoholic syrups, so the finished drink will read more acidic, too.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces elderflower syrup, such as Monin (or elderflower liqueur such as St-Germain)
instructions: 1. Prepare the tapioca pearls according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
2. Pour the hop water into a chilled tall glass.
3. In a cocktail shaker, combine the elderflower syrup (or liqueur, if using) and evaporated milk.
4. Dry-shake for 3 to 5 seconds to combine, then pour over the hop water.
5. Add the tapioca pearls and serve with a bubble tea straw.

title: Skåne Snaps
intro_philosophy: “I try to go a bit more heavy on the flavor of the snaps for Christmas… since the food around Christmas tends to be a bit more rich compared to the lighter cuisine in the summer,” says Jakob Sundin, Stockholm-based bartender and founder of the Bartender’s Choice Awards. In this version of his snaps, Sundin infuses vodka with all the best cold-weather spices—cumin, anise, fennel seeds—for a Christmas-ready take on the traditional Scandinavian liquor.
instructions: 1. Infuse bottle of Absolut for approximately 24 hours with the spices, fruit and sugar.

title: The Bennett
intro_philosophy: The Bennett is a seemingly simple variation on the Gimlet that leans on the all-important addition of Angostura bitters, along with a cinnamon-infused lime cordial that amplifies the spice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake and strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a floating lime wheel.

title: Savory Hunter
intro_philosophy: Adapted from the version served at Midnight Rambler, this recipe calls for ingredients more likely to be found in your kitchen than behind the bar. Chad Solomon swaps the traditional dash of bitters for a dash of fish sauce, instead, and infuses the gin with a mixture of lemongrass and makrut lime muddled with cilantro and Thai chili. The result is a savory, slightly salty delight.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce cream of coconut, preferably Coco Lopez
2 ounces lemongrass- & makrut-infused gin (see Editor's Note)
2 drops mineral saline (1:9, kosher salt: mineral water)
5 drops  fish sauce, preferably Red Boat
instructions: 1. Muddle cilantro and Thai chili slices with the lime juice and cream of coconut in a mixing tin.
2. Add the infused gin and dry shake.
3. Fine-strain into an empty double Old-Fashioned or rocks glass.
4. Top up generously with crushed or nugget ice.
5. Garnish with Thai chili and makrut lime leaf.

title: Aaron Polsky’s Coconut Cream
intro_philosophy: House-made coconut cream may not be the most versatile ingredient in a cocktail arsenal, but it’s essential to drinks like thePiña Colada. Combining equal parts cream of coconut and sugar, by volume, Aaron Polsky’s house recipe could not be easier.
instructions: 1. In a sealable container, combine ingredients and stir until the sugar is dissolved.

title: Cayo Coco’s Mai Tai
intro_philosophy: This recipe’s rum blend—Appleton Signature, Planteray and Myers’s—earned it the title “a Mai Tai for the people” inour 2025 Mai Tai tasting, where it took second place. (The bar uses limited-edition versions of each, but Josh Schaff suggested the flagships of each brand in their place.) In addition to the house-made orgeat, rich Demerara syrup and Pierre Ferrand dry Curacao round out the recipe. The judges found it bright, with a pleasant candied orange quality, and not too dry. It’s garnished with a mint sprig, to represent palm trees, a lime wheel to evoke the island of Jamaica and rock candy in a nod to the island’s mountains.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Cayo Coco’s orgeat (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
2. Shake and dump into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig, rock candy stick and lime wheel.

title: Gin Rickey
intro_philosophy: This variation on thefizztraces its origins to a whiskey-based drink created by Joe Rickey, a lobbyist from Missouri who moved to the nation’s capital in the late-19thcentury. He began requesting whiskey cocktails sans sugar from local bars. The drink was a hit and soon found nation-wide popularity, so much so that Rickey eventually got into the drinks business himself, selling soda water. This version replaces whiskey with gin, which has arguably become the drink’s most famous riff.
instructions: 1. Add gin and lime juice to a Collins glass.
2. Add ice and top with soda water.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Peppy Skinos Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Greek bartender Michael Menegos uses pink peppercorns to capitalize on the earthiness of Greece’s earthy mastiha spirit, bringing a whole new layer to this deceptively simple sour.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients into a cocktail shaker and shake well.
2. Double strain into a coupe glass.

title: Bamboo Highball
intro_philosophy: “All my favorite drinks that I’ve come up with have been classic variations that I’ve kind of turned on their heads,” says Stacey Swenson. Here, she re-imagines the vermouth-and-sherry-based stirred drink as a tall cooler, maintaining a low-proof profile while playing up the herbal notes of the olive bitters with Fever Tree Mediterranean tonic. “Its slightly salty but so easy-going,” says Swenson.
ingredients: 1 dash olive bitters, preferably The Bitter Truth
1 dash lemon bitters, preferably The Bitter Truth
tonic water, preferably Fever Tree Mediterranean (to top)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a highball glass over an ice spear or Kold Draft ice cubes.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with a rosemary sprig and an olive.

title: Hideaway Honey
intro_philosophy: From the team behind some of San Diego’s most notable watering holes, including Polite Provisions and Noble Experiment, comes this aquavit- and yogurt-laced cocktail which will star on the menu at the forthcoming Raised by Wolves.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake.
2. Strain into a collins glass over ice.
3. Top with club soda.
4. Garnish with edible flowers.

title: Snap Pea
intro_philosophy: This herbaceous spritz revolves around tarragon, accented by notes of lemongrass and black pepper found in botanical characteristics of both the gin and genepy. In this flexible recipe, any herbs on hand can be substituted to make the syrup, and the genepy can be swapped for another bitter, bright aperitif.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce tarragon simple syrup (see Editors’ Note)
1 1/2 ounces gin, preferably Bombay Sapphire East
instructions: 1. Muddle snap peas and Meyer lemon juice in a shaker tin.
2. Add all additional ingredients, save for the prosecco.
3. Shake with ice, then double strain into a wine glass with fresh ice (prime it with a little splash of prosecco for integration first)
4. Top with prosecco.
5. Garnish with a tarragon sprig.

title: Black Apple Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: A classic Old-Fashioned is sugar, water, spirit and bitters. “It’s my contention that Jägermeister already contains all of these components,” Teague says. “It’s basically a self-contained Old-Fashioned.” The Black Apple Old-Fashioned simply ups the spirit and bitters quotient by adding apple brandy and apple bitters. “The fruit notes and the ginger-cinnamon” present in Jägermeister “pair real well with the apple brandy,” he adds. “Who wouldn’t like apple pie with ginger and cinnamon in it?”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an ice-filled tumbler.
2. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Bijou
intro_philosophy: This improbable cocktail—a blend of gin, sweet vermouth andChartreuse—was invented in the United States in the late-19thcentury. The invention of the drink is commonly attributed to bartender Harry Johnson, who included the recipe in his 1900s tomeThe Bartender’s Manual, while its name, which means jewel in French, is said to have been inspired by the gem-colored alcohols combined in the recipe. The original formula calls for either a cherry or an olive for a garnish, but history has come down on the correct side of this debate: today’s version uses a cherry.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Gage Hotel Ranch Water
intro_philosophy: Though this West Texas spritz has been a favorite at the Gage Hotel’s Buffalo Bar in Marathon, Texas for many years, operations manager Phillip Moellering says it was only officially added to the cocktail menu in 2010. Naranja orange liqueur rounds the drink with a juicy sweetness, but Mollering says the Gage’s secret ingredient is “the extra lime and the colorful company it is enjoyed in.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces silver tequila, preferably Pura Vida
1/2 ounce  orange liqueur, preferably Pura Vida Naranja
4 ounces Topo Chico sparkling mineral water
instructions: 1. Add tequila, lime, orange liqueur and ice to a cocktail shaker and shake well.
2. Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
3. Top with Topo Chico and garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Neal Bodenheimer’s Whiskey Sour
intro_philosophy: To add bitters or to not add bitters? Neal Bodenheimer’s addition of a “spray” of Angostura bitters alongside the classic combination of whiskey, lemon, simple syrup and egg white earned him a spot in the top three during our recent blind tasting of nearly 20 Whiskey Sours.
ingredients: 2 ounces Evan Williams Single Barrel Bourbon
instructions: 1. Add the egg and lemon juice to a mixing tin, and dry shake.
2. Add bourbon and simple syrup to the other side of the shaking tin.
3. Add 5 Kold Draft cubes and shake 20 times.
4. Double strain over ice into a rocks glass.
5. Allow the egg white to separate and spray Angostura on top of the foam.
6. Express a lemon peel over the glass and garnish with the peel and a brandied cherry.

title: William Elliott’s Cape Codder
intro_philosophy: William Elliott’s take on the Cape Codder hews closely to the original recipe, with a few small upgrades: building on a base of Axberg vodka, his drink calls on a half-ounce of cranberry cordial and gets added depth from a dash of Angostura, plus a touch of fizz with its soda water topper.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda through a fine strainer.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Ranglum
intro_philosophy: TheRanglumwas invented by bartender Gonçalo de Sousa Monteiro in Berlin in the aughts and has since become a known entity at craft cocktail bars across Germany.While it remains a relative rarity in the States, it is perhaps only a matter of time before its challenges are embraced by a new generation of bartenders. Despite its complexities of flavor, it is a drink that thrives on the combination of a few simple ingredients. As de Sousa Monteiro summarizes: “You just need them in perfect balance.”
ingredients: scant 1 1/2 ounces heavy-bodied rum, such as El Dorado 12, Hampden Estate or Goslings Black
heavy 1/4 ounce overproof rum, such as Wray & Nephew
1/4 to 1/2 ounce lime juice, to taste (depending on the sweetness of the falernum)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Gradda’s Tamal
intro_philosophy: At Here’s Looking at You, this take on the Margarita is inspired by the tamales with salsa roja made by a former bartender’s grandmother. To a base of mezcal, the Los Angeles restaurant addsAlma Tepec, a pasilla mixe chile liqueur from Oaxaca, and kümmel, which adds cumin notes to the drink. A housemade savory syrup, meanwhile, channels the salsa, tying the whole thing together.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, such as Domingo Salmiana
3/4 ounce salsa roja syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with cube ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a charred corn husk.

title: The Paper Plane: an Uncomplicated Cocktail to Add to Your Arsenal
intro_philosophy: Since it wasfirst developed in 2007, the Paper Plane has become a fixture on cocktail menus around the world. It’s an uncomplicated drink, with equal-parts bourbon, Aperol, lemon juice, and Amaro Nonino. The recipe calls for a base ofAmaro Nonino Quintessentia, a digestivo from the legendaryNonino distilleryin Friuli, Italy. This particular amaro comes from an ancient recipe, passed down through generations of the Nonino family. The notes of spice, licorice, and herbs bring a level of complexity to the Paper Plane. Together, the ingredients combine to create a modern-day classic that’s here to stay.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a coup glass.

title: Nick Bennett’s Vieux Carré
intro_philosophy: Taking second place in our blind Vieux Carré tasting was Nick Bennett of New York’s Porchlight, whose recipe called on three-quarters of an ounce of sweet vermouth, albeit a 50/50 blend of Carpano Antica and Cocchi Vermouth di Torino. This was joined by one ounce each of Rittenhouse Rye and Pierre Ferrand 1840 Cognac, a quarter-ounce ofBénédictine, three dashes of Peychaud’s bitters and two dashes of Angostura bitters garnished with a lemon coin. It was considered a more delicate expression of the drink, in which the brandy was not bullied by the rye.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth blend (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir briefly.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon coin.

title: Frozen Jägerita
intro_philosophy:
Portland’s Jeffrey Morgenthaler first discovered the Jägerita in London back in 2008 and was instantly enamored by it. “It’s basically an amaro sour, which is a type of drink I really love,” he says. “So it only seemed natural to try it frozen.”

The recipe—perfected by Morganthaler’s former colleague, David Cordoba—delivers a playful and bitter take on a frozen Margarita. Pairing Jägermeister with sweet cointreau, lime and syrup, the Jägerita makes for an unexpectedly sophisticated frozen drink.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender.
2. Add ice, about six ounces crushed.
3. Blend until smooth.
4. Pour into a glass and garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Pisco Bee’s Knees
intro_philosophy: At Loma in Providence, Rhode Island (one of our Best New Bars of 2025), the drink menu has two sections. One comprises house cocktails like the#14, and the other is a list of rotating featured spirits available neat or in a pared-back drink that lets the star ingredient shine. This recipe, from the latter section, highlights Suyo’s Italia Pisco, a floral and “muscat-like” expression, according to co-owner Leishla Maldonado, who chose theBee’s Kneesformat because “rich honey syrup adds warmth, balancing the citrus without overpowering the Pisco’s elegance.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce rich honey syrup (2:1, honey to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe, then garnish with a de-seeded lemon wheel.

title: The Victorian
intro_philosophy: This cocktail is a warm-weather take on theBlack Manhattan, a modern classic riff on the Manhattan that subs Averna for sweet vermouth. In Tammy Bouma’s recipe, that Averna is replaced bypineapple amarofor a tropical twist.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a glass over a big cube, then garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Uncle Al
instructions: 1. Combine the gin, lemon juice, pisco, sherry, orgeat, and thyme in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Strain into a coupe and garnish with the dehydrated blood orange wheel.

title: Bee’s Knees
intro_philosophy: A twist on the Gin Sour, this shaken and strained mix of gin, honey, and lemon juice is thought to have bubbled up duringProhibitionin the United States, when questionable bootlegged spirits needed masking in the flavor department. The cutesy name is an idiom that developed—along with other, less-appetizing phrases such as “the flea’s eyebrows,” and “the cat’s whiskers.” The recent fascination with old-timey things has adjusted the spotlight on this simple, refreshing drink once again.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  honey syrup (2:1, honey: water, see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon peel or lemon wheel.

title: Avocado Margarita
intro_philosophy: Since avocado is a lush, buttery ingredient, it has a particular affinity for agave spirits and shines in drinks like the Avocado Margarita from Houston’s Better Luck Tomorrow. It’s blended with agave nectar, lime juice and salt to form a syrup that’s then shaken with tequila and the bar’s signature blend of Persian and Key lime juices.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Pueblo Viejo
3/4 ounce margarita juice blend (50:50 Persian and Key lime juice)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Garnish with avocado leaf, avocado ball and a pink Himalayan sea salt rim.

title: J & Tony’s Kold Brew Americano
intro_philosophy: J & Tony’s Discount Cured Meats and Negroni Warehousehas served the Kold Brew Americano, a mashup of the Americano cocktail and the Americano espresso drink, for years. “The combination of cold brew and bitter liqueur with a touch of fresh lemon acts like an espresso and tonic: tangy, bittersweet, refreshing,” says bartender Anthony Schmidt, all lengthened by effervescent seltzer, “a necessary step, since we’re using such intense ingredients.”
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi di Torino
instructions: 1. Fill a Collins glass with ice. Add the first four ingredients and stir.
2. Top with seltzer, then garnish with half an orange wheel.

title: Pine Sudachi Spritz
intro_philosophy: Han Suk Cho spent her childhood in Korea, where she learned to makesol ip chung (sometimes written as solip-cha),traditional pine needle syrup, from her grandmother. “Chung” refers to the technique of making fruit-based and other types of syrups by packing the key ingredient in sugar and leaving the mixture to gradually ferment; the sugar draws out flavor while liquifying. Though traditionalsol ip chungtakes six months to brew, Cho has created a quick method that produces pine needle syrup in minutes rather than months. To those keen on foraging, she recommends temperate climate–grown spruce tips as the base, which are at their youthful peak in spring. For those looking for a less seasonally dependent recipe, pine needle tea, which is widely available online, can be subbed in. (See Editor’s Note below.) The syrup is then mixed with sudachi or yuzu juice and sparkling water for a refreshing nonalcoholic cocktail.
ingredients: 1 ounce pine needle syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. In a highball glass, combine the pine needle syrup and sudachi juice, add ice and briefly stir.
2. Top with sparkling water.

title: A Swallow’s Leave
intro_philosophy: Maiko describes her Old-Fashioned riff as “nutty, sweet and savory.” Inspired by the time of year when chestnuts ripen and birds fly away—typically in autumn—charred chestnuts and browned butter are used to fat-wash the bourbon, creating a rich backdrop for Japanese American flavors.
ingredients: 2 ounces  butter chestnut–infused Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon (see Editor’s Note)
3 dashes  adzuki bean–Angostura bitters (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in an Old-Fashioned glass, and stir with ice.
2. Flame the orange peel, then place in the glass.

title: Daiquiri #4
intro_philosophy: Also known as the Daiquiri Floridita, this refreshing blended Daiquiri variation is named for its renowned place of origin, the La Floridita bar in Havana, Cuba. It’s also known as the Hemingway Daiquiri, named for writer Ernest Hemingway, who was known to consume plenty of these at Floridita. Note: Some versions use grapefruit juice, but that’s the #3, not the #4, says Julio Cabrera.
instructions: 1. Blend all ingredients with a scoop of crushed ice for 15 seconds.
2. Pour into an 8 1/2-ounce coupe glass.
3. Serve with straws.

title: Burro Tropical
intro_philosophy: Nacho Jimenez describes his Burro Tropical as something of a Moscow Mule on island time; the tequila-rum base offers leagues more complexity than a vodka ever could, and you still get that unmistakable stab of fresh ginger flavor. The tang of Calpico, Jimenez adds, helps ensure the citrus and passion fruit don’t get lost, and lends the finished product a texture reminiscent of a pina colada, sans any oily heaviness.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a highball glass over ice.
3. Top with soda.
4. Garnish with mini donkey, cocktail umbrella and mint sprig.

title: Jusanya
intro_philosophy: Translated as “The Thirteenth Night,” Jusanya takes its name from a short story by Higuchi Ichiyō, the first woman to be published in Japan and an ancestor of Christian Suzuki. The drink, a spin on a dirty vodka Martini, combines sesame-washed fino sherry (in place of vermouth) with a housemade sesame brine, as well as sesame-infused bitters. According to Suzuki, sesame is the one ingredient that’s most evocative of his heritage, drawing from not only Japan, but also El Salvador, where sesame is central to the cuisine. “[Jusanya] is that perfect representation of how two completely different backgrounds can come together and create one homogeneous, beautiful poem,” says Suzuki.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sesame oil-washed fino sherry (see Editor's Note)
2 dashes orange sesame bitters (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: A Scented Stretch
intro_philosophy: “More than anything else, it just needs to have a good amount of complexity,” says bartender Greg Best of a successful aperitif. Best and his contemporaries boast impressive credentials for creating such recipes, having developed a series of highly compelling, low-alcohol drinks for Atlanta’s Ticonderoga Club. A Scented Stretch is one such drink. Built on a base of white rum, it gets its sweetness from honey syrup and St-Germain, and its acidity from lemon juice and a shot of crisp white wine. A splash of soda water and an aromatic sprig of Thai basil lengthen the cocktail without sacrificing flavor, making the drink a steady, low-proof “pace car cocktail” to keep your night cruising.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crisp white wine, preferably grüner veltliner or Sancerre
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients except the soda water in a Collins glass over crushed ice.
2. Add the soda water and stir gently.
3. Garnish with the salt, lemon wheel and Thai basil.

title: JP Fetherston’s Negroni
intro_philosophy: In our blind tasting of 20 Negronis from America’s top bartenders in 2017, JP Fetherston’s recipe rounded out the top three. Fetherston used more gin than the other two components, calling on one-and-one-quarter ounces of Fords gin, one ounce of Cocchi Vermouth di Torino and one ounce of Campari.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large cube.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Nightstand
intro_philosophy: Nathan McCarley-O’Neill’s take on a Calvados & Tonic gets an extra dose of herbal bitterness, courtesy of the addition of the gentian root–based French aperitif Suze, along with a dash of Pernod absinthe. “I wanted to create a highball that has a depth of flavor,” says McCarley-O’Neill. “And thanks to acidity found in the apples from Normandy used to make the Calvados, you also get a lot of texture.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Roger Groult 8 Year Calvados Pays d’Auge
2 3/4 to 3 ounces Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water
instructions: 1. Add the Calvados, Suze, saline solution and absinthe to a chilled highball glass over ice.
2. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water.
3. Lightly stir, and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Matcha Biz
intro_philosophy:
This green tea–based biz is used for the offbeat Matcha Colada, which has the unexpected inclusion of Green Chartreuse in it.

Try it in aPiña Colada,CoquitoorCool as Clarence.
ingredients: 4 parts matcha vanilla syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bottle, seal and store refrigerated for up to two weeks.

title: Frozen Sherry Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Following in the footsteps of thePiña Colada, which was given the frozen treatment in the 1950s, and theMargarita, which got slushed in the ‘70s, theSherry Cobbleris the latest drink to be tossed in the blender. Rob Kreuger’s three-ingredient version hews close to the simplicity of the original, but replaces the traditional garnish—fresh berries and mint—with a brandied cherry and an orange half-wheel.
ingredients: 1 ounce oleo saccharum, preferably Cocktail & Sons
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in blender with the crushed ice.
2. Blend until smooth and serve in a glass of your choice.
3. Garnish with an orange slice and a preserved cherry.

title: Sun Stealer
intro_philosophy: “Crème de cacao definitely has a kitsch factor,which can be good in small doses,”says Henry Prendergast, Beverage Director at Chicago’s Analogue. “I think [it’s]great tempered with something a bit more bitter and austere…where the acid can balance out the richness of the syrup.” In the Sun Stealer, Prendergast does just that by mixing cacao white with bracing gin and herbal Fernet Branca, plus a dose of sweet vermouth, for a rich yet balanced spiced cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Punt e Mes
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Serve up, garnished with a lemon twist.

title: Padang Swizzle
intro_philosophy: Named for the capital of West Sumatra, Indonesia, Zac Overman’s Padang Swizzle plays with traditional tiki flavors, but adds a European twist. Rum, grapefruit, lime and cinnamon—tiki staples—mingle together with smokey Scotch and rich, dry amontillado sherry underscore the spicy, tropical qualities of a classic Rum Swizzle and make it a tiki drink suitable for any season.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces amontillado sherry (preferably Lustau Los Arcos)
1/2 ounce aged rum (preferably English Harbour 5 year)
1/4 ounce Scotch, Islay (preferably Laphroaig 10-Year-Old Single Malt)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a pilsner or Collins glass.
2. Add crushed ice and swizzle using a swizzle stick or bar spoon.
3. Add more crushed ice, and garnish with a smoking cinnamon stick (carefully light using a match or lighter) speared through with a lime wheel.
4. Be sure to extinguish cinnamon stick before attempting to take a sip of your swizzle.

title: MacIntosh Plus
intro_philosophy: Garret Richard’s reinterpreted Appletini, named after the Vaporwave artist of the same name, was a serendipitous invention spawned when the bar was looking for ways to use shagbark hickory syrup, made in-house from bark foraged by co-ownerDave Arnold. The meaty, sweet, smokey syrup is combined with delicately perfumed apple eau-de-vie to whichclarified limeand saline are added for tang, brightness and texture. Carpano Bianco rounds things out, while green food coloring imparts a neon hue—a playful reference to the Appletini.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Carpano Bianco
2 ounces apple eau de vie, preferably Drouin Calvados La Blanche
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Death Cookies
intro_philosophy: “When people ask me for a shaken whiskey cocktail, I find that it’s important to not lose the flavor of the whiskey among the citrus or other components,” says Phil Olson. Here, he shakes High West Double Rye, a blend of young and old rye whiskies, withgénépy, honey and lemon and tops it all with sour beer and fresh thyme. The herbal flavors play off the young rye’s floral notes, while the honey brings out the sweetness of the older spirit.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rye, preferably High West Double Rye
Flanders sour red/brown ale, preferably Petrus Oud Bruin
instructions: 1. Add the whiskey, génépy, lemon juice and honey syrup to a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain over ice in an Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Top with beer and garnish with fresh thyme.

title: Picon Bière
intro_philosophy: The Picon Bière is France’s version of a shandy based on the now-obscure bitter orange liqueur, Amer Picon. For the most refreshing version, build a crisp beer (pilsner or kolsch are both good options) over homemade Picon and a handful of ice, and garnish with an orange wheel.
instructions: 1. Build in a Collins glass and garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Martinez
ingredients: 1 part red vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth
1 part dry vermouth, preferably Dolin de Chambéry Dry Vermouth
1/2 part orange Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand Dry Orange Curaçao
1/2 part Irish whiskey, preferably Green Spot Irish Whiskey
instructions: 1. Stir ingredients together in a mixing glass with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Green Emanuelle
intro_philosophy: Milo and Miguel Salehi’sGreen Emanuelle is an experiment in what they call “color as flavor.” Realizing that they had no green cocktails on their menu, they set out to capture the flavor of green in a synesthesiac combination of all of their favorite green ingredients, including cucumber, kiwi, Thai lime leaf and absinthe, layered atop vodka, elderflower liqueur and manzanilla sherry. The result is a bright, verdant cocktail that has become one of the most popular drinks of all time at The Beehive.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the soda water, in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a highball glass, top with soda water, and fill with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a cucumber slice and Thai lime leaf.

title: In the Name of the Moon
intro_philosophy: This drink is “like a Hot Toddy you can actually eat and sip,” says Sharon Yeung.Tang yuan(glutinous rice balls filled with black sesame) can be purchased frozen, then boiled just before serving in a sweet, spiked and spicy ginger broth.
ingredients: 3 ounces hot ginger broth (see Editor’s Note)
2 dashes Chinese licorice root tincture (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Heat tang yuan in boiling water until they float. Transfer to a small bowl.
2. In a separate container, combine hot ginger broth, brandy or whiskey, and licorice root tincture. Stir briefly, then pour over tang yuan.
3. Garnish with edible flowers and, if desired, toasted sesame seeds.

title: Pisco Sour
intro_philosophy:
This frothy sour made with pisco, lemon juice, simple syrup and egg white has roots in both the U.S. and Peru. The story goes that American-born Victor Morris moved to Peru in the early-20thcentury to work on the railroads but ended up opening a bar instead. He supposedly fashioned an antecedent of what we know as the Pisco Sour, using Peru’s local liquor and the sour template.

Photo originally published inBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Photo by Ed Anderson © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
ingredients: 1/2 a large or 1 small egg white
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry shake (shake without ice).
2. Add ice to the shaker and shake well.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with Angostura bitters.

title: Hateful 8
intro_philosophy: Benjamin Purvis and Collin Nicholas collaborated on this cocktail with the goal of creating a house blend of amari for Fools & Horses, featuring many of their favorite bottles. What they came away with is an eight-touch tour de force that lovers of Italy’s bitter bounty won’t be able to resist.
instructions: 1. Throw ingredients over ice about 10 times with the goal of introducing 2 ounces of water, or 50% of the content of the final drink.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.

title: Tico Kafés
intro_philosophy: Dark, foamy and unfiltered is how most Greeks take their coffee, but instead of the traditional Loumidis or Bravo grounds, this drink uses freshly-ground Costa Rican beans. Created by illustrator John Perry Yates for the 2014 World Cup match between Greece and Costa Rica, the Tico Kafés mixes the anise flavor of ouzo with coffee, similar to Italy’s caffè coretto alla sambuca.
instructions: 1. Add coffee, sugar and water to a Bikri (or a small pot) and boil until foamy.
2. Pour, unfiltered, into a coffee cup.
3. Add ouzo and stir.

title: MARTINI & ROSSI® Negroni
intro_philosophy: Supposedly named for Count Negroni, a sort of Italian royalty-meets-Wild West character, the Negroni is a punchier take on the Americano. Equal parts BOMBAY SAPPHIRE® gin, MARTINI & ROSSI Rubino Vermouth di Torino and Bitter Liqueur, it’s the juggernaut of the Italian cocktail world, and a quintessential way to celebrate aperitivo.
ingredients: 1 ounce  MARTINI & ROSSI Riserva Speciale Rubino Vermouth
1 ounce  MARTINI & ROSSI Riserva Speciale Bitter Liqueur
instructions: 1. Fill a tumbler with ice.
2. Pour the ingredients in and stir gently for dilution.
3. Add the orange wedge to garnish.

title: A Summer Sip
intro_philosophy: For this twist on the classic spritz, bartender Valentino Longo plays up the bergamot note in Italicus by leaning into his Florida surroundings. The bitter orange–like flavor is layered with a vermouth-fortified blood orange “sherbet” and grapefruit-spiked saline. A half-rim of salt mixed with dried blood orange peel adds the finishing citrusy touch.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  fortified blood orange sherbet (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Place blood orange salt on a small plate. Moisten half of the outer rim of a highball glass. Press moistened rim into the plate of salt. Shake off any excess.
2. Stir all ingredients with ice.
3. Strain into prepared highball glass with clear ice stick.
4. Top up with Prosecco, and gently stir.

title: Pins & Needles
intro_philosophy: A hybrid between aDaiquiriand a spritz, Alex Day’s Pins & Needles combines aromatic rhum agricole with sweet, flowery Lillet Rosé and old-school sweetener pineapple gum. (We recommend usingSmall Hand Foods‘ version.) Lime and Angostura bitters balance the drink with a tangy, bitter bite before getting topped with the requisite spritz of bubbly soda water.
ingredients: 1 ounce white rhum agricole, preferably La Favorite "Coeur de Canne"
instructions: 1. Add rhum, Lillet, pineapple gum, lime juice and bitters to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a wine glass over ice.
4. Top with soda water and garnish with a lime wheel and a pineapple wedge.

title: Le Veau d’Or Martini
intro_philosophy: At the reimagined Upper East Side bistro Le Veau d’Or—New York’s oldest French bistro—Sarah Morrissey has created a Martini for the ages. An austere combination of high-proof Old Raj gin alongsideGonzález Byass’ fino sherry–based La Copa Extra Seco vermouthand four dashes of orange bitters in a 5:1 ratio, this is a true gin lover’s Martini. The Old Raj and La Copa together are a savory match, and yield an especially dry Martini that gets an aromatic lift by way of the bitters, which arean all too frequent omission in the modern Martini. Here, they are essential. To top it off, Morrissey serves the drink with a highball “sidecar” that consists of the leftover, ginny “dirty ice” and an additional dose of the La Copa vermouth, topped with the exceptionally salty Spanish mineral water Vichy Catalan, and, finally, a lemon peel.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce González Byass La Copa Extra Seco fino sherry vermouth
instructions: 1. Add gin, vermouth and orange bitters to a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until chilled and strain into a Martini glass. Reserve the ice and set aside.
3. Express the lemon peel over the glass and reserve.

title: Beton
intro_philosophy: The Beton is a Czech cocktail starring Becherovka, a digestif made with the supposedly curative thermal spring waters from the northern Bohemian spa town of Karlovy Vary and a secret recipe of herbs; it tastes something like the essence of a coniferous forest. Some like to say it’s a Czech version of the Gin & Tonic.
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to a highball glass with ice.
2. Garnish with a lemon slice.

title: Harrison Ginsberg’s Martinez
intro_philosophy: A split base of sweet Old Tom and crisp London dry gins differentiates this Martinez from the classic Old Tom–only version. While similar to a Martini, this drink is somewhat richer, Harrison Ginsberg notes. “It could be an aperitif, a digestif,” he says. “It’s one of those cocktails that could go both ways.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
1 ounce London dry gin, preferably Tanqueray
1 ounce Old Tom gin, preferably Porter’s Tropical
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass or small coupe.
3. Garnish with the lemon twist.

title: Kir Royale
intro_philosophy: While any cocktail can, with proper treatment, become a royale, rarely does the sparkling addendum outshine its classic forebear. That isn’t the case, however, with the Kir Royale, easily the most well-known in this school of drinks. Born in the 19th century as a bubbly alternative to the French aperitif cocktail, the Kir (which is made withcassisand still white wine), the Kir Royale has succeeded in becoming a popular menu item in its own right rather than an afterthought.
instructions: 1. Pour cassis into a fluted glass and top with Champagne.

title: Gunshop Fizz
intro_philosophy: The Gunshop Fizz was the signature cocktail of the originalRogue Cocktails, self-published in 2009 by Maks Pazuniak and Kirk Estopinal, two bartenders atCure in New Orleans. It was the drink that first caught everyone’s attention, and no wonder. The improbable Gunshop Fizz uses a full two ounces of Peychaud’s bitters, which is usually used only in dashes. It’s enough to make the same drink’s use of Sanbitter, a bright-red bitter Italian soda, seem almost dull. The rest of the drink includes lemon juice, simple syrup, strawberries, cucumbers and several twists of orange and grapefruit. It was a through-the-looking glass take on the Pimm’s Cup recipe at Chicago’s Violet Hour, where Estopinal had worked.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the Sanbitter in a mixing glass. Muddle and set aside for two minutes.
2. Add ice to mixing glass and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
4. Top with Sanbitter.
5. Garnish with cucumber slice.

title: Cynar Julep
intro_philosophy:
Parched one hot July day, Employees Only owner Dushan Zaric started messing around with some Ruby Red grapefruits he had on the bar, determined to refresh himself. “I wanted a long drink that I could enjoy with food,” he says. He ended up going the julep route, building on Cynar instead of bourbon. Still missing one note, Zaric raided chef Julia Jaksic’s spice rack, “started sniffing around,” and landed on the savory Moroccan spice blend ras el hanout, whose flavor Zaric loved as a stark complement to the mint.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Put the mint leaves in a julep tin and use a muddler to gently crush them.
2. Add the Cynar, soda water, grapefruit juice, simple syrup, and lemon juice, then fill the tin with crushed ice.
3. Swizzle to mix, then garnish with the mint sprig and a sprinkle of ras el hanout.

title: Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy:
The cocktail originally served at the Soho Brasserie on Old Compton Street was an off-menu special Dick Bradsell bestowed on favored friends and colleagues. There was no coffee liqueur in the drink at the time; only, as the original name—Vodka Espresso—would indicate, shots of vodka and espresso, tied together by a little simple syrup. The mixture was served on the rocks and topped with the now-iconic garnish of three espresso beans.

By the end of the 1990s, it was more commonly served in a coupe and traveled under a new name: Espresso Martini.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe.
4. Garnish with three coffee beans.

title: Marley’s Ghost
intro_philosophy: One would be inclined to think that the Marley’s Ghost was inspired by the eponymous apparition fromA Christmas Carol.But upon closer observation the layering of three types of Jamaican rum suggests it’s more likely an ode to the godfather of reggae, Bob Marley. No matter. This strong Manhattan-like cocktail from Pip Hanson of Minneapolis’sMarvel Bar, is still a winter-warmer with its rum medley and supporting spice from sweet vermouth and Cardamaro.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit coin.

title: Licorice Hot Toddy
intro_philosophy: “A chef from Momofuku showed me that the faster you get from hot to cold, the less crystallization you get with the sugar,” explains John deBary. “It’s optional, but it’s a nice touch, especially if you need to use it right away,” he notes of the ginger syrup that lends a spicy tang to this non-alcoholic take on a toddy.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce black pepper syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the tea bags, ginger syrup and black pepper syrup in a mug, then fill with boiling water.
2. Let steep for 4 to 5 minutes then discard the tea bags.
3. Garnish with a lemon wedge.

title: Picon Punch
intro_philosophy: San Francisco’s15 Romolois housed in a building erected in 1912, which served as a Basque family restaurant from the 1940s until the 1990s. Neighbors that once frequented the restaurant will stop into 15 Romolo for a Picon Punch, known as “the National drink of the Basques,” which is based on the obscure French orange bitter, Amer Picon. Because Amer Picon is no longer commercially available, bartender Andrew Meltzer created his own version using Ramazzotti amaro, orange curaçao and gentian liqueur.
instructions: 1. In a small cocktail or Irish coffee glass, combine Picon, grenadine and ice, and stir briefly.
2. Top with seltzer and float brandy on top.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Astoria #2
intro_philosophy: The Astoria #2 is Austin bartender Darren Scott’s citrusy play on aBrooklyn(rye, Amer Picon, maraschino and dry vermouth) which is itself a play on aManhattan. What it lacks in dry vermouth, it makes up for in Amer Picon, a bitter orange liqueur that Scott makes in-house atlaV.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Cherry Bounce
intro_philosophy: The Cherry Bounce has been a stalwart at Jonny Raglin’s San Francisco Bar, Comstock Saloon, for more than a decade. According to Raglin, a regular told him about a midcentury Hollywood restaurant that served a house cocktail called the Cherry Bounce, which contained both cherry brandy and Champagne. He used this as a starting point for his bourbon-based sour sweetened with cherry syrup (left over from Griottines brandied cherries) topped with sparkling wine. “My online research for Cherry Bounce led me to the Colonial bottled version and a recipe from Martha Washington. I was more than intrigued and set out to combine both ideas,” he says.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce brandied cherry syrup (Raglin uses the liquid from Griottines brandied cherries)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the sparkling wine in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a flip glass over a single large ice cube.
3. Top with sparkling wine.
4. Garnish with brandied cherries.

title: Arroz Con Leche
intro_philosophy: “Every time I would go over to my grand parents’ house they would make rice pudding,” recallsDemi Natoli. “There was always just a giant stick of cinnamon in there and the best part was licking the little crispy parts at the bottom of the pot.” To mimic the flavor of this dessert, Natoli incorporates Saigon cinnamon and coconut syrups atop a rum base, as well as amontillado sherry which provides a certain nuttiness to the drink. In a cheeky nod to her favorite part of the dessert, she garnishes the drink with a bite-size rice crispy treat. “It all rounds out to be just like a beautiful flip cocktail,” says Natoli.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce Barbados rum, preferably Real McCoy 5 Year
1/2 ounce overproof aged rum, preferably Plantation O.F.T.D.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with rice crispy treat.

title: Turmeric Blend
intro_philosophy: This housemade sachet blend can be used to infuse both hot and cold drinks. Steep this gently spiced sachet in hot milk for three minutes to create a “golden milk”-style drink, which can be mixed with aged rum and honey. The blend works equally well in cold drinks.
ingredients: 2 cardamom pods, crushed (or 2 pinches of cardamom powder)
instructions: 1. Place all ingredients in a tea bag or square of cheesecloth and close.

title: Tropical Itch
intro_philosophy: Harry Yee invented theTropical Itchcocktail in the late 1950s while he was running the bar at the Hawaiian Village Hotel on Honolulu’s Waikiki Beach. The original recipe called for bourbon, rums, passion fruit, Curaçao and Angostura bitters. At Tern Club in Knoxville, Jocelyn Morin and Ryan Shanley have resurrected the drink and dried it out. Rye stands in for bourbon, allspice dram replaces Curaçao, and lemon and pineapple add extra layers of flavor. The traditional back scratcher garnish from Yee’s original remains, catching the eye of many a curious customer.
ingredients: 1 ounce bonded rye, such as Rittenhouse
3/4 ounce Jamaican rum, such as Blackwell or Hamilton Pot Still Black
1/2 ounce 151 Demerara rum, such as Lemon Hart
1/2 ounce rich Demerara syrup (2:1, Demerara sugar to water)
1/4 ounce allspice dram, such as St. Elizabeth
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with crushed ice.
2. Shake and dump into a Hurricane glass.
3. Position a banana leaf in the glass and top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a straw, pineapple wedge and a back scratcher.

title: Blood Orange Margarita
intro_philosophy: When blood oranges appear in the midst of winter, it’s a bright spot for all citrus cocktails in the canon—especially the Margarita. Substituting ruby red blood orange juice for lime and adding a splash of rosemary-infused Cointreau turns this drink from a summer classic into a winter beauty.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice. (Salt rim optional.)
4. Garnish with a blood orange wheel.

title: Lucy Liu
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn’s Sama Street, Asian-inspired cocktails spotlight ingredients like pandan, galangal and yuzu. The bar’s Lucy Liu, a creamy, fruit-forward drink, puts a novel spin on the“spicy, with tequila”template: Rather than using a chile tincture or infusion, the bar makes a chile oil–washed blanco tequila that brings a tingling sensation and a rounded mouthfeel. The ingredient fits well into tropical drinks, like this one, but it is also versatile in agave classics like Margaritas and Palomas.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces chile oil–washed blanco tequila (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce Filipino rum, preferably Don Papa
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a Hurricane glass and top with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with an orchid.

title: Loser
intro_philosophy:
To explore the overlap between the worlds of drinks and music, we challenged bartenders to translate a song of their choice from a given era into cocktail form. Here, Brother Cleve, formerly of cocktail lounge band, The Combustibles, takes on grunge.

In creating this drink, Cleve explains: “I thought of Tad Doyle [lead singer of TAD], his roots of Ireland and the Northwest. Fortunately, the fine folks at Oregon’s Ransom distillery partnered withDavid Wondrichto concoct a lost style of making Irish pot still whiskey utilizing Oatmeal in the mash along with the usual suspects, malted and unmalted barley. The end result is big, bold, uncompromising and somewhat rude. Add some beef broth for beef-cake-y-ness, espresso liqueur in another nod to the area,Jägermeister, because, why not, and a bit of Bittermens Hellfire, and you’ve got a veritable homage. And, for a bit of sweetening, well, a band that recorded a song called ‘Jack Pepsi’ probably doesn’t want a different Cola in their drink. I’m just guessing, of course.”
ingredients: 2 ounces whiskey, preferably Ransom The Emerald 1865
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a coffee cup, add ice and stir.
2. Garnish with a piece of beef jerky or a Slim Jim.

title: Roasted, Spiced, Salted Banana Syrup
intro_philosophy: Banana isn’t just for tropical-leaningDaiquirisandPisco Sourriffs. Steeped with mashed roasted banana, this brown sugar-based syrup evokes the deep caramel notes of bananas foster in liquid form with a whiff of warm cinnamon spice. The viscous, almost salted toffee-like blend is built for darker rum-based concoctions or rich eggnogs, although it would also lend a sweeter foil to mildly bitter vermouths.
ingredients: 1/2 teaspoon ground royal or Saigon cinnamon
instructions: 1. Preheat oven to 350°F.
2. In a small bowl with a fork or spoon smash bananas just to break up and toss with ¼ cup of the brown sugar, cinnamon and salt.
3. Spread banana mash onto a parchment or silicone lined baking sheet and roast in the oven for 20 to 25 minutes.
4. Rotate pan and toss banana and sugar together every 10 minutes. Bake until the sugar around edges caramelizes and the mash darkens.
5. Meanwhile make your syrup base: bring water to a boil and dissolve remaining ¾ cup brown sugar and remove from heat.
6. Remove pan with hot roasted banana mash from the oven, transfer all contents to the pot with your syrup base and stir well to combine.
7. Let cool and refrigerate overnight to infuse.
8. Next day, remove the container from the fridge and strain to remove banana solids. Best if used within 1 week.

title: Enhanced Whiskey Cocktail
intro_philosophy:
Elijah Craig Bourbon’s annual Old-Fashioned Week returns for its second year supporting the Restaurant Workers’ Community Foundation, October 15-24.Sign up your bar or restaurantto participate by featuring Elijah Craig Old-Fashioned riffs on your menu.

Negranza specifically designed this Old-Fashioned variation as a way to reduce waste from the large amount of discarded citrus that a bar like his generates. He creates an oleo saccharum–style spiced citrus syrup by infusing peels from juiced lemons that would otherwise have been trashed. (He advises peeling the citrus before juicing it.) Combined with Elijah Craig bourbon and black lemon bitters, the resulting bright and slightly bitter cocktail has what Negranza describes as “some extra zing.”
ingredients: 2 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
1 barspoon  spiced citrus syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with lemon twist and spray absinthe over the top.

title: Gari Hai
intro_philosophy: Gari Hai is a spin on the shochu-based highball known aschu hai, which originated in post–World War II Osaka. At the time, whisky was limited and expensive, but shochu could be made from distilling various ingredients—such as sweet potato, rice, barley, buckwheat, sugar cane and even shiso—and proved to be a more affordable alternative that still quenched the thirst of Japanese drinkers. Today, a canned chu hai can be found on the low end for $1 at akonbini(convenience store) and runs an average of $3 to $5 at an izakaya or tachinomiya. The recipe is uncomplicated and malleable (try it with whiskey, for instance), hinging only on access to pickled ginger, something easily attained at just about any supermarket.
ingredients: 6 to 7 ounces soda water, to top
instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice, then pour in the shochu.
2. Top with soda water.
3. Garnish with a large pinch of pickled ginger atop the ice.

title: Egg Sour
intro_philosophy: This appears in the book’s “Morning” section ofThe Stork Club Bar Book, and is listed as a “less lethal and drastic cure” for what may be ailing you when you wake up. It’s creamy, rich and true to name in flavor. We recommend shaving some nutmeg over top for a fragrant garnish, and/or dash or two of bitters. But be judicious with the latter, as they can easily overpower the drink.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing tin.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Old King Cole Martini
intro_philosophy: The signature Martini at Brooklyn’s Maison Premiere is extravagant in its simplicity. Prepared tableside, the drink combines high-proof Old Raj gin pulled from the freezer, which adds body and backbone, and Bordiga extra-dry vermouth, which is, well, extra-dry, yielding a drink that has what William Elliott describes as “ultimate crunch”: that signature bite that only a Martini can deliver.
ingredients: 3 ounces gin, preferably Old Raj 110-proof gin (from the freezer)
1/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Bordiga Vermouth Extra Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir for approximately 45 seconds.
2. Strain into a Martini glass and serve with a sidecar of garnishes, including three skewered Castelvetrano olives and a manicured lemon twist.

title: The St-Germain Spritz
intro_philosophy:
“An aperitif in France is not just a drink—it’s part of our culture,” saysSt-Germainglobal ambassador Camille Vidal, who grew up in Nîmes, in the south of France. “If the happy hour celebrates the end of the day, the aperitif celebrates the beginning of the night.”

The St-Germain Cocktail, the classic spritz variation fueled by the iconic elderflower liqueur, embodies this spirit of low-alcohol conviviality prevalent throughout Europe. Light, floral and refreshing, it’s a warm-weather go-to, easy in both execution and drinkability.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Stir, then garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Lamb’s Wool
intro_philosophy: The Lamb’s Wool finds its beginnings as a wassail—a hot, mulled cider thought to have originated in England’s West Country—and takes its name from the Celtic pagan festival,La Mas Ubal,the Day of the Apple. Traditionally a spiced drink made with porter, New York’s Dead Rabbit updates the classic just slightly with the addition of Irish whiskey for a spiritous, not-so-sweet riff on the Whiskey Toddy.
ingredients: 3 ounces  spiced apple purée (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce spiced sugar syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a briki and heat to a boil.
2. When bubbling hot, pour into a porcelain mug and garnish with fresh nutmeg.

title: Old Pal
intro_philosophy: Harry MacElhone of Harry’s Bar in Paris credited his “old pal,” journalist William “Sparrow” Robertson, with the inspiration for this drink. As the sports editor for theNew York Heraldin Paris, Robertson frequented Harry’s place enough to receive mention in his 1922ABC of Mixing Cocktails.The Old Pal is essentially aBoulevardier, another drink by MacElhone, but drier thanks to mix of rye, Campari and dry vermouth in the place of sweet.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon or an orange peel.

title: Cricket Ball
intro_philosophy:
I came across this understated aperitif at theRed Catin the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan. So named because the drink’s hue matches the color of a traditional cricket ball, the drink also matches the red décor of Jimmy Bradley’s popular restaurant. What first attracted me to this drink were the bitters, of course, but also the use of Lillet Rouge, the too-often-overlooked sister spirit of the more popular Lillet Blanc. The version at the Red Cat calls for Angostura, but I’ve swapped in candy-colored Peychaud’s Bitters to continue the red theme and Fee Brothers Rhubarb Bitters for an unexpected sour note that cuts through the prosecco bubbles.”

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Drop the sugar cube into the bottom of a Champagne flute and douse with both of the bitters.
2. Add the Lillet Rouge, top off with chilled prosecco and stir.
3. Garnish with the lemon twist.

title: Maydan’s Southside
intro_philosophy: At Maydan in Washington, D.C., beverage director Drew Hairston’s nonalcoholic take on the classic Southside recipe reinforces the herbal flavor of zero-proof spirit Seedlip Garden 108 with a housemade mint syrup.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Maydan mint syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig and dehydrated lime wheel.

title: I Am Keith Hernandez
intro_philosophy: At new Upper East Side cocktail bar Jeremy’s, bar manager Ricardo Echeverri’s take on a dirty Martini swaps the expected gin or vodka for San Bartolo Mezcal. In homage to the briny classic, this version is shaken rather than stirred and garnished with a coppa-stuffed olive. The drink is named after the iconic Mets player and guest star onSeinfeld, Keith Hernandez.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice, and vigorously shake.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with an olive and smoked coppa on a pick.

title: Sazerac
intro_philosophy: Born in the mid-1800s at the Sazerac Coffee House in New Orleans, the Sazerac has been a beloved stalwart since. While some claim the drink was originally made with Cognac, that theory has largely been discarded as of late. The Sazerac’s alluring aromatic intensity—anise, peppery rye and and spiced Peychaud’s bitters—make this one of the most beloved drinks in the canon of classic cocktails.
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, add a dash of absinthe and swirl to coat. Discard.
2. In another rocks or mixing glass, add simple syrup, rye, bitters and ice and stir well.
3. Strain into the prepared rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an expressed lemon peel.

title: Christine Wiseman’s Frozen Margarita
intro_philosophy: Third place in ourfrozen Margarita blind tastingwent to Christine Wiseman, whose recipe ticked all the boxes: sweet, acidic and tequila-forward. Wiseman calls for a full two ounces of tequila (she prefers Ocho Plata), a half-ounce more than the other winners, alongside a half-ounce of Cointreau, an ounce of agave nectar, two ounces of lime juice and a Tajín-salt rim. Bartender Brian Evans deemed it the “most intense flavor-wise” in the group, while Channing Centeno found it to be perfectly “juicy.”
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with spicy salt.
2. Add all ingredients to a blender with 2 cups of ice, and blend to combine.
3. Pour into the prepared glass and garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Diamondback
intro_philosophy: The Diamondback is a 20th-century cocktail featured in the 1951 bookBottoms Upby Ted Saucier, who credits its creation to the Diamondback Lounge at the Lord Baltimore Hotel. The hard-hitting cocktail, which saw a revival in the cocktail renaissance, is a simple mix of rye, applejack and yellow Chartreuse. While the original version called for shaking the drink, more modern iterations tend to stir the cocktail and serve it up.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled glass.

title: The Last Frontier
intro_philosophy: A riff on theAlaska, the Last Frontier from New York bar Overstory adds manzanilla sherry, Cocchi Americano and verjus blanc to the template for brightness. The gin base is split between a beeswax-infused London dry gin and a satsuma-based Japanese gin.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce gin, preferably Komasa Sakurajima Komikan
3/4 ounce beeswax-infused London dry gin (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce manzanilla sherry, preferably La Cigarrera
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until properly diluted and chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or Martini glass.
3. Garnish with an orange peel coin.

title: Eric Alperin’s Vieux Carré
intro_philosophy: Eric Alperin, of The Varnish in Los Angeles, took third place in our blind Vieux Carré tasting with his version, which follows a more spirit-forward formula than the original: three-quarters of an ounce of Cocchi Vermouth di Torino, one ounce each of Old Overholt Rye and Pierre Ferrand 1840 Cognac, a quarter-ounce of Bénédictine and two dashes each of Peychaud’s and Angostura bitters. It was deemed “super expressive,” rye-forward and, crucially, “not too thin.” The drink was garnished with a lemon twist and a cherry, the latter the judges’ only minor quibble. It was balanced and robust, and did not shy away from the heavy-hitting nature of the original.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
instructions: 1. Measure all ingredients into a rocks glass.
2. Add a large ice cube and stir seven times.
3. Express the oils of a lemon twist over the surface of the drink. Insert a fresh lemon lemon twist and a cherry.

title: White Zombie
intro_philosophy: The White Zombie matches all of its precursor’s requirements—deceivingly strong, complicated recipe, a layered base—but it’s composed entirely of white spirits. Zac Overman ofFort Defiance, a neighborhood café in Red Hook, Brooklyn, retooled Don the Beachcomber’s 1930s classic with pisco, white rum and gin instead of three or four different rums. His formula hews tightly to the traditionalZombieblueprint with Don’s Mix (grapefruit and cinnamon syrup), falernum, absinthe and lime, but with the aromatic addition of maraschino liqueur and passionfruit. A potent staple at Fort Defiance’s weekly Thursday tiki night, the White Zombie is probably best handled with Don’s original rule: one per person, per visit.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Pour shaker contents into a tiki mug.
4. Garnish with an orange wheel, a mint sprig and an umbrella.

title: Appellation Cooler
intro_philosophy: With a clean base of dry muscadet, the Appellation Cooler becomes a sort of white sangria with the additions of Cocchi Americano and basil-infused Dolin Blanc, a white sweet vermouth. A splash of apricot liqueur and the clean aroma of cucumber round out this white wine cocktail. Though not part of the original recipe, we like to spritz-ify it with a splash of soda.
ingredients: 2 ounces muscadet wine, or any dry white wine
1 ounce Dolin Blanc, basil-infused (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a wine glass.
2. Add ice and stir.
3. Garnish with thin slices of seedless cucumber.

title: The Handsome Grandson
intro_philosophy: At Ramona, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Scott Schneider shakes together gin, lime juice and savory homemade bay leaf syrup with fresh basil. Topped with soda water and pomegranate juice, it makes for a refreshing, fall-ready cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce bay leaf syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water and pomegranate juice, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Hurricane or Zombie glass.
3. Pack the glass with crushed or pebble ice.
4. Top with a splash each of soda water, then pomegranate juice.
5. Garnish with a bay leaf.

title: Hot and Cold Pisco Sour
intro_philosophy: This drink pays homage to an experimental version of the drink created by chef José Andrés during his time with Ferrán Adrià at Spain’s El Bulli, a pioneering space for techniques now regarded as molecular gastronomy/mixology. Liquid nitrogen transforms pisco, lime, sugar and water into a chilled, sorbetlike mixture, while the frothy egg white cap is translated asespuma, a warm, mousse-like topping.
ingredients: 3 ounces liquid nitrogen, more as needed
4 ounces Pisco Sour Liquid Portion (see Editor's Note)
2 ounces Warm Pisco Sour Espuma (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Pour about 3 ounces of liquid nitrogen into a medium double-walled metal bowl.
2. Slowly add 4 ounces (per serve) of the Pisco Sour Liquid Mixture while whisking constantly.
3. Fill a chilled coupe glass halfway with soft-frozen Pisco Sour.
4. Top with about 2 ounces of warm Pisco Sour Espuma.
5. Garnish with 4 grates of lime zest.

title: Frank Sullivan
intro_philosophy: Also listed as the Odd McIntyre and the “Hoop La!” inThe Savoy Cocktail Book, theFrank Sullivanis a cousin of the Corpse Reviver No. 2 that swaps out the gin in favor of brandy. At Dario in Minneapolis, Stephen Rowe is reviving the drink—with a couple of significant alterations. First, he subbed in Creole shrubb for the traditional triple sec, which adds spice, bitter orange and vanilla to the equation. Then, he removed the quinquina and added blanc vermouth for a lighter mouthfeel.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Cognac, such as Renault VSOP
3/4 ounce Creole shrubb, such as Hamilton Petite Shrubb
3/4 ounce  blanc vermouth, such as C. Comoz
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe over a large ice cube.

title: Martini 1888
ingredients: 6 parts red vermouth, preferably Martini Rosso Vermouth
7/20 part orange Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand Dry Orange Curaçao
instructions: 1. Stir the liquid ingredients together in a mixing glass with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
2. Garnish with the twist of lemon.

title: Hard Sell
intro_philosophy: The Hard Sell is an easy sell in Chicago, where it was born in 2009. And Chicago largely remains its audience, probably owing to the fact that bartender Brad Bolt loaded the gin drink with 3/4 ounce of the treasured local poison, Malört.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Express a grapefruit peel over the surface of the drink and discard.

title: Coconut Oil–Washed Negroni
intro_philosophy: Inspired by theNegroni Riposatofrom Federico Pasian, this take on the aperitivo classic uses a genius coconut-washing technique for a fast track to tropical flavor. Like any freezer cocktail, this recipe can be made with or without dilution in the batch. If diluting, we suggest using coconut water; its salty tones balance out the inherent sweetness of the drink and complement the subtle flavor imparted by the coconut oil-lined bottle.
instructions: 1. Prep an ice bath or line a tray with an even layer of crushed ice.
2. Heat the coconut oil until liquid, then pour into a 375 milliliter bottle.
3. Pour the rest of the ingredients into it. Shake then let sit for a few hours.
4. Place the bottle on its side onto the ice or ice bath and spin until the oil inside is solidified, approximately 1 to 2 minutes.
5. To serve, pour a few ounces through a fine strainer into a chilled cocktail glass if the drink is pre-diluted, or serve on the rocks if it isn’t.

title: Sidereal
intro_philosophy: “Creating a good drink that sits in that ‘fruity, but not too sweet’ pocket is like writing a good pop song if you’re a well-respected artist” explain Honeycut’s Dave Fernie and Mary Bartlett. It’s a matter of creating broad appeal while still pushing conventional boundaries. The LA-based duo’s Sidereal does exactly that, with a tropical strawberry, Thai basil and coconut cream base that’s shaken with three types of rum.
ingredients: 1 ounce rum, preferably Flor de Cana 7 year
1/2 ounce  sherry, preferably Lustau East India Solera
1 1/2 ounces strawberry, Thai basil and coconut cream base (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing tin and shake with pebble ice.
2. Pour the drink into a pilsner glass and top with more pebbled ice.
3. Garnish with a halved strawberry.

title: Metexa
intro_philosophy: The recipe for theMetexafirst appeared in theCafé Royal Cocktail Book, which was published in 1930s London. Here, Jamie Boudreau of Seattle’s Canon updates the drink for the modern palate. Its unusual combination of Lillet (here, swapped out for Cocchi Americano), tequila and Swedish punsch makes for an uncommonly light and pleasant stirred drink, especially with Boudreau’s addition of grapefruit oil.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Stir with ice.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Remember the Alimony
intro_philosophy:
This is one of the best of the modern sherry cocktails out there. Dan Greenbaum created it in 2012 at the short-lived New York City cocktail bar The Beagle. It continues to be served—but maybe only because I keep ordering it and writing about it.

Reprinted with permission from3-Ingredient Cocktails: An Opinionated Guide to the Most Enduring Drinks in the Cocktail Canon,by Robert Simonson, copyright © 2017. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the orange twist in a rocks glass filled with one large piece of ice.
