2. Stir until chilled, about 30 seconds.
3. Express an orange twist over the drink and drop into the glass.

title: Soulmate
intro_philosophy: The light, nutty profile of the Glen Moray Elgin instantly had Tiffanie Barriere craving a Manhattan, but with a twist. She swapped out the traditional sweet vermouth by splitting oloroso sherry and Bénédictine, enhancing the drink with earthy, honey elements to balance out the oak from the Scotch. A splash of elderflower liqueur adds a light, floral sweetness, keeping this spirited cocktail approachable.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces  Glen Moray Speyside 12-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky (Elgin Heritage)
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until chilled, and double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated orange or lemon peel. dehydrated orange or lemon wheel

title: Box Lunch
intro_philosophy: Billy Sunday in Chicago is known for its regular use of oddball ingredients like kola nut, yerba mate and new American spirits. In this play on a boxed lunch milk jug, bartender Alex Bachman mixes together three unexpected parts—the lightly bitter Italian aperitivo genepi, palo cortado sherry and oatmeal-infused goat’s milk—to make a creamy, funky, ice-cold milkshake not unlike a savory-sweet bowl of morning oatmeal.
ingredients: 3 ounces oatmeal-infused goat's milk (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and strain into a glass bottle or rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a candy cane straw.

title: Bobby Heugel’s Margarita
intro_philosophy:
“What we wanted to do with this [drink] was to create a very solid, everyday Margarita,” says Bobby Heugel, who began workshopping the cocktail with Alba Huerta prior to opening theirmezcaleria,The Pastry War, back in 2013. At the time, Heugel—who also ownsAnviland the recently openedTongue-Cut Sparrow, among others—was in the process of building a tightlycurated list of agave spirits. So it was only natural that, for his own version of the drink, he’d build on the spirit-forward template of Julio Bermejo’s originalTommy’s Margarita, which the San Francisco bartender invented back in the 1990s.

Heugel’s version calls on blanco tequila, plus a combination of both Key and Persian lime juices, and employs a “shake and dump” technique, in which the cocktail is shaken and poured—ice and all—into a salt-rimmed glass.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Pueblo Viejo
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Pour ingredients (including ice) into a rocks glass with a salt rim.

title: Suppressor #M
intro_philosophy: This sangria-like suppressor from Atlanta’s Chris Molnar starts with a rich foundation of madeira and moscatel, cut by the bitterness of the gentiane-infused French aperitif liqueur, Salers. A topping of sparkling wine transforms this into something of a throwback spritz.
ingredients: 1 ounce  madeira, preferably Rare Wine Co. Charleston Sercial Madeira
instructions: 1. Stir first three ingredients and strain into a sherry tulip.
2. Top with sparkling wine.
3. Express and discard lemon peel over the top of the drink.

title: Si-Güey
intro_philosophy: This drink appears inRegarding Cocktails, written by late bar legend Sasha Petraske with Georgette Moger-Petraske.“Güeyis the colloquial Mexican Spanish way of referring to any person without using his name, andSí, Güey,was something Sasha and all the bartenders would say to one another at various points of the evening,” the book explains. Although the recipe specifically calls for “Islay whisky” as a shorthand for quality peated Scotch, it’s worth noting that peated Scotch is made in other regions, too.
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a whiskey glass, starting with the bitters and ending with the tequila.
2. Add one large ice cube and stir.
3. Top with a float of the whiskey.

title: Tiger Money
intro_philosophy: “This is definitely the weirdest drink I’ve put on the menu at Ticonderoga Club,” says Alec Bales of his shaken mixture of Paranubes Oaxacan rum, lemon juice, Drambuie and blueberry honey syrup. An unusual amalgam of ingredients, which even Bales admits is “not my normal speed,” the combination nevertheless works. “I had these four different things that all were not commonly used together, but when we mix them together in the right balance, it just created this really fun drink, almost like a Margarita,” he explains. “It’s one of the few drinks I’ve made that people come back and ask for years later.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Salsa y Pimienta
intro_philosophy: “I was taking inspiration from my grandma’s chili Verde for this cocktail,” saysBritt Foxof her combination of tequila, Cocchi Americano, muddledjalapeño and coriander seeds, topped with tonic. The result is a slightly vegetal, super bright and highly aromatic drink finished with a thin lime twist and cilantro bouquet.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Cocchi Americano or other blanc vermouth
instructions: 1. Muddle the jalapeño slices, coriander seeds and lime juice in a small tin or mixing pitcher.
2. Add vermouth and tequila to the muddled ingredients, and stir briefly to combine.
3. Combine tonic and the remainder of the mixed ingredients in an all purpose wine glass, add ice to fill and stir briefly to combine.
4. Garnish with a small bundle of cilantro tied with a thin lime twist.

title: Lemon-Lime & Bitters
intro_philosophy: A nearly nonalcoholic drink with a tradition rooted at the 19th hole of golf in Australia, the LLB is a simple mixture of lemon-lime soda and Angostura bitters. Eventually, the recipe was canned by Angostura into an RTD. This version eschews flavored soda for fresh juice, its zip and zing producing an ethereally breezy drink that showcases the stellar simplicity of a few everyday ingredients.
ingredients: Juice and zest of 3 limes, separated
Juice and zest of 3 lemons, separated
1 750 ml bottle of San Pellegrino or other sparkling water
instructions: 1. In a small bowl, steep the lime zest in the lime juice for 10 minutes. Repeat this process for the lemon zest and juice.

2. In a pitcher fitted with a small fine-mesh sieve, strain the lime juice and zest mixture, squeezing the pulp to ensure that all the liquid is removed from the zest. Repeat the process for the lemon zest and juice.
3. Add the simple syrup, bitters and sparkling water. Stir to combine. Pour into an ice-filled highball glass and garnish with a slice of citrus.

title: Mamadeta
intro_philosophy:
This sweet, subtly herbaceous, refreshing mixture of lemon granita, yellow Chartreuse and green Chartreuse is the signature drink ofthe Santa Tecla festivalin Tarragona, Spain.

During Santa Tecla, lemon granita is prepared in frozen-drink machines to be poured over Chartreuse, but at home you can makea simple granita in the freezerfor a close approximation. The drink is usually served in large, festival-branded cups, but this recipe has been scaled down to fit a standard highball or double rocks glass. The version here mirrors the low Chartreuse to granita ratio that is common at the festival, but feel free to experiment with different proportions.
instructions: 1. Pour the Chartreuse into a highball or large rocks glass and top with lemon granita.
2. Stir briefly to integrate until the mixture reaches a slushy consistency.
3. Serve with a wide straw.

title: Pisco Sour Brûlée
intro_philosophy: Chef Diego Muñoz of New York’s Popular and Cantina & Pisco Bar asked his bar team to play with both temperature and texture, resulting in the Pisco Sour Brûlée. Built on the blueprint of a traditional Pisco Sour, the drink gets a dessert-like boost from vanilla cardamom cordial, as well as torched caster sugar, which sits atop the cocktail’s fluffy egg white foam. Muñoz says the key to nailing this recipe is being mindful of the added dilution and carbonation, and therefore using an immersion blender or hand whisk rather than a cocktail shaker to create its foamy peaks.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Vanilla Cardamom Cordial  (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and blend with an immersion blender until very frothy.
2. Add one large, tempered cube of ice and shake until very cold.
3. Remove the ice with tongs and pour to the rim-level of a sour or coupe glass.
4. Express the orange peel to flatten the bubbles, and gently add the remainder of the drink and foam from the tin to create a shallow domed top to the drink.
5. Dust evenly with caster sugar, then torch with a handheld blowtorch, starting in the center and working around to the rim.

title: Sana Sana
intro_philosophy: In this riff on theSaturn, Demi Natoli once again draws on the flavors of her family’s dinner table to upend expectations. “Mangoes are a staple in the Cuban household,” says Natoli, “it’s a snack, it’s usually part of your dinner,” she says of one of the more prominent flavors in the drink, which she substitutes in place of passion fruit. “And then there’s also garlic—there’s not any kind of dish that doesn’t have garlic in it,” says Natoli, who incorporates roasted garlic into a house-made falernum for a subtle savory twist. “It’s still like something that’s familiar to the guests, but it’s not something that they’ve necessarily had before,” she says.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce navy strength gin, preferably Hayman's Royal Dock
3/4 ounce mango puree, preferably Perfect Puree
1 barspoon allspice dram, preferably St. Elizabeth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in Collins glass or tiki mug and fill with crushed ice.
2. Swizzle the ingredients until the drink is properly chilled.
3. Garnish with mint and an edible orchid.

title: ZZ’s Pineapple Cocktail
intro_philosophy: At ZZ’s Clam Bar in New York, Thomas Waugh serves some of the city’s most inventive (and tactile) drinks. This cocktail is served in a spectacular and hefty vintage, brass pineapple mounded with cobbled ice and garnished with a drift of aromatic chamomile powder and flowers. Waugh uses a base ofSt. George Terroir Ginfrom Alameda, California for its sage-forward flavor in tandem with a sweet-tart mix of house made limoncello, fresh lime and pineapple juices and organic sugar cane syrup. A Collins glass will do if you don’t own a brass pineapple, but sourcing one of these magnificent vessels is certainly worth the hunt.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin (preferably St. George Terroir Gin)
1/2 ounce sugar cane syrup (1:1, organic cane sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass filled with cobbled or crushed ice (or into a brass pineapple if you're fancy enough to own one).
4. Garnish with chamomile powder and chamomile flowers.

title: Banana Between the Sheets
intro_philosophy: A spin on theBetween the Sheets, Chip Tyndale’s straightforward update swaps the orange liqueur component of the original with banana liqueur and adds Angostura bitters and grated nutmeg as a garnish.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Grimace’s Day Off
intro_philosophy: Named for the giant purple character some may remember from childhood McDonald’s commercials, this drink gets its lavender hue from ube, a variety of purple potato. Just a couple of drops of ube extract, easily purchased online, is all that’s needed to tint thisRamos Gin Fizzriff.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce heavy ube syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/8 ounce hazelnut liqueur, preferably Luxardo Angioletto
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain and add back to the tin and dry shake, without ice.
3. Pour soda water into bottom of a chilled fizz glass.
4. Strain drink into fizz glass.
5. Garnish with ube cookie stick.

title: Negroni del Professore
intro_philosophy: This twist on the classic Negroni uses Vermouth del Professore Classico, an aromatized wine made from moscato grapes and based on a recipe created by The Jerry Thomas Project. The vermouth is made in collaboration with Piedmont’s Distilleria Quaglia.
ingredients: 1 ounce vermouth, preferably Vermouth del Professore
instructions: 1. Place a large ice cube in an Old-Fashioned glass and add the gin, Campari, bitters and soda.
2. Stir, garnish with lemon  zest and serve.

title: Meadowood’s Vieux Carré
intro_philosophy: In a variation on theVieux Carré, Meadowood bartender Sam Levy began with the idea of using apple brandy instead of cognac. With the help of Stillwater Spirits, he combined an apple mash with native yeast and fresh apples to distill his owneau de vie, which was then aged in American oak.  When applied to his Vieux Carré, Levy infused the eau de vie withwinter-sturdy Asian pears and quincefrom Meadowood’s Napa Valley grounds along with spicebush, vanilla, nutmeg and orange. The resulting infusion is then mixed withrye whiskey, sweet vermouth and Amaro Nonino, which substitutes for Bénédictine. A healthy dose of Peychaud’s bitters plus the traditional rinse of absinthe complete the saffron-hued cocktail, which is spilled over a large rock and garnished with an orange peel. Built on the foundation of a classic recipe,Levy’s Vieux Carré strays from the consistency of standard spirits and specs, instead molding the drink’s architecture and ethos to directly reflect Napa Valley’s winter harvestthis year.The same recipe will be different in winters to come depending on the apple variety, the quince yield, the spicebush availability and even the orange peel.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth (preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino)
instructions: 1. Rinse a rocks glass with absinthe, add a large ice cube and set aside.
2. In a mixing glass, add all ingredients, add ice and stir.
3. Strain into the rocks glass over the large ice cube.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Limonada Suiça Ramos
intro_philosophy: Limonada Suiça, or Brazilian Lemonade, is a summer staple. But in the winter, consider a Limonada Suiça Ramoscreated by Leanne Favre, of Brooklyn, New York’s Leyenda. Giving the cocktail its citrusy tang is “Lime Scrap Cello,” as Favre dubs it, an easy-to-make ingredient inspired by her Italian family’s homemade limoncello. This Ramos adds other accents to the fizz template, too, like the vanilla-forward Spanish liqueur Licor 43 andgénépy, which, with its bracing gentian flavor, further cements this spiked Limonada Suiça as a winter-appropriate drink.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Lime Scrap Cello (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce génépy, preferably Distilleria Alpe Herbetet
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except for soda water to a cocktail shaker and dry-shake, without ice.
2. Add ice and shake vigorously again.
3. Strain into a highball glass without ice.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Garnish with a lime twist.

title: The Overlook
intro_philosophy: A resinous riff on the Gin Sour, The Overlook’s dominant herbal note comes courtesy of Douglas Fir Eau de Vie from Portland’s Clear Creek Distillery. The name conjures a horizon filled with conifers while the mild heat of cinnamon mingles pleasantly with juniper to further enhance the feeling of standing at the tree line in high altitudes.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Clear Creek Douglas Fir Eau de Vie
1/2 ounce cinnamon simple syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with grated cinnamon.

title: Risorgimento d’Italia
intro_philosophy: A classic technique for adding aroma to a cocktail, perhaps most famously used to mist trace amounts of vermouth into an otherwise super-dry Martini, involves decanting spirits into an atomizer to gently spray over the top of a finished drink. Here, absinthe is spritzed over a finished twist on theGaribaldi, a cocktail made with orange juice and Campari, for a more spiritous, aromatic aperitivo.
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients in a Collins glass, then stir and add spear ice (or cubes).
2. Using an atomizer, spritz the absinthe over the top of the drink.
3. Garnish with an orange slice sprinkled with salt.

title: Alba Huerta’s Gimlet (2010 Version)
intro_philosophy: Technically, this is a sour, not a Gimlet, explains Alba Huerta. But it’s still bracing and citrusy, and beats versions made with Rose’s Sweetened Lime Juice. Besides, “In Texas, if you ask for a Gimlet you get something with fresh lime juice,” she notes.
ingredients: 2 ounces Old Tom gin, preferably Hayman's
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Fog Cutter
intro_philosophy:
In signature Trader Vic fashion, the Fog Cutter calls on a blend of three different base spirits (gin, cognac, rum) and a float of sherry. With so many different profiles competing, it’s a drink that can be difficult to balance. In the version Paul McGee serves at Lost Lake in Chicago, he tilts the axis of the drink more toward rum, in this case a lightly aged rhum agricole from Martinique rather than the “light rum” originally called for. A slightly amended version appears below, which simply loses the orange curaçao in favor of a hefty spritz of orange oil over the surface of the drink.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1 ounce aged Martinique rum, preferably Neisson Élevé Sous Bois
3/4 ounce orgeat (see Editor's Note, or Small Hand Foods)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and add 1 cup crushed ice. Shake for 5 seconds.
2. Pour into a tiki mug and top with another cup of crushed ice.
3. Garnish with an orange peel, first expressing its oils over the cocktail, then twirling it into a floret, a mint bouquet, orchid, and a swizzle stick and straw.

title: Regal Gold Rush
intro_philosophy: A simple grapefruit peel in the cocktail shaker helps balance the honey sweetness of this classic cocktail, Lieberman says. It also adds a brisk, citrusy aroma.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over fresh ice.

title: Manolito’s Swampwater
intro_philosophy: The Manolito team saw an opportunity in the Swampwater to improve on the original by using fresh ingredients and making significant tweaks to the spec.The ratio of Chartreuse to pineapple juice is flipped, basil is added, and the whole thing gets blended and garnished with mint. The rum float is optional, but strongly advised.
ingredients: 1 ounce dry rum, such as Don Q or Flor de Caña (optional)
instructions: 1. Combine all but the rum in a blender, and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a Swampwater jar.
3. Float rum on top (optional).
4. Garnish with mint.

title: Higher Value
intro_philosophy: With his Americano riff, Max Green took inspiration from the Nonino family’s efforts to uplift grappa in Italy, and their choice to opt out of DOCG classification. “We decided it was better to declare that having Nonino on the label is of much higher value than anything else,” Elisabetta Nonino was once quoted as saying. Green’s Higher Value hews to the classic build of vermouth, soda and amaro, with L’Aperitivo Nonino subbing in for the latter. Lighter than the original, it’s a touch sweet, with notes of summer fruit and gentian.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except sparkling green tea to a highball glass with ice
2. Stir until chilled, and top with sparkling tea.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist and a green olive.

title: High Ball Stepper
intro_philosophy: Served in a can of berry LaCroix, Benjamin Amberg’s High Ball Stepperbrightens the botanicals of gin with fresh mint syrup and a squeeze of lime in this modern take on the classicCollinsconstruction.
instructions: 1. Pour out half of the berry LaCroix and set aside.
2. Combine remaining ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with cracked ice.
3. Fine strain into the can using a small funnel.
4. Garnish with raspberries, blackberries, blueberries, mint and a straw.

title: Tunnel Vision
intro_philosophy:
The Tunnel Vision was born of Alex Day’s desire to create a drink that was simultaneously refreshing and savory, the latter of which is achieved with herb-infused vermouth and high-proof pear eau de vie. The drink’s real inspiration is hidden in its name, a phrase that describes Day’s blinding obsession with the combination when he dreamed up this tall, strange beauty.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail,with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 2 ounces basil-infused Dolin Blanc vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the vermouth, eau de vie, lime juice, simple syrup, and absinthe in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over ice and add the garnish.

title: Cetara
intro_philosophy: At Clementine in Edmonton, Alberta, Mitch Caddick was inspired by theNegroni Sbagliatowhen creating the Cetara. Punt e Mes and Campari harmonize with Italian bitter soda (the bar has used both Crodino and Stappi Red Bitter), brightened with lime juice that echoes the acidity of grapefruit peel–infused London dry gin.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces grapefruit peel–infused London dry gin (see Editor’s Note)
Italian soda such as Crodino or Stappi Red Bitter, to top
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients, except for soda, to a shaker, then shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Top with Italian soda.
4. Garnish with a slice of grapefruit.

title: Leyenda’s Michelada
intro_philosophy: Ivy Mix’s take on the Michelada swaps the tomato base with a citrusy, spicy sangrita. Traditionally taken with a shot of tequila, the sangrita here highlights the origins of this south-of-the-border classic.
ingredients: 2 ounces papaya and carrot sangrita (see Editor's Note)
beer, to top, preferably Pacifico or Negro Modelo
instructions: 1. Rim glass with salt.
2. Combine all ingredients except beer in glass and add ice.
3. Top with beer (Pacifico in warm months, Negro Modelo in colder months).
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Blood Orange Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: In this spin on the classic Garibaldi, freshly squeezed blood orange juice tops an Italian aperitivo liqueur for an immensely satisfying two-ingredient cocktail. (To get that signature frothy crown without a Breville juicer at the ready, hand-press the blood oranges and agitate the juice with a handheld frother or a blender.)
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Italian aperitivo liqueur, such as Contratto Bitter or Campari
instructions: 1. Pour the aperitivo liqueur into a highball glass.
2. Top with fresh-pressed blood orange juice.

title: Airmail
intro_philosophy: Though not fully official on account of the plane breaking down, the first attempt at modern airmail was documented in 1911. It traveled from Petaluma to Santa Rosa, California and contained exactly three pieces of correspondence. The first instance of the Air Mail cocktail was documented inEsquiremagazine’s 1949 edition ofHandbook for Hosts. It’s not certain why the drink is named for the modern delivery method, but it can be said the Air Mail is quite like the Caribbean version of aFrench 75, with a splash of lime whisked into a turbulent mix of rum, honey and Champagne.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rum, gold (Appleton or El Dorado)
instructions: 1. Add rum, lime juice and honey syrup to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with Champagne and add a straw.
5. Garnish with a lime or orange twist.

title: Rescue Team
intro_philosophy: “I’ve always said this is the best cocktail I’ve ever created,” says Alex Jump of her peanut butter Daiquiri, a drink she’s kept in her back pocket for years after first trying something similar in Puerto Rico, tinkering with the formula every now and again. “This is kind of like my 2.0 version,” she says. In the cocktail, peanut butter-infused rum is complemented by banana liqueur. Says Jump, “It’s so pleasant, it kind of tastes like a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.”
ingredients: 2 ounces peanut butter-washed rum (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Coconut Blast #3
intro_philosophy: A simple coconut-washed spirit offers a fast track to tropical flavor in just about any drink. If done correctly, the solution should be crystal clear and remain uncloudy when added to drinks. The Rockwell team suggests four dashes as the standard, but feel free to use more or less as necessary. “I’ve heard that a few dashes in coffee before a shift is quite nice,” they say.
ingredients: 75 grams (2/3 cup) organic unrefined coconut oil
instructions: 1. Weigh 39 grams of water in a measuring cup, then add Everclear until the total volume is 150 mL  (1 gram of water = 1 ml).
2. Heat coconut oil in hot Bain Marie (or double boiler, or a metal bowl placed over a pan of boiling water) until it becomes liquid and is completely clear.
3. Add oil to the Everclear-water solution and stir.
4. Allow to macerate for a minimum of 5 hours, stirring (or shaking) occasionally.
5. Place in freezer overnight. (While coconut oil can solidify within an hour or two, the cleanest/purest results have been as a result of longer freezing times).
6. Remove the solidified fat and discard.
7. Fold the seams of a #2 conical coffee filter and strain Coconut Blast.
8. Discard filter, and repeat the straining process with the second filter. Store in a dasher bottle.

title: French Martini
intro_philosophy: As Dale DeGroff notes inThe New Craft of the Cocktail, “this drink is one of the sparks that got the cocktail-as-Martini craze started.” A combination of vodka, Chambord raspberry liqueur and pineapple juice, the French Martini found an audience when DeGroff put it on the menu at Keith McNally’s Pravda, where it never came off.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Oregano Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Alba Huerta’s Oregano Cobbler pairs herbaceous gin and oregano with the rounded notes of bianco vermouth. “For most of the latter part of the 19th Century, Vermouth Bianco went mostly unnoticed,” says Huerta. Fortunately, it’s being rediscovered both as a delicious and versatile cocktail modifier and stand-alone aperitif.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing tin, add ice and shake.
2. Double strain into a cobbler glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with fresh oregano sprigs.

title: Bryant’s Wisconsin Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: While Bryant’s has no written menu (guests instead discuss what they’d like with the bartender), the iconic lounge—the oldest in the state—offers many Midwestern staples, like thePink Squirreland this Wisconsin Old-Fashioned.The drink arrives in a footed glass topped with soda—exactly which soda will depend on whether it’s ordered “sweet,” “sour” or “press”—garnished with a cherry and orange half-moon. Like just about everything at Bryant’s, ourIndustry Icon of 2024, it manages to feel like it has equal footing in the past and the present.
instructions: 1. In a 12-ounce footed Old-Fashioned glass, add the simple syrup, Angostura bitters and an ounce of soda.
2. Swirl these around the glass, allowing the ingredients to mix, creating a light foam. You should be able to smell the bitters.
3. Add the brandy, fill with ice and top with the remaining soda.
4. Garnish with a cherry and orange half-moon.

title: William Elliott’s Jungle Bird
intro_philosophy: At a recent Jungle Bird blind tasting,William ElliottofMaison Premiereplaced second. His recipe calls on the expected Cruzan Black Strap alongside Hamilton Jamaican Black rum as the boozy backbone.
ingredients: Scant 3/4 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Hamilton Jamaican Pot Still Black Rum
instructions: 1. Add pebble ice to a mixing tin and whip shake until dissolved.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over one large ice cube.
3. Garnish with Campari-soaked pineapple wedge and fanned pineapple leaf skewered with cherry.

title: Port Light
intro_philosophy: In the Trader Vic’s tradition, this drink is served in a Port Light glass, which resembles a rounded lantern with red glass and gold trim; the same glass in green is called a Starboard Light glass.A Port Light Highball appears inTrader Vic’s Bartender’s Guide(1947), but it’s very different from this drink,which Jeff “Beachbum” Berry discovered at the Kahiki Restaurant in Columbus, Ohio, in 1996.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce passion fruit syrup, see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. Put everything in a blender.
2. Blend at high speed for 5 seconds.
3. Pour unstrained into a Port Light glass, adding more ice to fill.
4. Garnish with a swizzle stick.

title: Shibuya Crossing
intro_philosophy: This Boulevardier from the Washington, D.C., restaurant Daikaya is built with a Japanese whisky andvermouth. The requisite Campari is combined with gum arabic, lending the liqueur—and the cocktail as a whole—a rounder, richer texture.
ingredients: 1 ounce Japanese whisky, preferably Iwai Black
1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Oka Kura Sweet Bermutto
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large rock.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Tendril Loving Care
intro_philosophy:
Assavory cocktailshave been gaining traction, Caer Maiko, bar manager of Austin’s DrinkWell and co-founder ofDaijoubu Pop Up, has found that snap peas can add “a garden-fresh note” akin to celery, without overpowering. She uses a snap pea shrub made with vinegar and mint in her Tendril Loving Care, a Collins-style drink incorporating gin and olive oil–washed blanco tequila, garnished with pea shoots and mint. “The future of cocktails seems to be leaning more and more toward savory items,” says Maiko. “Snap peas can walk the line between sweet and savory in the same cocktail.”

NB: Maiko notes that this recipe can easily be made non-alcoholic by substituting Seedlip Garden in lieu of the gin and tequila.
ingredients: 1 ounce London dry gin, preferably Tanqueray 10
3/4 ounce snap pea shrub (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with mint and pea shoots.

title: Shots and Stripes Forever
intro_philosophy: Few holidays call for technicolor layered cocktails like the 4th of July. Pamela Wiznitzer of the Dead Rabbit in New York City abides by Old Glory’s colors with this gin sour swizzle of sorts saturated with blue Curaçao and Peychaud’s bitters. The drink was originally created as a shot, so can be split up to create two servings. Just prepare extra crushed ice in two short glasses for half-sized drinks. All the better for raising a glass to America.
instructions: 1. Prepare a batch of completely crushed ice.
2. Add a layer of crushed ice to the bottom of a Collins glass.
3. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
4. Add ice and shake until chilled.
5. Strain over first layer of crushed ice in the Collins glass to create a "blue" layer.
6. Fill glass with remaining crushed ice to create a "white" layer.
7. Dash Angostura bitter over top for a "red" layer.

title: Rob Roy No. 3
intro_philosophy: It might look incorrect on paper, but Brian Silva’s overhaul of a classic scotch whisky cocktail is inspired by the structure of a “perfect” cocktail, harnessing the sweet and savory extremes of both dry and sweet vermouth in a crisp and dry orange peel garnished drink.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Pandan-quiri
intro_philosophy: French bartender Nico de Soto is famed for popularizing the Southeast Asian herb pandan, which has a coconut-like flavor. Here, he offers a straightforward riff on theDaiquiri, sweetened with a blended pandan syrup, which he says adds a grassy, bitter note.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Herbaceous Candied Citron Syrup
intro_philosophy: Inspired by both candied citron and traditional Christmas panettone, this syrup highlights seasonal winter citrus with a touch of aromatic herbs. Zesting the citron directly into the sugar allows the syrup to also capture its fresh and fragrant oils, creating the perfect setting for heartier sprigs of rosemary and thyme. Evocative of biting into a candied citron peel, this syrup with many vodka or gin-based cocktails, and would add refreshing balance to a lower-ABV aperitivo or spritz.
ingredients: 1 citron (inner pitch to be reserved for another purpose)
instructions: 1. Zest citron over and into sugar in a small saucepan away from heat.
2. With your fingers rub the citron zest and sugar together until the whole mixture looks like wet sand and the air is heavily perfumed.
3. Pour 1 cup water over sugar, stir with a whisk to combine and turn heat to medium.
4. Bring the syrup just under a boil, whisking occasionally, to dissolve sugar. Then lower heat and let cook until syrup appears clear rather than cloudy, 3 to 5 minutes total.

5. Remove syrup from heat and pour into a container, let cool to room temperature and then add sprigs of herbs to container, top with lid, shake to disturb the herbs and let sit overnight to marry. The longer you let the herbs sit in the syrup the stronger their flavor will become.
6. Next day, strain the syrup to remove herbs and zest and store refrigerated until ready to use.

title: Garden Paloma
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients and strain into a Collins glass.
2. Top with seltzer and a pinch of salt.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Bar Tartine’s Beet and Rye Kvass
intro_philosophy: At San Francisco’sBar Tartine, kvass(a fermented and subtly alcoholic Eastern European beverage) is made from beets and rye scraps from the belovedTartine Bakery. Cortney Burns, one of the restaurants chefs, isn’t doctrinaire about the recipe though—like making bread, it’s more a process that’s felt out and intuited. “Kvass has a natural acidity and gentle salinity which works well when blending drinks. I find it wildly refreshing,” Burns says. “It’s great with everything from mezcal to vodka.”
ingredients: 2 cups sour whey , from yogurt or beet juice (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Pour water, whey, (or water and salt if not using whey) into a large nonreactive container.
2. Stir to dissolve.
3. Add the beets and rye bread.
4. Top with a weight to keep beets and bread submerged in the brine.
5. Seal the container, using a lid with an airlock if you have one.
6. Place in a clean, well-protected, low-light area with an ambient temperature of 60° to 68°F/16° to 20°C until the beets develop a mild sour flavor, 7 to 10 days.
7. If you have sealed it without an airlock, open the container every few days or so to release carbon dioxide buildup and check for mold.
8. Strain the liquid, reserving the beets and liquid separately.
9. Transfer the liquid to one or more flip-top bottles or canning jars with tight-fitting lids and refrigerate for up to 2 months.
10. Pack the beets into one or more airtight containers and refrigerate for up to 4 days, or juice and drink.

title: The Lincoln
intro_philosophy: The Lincoln is named for the Lincoln Tower, the original name of undulating white skyscraper that is home to Rochester’s lobby watering hole, Bar Bantam. The drink was conceived by Charles Cerankosky as a Manhattan variant in the vein of theGreenpointorRed Hookcocktails.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Cap Corse Mattei Quinquina Rouge
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the apple slices in a rocks glass filled with one large ice cube.
2. Stir until chilled, about 30 seconds.
3. Arrange apple slices in the shape of a fan and fix in place with a toothpick. Perch on the rim of the glass.

title: Queen’s Park Swizzle
intro_philosophy: Created in Trinidad, this rum-based, bitters-topped drink gets its name from the Queen’s Park Hotel in the country’s capital, Port of Spain. However, its traditional dark and muggy Demerara rum base hails from neighboring Guyana, which had a more established rum industry than Trinidad when this drink was created in the early 20th century. With few ingredients, this drink gets its unique signature from the swizzle technique, which calls for agitating the drink with aswizzle stickuntil frost forms on the glass.
instructions: 1. In a Collins or hurricane glass, gently muddle mint leaves with simple syrup to release the oils.
2. Add lime juice, rum and crushed ice.
3. Swizzle with a straw or swizzle stick to mix.
4. Add more crushed ice and dash Angostura bitters over top.
5. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Casualty
intro_philosophy: From New York City’s Amor y Amargo, the Casualty showcasesByrrh’s versatility as a seasonless aperitif wine. Stirred with Scotch, Amaro Montenegro and two dashes of chocolate bitters, it serves as a pinch-hitter for sweet vermouth, resulting in a spirituous drink that’s cold weather-ready.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Famous Grouse
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir all ingredients with plenty of ice.
2. Strain the drink into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Express an orange twist over the drink and drop it in.

title: The Bar’s House Martini
intro_philosophy: For the revamp of New York’s iconic Four Seasons bar, head of bar operations for Major Food Group, Thomas Waugh, developed this houseMartini, which is pre-batched, pre-chilled and poured from a crystal decanter.
instructions: 1. Batch, add to a glass bottle and place in the freezer for 24 hours.
2. Pour into a coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with skewered Cerignola olives or a lemon twist.

title: Sbagliato Rosa
intro_philosophy: Tom Macy’s riff on theNegroni Sbagliatoswaps out Campari and sweet vermouth for an aromatic blend of Cappelletti and Cocchi Rosa. The rosé Champagne topper adds a light, playful effervescence to round it out.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with an orange peel and grapefruit peel.

title: Mahoney
intro_philosophy: This not-quite-fifty-fiftyMartiniriff appears inThe Nomad Cocktail Book, by bar directorLeo Robitschek. Note that “house orange bitters” refers to equal partsAngosturaand Regans’ orange bitters, mixed together in the same bottle.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Express the lemon peel and insert it into the drink.

title: Suppressor #246
intro_philosophy: Bartender Lara Creasy builds an innovative riff on mulled wine with the addition of housemade chai-infused vermouth and a few dashes of bitters, for a winter-friendly, low-proof cocktail with no shortage of warming power.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces chai infused Sweet Vermouth (See Editor's Note)
4 dashes  aromatic bitters, preferably Fee Brothers
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a footed cocktail glass.
2. Garnish with a swath of orange peel.

title: Yvonne’s Ward Eight
intro_philosophy: This version of the Ward Eight, created in collaboration with David Wondrich, gets a nutty complexity thanks to the addition of a half-ounce of palo cortado sherry, a trick gleaned from a 1934 column in theNew York Sun.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce sherry, preferably Lustau Palo Cortado Peninsula
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in tin, add ice and shake.
2. Strain into an ice-filled goblet, top with soda and garnish with a pineapple disc.

title: Room for Improvement’s Cosmopolitan
intro_philosophy: At Portland’s Room for Improvement, the cocktails are rooted in classics but feature spins that keep the drinks feeling fresh. For the bar’s Cosmopolitan, that means creating a “cranpari” cordial—cranberries blended with sugar and water, then mixed with Campari—that lends the cocktail some welcome bitter notes. Meanwhile, the blend of orange liqueurs not only adds depth of flavor, it also amps up the body of the cocktail, giving it a more rounded mouthfeel than the traditional version.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces vodka, preferably St. George California Citrus Vodka
1/4 ounce Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand Dry
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
2. Shake, then fine-strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Donga Punch
intro_philosophy: Jeff “Beachbum” Berry discovered this cocktail in a 1937 notebook of original Don the Beachcomber recipes, kept by bartender Ricardo Santiago.
ingredients: 2 ounces rhum agricole, preferably  Clément Rhum Vieux Agricole V.S.O.P.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with crushed ice.
2. Shake until chilled.
3. Pour into a tiki mug, topping with additional crushed ice if needed.

title: Shipwreck Saint
intro_philosophy: “The aim of thiscobbleris using cocoa nib-infused triple sec to achieve a happy marriage of bitter orange and chocolate without being cloyingly sweet,” explains Fu. “The rest is simple yet delicious: turbinado syrup, lime, pineapple, 5-Island Banks white rum and a dusting of coffee grounds on top.”
ingredients: 2 ounces rooibos tea-infused rum, preferably Banks 5-Island (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce cocoa nib-infused triple sec, preferably Giffard (see Editor's Note)
3/4 ounce rich demerara syrup (2:1, demerara sugar: water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with a few ice cubes.
2. Strain into a cobbler or Collins glass over crushed ice.
3. Top with more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with an orange half-wheel and a light dusting of finely ground coffee.

title: Heart of Glass
intro_philosophy: This modern creation draws on the old tradition of scaffa, which are mixed drinks that aren’t chilled or diluted with ice. (Back in the days before fridges, ice was, for many drinkers, rare and precious.) The Heart of Glass was one of a few scaffa that appeared in the influentialRogue Cocktailsbook series, which challenged a host of popular conceptions about how to make cocktails. For best results, reach for a top-shelf, sip-me bourbon like Sidle’s suggestion of Eagle Rare 10-year.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon, preferably Eagle Rare 10-year, plus more to rinse the glass
instructions: 1. Donate a little bourbon into a rocks glass, then twist at an angle to coat the entire inside, all the way to the rim of the glass. So as not to waste any of the bourbon, pour what’s left into a jigger.

2. Contribute more bourbon to that jigger, to total 1 1/2 ounces. Pour that into a mixing glass. Add the Carpano Antica, Cynar and Angostura to the mixing glass, then add enough water to remove the burn of the bourbon, but not too much as to needlessly dilute it; start with 1/2 ounce.
3. Carve an orange peel garnish over the mixing glass, so as to capture as much orange oil as possible, then pour into the bourbon-rinsed (aka “educated”) glass.

title: John’s Blend
intro_philosophy:
John’s Blend—the winning drink from the 2023 Most Imaginative Bartender competition, by Liverpool-bred, Orlando-based bartender Peter Hannah—is a gin-based riff on an Irish Coffee that gets its depth from the complex flavors of Bombay Sapphire Gin.

Hannah’s desire to seek out new expressions of familiar cocktails led him to explore as his template a hot gin drink, a style not often seen on cocktail competition stages, where shaken drinks tend to dominate.

“I feel like being creative is about doing different things rather than just doing the same things again and again,” he says.

Cacao-infused simple syrup nods to the Alexander cocktail, while a blend of Assam tea and spices complements the spirit’s herbal notes and evokes a strong British cuppa. A topping of whipped cream brings silky smoothness to the drink’s texture, while a spray of lemon herb hydrosol highlights the bright citrus aromatics of the Bombay Sapphire Gin. A three-ingredient drink, it’s a testament to how simplicity and complexity can complement each other.
ingredients: 2 3/4 ounces Lennon’s Evening Tea (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce cacao simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine gin, hot Lennon’s Evening Tea and cacao simple syrup in a 6-ounce Irish Coffee glass.
2. Shake heavy cream gently in a shaker for 6 to 7 seconds, then pour on top.
3. Spray lemon herb hydrosol on the side of the glass.

title: White Lyan’s Piña Colada
intro_philosophy: Perhaps the most iconic frozen drink, White Lyan’s take on the Piña Colada calls for blending with crushed ice for the ideal texture.
instructions: 1. Chill all ingredients, except vanilla salt, in advance. (You can place the rums in the freezer and the juice and Coco Lopez in the fridge.)
2. Add all ingredients to a blender, add ice and blend quickly until smooth.
3. Serve in highball or Hurricane glass.

title: Orchid Thief
intro_philosophy: Simply fino sherry, dry vermouth and a splash of Bénédictine, served up,the Orchid Thief reads like a hybrid of two of Chip Tyndale’s favorite cocktails: theBambooand the Chrysanthemum.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Future Dancer
intro_philosophy: Served atDarioin Minneapolis, the Future Dancer is a light, low-proof aperitif. It pairs a dry Spanish vermouth with Maleza’s herbal bitters, which are made with Mexican botanicals like avocado leaf and hoja santa, all balanced by lime juice and simple syrup.
ingredients: 2 ounces dry vermouth, such as Destilerías Acha Dry
1/2 ounce  rich simple syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake vigorously.
2. Strain into a small rocks glass or coupe.

title: Suplada Spritz
intro_philosophy: The Suplada Spritz pulls in layers of unexpected flavors to the recognizable Negroni Sbagliato blueprint thanks to a chile-garlic shrub inspired by the sour-sweet nature of adobo, a Filipino dish consisting of braised meat marinated in vinegar and soy sauce. “I like to draw on my own lived experiences,” explainsNapier Bulanan. “I lean heavy on nostalgia.”
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Casa Mariol Vermut Negre
scant 1/2 ounce adobo shrub (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the cava, in a wine glass filled with ice.
2. Top with cava.
3. Garnish with an orange twist and a bay leaf.

title: Behind Closed Doors
intro_philosophy:
This story is published in partnership with P(our), a symposium devoted to exploring new ideas and exchanging inspiration about the drinks industry, and beyond. The annual event promotes discussions and presentations that address issues critical to the trade; this year’s theme is “perfection.” The event is taking place in Paris on June 3rd—for more information, and for tickets,click here.

With this drink, Erik Lorincz was aiming to make a cocktail that looks like a Martini but tastes like a Bloody Mary—a goal that resulted in numerous technical challenges. In a long process during which “the drink really, really played in my mind for a long time,” Lorincz set about redistilling vodka with a homemade blend of tomato water. Only constant tweaking achieved the result he was looking for, teaching him that “if you’re not satisfied, that’s a good thing, because then you can perfect that recipe. Just keep going.”
ingredients: heavy 1 2/3 ounces vodka, preferably Grey Goose vodka, redistilled with El Diablo via rotovap
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with sundried tomato and caviar on the side.

title: The Irish
intro_philosophy: This cold weather-appropriate adaptation of theOld-Fashionedlays down a spicy baseline to fend off the winter blues thanks to a trio of ginger syrup, allspice tincture and the tiki liqueur, Velvet Falernum.
instructions: 1. Build the drink in a tumbler over ice.
2. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Dreamland’s French Martini
intro_philosophy: The way many bartenders see it, the French Martini has harmonious components; its main flaw is an absence of acidity. Nick Hartigan of Dreamland in Seattle addresses this imbalance by marrying the French Martini blueprint with that of theBreakfast Martini.“I wanted to put a juicy and crushable sour that can stand up to the onslaught of Bloody Marys and Mimosas during brunch,” he saysof the drink, which is composed ofgin, Chambord, lemon and local raspberry jam.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces London dry gin, preferably Fords
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Midnight Rider
intro_philosophy: Pineau des Charentes has “become one of those ingredients that finds itself in a cocktail at the most unexpected times,” says Alex Day, of Death & Co., Honeycut and many more. At New York’s Nitecap, he and Natasha David use it to give extra boost and body to apple brandy and Irish Whiskey before rounding it out with a barspoon of peach preserves and a dash of orange bitters.
ingredients: 1 ounce apple brandy, preferably 8-year-old Clear Creek Pomme Eau de Vie
3/4 ounces Pineau des Charentes, preferably Pierre Ferrand
instructions: 1. Place all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass and serve with an orange twist.

title: DuBoudreau Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Jim Meehan updates the rye-based Cooper Cocktail created by Seattle’s renowned Jamie Boudreau (see the recipe forCooper’s Nightcap) in an East Coast ode to the West Coast original. The addition of Dubonnet adds an herbal, spicy-sweet element to the bittersweet combo of Fernet Branca and St-Germain.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir.
2. Strain into a coupe and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Our Lychee Martini
intro_philosophy: AtMiami Beach’sSweet Liberty, you’ll find a number ofbeverage director Naren Young’sreinterpretations of ‘tinis, from the Appletini (made with Calvados and fresh apple cider vinegar) to the Lemon Drop. The bar’s Our Lychee Martini is a bestseller and  leans on lychee liqueur, St-Germain and sauvignon blanc.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a frozen lychee and spray of rosewater.

title: Hedge Maze
intro_philosophy: “The fewer the elements, the better,” says Yanni Kehagiaras of his approach to cocktails atStoa, one of ourBest New Bars of 2024. At the San Francisco bar, the team strives to coax the most out of minimal builds. As Kehagiaras explains, he focuses “on micro quantities of potent spirits and liqueurs to make loud impact.” Here, a small measure of green Chartreuse boosts the herbal complexity found in the base of St. George Spirits Terroir Gin, which is lengthened by blanc vermouth for body and just the right amount of sweetness.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces gin, such as St. George Spirits Terroir Gin
1/2 ounce blanc vermouth, such as Dolin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled and diluted.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Chokehold
intro_philosophy: This cocktail fromBecca Petersen, bartender atDaisies, pays homage to an unsung modern classic, the Art of Choke, created by Kyle Davidson at Chicago’s Violet Hour. Where the original combines rum, Cynar and green Chartreuse alongside a small measure of lime juice, Petersen swaps the base spirit for gin and splits the amaro quotient between CioCiaro and Zucca Rabarbaro. “I’m a lover of a stirred gin drink, of amaro, and of the unexpected,” says Petersen.
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, such as Xoriguer Mahón
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, including the mint leaves, in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Royal Gift
intro_philosophy: Basil-infused gin stars in this sour-style cocktail. The aromatic herb complements the spirit’s inherent botanical makeup, and pairs well with the pineapple liqueur, fresh lemon juice and lemon syrup that round out the drink. In other words, the Royal Gift puts refreshment above anything else. “It’s all about respecting the properties, the fragrance, of the basil,” says Cruz.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Dave Arnold’s Wassail
intro_philosophy: In this twist on one of the oldest warm drink templates, Dave Arnold heats the drink via hot poker which lends a caramelized flavor to the finished drink. Here, he adapts the recipe for stovetop preparation.
instructions: 1. In a mug, mix together brandy, Madeira, lemon juice, salt and thyme.
2. Heat sugar in a saucepan, until caramelized.
3. Pour in brandy mixture.
4. Use a long-handled match or kitchen torch to apply flame to the contents of the pan; it should catch fire.
5. Add water, dousing the fire. Add more water if needed to extinguish the flame.
6. Scrape the insides of the pan and briefly stir to combine.
7. Strain into mug.
8. Garnish with grated cinnamon.

title: The Remedy
intro_philosophy: This riff on the classicPainkilleruses acid-adjusted orange juice, made with citric and malic acids, in place of lime juice. This technique “adjusts” the orange so it reads as brighter and more acidic – similar to lime juice, although the drink actually contains no  lime at all.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce overproof white rum, preferably J. Wray & Nephew White Overproof Rum
3/4 ounce acid-adjusted orange juice (see Editor's Note)
3/4 ounce caramelized condensed coconut (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over pebble ice.

title: Erick Castro’s Piña Colada
intro_philosophy: Though most people make their Piña Coladas with white rum alone, Erick Castro incorporates four rums into his recipe, in a nod to tiki tradition. From there, he calls on an unorthodox preparation and shakes the drink with a half an ounce of pebble ice to better integrate measures of pineapple juice and Coco Lopez coconut cream.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce white rum, preferably Plantation 3 Stars
1/2 ounce overproof rum, preferably Smith & Cross
1/2 ounce dark rum, preferably Plantation Original Dark
1/2 ounce  rhum agricole, preferably Clément Rhum Agricole Première Canne
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with 1/2 ounce pebble ice, to dissolve.
2. Strain into a chilled Hurricane glass filled with pebble ice
3. Garnish with an orange slice, a brandied cherry and a pineapple frond.

title: Rob Jones’ Hot Buttered Rum
intro_philosophy: Bartender Rob Jones turns up the volume on the classic Hot Buttered Rum, swapping in hot cider in place of hot water, pairing it with his sweet-and-savory batter.
ingredients: 3 to 4 ounces batter, or to taste (see Editor’s Note)
4 to 5 ounces hot cider, to top
instructions: 1. n a mug that has been tempered with hot water, add 3 to 4 ounces of batter, based on your palate.
2. Add 1 ounce of overproof rum, top with hot cider and stir slightly to incorporate.
3. Garnish with a cinnamon stick or clove-studded apple slice.

title: Violet Hour
intro_philosophy: A play on the New York Sour, the Violet Hour uses a half-ounce of locally made haskap liqueur (made from a berry native to Hokkaido, Japan) and is finished with a float of Willamette Valley piquette syrah. “Oregon is truly a special place, and our program deeply celebrates our region,” says Lydia McLuen.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Stone Barn Brandyworks haskap liqueur, or cassis
1 ounce Dionystic Chios Piquette of Syrah 2020 (a light red may be substituted)
instructions: 1. Dry-shake all ingredients except wine. Add ice to tins, then shake.
2. Fine-strain into a large coupe, and float wine over the top.
3. Garnish by using bitters to make a design in the foam.

title: Spanish Gibson
intro_philosophy: This herbaceous take on the Gibson from Brooklyn’s Red Hook Tavern “is just salty and savory enough to scratch an itch in the era of ‘dirty Martini everything,’ but is softened by its use of rosemary alongside an especially herbaceous Basque vermouth,” according to Punch art director Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 2 1/4 ounces dry gin, preferably Hayman’s London Dry, or vodka, preferably Aloo
3 dashes lemon saline solution (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a pickled pearl onion.

title: Lust for Life
intro_philosophy: Joaquín Simó’s Lust for Life “is bright, it’s layered, and the earthy smoke of mezcal with bright, tropical pineapple and almond make it both crowd-pleasing and memorable,” says Meaghan Dorman, bar director of New York’s Dear Irving. She’s been serving the drink for years as a bartender’s choice and finds that it’s “a great entry point for drinkers not familiar with mezcal.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with cocoa powder.

title: Monkey Man
intro_philosophy:
To explore the overlap between the worlds of drinks and music, we challenged bartenders to translate a song of their choice from a given genre into cocktail form. Here, Jim Kearnstakes on reggae.

As Kearns explains of the inspiration behind the drink: “Theidea came from the fact that I have always tasted a strong banana note on Tennessee whiskey, and I thought it might be a fun bridge to the realm of tiki, a genre in which American whiskey is not the most frequently used spirit…The cocktail came quickly, with [Brian] Miller suggesting the vanilla, the El Dorado 15, and the name.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably George Dickel No. 12 Tennessee Whisky
1/2 ounce aged rum, preferably El Dorado 15 year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a banana chip.

title: Diamond Rye Back
intro_philosophy: The Diamondback is one of the gems of the pre-Prohibition canon, a potent mixture of rye, applejack and herbaceous yellow Chartreuse. The Diamond Rye Back taps into the famous whiskey drink’s legacy, brightening the powerful alpine profile of green Chartreuse with dashes of sherry and crème de peche. A grapefruit twist highlights the delicate citrus character of Belvedere Vodka’s Lake Bartężek, from the Single Estate Rye series, as layer gives way to layer in this lush variation on the original.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: John De Piper’s Mojito
intro_philosophy: Tied for second place in our recent Mojito tasting, John De Piper’s drink was shaken briefly with a few pieces of pebble ice and then strained into a glass filled with more pebble ice. The ingredients included two ounces of Real McCoy 3 Year Old rum, one ounce lime juice and—in its most singular feature—a sweetener blend of three-quarters of an ounce of cane syrup (De Piper prefers either Rhum JM or Petite Canne) and a brown sugar cube. This led to a slightly sweeter Mojito—and one that was deeply colored, owing to the brown sugar—but with great flavor and body.
ingredients: 2 ounces light rum, preferably Real McCoy 3 Year
3/4 ounce cane syrup, preferably Rhum J.M Sirop or Petite Canne
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, add the mint and sugar and muddle.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and shake lightly with a few pieces of pebble ice.
3. Pour into a Collins glass and top with pebble ice.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet in the middle of the glass.

title: Aperol Spritz Jello Shots
instructions: 1. Add fine-strained orange juice, sugar and Aperol to a mixing bowl.
2. Add gelatin and hot water (should be simmering, but not boiling).
3. Whisk together until all gelatin has dissolved, about 4 minutes.
4. Add prosecco and whisk gently.
5. Pour the mixture into 2 ounce plastic shot cups and place in the refrigerator.
6. Let chill at least 2 hours before serving.

title: Rebuttal Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Selena Donovan’s Rebuttal Cocktail is a riff on theTuxedo #2, a maraschino- and absinthe-tinted Martini variation. Her sleek update on the classic replaces gin with Grey Goose vodka and amplifies the garnish game with an oliveanda lemon twist. “I’m a firm believer that a lady shouldn’t have to choose just one garnish,” says Donovan.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces vodka, preferably Grey Goose Original
3/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat Extra Dry
1 dash  absinthe, preferably St. George or Vieux Pontarlier
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
3. Garnish with an olive and a lemon twist.

title: Bitter Intentions
intro_philosophy: The Bitter Intentions is bartender Bobby Heugel’s proof that beautiful things can happen when you embrace bitters in an atypical way. A combination of sour, sweet and bitter Heugel turns the Americano on its head and kicks it up with citrus for a cross between a bitter highball and a sour.
ingredients: 1 ounce vermouth , such as Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Pour the soda water in a Collins glass without ice.
2. shake the Campari, lemon, and simple syrup with ice and strain into the glass.
3. Add cracked ice.
4. Top with the Carpano Antica Vermouth and garnish with an orange slice.

title: Revenge of the Line
intro_philosophy: At Otis in Brooklyn, bartender Channing Centeno opts for a smoky mezcal base in his Revenge of the Line. Complemented by yellow Chartreuse, lime and charred pineapple, the drink reads like a beachside bonfire in a glass.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with pineapple dipped in chile powder.

title: Sorel Toddy
intro_philosophy: AtCurein New Orleans, this comforting recipe turnssorrelinto a wintry hot toddy with rum, Demerara syrup and lime juice. For all of your holiday entertaining needs, it couldn’t be simpler: You don’t have to make sorrel from scratch because the base of the cocktail is aspiced hibiscus liqueur, and you can easily scale this up (just multiply!) for a crowd.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce rum, such as Don Q 7 Year Rum
1/4 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Fill a footed mug with hot water to warm the glassware, then empty.
2. Add ingredients to the mug, then top with hot water to fill.
3. Garnish with a lime peel.

title: To Casimir
intro_philosophy: Riffing off the classic pairing of vodka and caviar by washing the glass with liquid caviar, the drink takes savoriness to the next level by adding a briny dram of saltwater to Belvedere Vodka’s Lake Bartężek, from the Single Estate Rye series. A caviar cube is the finishing Eastern European touch—appropriate for a drink named after the Polish king Casimir III the Great.
instructions: 1. Using a small, thin brush, swipe Petrossian liquid caviar around the inside of a chilled cocktail glass.
2. Combine all remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into prepared cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a skewered Petrossian caviar cube.

title: Another Country
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the Fault Line, a cocktail from bartender Shannon Tebay at Death & Co., New York, which Alex Jump describes as “arguably one of the best drinks Death & Co. has ever had on a menu,” Another Country reads like aBoulevardiervariation. A rye base marries equal parts J. Rieger Caffé Amaro and Cocchi Vermouth di Torino with a small measure of carrot eau de vie.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce vermouth di Torino, preferably Cocchi
1 teaspoon carrot eau de vie, preferably Reisetbauer
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Changes in Latitude
intro_philosophy: Heirloom’s Pineapple Amaroadds bittersweet tropical flavor to a range of cocktails, from the Manhattan to the Mai Tai. Here, it jazzes up the Margarita, subbing in for orange liqueur, while reposado tequila stands in place of the typical blanco.
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with salt.
2. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the prepared glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a brûléed pineapple wedge, if desired.

title: Baby Guinness
intro_philosophy: When Ryan Waters, bar manager at the Abbey Tavern in Dublin, hears “Let’s do shots!” he knows that the drink of choice will most likely beBaby Guinness. The layered shot likely originated from a pub near a maternity hospital, where a bartender would serve new fathers the celebratory shot. Today, it’s a staple at bars across Ireland.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces coffee liqueur, such as Kahlúa
1/4 ounce cream liqueur, such as Baileys
instructions: 1. Pour the coffee liqueur into a shot glass. Carefully pour the cream liqueur on top.
2. The cream liqueur should float on top, but if it doesn’t, set an inverted spoon over the glass, then slowly pour the cream liqueur over the spoon.

title: Corn Sour
intro_philosophy: Despite the name, Mezcaleria Alma, a Mexico City-inspired bar in Denver and one of ourBest New Bars of 2025, has a list of spirits that goes far beyond just mezcal. The breadth of its library of bottles is showcased in its signature drink, which layers corn through four different spirits: a mezcal distilled with corn, a corn liqueur, a corn whiskey and pox, a spirit made from corn, sugar and wheat. Finished with a fluffy corn foam, it’s a crowdpleasing ode to Mexican cuisine, where maize has long been an influential ingredient.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce corn whiskey, such as Abasolo Corn Whiskey
1/2 ounce Corn Turbinado Syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake for approximately 10 seconds.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Top with the corn foam, then sprinkle 2-3 dashes of corn salt over top of foam.

title: French Tuxedo
intro_philosophy: Coating the interior of the glass with a particularly aromatic spirit before the drink is poured means extra fragrance even before the glass is lifted for a sip. (Plus, it adds a little extra flavor, and proof, to the finished cocktail.) While absinthe is usually the go-to rinsing agent, at San Antonio’sJuniper Tar, caraway-accentedkümmeladds extra aroma to a vodka-based variation on the classicTuxedo, eventually melding into the drink and creating the effect of a spiced gin, hold the juniper.
instructions: 1. Pour the kümmel into a Nick & Nora glass.
2. Swirl to coat the interior, then pour out the excess liquid and set aside.
3. Combine the remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
4. Strain into the prepared glass.
5. Serve with a demitasse spoon of caviar on the side.

title: Bar Tonique’s Ramos Gin Fizz
intro_philosophy: Though the original cocktail was supposedly shaken for a whole 12 minutes, Mark Schettler of New Orleans’ Bar Tonique suggests that five minutes of shaking this laborious, gin-based classic is plenty. Here, the bar’s recipe for the classic cocktail.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce citrus juice (1:1, lemon juice:lime juice)
1 1/2 ounces Old Tom gin, preferably Hayman's
3/4 ounce  triple sec, preferably Luxardo Triplum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the orange flower water in a shaker tin with ice.
2. Shake until well chilled.
3. Strain the drink between the two halves of the shaker tin to remove the ice, then shake again for five minutes without ice until thick and emulsified.
4. Pour the drink into a Collins glass and set aside until the meringue has separated from the liquid beneath, about five minutes.
5. Place a barspoon into the middle of the drink and carefully pour soda water along the spoon (so as not to deflate the meringue) until the meringue has risen above the rim of the glass.
6. Top with three drops of orange flower water.

title: Excellent Negus
intro_philosophy: A variation on the bishop, the negus is a spiced wine lengthened with the addition of water. The Dead Rabbit’s version, the Excellent Negus—an adaption from the 1869 book,Cooling Cups and Dainty Drinks—gets its kick from sherry and cognac sweetened with vanilla syrup and balanced with lemon and nutmeg. Less concentrated than the bishop, the negus is best enjoyed when served in a wine glass.
ingredients: 6 ounces  Excellent Negus mix (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Warm the Excellent Negus mix in a small saucepan and pour into a wine glass.
2. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.
3. Twist the lemon peel over the glass to express the oils, then discard the peel. Do the same with the orange peel.

title: Cardinal
intro_philosophy: Belonging to the ecclesiastic family of punches that also includes the Pope and theBishop, the Champagne-based Cardinal was a drink popular in the 18th and 19th centuries. This version is adapted from William Terrington’s 1869 recipe.
ingredients: 1 ounce spiced wine syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. To a coupe or flute glass, add the spiced wine syrup and lemon juice.
2. Top with Champagne.

title: Tranquilizer
intro_philosophy: Third place inour blind tasting of 10 different Painkiller recipeswent to Chris Coy, of the Inferno Room in Indianapolis, whose recipe similarly called on a split rum base of four expressions in equal half-ounce measures: Bounty Dark Rum and Bounty Spiced Rum from St. Lucia, pot-still Jamaican rum Worthy Park 109 and the Guyanese Hamilton Demerara rum. To that, he added three ounces of pineapple juice, two ounces of toasted coconut cream and one ounce of orange juice, all flash-blended and topped with an impressive arrangement of a pineapple fan, pineapple fronds, an orange wedge and an orchid. The coconut and rum harmonized well in almost Piña Colada–like fashion. As any Painkiller ought to be, Frizell dubbed it “a crowd-pleaser.”
ingredients: 2 ounces coconut cocktail syrup, preferably Liquid Alchemist Toasted Coconut
1/2 ounce aged rum, preferably Bounty Dark Rum
1/2 ounce spiced rum, preferably Bounty Spiced Rum
1/2 ounce aged Jamaican pot-still rum, preferably Worthy Park 109
1/2 ounce Demerara rum, preferably Hamilton Demerara Rum
instructions: 1. Flash-blend all ingredients with 1 cup pebble ice.
2. Top with grated nutmeg.
3. Garnish with pineapple fan, pineapple frond, orange wedge and and orchid.

title: Café di Riflessione
intro_philosophy: Translated as “reflection coffee,” this drink flash-infuses hot water with whole coffee beans along with fresh herbs, spices and citrus peels. That infusion is combined with amaro for a fragrant nightcap that, in chef Oldani’s words, is “really, really Italian.”
ingredients: 1 teaspoon spices, such as black peppercorns, cinnamon sticks or star anise
6 ounces water, hot but not boiling (70 to 75 degrees Celsius, or 158 to 167 degrees Fahrenheit)
1 tablespoon coffee beans, preferably Lavazza Kafa
instructions: 1. Place spices and citrus peels in a tea filter bag or cheesecloth secured with twine.
2. In a moka pot, combine hot water, coffee beans and spice bag. Steep for 3 1/2 to 4 minutes.
3. Strain infused water (passing through a coffee filter set in a wire strainer) into the glass.
4. Add amaro to glass, then rosemary sprig. Use the rosemary sprig to stir, then remove the sprig.

title: Improved Hot Toddy
intro_philosophy: What do you do when you desperately need a Hot Toddy and the lemons in your fridge are at least a month old? In the winter of 2017, instead of walking 50 feet from her apartment to re-up, PUNCH’s Talia Baiocchi grabbed a bottle of Bragg Apple Cider Vinegar—the answer to all that ails—and used it as a replacement. Big ups to necessity being the mother of invention: we’ll never look at the Hot Toddy the same way again.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a tempered mug, add hot water and stir until the syrup is dissolved.

title: Bobby Heugel’s Tequila Sunrise
intro_philosophy: The Tequila Sunrise rose to popularity when Americans were looking south of the border during Prohibition to find a decent cocktail. While sunrise recipes commonly call for orange juice, Bobby Heugel’s version reflects early accounts of the popular border beverage, which omit the fruit juice altogether, relying instead on a combination of cassis and grenadine. The tart and fruity elements of the cassis tend to bring out the fruitier notes in the tequila, making this a more complex take on the oft-maligned drink.
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, stir together the cassis and grenadine. Fill the glass with crushed ice.
2. In a shaker, combine the tequila and lemon juice and shake without ice.
3. Pour over ice into the glass, and garnish with a lemon slice and blackberry.

title: Navarrico
intro_philosophy: When Alf del Portillo and Marta Premoli decided to open Quattro Teste—a Lisbon bar merging del Portillo’s Basque roots and Premoli’s Italian heritage—they wanted to feature drinks that were popular in their homelands but “didn’t get the recognition they deserve” worldwide, according to del Portillo. The menu features aKalimotxoand anAngelo Azzurro, and del Portillo felt that a version of the Butano, an underrated Spanish drink, was a must-have. When he first tasted the highball, 20 years ago at the San Fermín festival, “the mix of the pacharán with orange soda was so refreshing that it blew my mind,” he recalls. This is del Portillo’s contemporary spin on the typically two-part drink.
ingredients: 4 ounces fluffy orange juice from a high-speed Breville juicer (alternately, use juice spun in a high-speed blender with 1 to 2 pieces of ice or agitated with a handheld frother)
3/4 ounce Italian bitter liqueur, preferably Martini & Rossi Bitter
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a highball glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Garnish with an orange wedge.

title: Rum Penicillin
intro_philosophy: Created by Liz Kelley, lead bartender at New Orleans’ Cure, the Rum Penicillin doesn’t stray far from the modern classic it’s based on, but a few key changes seamlessly bring the blueprint from fireside to poolside. As the name suggests, the most significant update comes via the rum base in lieu of the typical blended Scotch. At Cure, Kelley uses a special cask of Cheramie rum, a Louisiana-made agricole-style rum that’s funky, grassy and high-proof, blended for sibling bar Cane & Table. (Other aged rhum agricoles, such asLa Favorite Rhum Agricole Ambré and Neisson Élevé Sous Bois, can be used as substitutes.)Then she swaps the expected lemon for lime juice, bringing the drink closer to Daiquiri territory.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously.
2. Double-strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.
4. Finish with 3 sprays of peated Scotch from an atomizer.

title: Jelani Johnson’s Mojito
intro_philosophy: The winner of our recent Mojito tasting,Jelani Johnsontypically opts for a true Cuban rum in this cocktail, preferring Havana Club 3-year-old. Knowing that that product is not readily available, he opted for two ounces of Flor de Caña 4 Year Old, along with one ounce of simple syrup and a three-quarters of an ounce of lime juice, which he likes to hand squeeze in order to get some oil from the skin into the drink. Uniquely, Johnson calls on three types of ice—cracked, cubed and crushed—which served to keep the mint in place at the bottom of the glass and prevent over-dilution of the drink. The tasting panel liked the blend of ices and the richness of the rum, and found the drink to be refreshing, crisp and cold.
ingredients: 2 ounces light rum, preferably Havana Club 3 Year or Flor de Caña 4 Year
instructions: 1. In a pilsner glass, gently muddle the mint leaves in the simple syrup.
2. Add the lime juice and rum then stir to integrate.
3. Add three cracked ice cubes and three whole ice cubes.
4. Add the soda water and gently agitate with a bar spoon to integrate ingredients.
5. Top the glass with a small mound of crushed ice.
6. Garnish with a lavish plume of mint and a straw.

title: Blanka
intro_philosophy: Schmuck’sBlanka balances the sweet-tart flavor of Granny Smith apples with the earthiness of celery and a spicy kick of ginger, against the backdrop of an herbaceous gin and just enough absinthe. It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: heavy 1 1/2 ounces gin, such as Fords
2 1/2 ounces apple celery shrub (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and add ice.
2. Throw three times then strain over a large ice cube in a rocks glass.

title: Rémy Espresso
intro_philosophy: This luxurious take on the Espresso Martini spotlights Rémy Martin 1738 Accord Royal, whose rich depth of flavor perfectly complements the bold coffee notes the modern classic is known for without sacrificing the spirit of the original.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin, and shake with ice.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with coffee beans.

title: Grapefruit Cooler
intro_philosophy: Audrey Saunders was one of the most resolute gin advocates of the cocktail revival, putting the botanical spirit in countless original cocktails served at her pioneeringPegu Club, many of which went on to become modern classics, like theGin-Gin Muleand theFrench Pearl. But in 2015, 10 years after opening, Saunders debuted the vodka-based Grapefruit Cooler, a combination of grapefruit-flavored vodka, grapefruit syrup, lemon, mint, honey and two types of bitters, signaling a shift in vodka’s standing among the cocktail cognoscenti.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce ounce grapefruit syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and briefly muddle the mint.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Millionaire Cocktail
intro_philosophy:
The Millionaire Cocktail is not as romanticized as theSouthsideor as revered as aWhiskey Sour. Little is known about this Prohibition-era cocktail except that it was a popular name for cocktails of that time. We have found five different cocktails carrying the moniker, with recipes varying from whiskey to rum to gin. Even Harry Craddock, author ofThe Savoy Cocktail Book, listed two completely unrelated recipes as Millionaire Cocktail No. 1 and Millionaire Cocktail No. 2.
