The first consists of Jamaican rum, apricot brandy, sloe gin, lime juice and grenadine; the second includes anisette, egg white, gin and absinthe. We have provided the Millionaire recipe fromThe How and Whencocktail book by Hyman Gale and Gerald F. Marco, first printed in 1938. Although it inspired the name for our Billionaire Cocktail, we made some slight adjustments to the proportions and added lemon juice for balance.

Reprinted with permission fromSpeakeasyby Jason Kosmas and Dushan Zaric. Copyright (c) 2010 by Jason Kosmas and Dushan Zaric. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with freshly ground nutmeg.

title: Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s Amaretto Sour
intro_philosophy: Since the early days of the cocktail revival, the Amaretto Sour has been regarded as nothing more than the butt of a joke. In fact, the widespread ridicule of the liqueur and sour mix-based drink quickly became a banner cause for the movement, which was defined by fresh ingredients and a rejection of any cocktail created after 1950. ForJeffrey Morgenthaler, the blanket derision of what was once “just a drink that nobody had an opinion on,” never sat well with him. His revamped version adds a measure of overproof bourbon for backbone, while just the right amount of egg white adds the desired texture. This whiskey-inflected take is now often considered a modern classic.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce cask proof bourbon, preferably Booker's
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist and brandied cherry.

title: Garret Richard’s Blue Hawaii
intro_philosophy: “This drink telegraphs a specific time and place, 1950s and ’60s Hawaii,” says Garret Richard,a torchbearer for the modern tiki revival. “I felt it was my duty to craft a drink that brought guests back to that era with one sip.” Having served other people’s versions of the drink as well as his own personal riffs for years, Richard eventually went back to the drawing board. “I thought . . . maybe I should just take it back from square one and see what the true intention of this drink is,” he remembers. With this as his guiding principle, it took Richard more than a year to arrive at his perfected recipe, which hews closely to the original. The biggest departure comes in the form of coconut oil-washed gin in lieu of vodka, a move which nods to the rival Blue Hawaiian, a cobalt-tinted spin on thePiña Colada.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce coconut oil-washed gin, preferably Plymouth Gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin.
2. Flash-blend for 4 to 5 seconds with 4 ounces of crushed ice.
3. Pour into a hurricane glass over 8 ounces of crushed ice.
4. Garnish with sliced pineapple, pineapple fronds and an orchid.

title: Harvest Time
intro_philosophy:
Peated Scotch in a warm drink? Yes, but here the famous “peat reek” is balanced by plenty of robust (non-alcoholic) apple cider, ginger and citrus. The end result should show the peat as more of a gentle campfire glow than an all-out rager.

“The cocktail’s flavor profile mimics an apple,” says head bartender and beverage director Shawn Chen, “sweet, tart, crunchy and appetite-inducing, with a hint of smoke.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce peated Scotch, preferably BenRiach 10 Year Old Peated Curiositas
1/2 ounce ginger syrup (2:1, sugar:fresh ginger juice)
instructions: 1. Bring apple cider to a simmer in a medium saucepan.
2. Stir in Scotch, Campari, ginger syrup, and yuzu juice.
3. Remove from heat and pour into a heatproof mug or glass.
4. Garnish with a half lemon wheel studded with cloves and a sprinkle of cinnamon.

title: Iosepa
intro_philosophy: This cocktail takes its name from a settlement of Native Hawaiians in Utah. “Brigham Young, the Mormon prophet, invited Hawaiians over and promised them that they would live side by side with the white man and have prosperity and wealth, but when they got here, they were actually exiled to the West Desert,” explains Arianna Hone. The Iosepa draws on flavors central to Pacific Islander cooking—which she picked up during a stint bartending in Kauai—like passion fruit and Hawaiian chile peppers (which have since been replaced with habaneros, which are more easily sourced). “Being an Indigenous person myself, I think it’s important these stories get passed down.”
ingredients: 1 ounce habanero-infused Smith & Cross rum (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except mezcal in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Double-strain into a large rocks glass or Mason jar over a large ice cube.
3. Float the mezcal over the top of the drink.
4. Garnish with a fennel frond.

title: Jamaican Zombie
intro_philosophy: This powerhouse Zombie iteration from the aptly named Zombie Village in San Francisco situates the original blueprint firmly within Jamaica. Three Jamaican rums, including one that’s been infused with searing Scotch bonnet chili peppers—a staple in the island’s culinary tradition—combine with mango syrup, grapefruit and Doc’s Spice Syrup #2 to create the amped-up cornerstone classic.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged Jamaican rum, preferably Mezan XO Jamaican Rum
1 ounce Jamaican black rum, preferably Hamilton Jamaica Black
1/4 ounce scotch bonnet chili-infused rum, preferably Doctor Bird Jamaican Rum (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with crushed ice.
2. Blend with a Hamilton Beach spindle blender for 2 to 4 seconds.
3. Pour into Zombie glass.
4. Garnish with a pineapple leaf, dehydrated lime wheel and a speared pineapple ball dusted with Tajin seasoning.

title: Campari & Soda
intro_philosophy:
In Italy, the Campari & Soda is a popular drink with democratic appeal, due to its simple yet stylish nature that comfortably travels the high-low spectrum. Whether you’re stirring one up at home, starting the evening at a restaurant, or looking for a last-call option at a dive bar, you can count on a bottle of Campari and cold soda water being at the ready. This, combined with its bittersweet and bubbly profile, has bartenders in the States, like Jack Schramm, championing the cocktail. “It hits every single mark that I need in a beverage,” he says. “It’s a perfect drink.”

As with any highball, the fewer ingredients in a drink, the more to consider—from glassware and garnish to ice and temperature to the type of sparkling water. The recipe here is a nod to the iconic serve at the drink’s birthplace, the historic Camparino in Galleria in the heart of Milan, where the glass and bottle of Campari are kept in the freezer for the most satisfying results.
ingredients: 6 ounces  ice-cold seltzer or club soda
instructions: 1. Add the chilled Campari to a frozen highball glass.
2. Top with seltzer or club soda.

title: Fives’ Rebujito
intro_philosophy: Common in Andalusia and elsewhere around Spain, the Rebujito is typically a simple mix of sherry and sparkling lemonade or lemon-lime soda. James O’Donnell, the bar manager at Fives in New Orleans, makes his version with fino sherry and housemade Key lime cordial. “At its core, it’s a simple and refreshing beverage to cut the summer heat here in New Orleans,” he says.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Key lime cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a highball glass over ice, and gently stir to combine.
2. Garnish with mint and a lemon wheel.

title: Milano-Torino Sour
intro_philosophy: The most minimalist entry to the aperitivo canon, the two-ingredientMilano-Torino, or “Mi-To” as it’s affectionately known, is also one of the mostflexible templates. Typically comprising equal parts Campari and sweet vermouth, the drink shines when personalized as Dan Sabo demonstrates here with a base of Campari and dry vermouth, which gets the sour treatment courtesy of both grapefruit and lime juice and an egg white for a frothy finish.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe.

title: MSG Martini
intro_philosophy: At Bonnie’s in Brooklyn, chef Calvin Eng was sure he wanted MSG on the menu, and incorporating it into a dirtyMartinifelt like a “perfect fit,” according toChanning Centeno, who developed the drinks program there. “It’s been a fight within the Asian American community for years and years and years, so I thought it’d be really fun to not just have MSG as an ingredient, but MSG in the name,” Centeno says. In the cocktail, MSG olive brine ups the umami for a dirty Martini “that makes you want to go back for more.”
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces gin, such as Botanist, or vodka, such as Grey Goose
1 ounce Bonnie’s MSG-olive brine (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Martini or coupe glass.
3. Garnish with 3 Castelvetrano olives.

title: Rye and Dry
intro_philosophy: Built on a rye base complemented by apple cordial, this autumnal highball is dispensed directly from an iSi at London’s Three Sheets.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces 30&40 Double Jus Aperitif de Normandie
instructions: 1. Mix all ingredients together, then refrigerate until well-chilled. Also refrigerate the liter-sized iSi canister.
2. Add the chilled liquid batch to the canister, charge it with one CO2 cartridge, then shake vigorously.
3. Allow the mix to rest for 20 minutes, then charge with another CO2 cartridge and shake a couple of times.
4. Rest in the refrigerator for as long as possible—at least 20 minutes—then de-gas the canister by pressing the trigger valve to boil off the CO2.
5. Unscrew the cap and gently pour the drink into a highball glass over ice. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Kiss the Boys Goodbye
intro_philosophy: Three years ago, Alessandro “Alex” Pisi took an online class with David Wondrich, where he first heard about theKiss the Boys Goodbye, a drink dating to the World War II era that was originally published inEsquire’s Handbook for Hosts(1949). Pisi brought the spec from the class to The Wells in D.C., where he’s the lead bartender. Pisi loves the split base of Cognac and sloe gin, along with the smooth and frothy one-two punch of the simple syrup and egg white. “It’s like laying on a bed with silk sheets, but on top you have a goose-feather duvet.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
2. Seal the shaker and dry-shake.
3. Add ice, and shake to chill.
4. Strain into a coupe.
5. To garnish, apply the bitters in the shape of a heart.

title: Coda di Leone
intro_philosophy: “This is my Italian Lion’s Tail,” explains Ward. The name means Lion’s Tail in Italian, and showcases Italy’samari—specifically, Sibona, a relatively bitter amaro that dries out this traditionally rich cocktail and adds complexity.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon, preferably Evan Williams Black Label
1/2 ounce allspice dram, preferably St. Elizabeth's
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Nuyorican Sour
intro_philosophy: “As a proud Boricua, I always try to find ways to incorporate my own culture [into] whatever I create,” saysAntonio Jimenez, head bartender at Bolo in Philadelphia. This take on the New York Sour, a Whiskey Sour variation topped with a float of red wine, is no exception. Made with a Puerto Rican rum—“my hometown rum,” says Jimenez—and an amaro from Brooklyn, this recipe pays homage to the Puerto Rican diaspora in New York City.
ingredients: 1 ounce  aged Puerto Rican rum, preferably Ron del Barrilito Three Stars
instructions: 1. In a tin, combine the rum, egg white, rye, juices, syrup and amaro.
2. Dry-shake for 30 seconds, then add ice to the tin and shake for 8 seconds.
3. Strain into a rocks glass with ice.
4. Top with wine, then add dashes of bitters.

title: Adonis
intro_philosophy: Of the stirred aperitif drinks of the 19thcentury that involvesherry, there are really two archetypes that are riffed on ad nauseum: the Bamboo and the Adonis. Both offer clues to their body type. TheBamboois lean and tough, the Adonis, a sort of classical beefcake—the brawnier of the two. The drinks, even when variations are applied, still split in two different directions. The Adonis was named after the 1884 Broadway burlesque show by William Gill calledAdonis, which is often credited as the first-ever Broadway musical. While the production enjoyed its popularity, the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City created a cocktail in its honor, using a base of sherry together with orange bitters and sweet vermouth. To this day it remains one of the most successful sherry-based aperitif cocktails in the classic canon.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Umami Grog
intro_philosophy: In cuisine, miso finds its way into marinades, dressings, broths and even pasta sauces, and as a cocktail ingredient, it enjoys a similar versatility. “I’ve had amazing results blending miso paste directly into sugar-, maple- or honey-based syrups to add a weighted richness and viscosity to classic sours and flips, but also to add complexity to tiki and tropical cocktail builds,” says Brian Evans, director of bars for Sunday Hospitality Group. In his Umami Grog, he combines a miso-honey mix and mushroom-infused rum. “The infused rum…, citrus and honeyed miso all come together to form a nostalgic flavor reminiscent of baked banana bread,” says Evans.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce white crème de cacao, preferably Giffard
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Shake, then strain into a rocks glass over pebble ice.
3. Garnish with mint and enoki mushrooms.

title: Bitter Giuseppe
intro_philosophy: A cult favorite within the modern classic amaro cocktail canon, Stephen Cole’s Bitter Giuseppe, created at Chicago’s Violet Hour, uses Cynar as the foundation. The cocktail can be enjoyed as an aperitivo or an after-dinner digestivo and is one of several rule-breaking modern cocktails that gets stirred, rather than shaken, despite the inclusion of fresh lemon juice.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Kevin Armstrong’s Satan’s Whiskers
intro_philosophy: Unsatisfiedwith the classic Satan’s Whiskers recipe as specified in Harry Craddock’s 1930TheSavoy Cocktail Book, Kevin Armstrong, owner of the London bar of the same name, tweaked the original to make it more palatable for his discerning guests. “It’s not god’s gift to classic cocktails,” he admits, but Armstrong’s version is as good as a Satan’s Whiskers gets without completely reconceptualizing the drink. He notes that, because the characteristics of fresh citrus vary from batch to batch, his recipe may need to be adjusted “with a little extra lemon, sugar or even gin.” The key is to taste the first round and adjust accordingly.
ingredients: heavy 3/4 ounce higher-proof London dry gin, preferably Tanqueray
heavy 1/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat
heavy 1/4 ounce orange liqueur, preferably Grand Marnier
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients, including the orange slice, to a cocktail shaker with ice.
2. Vigorously shake for less time than is typical to avoid adding too much water.
3. Double-strain into a chilled coupe and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Basil Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Sommelier Shelley Lindgren came upon a Basil Gimlet made with vodka while visiting the Boston restaurant Via Matta and shared the news with her husband, Greg Lindgren, owner of the San Francisco bar Rye. The idea was a perfect fit for San Francisco, where bartenders loved to use fresh produce in their cocktails. Substituting gin for vodka, Lindgren put the drink on his menu and, for a few years thereafter, the Basil Gimlet was ubiquitous throughout San Francisco.
instructions: 1. Muddle the basil leaves in the bottom of a cocktail shaker.
2. Add all other ingredients and ice.
3. Shake until chilled, about 15 seconds.
4. Fine strain into a chilled coupe and garnish with a basil leaf.

title: Peachy Keen
intro_philosophy: Chef-owner Steve McHugh is a huge fan of mesquite, using it for both savory and sweet applications in the kitchen, as well as at Cured’s bar. He likens this drink to “peach cobbler” for its flavor profile of “graham cracker, caramel and warm spice.” Texas’s famous Hill Country peaches play a starring role alongside white rum infused with mesquite flour.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mesquite-infused white rum (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle the peaches and mint.
2. Add the rum and ice and shake until chilled.
3. Double strain into a Collins glass filled with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with three peach slices and a mint sprig.

title: Ken Burns Effect
intro_philosophy: Erick Castro likes pairing sweet PX sherry with darker spirits, especially Cognac, rum and whiskey. Inspired by the 1934 book,Pioneers of Mixing at Elite Bars, his Ken Burns Effect is a riff on the Manhattan that replaces vermouth with Dry Sack sherry, a blend of Oloroso and PX and maraschino liqueur. “The raisin, toffee and caramel flavors contributed by the Pedro Ximenéz in the sherry mix so well with the spice already found in the rye whiskey,” says Castro.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir.
2. Strain and pour into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Sunday Mass
intro_philosophy:
At Las Perlas in Downtown L.A., bartender Nikki Sunseri’s Sunday Mass is an innovative mix of mezcal, citrus and fig and rosewater simple syrup, served on the rocks and garnished with chicharrón salt and rose petals.

“This drink is dark, austere and has the characteristics of smoke, roses and roasted pork,” says Sunseri, which adds up to an unorthodox response to the increasingly common “something smoky” call.
ingredients: 2 ounces mezcal, preferably El Silencio Espadín
1 ounce fig and rosewater syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in shaker with ice and shake.
2. Strain contents of shaker over ice into rocks glass rimmed with chicharrón salt.
3. Garnish with rose petals.

title: Miso Dark ‘n’ Stormy
intro_philosophy: A subterranean homage to a vinyl-spinning Japanese izakaya, New York’s Tokyo Record Bar features a rolling, antique bar cart, upon which low-ABV cocktails are made tableside. Among them is the Miso Dark & Stormy, a savory, bubbly drink built on shochu, yuzu, miso syrup and Cynar.
instructions: 1. Combine shochu, miso syrup and yuzu in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Top with soda and Cynar float.

title: San Pancho
intro_philosophy: “Manzanilla and strawberries are very good friends,” explains Caitlin Laman, a recent Mexico City transplant by way of San Francisco’s Trick Dog, who combines the two for her south-of-the-border spin on a simple Collins recipe. Named after the Mexican moniker for San Francisco (Laman’s former hometown and a common place-name in Mexico), the San Pancho swaps the typical gin base for subtler sherry to better balance the floral notes of St-Germain. Made tall with a measure of soda water, the San Pancho is designed for all-day drinking.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces manzanilla sherry, preferably La Cigarrera
instructions: 1. Shake all of the ingredients except the soda water.
2. Double strain into a Collins glass.
3. Add ice, top with the soda water, quick stir then garnish.

title: Cynar and Kola
intro_philosophy: A natural curiosity for employing alternative acids in cocktails led New York bartender Orlando Franklin McCray on a self-described “kola nut kick.” This, coupled with his continued desire to “make highballs a little more interesting but not at all complicated,” brought about his inventive take on the Cynar and Cola recipe found the back label of the Cynar bottle, which he spikes with his own version of cola syrup. “I wanted to make it my way,” says McCray, who, like many bartenders, is drawn to amaro for its versatility as a modifier, a base ingredient or simply a cocktail in and of itself, to be enjoyed neat.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Kola Cane Syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients except the soda water in a mixing tin filled with ice. Shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a Collins glass, then add hand-cracked ice.
3. Top with soda water, and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Voulez Vous Carré
intro_philosophy: Veteran bartender Katie Stipe was an early adopter of infusing spirits with cacao nibs to add depth to her cocktails. She asserts that nibs provide “a nice way to add coffee notes without adding actual caffeine.” She uses the nibs, along with chicory, to infuse the brandy for her Voulez Vous Carré, a Vieux Carré riff she currently serves at Voysey in Portland, Oregon, in which the infused brandy joins bonded rye, vanilla-heavy Carpano Antica and the traditionalBénédictine. She appreciates the “Café du Monde flavor profile” the infusion bestows on the drink, referencing the strong chicory-laced coffee at the famous New Orleans beignet spot.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce chicory- and cacao nib-infused brandy (see Editor's Note)
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: The Rule of Thirds Chu-Hai
intro_philosophy: Thechu-hai, an izakaya staple, is gaining ground stateside as a versatile, low-ABV showcase for Japan’s native spirit, shochu. At Brooklyn’s Rule of Thirds, a standard house mixture of soda, grapefruit and hojicha syrup acts as a unifying backdrop for different iterations of the spirit. “So far, we haven’t found a shochu that the blueprint didn’t work with,” says Evans.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweetened hojicha tea (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Build in a Collins glass over cubed ice.
2. Top with club soda, then stir to combine.

title: Metropolitan
intro_philosophy: TheMetropolitanis a true relic of the late 19th century, when vermouth made a big splash in the world of American mixology. Though it originally called for French vermouth and brandy, the 1910s saw it morph into something more like a brandy Manhattan with sweet vermouth. At Madeira Park in Atlanta, bar manager Philip Weltner serves a version with Calvados in place of the Cognac and a combination of three different vermouths.
ingredients: 1 ounce Calvados, such as Chauffe Coeur VSOP
1 ounce sherry-based vermouth, such as Navazos Palazzi Vermut Rojo
1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Bordiga Rosso
2 dashes aromatic bitters, such as Bogart’s
2 dashes lemon bitters, such as Bitter Truth
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a frozen mixing glass with ice and stir until well chilled.
2. Strain into a frozen Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Frosé Margarita
intro_philosophy: Classic and new-wave come together in this Team Lyan recipe that makes use of Zoë Van Der Grinten’s “Guilty Pleasures” Rosé, for a fermented mash-up of rosé and the Margarita.
ingredients: 4 ounces wildflower honey water (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender with two scoops of crushed ice and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into coupette glasses and garnish with a wheel of lime.

title: Dan Sabo’s Mojito
intro_philosophy: Although Dan Sabo splits the base between two rum bottlings for complexity in his version of the Mojito, this drink also works well with a simple two-ounce measure of Caña Brava or another preferred blanco rum.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  rich simple syrup (2:1; sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Place the mint leaves in a Collins glass. Muddle the leaves gently, pressing lightly 2 to 3 times to release the oils without breaking down the leaves.
2. Add the rums, lime juice and rich simple syrup to the glass.
3. Fill the glass three-quarters of the way with crushed ice.
4. Swizzle, using a swizzle stick or a barspoon.
5. Top with a splash of club soda, and top up with crushed ice, making a small mound on top.
6. Garnish with a mint sprig, and tuck a straw in next to the mint.

title: Rosemary Gin & Tonic
intro_philosophy: The classic Gin & Tonic gets winterized with the addition of aromatic rosemary and sweet-sour grapefruit shrub, making it a more appropriate blizzard companion than the original.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce grapefruit shrub (preferably Shrub & Co., or see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, muddle shrub with a sprig of rosemary.
2. Add gin and ice.
3. Top with tonic.
4. Garnish with a sprig of rosemary and a grapefruit wheel.

title: Spiced Sangria
intro_philosophy: You won’t find the traditional red wine in this wintertime sangria, but a healthy pour of rum and a bright pop of orange-forward aperitivo bitters more than make up for its absence. “The Spiced Sangria is my quick version of a traditional sangria, without any sacrifices to quality and flavor,” says Victoria. The three types of ginger used in the Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale are responsible for the “fresh green, chocolatey, and earthy flavor” of this aromatic and spicy long drink.
instructions: 1. Add the rum and Aperol to a Collins glass, then fill the glass with ice cubes.
2. Top with Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale.
3. Garnish with a cinnamon stick and orange wedge.

title: James Bolt’s Gin and Tonic
intro_philosophy: Third place in our recent Gin and Tonic tasting was won by James Bolt of The Gin Joint in Charleston, who used two ounces of Nikka Coffey Gin and twice as much Boylan Heritage tonic water, with a makrut lime leaf garnish. The surprising citrus flavors present in theJapanese ginhelped the drink stand out for the judges.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, preferably Nikka Coffey Gin
4-6 ounces tonic water, preferably Boylan Heritage
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over Kold Draft ice.
2. Garnish with a slightly bruised makrut lime leaf.

title: Phil Collins
intro_philosophy: From Boston’s The Hawthorne comes Jackson Cannon’s cucumber vodka-and-Chartreuse highball, the Phil Collins, which mixes music with wordplay. Developed in jest, the drink has become so popular that the bar now hosts a party each year commemorating the Genesis singer’s birthday.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces cucumber vodka, preferably Square One
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in shaker with ice and shake.
2. Strain into Collins glass and top with soda.

title: Peel Slowly and See
intro_philosophy: Kristy Bevis of Odette combines reposado tequila with Giffard Banane du Brésil and cinnamon syrup for a dessert-like spin on theMargarita.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces reposado tequila, preferably El Jimador
1 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banana du Brésil
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with cracked ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: High Borghese
intro_philosophy: Named for the eponymous park in Rome, Jon Mullen likens his High Borghese to “a refreshing smash.” Gin, lemon cordial and lemon juice are shaken with Suze, a French gentian liqueur and fermented tomato brine—the byproduct of the kitchen’s fermentation process. The result is, in Mullen’s words, “an elevated vegetal and herbal drink.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Chaotic Neutral
intro_philosophy: In a moral alignment chart, chaotic neutral represents people who feel free from both societal restraints and one’s own ethical imperatives. In Lauren Corriveau’s cocktail, a Daiquiri riff named after this moral alignment, Owney’s rum and St. George raspberry brandy meet alongside a mixture of lime and red pepper juices.
instructions: 1. Rim a double rocks glass with smoked salt and set aside.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Martin Cate’s Peachtree Punch
intro_philosophy: As one of the first contemporary bartenders to apply the craft cocktail principles of quality ingredients and diligent technique to the tiki template, Martin Cate rejiggered this 1970s Trader Vic recipe one ingredient at a time. Where the original calls for canned peach halves, Cate opts for fresh. He also adds lemon juice for an extra jolt of acidity, while natural peach liqueur replaces schnapps and a house-made coconut cream stands in for store-bought.
ingredients: 1/2 white or yellow peach, pitted and coarsely chopped
1 ounce Smuggler's Cove coconut cream (see Editor's Note)
1/4 ounce peach liqueur, preferably Mathilde or Combier Crème de Pêche de Vigne
instructions: 1. In a mixing tin, add the first three ingredients and muddle the peach.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and flash blend with stand-up mixer.
3. Double strain into a double Old-Fashioned or pilsner glass filled with cracked or cubed ice.
4. Garnish with grated nutmeg and a peach wedge.

title: Improved Whiskey Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Before the introduction of such baroque ingredients as maraschino liqueur andabsinthe, every cocktail was built like anOld-Fashioned—a simple mix of spirits, sugar, bitters and water. The Old-Fashioned was only christened when fanciful ingredients started popping up and devotees of the old school were forced to specify their preference for a whiskey cocktail “the old fashioned way,” sans fruit garnish or new-fangled European spirits. “Improved” cocktails subsequently featured a sweet liqueur and lemon swathed around the rim of a glass, and the Improved Whiskey Cocktail, the most enduring of them all, remains a window into a moment in cocktail history when drinks were progressing to a more complex level.
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, muddle sugar cube (or sugar or simple syrup) with maraschino, bitters and absinthe.
2. Add whiskey and stir.
3. Add ice (preferably a large cube) and stir until well chilled.
4. Garnish with a lemon or orange peel.

title: The Last Laugh
intro_philosophy: Created by Abigail Gullo, now withCompère Lapinin New Orleans, this Last Word variation is so named, Gullo says, because “the bubbles tickle your nose.”
instructions: 1. Add first four ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice, cover and shake well.
3. Strain into a champagne flute.
4. Top with cava and garnish with a lime twist.

title: Jelani Johnson’s Irish Coffee
intro_philosophy: Taking third place in our recent blind tasting of Irish Coffee recipes, Jelani Johnson’s version of the drink calls on flavored whipped cream, which adds an extra dimension to this recipe.
ingredients: 2 ounces Irish whiskey, preferably Powers Gold Label
1 ounce whipped cream mix (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Pour a small amount of boiling water into a glass coffee mug to heat it.
2. In a mixing tin, combine the coffee, whiskey and sugar and nestle the tin in the mug to heat it while preparing the whipped cream mixture.
3. Discard the hot water and pour the whiskey-coffee mixture into the mug.
4. Float the cream mixture over the top.
5. Garnish with freshly grated cinnamon.

title: Paddy O’Brien’s Last Word
intro_philosophy: Our 2018 Last Word tasting had a fairy-tale ending when the recipe from The Last Word, a cocktail bar in Queens, New York, won top honors. The recipe, by Paddy O’Brien, was straightforward aside from the gin. O’Brien bumps up its measure from three-quarters of an ounce to a full ounce, and uses the fairly obscure Warwick Rustic Gin, a juniper-forward craft spirit from New York state that was unfamiliar to the panel. Still, the judges found it piquant and well-integrated, with a creamy middle palate and pleasing lower-register notes throughout.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. (There will be excess liquid for a sidecar.)
3. Garnish the sidecar with a maraschino cherry and serve alongside.

title: Blood Moon
intro_philosophy: The Blood Moon is just one example of Joe Campanale’s ode toaperitivo, on display throughout the menu at Alta Linea. A combination of amaro, tonic and lemon, it ticks all the right boxes: bitter, low-alcohol and most importantly, transportive.
ingredients: 3 ounces tonic water, preferably Fever Tree
instructions: 1. Build in a wine glass over ice and garnish with a orange half-moon

title: Monaco Highball
intro_philosophy: French and Italian ingredients come together in this refreshing homage to the Mediterranean. The floral and citrus notes of Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic Water lighten the bitter notes of amaro from a small producer in Italy and the warm fruit tones of Calvados.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  Liquore delle Sirene Canto Amaro
Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic Water, to top
instructions: 1. Add the first two ingredients to a Collins glass filled with ice.
2. Top with Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic Water, and stir to combine.
3. Twist the lemon peel over the top of the drink to express essential oils, then use to garnish.

title: Will Pasternak’s Piña Colada
intro_philosophy: Third place in our recent blind tasting of Piña Coladas went to Will Pasternak from the Cuba-themed bar BlackTail in New York. There, the drink is served directly from a slushy machine, but his scaled-down rendition consists of 1 ¼ ounces Bacardi Havana Club Añejo Blanco, 1 ½ ounces Coco Lopez, 1 ¾ ounces pineapple juice and ¼ ounce lime juice, blended.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce Puerto Rican rum, preferably Bacardi Havana Club Anejo Blanco
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a Hurricane glass and serve with a straw.

title: Winterized Negroni
intro_philosophy: “I had never thought of Scotch and gin as such an agreeable flavor duo until stumbling across Michael Madrusan’s Death & Taxes cocktail, which was an enlightening blend of robust and malty flavors of blended Scotch rounding out the sharp, botanical edges of a London dry gin,” says New York bar director Brian Evans. Today, Evans’ favorite hack for adding depth to a Negroni is to add a half-teaspoon of Islay Scotch. It’s a technique used in a complex riff,the Hashira, at Rule of Thirds, but it also works in a more classic build like this, too.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi di Torino
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: Doppio Spritz
intro_philosophy: Joe Campanale’s Doppio Spritz was the winner of our recent blind spritz tasting. Making use of two different aperitivos—one classically Italian and one from Brooklyn—his formula is fairly straightforward, but omits prosecco in favor of tonic water for an extra gentian kick.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with orange wedge and green olive.

title: Kingdom of Savoy
intro_philosophy: The Kingdom of Savoy takes Nathan McCarley-O’Neill’s signature tack of defying expectations by looking one way and tasting another. “When people order this off the menu, nobody really knows what to expect,” he says. “It doesn’t really read like a drink that you’re going to like straight away.” A combination of absinthe, Nardini Amaro, Branca Menta, pineapple, lime and coconut syrup, it reads like a tiki drink by way of Europe. “The idea was to kind of not necessarily go down the route of rum, but to try and build off a multitude of different flavors.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake briefly with ice.
2. Strain into a Belgium beer glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with pineapple fronds and a mint bouquet.

title: The Infante
intro_philosophy: The Infante, a Margarita riff that introduces aromatic orgeat and rose water, shows how far the cantina staple has traveled. Named after Mexican actor Pedro Infante, the recipe was created in New York City by Giuseppe González, a testament to the way that craft cocktail circles have adopted the refreshing classic and made it their own.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with freshly ground nutmeg.

title: Josh Goldman’s Paloma
intro_philosophy: Coming in second in our blind Paloma tasting, Josh Goldman, of Bar Caló in Los Angeles, poured Squirt over 2 ounces of Siembra Azul tequila, 1/2 ounce lime juice and a pinch of sea salt—all built in the glass. The panel liked the drink for its traditional, stand-up profile.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Siembra Azul
instructions: 1. Add the tequila, lime juice and a pinch of salt into a Collins glass over ice.
2. Top with Squirt.
3. Garnish with a thick wedge of grapefruit.

title: Christine Wiseman’s Godfather
intro_philosophy: The Godfather may haverecently made its unlikely comeback, but according to Miami’s Christine Wiseman, it should be more widely acclaimed. When made with a tropical-leaning Scotch, like her preferred whisky for the drink, Dewar’s 12, the dive bar staple is “delightful” year-round, she says, whether it’s by the fireplace or the pool. Riffs on the drink abound, but Wiseman keeps her spec simple with just two ingredients to let the Scotch shine.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to chill.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Watermelon Rind Cordial
intro_philosophy: Despite being a key element in many easy-drinking cocktails, watermelon is more finicky than one might imagine. “The pink flesh doesn’t sit well in drinks,” says Kelsey Ramage, of the sustainability-mindedTrash Collective, describing the way watermelon’s “pink scum” tends to float atop drinks. Watermelon juice, meanwhile, is a delicate ingredient that, when mixed with alcohol, tends to change or “burn.” Trash Collective’s Watermelon Rind Cordial provides a solution to these issues, while making use of rinds that would otherwise be considered waste.
ingredients: 200 grams watermelon rinds, washed and cut into 2- to 4-inch pieces
instructions: 1. In a Cambro or large container, add watermelon rinds and cover with sugar.
2. Seal the container and refrigerate for 12 to 24 hours.
3. After resting, most of the sugar should have dissolved into a liquid; stir any remaining sugar.
4. Add the entire mixture to a blender or Vitamix, and blend until the sugar has completely dissolved. Water can be added to reach the desired consistency.
5. Pass the mixture through a fine-mesh strainer and store in a large container. Refrigerated, this cordial has a shelf life of 1 to 2 days, and it is not recommended to batch with alcohol.

title: The Pastry War’s Michelada
intro_philosophy: The Pastry War’s take on the Michelada is the OG in overdrive: a house blend of sweet, citrus, and spice topped with a dose of Mexican lager.
ingredients: 7 ounces beer, preferably a seven-ounce Dos Equis
instructions: 1. Rim a pint glass with chili pequin salt.
2. Squeeze half a lime into glass and put expressed lime into the glass.
3. Add Michelada mix.
4. Add beer.
5. Top with crushed ice.

title: Stroopwafel Syrup
intro_philosophy: The combination of malt powder, vanilla and honey is reminiscent of Dutch stroopwafel, a warm, wafer-thin sandwich cookie filled with caramel. The inclusion of malt powder evokes the essence of waffles hot off the iron without the heaviness of a cream and butter-based caramel sauce. Include it in your rotation of winterized whiskey and rum-based drinks, or let it pair naturally with eggnog. For a more dessert-leaning option, drizzle some over a Nocino-spiked affogato.
ingredients: 1 tablespoon glucose syrup, corn syrup, honey, agave syrup or golden syrup
instructions: 1. In a small bowl combine sugar, ¼ cup water and glucose or other syrup. Transfer mixture to a small pot and set over medium heat.

2. While sugar mixture is heating prepare malt water. Mix malt powder and salt with ½ cup hot water whisking well until completely dissolved. Then add ½ cup cold water to cool mixture down. Whisk in vanilla bean paste.

3. Cook until sugar mixture is a deep amber, swirling the pan to encourage even coloring once it begins to caramelize. When you see a small portion of the deepest amber begin to smoke, that's your queue to remove the pot from the heat and add your prepared malted water. Be careful as caramel may spudder, whisk to combine, the mixture may seize a bit. If this happens you can return the pot to low heat just to fully dissolve.
4. Let cool to room temperature and transfer to a container until ready to use. Best if used within 1 month, keep refrigerated but is easier to work with if at room temp.

title: Chupetini
intro_philosophy: Created at Brooklyn’s Llama Inn, theChupetinifinds a way to feel decidedly of-the-moment yet instantly classic. Served in an irresistible diminutive glass, the frosty, unconventional serve recalls one of the most iconic Martinis of all: theshot-glass MartiniofHarry’s Bar in Venice. The drink itself is classic, too—a simple 2:1 ratio of Japanese gin to dry vermouth—but with a thoroughly modern twist courtesy of an “umami bomb” infusion. For a traditionally sized serving, simply double the recipe.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Umami Bomb infused vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a small, chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a blue cheese–stuffed olive.

title: Ranch 616 Ranch Water
intro_philosophy: When restaurant owner Kevin Williamson found himself adding bubbly Topo Chico to extend the life of his Margarita, he discovered a new drink. His Ranch Water has now been on the Ranch 616 menu for 15 years—and can be made as strong or as bubbly as the drinker desires.
ingredients: 1 ounce orange liqueur, such as Patrón Citrónge
1 bottle Topo Chico sparkling mineral water
instructions: 1. Add tequila, orange liqueur and lime juice to a Collins glass.
2. Add ice and stir until cold.
3. Top with Topo Chico to desired taste and continue to add while drinking.

title: Frozen Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: When a supermodel asked him to create a drink that would “wake her up, then fuck her up,” Dick Bradsell famously created theEspresso Martini. This frozen riff on the modern classic calls on a mixture of coconut cream and coconut milk to balance the intensity of Borghetti Espresso Liqueur and adds a final bracing kick by way of a Fernet-Branca float.
ingredients: 1 ounce  coconut mix (3:1, Coco Lopez:coconut milk)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Top with a Fernet-Branca float.

title: Winter Waltz
intro_philosophy: Though winter weather is fleeting in New Orleans,French 75 Bar‘s Chris Hannah created a near-perfect winter foil with his whiskey-based spice bomb, the Winter Waltz. Dark and bittersweet Averna amaro combines with the bracing spice of rye whiskey and warm cinnamon and nutmeg aromas of St. Elizabeth Allspice Dram for a cocktail of modern classic proportions.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a star anise.

title: Tiny Sparrow Martini
intro_philosophy: Created for the first bar program Kitty Bernardo ran in New York City in 2023, this simple, thoughtful Martini variation might seem like a surprise coming from a bartender at Paradise Lost, better known for a maximalist approach to drink-making. But according toBernardo, the simplicity of the drink aligns with a style of bartending they have been developing since moving to New York in 2018, and reflects the types of drinks they personally enjoy. Inspired by their late best friend, who pushed them to pursue their passion for bartending, the Tiny Sparrow Martini “is a love letter to our friendship—this cocktail combines elements of both our Vietnamese and Filipino cultures, creating a more sessionable and unapologetically Southeast Asian Martini.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce calamansi liqueur, preferably Manille Liqueur de Calamansi
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir for approximately 60 revolutions.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass, keeping the sidecar chilled on ice.
3. Garnish with a lime twist.

title: Cuba Libre
intro_philosophy: The Cuban War of Independence began in 1895 and ended with Spain turning the reins over to the United States in 1898. Soon after, a flood of soldiers—and a flood of Coca-Cola to keep them satiated—landed on the island with the ingredients for one of the 20th century’s most ordered (and derided) drinks: the rum and coke. Named somewhat ironically for the rebel cry, “Vive Cuba libre!” the Cuba Libre is a perfect marriage of Cuba and America’s liquid sensibilities: good rum mingled with the unmistakable smack of Coke, lightened with a squeeze of fresh lime. The true Cuba Libre can now legally be consumed in the US, so go find yourself some Havana Club and a sixer of Mexican Coke and rejoice.
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, add rum and squeeze in lime halves.
2. Add ice and top with Coca-Cola.
3. Stir gently to combine.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel or slice.

title: Space Face
intro_philosophy: “Pineapple and mint is always such a great combination,” says Julia McKinley of the key flavors in her contemporary take on a sour. “That’s definitely a tiki influence,” she says, citing similarities between this drink and theMissionary’s Downfall. In place of a rum base, however, McKinley opts for a split between tequila and a particularly floral blanco vermouth that complements the grassy notes of the agave spirit while lowering the overall ABV. For the sweetener, McKinley relies on a honey-créme de menthe mixture bolstered by pineapple gum syrup. “Pineapple can just be such a multiplier of flavors,” she says. “It links things together in a really beautiful way.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Pueblo Viejo
1 ounce blanco vermouth, preferably La Pivón
1/2 ounce pineapple gum syrup, preferably Small Hand Foods
1/4 ounce honey-mint sweetener (2:1, honey:créme de menthe)
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, add the mint and lime wedge and muddle.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and shake with ice.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a large mint bouquet.

title: Paddington
intro_philosophy:
Those who have stepped through the phone booth at Crif Dogs intoPDTknow all about the bowler-hatted bear looming over the bar. That’s Paddington. “David Slape, the drink’s creator, was the first bartender I hired to work at PDT,” says owner Jim Meehan. “The Paddington is aHemingway Daiquirivariation of sorts made with orange marmalade, the fictional Paddington Bear’s treat of choice.” It’s appeared on nearly every PDT menu since its inception.

Reprinted with permission fromThe PDT Cocktail Book© 2011 by Jim Meehan, Sterling Epicure an imprint of Sterling Publishing Co., Inc.
instructions: 1. Add a dash of absinthe to a coupe or cocktail glass. Swirl to rinse, discard and set aside.
2. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker, add ice and shake.
3. Strain into absinthe-rinsed glass and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Bahama Mama
intro_philosophy: Tiki master Paul McGee’s recalibrated version of this mid-20th century classic involves dialing down the proportions and sweetness to yield an integrated, rum-forward cocktail with a skillfull layering of flavors. Rum-Bar Overproof White Jamaican Rum delivers notes of ripe tropical fruit, tempered by the funk and caramelized banana of Plantation Xaymaca Rum. Coconut syrup adds texture and sweetness, balanced by fresh pineapple juice, lemon juice and pomegranate syrup. A scant amount of Giffard Banane du Brésil liqueur adds aromatic intensity.
ingredients: 1 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Plantation Xaymaca
3/4 ounce overproof Jamaican rum, preferably Rum-Bar Overproof White Jamaican Rum
1/4 ounce Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand Dry Curaçao
1/4 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banane du Brésil
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin. Add 5 ice cubes and shake for 5 seconds.
2. Strain into a Hurricane glass filled with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with tropical fruit.

title: Embittered Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: This austere recipe from David Little, who formerly oversaw the bar program at Barnacle in Seattle, represents an inverse image of the classicGaribaldi’s bright sunrise hue. Combine two ounces of Braulio, one ounce of Amaro Montenegro and 2 pinches of kosher salt in a mixing glass with ice. Stir until chilled, then strain into a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube. Garnish with a lemon twist.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled double Old-Fashioned glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Donato Punch
intro_philosophy: As the launch bartender of North America’s first and only Punch Room, located in Tampa, Florida,Renée Fitzgeraldis dressing a centuries-old format of mixed drink in party clothes. Her modern takes on punch celebrate the flavors and spirits of the Caribbean and Gulf regions while incorporating contemporary techniques and unconventional ingredients. (Today’s wealth of agave spirits wasn’t so close at hand for yesterday’s punch makers.) Here, two types of clarified citrus join forces with manzanilla sherry, banana liqueur and crème de cacao atop a tequila base. True to tradition, a measure of orange rooibos tea remains in Fitzgerald’s modern punch.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce clarified lemon juice (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce clarified orange juice (see Editor’s Note)
1 bar spoon white crème de cacao
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in one side of a two-piece cocktail shaker and throw the drink between the two tins to aerate the mixture.
2. Pour over a large cube in a rocks glass, then garnish.

title: Six Samurai & Sonic
intro_philosophy: The name of this Sonic variation refers to the six Japanese botanicals found in Roku gin, as well as the classic Akira Kurosawa filmSeven Samurai.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  Kina aromatized wine (such as Cocchi Americano, Kina L’Aéro d’Or or Caperitif)
2 dashes  acid phosphate (Maiko recommends Horsford’s Acid Phosphate by Extinct Chemical Company)
instructions: 1. Combine the first three ingredients in a Collins glass with ice, and stir briefly.
2. Top up with soda water.
3. Garnish with strawberry slices.

title: Negroni de Nubes
intro_philosophy: Created in collaboration with fellow New York bartenders Tom Macy and Shannon Ponche, the Negroni de Nubes is not your average Negroni variation. Unsmoked mezcal forms the base, leaving room for the delicate flavors of a strawberry-infused Cappelletti-Suze mixture and the botanicals of blanc vermouth to shine through. “It just needed one final touch,” recallsLeanne Favre. “I had the idea to use rice to contribute texture and mouthfeel, drawing inspiration from the starchy texture of horchata.” Stirring the mixture with a few tablespoons of rice acts as an à la minute rice wash that lends texture and “delightful creaminess” to the drink.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces mezcal, preferably Derrumbes San Luis Potosí
3/4 ounce strawberry infused Suze-Cappelletti mixture (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

title: Best Day in Paradise
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn bar All Night Skate, the Best Day in Paradise adds complexity to the vodka-soda template. The basil vodka–based drink introduces acidity via three complementary ingredients: bright lime juice, pithy limoncello and a tart-sweet tamarind-lemongrass syrup, which the bar makes by combining tamarind pulp with fresh lemongrass stalks.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Square One Organic Basil Vodka
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients besides seltzer water to a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake aggressively.
2. Fine-strain into a Collins glass over fresh ice.
3. Top with seltzer water and stir lightly to combine.
4. Garnish with a sprig of fresh Thai basil and a small slice of Thai chile.

title: Dale DeGroff’s Champagne Cobbler
intro_philosophy:
“I researched [Jerry] Thomas’How to Mix Drinksinside and out…when I did the first menu for Rainbow,” explains Dale DeGroff, who took a liking to both the cobbler and julep sections of the historic cocktail book. “What rocked my world was Thomas shaking fresh fruit in a cocktail,” adds DeGroff, who applied this technique to a variety of drinks, including hisWhiskey Peach Smash.

Here, orange, lemon and pineapple add a brightness to DeGroff’s take on the classicChampagne Cobbler.
instructions: 1. Muddle the fruits and maraschino liqueur in the bottom of a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and Champagne.
3. Stir gently to retain the bubbles and strain into a flute or wine glass.

title: New Bullshot
intro_philosophy: When the Caucus Club, a renowned Detroit steakhouse, reopened after being closed for years, the restaurant’s signature midcentury cocktail, the Bullshot, was also resurrected. The drink was originally a combination of vodka, beef broth and savory seasonings, but in its current iteration, Moletto—an Italian tomato gin—replaces vodka. A housemade jus, Bloody Mary mix and candied pancetta round out the drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces steakhouse jus (or to taste, but heavy on the umami flavors)
3/4 ounce Bloody Mary mix, preferably Brewt’s
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with candied pancetta.

title: Barrymore Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Kenneth McCoy traces the origin of this drink back to a time in which he sampled an array of stirred cocktails in liqueur-rinsed coupes. He found particular harmony between whiskey-based drinks and small amounts of green Chartreuse. “Whether it was a bourbon, a rye, or a single malt, it just elevated the cocktail,” he recalls. “It just gives another edge to the cocktail.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Scotch, preferably Bruichladdich The Classic Laddie
1/2 ounce peated whisky, preferably Compass Box The Peat Monster
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir first three ingredients with ice.

2. Swirl Chartreuse in a coupe glass, using enough to generously coat the interior. Use a long-handled match to set the liqueur on fire. Swirl the liqueur in the glass for a few seconds. Strain the contents of the mixing glass over the flame to extinguish.
3. Twist orange peel over the drink to express the essential oils. Discard the peel.

title: Le Grand Sour
intro_philosophy: Somewhere between a Spritz and a classic Gin Sour, the Le Grand highlights the idiosyncratic herbal liqueur, Bénédictine, which is pumped up with gentian-infused Cocchi Americano, the aromatic stylings of rosemary and a topper of Prosecco.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except the Prosecco to a mixing tin.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a large coupe glass and top with Prosecco.
4. Garnish with a spring rosemary.

title: Scarlet Pimpernel
intro_philosophy: In her riff on a classic highball, Gillian White relies heavily on mint’s aromatics, shaking the herb directly into the cocktail and using it as a garnish. “I know some people think mint can be a useless garnish or ‘frilly,’ but I think it really helps transform a drink,” she explains. With its base of London dry gin,génépyand grapefruit liqueur, this intentionally low-ABV cooler was designed for New Orleans summers.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce grapefruit liqueur, preferably Giffard Pamplemousse
3/4 ounce génépy, preferably Dolin Génépy des Alpes
12 drops celery shrub, preferably Bittermens Orchard Street Celery Shrub
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients save for soda water over ice in a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake and double strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water and garnish with mint.

title: Sawyer
intro_philosophy:
I first encountered the Sawyer after a late-night gustatory marathon atMomofuku Ko, the twelve-stool East Village restaurant famous for its elaborate and inventiveomakase-style tasting menu and a sometimes confounding online reservation system. A nightcap seemed in order, so I walked over to Ko’s sister restaurant,Ssäm Bar. Don Lee, who spent time atPDTand was then the bar manager for the Momofuku empire, was behind the stick at Ssäm Bar that night, and when I told him I was looking for a post-Ko digestif, he went to work and presented me with the Sawyer, an icy, bitters-soaked twist on a gimlet doctored with nearly thirty dashes of bitters. Don explained that the drink was inspired bywd-50chef Wylie Dufresne (who loves gin) and was named after Wylie’s daughter.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Photos by Ed Anderson © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
ingredients: 7 dashes orange bitters blend (equal parts Fee Brothers West Indian Orange Bitters and Regans’ Orange Bitters No. 6)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake.
3. Strain into a chilled rocks glass.

title: Jelani Johnson’s Painkiller
intro_philosophy: Second place inour blind tasting of 10 different Painkiller recipeswent to Jelani Johnson, assistant distiller at Great Jones Distilling Co. The judges quickly picked up an additional source of acid, in this case lemon juice, and found the rum to shine through thanks to four different expressions, led by Coruba Jamaican rum alongside Plantation O.F.T.D., El Dorado 12-year and a teaspoon ofRum Fire. The judges thought the nutmeg was particularly well integrated thanks to Johnson’s decision to shake the drink with grated nutmeg, rather than simply dusting it atop the finished drink. Johnson’s was also the only drink served on Kold-Draft ice cubes rather than with pebble ice, making it read more like a traditional cocktail than a colada. As McGee observed, “It tastes like a Painkiller you would get at a cocktail bar.”
ingredients: 1 ounce aged Jamaican rum, preferably Coruba
1/2 ounce overproof rum, preferably Plantation O.F.T.D.
1/2 ounce aged Guyanese rum, preferably El Dorado 12-year
1/2 teaspoon Rum Fire overproof white rum
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake with 3 ice cubes.
2. Pour into a tin cup, and fill with fresh ice cubes.

title: Sleeping Lotus
intro_philosophy:
The Sleeping Lotus drinks like the Army & Navy cocktail on leave in the Bahamas. Rather than being served in a buttoned-up fashion, in a coupe with no garnish, the Sleeping Lotus relaxes over crushed ice in a Zombie glass, topped with an edible orchid and copious mint. To the expected gin, orgeat, and lemon, mint adds a cooling element, while orange bitters add a bitter citrus note.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
3. Strain into a Zombie or collins glass filled with crushed ice and stir to incorporate.
4. Top with more crushed ice.
5. Garnish with an edible orchid and a mint sprig.

title: Hannah Wooley Punch
intro_philosophy:
The recipe for Hannah Wooley Punch was originally published in 1672, making it a true old-school punch, and among the first punch recipes to be recorded on paper. Davide Segat, bar manager at London’s Punch Room, has taken this English classic—with a tip of his hat to nearby Hawksmoor Spitalfield, one of the first cocktail bars of the craft cocktail renaissance to bring the recipe back—and updated it withspicy Barolo Chinato. The resulting combination ofold-school and new embodies the best flavors of the holiday season.

Many thanks to our friends atOne Kings Lanefor outfitting our holiday punches photoshoot, and toPrime Meatsfor allowing us to make a mess of your beautiful space.
ingredients: 26 ounces dry red wine, preferably merlot
instructions: 1. Combine first five ingredients in punch bowl. Top with soda.
2. Garnish with red currant strings or cranberries, edible flowers (such as violas), grated nutmeg and orange wheels.
3. Ladle over cups with ice to serve.

title: Ferdinand & Isabella’s Punch
ingredients: 1 (750ml) bottle Ron Zacapa 23 Sistema Solera rum
instructions: 1. Peel the lemons, taking care to avoid as much of the bitter white pith as possible.
2. In a large bowl, combine the sugar with the lemon peels, then lightly muddle and let sit for 20 minutes to allow the citrus oils to infuse with the sugar.
3. Boil 3 cups of water and steep the tea bags in it for 3 minutes. Set aside to cool slightly.
4. To the bowl, add the rum, sherry, lemon and lime juices, bitters, and Velvet Falernum, and stir to combine
5. Add the tea and let cool to room temperature. If serving immediately, add several large cubes to chill.
6. Add lime and lemon wheels and grate some nutmeg over the punch.
7. Ladle into punch cups over ice, garnish with mint sprigs, and serve.

title: Yuzu Rozu
intro_philosophy: This slightly left-of-center highball, which Jeremy Rubinstein happened upon while tinkering with variations on theBrown Derby, sees seemingly disparate flavors elevating one another. Rosemary and Japanese whisky don’t seem like the most logical duo, but Rubinstein has found that they work well together. “The maltiness that normally would be hidden by the quinine is actually played up with the rosemary,” he says.
ingredients: 3 ounces tonic water, preferably East Imperial Yuzu Tonic
instructions: 1. Combine the lightly crushed rosemary and whisky in a chilled highball glass.
2. Add ice and top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with a fresh rosemary sprig.

title: TJ Smash
intro_philosophy: The cocktail that TJ Lynch makes more than any other is the TJ Smash—an extra-minty, bittered take on thewhiskey smash. “My wife and my business partner both make fun of me for being not very cautious,” says Lynch, “when it comes to things around the bar and at home, I tend to use brute force to ‘fix’ things,”—a trait that has led to repeated use of the phrase “TJ Smash”—as in “Hulk Smash”—suitable name for this over-the-top take on the classic recipe.
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients and shake vigorously with ice.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass over ice and garnish with tons of mint.

title: Quit That Racquet
intro_philosophy: Curaçao steps up to center stage in this elegant (and easy) gin cocktail from Atlanta’s Greg Best. The drink can be stirred and served up or made long by pouring the stirred drink over ice and topping it with soda. Win, win.
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, stir all ingredients with cracked ice until well chilled.
2. Strain into a stemmed cocktail glass, and garnish with a large lemon peel.

title: Eden Jade
intro_philosophy: A remix on theGimlet, New York bartender Naima Williams’ Eden Jade was inspired by an aromatherapy treatment. To capture that bliss in a sip, she started with a base of Star of Bombay gin and built citrusy, floral layers with yuzu juice and Italicus, an aperitivo liqueur with notes of rose and lavender. Eucalyptus bitters tie everything together, and an optional egg white fluffs it all up into breezy aromatic sour.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, preferably Star of Bombay
3 dashes Hella Bitters Founders Collection Eucalyptus bitters
1/2 bar spoon  green edible pearl dust
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add ice and shake again.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a eucalyptus sprig and dried rose buds.

title: E Tonico
intro_philosophy: This bubbly, rose-tinted aperitivo drink from New York’s Maialino (vicino) reads like a cross between aNegroniand aGin & Tonic. Instead of Campari, beverage director Patrick Smith turns to Mulassano Bitter, a lighter Italian red bitter with a slightly lower ABV, to reinforce the drink’s refreshing profile, alongside Cocchi’s Vermouth di Torino Extra Dry, a newer aromatized wine from the cult-favorite producer. For Maialino, a restaurant with a notable vermouth service, the chance to spotlight an interesting vermouth in a recipe was an exciting one. “I like the fact that the E Tonico is sort of a bridge from the vermouth service to the cocktail menu,” says Smith.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce gin, such as New York Distilling Co. Dorothy Parker
1/2 ounce navy-strength gin, such as New York Distilling Co. Perry’s Tot
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, such as Cocchi di Torino Extra Dry
1/4 ounce Italian red bitter, such as Mulassano Bitter
tonic water, such as Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic, to top
instructions: 1. Combine the first five ingredients in a Collins glass and fill with ice.
2. Top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with a bay leaf.

title: Grapefruit Collins
intro_philosophy: Hailing from proto-tiki bar Cane & Table, Sam Kiley gives this rum highball a tropical twist. “A float of pomegranate juice adds flavor, acidity and an ombre that goes beautifully with the pink soda,” she explains, yielding a highball that’s “fun, flirty and will transport you to an island state of being.”
ingredients: 1 ounce  Hamilton Jamaican Pot Still Gold rum
2 to 2 1/2 ounces  Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit
instructions: 1. Add the first four ingredients to a Collins glass half-filled with crushed ice.
2. Scoop in more crushed ice, to fill the glass.
3. Top up with grapefruit soda.
4. Float pomegranate juice on top by pouring it slowly over the rounded back of a spoon.

5. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel and a fennel frond. Serve with two straws. “Give your fennel frond a little slap against your wrist to enhance the lovely aroma,” Kiley advises, and position the straws as close as possible to the garnishes so the aromas are unmissable.

title: Sloe Gin Fizz
intro_philosophy: Until recently, sloe gin was best known as a base of such absurdly named collegiate classics as the Alabama Slammer and the Sloe Comfortable Screw, likely due to its provocative purple hue. However, the purple stuff that spilled across American campuses in the 1980s and 1990s was not proper British-style sloe gin, but merely a fruitier imposter. Luckily, the classic Fizz is enjoying a second renaissance in the United States with the return of true sloe gin—a mixture of English blackthorn sloe berries (a more petite relative of the plum) macerated in gin. This version is slightly unorthodox using a blend of regular gin and sloe gin, plus the optional addition of an egg white for a bit of fluffy oomph.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sloe gin (Plymouth is a good option)
instructions: 1. Add an ounce or so of soda to a fizz glass or coupe.
2. Add sloe gin, gin, lemon juice, simple syrup and egg white to a cocktail shaker.
3. Shake without ice.
4. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
5. Strain into prepared fizz glass or coupe over top of soda and observe the fluffy foam.

title: Campari Shakerato
intro_philosophy: You really have to like Campari to appreciate the austere and quite bitter Shakerato, but Naren Young at New York’s Dante makes it a bit more approachable with the addition of a saline solution and bright orange flower water.
ingredients: 2 dashes Maldon salt solution (1:1, Maldon salt:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Grapefruit Basil Martini
intro_philosophy: In the basement of a Spanish-style bungalow in Los Angeles’ Echo Park neighborhood is HaleKahiki, a 1950s-inspired home tiki bar built by Alan Smart and Michael Uhlenkott. With a beautifully crafted rattan-paneled bar, glowing sconces and a charming volcanic mural painted by Uhlenkott set back into the wall, the basement oasis is the setting for many a tropical-themed drink, including this simple citrus and herb sour. Equal parts grapefruit to vodka with a splash of basil-infused sugar syrup, Smart’s Martini is a pared down slice of paradise.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, lightly muddle basil leaves with simple syrup.
2. Add vodka, grapefruit juice and ice.
3. Shake until chilled.
4. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
5. Garnish with a basil leaf.

title: Valentino
intro_philosophy: The late bar legend Gary “Gaz” Regan published his Valentino recipe in his groundbreaking bookThe Joy of Mixology. Beginning with the Negroni template, Regan departed from the equal-parts ratio, swapped gin for vodka and served the drink up for a cocktail that he describes as “far different from the Negroni.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: El Duderino
intro_philosophy: Chris Amirault describes this cocktail as “a White Russian inspired by clarified milk punch.” The name of the drink pays homage to the central character ofThe Big Lebowski, who famously swills White Russians throughout the 1998 film.
ingredients: 1 tablespoon loose leaf Wuyi Oolong Tea
2 cups coffee liqueur, preferably Mr. Black
3 1/3 cups añejo tequila, preferably El Tesoro
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients (except bitters) and let rest for 30 minutes.
2. Spin in centrifuge at 4500 rpm for 15 minutes. (Alternatively, strain through coffee filter lined with cheesecloth until the mixture is clarified.)
3. For a single serve, pour 3 ounces into a coffee mug or rocks glass over a big piece of ice. Stir for 15 revolutions and add 1 dash of Angostura bitters.

title: Glasgow Razor Blade
intro_philosophy: The Glasgow Razor Blade takes its cue from a Genever-based sour, the Holland Razor Blade, switching up the serve by putting it on the rocks and playing on the depth of single malt Scotch. The Classic Glen Moray Elgin is a straightforward and traditional single malt, adding body and exotic spice that takes the drink to another level. Make sure your glass is cold, your ice is big and your cayenne pepper is fresh!
ingredients: 2 ounces  Glen Moray Speyside 12-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky (Elgin Heritage)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Fill with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled rocks glass over a single large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a dusting of cayenne pepper.

title: Smooth as Butter
intro_philosophy: A milk-washed riff on aVieux Carré—“we swapped every ingredient, except Bénédictine,” Daniel Villa says—this drink uses toasted powdered milk to yield a silky cocktail that tastes “as though it was simultaneously milk-punched and brown-butter fat-washed.” The sunken raisin garnish is a bonus. “It’s almost a rum raisin cure in the drink,” he says. “By the time you’re done, they’re delicious, and you can enjoy them at the end as a snack.”
ingredients: 8 ounces rehydrated toasted whole milk (see Editor’s Note)
9 ounces reposado tequila, such as El Tesoro
2 ounces mezcal, such as Ilegal Joven
1/2 teaspoon bitters (Villa prefers Crude Cardamom & Caramelized Raisin bitters, a limited-edition bottling, but says an equal amount of any style of bitters will work)
instructions: 1. Pour the rehydrated milk into a large mixing cup or Cambro.

2. In a second container, add the remaining ingredients, and stir to combine. Add the batched cocktail into the container with the rehydrated milk. Give it a gentle stir, and let it sit for about 10 minutes, during which it should curdle.

3. Pour the cocktail mixture through a fine-mesh sieve (a chinois strainer lined with a moistened linen towel or a micron bag/Superbag will also work) into a clean container. The resulting liquid should be slightly cloudy.
4. Pour the cocktail mixture a second time through the same sieve (including through the curds in the sieve) into a clean container. The resulting liquid should be fairly clear.
5. Funnel into a bottle and cap. Keeps, indefinitely, at room temperature.
6. To serve, pour 3 ounces over big ice, and stir to chill.
7. Garnish with raisins, which should sink to the bottom of the glass.

title: Yael Vengroff’s White Claw Cocktail
instructions: 1. After taking a few sips, add the yuzu juice directly into the can.
2. Garnish with mint sprig, raspberry and chili salt.

title: Bitter Tom
intro_philosophy: In an effort to create a bitters-basedTom Collins(and one-up fellow New York bartender Sam Ross’s Grapefruit Collins), Brad Farran created its “hotter, younger cousin,” the Bitter Tom made with Campari and Bénédictine. “Kevin Diedrich, who I was working with at the time, really helped to crystallize this cocktail by suggesting that I use pomegranate molasses to bring it together.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except soda water to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and roll back and forth from shaker tin to shaker tin.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Golden Horseshoe
intro_philosophy: By his own estimation, Garret Richard has collected most, if not all, of the Galliano advertisements from the 1960s and ‘70s, one of which served as the inspiration for his Golden Horseshoe. “There was a small little book that Galliano gave out and there’s a recipe in there that won a competition in the ‘70s that I believe was just pisco, blanc vermouth and Galliano. That was kind of my jumping off point,” says Richard. He swaps pisco for tequila and adds more savory elements, like thyme liqueur and saline, to highlight the lemon and black pepper elements of the gin, underscoring the vanilla notes in Galliano. While some might say a stirred tequila drink has no place in tiki, the Golden Horseshoe succeeds in layering seemingly disparate flavors in a manner akin to many tiki classics. “When you distill it down to what it is, tiki drinks have these weird curve balls and layers of complexity and you can do that in stirred drinks all day long,” he says.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce gin, preferably Xoriguer Gin de Mahon
3/4 ounce bianco vermouth, preferably Contratto Bianco
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a flamed orange peel.

title: Rule of Three
intro_philosophy: In this equal-parts concoction, Devin Kennedy crafts a Martini by way of Spain. Spanish gin, Spanish vermouth and dry sherry are stirred together with a grapefruit peel to incorporate citrus oil throughout the cocktail rather than simply spritzing it over the surface of the drink. Perhaps more than any other cocktail, Kennedy’s Rule of Three follows his driving principle: “Let’s keep it simple.”
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, preferably Xoriguer Gin de Mahon
1 dash pink peppercorn tincture (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

title: Whiskey Smash
intro_philosophy: The layman’s Mint Julep, the Whiskey Smash comes with all of the flavor of its more famous relative but without the associated frippery (tin cups, Derby hats, et al.). Jerry Thomas called it, “The Julep on a small plan.” A few slices of muddled lemon and a fistful of mint helps lift and brighten the flavors, making this potent number dangerously easy to toss back.
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, gently muddle mint with simple syrup to release oils.
2. Add lemon pieces and muddle to release juice.
3. Add crushed ice or small ice cubes and pour bourbon over.
4. Swizzle gently to mix.
5. Garnish with a mint spring and lemon wheel.

title: Sarah Morrissey’s Mojito
intro_philosophy: A runner up in our recent blind tasting of Mojitos,Sarah Morrissey‘s recipe calls on Banks 5 Island rum as the base of her take on the classic.
ingredients: 2 ounces light rum, preferably Banks 5 Island Rum
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, muddle the mint, sugar and lime.
2. Add the rum and whip shake with a handful of crushed ice.
3. Pour the drink into a Zombie glass and add a splash of soda water.
4. Top with fresh pebble ice.
5. Garnish with a large bouquet of mint.

title: Maison Premiere’s Ramos Gin Fizz
intro_philosophy: In a tasting of 10 Ramos Gin Fizzes from some of America’s best bartenders, the top honors went to this version from Maison Premiere in Brooklyn. Like most Ramos recipes, its showstopping meringue is a matter of method and the precise ratio of ingredients.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce simple syrup, (1:1, sugar to water)
3/4 ounce heavy cream, preferably Ronnybrook Farm
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the cream in a Boston tin and dry-shake.
2. Add heavy cream with one large and one small ice cube, and shake until ice is dissolved.
3. Pour into a Collins glass, and place the glass in the freezer to settle.
4. Poke the surface with a straw, then pour soda through the hole until the drink rises above the rim of the glass.
5. Express a lemon twist over the drink, and discard.

title: The Perfect BQE
intro_philosophy: Ivy Mix, now ofLeyenda, notes that this drink, which she created for Clover Club, is called “perfect” because it’s made with equal parts dry and sweet vermouth. As for the concept of the cocktail? “It’s a marriage of the Red Hook and the Greenpoint,” she explains. “And what connects them? The BQE.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
4. Garnish with a cherry.

title: Palmetto
intro_philosophy: First published inThe Savoy Cocktail Bookin 1930, the Palmetto reads like a rum Manhattan, according to rum expert Paul McGee, who makes the case for the forgotten classic. McGee’s take on the drink pulls from historian David Wondrich’s description of the extinct St. Croix rum—light-bodied, like Cuban rum; grassy, like Martinique rum; and funky, like Jamaican rum—by relying on a split base of three rums. In lieu of a Cuban bottling, however, he uses an aged Barbados expression to make the drink “a bit rummier” and richer-bodied.
ingredients: 1 ounce Barbados rum, preferably Real McCoy 5-Year
1/2 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Neisson Elevé Sous Bois
1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi di Torino
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice, then strain into a chilled coupe glass.
2. Express an orange peel over the drink, then discard.

title: Starry Night
intro_philosophy: Combining butterfly pea flower syrup and tonic water creates the blush-pink hue for this aperitivo, inspired by the bold strokes of Vincent Van Gogh’s famedStarry Nightpainting.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
1/4 ounce  butterfly pea flower syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake first four ingredients with ice.
2. Double-strain into a Bordeaux wine glass over Kold-Draft ice cubes.
