3. Top up with tonic water.
4. Garnish with a purple orchid spritzed with orange blossom water.

title: Lavender Mule
intro_philosophy: To the timelessMoscow Muleconstruction, Kathleen Hawkins adds a floral note by way of lavender syrup, but keeps the skeleton of the drink intact.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce  ginger syrup (1:1, ginger juice:demerara sugar)
1/4 ounce lavender syrup (1:1, lavender liquid [see Editor's note]:white sugar)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the ginger beer, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a glass over ice.
3. Top with ginger beer and garnish with a lavender sprig.

title: Antrim Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Originally nothing more than equal parts Cognac and Port, shaken with a little sugar over ice, the Antrim Cocktail is attributed to the American-born, Philippines-based barman Walter Ellett Antrim, an enigmatic soul better known as “Monk.” Seeking a more consistent mouthfeel and flavor, Brooklyn bartender Selma Slabiak introduces orange bitters, gomme syrup and a lemon twist to the proceedings.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Frojolais
intro_philosophy: Channeling—or amplifying, rather—the easygoing fruitiness of village-level Beaujolais, this red-wine based answer to frosé combines red wine, raspberry gomme syrup from Small Hand Foods, bitter Campari for dimension, a splash lemon juice and crushed ice.
ingredients: 1 ounce raspberry gomme syrup, preferably Small Hand Foods
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend until smooth.
3. Pour into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a raspberry and a lemon wheel.

title: All In
intro_philosophy: Nearly anOld Pal, the New York City bar Nitecap’s All In adds a rich, velvety layer of crème de cacao to the classic base of rye whiskey, Campari and dry vermouth. The result is an unlikely, yet curiously bittersweet cocktail reminiscent of the finest, darkest chocolate.
instructions: 1. Add rye, dry vermouth, Campari and crème de cacao to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Express a lemon twist over top to release oils. Discard.

title: King Neptune’s Tonic
intro_philosophy:
This low-alcohol, sherry-based winter spritz uses dark rum and coffee liqueur to prop up the savory, umami notes present in oloroso. It’s then topped up with lightly bitter tonic water. Taken together, it’s proof that a drink can be both complex and rich without being high octane.

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Galliano Ristretto
instructions: 1. Combine the sherry, rum and coffee liqueur in a mixing glass.
2. Add ice, stir to chill, and strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Add the tonic water and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Das Radler
intro_philosophy: The best selling radler at Chicago’s Das Radler is their blood orange rendition, a base of Ayinger Brau Weisse topped with sparkling blood orange soda with the optional shot of spirit.
instructions: 1. Pour beer into a pint glass and top with soda.
2. Finish with a shot of vodka or other spirit, if desired.

title: Boy Named Sue
intro_philosophy:
This story is published in partnership with Diageo Reserve World Class, which, since launch in 2009, has supported hundreds of thousands of bartenders through its training and advocacy program.  For this World Cocktail Day, on May 13th, World Class surveyed top bartenders around the globe—including World Class Bartender of the Year, Kaitlyn Stewart—on the most popular cocktails being ordered in their bars today; to see the results,click here.

In this play on a Pimm’s Cup, Kaitlyn Stewart wasinspired by culinary flavors and techniques. “Instead of using traditional Pimm’s, I was able to do a rapid infusion, using an iSi canister, to mimic the flavors that Pimm’s highlights. I caramelized lemons to make a charred lemonade and torched some rosemary for depth and aroma.” The drink is named in honor of the iconic song by her grandmother’s favorite artist.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces whiskey, preferably Johnnie Walker Black Label
1 ounce rapid infusion Pimm's (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with flamed rosemary, charred lemon wheel and pineapple fronds.

title: Bobby Heugel’s Rusty Nail
intro_philosophy: Bobby Heugeluses three Scotches in his riff on the Rusty Nail at his Japanese-inspired bar, Tongue-Cut Sparrow.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Caput Mundi
intro_philosophy: Emanuele Broccatelli’s cocktail named for his native city draws on the anise flavors that once characterized Roman desserts and drinks, likecaffè corretto.
instructions: 1. In a shaker filled with ice, shake the absinthe, anisette, Maraschino and lemon juice until chilled.
2. Strain into a highball glass and add ice.
3. Top with soda and garnish with lemon zest and a skewered cherry.

title: Le Papillon
intro_philosophy: François Vera’s Le Papillon is an ambrosial amalgam of citrus, cassis andsingani, served at LA’s Parisian-style Pour Vous. And while one might not think to pair the Bolivian spirit with one made famous in Burgundy, the inclusion of muddled grapes alongside the grape brandy suggests a nod to the original wine-based Kir, a genial gesture from one French institution to another.
instructions: 1. Muddle grapes in a cocktail shaker and add all ingredients except cassis.
2. Shake with a few ice cubes and strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Add crushed ice into the glass and pour the cassis on top.
4. Garnish with a grape and a blackberry.

title: Toki Berra
intro_philosophy: Michael Aredes’ Toki Berra draws inspiration from the JapaneseCalpico sodain its combination of creamy coconut-matcha yogurt, yuzu, soda water and Japanese whisky. As Aredes summarizes, it’s “a drink that will make you question it on paper, then bring you to a happy place of refreshment and delight.”
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces Japanese whisky, preferably Suntory Toki Whisky
1 heaping tablespoon coco-matcha yogurt (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Fill a zombie highball glass with Kold-Draft ice cubes. Top with soda.
2. Add the remaining ingredients to a mixing tin, and dry-shake to combine.
3. Using a bar spoon, pour the mixture in the tin into the club soda. Give a light stir.
4. Garnish with edible flowers.

title: French Manhattan
intro_philosophy:
The French are just as fascinated with America as Americans are with France. Although, as my friend Grégoire, told me, “We both admire the lifestyle of each other, but in the end, each of us prefers our way of life.” Even if you’re a die-hard (American) Manhattan drinker, this French version might change your allegiance.

Reprinted with permission fromDrinking French: The Iconic Cocktails, Aperitifs, and Café Traditions of France, with 100 Recipes, by David Lebovitz, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Ed Anderson.
ingredients: 1 dash orange bitters or Angostura bitters
instructions: 1. Add the Cognac, sweet vermouth, Grand Marnier, and Bitters to a cocktail mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until well chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Garnish with the cherry.

title: Amethyst Hour
intro_philosophy: “I think brandy, at its best, captures the essence of the fruit delicately but also retains great structure,” says bar director Sarah Crowl. Her Amethyst Hour, which is served nontraditionally in a rocks glass over ice, calls on basil eau de vie and is garnished with red grapes and basil.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce St. George Aqua Perfecta Basil Eau de Vie
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice, stir and strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with red grapes and purple basil.

title: Biloxi Deluxe #2
intro_philosophy: Though he normally likes to use Swedish punsch in drinks with a tiki bent, Michael Phillips’ Biloxi Deluxe #2 is anything but: Built in a glass rinsed with Pernod absinthe, it stacks punsch alongside Cognac and bitters for a room temperature drink, finished with an expressed orange peel.
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients at room temperature in a wine glass lightly rinsed with absinthe.
2. Express orange peel over drink and discard.

title: Tsukiji Highball
intro_philosophy: A simple Scotch & Soda serves as the inspiration for a savory highball whose seemingly austere profile packs an umami punch. Glenfiddich 12-year single malt is briefly infused with dried bonito flakes to deliver a distinctive fishy, smoky flavor. Urushido eschews the typical brightly colored garnish for a housemadenikiri-joyu“paint,” a blend of savory tamari and soy sauce that’s painted along the rim of the glass like the lime-slicked salt on a Margarita.
ingredients: Chilled soda water, preferably Q Spectacular Club Soda
instructions: 1. Use a clean paint brush or pastry brush to paint a thick stripe ofnikiri-joyuaround the rim of one side of a frozen highball glass or handled beer stein.
2. Place an ice spear or a stack of ice cubes in the prepared frozen highball glass or handled beer stein.
3. Add the bonito-infused Scotch.
4. Top off with chilled soda water and gently stir.

title: My Cherry Amour
intro_philosophy: “Finding drinks that meld well with cherry syrup and being able to utilize it on a consistent basis isn’t easy,” says Josh Ibañez, bartender at Seattle’s Rumba and The Doctor’s Office.“It should play a role and also uplift all the other ingredients.” This is precisely what the syrup does inIbañez’saptly named My Cherry Amour, where it plays off of the tart cherry liqueur in the drink, creating another layer of like-flavor to complement the rum and amaro base as well as the pineapple and lemon juices that complete the recipe.
ingredients: 1 ounce aged rum, preferably Ten to One Dark
1/4 ounce Leopold Bros. Michigan Tart Cherry Liqueur
1/4 ounce unaged Jamaican overproof rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
1/4 ounce cherry syrup (from a jar of maraschino cherries)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a pineapple triangle, a cherry and mint.

title: Christine Wiseman’s Margarita
intro_philosophy: The winner ofour 2024 Margarita blind tasting, Christine Wiseman’s recipe reads like a hybrid of a classic Margarita and a Tommy’s Margarita. There’s a half-ounce of orange liqueur, the default in classic iterations of the drink, plus a half-ounce of agave syrup, the sweetener of choice in the latter build. The result is a Margarita with zip, body and balance and a tequila that shines through beautifully.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce agave syrup (1:1, agave to water)
instructions: 1. Prep a rocks glass with a half salt rim.
2. Combine all ingredients in a tin with ice and shake.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.
4. Add fresh ice.
5. Garnish with a lime wheel or wedge.

title: Brooklynite Cosmo
intro_philosophy: This Thanksgiving-inspired Cosmopolitan riff calls on a playful syrup made with cranberry sauce, cranberry juice and cranberry bitters, which gives the drink a deep, rosy hue. For added complexity, the orange liqueur—traditionally, Cointreau—is split betweendry Curaçaoand a sweeter triple sec.
ingredients: ¼ ounce dry Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
1/4 ounce triple sec, preferably Dekuyper O3 Premium Orange Liqueur or Grand Marnier
1/2 ounce cranberry sauce mix, see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, combine all ingredients with ice.
2. Shake well, and strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lime twist.

title: Attack of the Banantulas
intro_philosophy: At its core, the Attack of the Banantulas is a frozen banana Daiquiri. ButKitty Bernardo’sversion, created for Manhattan bar Paradise Lost, puts Filipino flavors at the forefront, specifically, banana ketchup—a uniquely sweet-sour Filipino condiment. “Being the face of Paradise Lost, a bar rooted in tiki origins while eschewing the typical Polynesian-inspired kitsch, presented a unique opportunity to reclaim the tradition of sharing Filipino flavors in a way that pushes the palates of our patrons while being anchored in the approachable,” explains Bernardo. They describe this drink, which takes its name from the stowaway tarantulas that would sometimes accompany crates of bananas, as “weird on paper, but refreshingly familiar on the palate.”
ingredients: 1 ounce lightly aged rum, preferably Planteray 3 Stars
1 ounce acidulated banana cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a flash blender with the pebble ice and blend.
2. Pour into a Hurricane glass and top off with more pebble ice before garnishing.

title: Frozen Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: The Garibaldiis a classic Italian aperitivo drink that traditionally calls on equal parts Campari and fresh orange juice—a simple, two-ingredient formula that begs to be built upon. Here, we up the ratio of orange juice to Campari to increase the viscosity and trademark frothiness of the drink and then add a bit of simple syrup to make sure the drink stands up to dilution.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a blender and process until smooth.
2. Pour into a short Collins glass, then garnish with the orange half-wheel.

title: Rouge Tomate Penicillin
intro_philosophy: Instead of smoky Islay Scotch, this version of the classicPenicillingets topped with a spritz of mezcal. The concept of the entire cocktail menu at Rouge Tomate revolves around fresh juices and “healthier” versions of classics. For the honey component of this drink, they heat local honey and then pour it into barrels to ferment (to make this drink at home, non-fermented honey will suffice). That element is echoed in the bee pollen garnish that sits atop a cap of egg-white froth.
ingredients: 2 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Duncan Taylor Scottish Glory
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients in a mixing tin and shake without ice.
2. Add one large ice cube and shake again.
3. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass or a coupe.
4. Garnish with bee pollen.

title: Jamie Boudreau’s Toronto
intro_philosophy: A split whiskey base (rye and bourbon) and a nuanced sweetener create a “simple drink with a ton of complexity” that’s also “a great way to introduce people to Fernet without abusing their palates,” says Canadian bartender Jamie Boudreau. Note: For optimal balance, Boudreau advises using just slightly less than a quarter-ounce of simple syrup if the drink is served up; use the full quarter-ounce if serving over ice.
ingredients: 1 ounce rye whiskey (100 proof, such as James E. Pepper rye, preferred)
1 ounce high-proof, big-bodied bourbon (such as Pure Kentucky XO)
1/4 ounce rich simple syrup (2:1, sugar blend to water; Canon uses equal parts Demerara, muscovado and white sugars in the blend)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Twist the orange peel over the top of the drink to express essential oils through a flame, then use the peel to garnish the drink.

title: Almost Foxy
intro_philosophy: TheFox Riveroriginally appeared in the 1905 edition of Charles S. Mahoney’sHoffman House Bartender’s Guide, where it was listed as the Fox River Toddy, a rye-based cocktail with crème de cacao, sugar, German bitters and a lemon twist. Almost 20 years later, Harry MacElhone included his version inHarry of Ciro’s ABC of Mixing Cocktails, where bourbon is swapped in for rye, while peach bitters replace the German bitters. Adam Fournier’s Almost Foxy takes the stone fruit aspect of MacElhone’s recipe up a notch, “amaretto-fying” high-rye bourbon with toasted apricot kernels and adding housemade apricot bitters to the recipe. It’s shaken with mint and served as a julep.
ingredients: heaping 1/4 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
8 dashes homemade apricot bitters (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Whip-shake all ingredients and dump into a rocks glass.
3. Top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet and serve with a straw.

title: Espresso Martini Granita
intro_philosophy: The caffeinated cocktail gets a granita upgrade in this recipe from Jelani Johnson. Because the Espresso Martini doesn’t call for juice, its texture when frozen and whipped comes out more fragmented, like shaved ice, rather than a frappé. Johnson recommends serving this rum-based take with unsweetened evaporated milk or cream for a richer, rounder texture and dessert-like feel.
ingredients: 2 ounces lightly aged rum, such as El Dorado 3-year
1 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water, by volume)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an 8- or 16-ounce deli container and stir to combine.
2. Cover with a lid and freeze overnight.
3. After 24 hours, use a fork to scrape and whip the mixture until it reaches a slushy texture.
4. Serve in a chilled glass and top with whipped unsweetened evaporated milk, if using.

title: Sling Bar’s Gin Pahit
intro_philosophy: At Sling Bar, the gin-focused stall at Manhattan food hall Urban Hawker, the Gin Pahit is one of the most popular cocktails. The Malaysian classic is a cousin toPink Gin, and was similarly influenced by the British Royal Navy; bitters were originally seen as a cure-all for nausea and various other ailments. While traditional recipes for the drink call on absinthe, Sling Bar simplifies the cocktail with an aromatic and licorice-accented gin.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces gin, such as Tanglin Orchid
1/2 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass, then garnish with the lemon twist on the rim of the glass.

title: Steaming Bullshot
intro_philosophy: The Whisky Parlor’s wintertime variation of The Bullshot gives the drink a cold weather makeover by swapping the typical chilled beef broth for piping-hot ramen broth.
ingredients: 4 ounces hot bone broth or ramen broth
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in an Irish Coffee mug rimmed with celery or chile salt.
2. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Amaro de Galo
intro_philosophy: An extra bittersweet take on theRabo de Galo, Brazil’s most popular cachaça cocktail, the Amaro de Galo introduces Averna to the mix. The drink is created by São Paulo bartender Néli Pereira, who serves variations on the classic at her bar Zebra.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Garnish with a lemon slice or peel.

title: Oops I Forgot My Line
intro_philosophy: While Nikolas Zoylinos was applying to London’s Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts, he drank a steady stream of tea for his vocals, often blending three favorites. That tea combination became the inspiration for this drink, which plays off the gin with base notes of dried herbs and spice. Scotch adds a smoky depth, leavened by milk-washed dry vermouth—cream being a classic tea pairing, and a way to soften tannins. The citrus notes from the orange bitters, lemon juice and lemon peel provide balance and freshness, and a savory pinch of salt ties everything together.
ingredients: 2/3 parts  milk-washed dry vermouth  (see Editor’s Note)
3 dashes  smoky whisky,  such as Ardbeg 10 Year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker, fill with ice, and throw between shakers until chilled.
2. Strain into a glass over a hand-chipped block of ice.
3. Express lemon peel over top and discard.

title: Pino Frio
ingredients: 3/4 ounce lime juice (plus the spent hull)
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, muddle pineapple chunks along with the pineapple shrub and sugar.
2. Add lime juice and the spent hull, rum and 2 ice cubes.
3. Shake for 10 seconds and strain into a coupe filled with shaved ice.

title: VG GF AF
intro_philosophy: “I am consistently trying to make everyone that sits down at Standby the healthiest cocktail imaginable,” says head bartender Dorothy Elizabeth, “It’s my stealth mission to saturate alcohol with antioxidants and vitamin C.” Here, she marries mezcal with bright and bitter arugula, then shakes the mixture with fresh bell peppers, in what she aptly describes as a “pseudo-healthy creation.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
1 ounce ginger syrup or liqueur, preferably Kings Ginger (see Editor's Note)
3 to 4 quartered pieces of bell pepper
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.

title: Deepesh Mode
intro_philosophy: At The Wallingford Dram, banana-infused Jameson shines in the Deepesh Mode, a house cocktail that also includes Redbreast 12-year whiskey (another Irish whiskey, produced in copper pot stills and aged in oloroso sherry casks), bitters and Fernet Michaud (a local amaro aged in Maine blueberry wine barrels).
ingredients: 1 ounce Irish whiskey, preferably Redbreast 12 Year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Alexander the Great
intro_philosophy: Like the forefather of an Espresso Martini, this relative of a traditional Alexander goes down like a milkshake with a sharp boozy snap at the end. Adapted fromThe Stork Club Bar Book,in which author Lucius Beebe warns that drinking more than three of these gives one a “wolfish appetite.” We recommend substituting the vodka with a more flavorful spirit, like brandy.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  coffee liqueur, preferably House Spirits
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin.
2. Shake with ice until “cold as Siberia.”
3. Pour into a chilled coupe.

title: Bombardino
intro_philosophy: A hot, spirituous cocktail featured at Italian ski resorts in the winter, Bombardino is typically made by mixing Italian egg liqueur with whiskey, rum or brandy, and sometimes fortified wine. At Quattro Teste, a bar in Lisbon, Portugal, themed around Basque and Italian drinks, theBombardinogets a Basque twist: The bar makes its own egg liqueur, with txakoli-based vermouth and amontillado sherry, which is then spiked with Scotch and topped with salted cream as well as freshly grated nutmeg and cinnamon.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended Scotch whisky, preferably Dewar’s 12
4 1/4 ounces homemade egg liqueur (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. In separate containers in a sous vide or hot water bath, warm the Scotch and egg liqueur to 140°F (60°C) before preparing the drink.
2. Pour the whisky into a glass. (Quattro Teste uses a200-milliliter footed flute.)
3. Add the egg liqueur and stir to combine.
4. Using a spoon, layer the salted cream on top.
5. If using, grate nutmeg, cinnamon and/or chocolate on top of the drink.

title: Maluma
intro_philosophy: This stirred cocktail, created by Team Lyan, combines rye whiskey with a housemade raspberry “syrup,” which gets some of its sweetness from the unexpected addition of licorice root. Built in a rocks glass over ice, the drink is finished with dashes of both chocolate bitters and vanilla extract.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a rocks glass over ice and stir to integrate.

title: Sailin’ On
intro_philosophy: Karri Cormican’s take on the nightcap fuses the traditions of the after-dinner coffee and the digestif. The mellow coffee flavor of Galliano Ristretto balances the bright notes of herbs and mint of St-Germain and Fernet Branca to form a sipping cocktail that will keep the night sailing on.
instructions: 1. Stir all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Colonial Ties
intro_philosophy: “There is something magical about rye and Jamaican rum together—almost creating the impression of an earthy Cognac,” says Devon Tarby of this Sazerac-style cocktail fromThe Varnish‘s Eric Alperin.
instructions: 1. In a chilled mixing glass, soak the sugar cube with orange bitters.
2. Add a barspoon of soda water and muddle into a paste.
3. Add the rye and rum and cracked ice and stir.
4. Strain into a chilled rocks glass rinsed with absinthe.
5. Express the lemon twist and use as garnish on the rim of the glass.

title: Cognac Queen
intro_philosophy: Named for the Megan Thee Stallion song, Cognac Queen represents whatEric Simmonsdescribes as a “strawberry-lavender Sidecar.” Though it hews closely to the spirit-forward construction typical of steakhouse cocktails, the boozy backbone is tempered by rhubarb shrub, lemon juice and a fruit-forward, floral syrup.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce strawberry lavender syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a sage leaf.

title: Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s Negroni
intro_philosophy: Second place inour blind Negroni tasting in 2024went to Jeffrey Morgenthaler of Portland’s Pacific Standard, whose equal-parts construction was identified as such immediately by the judges, who found it to best satisfy the qualifications for the pre-dinner Negroni role. Compared to the gin-forward builds that made up the majority of entries, this one felt rounder and richer, without veering towards syrupy. As one judge described, it was “the poster child for the classic Negroni.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain over ice and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Daiquiri al Pastor
intro_philosophy: “My inspiration for this drink is an al pastor taco—one of my favorite things,” saysLeyendabartender Shannon Ponche, “and we have pernil [Puerto Rican–style brined, slow-roasted pork] on our menu at Leyenda,” Ponche explains. For this drink, she begins with a pork fat–washed rum that calls on a tablespoon of fat from the pernil. Then, Ponche adds more bold flavors to the drink by way of pineapple juice andagave nectar infused withachiote, an orange-red seed with an earthy flavor, used often in Mexican cooking. Ifachioteis unavailable, an unspiced agave nectar will do just fine.
ingredients: 1 ounce pork fat–washed rum (see Editor's Note)
1 ounce white rum, preferably Planteray 3 Stars
1/2 ounce achiote agave nectar (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Pour the chicharrón salt in a shallow dish. Moisten the rim of a coupe glass with a lime wedge, then roll it in the salt mix to coat. Set aside.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the prepared coupe glass.

title: Color Me Dazzled
intro_philosophy: “At Nitecap, we were always trying to find small ways to be as environmentally conscious as possible,” writes Natasha David in her book,Drink Lightly. After learning about the environmental impact of almond orchards, she wanted to change her bar’s traditional homemade orgeat to something more sustainable. Arianna Daskauskas, at the time Nitecap’s head bartender, developed a version made from oat milk, which has been adapted for David’s book. Inspired by a French cocktail, the Mauresque (a combination of pastis, orgeat and water over ice), Color Me Dazzled brings the sweetener together with Granny Smith apple juice and pastis.
ingredients: 3 ounces fresh Granny Smith apple juice
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker with crushed ice and shake.
2. Strain into a festive glass over crushed ice.
3. Top with more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with an apple fan and mint bouquet, and serve with a straw.

title: Cucumber G & T
intro_philosophy: What, you might ask, is so special about adding cucumber to the classic gin and tonic? Everything. Josh Williams and Eric Prum ofThe Mason ShakerandW&P Designteamed up with classic soda makerBoylanto come up with a lime-spiked, full-bodied tonic that pairs perfectly with the summery addition of crisp cucumbers.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle cucumber slices.
2. Add gin and ice and shake.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
4. Top with tonic water and garnish with a cucumber slice and a lime wheel.

title: The Sun King
intro_philosophy:
Sarah Morrissey swears by keeping a bottle of the Cognac-based French aperitif Pineau des Charentes on hand, often turning to it at home when she’s looking for a vermouth alternative for a low-ABV spritz or a neat after-dinner pour that could serve as dessert on its own. In The Sun King (named after Louis XIV, for his practice of exporting Cognac in exchange for rum), she pairs the sweet aperitif with a funky Jamaican rum and a base of muddled lime, in a highball that’s lengthened with spicy ginger ale. She advises growing your own mint at home for the freshest sprigs (and to save a grocery run). “A package of seeds is $2, and mint grows like wildfire,” says Morrissey. “If you pick too much mint, put it in a quart container wrapped in a cold, wet paper towel, and it will last much longer.”

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
instructions: 1. Squeeze the juice of two lime wedges into a Collins glass then lightly muddle the spent shells in the glass.
2. Add the Pineau des Charentes and rum and fill the glass with ice.
3. Top with ginger ale and stir.
4. Garnish with a fresh mint sprig.

intro_philosophy: Thismezcal– and Cognac-based spin on theManhattantakes its name from the year of the Mexican Revolution and nods to the 1919, another house cocktail atDrink, named after the year of Boston’s Molasses Flood. “I’ve become obsessed with this build over the years,” says Ezra Star, “Really, I just put all my favorite things in glass.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Caramelized Rum Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: The cocktail program at El Che in Chicago honors the restaurant’s South American heritage, including this adaptation of theBuenos Aires-style Old-Fashionedin which the inside of the glass is coated with a paste of Demerara sugar and Angostura bitters set on fire.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces overproof rum, preferably Plantation O.F.T.D.
1/4 ounce caramelized bitter syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in an Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled and slightly diluted.
3. Garnish with a flamed orange twist.

title: Satsuma Coffee
intro_philosophy: “While I’m a fan of shochu in general, I like using Kuradashi Genshu from Satsuma in cocktails,” Kenta Goto says, noting that Kagoshima is “a mecca” of sweet potato shochu. At 37 percent ABV, this particular bottle is slightly higher proof and has a hint of toasty chocolate. Both features pair well in a coffee drink “served hot to allow the flavor and aroma of the shochu to come out more.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Satsuma Shiranami Kuradashi Genshu shochu
3/4 ounce Mr Black cold brew coffee liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin.
2. Place the tin in hot water and heat for approximately 5 minutes.
3. Pour into mug or cup to serve.

title: Hey Baby, Que Paso?
intro_philosophy: San Antonio loves its Daiquiris, and isn’t above “slamming a Daiq”—drinking a full-sized Daiquiri in a single go. This fruit-forward Daiq is ideal for a Daiquiri slam, but it also lends itself to sipping and savoring. Amaro Sfumato, a rhubarb-based amaro, adds bitter interest and an enticing hint of smoke.
ingredients: 2 ounces pineapple rum, preferably Stiggins' Fancy Plantation Pineapple
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Imperial Opal
intro_philosophy: Stephen Palahach of Brooklyn’sMaison Premierestacks anise-flavored Ojen atop absinthe swizzles it with yellow Chartreuse. “Lighter herbal liqueurs are . . . great bedfellows with Ojen,” says Palahach, who demonstrates the principle in his refreshing and aromatic Imperial Opal.
instructions: 1. Swizzle in a rocks glass with crushed ice until well diluted, then top with more crushed ice.
2. Finish the cocktail with a few drops of rose water and two lemon twists tucked into the side of the glass.
3. Serve with two small straws.

title: Limeless Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Atthe pioneering cocktail bar White Lyan(which closed in April 2017), they used a combination of acids (notably citric, malic and phosphoric) to mimic fresh citrus. In their Limeless Daiquiri, they combine “fake lime juice” with rum and rich simple syrup for a modernist take on the classic.
ingredients: 2 ounces white rum, preferably Bacardi Carta Blanca
1 ounce fake lime juice, (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce rich simple syrup, (2:1, sugar: water)
instructions: 1. Chill the rum and fake lime juice.
2. Combine the rum, fake lime juice and simple syrup in a mixing glass and stir without ice.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Astral Plane
intro_philosophy: This reinterpretation of the notably sweet White Port & Tonic gets a balancing one-two hit of bitterness from Salers and Peychaud’s, alongside the notable dose of lemon juice.
ingredients: 1 ounce white port, preferably Quinta do Infantado White Porto
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients except for soda water with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water and garnish with a grapefruit crescent.

title: Bay Watch
intro_philosophy: “My family is from the West Indies, so my mom grew up her whole life eating [soursop],” explains Paige Walwyn of her interest in the tropical fruit, which she incorporates into a syrup for this cocktail. Combining bay leaf–infused blanco tequila, lime juice, vanilla liqueur and a Thai chile tincture, the Bay Watch reads like a spicy Margarita, by way of the tropics.
ingredients: 2 ounces bay leaf–infused blanco tequila, preferably Lunazul (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce vanilla liqueur, preferably Giffard Vanille de Madagascar
2 drops Thai chile tincture (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a mint bouquet.

title: Disco Volante
intro_philosophy: “I find that most milk punches are on the wintry end of the spectrum—lots of rum, brandy and whiskey with cloves and nutmeg,” says Up and Up’s Matt Piacentini, noting that those flavors typically work in tandem with the heavy, smooth textures that the milk punch application contributes to drinks. But veering away from the familiar, Piacentini’s Disco Volante, built on a foundation of Aperol and gin, reads more like a bracing, herbal aperitif with the added roundness of a milk punch.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except milk, in a container and set aside.
2. Heat the milk in a medium pot over the stove to around 170ºF, enough to break it and get it steaming, but not enough to scald it.
3. Remove pot from heat, and add Aperol mixture to the pot. It will begin to curdle immediately.
4. Stir for 1 to 2 minutes to let it finish curdling before clarifying.

5. Line a large sieve with four layers of cheesecloth so that the cloth is hanging over the edges. (As the liquid goes in, it will pull the cloth down, and you want enough slack to keep it from falling in on itself.) Prepare two separate containers to strain the liquid into.

6. Pour in enough of the liquid to fill the sieve about an inch from the top.  At first, the liquid will run through fast and be cloudy—You are creating the curd layer that will actually do the filtering. After about 15 to 20 seconds, the stream will slow down to a trickle and become clear.  At this point, lift the (still draining) sieve to the second container and rest it on the rim.

7. Pour the cloudy liquid from the initial straining back into the sieve into the second container. As the sieve drains, continue to pour the contents of the pot into it, never going above the line of the initial pour, or you will get solids going through the cloth. (It can take about 20 minutes per liter to strain through.)

8. As it’s straining, check to make sure the output is perfectly clear. It will a pinkish orange color, but still transparent. If it is cloudy, just pour it in a new container and re-run it through the sieve.
9. Allow mixture to cool in fridge.
10. Serve in a rocks glass over ice.
11. Express grapefruit peel and discard.

title: Harry’s Matador
intro_philosophy: This version of the classicMatadorcocktail drinks like a tequilaManhattan, with the rich, almost chocolatey notes of reposado tequila taking center stage. Choose a good reposado or añejo tequila, Ivan Mitankin advises: “You need a wood-aged tequila for the cocktail to come alive. With a blanco, it just loses it.”
instructions: 1. Combine first four ingredients in a mixing glass over ice.
2. Twist a grapefruit peel over the top of the glass to express the essential oils, then discard.
3. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
4. Garnish with dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Electric Circus
intro_philosophy: “I wouldn’t describe myself as a Midori fanatic,” says Chall Gray, co-owner of Asheville, North Carolina’s Little Jumbo. However, in thisLast Wordriff, the melon liqueur nicely accentuates the herbal notes of gin andgénépy, and plays well with tart lemon juice, he notes.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce gin, such as The Botanist
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Cool As Clarence
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to create something with complementing, cooling flavors,” says Stacey Swenson of her “chill summer highball.” The combination of blanco tequila and blanc vermouth pops with notes of fresh cucumber and melon; a splash of coconut milk adds texture. The drink is rimmed with salt kicked up with sesame and Thai chili, introducing a touch of heat with every sip.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Espolón Blanco
1/2 ounce blanc vermouth, preferably Dolin Blanc
3 1/2 ounces Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water
instructions: 1. Cut a small notch in the center of the lime wedge and run it around half the rim of a chilled Collins glass, gently squeezing the lime as you go, coating around two inches of the outside of the glass.

2. Add a combination of sesame seeds, ground dried Thai chilis and sea salt (in a 2:2:1 ratio) to a plate and tip the lime-slicked portion of the glass onto its side, parallel to the plate. Gently roll to coat half the rim and outside of the glass with a thick layer of the spice mixture. Gently shake off any excess.
3. Combine all the ingredients except the Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water in a mixing tin filled with ice and shake until chilled.
4. Add the Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water to the mixing tin and strain into the chilled, rimmed Collins glass over fresh ice.

title: Raspberry Beret
intro_philosophy: While ginger beer has always been the defining characteristic of the mule, today’s bartenders often translate its spicy character in a more concentrated form by way of ginger syrup, using elements like fresh fruit and liqueurs to up the flavor ante. Such is the case with Jordan Brower’s rendition, which relies on muddled raspberries and Luxardo bitters to brighten the bourbon-base.
instructions: 1. Muddle the raspberries in the bottom of a mixing tin.
2. Add in all remaining ingredients, except the soda water, shake with ice.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Top with soda water and garnish with raspberry and candied ginger.

title: Pebble Rebel
intro_philosophy: Broken Shaker L.A.’sChristine Wisemanemploys spent espresso in a cordial inspired by Trash Tiki’s Kelsey Ramage and Iain Griffiths. “I’m always looking for ways to reuse ingredients that we use throughout the hotel,” says Wiseman. “It helps with your liquor cost on that cocktail,andit’s a win for the environment.” But beyond the anti-waste sentiment, she prefers second-use espresso in her Pebble Rebel, for its lighter, less intense coffee flavor compared to traditional grounds, which pairs with Fruity Pebbles–infused vodka, cold-brew liqueur and sunflower seed milk.
ingredients: 1 ounce Fruity Pebble-infused vodka (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce Ketel One Botanical Peach and Orange Blossom
1/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
1 ounce berry sunflower seed milk (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce spent espresso ground cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in rocks glass over crushed ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with Fruity Pebbles.

title: Hot Lips
intro_philosophy: “This cocktail is a brilliant mix of flavors that just work,” saysLynnette Marreroof this smoky-spicy Margarita made famous at The NoMad.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon Petite Canne sugar cane syrup
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass filled with ice.

title: Gin & Juice
intro_philosophy:
At New York City’s first cider bar, Wassail, cider cocktails are a mainstay, and bartender Jade Sotack rotates her Gin & Juice seasonally. “The Gin & Juice is a seasonal take on sidra, plus an adjunct,” she explains.

A recent iteration saw a play on the G&T: tonic syrup and gin topped with sidra, for a funkier version of the classic refresher.
ingredients: 1 ounce  tonic syrup, preferably Yeoman from Small Hand Foods
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to an ice-filled Collins or double rocks glass, and stir to combine.
2. Garnish with a lemon peel.

title: Jelani Johnson’s Mai Tai
intro_philosophy: Placing third in our recent Mai Tai blind tasting,Jelani Johnson’s drink had a fruity abundance of mint, lime and orange in the glass and a long finish.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Worthy Park Single Estate Reserve Rum
1 ounce lime juice (hand squeezed, with one shell reserved to shake and one reserved for garnish)
1 teaspoon rich cane sugar syrup (2:1, cane sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except garnish lime shell in a mixing tin and shake with a four-finger pinch of crushed ice until dissolved.
2. Pour into a double rocks glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with lavish mint plume with reserved lime shell tucked besides it. Serve with a straw.

title: Michaelmas Term
intro_philosophy: An improved Whiskey Cocktail in the style of the decades following the Civil War. Michaelmas (pronounced “mickle-mus”) is the fall semester in the British academic system, typically spanning from late September through Christmas. Al Culliton notes that the word transports them back to fond memories of their days as a young medievalist studying in Canterbury, England, and inspired this autumnal cocktail modified with port, amaro and crème de cacao.
ingredients: 2 ounces bonded rye whiskey, preferably Rittenhouse
1/4 ounce ruby port, preferably Quinta do Infantado
1/4 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
5 drops saline solution or a tiny pinch of salt
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass, fill with ice, and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express the orange peel over the drink and garnish with the peel and a cherry.
4. If using, serve the cola neat in a very small glass on the side.

title: Gram-Arita
intro_philosophy: Singer-songwriter Gram Parsons’ favorite cocktail was theCadillac Margarita. In an ode to the artist, who had his last Margarita at the Copper Room, the Yucca Valley bar created this on-tap rendition garnished with a half salt rim, as Parsons liked it. While the Copper Room pre-batches the drink to have on draft, this version is scaled down for a single serving.
instructions: 1. Rim half of a glass with salt and set aside.
2. Combine first three ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared glass over ice.
4. Float Grand Marnier on top.
5. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Pearl Diver
intro_philosophy: The most celebrated drink to feature Gardenia Mix—an unusual amalgam, consisting of honey, butter and spiced syrups—the Pearl Diver is Donn Beach’s iced take on the Hot Buttered Rum. “The mouthfeel on that drink,” says Jeff “Beachbum” Berry, “is just unbelievable.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce demerara rum, preferably Hamilton 86-proof or El Dorado 8-year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender, starting with the Gardenia Mix and finishing with the ice.
2. Blend at a high speed for 15 seconds.
3. Strain through a medium-mesh wire sieve into a Pearl Diver glass, pressing gently on the solids to express all the liquid.
4. Add crushed ice ice to fill the glass.
5. Garnish with a geranium leaf.

title: Distiller’s Pick-Me-Up
intro_philosophy: Bartender Jelani Johnson, a former rum distiller himself, looked to the early mornings of his distilling days as inspiration for this highball, which uses as a base premiumBACARDÍ Añejo Cuatro Rum. Inspired by what he knowingly calls “a distiller’s morning coffee,” he builds upon the rich backbone of molasses and baking spice present inFever-Tree Distillers Colato offer a tropical twist on the classic Rum & Cola.
instructions: 1. Pour Fever-Tree Distillers Cola into a highball glass over ice.
2. Shake rums, juices and liqueur, then strain over cola.
3. Garnish with pineapple fronds, a swizzle stick and a lemon wheel. Serve with a straw.

title: New Dawn
ingredients: 1/2 part jasmine tea syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the liquid ingredients in a cocktail shaker with one ice cube and shake vigorously until the ice is melted and all the ingredients are incorporated.
2. Pour into a collins glass, filled with crushed ice, and garnish with a pineapple frond and a cherry.

title: Prado
intro_philosophy: The Prado, a little-known egg white sour from Stan Jones’ 1977Barguide, calls for tequila, maraschino and lime. At Good Neighbor Bar in Altadena, California, Jesus Gomez is bringing the cocktail to a new generation of drinkers. It’s been incredibly well-received—likely because of its unusual combination of tequila and egg white, along with its overall dry profile.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blanco tequila, such as Gran Clásico
1/2 ounce maraschino liqueur, such as Maraska
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Dry-shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake to chill.
4. Double-strain into a coupe.
5. Garnish with a cherry and a lime wedge on a pick.

title: Appetizer à L’Italienne
intro_philosophy: “Of all of the drinks in the world, there are few as mystical and confusing as the Appetizer à L’Italienne,” says bartender Ezra Star, who finds herself turning to the oddball concoction as a post-shift drink that can be thrown together with ease. Originally published in 1892 by William Schmidt inThe Flowing Bowl, the recipe is an enigma. As Star explains, it’s a “drink that is not an appetizer but a digestif, and a name that is not Italian but French, despite having only one French ingredient.”
ingredients: 2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
1/4 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Bright Side
intro_philosophy: Pisco is the star of Portland, Oregon’s bestselling drink, the Bright Side. The refreshing drink features tropical staples like rum, pineapple juice and mango purée, but it also gets the surprising addition of turmeric syrup, which the bar makes by combining fresh-squeezed turmeric juice, water andcane sugar.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce turmeric syrup (1 part fresh turmeric juice, 1 part filtered water, 2 parts cane sugar)
1/2 ounce mango puree, such as Boiron or Perfect Puree
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and short-shake with a few large ice cubes.
2. Strain over cobbled ice into a tall glass.
3. Garnish with a pineapple frond and slice, and an optional cocktail umbrella.

title: Watership Down
intro_philosophy: Named for the adventure story about an anthropomorphized pack of English rabbits, the Watership Down is New York bartender Jeremy Oertel’s ode to the classic novel of the same title. “Rabbits like grass and celery and the flavors make me think of fields and summer,” he says. This light, dry cocktail is a riff on one of Oertel’s favorites, the Loop Tonic, a staple of the tequila and mezcal barMayahuel. Oertel makes his version for the Brooklyn bar Donna with fresh ginger syrup and Brooklyn-madeDorothy Parker Gin.
instructions: 1. Add gin, vermouth, ginger syrup and shrub to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Garnish with a celery stick.

title: Salt & Ash
intro_philosophy: Originally created for the Counting Room in Brooklyn, Maks Pazuniak brought his Salt & Ash toJupiter Discowhen he and Al Sotack opened the bar in 2016. The recipe, which combines smoky mezcal, grapefruit-infused tequila, lemon juice and several other modifiers, is itself a riff on Pazuniak’s own Improved Scotch Sling that was featured on the menu at New Orleans’Cureas well as in the recipe collection entitledBeta Cocktails.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Chichicapa
1/2 ounce Lapsang tea-infused sweet vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Express a grapefruit twist over the surface of the drink then discard.

title: New Tone
intro_philosophy: “Cynar was really the first amaro I dug into and thought about mixing into non-classic cocktails,” says Claire Sprouse. Her New Tone is a food-friendly spritz-highball hybrid that takes inspiration from a classic Cynar and soda mixed with a bittersweet twist on a Dark & Stormy. The secret ingredient is a homemade fig leaf soda in place of club soda or ginger beer. “It tastes like grassy coconut,” says Sprouse of the fig leaf. “It’s completely insane.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce overproof rum, preferably Wray & Nephew
4 ounces Fig Leaf Soda (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins or highball glass over a clear ice spear, layering first the soda, then rum, then top with Cynar.

title: Juniperotivo
intro_philosophy: Traditional formulas were a significant source of inspiration for bartenders in the early years of the cocktail renaissance. The Mojito, in particular, proved to be a fruitful template to riff on, spawning such classics as theGin-Gin Mule, theOld Cubanand this, the Juniperotivo: a straightforward mixture of gin, lime and muddled mint, with the unexpected addition of pomegranate syrup, which would further the trend of fresh ingredients and culinary inspired cocktails.
instructions: 1. In mixing glass, using a spoon, crush two mint leaves in the simple syrup, and add gin, lime juice and pomegranate syrup.
2. Pour into ice-filled shaker. Shake well and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
3. To garnish, float the two remaining mint leaves on surface of drink.

title: One Toucan Can
intro_philosophy: “I wouldn’t be surprised if my love for global cuisine started as a kid growing up in Florida, spending so many days at Disney World—namely Epcot—with my family,” saysMak Kelly, bar manager atLady Jane.“Usually I am inspired by something really specific—it becomes kind of like a science project to see how true to the original material I can be.” TheOne Toucan Can combines pineapple-infused rum and spicy green chile vodka, with extra tropical flair courtesy of banana liqueur and pineapple amaro. Small measures of Salers and Cocchi Americano bring depth and a drying effect to the glass for a drink meant to evoke “hot Orlando afternoons and spicy pineapple hot dogs.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces pineapple rind rum (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce St. George Green Chile Vodka
instructions: 1. Place the banana leaf at the bottom of a rocks glass below a large ice cube.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared glass.
4. Spritz the pechuga from an atomizer over the finished cocktail.

title: Banana Bliss
intro_philosophy: Caitlin Laman, beverage manager at the Ace Hotel Chicago, builds on an under-publicized entry from the 1937Café Royal Cocktail Bookwith this riff on the Banana Bliss. The original recipe calls for shaking equal parts Cognac and banana liqueur, but Laman introduces oloroso sherry to the mix and opts to stir the drink to maintain the sharpness of the base flavors.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce oloroso sherry, preferably César Florido Oloroso Cruz del Mar
1/4 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Nui Nui
intro_philosophy: The reasons the Nui Nui, a Donn Beach classic, makes for a Christmas hit are obvious: It’s got cinnamon, spice and everything nice, and all the world wants this time of year is vanilla-flavored everything, not to mention peak citrus season starts in December. The 1930s recipe delivers, then adds a hearty dose of rum into the equation. Seattle bartender Andrew Bohrer prefers to split the rum quotient into a blend of Demerara and Jamaican versions, plus cachaça.
ingredients: 2 ounces aged rum, or an equal-parts blend of Demerara rum, Jamaican rum and cachaça
3/4 ounce cinnamon syrup, preferably BG Reynolds
1/4 ounce vanilla syrup, preferably BG Reynolds
1/4 ounce allspice dram, preferably St. Elizabeth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Shake and strain over crushed ice.
3. Top with a couple dashes of your favorite aromatic bitters, a dash of vanilla extract, a dusting of cinnamon and a citrus twist.

title: Best G&T You Can Muster If You Can’t Muster Much
intro_philosophy: Though Dave Arnold—founder of New York’s Museum of Food and Drink and the pioneering cocktail bars Booker and Dax and Existing Conditions—has obsessed over the Gin & Tonic, creating his archetypal version of the drink with a force-carbonated mixture of clarified lime juice, housemade tonic syrup and filtered water, this version is much simpler. This recipe eschews special equipment to hyperfocus on the procedure of building the drink for maximum carbonation with the drink’s common ingredients.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces London dry gin, preferably Bombay Dry
3 1/4 ounces tonic water, preferably in a glass bottle
instructions: 1. In preparation, place a highball glass or glass of your choice as well as the gin in the freezer.
2. Place a fresh glass bottle of tonic water in an ice bath.
3. Once the ingredients have chilled, pour the gin into the glass.
4. Angle the glass and ease the tonic water down the side of the glass as delicately as possible.
5. Squeeze the lime wedge into the glass.
6. Gently lower a large ice cube into the drink, being careful to agitate the mixture as little as possible.

title: Colonial Affair
intro_philosophy: In his riff on theTwentieth Centurycocktail,Joaquín Simóstays true to the spirit of the original by sticking with a clear spirit base, but opts instead for a blend of pisco and cacao spirit (“adistillate derived from the pulpy fruit surrounding the cacao seeds,” he explains) in place of gin. The slight chocolate notes are further enhanced by whitecrème de cacaoon the finish.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce pisco, preferably Campo de Encanto Acholado
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.

title: Redemption #3
intro_philosophy: Melon-flavored Midori meets its match with herbal green Chartreuse. Together, they make a neon-bright drink that calls on a bevy of quintessentially Japanese flavors by way of Suntory Toki whisky, wasabi tincture and a matcha garnish.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Japanese whiskey, preferably Suntory Toki
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin without ice.
2. Dry shake, then add ice, shake again.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.
4. Garnish with matcha.

title: Manhattan Highball
intro_philosophy: A classicManhattanmade tall by the addition of tonic water, Alexis Simonidis of Theory Bar turns the bracing, boozy drink on its head for a tall and bubbly rendition.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, chilled (preferably Mancino Rosso)
instructions: 1. In a highball glass with a long ice spear, add the rye and sweet vermouth.
2. Top with tonic.
3. Garnish with an expressed and discarded orange peel and a maraschino cherry.

title: Amaretti Sour
intro_philosophy:
At Swan Room in New York City, the Amaretti Sour is a nonalcoholic take on theAmaretto Sour, which swaps out the namesake liqueur and whiskey for two analogous zero-proof products from Lyre’s.

NB: The foaming agent used in this recipe contains a small amount of alcohol. For a completely alcohol-free drink, substitute an egg white or aquafaba.
ingredients: 6 drops Ms. Better Bitters Miraculous Foamer
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with ice and shake well.
2. Strain over fresh ice into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon-cherry flag.

title: Chartreuse Saz
intro_philosophy: “The first time I made this drink, it was because someone wanted a strong cocktail,” Seth Raymond says of this Sazerac variation. His solution: swap out a half-ounce of simple syrup for yellow Chartreuse. For a less-boozy Sazerac, use a quarter-ounce each of rich simple syrup and yellow Chartreuse; it will still add subtle honey and spice to the drink.
instructions: 1. Pour absinthe into a rocks glass, and rotate the glass to coat the interior. Pour out excess absinthe.
2. Twist lemon peel over glass to express oils, then drop peel into the glass. Set glass aside.
3. Combine remaining ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
4. Strain into the prepared rocks glass.

title: Penichillin
intro_philosophy: At Diamond Reef, this frozen Penicillin riff is made in large batches in a Slushie machine, ideal for sipping in the expansive backyard space. This adaptation uses the blender for a similar effect. Note that the peated Scotch is not added to the blender; it’s added at the last minute over the top of the drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces blend Scotch whisky, preferably Monkey Shoulder
instructions: 1. In a blender, combine first four ingredients and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a footed Irish whiskey glass.
3. Gently pour the peated whiskey on top of the drink.
4. Serve with a straw and garnish with a paper parasol.

title: Mojito Caballito
intro_philosophy: The Mojito Caballito is a little-known riff on theCuban classicthat adds French vermouth to the Mojito’s traditional mix of rum, lime, sugar, mint and soda. According to Jeff “Beachbum” Berry, the drink was first recorded aticonic Havana bar Sloppy Joe’sin the early 1930s. At Lei Low in Houston, owner Russell Thoede interprets “French vermouth” as blanc (instead of dry), and his choice of a sherry-based blanc vermouth binds the whole drink together with its combination of salinity and rancio, citrus and pear notes. Thoede pairs this vermouth with a blended white rum that delivers vanilla, tropical fruit and a touch of funk. Lei Low is so proud of the “Caballito” spec that all calls for Mojitos at the bar are answered with it.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces carbonated mineral water, such as Topo Chico
1 1/2 ounces white rum, such as Foursquare Probitas
3/4 ounce sherry-based blanc vermouth, such as Lustau Vermut Blanco
instructions: 1. In a Zombie glass, combine the lime juice, syrup and mint.
2. Pour the mineral water on top and gently agitate to extract the mint's oils.
3. Add pebble ice or similar, top with rum and vermouth, and lightly swizzle.
4. Top with more pebble ice, then garnish with a lime wheel and a slapped mint bouquet.

title: The Art of Choke
intro_philosophy: With its split base of white rum and Cynar, The Art of Choke was first created by bartender Kyle Davidson at The Violet Hour in Chicago in 2008. “That drink ran against everything I taught him,” says Toby Maloney, who was dumbfounded when he was first presented with the cocktail. Nonetheless, people ordered it. Today, it’s considered a modern classic.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Nice One
intro_philosophy: The work of bartender Dan Greenbaum—who is known for his affinity with sherry—the Nice One is basically an equal partsAdonis(amontillado sherry and sweet vermouth), with a half ounce banana liqueur thrown in, garnished with an orange twist. It’s light and nutty, with the banana keeping respectfully to the rear.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces amontillado sherry, preferably Lustau Amontillado Los Arcos
Shy 1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with an orange twist.

title: Barbacoa
intro_philosophy: Created in Los Angeles in 2009, the Barbacoa belongs to the culinary cocktail movement, representing the West Coast style of bartending that leaned into fresh, local produce. The recipe, which calls for muddling bell peppers and Fresno chiles alongside ginger syrup and citrus juice, is emblematic of the then-nascent farm-to-glass ethos of cocktails. Savory, spicy and smoky, it helped pave the way for the recent wave of modern cocktails that seek to translate food into drinks.
ingredients: 1 pinch thinly sliced red Fresno chile
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, combine all the ingredients and muddle them together.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Pour into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
4. Garnish with a piece of beef jerky.

title: Beertini
intro_philosophy: In certain pockets of the Midwest, the combination of beer and olives is known as the Beertini, a drink deeply engrained in barroom culture. What the drink lacks in a colorful origin story, it makes up for in simple best practices: Craft beer varieties need not apply, and the olives can only be green, the kind most often found swimming in their own juices on dusty bar tops.
instructions: 1. Pour beer into a chilled mug.
2. Add in the olives and olive brine, if desired.

title: Sunflower Seed Orgeat
intro_philosophy: “I like sunflower seeds for a lot of reasons,” says Claire Sprouse: they’re drought-resistant, have deep root systems that reach untapped nutrients in lower soils, they gobble up excess nitrogen in the soil, the market is GMO free, they’re relatively low-carbon intensity to harvest and process, and the flowers can be used to feed animals or as a fertilizer for other crops. Plus, she adds, “they are delicious!”
ingredients: 200 grams sunflower seeds, unsalted and roasted
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Strain through a chinois.

title: Suze & Tonic
intro_philosophy:
An uncomplicated low-ABV alternative to the Gin & Tonic, this cocktail swaps out the juniper for bracing but refreshing gentian flavors at a fraction of the proof. This super easy format reflects the way the yellow Swiss-made aperitif is most commonly consumed on its home continent: with a single mixer, or simply straight.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Fill a Collins glass with ice.
2. Add the Suze.
3. Top with tonic water.

title: Endless Summer
intro_philosophy: In his Endless Summer, or a “Negroni on vacation,” as he calls it, Yanni Kehagiaras combines the big three—Campari, gin, sweet vermouth—with an ounce of pineapple and shakes the drink, pours it over ice and, in a testament to his more minimalist approach to tropical drinks, goes garnish-less.
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, preferably City of London
instructions: 1. In a large shaking tin, add all ingredients. Add ice, and shake well.
2. Fine strain into a Collins glass over ice.

title: Clarito
intro_philosophy: The Clarito, a charitable pour of extra-dry gin and a splash of dry vermouth, perfumed with lemon peel, is Buenos Aires, Argentina’s signature Martini.
instructions: 1. Prepare two coupe glasses by moistening each rim with a lemon peel, then pressing the rim into a plate of sugar.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with walnut-size ice and stir for 1 minute.
3. Strain into the sugar-rimmed coupe glasses.

title: Refuge’s French Martini
intro_philosophy: At Refuge in Houston, bartender Máté Hartai set out to make “a really good French Martini without being too serious about it.” Swapping out the Chambord for raspberry brandy and liqueur, this version could arguably fit on any menu in 1995.
ingredients: 1 ounce raspberry brandy, preferably Schladerer Himbeergeist
3/4 ounce raspberry liqueur, preferably Schladerer Himbeer
3/4 ounce pineapple juice with a 3% by-weight addition of citric acid
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a V-shaped cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a raspberry skewered to a pineapple frond with your fanciest cocktail pick.

title: 19th Century
intro_philosophy: Commonly associated with theTwentieth Centurycocktail—a gin-based drink with Lillet blanc, cacao and lemon—cacao also makes an appearance in this classic bourbon-based riff, originally created by Brian Miller at New York’s Pegu Club. Beginning with a hefty base of bourbon, it’s shaken with equal parts cacao white, Lillet rouge and fresh lemon juice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin with ice and shake.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.

title: Negroni Sbagliato
intro_philosophy: Like all good stories should, the one about theNegroni’sorigin involves rakish Italian nobility. Most accounts credit the recipe to one Count Negroni, a swashbuckling proto-boho who reportedly spent time as a rodeo cowboy in the United States. Compounding his wild ways, legend has it that back at a bar in Italy in 1919, he asked for a something like an Americano, but boozier. Swap gin for soda water, and presto, the Negroni. Thesbagliatoaddendum translates to “incorrect” or “mistaken.” The Negroni’s spritzy cousin, the Sbagliato subs prosecco in for gin, creating a buoyantly bitter Italian aperitivo drink.
instructions: 1. In a rocks or lowball glass, add Campari, sweet vermouth and ice.
2. Top with prosecco or sparkling wine and stir gently to combine.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Enzoni
intro_philosophy: When it was created in the early 2000s, the Enzoni was ahead of its time. It would take two decades and a wave of aperitivo mania for the bittersweet Campari-spiked sour to shine in the spotlight. Today, it has become a popular entry point for drinkers just discovering the world of bitter cocktails.
instructions: 1. Add the grapes to a cocktail shaker and muddle.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and ice, and shake until chilled.
3. Double-strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
4. Garnish with an orange slice and a green grape.

title: Wild Green Strawberries
intro_philosophy: Annie Williams Piercecame up with this “juicy, herbaceous green cocktail” after trying Casamara Club’s chamomile-forward Capo amaro soda, which she pairs with strawberry-infused blanc vermouth and aquavit. She notes that it’s important to use only a small amount of ice, to prevent over dilution of the soda.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce strawberry-infused blanc vermouth, preferably Dolin Blanc Vermouth de Chambéry (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass.
2. Add half the quantity of ice to prevent over-dilution of the soda.
3. Stir to integrate.
4. Garnish with infused strawberries.

title: BB Highball
intro_philosophy: Brooklyn bartender Jon Mullen’s avant-garde highball is inspired by seasonality and sustainability. To a base of Braulio, he adds dehydrated citrus juice (or “citrus caramel,” as he calls it), fall-forward concord grape juice, a measure of gin and bitters. The dehydration of the juice is his means of repurposing fresh citrus that is past its prime and would otherwise be tossed out; it results in a high-acid jelly that is a great balancer in drinks and, in this case, punches up the aromatics in Braulio. “Small doses of amaro are great to add bitterness and texture to drinks,” says Mullen, “while more amaro-forward cocktails offer an opportunity to introduce guests to the category and the complex flavors it has to offer.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce fresh Concord grape juice or Grower's Co-Op Concord Grape Concentrate
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the garnish in a Collins glass filled with ice and stir to chill.
2. Top with soda water.
3. Garnish with fresh purple shiso leaves, a mint sprig and a lemon peel trimmed into a rectangle or parallelogram.

title: Bluebird Eggnog
intro_philosophy: The traditional holiday classic is made lighter and frothier in this made-to-order riff fromThe Bluebirdin Baltimore. Co-owner Paul Benkert added the classic to the menu as a way to complement the bar, which gets decked out every winter. A local white rum with molasses notes and a smoked-apple brandy provide the base, with simple syrup, heavy cream and an egg completing the Christmastime cocktail. The unique garnish is made from tempered high-quality white chocolate in the shape of an eggshell. Says Benkert:“The garnish transforms it from just feeling like a glass of milk into a cocktail.”
ingredients: 1 ounce rum, preferably Lyon White Rum
1 whole egg, preferably an Amish egg
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and dry-shake vigorously.
2. Add ice, and quickly hard-shake.
3. Double-strain into a rocks glass with light ice.
4. To garnish, place a white chocolate eggshell on top of the cocktail.

title: House Martini
intro_philosophy: The House Martini from Public Parking, one of ourBest New Bars of 2024, relies on arice-washed Japanese ginas the base, lending the drink a slightly cloudy appearance and a sake-like note that distinguishes the drink from a classic dry Martini. It’s finished with a salted cherry blossom solution and served with a garnish of dried seaweed topped with toasted rice and dried shiozakura (left over from the rice wash and solution-making process, respectively).
ingredients: 2 ounces mochi rice–washed gin, such as Tenjaku (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce dry vermouth, such as Brovo Spirits Witty
3 drops of shiozakura saline solution (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Serve with dried seaweed, pickled ginger, dried shiozakura (salt-preserved cherry blossom), toasted rice tossed in wasabi powder and Japanese seven-spice.

title: Capitán
intro_philosophy: A pisco-based cocktail dating from Lima’s Belle Époque era,the Capitáncombines pisco and sweet vermouth, served up with a green olive. At Bar Capitán Meléndez, Roberto Meléndez serves a traditional version of the coastal capital’s classic, which appeals to enthusiasts of the Manhattan or Martini.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Cinzano Rosso
instructions: 1. Combine the pisco and vermouth in a mixing glass with ice and stir for a few seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with an unpitted green olive.

title: Expect the Unexpected
intro_philosophy: Eric Simmonsdescribes his Expect the Unexpected as “one of those kitchen drinks.” That is, the sweetener is a  cilantro-cayenne-honey syrup, which is shaken with tequila, lime and grapefruit juices, made frothy by aquafaba, or chickpea cooking liquid. Though it may strike certain drinkers as adventurous, Simmons insists that the elements he pulls in from the kitchen “hit all points for everybody”—they are culinary and crowd-pleasing.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain until a coupe.
3. Garnish with a cilantro leaf.

title: Petit Fleur
intro_philosophy: “Bright, refreshing, slightly bitter; these are the hallmarks of a perfect aperitif,” explains Ryan Wainwright. Here, St-Germain forms the backbone of Wainright’s pre-dinner drink, while bitter and citrus elements complement the floral aromatics of the elderflower liqueur. “For me it is all about creating a drink that reminds me of an apothecary’s staff,” explains Wainwright, “The St-Germain being the staff and the rest being the snakes winding around it, bound to it but also creating new intrigue to complement it.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat original
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with cracked ice.
2. Pour into a wine glass with 5 1-inch ice cubes.
3. Top with soda water and Champagne.
4. Garnish with an orange wedge.

title: Misses Doe’s “Menschy” Manhattan
intro_philosophy: Jill Dobias of Joe & Misses Doe mixes equal parts dry vermouth and super-sweet Manischewitz for a riff on the classic Manhattan.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Yzaguirre Dry Riserva
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a Martini glass.
4. Garnish with soaked cherries.

title: Rum to the Jungle
intro_philosophy: The Rum to the Jungle is Fanny Chu’s nut-free take on the Mai Tai. “I feel really bad that people can’t taste a proper Mai Tai,” says Chu, noting that allergies to the almond-based orgeat preclude many people from trying one of her favorite drinks. Her Rum to the Jungle calls on a housemade cinnamon oat syrup in place of orgeat as well as Clairin and banana liqueur, an oddball addition that manages to make this spin even more tropical than the original.
ingredients: 1 ounce cinnamon oat syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce port, preferably Graham's Six Grapes Reserve Port, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except port, in a mixing tin, and whip shake with a few pieces of pebble ice.
2. Strain into a snifter glass over pebble ice.
3. Top with port, then add more pebble ice.
4. Garnish with mint sprigs, orchid and torched cinnamon stick.

title: 50/50 Martini With House Vermouth
intro_philosophy: Severance uses its house vermouth blend across all of its Martini variations, “but specifically in a 50/50 with a dash of orange bitters, it is rather unstoppable,” says Evan Charest. The secret: a small measure of manzanilla sherry, which “adds a freshness to the house style that cannot be matched.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Severance House Vermouth (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Brucio in Bocca
intro_philosophy: One of the top sellers at Miami’s ViceVersa, one of ourBest New Bars of 2024, this play on the spicy Margarita leans on fresh, fluffy pineapple juice in lieu of lime and sweet vermouth, and a Barolo reduction in place of orange liqueur. The drink is garnished with a rim of red wine salt, made with leftover wine that might otherwise go to waste.
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass by adding red wine salt around the rim.
2. Combine the ingredients in a shaker and dry-shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake again.
4. Strain into the prepared rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: 86 Long Island Iced Tea
intro_philosophy: Responsible for many a headache (and a bad decision), the Long Island Iced Tea is a potent mix of four white spirits including vodka, tequila, rum and gin swirled together with sugar and lemon, and topped with Coca-Cola to create the hue of golden iced tea. Bob “Rosebud” Butt claims to have created the cocktail during a competition in 1972 at the Oak Beach Inn East on (of course) Long Island. His version included triple sec, the competition’s challenge ingredient. This recipe, from New York 1970s meccaGolden Cadillac, eliminates triple sec and uses the86 Co.’s portfolioto create the heady base for one of the most famous hangover instigators the bar has ever known.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients (except Coca-Cola) to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with a splash of Coca-Cola and garnish with a lemon wedge.

title: Sixty Forty
intro_philosophy: At Sip—one half of the bi-level New York bar Sip & Guzzle—the Sixty Forty is designed to channel a Martini when ice-cold, then a Manhattan as it settles. It calls on gin and whiskey, both dry and sweet vermouths, and, as an accent to the drink, Seedlip Spice and Seedlip Garden, two N/A spirits.
ingredients: 2 ounces gin, such as Bombay Sapphire
1/3 ounce rye whiskey, such as Rittenhouse
1/3 ounce dry vermouth, such as Mancino Secco
1/3 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Mancino Rosso
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a Martini glass.
3. Garnish with an olive and a cherry.

title: Trash-Tini
intro_philosophy: Despite the name, a surprising amount of precision and care goes into this multilayered creation by Christine Wiseman. The kitchen-sinkMartinivariation includes gin, vodka, Luxardo Bitter Bianco, charred onion–infused dry vermouth, celery shrub, sherry vinegar and two garnishes: an olive and a cocktail onion. The kitchen sink never tasted so good.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce gin, such as Plymouth Gin
3/4 ounce vodka, such as Grey Goose
3/4 ounce charred onion–infused dry vermouth (see Editor's Note)
2 dashes Bittermens Orchard Street Celery Shrub
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a mixing glass over cubed ice and stir until chilled.
2. Using a julep strainer, strain the cocktail into a chilled coupe glass, or serve on the rocks.
3. Garnish with a cocktail onion and an olive on a pick.

title: Dark ’n’ Stormy
intro_philosophy: This simple mix of dark rum and ginger beer over ice has roots in colonial Bermuda, where England’s Royal Navy opened a ginger beer plant in the late 19th century. The drink was traditionally made with a dark, heavy Demerara-style rum, which was part of the sailors’ daily rations. A note: Gosling Brothers bought the trademark to the Dark ’n’ Stormy name and recipe, so Gosling’s Black Seal rum is the official rum of record for this drink.
ingredients: 4 ounces ginger beer (preferably something dry and spicy like Fentiman's or Fever Tree)
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, add rum and lime juice.
2. Add ice and top with ginger beer.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Shandy
intro_philosophy: Among the most well known in the catalogue of beer cocktails, the two-ingredient shandy has remained popular since its invention, thanks in part to its sheer simplicity. The fifty-fifty split between beer and ginger ale (or ginger beer) was first mentioned in its elongated form, shandygaff, in Edward Bradley’s 1853 comic novelThe Adventures of Mr. Verdant Green. Within a few decades, the mixture was established enough to earn a spot in Harry Johnson’sBartenders’ Manual,preserving the effortless and refreshing recipe for posterity.
