ingredients: 8 ounces ginger ale  or ginger beer
instructions: 1. Refrigerate the ginger ale or ginger beer and lager until well chilled.
2. Combine both ingredients in a pint glass.
3. Stir gently to integrate.

title: State Street Bloody Mary
intro_philosophy:
“Like any good cocktail, it really does reflect balance,” says Brian Bartels of the Bloody Mary. Havingauthored a book on the classic cocktail, he should know.

In his State Street, named for the main street in Madison, Wisconsin, where Bartels learned to bartend, he relies on a pre-batched mix with a variety of savory ingredients (Worcestershire sauce, soy sauce and Old Bay seasoning) and spicy ones (a trio of Tabasco Chipotle Sauce, Sriracha and both black and white peppers). Though he calls on mezcal to be used directly in the mix, any clear spirit, such as vodka, gin, tequila, mezcal or white whiskey, can be used as the base of this drink.

Finally, for a garnish, he stays close to his Wisconsin roots. Garnished with a skewer of cured meats and a celery stick, the drink comes with an additional “snit” of beer, or a three-ounce pour.
ingredients: 5 ounces State Street Bloody Mary mix (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine the vodka and Bloody Mary mix in a shaker tin.
2. Roll the ingredients back and forth between the shakers several times to combine.
3. Pour the mixture into a rocks glass filled with ice.
4. Top the drink with freshly ground black pepper, to taste, and garnish with skewered cured meats and a celery stalk.
5. Serve the Bloody Mary with a three-ounce beer chaser, or "snit."

title: Guinn & Tonic
intro_philosophy: This low-ABV drink looks and tastes a little like a boozy root beer float, enlivened by a pop of fresh-orange acidity. The secret ingredient: rich, chocolatey Guinness. (Note: The drink is pronounced with a hard G, like “Guinness,” not the soft J-like G of “gin,” and definitely not “gwinn.”)
instructions: 1. Pour the Montenegro and tonic water into a Collins glass.
2. Fill the glass with ice.
3. Add Guinness until the glass is about three-quarters full, and let it settle.
4. Top up with cava.
5. Squeeze an orange wedge into the drink, then use the wedge to garnish.

title: Fizz Italiano
intro_philosophy: At Los Angeles bar The Let’s Go Disco, the menu features all things bubbly and bittersweet. Fitting squarely within the“disco aperitivo” trendis the Fizz Italiano, which is built on a base of London dry gin and topped withnonalcoholic Italian sodaSanbittèr.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce maraschino liqueur, such as Leopold
instructions: 1. Combine the first six ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice.
2. Add a few ice cubes and shake again until the egg white is frothy.
3. Single-strain into a Collins glass.
4. Top with Sanbittèr

title: Gun Club Toddy
intro_philosophy: “I’m particularly fond of using [Pineau des Charentes] to amplify brandies, taking advantage of their inherent roundness and giving them just a bit more body,” explains Death & Co.’s Alexander Day. His riff on aHot Toddysees sweet, fruit-forward Pineau mixed with chamomile-infused Calvados, honey syrup and lemon juice, before being lengthened with water and garnished with an apple slice.
ingredients: 1 ounce Pineau des Charentes, preferably Paul-Maire & Fils
instructions: 1. Place all ingredients, except water, in a toddy mug.
2. Pour in boiling hot water and garnish with thin apple slices.

title: Consolation Prize
intro_philosophy: Cachaça and genever are not the easiest pairing, but in the right ratio, malty genever and oaky aged cachaça combine to create a near-whiskey flavor. Created by illustrator John Perry Yates for the 2014 World Cup third-place match between Brazil and the Netherlands, this Old-Fashioned style drink has shades of Jerry Thomas’s Improved Holland Gin Cocktail with its orange-y malt flavors. Maybe not the perfect cocktail, but good enough for third place.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain over a large rock into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Hinoki Martini
intro_philosophy: As befits a bar that tries to straddle Japanese and American cocktails styles, thisMartiniis an international affair, made with French vodka, Colorado gin, sake and sherry. This version, served at Katana Kitten, is accented by a tincture inspired by hinoki, a type of cypress tree native to central Japan; ashinokiis not available in the U.S., a close species of cypress tree from Colorado is used in its place. The tincture is applied in both dash and spray form—five of each—which lends a woodsy, cooling air to the drink.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces vodka, such as Grey Goose
1 1/4 ounces gin, such as Spring44 Mountain Gin
1/2 ounce fino sherry, such as Lustau Jarana
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled, about 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a stemless frozen glass. If you own a masu, fill it with crushed ice and nestle the glass in the ice.
3. Express a lemon twist over the drink and discard, then spritz hinoki tincture over the drink five times.
4. Garnish with an olive, rakkyu and cypress leaf in the masu.

title: Seoul Forest
intro_philosophy: Sungrae Choi, bartender at Seoul Salon, explains that pine is a touchstone of Korean culture, representing sincerity and tenacity (as an evergreen would). Koreans often embark on therapeutic “forest baths” to reconvene with nature, Choi says, and this cocktail is intended to evoke that sensation through its pine cordial. “I wanted to bring that pine flavor to the bar, so people can drink the cocktail and understand that part of Seoul.”
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, preferably Bombay Sapphire Premier Cru
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except prosecco in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake briefly.
2. Strain into a chilled rocks glass over a large ice cube, then top with prosecco.
3. Garnish with an herb bouquet.

title: Ti’ Punch Highball
intro_philosophy: Paul McGeestretches the classicTi’ Punchinto a highball-like format with the addition of coconut water and tonic.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rhum agricole, preferably J.M Rhum Agricole Blanc
3/4 teaspoon cane syrup, preferably Petite Canne
1 half-dollar-sized lime coin with some flesh on it
instructions: 1. In a highball glass, add the lime coin and muddle it to express the oils.
2. Add the sugar syrup, rum and 4 ice cubes and stir for a few seconds.
3. Add the coconut water and tonic water, then give one quick stir to integrate the ingredients.

title: Café Orgeat
intro_philosophy: For those who can’t bear the thought of going without almonds, Trash Tiki has a compromise: upcycled day-old almond croissants. “Just just hit up your local cafe and ask them to not throw out what they don’t sell,” the team suggests. The sugar, butter and oil are the functional ingredients, so don’t worry if the pastries aren’t perfectly fresh.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a sealed container for a minimum of 12 hours. Stir occasionally.
2. Blend all the ingredients in a blender or Vitamix until croissants are fully shredded.
3. Filter using a superbag or similar.
4. Store in the refrigerator or in an air-tight container.

title: Long Island Bar Gimlet
intro_philosophy:
Essentially a Gin Sour made with lime juice, legend has it that the Gimlet was created in the mid-19thcentury to encourage Royal Navy sailors to consume their rations of scurvy-preventing lime juice. The name? Possibly a reference to Thomas Desmond Gimlette, a naval medical officer who served during that era. Rose’s Lime Cordial, a syrup of sugar and lime juice, was invented around the same time to preserve lime juice during long bouts at sea; fundamentalist versions of the drink still call for it. The Rose’s of today, however, is a different animal, with high-fructose corn syrup and additives—stuff that wouldn’t make it past the door of any self-respecting craft cocktail bar.

This version is Brooklyn bartender Toby Cecchini’s rendition, which he serves atThe Long Island Bar. His Gimlet is infused with ginger-lime cordial and served on the rocks.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass (or into a chilled coupe glass).
4. Garnish with two lime wheels.

title: Harrison Ginsberg’s Sherry Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Deemed “the most crushable” in a recent blind tasting of Sherry Cobblers, Harrison Ginsberg’s raspberry-forward recipe opts for a medley of oloroso, PX and manzanilla sherries as the base of his mixture, which gets double strained for a cleaner presentation.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce oloroso sherry, preferably Callejuela “El Cerro” Oloroso
1/2 ounce Pedro Ximenez sherry, preferably El Maestro Sierra PX
1 ounce manzanilla sherry, preferably La Guita Manzanilla
instructions: 1. Muddle the berries in a cocktail shaker.
2. Combine all other ingredients in the cocktail shaker, then fill with ice and shake.
3. Double fine strain into cobbler or julep cup filled with crushed or pebble ice.
4. Top with more crushed or pebble ice to serve.

title: Winona Hawkins
intro_philosophy: “If a guest wants ‘an Old-Fashioned but not an Old-Fashioned’ I’ll make them something like this,” explains McCray of his “fruit-washed” Old-Fashioned, which calls on dehydrated cranberry- and orange-infused whiskey for a shelf-stable spin that cleverly nods to the “new-fashioned,” post-Prohibition take on the drink, which incorporated muddled fruit, marring the cocktail for decades.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated orange wheel and cranberries.

title: Ci Siamo’s Gin-Tonic
intro_philosophy: At New York’s Ci Siamo, the Gin-Tonic changes seasonally. The late-winter iteration is garnished with grapefruit, thyme and juniper berries, while past spring variations have featured cucumber and dill.
ingredients: 3 ounces tonic water, preferably Fever-Tree Mediterranean Tonic
instructions: 1. Add the gin and lemon juice to a highball glass and stir to incorporate.
2. Top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with a red grapefruit half moon, fresh thyme sprigs and juniper berries.

title: See Way Punch
intro_philosophy: In this low-proof punch, Caitlin Laman hews closely to the traditional five-ingredient punch formula, but trades the spirit for a mix of manzanilla sherry and red vermouth for a slightly spiced recipe that’s festively topped with a splash of Cava.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces manzanilla sherry, preferably La Guita
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass.
3. Add ice and top with Cava and garnish with lemon grass and a lemon wheel.

title: The Memory Remains
intro_philosophy:
From Alden & Harlow’s Seth Freidus, this cocktail was inspired by a late ’90s Metallica song of the same name. “This song has a strong start and an extremely aggressive end, as does the cocktail.”

“This is a band that had energy that I correlate with bar energy,” Freidus says. With it’s blend of strong flavors in rye, Suze, spicy sweet vermouth and smoked cocoa and coffee bean-infused Curaçao, this drink is a similar compilation.
ingredients: 1 bar spoon smoked cocoa and coffee bean-infused Curaçao (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in mixing glass and stir.
2. Strain over handcut ice into a chilled lowball and garnish.

title: Shady Lane
intro_philosophy:
“Blind date with a chancer, we had oysters and dry Lancers” begins the Pavement classic “Shady Lane.” As far as this warm-weather cooler is concerned, the song’s refrain says it all: “A Shady Lane, everybody wants one.”

Muddling the aromatic shiso leaves (found at Japanese markets), which taste something like a cross between mint and basil, lends a peppery element to this sweet-tart cocktail. The drink is also a tip of the hat to one of my favorite haunts,Momofuku Ssäm Bar, where David Chang keeps Pavement in heavy rotation, and where shiso pops up in both the food and the drink menus. In fact, Pavement bassist Mark Ibold is a bit of a gastronaut himself. In addition to playing with Sonic Youth and dabbling in freelance food styling, he also holds down a gig as bartender at the Great Jones Cafe in the East Village. Maybe if you see him and you ask very nicely, he’ll make you your own Shady Lane.

Reprinted with permission fromBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Photo by Ed Anderson © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Muddle the syrup, shiso leaves and blackberries in the bottom of a shaker.
2. Fill with ice, then add the gin, Lillet, lime juice and bitters.
3. Shake until well chilled, then strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with cracked ice and top with soda water.
4. Garnish with the shiso leaf and blackberries.

title: The Dead Rabbit Irish Coffee
intro_philosophy: Making a great hot drink, explains Dead Rabbit’s Jack McGarry, has a lot to do with temperature. In the case of the bar’s famous Irish Coffee, the correct temperature—right around 75 degrees—prevents the coffee from taking on a burnt, metallic taste. Another key component to this Irish-American classic is the glassware: a stemmed six-ounce, tulip-shaped glass showcases the drinks layers of dark coffee, whiskey and sugar beneath very soft, barely whipped heavy cream.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Irish whiskey, preferably Powers Gold Label
1/2 ounce  Demerara sugar syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to an Irish coffee glass.
2. Float an inch of whipped cream on top.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg

title: Erbin Garcia’s Mojito
intro_philosophy: Tied for second place in our recent Mojito tasting, Erbin Garcia’s recipe gets built in the glass and asks for muddled mint, two ounces of Plantation 3 Star, one ounce of lime juice, three-quarters of an ounce of simple syrup, a single dash of Angostura bitters and one-and-a-half ounces of soda water. An unorthodox addition, the bitters escaped the judges’ attention, as it was minimal and fully integrated into the overall drink.
ingredients: 2 ounces light rum, preferably Plantation 3 Star
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, combine all ingredients apart from the soda water and muddle gently.
2. Add the soda water and top with crushed ice.
3. Swizzle to incorporate all the ingredients.

title: Mauresque
intro_philosophy: The Mauresque is an old-fashioned preparation for pastis wherein the anise spirit is flavored with orgeat syrup and, like all pastis, lengthened with water. Some bars, like CopperBay in Paris and Marseille, have modernized the drink by dialing back the sweetness, but this is the most classic preparation, which can be adjusted to taste.
instructions: 1. Combine pastis and orgeat in a tall glass.
2. Add ice and top with water.

title: Rusty Ringo
intro_philosophy: Today, Drambuie is most likely to be spotted flankingScotchin cocktails, usually in drinks that wink at the structure of the Rusty Nail. Such is the case in Bar Goto’s Rusty Ringo, a modernized spin on the formula that dials back the Scotch and adds a calvados base, finished with a half ounce of Drambuie.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir for 60 rotations.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with gold leaf.

title: French Toast Flip
intro_philosophy: Whereas the original Sherry Flip takes its character from nutty, rich oloroso sherry (at least in our version), so, too, does Erick Castro’s breakfast-ready French Toast Flip, which is also fortified with Scotch, applejack brandy and maple and allspice syrups.
ingredients: 2 dashes whiskey barrel aged bitters, preferably Fee Bros.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients into shaker and shake vigorously without ice.
2. Fill shaker with ice and shake again until cold.
3. Strain into a sour glass and garnish.

title: Los Galgos Panky
intro_philosophy: Buenos Aires’ old-school bar traditions stay alive withcafés notables(historical cafés) like Los Galgos, which was recently revitalized and refurbished after it shuttered in 2015. Owner and bartender Julián Díaz reopened the 90-year-old bar to create a multi-generational aperitivo meeting point. There’s always vermouth and aperitivos rotating on tap, like Los Galgos Panky, a riff on theHanky Panky.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a Collins glass over ice
2. Garnish with orange slice.

title: Soft Shock
intro_philosophy: In our house Gin & Tonic recipe we cut down the proof by splitting the base between gin and fino sherry, and kick up the aromatics by way of a dose of both lime and mint.
ingredients: tonic water, to top (preferably Fever Tree)
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, muddle the mint leaves in the simple syrup.
2. Add the gin, sherry and lime and fill with ice.
3. Top with tonic water.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet and a lime wheel.

title: Bikini Martini
intro_philosophy: The onetime ubiquity of artificially flavored coconut rums like Malibu and Parrot Bay gave rise to a bevy of fruity drinks like theBikini Martini. But Peter Canny recognized something special in the pink, vodka-based cocktail when he was introduced to it decades ago as a club bartender. Now heading up the beverage program at Madeline’s Martini, Canny revisited the recipe for the cocktail bar’s debut menu, giving the Bikini Martini freshness and balance with fat-washed coconut rum, housemade grenadine and fresh pineapple juice.
ingredients: 1 ounce coconut oil–washed white rum (see Editor’s Note)
1 ounce  vodka, preferably Smirnoff or Ketel One
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake vigorously with ice.
2. Double-strain into a chilled Martini glass.

title: The Kerryman’s Irish Coffee
intro_philosophy: Tied for top honors in our recent blind tasting of Irish Coffees, this recipe from The Kerryman in Chicago is archetypal, calling on one and a half ounces of Irish whiskey, three ounces of hot coffee and half an ounce of demerara syrup. A dusting of fresh nutmeg on top of the finished drink sets it apart from similar recipes.
ingredients: 1 ounce whipped heavy cream (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Fill a 6-ounce Victorian Irish coffee glass or mug with hot water to heat it.
2. Discard the water and add all the ingredients except for the heavy cream.
3. Float the whipped heavy cream on top.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Amaro Shakerato
intro_philosophy: The Caffè Shakerato (Italy’s take on iced coffee) and theCampari Shakerato, a drink made famous at the historic Camparino bar in Milan, represent the primary shakerato styles you’ll encounter across Italy. And though amaro is traditionally served neat at room temperature, applying the shakerato method byreverse dry shaking certain stylescan amplify its aroma, flavor and texture. When experimenting with your own amaro shakerato, consider that alpine styles tend to work best with this technique.
instructions: 1. Combine your favorite amaro in a tin with ice and shake hard for 10 seconds.
2. Fine-strain the amaro into an empty tin and discard the ice.
3. Dry shake the amaro, without ice, for 10 seconds.
4. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass, and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Yellow Parrot
intro_philosophy: Featuring the odd trio of absinthe, yellow Chartreuse and apricot liqueur, the Yellow Parrot is not your average equal-parts cocktail. While the ingredients read incongruously on paper, they unify in the mixing glass to create something unexpected in both taste and texture. The key to achieving the best results with this recipe, which first appeared in London bartender Robert Vermeire’sCocktails: How to Mix Them(1922), is an extended stirring time of at least 1 minute. Dilution encourages latent flavors in the absinthe and Chartreuse to emerge, and causes an emulsifying louche effect that imbues the drink with a silky, almost velvety mouthfeel.
ingredients: 1 ounce apricot liqueur, preferably Giffard Abricot du Roussillon
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass. Add whole and cracked ice cubes, and stir for 1 minute.
2. Double-strain into a chilled Sazerac glass or five-sided Libbey rocks glass filled with 4 to 5 Kold-Draft (or similar) ice cubes.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Remember The Grain
intro_philosophy: A playful nod to the classic midcentury rye cocktail, Remember The Maine, this drink summons the cherry flavors of sweet vermouth to play against the cocoa hint of the bitters, while Belvedere Vodka’s Smogóry Forest, from the Single Estate Rye series, supplies a velvety texture. The dash of absinthe comes through on the clean, anise-y finish, making for a perfect after-dinner drink that’s light in texture but dessert-like in flavor.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a tumbler over ice.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Jordan Valls’ Rusty Nail
intro_philosophy: “This cocktail seems to be regarded as an ‘old man’s drink,’” explainsJordan Vallsof the Rusty Nail, “when in fact, it has so much more to offer.” In his take on the Scotch classic, Valls adds a tropical note by way of housemade papaya cordial and cocoa bitters. The rest of the build sticks to the typical components of the original—Scotch and Drambuie—combined in a more spirit-forward construction, which Valls designed to appeal to a broader audience.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Johnnie Walker Red Label
1/2 ounce higher-proof blended Scotch, preferably Cutty Sark Prohibition
1/2 ounce semiclarified papaya cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large cube.
3. Garnish with an orange coin.

title: The NoMad’s Montauk
intro_philosophy: Like theNegroni, the Montauk traditionally employs a formula of equal measures, in this case of gin, sweet vermouth and dry vermouth. In his rejiggering, bar director Leo Robitschek eliminates the dry vermouth altogether, replacing it with a blend of sweet vermouth, blanc vermouth and Punt e Mes to add structure, bitterness and balance.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
1 ounce navy strength gin, preferably Hayman's Royal Dock
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients together in a mixing glass over ice and stir together.
2. Strain into a double rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Forager’s Remedy
intro_philosophy: “I really enjoy layering warm and cool flavors in cocktails,” bar owner Jessica Sanders says of this bold Gin & Tonic riff. “One of my favorite foils is basil set against baking spices like cardamom or cinnamon.” In this case, basil—in the form of eau de vie as well as the aromatic garnish—plays up the spice notes found in The Botanist gin.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  The Botanist Islay Dry gin
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a 10-ounce highball or Collins glass.
2. Fill glass with cubed ice, and gently stir.
3. Garnish with basil, grapefruit peel, and toasted cardamom pods.

title: Zitalicus Al Pesto
intro_philosophy: Pasta with pesto is “one of the most-cooked dishes you make as a young guy living alone,” says Donvito. Here, he translates the key components of the Italian classic—tomatoes, basil, pine nuts—into aperitivo form.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
tomato soda, to top (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake first four ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over a long ice stick.
3. Top up with the tomato soda.
4. Garnish with a basil leaf.

title: Cilantro Infusion Spray
intro_philosophy: Cilantro pairs well gin and tequila-based cocktails, but it can be too delicate to act as a garnish. This infusion can be sprayed over a drink to add the herbal aroma without the finicky leaves.
instructions: 1. Steep cilantro in the vodka-water mixture for two hours (it should infuse relatively quickly), or until the desired aroma is achieved.
2. Strain and funnel into an atomizer bottle.

title: Joaquín Simó’s Sidecar
intro_philosophy: In this straightforward drink, every ingredient matters, saysJoaquín Simó. First things first: He steers toward selecting VS or VSOP Cognac rather than an older XO. “You don’t want a Cognac so fine that its only purpose is to be cradled in a snifter as you sit by the fireside and contemplate the mysteries of life,” Simó directs, since adding lemon juice “will obliterate the nuance.” Instead, he looks for a younger, bolder Cognac to stand up the layers of flavor in a Sidecar, such as Pierre Ferrand’s 1840, bottled at a slightly higher-than-average 90 proof. Beyond that, he adds a fourth ingredient to the traditionally three-ingredient template: a teaspoonful of rich demerara syrup, which lends sweetness, body and depth of flavor.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand Dry Curaçao
1 teaspoon rich demerara syrup (2:1, demerara sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Ancient Mariner
intro_philosophy: Following a typical tiki construction,Jeff “Beachbum” Berryrelies on a split rum base—part Jamaican rum, part demerara rum—and fresh citrus juices (lime and grapefruit) alongside a quarter of an ounce of allspice dram, which brings a richness and depth of flavor to this tiki rum sour.
ingredients: 1 ounce aged demerara rum,  preferably El Dorado 8-year or Hamilton Guyana 86-proof
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a double rocks glass filled with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig and a scored lime wedge.

title: The Dutch Nemesis
intro_philosophy: “The bready or cereal notes in genever can add a mysterious backbone to many gin cocktails,” says Alex Smith, who often combines the two spirits, riffing on the tiki tradition of using two rums in the same drink. But here he lets genevershine on its own, shaking it with savory, caraway-lacedkümmelfor an herbaceous drink that’s sweetened with pineapple gum syrup and lightened with sparkling wine.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the sparkling wine in a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake and strain into a large coupe.
3. Top with sparkling wine.

title: Blue Angel Highball
intro_philosophy: The Blue Angel (akaAngelo Azzurro) is a Roman-born cocktail with a notorious reputation. But that didn’t stopMasa Urushidofrom transforming this boozy blue club drink from the 1980s into an azure-colored, sessionable highball.
instructions: 1. Place an ice spear or a stack of ice cubes in a frozen highball glass or handled beer stein.
2. Add the gin, sherry, blue Curaçao, Combier and maraschino.
3. Top off with chilled tonic water and gently stir.
4. Garnish with a cherry, and serve.

title: Dry Pornstar Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Julian de Féral brought the Dry Daiquiri he learned while working at Match Bar Group to the West London members’ club Kindred. A cross between the Dry Daiquiri and another British modern classic, the Pornstar Martini, the Dry Pornstar Daiquiri is both sophisticated and playful.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce passion fruit syrup, preferably Monin
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice.
2. Shake vigorously to chill and dilute.
3. Strain into a frozen coupette glass.
4. Add a bar spoon of passion fruit caviar to a shot glass and top with Prosecco, then serve as a sidecar to the cocktail.

title: Mid-Morning Fizz
intro_philosophy:
The Mid-Morning Fizz is our take on the classic Ramos Gin Fizz and is our choice for the perfect summer eye-opener. Our variation loses the cream of the original recipe and adds greenChartreusefor a more pronounced spiciness. It is a lighter but more complex cocktail and loves to pair with traditional brunch grub like croque monsieur, burgers, steak and eggs, and especially French toast. Like all cocktails containing egg whites, the Mid-Morning Fizz requires a long, hard and steady shake.

Reprinted with permission fromSpeakeasyby Jason Kosmas and Dushan Zaric. Copyright (c) 2010 by Jason Kosmas and Dushan Zaric. Photo (c) 2010 John Kernick. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Pour the Chartreuse into the bottom of a Collins glass.
2. Fill with large cold ice cubes and add the soda. Place glass in the freezer.
3. Add gin, lemon juice, simple syrup, orange blossom water and egg white in a mixing glass.
4. Add ice and shake vigorously to make sure the cocktail has sufficient texture and frothiness.
5. Remove Collins glass from the freezer, and to achieve a layered effect, strain carefully over the chilled Chartreuse mixture.
6. Garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Kirk Estopinal’s Absinthe Suissesse
intro_philosophy: The Absinthe Suissesse went through many twists and turns before landing in New Orleans and morphing into the creamy drink it is today. Kirk Estopinaldispatches two versions, depending on the season. In hot weather, he prefers the version without orgeat, citing the refreshing, clean combination of herbaceous absinthe and mint. Winter calls for the grounding nuttiness of the orgeat, which also lends “a little bit more texture and a more creamy mouthfeel.” The recipe published here is his “winter” version.
ingredients: 1 ounce absinthe verte (140 proof or higher), such as Nouvelle Orleans
1/4 ounce white crème de menthe, preferably Marie Brizard, for float
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, dry-shake the absinthe, orgeat and egg white.
2. Add the cream and ice.
3. Shake to chill.
4. Double-strain into a coupe.
5. Float the crème de menthe on top and garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Roma Norte’s Rosita
intro_philosophy: At Roma Norte, a Mexico City–inspired bar in San Diego, the Rosita swaps the expected reposado tequila for a brighter blanco expression. In keeping with this lighter play on the modern classic, the citrus-forward Mommenpop Ruby Grapefruit aperitif subs in for sweet vermouth, rounded out by blanc vermouth and Campari with its trademark bitterness. Rather than serve it on the rocks, the bar opts for an elegant coupe, garnished with a grapefruit twist.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail coupe.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Push-Pop
intro_philosophy: In his Push-Pop cocktail, a frothy sour that calls for a full bar spoon of milk powder, Orlando Franklin McCray draws inspiration from the popular Japanese melon cream soda—carbonated melon juice that’s been served over a scoop of vanilla ice cream. “We paired [muskmelon] eau de vie with fresh melon juice that we adjusted with lactic acid,” explains McCray. “This gave the cocktail the acidic pop needed to balance the drink, but it also tastes slightly sweet and creamy.”
ingredients: 1 ounce muskmelon eau de vie, preferably Matchbook Distilling Sorted Fortune
4 ounces acid-adjusted honeydew juice (see editor's note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with a small handful of crushed or pebble ice.
2. Shake until the ice has fully melted.
3. Pour into a chilled rocks glass.

title: Shore Leave Spritz
intro_philosophy:
Matt Belanger likes to “shoehorn tiki into everything,” as he puts it, which is reflected in the perpetually tropical cocktail menu at Brooklyn’s Donna. Based on tiki baron Don the Beachcomber’s 1941 recipe for Navy Grog, this drink stays true to its maritime origins but lightens the usual three-ounce rum base in favor of a small dose of navy-strength gin and Cocchi Americano to create the sort of spicy, juicy cocktail you’d want to drink while on dry land.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail,with Recipesby Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine the Cocchi Americano, gin, lime juice, grapefruit juice, honey syrup, vanilla syrup, and allspice dram into a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake briefly.
3. Strain over crushed ice into a hurricane glass, top with the soda water, and add the garnish.

title: Day-O’ Fashioned
intro_philosophy: To develop the tropical theme and cocktails at Berwick’s Bird of Paradise, one of ourBest New Bars of 2025, owner Robin Berwick drew on her travel experiences from her youth, when her dad worked in Veterans Affairs. The drinks add fruit and funky flavors to the classics, like the Martini, or, in this case, the Old-Fashioned. This recipe is an ode to Civil Rights hero and artist Harry Belafonte, and it includes a split base of rye and whiskey, a measure of dark rum, some banana liqueur and a bit of cold brew concentrate from Double Trouble, a coffee-meets-cocktail shop where Berwick once worked.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce rye whiskey, such as Rittenhouse Rye Bottled-In-Bond
3/4 ounce dark rum, such as Worthy Park 109 Dark Jamaican Rum
1/4 ounce banana liqueur, such as Giffard Banane du Brasil
instructions: 1. In a rocks glass, muddle the orange peel with the bitters.
2. Add the rest of the ingredients and ice, and stir gently until well-chilled.
3. Garnish with an orange slice and a black cherry.

title: Sweet Mezcal Martini
intro_philosophy:
Author Robert Simonson developed this “proto” Martini for his bookMezcal & Tequila Cocktails.Closer to a Martinez, the Martini’s supposed predecessor, the two ounces of blanc vermouth temper the powerful profile of the mezcal.

Reprinted with permission fromMezcal & Tequila Cocktails: Mixed Drinks for the Golden Age of Agaveby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2021. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Combine the ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe and garnish with a cherry.

title: Jelani Johnson’s Vesper
intro_philosophy: “I saw the potential in making the Vesper better than that weird, esoteric James Bond drink, and turning it intoMartinifor a modern palate,” saysJelani Johnson. Small measures of gin and Cocchi Americano add nuanced sweet and bitter tones to the vodka base, which serves to elongate the botanical character of the supporting ingredients.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Martini or coupe glass.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Dear Prudence
intro_philosophy: Joaquín Simó refers to his Dear Prudence as a “roast chicken dinner drink”—meaning, he explains, that everyone is going to like it. The citrus-heavy punch combines vodka, lemon juice and grapefruit juice. “I just wanted something fruity and accessible,” says Simó. “Something eminently quaffable.”
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker.
2. Shake and fine strain into a collins glass.
3. Garnish with a raspberry and lemon wheel.

title: Alabazam
intro_philosophy: American expatriate Leo Engel was working at the Criterion Hotel in London when he supposedly created the Alabazam, an obscure recipe that appears in his 1878 bookAmerican and Other Drinks. The drink is basically a BrandySour, aromatized with several dashes of bitters to highlight the citrus tang of curaçao and the spice of its unusual Armagnac base. This cognac-based version was created by Jamie Boudreau ofCanonin Seattle for the modern palate that prefers a zing of bittered spice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Marvel at the spiciness.

title: My Dear Unfortunate Successor
intro_philosophy:
Having first appeared as part of the Moody Authors menu atPouring Ribbons, the star ingredient in this loose riff on theSazeracis chocolate milk-washed mezcal. “It’s not an overwhelming flavor,” Colarik notes. “It doesn’t take over.”

Addictive as the final result may be, Colarik explains one potential drawback, namely that milk-washing doesn’t remove lactose from the drink: “One of our regulars came in and took a Lactaid pill just to try [it].”
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
3/4 ounce chocolate milk-washed mezcal (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Rinse a teacup with lavender absinthe. Pour out the excess, and set aside.
2. Combine all remaining ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into prepared teacup.
4. Twist orange peel over the top of the drink to express oils, then discard.

title: Trader Vic’s Sour
intro_philosophy:
Trader Vic created a number of variations on the sour, which call on various base spirits and a variety of different types of citrus. Here, Jelani Johnson offers a template that works equally well with bourbon, Scotch, or brandy as the base.

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
3. Strain into a double rocks glass filled with ice.
4. Garnish with an orchid and a flag.

title: Praying Mantis
intro_philosophy: Herbaceous Branca Menta takes a starring role in this digestivo-ready play on theGrasshopper, while a dose of RumChata adds creamy ballast.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: San Sebastian
intro_philosophy: For his wine-based recipe, Dan Sabo combines a half bottle of young Rioja, plus bourbon, Spanish brandy, rich simple syrup and Ancho Reyes Verde for a fall-ready punch, built directly in the bottle.
ingredients: 3 1/2 ounces Spanish brandy, preferably Torres 10 Gran Reserva
instructions: 1. Pour out half the bottle of wine.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and re-cork the bottle.
3. Shake the bottle to incorporate.
4. Refrigerate before serving over ice.

title: Chip Tyndale’s Vieux Carré
intro_philosophy: Taking first place in our blindVieux Carré tastingwasChip Tyndale, of New York’s Dutch Kills and the newly opened Saint Tuesday. His recipe called for one ounce each of Michter’s Rye and Rémy Martin VSOP Cognac, with only three-quarters of an ounce of Carpano Antica sweet vermouth, a quarter-ounce of Bénédictine and three dashes each of Peychaud’s and Angostura bitters, garnished with a lemon twist. It was one of the few where the honeyed note of Bénédictine was detectable without overpowering. Joaquín Simó described it as “dancing the most” of any we tasted, while Talia Baiocchi, Punch editor-in-chief, praised its “long, complex finish,” noting that “it sticks with you in a good way.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Cognac, such as Rémy Martin VSOP
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Abigail Gullo’s Negroni Sbagliato
intro_philosophy: Tied for first in our blind Negroni Sbagliato tasting, Abigail Gullo’s rendition was found to be classical, with a dry finish and notes of vanilla and creamsicle, and the prosecco showing strong at first sip.
ingredients: 1 ounce L.N. Mattei Cap Corse Rouge Aperitif
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Nonalcoholic Sour
intro_philosophy: Replicating the bite and body of a cocktail can be difficult. At Barbuto, bar manager John Dillon turns to Scrappy’s Bitters Firewater tincture, a habanero chile tincture, to mimic the burn of alcohol in his zero-proof sour recipe. The inclusion of egg white gives the drink a fuller texture.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce brown sugar simple syrup (1:1, brown sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker and dry shake (without ice) for 30 seconds.
2. Add ice and shake for 10 seconds.
3. Double-strain into a coupe.

title: Cherry Biz
intro_philosophy:
This supercharging of five different cherry flavors is added to Wild Turkey Rare Breed and the house sweet vermouth to create the bar’s $21 Reserve-list Manhattan.

Try it in aManhattan,BoulevardierorNegroni.
ingredients: 1 part Rapa Giovanni Ratafia Cherry Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bottle, seal and store refrigerated for up to two weeks.

title: Tuscan Toucan
intro_philosophy: Nearly half of the drinks on the menu at the snug San Diego tiki den False Idol feature amaro, and the Tuscan Toucan is no exception. A full ounce and a half of bittersweet and savory Amaro Montenegro is blended with high-proof Jamaican rum, spicy cinnamon syrup and a trio of fresh citrus juices for a dynamic twist on the typical baking spices found in exotic cocktails. “It’s a thing you taste but can’t quite explain,” says beverage director Adam Schmidt. “It’s mysterious and lovely.”
ingredients: 1 ounce overproof unaged rum, preferably Rum-Bar
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend on medium until smooth.
2. Pour into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a pineapple frond, mint sprig and orchid.

title: Kung Fu Furi
intro_philosophy: Kung Fu Furi, a celery- and sesame-laced mezcal Margarita served at Sama Street, is based on one of head bartender David Muhs’ favorite bar snacks: the Kombu Celery from New York’s Bar Goto. He sought to replicate the simple dish—a mix of celery sticks, furikake, sesame oil and soy—in drink form. “The end result,” he says, “is a tequila and mezcal sour with two layers of celery [bitters and liqueur] and lots of umami.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce Apologue Celery Root Herbal Liqueur (if unavailable, increase the mezcal and tequila to 1 ounce each)
1 dash foamer, preferably Ms. Better’s Bitters Miraculous vegan foamer
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients together with ice in a tin, then double-strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
2. Garnish with a couple pieces of nori.

title: Pistachio Fizz
intro_philosophy: This Ramos-inspired gin fizz gets a double punch of nutty sweetness thanks to pistachio syrup and Faretti Biscotti liqueur, which—like its namesake cookie—has a luscious almond quality.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the soda water in a mixing tin without ice.
2. Shake for 30 seconds, then add ice to the mixing tin.
3. Shake well for five minutes.
4. Pour two ounces of soda water into a chilled Collins glass, then strain contents of mixing tin into the glass.
5. Top with more soda water, until the head rises about 1/2 to 3/4 inch above the rim of the glass.
6. Garnish with chopped pistachios.

title: But First, Coffee
intro_philosophy: “I wanted to make an Espresso Martini-style cocktail but I always like to make something a little different,” explains Charity Johnston, Beverage Director of Toca Madera West Hollywood. “I wanted this cocktail to taste as if you’d just had a cold brew coffee from your favorite shop,” and opted for the Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur. “It really is like drinking cold brew, and I love that it’s caffeinated.”
tags: Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin, and ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a mint sprig and serve with a straw.

title: Sacred Sunday
intro_philosophy: “I feel like some spritzes can be a bit too mild, and I often think of them as breakfast drinks, so I wanted something that would wake you up,” says Luke Danner of his summery spritz. For him, the French spritz embodies simplicity—the sorbet on top is a modest garnish, but still adds flavor and body to this crisp cocktail without becoming too sweet. Used in lieu of simple syrup, the St-Germain provides added complexity.
ingredients: 1 ounce Ketel One Botanicals Grapefruit & Rose
1/2 ounce almond honey, or single-origin honey
1 tablespoon ginger sorbet , or any bright, citrusy sorbet
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except soda water and sorbet, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water and a scoop of ginger sorbet.

title: Tordesilhas’ Caju Amigo
intro_philosophy: It’s only recently, amid growing interest in retro cocktails and theBrazilian classics, that theCaju Amigohas been widely reinterpreted in a more artisanal way, using fresh fruit and housemade juices and compotes. At Tordesilhas, for example, the Caju Amigo is made with high-quality white cachaça, as well as cashew juice, preserves and syrup, which are all made in the restaurant.
ingredients: scant 6 ounces (175 milliliters) prepared caju juice (see Editor’s Note)
2 1/2 ounces (75 milliliters) cachaça, such as Guaraciaba
instructions: 1. Prepare a tall glass by drizzling some of the caju caramel into it, smearing a little bit on the inside wall so it starts to run a little.
2. Add the caju juice and cachaça to a shaker with ice and shake.
3. Strain into the prepared glass, then garnish with a very thin slice of lemon and the caju compote.

title: Blue Calpico Chu-Hai
intro_philosophy: The traditional shochu highball, or “Chu-Hai,” is a clean no-faff favorite with izakaya-goers who want to ease their way into the night. Calpico here acts as a tart-n-creamy cheerleader, for both the gin’s botanicals and the whispered floral notes from orange blossom water. Working a touch of eye-catching blue curaçao into the equation, of course, is just fun.
ingredients: 1 ounce green tea shochu, preferably Gyokuo
instructions: 1. Add blue curacao to the bottom of a frosted 12-ounce mug.
2. Combine Calpico, shochu, gin and lemon in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Pour entire shaker into frosted mug.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Mist with orange blossom water. Garnish with orange twist.

title: Several Types of Orange
intro_philosophy: Orlando Franklin McCray “triples down” on the orange flavor profile of his refreshing and aromatic vodka highball by featuring three different ingredients with distinctive approaches to citrus, while enhancing the overall spice notes with a touch of pimento dram.
ingredients: Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the ginger ale in a mixing tin filled with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Spiced Orange Ginger Ale, and garnish with an orange ribbon.

title: Caitlin Laman’s Bamboo
intro_philosophy: In our recent blind Bamboo tasting Chicago bartenderCaitlin Lamantook third place with her bitters-less mix of 1 ounce El Maestro Sierra Fino, ½ ounce Valdespino Amontillado Tío Diego, 1 ounce Dolin dry vermouth and, unusually, ½ ounce Dolin sweet vermouth.
ingredients: 1 ounce fino sherry, preferably Maestro Sierra
1/2 ounce amontillado sherry, preferably Valdespino Tio Diego
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with pitted green Spanish olive.

title: Hummingbird
intro_philosophy: AtDeath & Co., Matthew Belanger deploys the stone fruit-notes of umeshu to complement the botanical character of Dorothy Parker gin in a Martini variant called the Hummingbird. “A well-made umeshu…can bring bright acidity and almost floral fruit notes to a cocktail,” explains Belanger.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce plum eau de vie, preferably Maison de la Mirabelle
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass and serve with a "sidecar" containing an extra pour of the cocktail.

title: Old Grampian
intro_philosophy: An unusual mix of two scotches—meaty blended Blank Note and the high-end Islay single-malt Lagavulin 12-year-old—this riff on theOld-Fashionedcan be found at the renewed iteration of San Francisco’s Tosca Café. Where many Old-Fashioneds require a healthy stir, this one is meant to tell a story as the ice melts. Rich, full-bodied and complex with a touch of honey for sweetness and two kinds of bitters, the Old Grampian is a cocktail that evolves in the glass.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended scotch, preferably Bank Note
instructions: 1. Add honey syrup, bitters and scotch to a rocks glass.
2. Squeeze the orange peel over the glass to release oils and rub the peel around the inside of the glass. Set aside.
3. Add a large piece of ice and stir briefly.
4. Garnish with the orange peel.

title: Campari Sour
intro_philosophy: Because, obviously.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker, and dry shake.
2. Add ice, and shake vigorously.
3. Strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Alicia Perry’s Whiskey Sour
intro_philosophy: Alicia Perry’s recipe tied for top honors in our2024 Whiskey Sour blind tasting. It was one of two recipes in the tasting that featured rye, both of which were favored by the judges. Perry splits the base between rye and bourbon, and opts for a lemon twist expressed over the top of the drink, which made it stand out as the most aromatically compelling of the bunch. Described as both “classy” and “thoughtful” by the judges, Perry’s highly considered spec led one taster to declare: “I want two of those.”
ingredients: 1 ounce bourbon, preferably Elijah Craig Small Batch
1 ounce rye, preferably Rittenhouse Straight Rye
3/4 ounce cane sugar simple syrup (1:1, water to cane sugar)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker tin and dry-shake without ice.
2. Once the tins start to loosen, open and add Kold-Draft-style ice.
3. Shake again, firmly, to chill, but do not overdilute.
4. Strain into a coupe.
5. Allow the cocktail to “set” for just a moment, then express a lemon twist over the cocktail, not too close to the surface of the drink, then discard.
6. Dash Angostura bitters over the top of the drink in a minimal design of your choosing.

title: Ol’ Pepper
intro_philosophy:
“When I am thinking savory for a cocktail, I think ‘chewy’ flavors, like a savory bite of food that lingers,” saysDear Irving‘s Meaghan Dorman, in response to the request for a cocktail that’s strong and savory.

To accomplish this, Dorman leans toward warmth and spice—the latter a go-to in the toolkit for this flavor profile, whether in infused syrups, spirits or as a garnish, as it amplifies the savory effect of any drink. In the Ol’ Pepper, the combination of chipotle honey and biting rye (Dorman prefers Rittenhouse) offers up a one-two punch of spice, while a dash of worcestershire provides a bonus hit of umami.
ingredients: 1 dash worcestershire sauce, preferably Lee and Perrins
instructions: 1. Shake with ice and strain into double Old-Fashioned glass over one rock.
2. Garnish with a lemon wheel and sprinkle of ancho chile.

title: Caña Rum Bar’s El Presidente
intro_philosophy: Erbin Garcia ups the measure of Curaçao and rum for a more spirituous take on the Cuban classic.
ingredients: 2 ounces golden rum, preferably Ron Barcelo Imperial
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with an orange peel.

title: Siesta
intro_philosophy: This modern classic from the Flatiron Lounge is a slightly bitter spin on theHemingway Daiquiri, with tequila standing in for rum, and Campari taking the place of maraschino liqueur.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: John deBary’s Blue Hawaii
intro_philosophy: “I feel like everyone has a memory of drinking too many of these during a regrettable stay at an all-inclusive resort in the Bahamas,” says John deBary of the blue Curaçao, coconut and pineapple concoction. His modern reworking calls on coconut liqueur in place of the traditional coconut cream for a slightly dryer take.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice for 15 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: The Fizz’s Doudou
intro_philosophy:
Yves Massoud is the bartending co-partner at Fizz, a neighborhood bar in the Mar Mikhael area of Beirut, where he serves his own take on the city’s homegrown Doudou shot, a briny mix of vodka, lemon juice and hot sauce served with an olive. “Doudou is part of the culture and part of Lebanese hospitality,” says Massoud.

The Fizz Doudou maintains the essence ofthe classic, but adds chipotle Tabasco, Worcestershire sauce and soy sauce to enhance the smoke and umami notes. The olives are local, sourced from another partner’s lands in the southern Lebanon village of Lebaa. (While Fizz makes its own hot sauce, bartenders don’t use it in the Doudou yet; it’s a matter of mechanics as the bottles’ stoppers make it difficult to dash the correct amount.)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shot glass and serve.

title: Babs in D.C.
intro_philosophy:
Named after a bartender’s cat, Chantal Tseng’s Babs in D.C. is a reinvention of a Barbara West—a vintage Sherry cocktail with a lax recipe. “The recipe never quite specified the type of gin or type of sherry,” says Tseng. “This allowed for quite a lot of variation in the re-creation of the recipe.”

Tseng decided on Green Hat’s aromatic Spring/Summer Gin, paired with sweet Moscatel sherry and raspberries.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce gin, preferably Green Hat Spring/Summer
1/4 ounce raspberry tea syrup (See Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to shaker with cracked ice, and shake well.
2. Double-strain into a chilled glass.
3. Garnish with lemon slice and frozen raspberry; a sprig of mint also works nicely.

title: Trinidad Sour
intro_philosophy: BartenderGiuseppe Gonzalezclaims to have created this unusual modern classic during the early days of his brief employment atClover Club, the Brooklyn cocktail bar that opened in 2008. The use of Angostura bitters as a base made the drink an immediate stand-out—as well as prohibitively expensive. Nonetheless, in the years to come, the Trinidad Sour girdled the globe, appearing on cocktail menus in multiple countries. Some bartenders, following traditional sour guidelines, opt to add an egg white to the mix.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Cradle to The Grave
intro_philosophy: Inspired by a trip to Jamaica and its abundance of allspice trees, Mary Palac created this rich stirred cocktail. “Everything had this spice to it,” she recalls of the cuisine, which forms the inspiration for this funky, complex drink built on Jamaican rum. (The name borrows a phrase from Appleton distiller Joy Spence, in reference to how Jamaicans drink rum throughout their life.) To the rum base she adds nutty oloroso sherry, herbal Cynar and a measure of allspice dram, all accented by a dusting of freshly grated nutmeg.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg.

title: Autumn in New York
intro_philosophy: Though she’s not from the Big Apple, Parker explains this is exactly what she wants her Manhattan to taste like—a stroll through the town in the fall—hence the clever name. She opts for Knob Creek®Rye because it is so sui generis to her; while many whiskeys get covered up by the other Manhattan components, the Knob Creek is so robust that it never gets lost. But it’s not a bully, as its dark fruit and burnt sugar notes pair perfectly with fig and molasses, making for a rich and incredibly warming version of the cocktail classic.
ingredients: 1 part  fig-infused sweet vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
2 dashes  Fee Brothers black walnut bitters
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Strain over a big cube in a double Old Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with a fig slice and a handful of walnut halves.

title: Parkeroo
intro_philosophy: TheParkeroois the only tequila-based cocktail featured inThe Stork Club Bar Book, published in 1946. Called a “bastard Martini” in the headnote preceding the recipe, the original drink called for two parts dry sherry to one part tequila, chilled and brightened with a lemon twist. Alejandro Medina of Bar Bludorn in Houston has shifted the drink in the direction of aMartinez, the early Martini that, to modern eyes, reads more like a gin Manhattan. Medina uses a sherry-based sweet vermouth and adds body and flavor with a touch of agave syrup, grapefruit bitters and a grapefruit twist for garnish.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sherry-based sweet vermouth, such as Lustau Rojo
1 1/4 ounces blanco tequila, such as Cascahuín Plata 48
1 dash grapefruit bitters, such as The Bitter Truth
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Stir until well-chilled, then strain over a large cube in an Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit peel, pierced with a clove.

title: Simplified Zombie
intro_philosophy:
Don the Beachcomber’s 10-ingredient Zombie is one of the most storied cocktails in the tiki canon. Like many of the Beachcomber’s recipes, its contents were a mystery until Jeff “Beachbum” Berry decoded its cryptic ingredients, but its potency was legendary from the start. Customers who visited any Beachcomber outpost were limited to two per sitting, a mandate that helped shape the lore of this drink. In 2007, Berry created this simplified rendition, of which he says, “While nowhere near as layered and complex as Don the Beachcomber’s ten-ingredient original, my bare-bones version does approximate its flavor profile, without sending you on a scavenger hunt for 151-proof Lemon Hart rum, falernum, a blender or crushed ice.”

Reprinted with permission fromEasy Tiki: A Modern Revival with 60 Recipes, by Chloe Frechette, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. Photographs copyright © 2020 by Lizzie Munro.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce overproof aged Puerto Rican rum , preferably Don Q
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled, about 10 seconds.
3. Pour into a tall glass, adding more ice to fill if necessary.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Champagne Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Swap whiskey for Champagne in theOld Fashionedtemplate, and you’ll get this pedigreed cocktail, which was first mentioned in Jerry Thomas’s 1862How to Mix Drinks. With its low alcohol content and bubbly constitution, this recipe makes a good candidate for day drinking. The question as to whether you pony up for the good stuff or choose a down-market sparkling wine depends largely on your opinion of the sacredness of Champagne.
instructions: 1. Add sugar cube or sugar to a flute.
2. Dash Angostura bitters over sugar to soak.
3. Slowly top up with Champagne.
4. Garnish with a long, curly peel of lemon.

title: Short & Stout
intro_philosophy: A Scotch-based riff on theOld-Fashioned, this recipe from Passing Fancies in Birmingham calls on an easy-to-make Guinness Caramel. The sweetener adds toasty, salty-sweet flavor to the drink, and can be used in other cocktails like aSazeracor anEspresso Martini.
ingredients: heavy 1 1/4 ounces Scotch, such as Johnnie Walker Black Label
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Watermelon Pastis
intro_philosophy: While Orlando Franklin McCray uses a centrifuge to clarify the watermelon juice to a transparent, pale-pink state, he recognizes that it’s a piece of equipment few have at home. The drink works with non-clarified juice too, he notes, and will appear “milky pink” once added to the pastis.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces pastis, such as Henri Bardouin
6 ounces clarified watermelon juice (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Serve the pastis in a rocks glass with 2 ice cubes alongside clarified watermelon juice in a separate highball glass.
2. Pour the watermelon juice into the pastis until it louches (changes to a cloudy or milky hue).

title: The Varnish’s Tuxedo No. 2
intro_philosophy: One expectsstandard-bearer craft cocktail bars like The Varnishto get the classics right. And, indeed, they nailed this one like nobody’s business, creating a cocktail that is as smooth as glass.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass, add ice and stir until chilled.
2. Rinse a chilled coupe or cocktail glass with absinthe and discard excess.
3. Strain remaining liquid ingredients into the glass.
4. Garnish with lemon twist and cherry, fixed together with a toothpick.

title: Between the Sheets
intro_philosophy: It’s not certain that this drink originated at Harry’s Bar in Paris, but considering Harry MacElhone’s penchant for creating facetiously-titled cocktails like the manhood-enhancing Monkey Gland and the Scofflaw, it does seem likely. The Between the Sheets is a rum-laced riff on theSidecar, another classic christened at Harry’s offering yet one more reason to suspect MacElhone as the drink’s creator. As for the name itself, it likely refers to the drink’s potency and the potential for a risqué end to an evening spent sharing one too many.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Venus Fly Trap
intro_philosophy: Inspired by a sponsored Tiki Monday with Miller, helmed by tiki iconoclastBrian Miller, which highlighted pisco, gin and rum brands, this drink calls on all three for a result that’sas unexpected as the carnivorous plant from which it takes its name. “I like to make spirit blends,” says Jelani Johnson by way of explanation. To a pisco base, Johnson adds Jamaican rum and gin, which are complemented by passionfruit, orgeat and lime and served over crushed ice. The result is, in his words, “fruity, complex, tropical.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce passionfruit concentrate, preferably The Perfect Puree of Napa Valley
1 teaspoon cinnamon bark syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and whip shake (with crushed or pebble ice) to chill.
2. Pour into a tall Pilsner glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a Fly Trap (lime and cherry, skewered) and an orchid.

title: Tom Collins
intro_philosophy:
If you take the American side of the story, the Tom Collins evolved from the “The Great Tom Collins Hoax” of 1874, in which pranksters would tell a friend they had run into one “Tom Collins” at a bar around the corner who had said some slanderous things about said friend. Said friend would then leave to find “Tom Collins” at the bar around the corner, sparking a goose chase of, perhaps, not-so-epic proportions.

Or you can choose the British side, which (more likely) suggests that the Tom Collins was the creation of London bartender John Collins, who dreamed up an eponymous gin punch in the latter half of the 19thcentury, that, when made with Old Tom Gin, presumably became the Tom Collins. The first published recipe appears in Jerry Thomas’s 1876The Bartender’s Guide.By either route (or perhaps a combination of the two), the Tom Collins is a spritzy drink made of lemon, sugar, soda water and gin—which combine to form, what is essentially, the original hard lemonade.
instructions: 1. Add gin, lemon juice and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Garnish with a brandied cherry and an orange wheel.

title: El Diablo Pepino
intro_philosophy: Bill Norris’s El Diablo Pepino is a very simple twist on the classic El Diablo cocktail, a tequila-based drink with cassis, lime juice and ginger beer.  It builds on the original template, but adds refreshing cucumber to highlight the bright notes on the blackcurrant liqueur and the classic agave character of Tapatio Blanco tequila.
ingredients: 3 seedless cucumber slices, sliced into 1/4-inch rounds
instructions: 1. Place two of the cucumber slices in a cocktail shaker with the lemon juice and muddle to break up them up.
2. Add the tequila, cassis and ice to the shaker and shake until cold and well combined.
3. Strain into an ice filled collins glass and top with ginger beer.
4. Garnish with the remaining cucumber slice.

title: Chrysanthemum #2
intro_philosophy:
An early twentieth-century session recipe, the Chrysanthemum cocktail appears, with small variations in proportions, in influential texts like Hugo R. Ensslin’sRecipes for Mixed Drinks(1916) and Harry Craddock’sSavoy Cocktail Book(1930). Canon owner Jamie Boudreau’s update downgrades the absinthe from dashes to a rinse and incorporates citrus. “The Chrysanthemum is an old recipe, but I always found it unbalanced,” he says. “Adding a touch of lemon, but still stirring, elevates a recipe that tends to be sweet and flat.”

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces dry vermouth, preferably Dolin dry
instructions: 1. Rinse a coupe with a small amount of absinthe and dump.
2. Combine the vermouth, Bénédictine, and lemon juice in a mixing glass, add ice, and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into the absinthe-rinsed coupe.

title: The Armada
intro_philosophy: This mezcal Negroni variation was created for a 2010 event celebrating the 150th anniversary of Campari. “I was starting to play with sherry,” Marrero recalls. “I wanted to use all Latin American ingredients,” she notes, except for the required Campari. The drink can also work with blanco tequila in lieu of mezcal.
ingredients: 1 ounce cream sherry, preferably Hidalgo Alameda sherry
3/4 ounce espadín mezcal, preferably Los Danzantes Espadín
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Twist the grapefruit peel over top of the drink to express essential oils, then use the peel to garnish the drink.

title: The Way of The G&T
intro_philosophy: This recipe is the result of much experimentation at the hands of science-minded bartenderDave Arnold. In search of the ideal bubbly, crystalline Gin & Tonic, Arnold landed on this recipe designed around maximum carbonation. To achieve it, a housemade tonic syrup is combined with gin and filtered water before beingforce-carbonatedfor an eminently refreshing take on the G&T. If you include lime juice in that batch, as Arnold does, the drink is best served the same day. For a more stable version, the juice may be added just prior to serving.
ingredients: heavy 1 3/4 ounces (53.5 milliliters) London dry gin, preferably Tanqueray
scant 1/2 ounce (12.5 milliliters) quinine simple syrup or cinchona syrup (see Editor’s Note)
3/8 ounce (11.25 milliliters) clarified lime juice (see Editor’s Note)
1 to 2 drops saline solution or a pinch of salt
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a liter-sized plastic bottle and chill between –10°C and –5°C (14°F to 23°F). (For a G&T solution that will keep indefinitely, leave the lime juice out in this step.)
2. Using a carbonation rig, carbonate at 42 psi.
3. If omitted from the first step, add the lime juice as the drink is poured into a chilled flute.

title: Two-Piece Martini
intro_philosophy: “There’s always been a strong creative duality between myself and [my twin brother] Miguel,” saysMilo Salehi. “We just work better when we’re bouncing ideas off of each other, so I wanted to express that partnership with two contrasting but complementary flavors and aromatics.” In this Tuxedo variation, Milo focuses on bold flavor pairings, like carrot eau de vie complementing coriander-forward gin, sarsaparilla aromatics and Key lime oil, which, in Milo’s words, “work beautifully together.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces coconut-washed gin, preferably Bombay Sapphire (see Editor's Note)
1 spritz sarsaparilla aromatic spray (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for the aromatic sprays, in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Top with one spritz each of the sarsaparilla aromatic and Key lime oil.
4. Garnish with a fresh carrot twist.

title: The Tijuana Rocket
intro_philosophy: “Good summer drinks are going to the garden,” explains Jane Danger, who pares down her typical tiki palette for this simple end-of-summer drink made with fresh ingredients. Bell and jalapeño peppers are muddled and shaken with tequila, lime juice and pomegranate molasses, for a piquant farewell to the warm-weather season.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker tin and muddle.
2. Shake and fine strain into a coupe glass.

title: Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: This blend of vodka, coffee liqueur and fresh espresso—first called the Vodka Espresso—is universally regarded as a modern classic cocktail. It is, in fact, the most influential and popular java drink to come along since the Irish Coffee. Dick Bradsell famously created the drink at the request of a supermodel who asked for something that would, “Wake her up, then fuck her up.” This version comes by way of New York’s Suffolk Arms, which has a section of its menu dedicated to influential vodka drinks.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Galliano Ristretto
instructions: 1. Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker and shake.
2. Strain into a coupe and garnish with three coffee beans.

title: Word to Your Cardamom
intro_philosophy: This tongue-in-cheek creation began with bartender Sylvanus Johnson’s homemade cardamom syrup, which he makes in the kitchen at New York City bar Mother’s Ruin. This toasty, sweet syrup blends with the smokey duo of mezcal and tequila, which are all rounded out by tart lime juice and the warm spice of Barolo Chinato.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Don Gorgon
ingredients: 1/2 ounce demerara syrup or cane syrup (1:1, sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except soda water in an ice-filled shaker.
2. Shake well and strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with a lemon wedge and a cinnamon stick.

title: Pastis Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Pastis, the anise liqueur that has a long history in French aperitif culture, hasn’t achieved mass popularity stateside—but some U.S. bars and restaurants are slowly changing that.Crevette, in New York City, offers both pastis service and pastis in cocktails, like this refreshing Gimlet served on pebble ice.
ingredients: 2 ounces pastis, such as Pernod Ricard
1/2 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass, then pack with pebble ice.
3. Garnish with lime wheel.

title: Pimm’s Cup #18
intro_philosophy: Almost a cross between a Pimm’s Cup and a mint julep, this overproof bourbon and nutty PX sherry combo pairs with mint and peach flavors for the winter 2017 rendition. The end result: “the most quenchable, drinkable Pimm’s we’ve had,” says bar director William Elliott.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with mint bouquet topped with pecan, nutmeg and confectioner’s sugar. Serve with a straw.

title: Mr. Ness’ Highland Swizzle
intro_philosophy: The eponymous Mr. Ness in this cocktail is bartender Jonathan Ness, who was concerned about all of the spent lime shells going to waste after juicing for service. Together with fellow bartender Anthony Schmidt they collaborated on developing a tiki-inspired cordial incorporating those lime shells as well leftover ginger peels and mint stems. Schmidt’s favorite way to showcase their sustainably-minded syrup is through this tequila swizzle riff. “The El Tesoro™ Blanco Tequila enhances the bright green flavors from our process-driven syrup—and vice versa, the cordial showcases the grace of a really well made agave distillate,” says Schmidt. “Like the cordial, the agave is plant-based in flavor with sweetness from the roasted nectar. They’re natural mates.”
ingredients: 1 part Jonathan Ness' Dumpster Demerara Syrup  (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the garnish in a stainless-steel julep cup.
2. Fill with pebble ice or cracked ice and using a swizzle stick or bar spoon, swizzle to combine the ingredients while adding a bit of aeration (like trying to start a fire).
3. Top with more ice.
4. Dash additional Peychaud's® bitters over the ice and garnish with a fresh mint sprig.
5. Serve with a reusable straw.

title: Orchard Caipirinha
intro_philosophy: On every cocktail menu, the Broken Shaker on Miami Beach includes a seasonalCaipirinha, always with a traditional Brazilian cachaça base and a few rotating elements in keeping with the spirit of a fruit-forward drink, blended together with a bit of sugar and a heap of fresh fruit garnish. This version is evocative of the autumn months (when Miami Beach still swelters at 80 degrees) with the addition of spiced apple syrup layered over lime juice for lift.
ingredients: 1 ounce spiced apple syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon wheel and a flower.

title: The Mere Wife
intro_philosophy: This toddy is named after Maria Dahvana Headley’s modern-day retelling ofBeowulf. Both of Chantal Tseng’s preferred aquavits are aged in sherry casks; combined with Madeira, a bracing alpine amaro, St. Elizabeth allspice dram and a hot chai base, the resulting toddy is complex and spice-driven, with notes of sweet, stewed fruit and bitter herbs. For extra kick and medicinal benefits, Tseng likes to add “a hefty dose of freshly cut ginger, skins and all, to my tea, especially during the winter months.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce aquavit, preferably Hovding or Linie
3/4 ounce Madeira, preferably Saveiro Vento do Oeste Madeira
2 dashes allspice dram, preferably St. Elizabeth
4 ounces hot chai tea such as Adagio's Masala Chai or Raja Oolong Chai
instructions: 1. In a mug or other toddy vessel, combine all ingredients.
2. Express orange oil into mug and add peel as garnish.

title: Bitter Mocha Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: “With this Old-Fashioned riff, I really wanted to put together flavors that brought out the natural toasted vanilla that I got from the [Elijah Craig] bourbon itself,” Castro explains. He homed in on bitter chocolate and roasted coffee, which he plays up with chocolate bitters and coffee amaro, respectively. The toothsome end result: “a vanilla mocha, except in the form of an amaro-accented Old-Fashioned
ingredients: 2 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
¼ ounce  Caffè Amaro (a coffee liqueur–amaro hybrid made by J. Rieger)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a large cube of ice.
3. Grate dehydrated orange zest over top to garnish.

title: Grapefruit, Fennel and Habanero Salt
intro_philosophy: A bittersweet combination of grapefruit and fennel gets a dose of habanero heat in this salt that can be used as a cocktail rim for Margaritas, Palomas and more.
ingredients: 2 packed tablespoons fennel fronds, finely chopped (from 1 fennel stem)
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients together in a small bowl.

title: Queen-Kina
intro_philosophy: While getting her start at Sauvage, Florencia Garcia De Onrubia was introduced to an array of aperitifs, with quinquina (aka “kina”) being a standout. For her, “’spritz French’ defines that afternoonapéromoment.” Using kina as a base brings out an herbal bitterness that’s more unexpected in a spritz. Floral St-Germain adds balance while playing with the quince elements. “Together with citrus, they give off a bitter grapefruit taste that is refreshing and drying,” she mentions, “[it] makes you salivate the way an aperitif should.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a large wine glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with pét-nat of your choice.
4. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

title: The Goldfish
intro_philosophy: A traditionalMartiniperked up with the addition of Goldwasser, the Goldfish was said to be the signature drink of the Aquarium, a Prohibition-era New York speakeasy.Originally mixed in equal parts, Rob Roy’s Anu Apte-Elford recalibrates the ratio, upping the gin and relaxing theGoldwasser for a drier rendition.
ingredients: 2 ounces London dry gin, preferably Beefeater
1 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Noilly Prat
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Joaquín Simó’s Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Placing in third in our recent blind tasting,Simó‘s recipe calls on two ounces of Russell’s Reserve 10 Year Old Bourbon, a quarter-ounce of rich demerara syrup and three types of bitters. The tasters thought the drink spicy and complex, with the sugar content and mouth-feel right on the money.
ingredients: 2 ounces Russell's Reserve 10 Year Old Bourbon
1/4 ounce rich demerara syrup (2:1, demerara syrup:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir briskly for 15 to 20 seconds.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a long swath of orange peel.

title: PDT’s House Ginger Beer
intro_philosophy:
PDT, a cocktail bar in New York City, makes this spicy ginger beer from scratch for theMezcal Mule, a riff on the 20th century classicMoscow Mule.

Reprinted with permission fromThe PDT Cocktail Book© 2011 by Jim Meehan, Sterling Epicure an imprint of Sterling Publishing Co., Inc.
instructions: 1. Boil water, then turn off heat.
2. Add minced ginger and cover. Allow to infuse for one hour.
3. Strain mixture through a chinois. Press down on the ginger with the back of a spoon to force as much liquid through the chinois as possible.
4. Once the ginger beer has been strained, add citrus and sugar and stir.
5. Bottle and store in the refrigerator.

title: Cafe du Horchata
intro_philosophy:
Abigail Gullo’s buzz-y riff on horchata mixes homemade horchata with cinnamon, rum, Cathead Pecan Vodka and the bar’s cold-brew coffee.

Pro-tip: As Gullo recommends, it can be mixed with herCajun Coquitofor fall-ready “spice delight.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Add ice and blend until smooth.

title: The Prince of Wales
intro_philosophy: As the British crown prince for nearly six decades, Albert Edward, the eldest son of Queen Victoria, spent much of his life traveling the world as an official representative of the crown, from the United States and Canada to the Mediterranean and Middle East. Less officially, Bertie, as he was known by most, also snogged his way across several continents, amassing dozens of mistresses and shaping culture and fashion for the leisure class in Europe. He is also the probable inventor of, and certainly the inspiration behind, the Prince of Wales cocktail.
