The drink originally consisted of rye, pineapple, maraschino liqueur and bitters, plus sugar and Champagne doubling as both an Improved Whiskey Cocktail and a royale.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Champagne, in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and rigorously shake until chilled and the pineapple chunk has been crushed into pulp.
3. Strain into a cocktail glass and top with Champagne.
4. Garnish with an expressed lemon twist.

title: Embassie
intro_philosophy: Scottish bartender, Mal Spence of theKelvingrove Café, created this play on the White Lady, a smoothed out Gin Sour made famous by Harry Craddock at the Savoy in London. Its creator, Harry MacElhone of Harry’s New York Bar in Paris, noted several different versions throughout the 1920s (including one with unsavory proportions of crème de menthe), but settled on a pared-down mix of gin, Cointreau and lemon juice with an optional egg white. Spence’s variation does away with Cointreau in favor of equal parts Cocchi Americano and yellowChartreuse.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Tom Macy’s Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Tom Macy, who took the top spot at our tastings in2018and2024, builds his Old-Fashioned on two ounces of Wild Turkey 101 rye, a teaspoon of 2:1 Demerara syrup and three dashes of his personalized bitters blend known as Dad’s Bitters—a mix of Angostura, Bitter Truth orange and Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas’ Own Decanter bitters—stirred and strained, then garnished with both lemon and orange twists.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with orange and lemon peels.

title: Coconut Water Highball
intro_philosophy:
When asked to describe his “desert island” drink, Giuseppe González gave a lengthy response, diving into the practical merits of coconuts, overproof spirits and more.

Says González, “[Coconut trees] are‘The Tree of Life,’ and that is exactly what they do. Keep your dumbass who is stuck on an island alive.”Simultaneously a source of sterile water (“you can hydrate intravenously using coconut water,” he explains), they can act assunscreen (“rub some [coconut oil] on your skin”), fuel (“coconut fibers dry out and can be lit . . . if you have some flammable booze, life just got easier”), fishing spears (“the center spine of the coconut tree leaf is very stiff and easy to shape”) and even weaponry (“Coconuts can be used like baseballs. Baseballs are weapons.”) Add to that some overproof rum—which can be used as everything from a food preservative to a disinfectant—and you arrive at his Coconut Water Highball, or as we like to think of it, survival in a cup.
instructions: 1. Build over ice in a highball.

title: Duppy Conqueror
intro_philosophy:
To explore the overlap between the worlds of drinks and music, we challenged bartenders to translate a song of their choice from a given genre into cocktail form. Here, Brian Millertakes on reggae.

Of the inspiration behind this drink, Miller explains: “My happy place is on a beach in the Caribbean at sunset listening to reggae. And this is [named for] one of my favorite Bob Marley tunes—a sipper with loads of Jamaican rum to set my mind adrift.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton 12 year
1 ounce Jamaican pot still rum, preferably Hamilton Gold
1 dash Dale DeGroff's pimento aromatic bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Scotch & Soda
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn’sLong Island Bar,Toby Cecchinihas kept his dead-simple Scotch & Soda, which was inspired following a trip to Japan, on the menu for the past year. “I wanted something that… had a slight twist to it, and a subtle nod to Japan as the inspiration,” he says of the drink, which is garnished twice, with an aromatic twist of grapefruit peel and a shiso leaf. As a base, Cecchini experimented with a number of lighter-style whiskies from both Japan and Speyside, but settled on the fruity and “featherlight” Compass Box’s Great King Street Artist’s Blend, which he describes as “perfection” in the two-ingredient formula.
ingredients: 2 ounces whiskey, preferably Compass Box Great King Street
instructions: 1. Fill a highball glass halfway with ice to ensure enough space for the water.
2. Add the whiskey.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with one shiso leaf and a twist of fresh grapefruit peel.

title: Golden Slumbers
intro_philosophy: At The Danforth (the latest project from the hospitality team behind Death & Co.), the food and drinks are inspired by New England Americana. The Golden Slumbers feels right at home on the East Coast, stirring together classic flavors such as apple and pear with bright verjus blanc and bitter Luxardo Bitter Bianco, resulting in a cocktail that tastes nostalgic, yet modern.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce pear brandy, preferably Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over a large rock.
3. Garnish with a Granny Smith apple fan.

title: Through the Light
intro_philosophy: Valentino Longo challenged himself to see if he could combine two of his favorite classic cocktails—the 50/50 Martini and the Gin and Tonic—into one original drink. The result is the Through the Light, which Longo builds on a floral, Martini-like base of equal parts gin and vermouth, layering on a house-made tonic syrup and a crystal-clear sour blend in place of lemon, allowing the drink to be stirred. Soda water lends fizz, while the juniper-accented olives recall a classic Martini garnish. “It’s very elegant, very light and delicate, but still refreshing,” says Longo.
ingredients: 1 part  Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Ambrato vermouth
1/4 parts  chamomile sour blend (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass except for the soda water and olives.
2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass with a big ice block.
3. Add soda water.
4. Garnish with botanical-infused olives.

title: The Mutineer
intro_philosophy: While head bartender David Roth has experimented with both coffee Ango and vanilla Ango for cocktail competitions, the coffee-spiked bitters offer a “fresh and vibrant” aroma that particularly appeals in this nuanced rum Old-Fashioned variation.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces rum, preferably Santa Teresa 1796 Solera
3 dashes coffee-infused Angostura bitters (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Express the lemon peel and use as garnish.

title: Take the Long Way Home
intro_philosophy: This rum drink was created for a “Yacht Rock Sundays” blog event. A small amount of maraschino liqueur helps accent the caramel of the rum and the nuttiness of theMadeira. Yarm recommends a dry Madeira style for this drink, such as verdelho or sercial (as used here), a particularly dry style.
ingredients: 1 ounce aged rum, preferably Angostura 5 year
3/4 ounce sercial Madeira, preferably Blandy's 5 year
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with mint leaf, floated on top.

title: Le Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: Beni imo, or Okinawan sweet potatoes, and pandan leaves put an earthy spin on this Daiquiri from The Pig and the Lady, a Vietnamese restaurant in Honolulu whose cocktails are infused with locally sourced spirits and flavors. For Punch copy editor Catherine Sweet, the Le Daiquiri “was a tart, fuchsia revelation.”
ingredients: 2 ounces unaged rum, preferably Kō Hana Kea
3/4 ounce pandan sweet potato syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Double-strain into a coupe glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Ode to Tomatoes
intro_philosophy: At Washington, D.C.’s Little Coco’s, the Ode to Tomatoes is inspired by the “smell of a summer garden.” A housemade tomato water and tomato brine from pickled tomatoes lends umami, earthy flavor to this dirty Martini–like drink. For a more “purely tomato” flavor, general manager Anna Wonson says that the water and brine can be prepared without fresh herbs.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces vodka, preferably Republic Restoratives Civic Vodka
1/4 ounce tomato brine from pickled tomatoes (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir to combine.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a pickled tomato.

title: MARTINI & ROSSI® French Spritz
intro_philosophy: Make a couple of tweaks to “aperitivo,” and you get its French cousin, “aperitif”; likewise, you can swap a few ingredients in the Italian Spritz blueprint and make its continental kin. To MARTINI & ROSSI Bitter Liqueur and Prosecco, add a dose of GREY GOOSE® vodka and a splash of soda water. Andvoilà: the French Spritz. The higher proof is balanced by Prosecco’s dry sparkle and, garnished with aromatic raspberries, is an elegant way to go from afternoon to evening.
ingredients: 2 ounce  MARTINI & ROSSI Prosecco or Rosé Italian Sparkling Wine
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a wine glass with ice.
2. Stir gently to integrate.
3. Garnish with raspberries.

title: Billionaire Cocktail
intro_philosophy: This Employees Only take on the Prohibition classicMillionairewas named the Billionaire “because of inflation and the fact that ours is a ‘richer’ cocktail,” the authors quip. While their version uses house-made grenadine, Kala Brooks of Top of the Monk in Asheville, North Carolina, puts her own spin on the drink by swapping in bittersweet Campari for grenadine: “The amaro, fresh lemon and overproof whiskey, dance nicely with the absinthe bitters,” she notes. “It doesn’t even taste like Campari anymore, it’s so weird!”
ingredients: 2 ounces overproof bourbon, preferably Baker’s 107 Proof
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with lemon wheel.

title: Toma-tini
intro_philosophy: The key to Leyenda’s take on the “dirty tequila Martini” is finding the right balance of brine and vermouth. At the Brooklyn agave-centric bar, the brine comes from house-pickled tomatillo in place of the more traditional olive. “We wanted it to be a bit more Latin driven,” says Leanne Favre, head bartender, and she doesn’t hold back: “I started with less, and I realized it wanted to be dirtier. We’re always desiring more tomatillo.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces tequila, preferably El Velo blanco
1/4 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Gonzalez Byass Vermut Seco
1/2 ounce pickled tomatillo brine (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with pickled tomatillo.

title: Royal Afternoon
intro_philosophy:
Sother Teague describeshisAperol Spritzvariationas “a sunny spritz filled with bright citrus notes and a hint of sweetness, perfectfor sipping on the porch on a summer day.”

Showcasing the Italianbitterliqueur alongside orange citrate and sparklingrosé, this is a take on the iconic drink thatis light,compared to the strong-and-stirred template for whichAmor y Amargois typically known,but still complex.
instructions: 1. Pour first three ingredients into a Collins glass and fill with ice.
2. Top with rosé.
3. Express the oils from a long orange twist over the drink and place decoratively into the glass.

title: Diamond Fizz Spritz
intro_philosophy:
The Diamond Fizz was born around the turn of this century, when the fizz was hitting the big time in American bars. A deceptively strong and highly drinkable mixture, it replaces the Gin Fizz’s soda water with Champagne, transforming it into a royale of sorts. Isaac Shumway’s spritz-ified version replaces the gin with Aperol and dry vermouth, the sugar with honey syrup and amaro, and the lemon juice with orange juice. The result is a fluffy orange cloud of a cocktail that tastes something like a bitter Orange Julius.

Reprinted with permission fromSpritz: Italy’s Most Iconic Aperitivo Cocktail, with Recipes by Talia Baiocchi and Leslie Pariseau, copyright© 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Add the Aperol, lemon juice, vermouth, syrup, Gran Classico, orange juice, and egg white to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake without ice, and then add ice and shake very hard for 20 seconds.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over a very small amount of ice.
4. Slowly top with the sparkling wine and add the garnish.

title: Sharon
intro_philosophy:
Tristan Willey’s low-proof variation on theNegronireplaces the gin withmanzanilla sherryand dials back the Campari for a salty, lightly bitter take on the Italian classic that does not want for complexity. “Dry sherry has such a strong backbone,” says Willey. “It lends so much to a drink while asking so little of the drinker.”

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express the orange twist over the glass and discard.

title: Pink Lady
intro_philosophy: Essentially aGin Sourcolored with grenadine and fortified with applejack, the Pink Lady is thought to have originated during Prohibition, when grenadine was most likely included as a masking device for poor gin. Tart, fairly dry and seriously strong, it’s nearly identical to theClover Club, save for the addition of applejack.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
4. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
5. Garnish with a brandied cherry.

title: Pickletini
intro_philosophy: Co-owner Stephanie Fesko can’t say exactly when theRustic Caféstartedpouring Pickletinis. She certainly didn’t set out to brand the bar into the “pickle place”—it just kind of happened. All these years later, Rustic sells its proprietary pickle juice by the bottle, and the bartenders “don’t have the specific recipe written down,” Fesko says, offering her best approximation. To make it spicy, just add Tabasco to your brine and soak your pickle in it for a bit before assembling.
ingredients: 4 1/2 ounces vodka, preferably Tito’s or Ketel One
a “blip” (more than 2 drops, less than a splash) of dry vermouth
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients with ice in a shaker and shake.
2. Strain into a chilled Martini glass.
3. Garnish with a pickle spear.

title: Colaroso
intro_philosophy: The inspiration for this drink is the pebble, or cobbled, ice used in soft drinks at the drive-in chain Sonic. “I really love cobbled ice with my cola,” Emilio Salehi says. “It makes the drink super cold.” Mixed with amaro and oloroso sherry, this low-alcohol drink yields “equal parts nostalgia and sophistication!”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a tall glass, and stir to combine.
2. Fill glass with cobbled (pebble) ice. Stir again.
3. Garnish with orange twist.

title: Sammy Davis Jr. Sour
intro_philosophy: Co-created by bartenders Pam Wiznitzer and Jonathan Pogash, this drink flips the traditional New York Sour. Instead of a float of red wine on top of the drink, here, sweet, viscous Manischewitz Concord grape wine sinks to the bottom.
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe glass.
4. Drop in the Manischewitz; it should sink to the bottom of the glass.
5. Garnish with Luxardo maraschino cherry on a skewer.

title: Breakfast Martini
intro_philosophy:
One of the earliest—and still the most famous—examples of jam as an ingredient in a cocktail revival era. Bartender Salvatore Calabrese created the drink at the Lanesborough, a posh hotel in Mayfair. “I’m a very typical Italian person,” he said. “The first thing in the morning, all I can do is an espresso. I’m like a zombie.” He said his wife made him eat marmalade. The bitter, tangy flavor intrigued him, leading him to create the cocktail. Some have noticed a similarity between this cocktail and the Marmalade Cocktail found in the 1930Savoy Cocktail Book. Calabrese says he was not aware of the Savoy recipe when he created this drink.

Reprinted with permission fromAProper Drinkby Robert Simonson, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Stir the marmalade with the lemon juice at the bottom of a cocktail shaker until it dissolves.
2. Add the gin and Curaçao. Shake with ice. Fine strain into a chilled cocktail coupe.
3. Shred some orange peel on the top of the drink as a garnish.

title: Hollow Kingdom Zombie
intro_philosophy: Taking third place in our Zombie blind tasting, this recipe is bold and spice-forward, with a thoughtful, theatrical and aromatic garnish: An inverted lime shell is filled with overproof Demerara rum, topped with a few drops of absinthe and Angostura bitters, and then ignited, dusted with nutmeg and poured over the drink. Chantal Tseng was the only bartender in the tasting to opt for a measure of rhum agricole—a half-ounce, which she paired with overproof Jamaican and Demerara rums. Though the absinthe—a full quarter-ounce, compared to the drops and dashes of most other recipes—tilted the drink away from the archetype, it still stuck in the judges’ minds after tasting (and re-tasting) the lineup.
ingredients: 1 ounce overproof Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
3/4 ounce falernum, preferably Maggie’s Farm Falernum Liqueur
1/2 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Neisson Blanc
1/2 ounce overproof Demerara rum, preferably Hamilton 151-proof
1/4 ounce absinthe, preferably La Muse Verte, Pernod or Kübler
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with cracked ice for a quick and hard 5 seconds.
2. Double-strain into a chilled large Collins glass, ceramic mug or Hurricane glass.
3. Fill with crushed ice and stir quickly with a long metal spoon, then insert a straw.
4. Re-top with crushed ice.
5. To garnish, tuck a bunch of fresh mint leaves into the edge of the glass, then fan them out. Spear an optional Luxardo or marasca cherry into the mint.
6. Place an inverted lime shell on top and fill with about 1/2 ounce Hamilton 151-proof Demerara rum, a few drops of absinthe and an extra dash of Angostura bitters.
7. Light the shell on fire and grate nutmeg over the top.
8. After blowing out the fire, dump the contents of the lime over the drink and sip from the straw.

title: Chauncey
intro_philosophy: A supercharged formula dating back to the halcyon days of New York’s Waldorf Astoria hotel, the Chauncey stands out due to its unusual triple base: gin, whiskey and Cognac in equal measure, along with vermouth and orange bitters.Waldorf Astoria Bar Bookauthor Frank Caiafa encourages experimentation and personalization when approaching this recipe. Though he opts for a bold gin in the 96-proof Bowling and Burch, matched with the gentler H by Hine Cognac and Ragtime Rye, you can just as easily emphasize a big-flavor brandy or whiskey.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Cognac, preferably H by Hine
3/4 ounce rye, preferably Ragtime Rye cask strength
3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Martini & Rossi
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lemon or orange twist.

title: El Chapulín
intro_philosophy: While mostGrasshoppersshowcase brandy, this stirred, boozy variation showcases tequila instead, specifically Tequila Ocho. “It has a bit of menthol on the nose, and we thought, ‘Hey, who would ever think of tequila for a Grasshopper?’” explains Jonathon Bush. The drink’s name is Spanish for a variety of grasshopper that is commonly eaten in certain areas of Mexico.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Float the absinthe over the top of the drink.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig.

title: Run the Julius
intro_philosophy: Run the Julius is what we’ve all been waiting for: a Campari Ramos. To the expected cream and Campari base,Annie Williams Pierceadds a hint of tropical fruit by way of banana liqueur while a small measure of Montenegro adds a subtle herbaceous quality as acid-adjusted orange juice lends a welcome citrus tang.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard  Banane du Brésil
3/4 ounce acid-adjusted orange juice (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except cream and Topo Chico to a cocktail tin and shake vigorously to integrate.
2. Add the cream and two ice cubes to the cocktail tin and shake until the ice has completely incorporated.
3. Double strain into a short, 8-ounce juice glass and let sit for 30 seconds.
4. Slowly pour the Topo Chico or other sparkling water into the glass to create that perfect frothy pillow.

title: Clarified Pineapple Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: This take on the tropical staple from Sunken Harbor Club’s Kern Rodriguez puts a silky spin on the typically shaken drink thanks to the milk punch treatment, which comes courtesy of a blend of whole-milk yogurt and kefir yogurt. Acid-adjusted pineapple juice, meanwhile, makes the whole drink pop.
ingredients: 4 quarts yogurt blend (1:1, whole-milk yogurt to plain kefir yogurt)
12 3/4 ounces Jamaican rum, such as Denizen Merchant’s Reserve 8-year
6 3/8 ounces acid-adjusted pineapple juice (see Editor’s Note)
4 1/4 ounces unaged rum, such as Uruapan
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients to a container and stir to combine. Let sit for 8 hours in a cool, dry area.
2. Rinse 2 coffee filters with water to remove the paper taste, then filter the mixture through the coffee filters to remove solids.
3. Serve in a chilled Nick & Nora glass.

title: Hemingway Spritz
intro_philosophy: This isn’t a Hemingway Daiquiri; it’s a spritz inspired by the time American writer Hemingway spent living in Cuba. A housemade “coconut soda” crafted from carbonated coconut water adds tropical appeal.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
1/2 ounce  butterfly pea flower syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Shake first four ingredients with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over a Collins ice stick.
3. Top with coconut soda.
4. Garnish with the lemon leaf.

title: Summer of George
intro_philosophy: “I tend to get a lot of pear notes off tequila,” says Jeremy Oertel, bar manager of Donna in Brooklyn, who pairs St. George Spiced Pear Liqueur with two tequilas, lime and orgeat in this Mai Tai variation.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce spiced pear liqueur, St. George
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into cocktail glass over crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a slice of pear.

title: Carmelite Water
intro_philosophy:
Carmelite Water, an herbal infusion featuring aromatic lemon balm, was created in the 14th century by Carmelite nuns for King Charles V of France. At Harlem’s Sugar Monk, proprietor Ektoras Binikos spritzes the fragrant elixir in cocktail glasses, creating an effect similar toan absinthe rinse. Compared to the anise flavor of absinthe, however, Carmelite Water offers a citrus-forward option that’s particularly harmonious with white spirits, such as gin or unaged agave spirits. Binikos suggests trying it in a classic Paloma.

In addition, “our bartenders love to set it on fire on top of a drink,” Binikos says, as it “creates a beautiful blue blaze and a cloud of wonderful caramelized herbal flavors, right on top of the cocktail.” At the beginning of the pandemic, Sugar Monk began making its own Carmelite Water, which isavailable for purchase. For those who have access to plenty of lemon balm, he offers this DIY recipe.
ingredients: 1/2 cup dried fliskuni (Greek water mint) or Egyptian mint
1/4 cup dried organic angelica root,crushed with a spice grinder
1 tablespoon dried organic coriander seed,crushed with a spice grinder
1 tablespoon fresh Meyer lemon zest (from about 1 small organic Meyer lemon)
1 tablespoon fresh Seville orange zest (from about 1 orange)
1 teaspoon Cassia bark (crushed on a spice grinder,crushed with a spice grinder
1 bottle (750 ml) high proof vodka (151 proof)
instructions: 1. In a glass quart jar with a lid, stir together all the herbs and spices with the vodka. Cover with lid, and steep for 36 hours.
2. Strain through several layers of cheesecloth or a coffee filter. (Binikos recommends composting the spent herbs).
3. Place the infused spirit in an airtight container and keep it in a cool place for 3 days.
4. To use, decant into glass spray bottles. The infused spirit keeps for up to one year.

title: Manila Hotel Mint Julep
intro_philosophy: A circa-1926 specialty of The Manila Hotel, a turn-of-the-century Philippine landmark still in operation today, this iconoclastic Mint Julep capitalizes on the distinctive pleasures of bonded bourbon and Guyanese and Caribbean rums. It’s Philadelphia bartender Resa Mueller’s modern-day tribute to a drink Charles H. Baker raves about in his influential 1946 travel book,The Gentleman’s Companion.
ingredients: 1 ounce bonded whiskey, preferably Old Grand-Dad 100 Proof
1/2 ounce aged rum, preferably El Dorado 5 Year
1/2 onunce pineapple rum, preferably Plantation Stiggins’ Fancy Pineapple
instructions: 1. Combine 6 mint leaves and the demerara syrup in the bottom of a rocks glass, then muddle lightly to release the fragrant oils in the mint.
2. Fill glass with finely crushed ice.
3. Pour the bourbon and both rums over the ice.
4. Garnish with mint, pineapple and cherries. Serve with a straw.

title: Dear Elijah
intro_philosophy: After the bourbon, ice is the most critical component in Cross’ interpretation of the Old-Fashioned. It’s where she stashes certain flavors she hopes to unlock as the drink warms—namely, toasted coconut, a key basenote in Elijah Craig. She prepares a flavored mixture that is frozen into the glass on the bias (in other words, a diagonal slab, slanted from the bottom of one corner to the top of another). As the ice melts, the cocktail becomes infused with its flavor.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass and stir.
2. Pour into a double Old-Fashioned glass prepared with a frozen ice mixture (see Editor’s Note).
3. Express an orange peel over the drink and discard.
4. Garnish with white and purple orchids.

title: Eternity
intro_philosophy: Featuring flavors inspired by ancient Rome, this drink is thrown, meaning it’s mixed by pouring the liquid from one tin to another, rather than shaking or stirring. An “acqua di posca” references flavors of the empire and those found in ITALICUS bergamot liqueur.
tags: The Art of ITALICUS Aperitivo Challenge
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  ITALICUS Rosolio di Bergamotto liqueur
1 1/2 ounces  acqua di posca (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce  succo di bergamotto (bergamot juice, can be purchased online)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin with ice.
2. Using a strainer, throw the liquid from one tin to the other, from a higher distance.
3. Pour from a higher distance into a chalice glass (with no ice).
4. Spray elderflower water 2 to 3 times around the glass.
5. Serve on a marble coaster with focaccia, cheese and grapes.

title: The Kapre
intro_philosophy: “This drink started as a riff on a caipirinha with muddled limes and cachaca,” says bar manager Matt Grippo of Blackbird in San Francisco. “It’s obviously a tropical drink, and there’s nothing more tropical than a good banana,” which Grippo achieves via the addition of Giffard’s culty Banane du Brèsil liqueur.
instructions: 1. Add a dash of mezcal to a chilled coupe glass. Swirl and discard.
2. In a cocktail shaker, muddle lime wedges with gum syrup.
3. Add remaining ingredients and then add ice.
4. Shake until chilled.
5. Strain into the mezcal-rinsed coupe glass.
6. Garnish with a kumquat.

title: Rio Grande Sour
intro_philosophy: Brazil and Germany always make for exciting matchups. Going off the traditional sour build, the Rio Grande Sour plays funky, aged cachaça against herbaceous, bittersweet Jägermeister.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce aged cachaça, preferably Novo Fogo Barrel-Aged
instructions: 1. Combine all Ingredients in a tin.
2. Dry shake and then shake again with ice.
3. Double strain into a coupe.
4. Garnish with fresh orange zest.

title: Creole-Rum Sazerac
intro_philosophy: Can we legitimately call this drink, which originates in 1977’sTwo-in-One International Recipe Card Collection for Mixed Drinks and Hors d’oeuvre, a “Sazerac”? Probably not, butTakoi beverage director Drew Pompa thinks it deserves a fair shake nonetheless. A split base of Guyanese and Jamaican rums provides a well-calibrated starting point, complemented by a number of disparate but cooperative ingredients, including Louisiana staples Peychaud’s bitters and Crystal Hot Sauce.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce Guyanese rum, preferably El Dorado 3-Year
3/4 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Plantation Xaymaca Special Dry
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with lemon peel.

title: Queen Garden Swizzle
intro_philosophy: A nonalcoholic take on the swizzle, Lydia McLuen combines the tropical flavor of pineapple gum syrup with mint tea, lemon, Seedlip Garden and a bar spoon of umeboshi plum vinegar for a drink she describes as “refreshing, not too sweet and deeply satisfying.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce chilled flash-brewed mint tea (see Editor’s Note)
1 bar spoon umeboshi plum vinegar, preferably Rare Tea Co.
instructions: 1. Pour all of the ingredients except the vinegar into a chilled Collins glass.
2. Fill the glass halfway with pebble ice, then swizzle until frosty.
3. Top with more pebble ice, forming a mound above the rim.
4. Pour the vinegar over the top, then garnish with a lavish mint bouquet.

title: Pantheon
intro_philosophy: Daisuke Ito, owner of Tokyo’s Land Bar Artisan,created the Pantheonspecifically so others could take it and play with it. At a time when invention so often means novel syrups, cordials or distillates and an appliance or two, a three-ingredient, easy-to-replicate formula seems to have struck a chord with its simplicity, making it onto menus as far away as Thailand and Germany in just five years.
instructions: 1. Combine the ingredients with ice in a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake vigorously, and strain into a cocktail glass.

title: Pineapple and Sage Martini
intro_philosophy:
This was the first ever cocktail to get on the menu when NOPI opened. It was created by Niall Downey, who was living with Scully at the time. The cloves make it particularly well suited to festive parties. Its constant presence on our menu, however, hints at its suitability for drinking throughout the whole year.

You’ll make more of the pineapple purée than you need, so you can either freeze the remainder in batches, to be re-used when needed, or eat it as a delicious purée, swirled into semi-whipped cream or spooned on top of some plain yogurt for breakfast. The remaining clove syrup can be kept in the fridge for a few weeks or frozen for longer.

Reprinted with permission fromNOPI: The Cookbookby Yotam Ottolenghi and Ramael Scully, copyright © 2015. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House LLC.
ingredients: 4 cardamom pods, roughly crushed by hand or in a mortar and pestle
1 large pineapple, unpeeled, leaves trimmed and discarded
instructions: 1. Preheat the oven to  390°F/200°C (360°F/180°C convection).
2. Wrap the pineapple in foil and roast in the oven for 3 hours. Remove and set aside to cool.
3. Peel the pineapple and cut it lengthwise into 4 wedges. Cut out and discard the core, then place the flesh in a blender. Blitz to form a purée and set aside.
4. Add the crushed cardamom pods and sage leaves to the bottle of gin and set aside for at least 3 hours, swirling the bottle from time to time.
5. Strain through a fine-mesh sieve, discard the cardamom and sage, and return the gin to the bottle.
6. Pour 3 1/2 ounces of infused gin into a shaker with 1 3/4 ounce of the pineapple purée, 3/4 ounce of lemon juice, and 2/3 ounce of the clove syrup.
7. Add ice, shake vigorously for 10 to 15 seconds, and strain into prechilled martini glasses.
8. Garnish each with a fresh sage leaf and serve at once.

title: Horse’s Neck
intro_philosophy:
The Horse’s Neck falls within the “cooler” category, a style of long drink that accomplishes exactly what it advertises. The drink—which gets its name from its long, loopy lemon twist garnish that curls along inside of the glass—is one of several classic drinks that devolved into a mocktail around Prohibition. Before its demise, it had been an early 20th-century staple cocktail of the Atlantic City bar scene and sometime in the years following repeal, the formula found its way back to cocktail status with a sweet and spicy mix of bourbon, bitters and ginger.

Photo originally published inBittersby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2011. Photo by Ed Anderson © 2011. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Using a channel knife, peel a lemon in one long spiral. Twist around your finger or a barspoon to create a coil.
2. Drop the lemon coil into a highball or Collins glass leaving the end hanging over the lip and fill with ice.
3. Add bourbon and bitters. Top up with ginger ale or soda.

title: Autumn Leaf
intro_philosophy: An inspired marriage between two classics—the Bijou and the Adonis—the Autumn Leaf highlights the distinctive botanical character of Du Nord Prominence Gin, which features a strong nose and body. “Inspired by the Adonis, I used the salty dry notes of fino sherry instead of dry vermouth, complementing the citrus-juniper profile of Prominence Gin,” says Cruz. “Then I took the Bijou cocktail as inspiration and added green Chartreuse and Punt e Mes to bring a peppery, bitter end that rounds up the herbal profile. The result is a delightful, bold and complex combination of flavors with a long finish that’s ideal for autumn nights.” When mixing drinks, Cruz advises to start by pouring the ingredients with the smallest quantity first to avoid wasting any liquor if you make a mistake when measuring.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice.
2. Stir until chilled, then strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with an expressed lemon peel.

title: Champagne Julep
intro_philosophy: The Mint Julep is a potent afternoon cocktail of mostly whiskey and a dash of minted-sugar whose strength is masked only by a drift of crushed ice. If you’re not looking to get knocked on your ass by the first drink of the day, this sparkling, lower-proof classic is a far more subtle way to ease into day drinking. Bourbon is replaced with a smaller dose of cognac and mixed with dry sparkling wine, a bit of mint and sugar and a dash of bitters. Any combination of fruit, mint or citrus is an appropriate garnish.
ingredients: 3 ounces champagne or other dry, sparkling wine
1/2 ounce simple syrup or one sugar cube
instructions: 1. In a julep tin or rocks glass, add mint leaves and simple syrup (or sugar cube and a splash of water). Gently press mint leaves with a muddler to release oils.
2. Add cognac, champagne, bitters and crushed ice and stir gently.
3. Top with more crushed ice to mound.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet and lemon peel.

title: Hard Start Alexander
intro_philosophy: Robby Dow describes this modern Alexander as “the perfect end of your evening: smooth, balanced, mentholated goodness with a nuance of banana on the finish, and definitely not too sweet.” The Hard Start Alexander hops into Grasshopper territory thanks to its namesake 50/50 base of Fernet-Branca and Brancamenta, which lends a distinctly minty note that’s rounded out with crème de cacao and a rich, housemade banana cream.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Hard Start (equal parts Fernet-Branca and Brancamenta)
1 ounce Crème de Cacao, preferably Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled, then fine-strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with shaved dark chocolate.

title: Alpine White Negroni
intro_philosophy: Naren Young, whose New York bar, Dante, famously boasts an entire section of its menu dedicated to theNegroni, offers this bitter, winterized rendition on theWhite Negroni. Swapping inCocchi Americanoin place of Lillet Blanc, and adding in a measure ofgénépyplus a bracing splash of crème de menthe, it’s a familiar play on a bitter mainstay.
ingredients: 1 barspoon white crème de menthe, such as Tempus Fugit
1 dash saline solution (1:1, salt to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

title: Margarita al Pastor
intro_philosophy: At Licorería Limantour, the house Margarita puts a savory spin on the template. Inspired by Mexico City’s tacos, the recipe calls on “taco mix”—a blend of pineapple juice, fresh herbs and serrano chile—to replicate the flavors of an al pastor taco.
ingredients: heavy 1 1/2 ounces Taco Mix (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with cilantro salt and set aside.
2. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared glass over ice.
4. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

title: Golden Glove
intro_philosophy: TheGolden Gloveis a Jamaican rum–based, Cointreau-laced frozen Daiquiri from the heyday of Havana’s El Floridita bar. At Bar Kabawa in the East Village, Kathryn “Pepper” Stashek is reviving the drink on her rum-soaked menu. She asserts that the original spec is near-perfect, and makes just a few slight tweaks, including upping the sugar and adding xanthan gum for texture. Stashek hopes that, through the Golden Glove, guests will get a taste of Prohibition-era Cuban cocktail history and begin to grasp the noble mixological past of the frozen Daiquiri genre.
ingredients: 2 ounces Jamaican rum, such as Appleton Estate Signature
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend for 20 seconds.
2. Pour into a large coupe.
3. Garnish with an expressed orange twist.

title: Midori Cream Soda
intro_philosophy: A splash of whisky is the key to this boozy ice cream soda inspired by Kayoko Seo’s childhood—without it, Seo insists, the drink is too sweet. “The whisky stabilizes it,” she says. “I don’t taste it that much, but it’s a good combination. It gives it a nice balance.” The scoop of ice cream can be stirred into the drink or eaten right away.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce Japanese whisky, preferably Suntory Toki
instructions: 1. In a large footed glass, combine all ingredients, except for soda water and ice cream, over ice.
2. Top with soda water.
3. Add the ice cream and garnish with a maraschino cherry.
4. Serve with a long-handled spoon and a straw.

title: Benton’s Bacon Fat-Infused Bourbon
intro_philosophy:
The base of cocktail barPDT‘s most famous cocktail, this bacon-infused bourbon created by Don Lee for theBenton’s Old Fashionedis the spirit that introduced the cocktail world to fat washing.

Reprinted with permission fromThe PDT Cocktail Book© 2011 by Jim Meehan, Sterling Epicure an imprint of Sterling Publishing Co., Inc.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bacon fat (preferably Benton's, or a thick cut bacon)
instructions: 1. On low heat, warm bacon fat in a small saucepan.
2. Stir until it melts, about five minutes.
3. Combine the molten fat and bourbon in a large nonreactive container and stir.
4. Infuse for four hours, then place the container in the freezer for two hours.
5. Remove solid fat, fine-strain bourbon through a terry cloth or cheesecloth and bottle.

title: Franky Marshall’s Sidecar
intro_philosophy: Second place in our recent Sidecar tasting went to bartender Franky Marshall, who was one of the only contestants to split her brandy base, using one ounce Pierre Ferrand 1850 and one ounce H by Hine. Three-quarters of an ounce of Grand Marnier, a Cognac-based modifier, was her orange liqueur choice. Completing the recipe was three-quarters of an ounce of lemon juice and a ¼ ounce of demerara syrup.
ingredients: 1 ounce H by Hine VSOP cognac
1/4 ounce demerara syrup (1:1, Billington’s demerara sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Banana Oleo Saccharum
intro_philosophy: At Project Halcyon, the bar sought out ways to use peels—a byproduct from the house Martini, which features clarified banana juice—to use the whole ingredient and avoid waste. According to general manager Adam Montanaro-Taylor, the bar experimented with a host of banana peel garnishes, but in the end, what stuck was this easy-to-make banana skin “oleo.” For at-home bartending, the ingredient could replace simple syrup in a classic Daiquiri or an Old-Fashioned; adding a dash of saline solution makes the banana peel’s subtleties pop.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a sealed plastic bag and macerate for 48 hours. Strain the liquid and bottle, then refrigerate.

title: Star Daisy
intro_philosophy: “Sasha Petraske first introduced me to the Star Daisy at the OG Milk & Honey, and I’ve been captivated by it ever since,” says New York’s Joaquín Simó of the lesser-known classic that dates back to at least the early 20th century. With bright citrus and autumnal apple brandy, the unsung cocktail is well-suited to drinking all year round. In Simó’s take on the drink, he adds a bit of extra sugar, finding that orange liqueur needs a bit of “fattening up” to achieve the right mouthfeel.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce high-proof London dry gin, preferably Junipero
3/4 ounce apple brandy, preferably Laird’s Bottled in Bond
3/4 ounce dry Curaçao, preferably Pierre Ferrand
1/3 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake hard with ice until very cold.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Chimayó
intro_philosophy: In 1965, New Mexican restaurant owner Arturo Jaramillo created this seasonal take on the Margarita for his restaurant Rancho de Chimayó, calling on apple cider to complement the tequila base. Our modern spin hews closely to the original, with the addition of a small measure of ginger beer to lengthen the drink and bring some added zip and dimension. For those who prefer the drink served up, try subbing in a quarter-ounce of ginger syrup in lieu of the ginger beer.
instructions: 1. Add all of the ingredients except for the ginger beer to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake.
3. Strain over ice into a Collins glass.
4. Top with ginger beer.

title: Prancing Horse
intro_philosophy: This is a variation on the Horse & Cart, a drink that Fox Liquor Bar in Raleigh, has had on the menu since opening in September 2011. With similar flavors to aMoscow Mule, the addition of Aperol gives the drink a nicely balanced bitterness. In this version, bartenders John Parra and Kyle Hankin swap the Aperol for theirFerrari mix(a 50/50 combo of Fernet Branca and Campari) which makes the drink even more bitter, while still super drinkable and refreshing. This is a great gateway drink for folks who aren’t familiar with (or don’t care for) Fernet.
instructions: 1. In a shaker, combine vodka, Ferrari, ginger syrup, lime juice and bitters.
2. Fill with ice and shake until very cold.
3. Strain into a Collins glass filled with fresh ice.
4. Top with soda, and garnish with the speared candied ginger.

title: Smoke Flowers
intro_philosophy: For his Smoke Flowers, Orlando Franklin McCray looked to theChrysanthemumcocktail—a relatively obscure classic made with dry vermouth, Bénédictine and absinthe—for inspiration. The rich flavors of apricot liqueur and the Fever-Tree Smoky Ginger Ale complement each other in this complex long drink.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces dry vermouth, such as La Quintinye Extra Dry
1 teaspoon apricot liqueur, such as Giffard Abricot du Roussillon
ginger ale, such as Fever-Tree Smoky Ginger Ale, to top
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the ginger ale in a mixing tin filled with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Smoky Ginger Ale.
4. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Garden Star
intro_philosophy: Somewhere between aSouthsideand aGimlet, this savory cocktail combines crisp summer cucumbers with cooling mint and gin. (It’s creators Eric Prum and Josh Williams use their ownhomemade gin.) A verdant and aromatic lime-green drink, the Garden Star may or may not count as a daily serving of vegetables.
ingredients: 4 cubes sugar, or 3 ounces simple syrup (1:1, sugar:water)
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle sugar cubes or simple syrup with the cucumber slices and mint.
2. Add gin, lime juice and ice, and shake until well chilled.
3. Double-strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a slice of cucumber.

title: Andrew Cordero’s Miami Vice
intro_philosophy: “We’re a heavy aperitif, amaro, fortified wine bar,” explains J & Tony’s bar manager Andrew “Coco” Cordero. With that in mind, he found a way to tweak the classicMiami Vice—which mixes a frozen Piña Colada with a frozen Strawberry Daiquiri—to fit the bar’s identity. Namely, he adds Amaro Montenegro and nutty amontillado sherry to the Piña Colada half, while switching out the Daiquiri for a bittersweetJungle Birdvariation.
ingredients: 1 recipe Improved Big Red Jungle Bird (see Editor's Note)
1 recipe Coco's Colada Mountain (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine Improved Big Red Jungle Bird and Coco's Colada Mountain side-by-side in a tall glass that holds at least 15 ounces.
2. Garnish with mint bouquet.

title: Michelada de la Madre
intro_philosophy: The longer you savor Jason Eisner’s riff, the more there is to savor—the basil-lemon ice cube lends subtle citrus notes that temper the heat of the peppers in this herbaceous take on the Michelada.
ingredients: 12 ounces blonde ale, preferably Eel River
1  large lemon-basil ice cube  (see Editor's Note)
lime wedge, for the rim of the glass
spicy salt, for the rim of the glass (equal parts sugar, salt and chili de arbol)
instructions: 1. Rub the rim of a pint glass with a lime wedge and rim the glass with spicy salt.
2. In the bottom of the glass, combine two dashes of bitters, lime juice, basil and worcestershire sauce and gently muddle.
3. Slowly top with the beer and add in the lemon-basil ice cube.
4. Sprinkle spicy salt on the surface of the drink and garnish with another lime wedge.

title: Millennial Pink
intro_philosophy: Calling on a base of rosé, the Millennial Pinkincorporatesrosé syrup, alongside Aperol,Pamplemousseand fresh grapefruit and lemon juices. Poured over ice and topped with a sprig of mint, it’s an easy-to-make ahead cocktail that’s perfect for late summer.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 750ml bottle and refrigerate.
2. Serve in a Collins glass over ice and top with soda water.
3. Garnish with an expressed grapefruit peel and a small bouquet of mint.

title: What Betty’s Having
intro_philosophy: Karri Kiyuna loves a whisky highball. “Like, a lot.” For the “Head Bird” at San Francisco’s Wildhawk, theres no drink more refreshing. This variation is a winter-ready version, with the addition of some Martini & Rossi Bitter lending earth and saffron notes. “This is my little shout-out to all the Bettys who love their whiskey,” Kiyuna says.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce Scotch, preferably Dewar’s 12 Year Scotch Whisky
instructions: 1. Build in a collins glass over ice.
2. Top with cold club soda and gently stir.

title: Three-Minute Toddy
intro_philosophy: This gin-based hot drink looks clear at first, then turns a bright ruby hue as the sachet, which is filled with hibiscus tea, infuses. “The changing color is part of the surprise,” MaximeBelfand explains.
instructions: 1. In a footed Irish coffee mug, stir together first four ingredients.
2. Add sachet, and allow to steep for three minutes.
3. Remove the sachet and garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Cantaloupe & Chamomile White Negroni
intro_philosophy: A fruit-forward, slightly floral spin on theWhite Negroni, whose delicate profile comes courtesy of chamomile-infused gin.
instructions: 1. Add ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice.
2. Stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Express a lemon peel over the drink, then discard. Garnish with a fresh edible flower.

title: Bumble Bee
intro_philosophy:
The Bumble Bee is from Charles H. Baker’sThe South American Gentleman’s Companion. A crowd favorite, this frothy, rich and bright drink regularly makes the rotation at the Slanted Door.

Reprinted with permission fromThe Slanted Doorby Charles Phan © 2014. Published by Ten Speed Press. Photography © 2014 by Ed Anderson.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Jamaican rum (preferably Appleton Estate V/X)
1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, funky (preferably Smith and Cross)
instructions: 1. Add ingredients (in the order listed above) to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake without ice for 6 seconds to emulsify egg white.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Double-strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.
5. Express an orange peel over top of the cocktail and discard.
6. Using an eyedropper, drop Angostura bitters over top of the foam. Drag a toothpick through them to create a design.

title: Smoking Jacket
intro_philosophy: When Chris Amirault tastes Averna, its subtle sweetness conjures memories gathered around a table of friends for an alfresco dinner under the stars. “The brighter citrus notes of pomegranate and orange of the Averna told me that I wanted something earthy, so I chose a smoky mezcal that has some notes of red chile and chocolate to pair with that,” he says. The custom tonka bean cream in The Smoking Jacket introduces distinctive finishing notes of tobacco and a mellow texture that might remind you of a deconstructed White Russian. “I think if the ‘The Dude’ went to Italy, he would definitely want try one of these.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, preferably Rey Campero Jabalí
1 ounce tonka bean cream (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the tonka bean cream, in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
3. Top with tonka bean cream.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Batida Ramos
intro_philosophy: In this mashup of a Ramos Gin Fizz and a Batida (a Brazilian drink that typically incorporates coconut milk and cachaça) Team Lyan incorporates housemade whey to pump up the tang and texture of the drink. Like a good Ramos, it has that drinking-clouds delicacy, but also packs a weight that is immensely satisfying.
ingredients: 1 ounce blackberry and orange blossom syrup (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except soda water to a shaker, and dry shake.
2. Add ice and shake until well chilled.
3. Double strain into a chilled highball glass, and gently top with soda.
4. Express a lemon peel over the top of the glass, and discard.

title: Agricole Rhum Punch with Red Wine
intro_philosophy: At the recently reopened Bar Agricole in San Francisco, the Agricole Rhum Punch with Red Wine is a riff on Charles Baker’s Obispo de Cuba, which is usually made with a dry Cuban rum. While almost all of Bar Agricole’s drinks comprise ingredients or spirits made by the bar, this recipe can be replicated at home with an aged agricole rhum and a light-bodied red wine.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce light-bodied red wine, such as Beaujolais
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a stemless glass or coupe of your choice.

title: Canary Nest
intro_philosophy: Sprouse’s friesling iteration goes in a richer, spicier direction—she recommends using an off dry riesling as a base for sweet vermouth and pear brandy. And while the wine choice here is more flexible, Sprouse has preferred mixers. “The botanicals in Lo-Fi’s vermouth add complexity without muddying the fruit notes of the riesling.”
ingredients: 1 ounce pear brandy, preferably St. George
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and whip with pebble ice or crushed ice.
2. Pour into a glass of your choosing.
3. Garnish with grated cinnamon and an orange slice.

title: La Rambla
intro_philosophy: Inspired by theSiesta, La Rambla at San Diego restaurant Mabel’s Gone Fishing is refreshingly citrusy and tart, with a bitter backbone. Bar manager Tony Roehr was inspired by Spanish poet Federico García Lorca, who said that the Barcelona street is the only one in the world he wished would never end. “I was hoping that people would feel that way about the drink,” says Roehr. “A drink they wished never ended.”
ingredients: 1 ounce London dry gin, preferably Fords
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and vigorously shake.
2. Strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Salted Lemon Martini
intro_philosophy: Today’s bars are getting creative with all the ways to “dirty” a Martini:olives,MSG,ceviche brine,tomatillos. AtCrevettein New York City, this Martini calls on the brine from preserved lemons for its salty, tart tang. For added texture, the bar team fat-washes the Lillet in the drink with olive oil, which is also used as a garnish on top of the drink.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce olive-oil washed Lillet Blanc (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce dry vermouth, such as Noilly Prat
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Express a lemon peel over the drink, then discard.
4. Add three drops of olive oil to the surface of the drink.

title: Aged Eggnog
intro_philosophy:
In February 2020, Hannah Jones took over the bar program at Kansas City’s Corvino Supper Club and Tasting Room. Shortly after, the world shut down. “I inherited a couple gallons of Adam Chase’s eggnog left over from the holidays,” says Jones, who is now the general manager at the Hotel Kansas City. “My husband and I were joking around about a ‘solera-style nog,’ and I decided to put Adam’s gallons into mine before sealing them into vacuum bags to age until Thanksgiving.” The result? An eggnog that Jones describes as “liquid gold.”

Note: This recipe yields about 5 gallons of eggnog (before adding the optional aged eggnog), but it can easily be halved or quartered for a smaller quantity.
ingredients: 8 ounces Laird’s Jersey Lightning apple brandy
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a large container and keep refrigerated indefinitely.
2. To serve, pour into a Nick & Nora glass and top with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Pink Squirrel
intro_philosophy: Though John Dye, who’s owned the venerated Bryant’s Cocktail Lounge since 2008, doesn’t have any hard evidence backing up the belief that The Pink Squirrel was invented at his 86-year-old Milwaukee bar, he feels confident sharing this origin story anecdotally, based on his numerous conversations with old-timers over the years. Built upon a sweet split of crème de noyaux and crème de cacao that produces a pleasantly rosy hue, the Squirrel might be the rare cream-based cocktail that was originally made with ice cream in lieu of heavy cream.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender.
2. Blend until smooth and serve in a Hurricane glass.

title: Knickerbocker
intro_philosophy: Theclassic Knickerbockeris a single-serving rum punch made with Curaçao, raspberry syrup and lemon or lime juice. Though it may date to the 1840s, the earliest recipe we have for it comes from Jerry Thomas’Bartender’s Guide, published in 1862. At Vulture in San Diego, Lucas Ryden has created blends of both rum and orange liqueur for his take on the drink, in which he swaps out the raspberry syrup in favor of a blackberry and cacao shrub and a cinnamon and black pepper syrup. The whole thing is dressed up in 1860s style with mint, an orange wheel and piles of pebble ice.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce aged white rum, such as Probitas
3/4 ounce aged St. Lucia rum, such as Chairman’s Reserve
3/4 ounce clairin, such as Saint Benevolence
1/2 ounce blackberry shrub, such as Cool Hand Co.
1/4 ounce cinnamon and black pepper syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/8 ounce (3/4 teaspoon) orange liqueur, such as Alma Finca
1/8 ounce (3/4 teaspoon) Creole shrubb, such as Clément
2 dashes saline solution (5:1, water to salt)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add a small amount of pebble ice or a Kold Draft–style cube and whip-shake.
3. Dump into a footed rocks glass and top with pebble ice.
4. Add a mint bouquet and an orange wheel. Serve with a straw.

title: Crystal Visions
intro_philosophy: This crisp, white wine spritz gets a floral hit from St-Germain, while Salers and fennel liqueur counter with vegetal notes, all finished with a cooling hit of eucalyptus extract.
ingredients: 2 ounces dry white wine, preferably txakolina
1/2 ounce fennel liqueur, preferably Don Ciccio & Figli Fennel
1 dash eucalyptus extract, preferably Terra Spice
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a wine glass over ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with cucumber ribbon.

title: Pineapple Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: When juiced in a high-speed juicer (or simply by hand and then whirred in the blender), pineapple is among the frothiest of fruits, making it an ideal candidate for the Garibaldi construction. Rather than Campari, the moregentian-forward génépyforms the base here—its bitter, herbaceous qualities countered by pineapple’s inherent sweetness. With its alpine-meets-tropical profile and fresh-pressed fluffiness, this reads like a breakfast-readyChartreuse Swizzle.
instructions: 1. Pour the genepy into a Collins glass.
2. Add ice (optional) and top with fresh-pressed pineapple juice.
3. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

title: Dan Sabo’s Whiskey Sour
intro_philosophy: In our Whiskey Sours tastings in2017and2024, Dan Sabo’s unorthodox addition of a half-ounce of orange juice to the classic construction earned his drink top honors.
ingredients: 2 ounces rye, preferably Rittenhouse Rye 100 Proof
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing tin and dry shake (without ice).
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass and garnish with an orange half-wheel and a brandied cherry.

title: Boardwalk Flyer
intro_philosophy: The Boardwalk Flyer—a combination of  aged cachaça, vermouth and banana liqueur—is meant to evoke the feelings and flavors of a domestic beach vacation: “…there’s something very American about the idea of that,” says Boelte. But when you really get down to it, Boelte credits the original inspiration behind the banana-fied drink to be none other thanArrested Development.
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a Collins or pilsner glass and fill with pebble ice and swizzle.
2. Top with mole bitters, fresh grated nutmeg and mint.

title: Eggnog
intro_philosophy: Eggnog is a drink that currently exists within cruel parameters—compulsory on the days near Christmas and strictly contained to that fleeting window. In Colonial days, whole-egg drinks mixed with ale (calledflips) were common cold-weather fortifiers and, at least by Dickens’s standards, breakfast. Despite the fact that by the mid-19th century the presence of the egg in everyday drinks had fallen dramatically, eggnog, according to Jerry Thomas’s records, came to reign as a somewhat mandatory seasonal delight. The rich mixture of egg, cream and sugar is a great masker of booze. While it feigns the role of liquid Christmas confection, eggnog has been responsible (some reading this may even attest) for many a holiday altercation, including the Eggnog Riot of 1826—a Westpoint holiday party that began with a whole lot of smuggled whiskey and a crowd of liquored-up cadets.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake without ice very well.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Nashi Highball
intro_philosophy: Kikois a destination neighborhood restaurant. That might seem like an oxymoron, but it’s exactly what sets Kiko apart. The program is a masterclass in fine-tuning the classics, and the Nashi Highball is the best example of the kind of nuance, attention and restraint the drinks exhibit. It wasone of our favorite cocktails of 2025.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce Japanese whisky, such as Suntory Toki
3/4 ounce St. George Spiced Pear Liqueur
1/4 ounce verjus blanc, such as Fusion
1/4 ounce pickled ginger syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 teaspoon cane syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except for the soda water to a glass and stir to combine.
2. Top with soda water.
3. Garnish with a fresh bay leaf.

title: Fort Defiance’s Pan American Clipper
intro_philosophy: Two important changes from the original set this version apart. First, the brandy component is split between bonded apple brandy and unaged brandy, which makes the drink “more lively,” notes Frizzell; it also gives it a brighter pink hue, almost resembling aCosmopolitan. Second, the absinthe is spritzed directly into the glass before the drink is poured, as well as on top of the drink, for extra aromatics.
ingredients: 1 ounce unaged apple brandy, preferably Laird's Jersey Lightning
1 ounce bonded apple brandy, preferably Laird's Straight Apple Brandy
instructions: 1. Combine the first four ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Mist a chilled coupe glass with absinthe, then strain into a glass.
3. Spritz absinthe on top of the drink.

title: Paloma
intro_philosophy: La paloma means “the dove” in Spanish. Not much is known about its provenance, but what’s certain is that it’s wildly popular—perhaps even more so than the Margarita—in its home country, Mexico. Technically a cooler (Mexico’s weather requires a steady diet of long, cool drinks), it’s simply a tall, salt-rimmed glass (optional) of tequila, lime juice and grapefruit soda like Fresca or Squirt, which can be substituted for fresh grapefruit and soda water. Fizzy and cooling, the Paloma is like the sweet-tart love child of a Margarita and a Greyhound.
instructions: 1. Add first four (five if using bitters) ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
4. Top with soda water.
5. Garnish with a half wheel of grapefruit.

title: Highball to Heaven
intro_philosophy: In her bookDrink Lightly,Natasha David describes the Highball to Heaven as an “ultra-luxe highball that feels part sophisticated screen siren and part off-duty club kid.” Citric and lactic acids, the latter in an orange juice–spiked simple syrup, amp up the flavor.
ingredients: 2 ounces clove white port (see Editor’s Note)
1 1/2 ounces orange cream syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1 dash citric acid solution (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Whip-shake the first three ingredients with ice.
2. Pour into a highball glass over crushed ice.
3. Top with bubbly water, and stir to incorporate all ingredients.
4. Garnish with a clove-studded orange crescent. Serve with a straw.

title: Natasha David’s Vanilla Lactic Syrup
intro_philosophy: Combining vanilla extract with lactic acid powder creates a simple syrup that adds the perception of creaminess to drinks—without dairy.
ingredients: 500 grams simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. In a medium bowl, combine the syrup, vanilla extract, lactic acid powder and salt.
2. Using a whisk, combine until the lactic acid and salt are dissolved.
3. Refrigerate in a sealed container for up to 4 weeks.

title: Wind, Water, Stone
intro_philosophy: Gin and vodka aren’t the only clear spirits that get on famously with tonic. Named after an Octavio Paz poem, Phoebe Esmon’s cocktail starts withblanco tequila, building complexity with citrus and chile liqueur. The addition of Indian tonic helps smooth out the edges.
ingredients: tonic water, preferably Fever-Tree East India Tonic (to top)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for tonic water, in a Collins glass over ice.
2. Top with tonic water.
3. Garnish with fresh celery leaves.

title: Choke Artist
intro_philosophy: Chris Amirault looked back to his early days as a bartender when developing the Choke Artist. “I was trying to memorize every recipe and wasn’t able to retain a single one,” says Amirault. “I would practice making drinks at home and would mess them up every time. But as most artists would agree, sometimes the best creative ideas are born out of mistakes.” Amirault’s “mistake” takes inspiration from the aperitivo tradition of Milan and the Negroni, using a combination of Cynar and Cynar 70 for the bitter element, and tequila in place of gin, in smaller measure. “It’s still in the Negroni family, but the bitterness brought on from the Cynar is the star of the show.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: The Bitter Swagger
intro_philosophy:
Nick Talarico oversees the front of the house and the beverage program for Memphis chefs Andy Ticer and Mike Hudman’s ever-expanding restaurants and also makes a mean Old-Fashioned, which he doctors with house-made Shiftless Hog orange bitters. I always love geeking out over cocktails and trying new local spirits and beers with Talarico and he kindly shared the story of the Bitter Swagger with me, a cocktail on the menu at Andrew Michael Italian Kitchen, just across the street from Hog and Hominy. “We had a comedian come in after his show downtown late one Saturday night, and he and I talked for a bit about Nardini amaro. He ended up leaving with a bottle from our stock to take with him on his tour and after he left.” That encounter inspired Nick to add a drink on the menu that focused on amaro as a base spirit, and a pisco sour template did the trick. “It’s a total cocktail nerd drink—amaro, pisco, and egg whites don’t necessarily sell themselves—but that’s the fun of having a few cocktail lists where you can hide your nerdiest drinks,” Talarico says.

Reprinted with permission fromAmaroby Brad Thomas Parsons, copyright © 2016. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Random House, Inc.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and dry shake (without ice) for at least 10 seconds to fully incorporate the egg white.
2. Add ice and continue shaking until chilled and then double-strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Kingston Soundsystem
intro_philosophy:
To explore the overlap between the worlds of drinks and music, we challenged bartenders to translate a song of their choice from a given genre into cocktail form. Here, Shannon Mustiphertakes on reggae.

Of the inspiration behind this drink, Mustipher explains: “My favorite reggae song is ‘Skylarking’ by Horace Andy, one of the genre’s most influential artists, whose music dominated dub in the ’70s and went on to inspire dancehall…In keeping with the bird motif in the song’s title, I decided to base my recipe on theJungle Bird, one of my favorite tiki cocktails to riff on.

“The end result—a ‘trickster’ of a drink that blends unlikely elements—looks more innocent than it turns out to be in the end (the overproof rum, whose heat is barely detectable, sees to that), and, hopefully, is a great accessory to an afternoon—or evening—of hanging and pranking around.”
ingredients: 1 ounce aged pot still Jamaican rum
1/2 ounce overproof rum, such as Rum Fire
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a double rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with two pineapple fronds and a lime wheel.

title: Jelani Johnson’s Rum Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Taking first place in our rum Old-Fashioned tasting was Jelani Johnson’s recipe, which calls for a blend of three rums: Mount Gay XO from Barbados, Hamilton 151-Proof Demerara rum from Guyana and Smith & Cross from Jamaica, complemented by a teaspoon of rich cane sugar syrup and a dash each of Angostura and Bittermens ‘Elemakule Tiki Bitters. “This drink is trying to do something, trying to take you to a Caribbean place,” said St. John Frizell. “It doesn’t taste like a rye Old-Fashioned, it’s a rum Old-Fashioned.” The drink was stirred with an orange twist and served with a lime coin, adding just the right amount of aromatics for what bar owner Paul McGee likened to a “Ti’ punch–style serve.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Barbados rum, preferably Mount Gay XO
1/2 ounce  overproof Guyanese rum, preferably Hamilton 151-proof Demerara rum
1 teaspoon Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross
1 teaspoon rich cane syrup (2:1, cane sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Express the orange twist into a mixing glass then drop it in.
2. Add the remaining ingredients then ice, and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
4. Garnish with a small lime coin, sliced off the side of the lime, about the size of a nickel. Express the lime coin from about a foot away from the glass then drop it in.

title: Sour Cherry Shandy
intro_philosophy: Few things are more indicative of summer’s zenith than ripe cherries from the farmer’s market. Created by New York farmer’s market regulars, Eric Prum and Josh Williams, the Sour Cherry Shandy is a perfect example of their food-as-drink philosophy. Muddled and mixed with lime juice and orange liqueur, tart sour cherries are an unexpected, yet amicable companion to crisp lager in this tall, summer cooler.
ingredients: 2 cubes sugar, or 1 1/2 ounces simple syrup (1:1, sugar:water)
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle cherries with sugar cubes or simple syrup.
2. Add Cointreau, lime juice and ice, and shake until well chilled.
3. Strain into a pint or Collins glass over ice.
4. Top with beer and garnish with two cherries.

title: Absinthe Frappé
intro_philosophy: “At the first cold sip on your fevered lip, you determine to live through the day.” So went the ode, “Absinthe Frappé,” from the 1904 musical,It Happened in Nordland. This drink hails from a time when absinthe was a highly popularaperitif(pre-1912 ban) and a morning pick-me-up. Simple, icy and strong, the frappé is a less fussy alternative to the pomp and circumstance of traditional absinthe service.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Pour into a rocks or Collins glass over crushed or pebble ice. Top with additional ice.

title: Gin Rickey
instructions: 1. Pour the liquid ingredients into a highball glass over cubed or hand-cut ice.
2. Garnish with the lime wheel.

title: Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Essentially a Gin Sour made with lime juice, legend has it that the Gimlet was created in the mid-19thcentury to encourage Royal Navy sailors to consume their rations of scurvy-preventing lime juice. The name? Possibly a reference to Thomas Desmond Gimlette, a naval medical officer who served during that era. Rose’s Lime Cordial, a syrup of sugar and lime juice, was invented around the same time to preserve lime juice during long bouts at sea; fundamentalist versions of the drink still call for it. The Rose’s of today, however, is a different animal, with high-fructose corn syrup and additives—stuff that wouldn’t make it past the door of any self-respecting craft cocktail bar. The recipe below skews secular, interpreting lime cordial as a mix of fresh lime juice and sugar.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Powerful Baritone
intro_philosophy:
To explore the overlap between the worlds of drinks and music, we challenged bartenders to translate a song of their choice from a given era into cocktail form. Here, Sother Teague ofAmor y Amargotakes on grunge.

In creating this drink, Teague explains: “I chose the song ‘Even Flow’ from Pearl Jam. It’s about the plight of a homeless man who likely also suffers from mental illness. Classic chicken-and-egg story of which came first, the homelessness or the illness.

“My drink harkens back to my youth. When I would go to punk rock shows as a young man, we’d always drink Cutty Sark. Among my friends, we still refer to it as ‘the punk rock Scotch,’ so it seemed fitting to use in a grunge-related cocktail.

“This cocktail is a riff on the Sammy Ross neoclassicPenicillin. Bold Scotch plus floral Strega and … Becherovka, all tempered by the juiciness of Montenegro.

“In ‘Even Flow’, the man chases away his thoughts like butterflies; the atomized Scotch atop the drink is representative of something critical to the whole, but is somewhat unobtainable. The name is a simple descriptor of Eddie Vedder’s unmistakable voice.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces blended Scotch, preferably Cutty Sark Prohibition
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a double rocks glass.
2. Add a large ice cube and stir to combine.
3. Garnish with a spray of peated Scotch, such as Laphroaig, and garnish with a lemon twist, expressed and inserted into the drink.

title: Safari Julep
intro_philosophy: According to Joaquín Simó, this drink “honors the ancient horticulturist Safr, who brought the pomegranate from the Middle East to Spain.” It echoes the flavors of the British spice trade with Scotch, Jamaican rum and chai tea.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce overproof Demerara rum, preferably Hamilton 151
1 teaspoon house grenadine (see recipe for Pouring Ribbons' grenadine )
1 teaspoon  chai syrup (1:1, sugar: brewed chai tea)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a julep cup.
2. Fill the cup with crushed ice.
3. Use a swizzle stick to combine.
4. Garnish with a mint sprig and a curry leaf.

title: Chris Hannah’s Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Chris Hannah’s recipe, which came in second place in our recent blind-tasting, calls for a high-rye bourbon (Bulleit was employed for the tasting), two muddled demerara sugar cubes, two dashes each of Angostura and NOLA’s own Peychaud’s and an orange twist. The judges thought the drink likably strong, with the correct sugar level.
ingredients: 2 ounces high-rye bourbon, preferably Woodford Reserve or Bulleit
instructions: 1. In a mixing glass, muddle the sugar with the bitters.
2. Express the orange peel over the mixing glass and toss in, along with the bourbon and ice.
3. Stir until chilled.
4. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
5. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Cruise Control
intro_philosophy: “I love my low-ABV drinks,” says Natasha David of this cocktail, which loosely builds on a Tom Collins framework.  “Pommeau [is] … one of the most underrated ingredients, and I wanted it to be the star of the drink, which it isn’t very often.” Mixed with St-Germain, for “beautiful, earthy notes” and a cordial designed to minimize waste by using day-old citrus juices, the end result is “a light, bright, easy-to-drink highball.”
ingredients: 1 ounce salted lemon-lime cordial  (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over Kold-Draft ice cubes.
3. Garnish with cucumber fan.

title: Bergamot Blazer
intro_philosophy: While a most spectacular show of bartender brawn, the Blazer is a simple drink which just happens to entail rolling flaming whiskey back and forth between two metal mugs. A number of mid-19th century bartenders claim the creation, but Jerry Thomas, of course, rises to the forefront with his authoritative recipe inThe Bon Vivant’s Companion, 1862, flame-throwing selfie illustration included. Though the recipe is relatively basic, the trick lies in the tossing of fiery liquid from one mug to another without injury. PUNCH recommends practicing with a non-flaming substance first, and then proceeding with extreme caution. This variation comes from Seattle bartender Andrew Bohrer, who added earl grey tea and elderflower liqueur to the mix. He says the drink mixes just as well without fire, but a little flair never hurts.
ingredients: 2 ounces earl grey tea, double strength
3/4 ounce St. Germain liqueur (or 1 ounce elderflower syrup)
instructions: 1. Fill up two silver-plated mugs with handles with hot water to warm them up. Discard after a minute or two.
2. Fill a rocks or wine glass with hot water to warm. Set aside.
3. Add two ounces bourbon to one mug.
4. Add two ounces earl grey tea to the second mug.
5. Carefully light a long match and touch to the contents of the bourbon mug.
6. Extinguish match and pour the lit bourbon mug into the tea.
7. Pour back and forth 4 or 5 times.
8. Extinguish the mugs by alternately placing one on top of the other.
9. Discard water from rocks or wine glass.
10. Pour mug contents into the warmed up glass.
11. Top with 3/4 ounces St. Germain elderflower syrup. (See Editor's Note.)
12. Add more hot water if desired.
13. Garnish with the peel of an entire lemon.

title: Destroyer Cocktail
intro_philosophy: Joaquín Simó based this Manhattan-style drink on the Deshler Cocktail—named for lightweight Dave Deshler—from Hugo R. Ensslin’s 1917Recipes for Mixed Drinks. So Simó looked to Mexican boxer and heavyweight champion Andy “Destroyer” Ruiz Jr., for inspiration, reworking the original rye cocktail with a tequila base, and balancing it with the spice and fruit of Dubonnet and a splash of blood orange liqueur. A dash of Bittermens Xocolatl Mole bitters and two blood orange peels and a lime peel pay homage to Ruiz’s heritage. “The spice and fruitiness of Dubonnet anchors the drink, with dancing agave notes and a flurry of citrus flavors rounding out the cocktail,” says Simó. But, he warns, “Just don’t have too many or you’re likely to end up like Ruiz’s unfortunate opponents: flat on your back and wondering what just happened.”
ingredients: 2 blood orange peels, cut with as little pith as possible (regular oranges can be substituted when blood oranges are not in season)
1 lime peel, cut with as little pith as possible
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a blood orange peel, expressed over the top of the drink, and notched onto the rim.

title: Fifty-Fifty Martini
instructions: 1. Stir ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and either strain into a chilled cocktail glass or pour it into an ice-filled rocks glass.
2. Garnish with either a lemon twist or an olive.

title: Born A Star Martini
intro_philosophy: Adam Fournier wanted to incorporate a “uniquely Southern Californian” flavor to the Pornstar Martini, a drink international guests often ordered from him.
