Mamey sapote, a fruit found in the state as well as in Central America and the Caribbean, supplied that flavor, along with “wonderful texture and weight” that goes well with the brightness of passion fruit and decadent vanilla syrup.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce passion fruit syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce mamey sapote syrup (see Editor’s Note)
3 ounces dry sparkling wine, to top
instructions: 1. Add the first five ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake hard with ice.
2. Double-strain into a chilled cocktail coupe.
3. Top with dry sparkling wine.
4. Spray vanilla-sherry mist over the drink, and garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel.

title: Pan American Clipper
intro_philosophy: This cocktail recipe is credited to world traveler Charles H. Baker Jr., who in his later years settled into Coconut Grove, Florida—very close to where Pan Am had just opened the first international airport. It was there that he might have started keeping company with the Pan Am pilots; he cites this drink as hailing “from the notebook of one of our pilot friends.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with cracked ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Sloe & Fast Americano
intro_philosophy: Ryan Chetiyawardananotes that sloe gin is best when made with enough time to allow the flavors to develop, as the tart fruit infuses with the botanical spirit base. A microwave and sweeter, lower proof Campari and vermouth are his way of “cheating the process,” to extract depth and add fruitiness and a sour pop to a batched cocktail.
ingredients: 2 cups fresh sloe berries, or half the amount of dried stonefruit, such as cherries, peaches or apricots
8 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Martini Riserva Rubino
8 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Martini Rosso
instructions: 1. Rinse, pick over and dry the sloe berries, then prick each with a needle.
2. Combine all ingredients in a vacuum-sealable, microwave-proof bag and microwave for 5 minutes on medium power.
3. Allow to cool, then blast again for 5 minutes. Cool thoroughly, then strain.
4. To serve, add 1 1/4 ounces to a highball over ice.
5. Top with 3 1/3 ounces chilled soda water.
6. Garnish with lemon twist and a mint sprig.

title: Mackinaw Highball
intro_philosophy: At Hawksmoor in New York, the Mackinaw Highball takes its inspiration from peach iced tea. It is a stone fruit triple threat: crème de pêche, Cognac—chosen for its stone fruit flavors—and a touch of peach-infused white balsamic vinegar, for a final peachy punch. “It pulls out more of the fruitiness of the fruit,” Montgomerie explains. Still, when it comes to vinegar, he advises treading lightly: “As soon as you can taste it, it’s too much,” he warns. At the bar, the drink is force-carbonated, but an at-home version calls on club soda for effervescence.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon crème de pêche, preferably Les Reserves d’Arton Crème de Pêche de Vigne
1 teaspoon sugar syrup (2:1, sugar to water)
1/2 teaspoon Sparrow Lane California Peach Vinegar
instructions: 1. Combine the first eight ingredients, chilled, in a highball glass over a single spear of ice.
2. Top with club soda, then garnish with a lemon coin.

title: Greenhorn
intro_philosophy: At Refuge in Houston, Bobby Heugel wanted to create a stirred drink that highlights Midori and could be easily replicated by others. With a base of blanco tequila (El Tesoro in this case), the Greenhorn balances the melon liqueur’s sweetness with the bitter gentian flavor of Suze. The resulting drink—which tastes “like a fun dropout Negroni of sorts,” he says—is finished with an equally verdant neon green maraschino cherry.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces blanco tequila, preferably El Tesoro
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a green maraschino cherry.

title: Chance Encounter
intro_philosophy: Brian Sturgulewski’s Chance Encounter uses the apricot and peach notes of Dimmi to enhance the floral flavors of pisco, while adding a “unique viscosity and weight” to this citrusy cocktail.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients.
2. Strain in a coupe.
3. Express grapefruit peel over the surface.

title: Jeff “Beachbum” Berry’s Daiquiri
intro_philosophy: The house Daiquiri atJeff “Beachbum” Berry‘sLatitude 29took more than a year to perfect. In an effort to cut down on dilution, Berry omits simple syrup, preferring instead to dissolve a mixture of sugars directly into fresh lime juice. As for his choice of rum, he opts for either Bacardi 1909 Superior Limited Edition (89 proof) or Caña Brava (86 proof), which he says are most similar to the rum—Bacardi Carta Blanca—that would have formed the base of the Daiquiri before Prohibition.
ingredients: 2 level teaspoons sugar blend (see Editor's Note)
2 ounces white rum, preferably Caña Brava or Bacardi 1909 Superior Limited Edition
instructions: 1. Combine the sugar blend and lime juice in a mixing tin.
2. Stir until the sugar has fully dissolved into the lime juice.
3. Add the rum to the sugar and lime mixture, along with large cubes of ice, cracked with a bar spoon.
4. Quickly shake and strain the drink into a coupe.
5. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: Hot Daiquiri
intro_philosophy:
While turning a summer drink like the daiquiri into what is essentially a rum hot toddy seems like a bibulous fool’s errand, this drink is something of a nonsensical triumph. And it is one hell of a holiday party trick.

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 1 ounce dark rum, preferably Diplomatico Reserva Exclusiva
Angostura whipped cream, to top (see Editor's note)
instructions: 1. Combine the hot water, dark rum, pineapple rum, simple syrup, and lime juice in a tempered glass or mug and top with 2 to 3 tablespoons whipped cream.

title: Watermelon Cucumber Cooler
intro_philosophy: In Japan, salt is often sprinkled atop watermelon to enhance the flavor. The same idea is at play here, with a combination of wasabi powder: Salt and sugar for a little something extra.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  lime and lemon juice, mixed
instructions: 1. Combine peeled cucumber and cane syrup to a shaking tin, and muddle gently.
2. Add the rest of the ingredients, except for the watermelon.
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Strain into a highball glass.
5. Add watermelon juice.
6. Stir lightly, and serve.

title: Congas y Coladas
intro_philosophy: A twist on thePiña Colada, Demi Natoli’s Congas y Coladas cuts the coconut syrup component with “Doña’s Mix,” a play on Donn’s Mix that incorporates cumin, layered on top of pineapple juice and funky Jamaican rum. “The drink pulls together to make a really savory, but also refreshing cocktails,” says Natoli.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce overproof aged rum, preferably Plantation O.F.T.D.
1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Smith & Cross Rum
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a Hurricane glass.
3. Garnish with pineapple fronds, a pineapple wedge and an edible orchid.

title: Lysette
intro_philosophy: The hallmarks of the aperitif are the driving forces behind the Lysette, a three-ingredient cocktail as relevant for the home bartender as it is for the pro. “After all,” explains bartender Franky Marshall, “the less time you spend making drinks, the more time you have to enjoy good company.” In a nod to the aperitif’s origins, the components are all French—from the gentle bitterness of Salers to the light, floral notes of St-Germain to the fizzy smack of Kronenbourg.
instructions: 1. Combine the St-Germain and gentian liqueur in an ice-filled stemmed glass or goblet and stir briefly.
2. Top with the lager and stir once to integrate.
3. Express the grapefruit peel, then discard.
4. Garnish with chrysanthemum blossoms.

title: Cali-Fornication on the Beach
ingredients: 1/2 ounce apricot vodka, preferably SKYY California Apricot
3/4 ounce orange- and cranberry-infused bianco vermouth (see Editor's Note)
2 dashes Miracle Mile Sour Cherry Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lime wheel and a decorative mermaid.

title: Plain Sailing
intro_philosophy: A straightforward mixture of gin, blanc vermouth, manzanilla sherry and sloe gin that feels like it’s pulled from the pages of Harry Craddock, this cocktail is exemplary ofPaige Walwyn’s classics-inspired approach to cocktail creation.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce blanc vermouth, preferably Comoz Vermouth Blanc
3/4 ounce manzanilla sherry, preferably Bodegas Yuste Aurora
1/4 ounce sugar cane syrup, preferably Petite Canne Martinique
instructions: 1. Rinse a Nick & Nora glass with absinthe and set aside.
2. Combine all remaining ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into the prepared glass and garnish with an expressed and discarded lemon twist.

title: Lemony Snicker
intro_philosophy: In her take on sgroppino, a traditional Italian palate-cleanser, Karen Fu harnesses the refreshing qualities of citrus in multiple forms: yuzu-inflected Japanese gin, frosty lemon sorbet, bright meyer lemon juice and fizzy lemon-lime soda. Bianco vermouth rounds out the recipe, but Fu notes that fino sherry can easily stand in (she recommendsBarbadillo).
ingredients: splash Jarritos Mineragua or Maine Root Lemon Lime soda
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a bowl and gently whisk or mix with a spoon to integrate.
2. Pour into a chilled sundae glass.
3. Garnish with thyme and serve with a metal straw or spoon.

title: Flamingo Milanese
intro_philosophy: At Rita’s Tiki Room in Milan, tropical flavors and classic aperitivo cocktails co-mingle as a matter of practicality. (According to owner Edoardo Nono the concept of a tiki bar in Italy is new to most Italians, so wrapping the experience around the word “aperitivo” made it easier for customers to understand.) Here, the Milanese classic Campari Shakerato heads to the beach.
ingredients: 1/3 ounce lime oleo saccharum (see Editor's Note)
2 dashes absinthe, preferably La Fée Parisienne
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled then strain into the other tin.
3. Discard the ice then dry shake without ice to fully combine.
4. Fine-strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass and garnish with a bamboo leaf.

title: Sundial
intro_philosophy: In this complex sour, Death & Co.’sShannon Tebaybuilds on the Cognac base with cherry eau de vie, orgeat and small doses of elderflower liqueur and amaro. The result is a frothy, rich, layered cocktail ideal for the colder months.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces Cognac, preferably Paul Beau VS
3/4 ounce cherry brandy, preferably Clear Creek
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Express the grapefruit twist and discard.

title: Plum Royale
intro_philosophy: Kathleen Hawkins’ take on Champagne punch borrows from the classicKir Royale, combiningcrème de cassiswith plum shrub, and topping it all with Champagne and orange bitters.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounce créme de cassis, preferably Pierre Chermette
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a pitcher or a punch bowl.
2. Serve in a flute or small Collins glass and garnish each serving with a lemon peel, torched rosemary sprig and a dash of orange bitters.

title: Disco Medley
intro_philosophy: Natasha David created this cocktail forOne Last Shift, a party that brought back Nitecap—her beloved Lower East Side bar—for one night. According to her, the Disco Medley is “a new drink, inspired by the evolution of Nitecap and the drinks we might have been creating today.” The tropical sour balances juicy bitterness against the body of reposado tequila, topped, of course, with glitter.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake well.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with a shake of edible glitter.

title: The Dead Rabbit’s Whiskey Cocktail
intro_philosophy:
Inspiration: William Schmidt,The Flowing Bowl,1892

Schmidt’s original is heavily boozy, a whiskey and bitters brawler in the best cocktail tradition. As with many of the drinks in this chapter, we’re taming the beast and evening out the flavors. For this recipe, we will ratchet up the bitters component with two complementary formulas, plus our old standby, absinthe. Further seasoning comes via gloriously herbal Bénédictine (perhaps familiar to most imbibers when combined with brandy as B&B) and Royal Combier, which is a spicy liqueur that has in fact already been blended into brandy.

Royal Combier, featuring aloe, nutmeg, myrrh, cardamom, cinnamon, and saffron, is a perfect foil to the nuttiness of Old Overholt. Bénédictine involves twenty-seven secret herbs and spices, far more than needed even for fried chicken. Nonetheless, fried chicken goes great with a Whiskey Cocktail.

Text Excerpted fromThe Dead Rabbit Drinks Manual(c) 2015 by The Best Bar in the World LLC. Reproduced by permission of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. All rights reserved.

Photos (c) Brent Herrig Photography
ingredients: 3 dashes Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters or Angostura Aromatic bitters
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients, except the garnish, to a mixing glass.
2. Fill with ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain the mixture into a cocktail glass.
4. Twist the orange peel over the glass to express the oils, then discard the peel.

title: Valentino Longo’s Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: This recipe tied for first place inour Espresso Martini tasting. Valentino Longo, of ViceVersa in Miami, leans on fresh espresso in addition to vodka and Borghetti coffee liqueur in his take, while an unexpected splash of amaretto brings another layer of richness to the recipe. “It has a charming ‘burnt cinnamon roll’ thing going on,” said Brian Evans, a bartender who was one of the assembled judges, who noted that while he typically only indulges in one Espresso Martini per sitting, “I would drink two, if not three, of these.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce honey syrup (1:1, water to raw millefiori honey)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake, then dry-shake again without ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with coffee salt on top of the drink.

title: Butternut Squash No. 1
intro_philosophy: At Atomix, bar managerMarc Rodriguezinsists on crafting most of the nonspirit components of the Korean restaurant’s cocktails in-house, from Sichuan peppercorn tincture to kelp syrup and house-fermented elixirs. In this drink, an unconventional cocktail ingredient—butternut squash—drives the flavor alongside curry leaf–infused oat milk, two types of citrus, acidified syrup and both gin and rye.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce curry leaf–infused oat milk (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce lactic acid simple syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce rich cane syrup (2:1, turbinado sugar to water)
6 drops saline solution (4:1, water to salt)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe or coupette.

title: Infernal Collins
intro_philosophy: Built on a base of Campari and Maurin Quina, the Infernal Collins—with its slightly spicy kick from ginger syrup—reflects Zac Overman’s approach to the aperitif cocktail, which finds further expression throughout the drink menu at Seattle’s L’Oursin.
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients except for soda water with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water and garnish with candied ginger.

title: Squash & Sorghum
intro_philosophy:
The main cooking method at the Dabney? Live fire. (The hearth was constructed by chef-owner Jeremiah Langhorne’s father and brother.) Inevitably, roasted fruits and vegetables find their ways into beverage director Brad Langdon’s cocktails, but in the case of this butternut squash shrub, it’s the squash juice that gets cooked. This step takes a raw, almost potato-y liquid and turns it into something rich and toasty with a beautifully rusty color. Paired with a watercress salad or roasted pork, this makes for a great fall meal.

Reprinted with permission fromGood Drinks: Alcohol-Free Recipes for When You’re Not Drinking for Whatever Reasonby Julia Bainbridge, copyright © 2020. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces Squash and Sorghum Shrub (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Place one large ice cube in a rocks glass. Pour in the shrub, then top with the soda water.

title: Fermented Citrus Garibaldi
intro_philosophy: When you make a lot Negronis, you’re left with a lot of zestless oranges. Matthew Bax, owner and head bartender of Bar Americano in Melbourne, repurposes these leftovers in a funky fermented orange juice. (You can turn to a citrus kombucha at home if you don’t have the time or ambition to take on a major fermentation project.) After fermentation is complete, the blend of sugar, orange juice, and sweet vermouth is blended with Campari, Aperol and orange bitters and served over a large ice cube with a splash of fresh orange juice.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces Batched Garibaldi Base (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in chilled double rocks glass over a large ice cube.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Garnish with orange wedge.

title: Rabbit Hole
intro_philosophy: This bracing fernet-forward drink, created in 2015, is adapted fromThe Bartender’s Manifesto(Clarkson Potter, June 2022), a new book from Violet Hour proprietor Toby Maloney.
instructions: 1. Build all ingredients in a double Old-Fashioned glass.
2. Add enough crushed ice to fill the glass about three-quarters full, and swizzle.
3. Add more ice and swizzle again just briefly, to combine. Top up with more crushed ice.
4. Garnish with orange half-wheel and strawberry half.

title: Pope
intro_philosophy: While George Saintsbury deemed it a “capital crime” to mull good Burgundy in his 1920Notes on a Cellar-Book, the Pope nevertheless found popularity in Europe in the 18th and 19th centuries. This version is adapted from William Terrington’s 1869 recipe.
instructions: 1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Wash and dry the oranges. Pierce and stud each orange with 10 cloves.
3. Place the oranges in a baking dish and roast until lightly browned all over, 60 to 90 minutes. Remove the oranges from the oven and set aside to cool.
4. Cut each orange into quarters and place them in a large saucepan with wine, water and sugar.
5. Simmer the mixture over low heat for 15 to 20 minutes.
6. To assemble: Pour an ounce of brandy or rum into each mug if desired.
7. Top with the wine mixture.

title: Absinthe Minded
intro_philosophy: Self-fulfilling pun and prophecy, perhaps. Nevertheless, what will surprise you about this tequila-based beverage by Patrick McNicholas is the combination of lime, honey, cucumber, Herbsaint and chai. If time allows, let the cocktail rest on muddled cucumbers a minute before indulging.
instructions: 1. In a cocktail shaker, muddle the cucumber with all other ingredients.
2. Let stand for a few minutes and then fine strain into a Collins glass with ice.
3. Top with soda and garnish with cucumber.

title: Get It Done
intro_philosophy: Inspired by a Michelada variation from the now-shuttered New York bar Mayahuel, Natasha David turns the recipe into a refreshing and smoky cocktail. “It’s the perfect partner to an extravagant snack setup,” writes David.
ingredients: 2 12-ounce bottles Mexican lager, such as Modelo Especial
instructions: 1. In a pitcher filled halfway with cubed ice, add the beer and let settle.
2. In a large shaker, or working in batches with a small shaker, combine the pineapple juice, chile liqueur, lime juice and agave nectar.
3. Add ice and shake.
4. Strain into the pitcher with the beer.
5. Fill pitcher with more ice, and stir to incorporate ingredients.
6. Garnish with lime wheels.

title: Phil Ward’s Margarita
intro_philosophy: In our recent blind tasting of Margaritas,Phil Ward’s recipe secured itself a spot in the top three. In this quintessential take on the cocktail, Ward calls for Siete Leguas Blanco as the tequila base, and a traditional mix of Cointreau and lime juice, tied together with a salt rim.
ingredients: 2 ounces tequila, preferably Siete Leguas Blanco
instructions: 1. Rim a rocks glass with salt and set aside.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
3. Strain into the rocks glass over ice.

title: Carpano Negroni Sbagliato
intro_philosophy: The “mistaken” version of the classic Negroni swaps the gin for Prosecco, resulting in a lighter, brighter and more sessionable take that bridges the best elements of the spritz with the bold flavor of the iconic Negroni. Try the cocktail with various expressions of Prosecco, ranging from dry to juicy, for different results.
instructions: 1. Add the Carpano Botanic Bitter and Antica Formula vermouth to fluted glass.
2. Top with Prosecco, and gently stir to combine.
3. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: Naked & Famous
intro_philosophy: Joaquín Simó created this modern classic while working at New York’s Death & Co. in the early aughts. A rare equal-parts recipe, the drink reads like a cross between a Last Word and a Paper Plane with a smoky mezcal base.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Chichicapa
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice, cover and shake well.
3. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: First of Four
intro_philosophy: In this riff on theAviation, Scofflaw’s Luke DeYoung replaces the maraschino liqueur with the bitter, gentian root-based Avèze. “It gives the cocktail body while not adding an overwhelming bitterness,” he says of the swap.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a cucumber slice.

title: Come Sta, La Luna
intro_philosophy: This mellow take on a winterizedDaiquiribecame Shae Minnillo’s go-to decompression cocktail after one of those 70 hour-plus workweeks. The subtle funk ofcachaçaconnects the dots between bright citrus and warming cinnamon. As for the bitter, it’s gentle—Minnillo says Luxardo Bitter Bianco “doesn’t demand much.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Tex-Anne
intro_philosophy: Created for a Texas friend of Jim Troutman’s, “who narrowly escaped being given the name Tex-Anne,” this recipe is, at heart, a mezcal Margarita amped up with spice from the Chartreuse and Tabasco and given nuttiness from the orgeat. Troutman describes this drink as “savory but refreshing,” ideal for “a long afternoon spent whiling away the hours in the hot Texas sun.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Del Maguey Crema de Mezcal
1 ounce blanco tequila, preferably Siete Leguas
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients with ice. If it’s too spicy, add a little simple syrup to smooth out the heat from the Tabasco.
2. Strain into an Old-Fashioned glass over a large chunk of ice.
3. Twist grapefruit peel over the drink to express the essential oils, then insert the peel in the glass upright, so it almost looks like a tongue sticking out of the glass.

title: Bar Agricole’s Japanese Cocktail
intro_philosophy: At San Francisco’s Quince, where Bar Agricole is in residence, overseeing the bar program,the Japanese Cocktail is a standout. Thad Vogler uses Bar Agricole’s ownbiodynamic California brandy, a blend of barrels aged 8 to 15 years, for the base, complemented by housemade orgeat and aromatic bitters. The farm that grows the grapes for the brandy and for the high-proof spirit that stabilizes the bitters is the same one that grows the almonds that go into the orgeat. “So it’s a single-estate, grower-producer cocktail,” says Vogler.
ingredients: 1 1/4 ounces California brandy , such as Bar Agricole Biodynamic California Brandy
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Double strain into a coupe glass.

title: Hanky Panky
intro_philosophy: Ada “Coley” Coleman—who preceded legendary bartender Harry Craddock at the Savoy Hotel—had, like any great bartender, a following of devoted regulars. One of them, English stage actor Sir Charles Hawtrey, often came in following a long day requesting “something with a bit of a punch.” On one occasion, Coleman responded with a sweet Martini livened with a splash of Fernet-Branca (a bitter Italian amaro), which Hawtrey called, “the real hanky-panky.” To this day, the drink remains Coleman’s most famous invention.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with an orange peel.

title: The Dreamer
intro_philosophy: This cocktail is an ode to Watsonville, California, whereManny Hernandez, a cantinero at Stokes Adobe, lives. The Central Coast community “is an important area for agriculture where I live and throughout the U.S.,” he says. Hernandez marries ingredients that represent the diverse produce grown there—from the raspberries in the syrup to the aloe in the liqueur—with a spirit, mezcal, that has “a connection to my identity and honors the cultural roots of the many Mexicans working in California fields.” The drink’s name, too, is symbolic: “The ingredients in this cocktail represent the dreamer who works hard for family and community.”
instructions: 1. Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.
2. Double-strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Garnish with mint and raspberry on a bamboo pick.

title: Hot for Teacher
intro_philosophy: A tiki-fied version ofHot Buttered Rum, Matthew Belanger and Shannon Tebay’s (of Pouring Ribbons) Hot for Teacher adds banana (Giffard Banane du Brésil), a proprietary “Improved Gardenia Mix”—a blend of honey, butter, cinnamon and Donn’s spices—coconut cream and two types of rum. Served hot, it’s winter’s version of a Caribbean mirage.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce aged rum (preferably El Dorado 8 year)
1 ounce Improved Gardenia Mix (see Editor's Note for recipe)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredient to a saucepan and heat over a low burner until steaming.
2. Pour into a mug and garnish with a cinnamon stick or a dehydrated banana chip.

title: Open Air
intro_philosophy: For Kristina Magro’s modern take on mulled wine, she set out to create an improved iteration of the mugs ofglühweinsold on blustery days at Chicago’s annual Christkindlmarket, a sprawling outdoor festival featuring ornament vendors and stands hawking strudel. Her recipe puts to use a malbec made specifically for the bar by winemaker Brianne Day in Oregon. To that, she addsLustau Vermutand Lustau Grand Reserva Brandy to up the proof, plus apple chunks, which are simmered and then strained through a chinois, for complexity and textural richness.
ingredients: 1 liter dry red wine, preferably Day Wines Malbec
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a large pot set over low heat, and simmer until the apples are soft enough to be cut with a spoon, about 20 minutes.
2. Remove the pot from the heat and allow the mixture to rest for 20 minutes.
3. Press the mixture, with the apples, through a chinois, making sure to push all of the liquid out.
4. Serve the mulled wine in clear, tempered glasses and garnish with clove-studded orange half wheels.

title: The Spaghetti Incident in the Jungle
intro_philosophy: “There are enough variations on the Jungle Bird,” says The Rockwell Place’s Alex Kveton. Like theSpaghetti Incident?album of covers by Kveton’s favorite band, Guns N’ Roses, this riff felt a little unnecessary, but still enjoyable. “This Jungle Bird doesn’t need to happen, but at least it’s going to go down much easier than the album.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rum, such as El Dorado 8
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel with two pineapple fronds sticking through to rest on the rim of the glass.

title: Mai Tai Soda
intro_philosophy: AtPitt’sin Brooklyn, beverage director Ben Hopkins combines the lush tropical flavor of a Mai Tai with the crisp refreshment of a highball. At the restaurant, this drink is clarified and force-carbonated, but at home, you can top the milk punch with soda water, as shown here.
ingredients: 3 3/4 ounces Mai Tai Milk Punch (see Editor’s Note)
1 1/4 ounces soda water with high carbonation, such as Topo Chico
instructions: 1. Add ice to a frozen highball glass.
2. Pour the Mai Tai Milk Punch over the ice, then top with soda water.
3. Using a barspoon, lift the ice so the two ingredients incorporate.
4. Garnish with fresh mint and grated nutmeg.

title: Curdled Colada
intro_philosophy: Team Lyan’s on the classic Piña Colada reimagines the creamy classic as a clear, bubbly long drink. For a boozier take on this cocktail, substitute sparkling wine for sparkling water.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces chilled curdled syrup, see Editor's Note
1 1/4 ounces soda water, or sparkling wine
1/4 ounce fake lime juice, see Editor's Note
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a flute and serve.

title: The New New Steady
intro_philosophy: Though coconut oil-infused gin is the main player in Columbia Room bartender Tom Martinez’s -tini, he also shouts out other variations on the classic — the “50-50,” with the vermouth half here between Cocchi Americano and Dolin Dry; the dirty martini, via olive bitters; and the Gibson, given nod via cocktail onion garnish.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces coconut-washed Plymouth gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with cocktail onion.

title: Sarah Morrissey’s Eggnog
intro_philosophy: Sarah Morrissey’s eggnog was deemed the most “cocktail-like” of the entries in our blind tasting, partly due to its presentation, which called for a lavish plume of mint dusted with cinnamon and nutmeg, served in a rocks glass. The recipe itself, however, is categorically nog, with the clever but unexpected flourishes of coffee and vanilla liqueurs bolstering the heirloom eggs, Ronnybrook cream and Lustau brandy de Jerez, for a drink that reads like a melted coffee milkshake in the best possible way.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce rich cinnamon syrup (see Editor's Note)
1/2 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Mr. Black
Scant 2 ounces brandy, preferably Lustau Brandy de Jerez
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Roll into a large rocks glass.
3. If necessary, add an ice cube or two to the glass.
4. Garnish with a large plume of fresh mint and top with grated nutmeg and cinnamon.

title: Mull It Over
intro_philosophy: Developed during Natasha David’s time at Brooklyn’s Maison Premiere, Mull It Over reads like a modern take on the Pope. Lillet Rouge fortifies the dry red wine base of this low-proof cocktail, which gets an herbal kick from Becherovka complemented by the spice of cinnamon bark syrup.
instructions: 1. Build in a wine glass and stir.
2. Add three hand cracked ice cubes and top with regular ice cubes.
3. Garnish with an orange half wheel.

title: Danger Zone
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn’s racing-themed bar, OTB (Off Track Betting), Alla Lapushchik mixes rum, spicy Frangelico, citrus and a whole egg to create this tall flip that drinks like the love child of eggnog and an Orange Julius.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Dry shake (shake without ice).
3. Add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Strain into a Collins glass and top with seltzer.
5. Garnish with a dash of Angostura.

title: Bushwick
intro_philosophy: Originally a riff on the Manhattan, the versatileBrooklyn cocktailhas sparked its own family of drinks over the past decade, each named for one of the borough’s neighborhoods. The Bushwick, created by Phil Ward for New York City’s Death & Co., sees base ingredients of rye and sweet vermouth stirred with Luxardo and Amer Picon, a bitter orange liqueur.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Stir ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Tree-Chu-Hi
intro_philosophy:
The shochu highball, more popularly known as a chu-hai, is a combination of shochu, fruit juice and soda water, and is served both à la minute and prepackaged in cans. With his Tree-Chu-Hi, Orlando Franklin McCray marries a barley-based shochu with tonic liqueur and Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit soda. “I tend to avoid using grapefruit juice as a cocktail ingredient because of how widely they can vary in flavor,” says McCray. “The grapefruit soda provides an opportunity for consistent flavor.”

Order Fever-Tree for delivery viaAmazon.
ingredients: 1 ½ ounces Mizu Saga Barley Shochu
½ ounce  Bittermens Commonwealth Tonic Liqueur
4 ounces  Fever-Tree Sparkling Pink Grapefruit soda
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a Collins glass filled with ice.
2. Swizzle to combine ingredients.
3. Garnish with grated grapefruit zest or a grapefruit twist, and finish with a pinch of salt.

title: Patrick Smith’s Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: Patrick Smith’s Espresso Martini recipe tied for first place in our 2019 and 2025 tastings. It calls for an ounce of vodka, three-quarters ounce each of espresso and Mr Black Cold Brew coffee liqueur, half an ounce of Giffard Vanille de Madagascar and a quarter-ounce of Demerara syrup. The inclusion of the vanilla liqueur gave the drink a more fulsome, candied quality, while keeping it within an archetypal framework.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Mr. Black Cold Brew Coffee Liqueur
1/2 ounce vanilla liqueur, preferably Giffard Vanille de Madagascar
1/4 ounce Demerara syrup (1:1, Demerara sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double-strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with three coffee beans.

title: Lost Lake’s Mai Tai (2015 version)
intro_philosophy: Created for the opening of Lost Lake in 2015, this version of the classic Mai Tai is loosely structured on the Trader Vic version of the classic—meaning equal parts Martinique and Jamaican rums. However, it’s buzzed in a drinks mixer instead of shaken, a move intended to create a faster serve. In 2018, Paul McGee, co-owner of Lost Lake,revisited the recipe, altering the rum selection and the technique.
ingredients: 1 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Duquesne Eleve Sous Bois
1 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Appleton Signature Blend
3/4 ounces orgeat, preferably Small Hand Foods
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin, along with 1 cup crushed ice.
2. Buzz (with Hamilton Beach Drinks Mixer) for 4 seconds.
3. Pour into a Mai Tai glass.
4. Top with an additional 1 cup of crushed ice.
5. Garnish with big mint bouquet, orange floret, orchid, swizzle stick and straw.

title: SB Espresso Martini
intro_philosophy: By now, we’ve seen that the Espresso Martini shows no signs of stopping. Washington, D.C.’s Service Bar dialed in its own take on the drink, the SB Espresso Martini, which calls on fresh espresso as well as local coffee liqueur from Don Ciccio & Figli, plus housemade dark chocolate–washed vodka and coconut syrup.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces double-brewed dark roast espresso ground coffee
1/2 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably Don Ciccio & Figli Concerto
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a coupe.

title: Frozen Negroni
intro_philosophy:
Portland bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s frozen Negroni began as a Negroni Sno-Cone he used to serve at backyard dinners. He’s iterated a little over time but doesn’t stray too far from tradition: Campari, gin and sweet vermouth, along with simple syrup and lots of ice.

“Negronis can really stand up to a lot of crushed ice, so preparing it frozen just … works,” he says.

Special thanks to our friends atWest Elmfor outfitting ourfrozen drinks photoshoot.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender.
2. Add ice (Morgenthaler suggests six ounces, crushed).
3. Blend until smooth.
4. Pour into a glass and garnish with an orange wheel.

title: Suppressor #1766
intro_philosophy: When Greg Best and Paul Calvert started thesuppressor movement,they were reacting to the ubiquity of strong and layered drinks that have a tendency to pack a “punch,” as Calvert puts it. “It’s a beautiful punch… but I’m kind of tired of being punched in the face.” Low-alcohol cocktails, on the other hand, can be enjoyed throughout an evening. At Ticonderoga Club in Atlanta, the 1766 (aka The Courier), is a warming combination of vermouth and amontillado, cut by bracing coffee liqueur and orange bitters. “The suppressor, to me, is something with delicacy and nuance,” Calvert says. “They kind of just coast.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth, preferably Miro Spanish Vermut Rojo
3/4 ounce coffee liqueur, preferably St. George NOLA
2 dashes  orange bitters, preferably Regan’s Orange Bitters No.6
instructions: 1. Build ingredients over ice in a Collins glass.
2. Top with tonic water and stir quickly to incorporate.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist and a fresh cardamom leaf.

title: My Loup’s Tuxedo No. 2
intro_philosophy: “Our team has been working on building a cocktail classics Rolodex of handwritten recipes that everyone can access during service,” says Jillian Moore, bar director at My Loup in Philadelphia. Putting the Tuxedo No. 2 on the list “was a two-birds-one-stone scenario,” she says. “It was a perfect addition to our summer menu, and I like to have a placement for a classic gin Martini, as they go so well with oysters and our cold seafood dishes.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce dry vermouth, preferably Dolin Blanc
3 spritzes absinthe, preferably Pernod Absinthe Supérieure
instructions: 1. Chill a glass with ice or water and set it aside.
2. In a separate mixing glass, combine all ingredients except absinthe over ice and stir until chilled.
3. Dump ice or water from the chilled glass, then spritz the glass with absinthe in an atomizer.
4. Pour the mixed drink into the glass, then finish with a cherry and expressed lemon peel.

title: Rabbit Szn
intro_philosophy: At R&D in Philadelphia, the most popular cocktail at the moment is “a bright and easy crowd-pleaser,” the Rabbit Szn. A mix of blanco tequila, lime juice and ginger syrup, the bestseller gets topped with club soda and a float of sweet vermouth from Fell to Earth, a local Philadelphia producer.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce blanco tequila, such as Teremana
1/2 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Fell to Earth, to float
instructions: 1. Add the first three ingredients to a shaker and whip-shake with a few ice cubes.
2. Strain into a Collins glass.
3. Top with club soda, add ice, then float sweet vermouth on top.
4. Garnish with a sprig of mint.

title: Bridgetown Negroni
intro_philosophy: This riff on aKingston Negroniswaps the expected Jamaican rum forcoconut rumfrom Barbados, putting an extra tropical spin on the drink. It takes its name from the hometown of the historic West Indies Rum Distillery, where Planteray is distilled. Because the rum has a small amount of added sugar, using a drier red bitter, such as St. George Bruto Americano or Forthave Red, in the equal-parts formula can help dry out the drink for anyone sensitive to sweetness.
ingredients: 1 ounce coconut rum, such as Planteray Cut & Dry
1 ounce red bitter, such as Bruto Americano or Forthave Red
1 ounce sweet vermouth, such as Dolin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.

title: Pinkies Out
intro_philosophy:
Gina Chersevani’s sophisticated variation on the classic Pink Lady omits grenadine in favor of bittersweet Campari instead.

This recipe also makes a great pitcher drink, she adds: “Do the same everything times eight, sans egg white. Put it over ice and it’s an incredible little punch.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake without ice until frothy.
2. Add ice and shake hard, until the sides of the tin are frosted over and the drink is super frothy.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Garnish with a pinch of zested orange rind.

title: Mezcal Margarita
intro_philosophy: Potent, piquant and perfectly balanced, this Margarita recipe comes from the now-shuttered bar Mayahuel. Trailblazing for being one of the first bars to champion mezcal, Mayahuel helped pave the way for the ascent of drinks like the Oaxaca Old-Fashioned and the mezcal Negroni. This simple recipe swaps tequila for mezcal for a smoky take on the original.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Leopold’s Grasshopper
intro_philosophy: “Grasshoppers and ice cream drinks of any kind are quite popular in Wisconsin,” says Sam Brown, owner of Leopold’s inMadison, Wisconsin. The bar’s take on the iconic cocktail adds Meletti Fernet—which Brown calls “the most wonderful, herbaceous and minty fernet on the market”—for a digestivo-like intrigue, while a duo of mint liqueurs brings layers of flavor into the dessert drink.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce crème de menthe, preferably Bols Green Crème de Menthe
1/2 ounce mint liqueur, preferably Giffard Menthe-Pastille liqueur
3/4 ounce crème de cacao, preferably Giffard white crème de cacao
5 scoops (about 1 1/2 cups) vanilla ice cream (Leopold’s uses a locally made gelato)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a milkshake glass and garnish with fresh mint.

title: Bunny Lebowski
intro_philosophy: A fruity drink at heart, the Bunny Lebowski, surprisingly, doesn’t contain any fresh fruit. Instead, Erick Castro conjures up those flavors with fruit-forward raspberry brandy, pisco and Aperol, all shaken with lemon and served on the rocks.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces pisco, preferably Campo De Encanto
1/4 ounce raspberry brandy, preferably St. George
instructions: 1. In a shaker tin, combine all ingredients and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a double Old-Fashioned glass over ice.
3. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

title: Winters in Wautoma
intro_philosophy:
Liz Pearce has a cabin in Wautoma, Wisconsin, where she enjoys drinks like this one. “This is the kind of thing I want to drink sitting in front of a fire up there, after snowshoeing,” she says. The rich, bitter, slightly spiced cocktail sees a base of Scotch mixed with amaro and vermouth, garnished with wintry cinnamon and a Manhattan-inspired cherry.

“From about December 10thto February 10th, I want to drink something like a Manhattan. The rest of the year, it’s Margaritas.”
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients and serve over rocks.
2. Garnish with a brandied cherry and a long cinnamon stick for stirring.

title: Session Dark ‘n’ Stormy
intro_philosophy:
In this low-proof spin on the two-ingredientDark ‘n’ Stormy, Amaro Montenegro plays the role of the base spirit while a hit of blackstrap rum delivers the familiar caramel notes of the original.

Reprinted with permission fromSession Cocktailsby Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Pour the rum, amaro and lime juice into a Collins glass filled with ice, then top with ginger beer.
2. Garnish with a lime wedge.

title: Margaladaoma Ice Pops
intro_philosophy:
Each year, culminating right around Cinco de Mayo, the drink-o-sphere gets even more saturated with an annual parade ofMargaritas,MicheladasandPalomas. But even better than each of these drinks on their own is a mixture of all three—aMargaladaoma, if you will—which is just as delicious frozen into a kicked-up popsicle as it is enjoyed in a glass.

With a frozen Michelada-inspired topper and a fresh grapefruit and tequila center, these adult Otter Pops offer a dose of savory heat by way of Mexican hot sauce and a tart-sweet finish via their candied lime base. They’ll require a bit of freezing time (and an order offlavor ice bags), but are otherwise easy to throw together, proving once again that #margaladaoma might just be the greatest thing to happen on May 5 since the Battle of Puebla.
ingredients: 10 ounces  fresh grapefruit juice (from one large grapefruit)
2 ounces lime simple syrup (see Editor's Note)
12 dashes  Mexican hot sauce, preferably Tapatío or Cholula
2 tablespoons candied lime segments (see Editor's Note)
1 ounce Mexican lager, preferably Sol, Corona or Pacifico
1/4 teaspoon lime simple syrup (see Editor's note)
1 dash Mexican hot sauce, preferably Tapatio or Cholula
instructions: 1. Make the marga-oma base: Stir together the grapefruit juice, tequila, lime simple syrup and hot sauce in a 2-cup liquid measuring glass.
2. Place six 3-ounce flavor ice bags inside a wide mouth glass or jar. Using a small funnel, pour 2 ounces of marga-oma base into each bag.
3. Divide the candied lime segments evenly between the bags and freeze until the pops are frozen, about 4 hours.
4. Make the lada base: Stir together the tomato juice, lager, worcestershire sauce, lime simple syrup and hot sauce in a 2-cup liquid measuring glass.

5. Stand the frozen pops in a wide mouth glass or jar and use a funnel to distribute the mixture evenly between the frozen bags, pouring it over the top of the marga-oma base. Freeze until almost frozen, about 1 hour.
6. Working one at a time, seal the flavor ice pop bags with a manual heat sealer or with rubber band. Store the pops in the freezer until completely frozen, about 3 hours more.
7. Trim the tops of the flavor ice bags before serving to remove the extra plastic.
8. To serve, cut the end off of the red lada base and sprinkle with kosher salt.

title: Go-To
intro_philosophy:
“Ginger beer has been called ketchup,” says Rob Krueger, meaning that it’s a dependably crowd-pleasing ingredient in the cocktail world. But that doesn’t make it any less delicious. Here, Krueger puts it alongside gin, cucumber, mint, and St-Germain—the original bartender’s ketchup. Variations on this drink have long been Krueger’s answer to requests for a refreshing gin or vodka drink that’s not too sweet or might have cucumber, etc. He mentioned this to a guest one night, to which she responded,“Oh, so it’s your go-to?”inspiring the cocktail’s name.

Reprinted with permission fromThe Essential Cocktail Book: A Complete Guide to Modern Drinks with 150 Recipes, Edited by Megan Krigbaum copyright 2017. Photographs by Daniel Krieger
instructions: 1. Combine gin, St-Germain, and lime juice in a Collins glass.
2. Add ice, then top with cucumber slices and mint.
3. “Cheat shake” by capping the glass with a small mixing tin and shaking briefly.
4. Top with ginger beer.
5. Garnish with fresh mint and cucumber wheels.

title: Barrymore Room
intro_philosophy: A former bartender at Brooklyn’sClover Club, Brad Farran created this variation on the bar’s namesake cocktail. “It’s essentially aClover Club, but reverse engineered with bourbon,” says Farran of his riff on the cocktail named for the men’s club who met at Philadelphia’s former Bellevue Stradford Hotel starting in the 1880s. In his version there is lime instead of lemon, and sweet vermouth subbed in for dry, while a bit of muddled strawberry is added to maintain the classic pink hue. The drink is cleverly named for the grand lobby of the hotel where the Clover Club met and partied like it was 1888.
instructions: 1. Muddle strawberry with simple syrup in the bottom of a cocktail shaker.
2. Add remaining ingredients and shake without ice.
3. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
4. Double straininto a chilled cocktail or coupe glass.

title: Pimm’s Cup #27
intro_philosophy: Styled for the autumn of 2019, this Pimm’s Cup is tricked out with plenty of cranberry and spice. The aged plum brandy is “super aromatic,” with a tinge of vanilla from barrel aging, says William Elliott, while sherry “gives it weight and mouthfeel.”
ingredients: 3/4 ounce plum brandy, preferably Louis Roque La Vielle Prune
1/4 ounce blueberry-black cardamom cordial (see Editor’s Note)
1 teaspoon Bittermens New England Cranberry bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda water.
4. Garnish with mint bouquet, blueberries, cardamom pods and cinnamon. Serve with a straw.

title: Seaside
intro_philosophy: An all-time favorite and one of the White Lyan’s classics, the Seaside is essentially a more savory take on the Paloma. Calling on yuzu syrup, sweetened with agave and glucose, the drink is bittered with lemon juice and lengthened with both soda and housemade “seaweed water.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the soda water, in a highball glass over ice.
2. Top with soda water.

title: Joy of Cooking‘s Gin Cocktail
intro_philosophy: “It might surprise casual readers of theJoy of Cookingto learn that the first recipe that appears in the first edition (published during Prohibition, in 1931) is for a juiced-up Gin Cocktail meant to mask the flavor of bathtub gin. It’s accompanied by a note that reads: “Most cocktails containing liquor are made today with gin and ingenuity. In brief, take an ample supply of the former and use your imagination.'” This is theJoy of Cooking‘s Prohibition-era gin and juice, updated for the modern home bartender.
instructions: 1. Prepare a rocks glass with a grapefruit section and lightly sprinkle it with sugar.
2. Add all ingredients together in a mixing glass and shake.
3. Strain over ice in the rocks glass.
4. "Serve with Hot Cream Cheese Canapés or some other appetizer."

title: Lemon & Cardamom Gimlet
intro_philosophy: In this batched Gimlet variation, Max Venning combines gin with a cordial made from lemon juice, lemon zest and crushed cardamom pods. “This involves an ancient method of flavor extraction known as an oleo saccharum, in which sugar pulls oils from citrus,” explains Venning. “Along with perfumed cardamom, it creates a delicate and easy-drinking Gimlet.”
ingredients: 8 ounces lemon and cardamom cordial (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a 30-ounce sterilized bottle.
2. Store in the freezer, where it will keep up to 6 months.
3. For an individual drink, pour into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Winter Mojito
intro_philosophy:
Our position on theMojitois that it need not be relegated to the warmer months. If you consider its simple combination of fresh herbs, sugar, citrus, rum, and soda water, it’s easy to slot in alternative herbs and a richer spirit for a winter revamp. In our cold-weather version we sub out white rum for rich, brooding blackstrap and mint for muddled rosemary.

Reprinted with permission fromWinter Drinksby the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, a division of Penguin Random House.
instructions: 1. Remove the stem from the sprig of the rosemary and combine with the simple syrup in a cocktail shaker. Use a muddler to lightly crush the rosemary and let sit for a few minutes.
2. Add the rum and lime juice. Add ice, shake, and pour through a finemesh strainer into a collins glass over ice.
3. Top with soda and garnish with a lime wheel and a sprig of rosemary.

title: Mint Julep
intro_philosophy: When done up properly, the Mint Julep can be a fussy drink—all crushed ice and fancy silver cup—which is exactly why it might be surprising that it packs such a punch. Essentially sweetened bourbon over ice with some mint for aromatics, the drink is one of the more powerful cocktails to be associated with contemporary day drinking—the association, of course, owing much to the Kentucky Derby, where 120,000 juleps are said to be sold every year. Skip over the trappings though, and you’ll find an all-American drink with roots dating back to 18thcentury. The exact origins and recipe have no doubt inspired countless dissertation, but, in short, it most likely originated in Virginia in the late 1700s when it was considered an aristocratic drink. (Who else could afford silver tins and a coveted block of ice used simply for crushing?) The drink spread throughout the South during the first half of the 19thcentury, eventually becoming the“Coca-Cola of its time,” as William Grimes calls it in hisStraight Up or On the Rocks. Bourbon became the preferred spirit only after the Civil War, when the South was impoverished and, thanks to phylloxera, brandy had all but disappeared.
tags: Straight Up or On the Rocks
instructions: 1. In a julep tin or rocks glass, muddle the mint sprig with simple syrup by gently pressing to release the oils.
2. Pack the glass with finely crushed ice.
3. Pour bourbon over ice, and mound more ice into the top of the glass.
4. Garnish with a bouquet of spanked mint.

title: Tierra Verde
intro_philosophy: Molly Gajdosik,assistant manager atGigantic, likes to create drinks that don’t take themselves too seriously. Having been drawn into bartending by tiki drinks, they often turn to tropical flavors in their own creations. Inspired by a passion fruit matcha fizz served at a local coffee shop, Gajdosik brought those two flavors together, along with mezcal, coconut rum and lime juice. “It took a lot of trial and error before I landed on what I [was] looking for.” The result is, in their words, “definitely unconventional.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces mezcal, such as Del Maguey Vida
1 1/2 ounces passion fruit syrup (4:1, passion fruit purée to rich simple syrup)
1 1/2 ounces coconut matcha (16 ounces coconut water blended with 12 grams powdered matcha)
1/2 ounce coconut rum, such as Planteray Cut & Dry
1/2 ounce cream of coconut, such as Coco Lopez
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
3. Dump into an oversized tall glass and top with pebble ice (or cubed or cracked ice).
4. Garnish with mint.

title: Jam Session
intro_philosophy: This effervescent large-format cocktail “has the sort of bracing acidity you can’t quite get enough of,” according to Natasha David. Calling on ginger kombucha and watermelon juice, the drink is piquant and refreshing.
instructions: 1. In a pitcher filled halfway with ice, add all ingredients.
2. Top with more ice.
3. Stir to chill and incorporate ingredients.
4. Garnish the pitcher with cucumber slices.

title: Iz Bananaz
intro_philosophy: At first glance, this mix of funky cachaça and bittersweet Amaro Montenegro seems like an odd combination, but they blend together seamlessly when shaken up with the sweet and sour notes of toasty banana liqueur and lemon juice. Extra Fancy’s Rob Krueger loves a whimsical garnish, so he tops this Brazilian cooler with a feathered orange peel.
ingredients: 1 dash Hella Aromatic Bitters (or 1 dash Angostura)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a crazy orange peel.

title: Solitude Is Bliss
intro_philosophy:
According to Chris Bostick, “Bianco vermouth is perfect for that moment when you want to dial down the bitter and enjoy something softer and a bit more floral… We also like to use it with fresh ruby red grapefruit juice and seltzer water for a refreshing mid-day sipper.”

The Solitude Is Bliss takes that ethos a few steps further with the additions of herbaceous gin and floral chamomile, resulting in a balanced, refreshing cooler.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bianco vermouth , preferably Dolin Blanc
1 ounce fresh grapefruit juice, preferably from a Red Ruby
1/4 ounce chamomile syrup (1:1 chamomile tea and sugar)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin, add a small amount of ice and shake.
2. Pour into a Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Top with seltzer water and stir to incorporate.
4. Garnish with wedge of grapefruit lightly dusted with small amount of salt.

title: Snake Eyes
intro_philosophy: Inspired by the Caribbean combo of blended Scotch and coconut, the Snake Eyes from Grand Army Bar swaps in smoky mezcal in lieu of whisky and adds a teaspoon of banana liqueur for an extra tropical kick.
ingredients: 2 ounces organic coconut water, such as Harmless Harvest
1 1/2 ounces mezcal, such as Agave de Cortés Espadín
1/2 ounce cane syrup, such as JM Sirop de Canne
1 teaspoon banana liqueur, such as Tempus Fugit
instructions: 1. Salt the rim of a large rocks glass.
2. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker, add ice, then shake until chilled.
3. Fine-strain into the large rocks glass filled with ice.

title: Blue Angel
intro_philosophy: Originally written to include blue curaçao and Parfait Amour—often simply an imitation version of Crème de Violette—this recipe looked like a smurf’s breakfast shake and tasted like a melted popsicle. With a few ingredient swaps, however—Cointreau for blue curaçao, Crème de Violette for the Parfait Amour—Tristan Willey of Brooklyn’s Long Island Bar has turned it into a charmingly retro after-dinner drink.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaking tin and shake well with ice.
2. Strain into a pre-chilled cocktail glass.

title: Billy Sunday’s Blackthorn
intro_philosophy:
Sloe gin is “definitely a product that went down the dark rabbit hole of poorly-made liquors for a long time,” says Alex Bachman of Chicago’s Billy Sunday. But,“when made correctly, it’s a fantastic ingredient that has a long history in classic cocktails, and can add really dark blue fruit character and a brambly greenness.”

Bachman incorporates it into this bergamot bitters-spiked riff on the traditional Blackthorn at Billy Sunday, made with either a California-produced sloe gin or, when feeling ambitious, one the bar infuses in-house.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  sloe gin, preferably Spirit Works
2 to 3 dashes bergamot bitters, preferably Willett
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and add ice.
2. Stir until chilled and strain into a chilled rocks glass.
3. Express orange peel and discard.

title: Penca’s Tepache
intro_philosophy:
Walk down a bustling city street in one of Mexico’s major cities and it won’t be long before you run into a street vendor peddling a curious lineup of Technicolor beverages from industrial-sized plastic containers. Within these jugs one can find an array ofaguas frescas—from horchata to tamarindo—but most interesting istepache, a tangy, fermented beverage whose alcohol content places it outside the realm of fruit juice. It’s a staple on the streets of Mexico and has been consumed and produced all over the country since pre-Columbian times. Corn was the original base ingredient for the drink up until at least the early 1500s (hence the nametepache, which comes from the nahuatl wordtapiatlmeaning “drink made from corn”), but today it’s most commonly made with pineapple flesh and rinds, invigorated with cinnamon, clove and other spices, and sweetened withpiloncillo(Mexican brown sugar).

At Penca, in Tucson, Arizona, the housetepacheis made with whole overripe pineapples, cloves, allspice and a finisher of Mexican beer and brown sugar. The result is a pungent, tangy version perfect for mixing with beer or into a stronger cocktail like Brian Eichhorst’sBourbon and Tepache.
instructions: 1. Cut crowns and butts from the pineapple. Leave the rest of the skin.
2. Roughly cube pineapple.
3. In a 6-quart food-safe container, add pineapple (with leaves and skins), spices and enough water to fill the remaining space.
4. Cover partially, leaving lid slightly ajar and put in a warm place for 3 days.
5. After three days, add beer and sugar.
6. Close and let sit for two more days.
7. Strain off solids and add more sugar to taste.
8. Refrigerate. Bottle if desired, but "burp" (open to release pressure) regularly.

title: Marguerite
intro_philosophy:
A forebear of the dry Martini, the first-recorded recipe for the Marguerite appears in the 1900 edition of Harry Johnson’s New and Improved Bartender’s Manual. Although a part of the story of the dry Martini, it is still quite sweet with its 1-to-1 gin-to–dry vermouth ratio, not to mention the inclusion of anisette, a potent and sweet liqueur.

By 1903, Daly’s Bartenders’ Encyclopedia was still calling for Italian (sweet) vermouth in its Martini. However, in that same book, the Marguerite cocktail stipulates the use of French, and therefore dry, vermouth, showing the importance of this cocktail in the evolution of the Martini.

Just one year later, in the 1904 edition of Stuart’s Fancy Drinks and How to Mix Them, the orange curaçao is absent from the Marguerite, making it the first prominent cocktail recipe to omit a sweetener while simultaneously making a dry gin the star. “I may, of course, be biased here,” claims Plymouth’s Global Brand Ambassador, Sebastian Hamilton-Mudge, “however, it wouldseem that Plymouth Gin certainly had the style and qualities that bartenders were looking for to finally let go of sugar, put gin in the limelight, and make a truly light and dry cocktail.”

These three recipes show the significance of the Marguerite cocktail in the evolution toward a dry-style Martini. The original ingredients for each version here show how Hamilton-Mudge adapted the recipes to use modern-day Plymouth Gin. He used corenwyn to compensate for the sweet ingredients used in those early incarnations.
ingredients: 1 part dry vermouth, preferably Dolin de Chambéry Dry Vermouth
1 dash orange bitters, preferably Bitter Truth Orange Bitters
instructions: 1. Stir all the ingredients together in a mixing glass with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

title: Charles Dickens’s Punch
intro_philosophy: There are few things that are more Dickensian than a bowl of punch. A great lover of drink, Dickens wove spirits into his writing repeatedly and even conceived of his own punch, whose recipe he included in a letter to a friend, writing that it might make her “for ninety years…a beautiful Punchmaker in more senses than one.” A cheek-warming mix of cognac, rum, citrus and sugar, Dickens required this recipe to “cook” by setting the spirit mix on fire. We urge you to take care with this step to avoid any singed eyebrows.
ingredients: heat proof bowl or enameled cast-iron pot
instructions: 1. In the basin of an enameled cast-iron pot or heatproof bowl, add sugar and the peels of three lemons.
2. Rub lemons and sugar together to release citrus oils. For more greater infusion, let sit for 30 minutes.
3. Add rum and cognac to the sugar and citrus.
4. Light a match, and, using a heatproof spoon (stainless steel is best), pick up a spoonful of the spirit mix.
5. Carefully bring the match to the spoon to light.
6. Carefully bring the lit spoon to the spirits in the bowl.
7. Let the spirits burn for about three minutes. The fire will melt the sugar and extract the oil from the lemon peels.
8. Extinguish the bowl by covering it with a heatproof pan or tray.
9. Skim off the lemon peels (leaving them too long in may impart a bitter flavor).
10. Squeeze in the juice of the three peeled lemons, and add hot tea or water.
11. If serving the punch hot, skip to the next step. If serving cold, cool punch in the refrigerator and, when cooled, add ice.
12. Garnish with citrus wheels and grated nutmeg.
13. Ladle into individual glasses.

title: Jeff “Beachbum” Berry’s Passionfruit Syrup
intro_philosophy: Jeff “Beachbum” Berrynames passionfruit syrup as one of his essential backbar staples, but advises against using commercial passion fruit juice in the recipe, preferring instead to combine equal parts frozen passionfruit pulp and simple syrup.
ingredients: 1 part frozen 100% passionfruit pulp, preferably Goya, El Sembrador or La Fé
instructions: 1. Allow the frozen passionfruit pulp to defrost.
2. Combine with simple syrup in a sealable container and refrigerate until use.

title: De La Louisiane
intro_philosophy:
This deep, boozy number goes by other names, including La Louisiane and Cocktail à la Louisiane. And the recipe varies. Traditionally, it’s equal parts rye, Bénédictine and sweet vermouth—a simple ratio that can skew syrupy-sweet. In this version, fromThe PDT Cocktail Book, the amount of rye is upped to cut the saccharine notes. Dashes of Peychaud’s bitters and absinthe add spicy and earthy notes, and blend the ingredients seamlessly.

As its French-inflected name hints, it’s a New Orleans creation. In his authoritative 1937 bookFamous New Orleans Drinks and How to Mix ‘Em, Stanley Clisby Arthur notes that it was the Restaurant La Louisiane’s house cocktail, where it presumably paired well with the rich, sometimes fiery Creole cuisine.

Reprinted with permission fromThe PDT Cocktail Book© 2011 by Jim Meehan, Sterling Epicure an imprint of Sterling Publishing Co., Inc.
tags: Famous New Orleans Drinks and How to Mix 'Em
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
4. Garnish with three brandied cherries.

title: Peninsula Cobbler
intro_philosophy: At Voysey in Portland, Oregon, Katie Stipe’s Sherry Cobbler riff incorporates oat orgeat, a more sustainable and easier-to-make alternative to the traditionally almond-based ingredient. A finishing spritz of rose water echoes the floral notes of the syrup, tying the low-proof drink all together.
ingredients: 3 ounces dry amontillado sherry, preferably Lustau Amontillado Los Arcos
instructions: 1. Muddle orange slices in oat orgeat.
2. Add sherry.
3. Short shake with 2 to 3 ice cubes, then fine-strain over cobbled ice into a highball glass.
4. Garnish with 2 to 3 sprays of rose water and a crushed rosebud.

title: Suppressor #1280
intro_philosophy: Alex Jump’s Suppressor-style cocktail, traditionally made without any high-proof spirits, honors the Southern bartenders she learned from when coming up in the industry. A combination of liqueurs and vermouth kicked up with citrus, it’s a low-ABV summertime refresher that cuts a middle path between bitter and floral.
ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water in a mixing tin filled with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a wine glass filled with ice.
3. Top with chilled Fever-Tree Refreshingly Light Cucumber Tonic Water.
4. Garnish with a cucumber wheel and orange zest.

title: Sherry Colada Highball
intro_philosophy: Low-proof and easy-drinking, theSherry Colada Highballserved upstairs at the bilevel bar Sip & Guzzle is like aRebujitoon a tropical vacation, the sort of unfussy, deeply satisfying drink that works any time of day or night. For the drink’s creator, Steve Schneider, it’s as perfect in a bar setting as it is lounging at home. “It’s what I drink when playing video games,” he says. “I can get a buzz, but still see the bad guys.”
ingredients: 1 part cream sherry, such as Harveys Bristol Cream sherry
2 parts coconut-pineapple seltzer, such as Bubly
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a highball glass over a piece of spear ice.

title: Aperol Spritz
intro_philosophy: Aperol, the classic Italian bitter liqueur from Padua, provides the base for this iconicaperitivodrink. A simple combination of three parts Prosecco, two parts Aperol and one splash of soda water, the Aperol Spritz is an outright phenomenon in Italy. It has also made significant inroads in America, where riffs on its bitter, bubbly, low-alcohol formula have proliferated.
instructions: 1. Add cubed ice to a stemmed wine glass.
2. Add Prosecco, Aperol and soda and gently stir to combine.
3. Garnish with an orange half-wheel.

title: Jim Kearns’ Cinnamon Syrup
intro_philosophy: Cinnamon syrup is one of the simplest ways to up the flavor ante in just about any formula, whether it be winterizing a summer classic like theDaiquiri, or adding warm baking spice notes to a tiki staple like theJungle Bird.In his house recipe, Jim Kearns opts for cassia in place of true cinnamon. “Cinnamon stickswill also work for this,” he explains, “but…I like cassia, because it’s a little mellower and more complex.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a saucepan and bring to a boil.
2. Stir until sugar is dissolved.
3. Lower the heat to 180 degrees, cover the saucepan and let simmer for two minutes.
4. Remove the saucepan from the heat and let sit for at least 24 hours.
5. Strain into a sealable container and use within two weeks.

title: Bar Americano’s Negroni
intro_philosophy: At Brooklyn’sBar Americano, the house Negroni upgrades the classic template with a few thoughtful tweaks. One is an orange peel–infused vermouth, which adds oils and aromatics, and another is a bespoke saline solution—a mix of sodium chloride, magnesium chloride, calcium chloride and sodium bicarbonate—that the bar dashes into the drink. At Bar Americano, the Negroni is pre-batched, but this recipe is for a single serve.
ingredients: 1 ounce orange peel–infused vermouth (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir with ice.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
3. Garnish with an orange wedge.

title: Nudie Beach
intro_philosophy: In his Nudie Beach, Brian Griffiths of Miami’s Broken Shaker accentuates the floral quality of St-Germain with fresh melon notes in the form of housemade honeydew syrup. A dash of rosewater brightens things up, while tart passion fruit cools the sweet spice of ginger for a tall, refreshing and balanced daytime sidekick.
ingredients: 1/4 ounce passion fruit puree, preferably Boiron
instructions: 1. Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker.
2. Shake and strain into a pilsner glass and fill with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with candied ginger and mint.

title: Counterpoint
intro_philosophy: “An Espresso Martini can change the trajectory of your night, and the older I get, the earlier I tend to drink mine,” says Lauren Corriveau. Her Espresso Martini riff, the Counterpoint, introduces tonic, reminiscent of the classic café combination of espresso and tonic. Cold-brew concentrate combined with a split base of Rémy Martin 1738 Accord Royal and bittersweet Italian vermouth Punt e Mes mixes the flavors of dark cherry, chocolate and orange notes with the fruity, oaked qualities of the Cognac. Corriveau advises to spare no expense when it comes to the espresso element. “Remember, the Espresso Martini is named for the coffee for a reason,” she says.
ingredients: 1 ounce  freshly brewed espresso or cold-brew concentrate
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice, and briefly shake to chill.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over ice cubes.
3. Top with tonic water and garnish with an orange wedge.

title: Angostura Colada
intro_philosophy: A new wave of “coladas” have begun to crop up in several Brooklyn bars where tiki and tropical drinks aren’t the dominant cocktail style, but persist as cult favorites. At the now-closed café Fort Defiance, the Angostura Colada became a favorite at the bar’s weekly tiki night. Based on the structure of a traditional Piña Colada (rum, pineapple and coconut), Zac Overman’s riff replaces most of the rum with spicy Angostura bitters. A bit of lime and overproof rum smooth out and balance the lip curling bitters, while pineapple and cream of coconut maintain the Piña’s tropical spirit.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Pour shaker contents into a snifter and fill with crushed ice.
4. Stir gently and garnish with an orange slice, pineapple leaves and freshly grated nutmeg.

title: Finding Peggy
intro_philosophy: “I love the combination of Dubonnet and Pastis,” says Ezra Star of Drink in Boston. “Each one brings out something unexpected in the other.” Based on the Peggy cocktail, a two-to-one Martini improved with a touch of pastis and Dubonnet from the 1935Mr. Boston,Ezra Star’s Finding Peggy brings Dubonnet front and center. “I wanted to take this combination and flip it on its head,” says Star. She means that literally: Star doubles the aperitif and reduces the gin by half. Spicy dry vermouth underscores the Dubonnet, which plays up the floral, anise quality of pastis.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass or coupette.

title: Lost Lake’s Mai Tai (2018 version)
intro_philosophy: An update to Lost Lake’s2015 take on the classic, this version employs much higher-proof rum for extra flavor and punch. It also adds a lime hull to the shaker, a technique Trader Vic used in his 1944 classic, which releases extra lime oils into the drink.
ingredients: 1 ounce rhum agricole, preferably Neisson Eleve Sous Bois Rhum Agricole
1/2 ounce overproof Jamaican rum, preferably Smith and Cross
1/2 ounce Jamaican rum, preferably Plantation Xamayca
1 ounce lime juice, plus the spent hull
3/4 ounce orgeat, preferably Small Hand Foods
instructions: 1. Using a hand squeezer, hand squeeze lime juice and drop the hull into mixing tin.
2. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with 4 Kold Draft ice cubes.
3. Pour into a Mai Tai glass.
4. Top with an additional 1 cup of crushed ice.
5. Garnish with big mint bouquet, orange floret, orchid, swizzle stick and straw.

title: Treasure Chest
intro_philosophy:
“Drinking low-ABV cocktails enables you to be more social, and in the winter time when it’s dark and cold, engaging with others is super important,” says Nitecap’s Natasha David. In her low-proof Treasure Chest, the cranberry notes of gamay (David uses one that’s organic and unfiltered, but advises that any dry and red fruit-forward bottle will do) and herbaceous Lillet pair with spicy chai-infused sherry and cinnamon syrup, for a holiday-season-ready cocktail that’s a delicious cross between Lambrusco and mulled wine.

Of it, she says, “It’s important that the flavors are comforting and warming, and still sort of have the illusion of a ‘real’ cocktail.”
ingredients: 1 ounce chai tea-infused oloroso sherry  (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for sparkling wine, in a mixing glass with ice and stir.
2. Strain into a wine glass and top with sparkling wine.

title: Gunmetal Fix
intro_philosophy: “Mezcal was always seen as a smoke bomb and a really aggressive flavor,” says Mary Palac, “and every time you see it in a drink it’s usually in a spicy Margarita; I wanted to try something a little more delicate.” Inspired by Dick Bradsell’s modern classic, the Bramble, Palac achieves a similarly craveable combination of agave spirit, lemon juice and pineapple gum syrup. It’s topped with a float of violet liqueur, which gives it the gunmetal-gray appearance that inspired the name. “I remember smelling the mezcal and thinking immediately of flowers, so I tried it with the violet [liqueur],” she says.
ingredients: 1 3/4 ounces mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida
3/4 ounce pineapple gum syrup, preferably Small Hand Foods
2 dashes rhubarb bitters, preferably Fee Brothers
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except violet liqueur, in a double rocks glass over crushed ice.
2. Stir to integrate.
3. Top with violet liqueur.
4. Garnish with lemon wheel.

title: “Orange Wine”
intro_philosophy: This cocktail takes its cues from the Futurist Mixology movement, an offshoot of the Italian Futurist art movement, which was often less about ingredients and more about expectations—or rather, the unexpected. In this case, the surprising element is the drink’s ability to masquerade as a style of white wine often referred to as “orange,” thanks to its slight oxidation and time spent macerating on the skins. The mixture of the slightly bitter Contratto Bianco, oxidized Carpano Antica and savory Strega, as well as a dash of tangerine juice for acidity, mimic the flavor and color of orange wine, while prosecco adds freshness.
instructions: 1. In a wine glass filled with ice, add all ingredients except prosecco and stir gently.
2. Top with prosecco, and stir.
3. Garnish with three Aperol-soaked white grapes (see Editor's Note) arranged on a skewer.

title: Cape Cod Margarita
intro_philosophy: For this mashup, food and cocktail scientist Dave Arnold uses a technique called the “juice shake.” He combines all the drink’s ingredients except the orange juice, and freezes that mixture, yielding slushier cubes; for home use, he recommends freezing only the cranberry. “It can be done either way essentially, for whatever mood you are in,” he says. Of note, the OJ is not frozen; it adds welcome texture to the drink, Arnold says.
ingredients: 2 ounces unsweetened cranberry juice, frozen into two 1-ounce cubes
3/4 ounce mezcal, preferably Del Maguey Vida (tequila may be substituted, if preferred)
7 drops 20% saline solution (1:5 salt to water; alternately, just add a pinch of salt)
2 "hard ice" cubes (two 1-ounce cubes of frozen water)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients until the cubes dissolve. “You’ll hear the cube break up, and it will almost all be gone,” Arnold notes.
2. Pour into chilled coupe glass.

title: Hanky
intro_philosophy: New and experimental drag, techno music and house drinks fill the space at queer multiclub compound Kremwerk + Timbre Room Complex. The Hanky, one of the club’s signature drinks, takes inspiration from the Prohibition-era Hanky Panky (Fernet-Branca, gin and sweet vermouth) and adds soda and grapefruit for a refreshing twist.
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, combine first four ingredients with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Top with soda water.

title: Añejo Highball
intro_philosophy: Amid the apple- and lychee-flavored ‘tinis that defined the ’90s emerged a more muted class of cocktails that had a lasting impact on bartending methods around the world. The Añejo Highball was among this class, offering a lesson in restraint in its simple combination of rum, Curaçao, lime juice and ginger beer.
instructions: 1. In a highball glass filled with ice, add the rum, Curaçao, lime juice and Angostura bitters.
2. Top with ginger beer.
3. Garnish with a lime wheel and an orange slice.

title: Just a Really Good Sazerac
intro_philosophy: In his Sazerac, Houston’s Matthew Tanner focuses on elevating the Knob Creek Rye and Peychaud’s notes. This riff on the Sazerac has no bells and whistles, but rather a new sweetener. The combination of turbinado and light brown sugar amps up Knob Creek®Rye’s burnt caramel and maple syrup notes, making this a very barrel-forward cocktail.
ingredients: ¼ part  dark sugar syrup(see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir.
2. Using an atomizer filled with absinthe, spritz a rocks glass.
3. Strain into glass.
4. Express a lemon twist and garnish.

title: Nancy Whang’s Pimm’s Cup
intro_philosophy: While on the road, LCD Soundsystem was always prepared with a mobile bar perpetually stocked with Champagne and Jameson. In the warm months, Pimm’s Cups were a band staple. “I can’t remember where I had my first Pimm’s Cup, but I remember liking it so much I bought a few bottles from duty free on my way home and spent the rest of the summer drinking them,” says former member Nancy Whang. “Then LCD went on tour in the UK and made sure we had all the ingredients on our rider.
