It took me a while to figure out that when the British say ‘lemonade’ they mean ‘7UP.’ I had been making them with American-style lemonade the whole time and I think it’s better that way. If you can’t find lemonade, try ginger beer before you reach for the 7UP, because who drinks 7UP?”
ingredients: 3 ounces lemonade (Whang likes Newman's Own or subs in ginger beer in a pinch)
instructions: 1. In a Collins glass, add Pimm's, lemonade and ice.
2. Top with soda water.
3. Garnish with a cucumber slice. Add orange slices, mint and strawberries if desired.

title: Attaboy’s Dark ’n’ Stormy
intro_philosophy: “It’s our version of a Dark ’n’ Stormy, if we were making the ginger beer ourselves,” says Attaboy proprietor Sam Ross. The key ingredient in this updated highball is fresh-pressed ginger juice, which remains “nice and spicy” for up to two days, but loses intensity after that, he notes.
ingredients: 2 ounces black rum, preferably Goslings Black Seal
3/4 ounce sweetened ginger juice (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Whip-shake the first three ingredients with a small handful of crushed ice, until you can no longer hear the ice in the tin.
2. Open the tin and pour in the club soda.
3. Pour the drink into a chilled Collins glass over an ice spear.
4. Garnish with candied ginger. Serve with a metal straw.

title: Harrison Ginsberg’s White Negroni
intro_philosophy: The unanimous winner in our blind White Negroni tasting, Harrison Ginsberg’s recipe combines equal parts gin and Cocchi Americano with a smaller measure of Suze–for the requisite “gentian punch,” as Toby Cecchini described it—and a teaspoon of verjus blanc for a bright boost. The combination of ingredients presented a fresh green pepper quality that was unexpected but not unwelcome, and still held true to the aperitivo nature of the original White Negroni.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon verjus blanc, preferably Fusion Napa Valley Verjus Blanc
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Pretty Decent’s Carajillo
intro_philosophy: At Pretty Decent, a mezcal-focused bar in Louisville, Kentucky, co-owner John Douglass spikes its carajillo with Alma Tepec, a smoked chile liqueur from Oaxaca. “I find it less sweet than other chile liqueurs, allowing us to best manage the overall balance of a drink,” he say. “I like the slight hint of smoke and earthiness that it adds to the cocktail.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce hazelnut cinnamon syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.

title: Celery Gimlet
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Shake and strain on fresh ice into a rocks glass.
3. Garnish with a celery stick and a lime wheel.

title: Heat Island Effect
intro_philosophy: This drink is inspired by a phenomenon Bingham learned about in her sustainability studies: the urban heat island effect, in which cities experience higher heat levels than surrounding natural areas. Bingham set out to highlight Sonoran Desert ingredients that could be threatened by rising temperatures around Phoenix. “I just kind of wanted to put Arizona in a glass,” she says. Dry and spicy with a hint of sweetness, the sage-touched aromas evoke the smell of the desert.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce  Desert Bloom cordial (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 ounce palo verde honey syrup (see Editor’s Note)
6 drops  wolfberry chiltepín tincture (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Rub the rim of a coupe glass with a sage leaf and reserve for garnish. Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and fill with ice. Shake hard until chilled.
2. Double-strain into the prepared coupe glass. Garnish with a sage leaf, and accent with orange flower water.

title: Judgement of Paris
intro_philosophy: Paul MacDonald, of Philadelphia’s Friday Saturday Sunday, uses the tropical tradition of floating bitters to create a drink with a “temperate-zone tiki” vibe. His calvados swizzle, the Judgement of Paris, blends the French apple brandy with Cocchi di Torino, lemon and rich Demerara syrup, topped with a generous dose of Angostura bitters and garnished with a cilantro sprig.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Cocchi Vermouth di Torino
1/2 ounce rich Demerara syrup (2:1 Demerara sugar:water)
instructions: 1. Combine all but the bitters in a snifter.
2. Fill with pellet ice and swizzle.
3. Top with a generous dose of Angostura bitters.
4. Garnish with a sprig of cilantro.

title: Use Your Illusion I.5
intro_philosophy: When the pandemic forced The Rockwell Place to temporarily close, cases of beer were left unrefrigerated and therefore unusable. Bartender Alex Kveton devised a sustainable solution: beer syrup, which now has a home in three cocktails on the bar’s menu. Use Your Illusion I.5 plays on the aroma from the Huell Melon hops used in Perennial’s saison, complementing it with cantaloupe syrup.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce Cognac, preferably H by Hine
1 bar spoon ginger syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Fine-strain into a coupe.
3. Garnish with a melon ball on a pick.

title: The Smillie
intro_philosophy: Named after chef Justin Smillie at the restaurant Upland in New York, the cocktail it is a dazzling rainbow of a drink. The tangy-savory blend of tequila, lime juice and agave syrup infused with golden beets, ginger and turmeric is given a striking visual accent in the form of a half-and-half rim of golden turmeric salt and red beet salt.
ingredients: 2 ounces blanco tequila, preferably Olmeca Altos
3/4 ounce golden beet, turmeric and ginger agave syrup  (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Moisten the rim of a rocks glass with lime.
2. Rim one half of the glass in turmeric salt and the other half in beet salt.
3. Combine the rest of the ingredients in a shaking tin, add ice and shake until chilled.
4. Fine strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

title: Erik Adkins’ Whiskey Sour
intro_philosophy: Erik Adkins’ restrained recipe for the Whiskey Sour earned it the second spot in our recent blind tasting of nearly 20 takes on the classic cocktail. According to panelistKaren Fu, “This is what you think of as a traditional Whiskey Sour.”
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients to the a mixing tin, and dry shake.
2. Add four Kold Draft ice cubes to the tin, and shake until chilled.
3. Fine strain into a coupe.

title: Matador
intro_philosophy: Riffing on the Trader Vic’s version of the Matador, this drink takes a couple of unusual turns, adding green Chartreuse for a herbal variation served as a refreshing highball.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a Mexican cantarito [a clay jug] or highball glass.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated pineapple and lime, and a grinding of pink peppercorns.

title: Averna Limonata
intro_philosophy: This sparkling Sicilian highball is in season any time of year, blending the bright citrus notes of Averna with fresh lemon juice for a light, refreshing take on a bittersweet aperitivo.
instructions: 1. Add Averna, lemon juice and simple syrup to a chilled Collins glass filled with crushed ice.
2. Stir or swizzle to combine.
3. Top with chilled soda water, adding more crushed ice if needed.
4. Garnish with fresh seasonal herbs, such as mint, rosemary or sage.

title: Culture to Culture
intro_philosophy: Bartender Derek Stilmann explores his love for fermentation through this gin-based cocktail that’s loosely inspired by a traditional Indian mango lassi. Kefir, a fermentable yogurt, takes on a strong herbal, piney expression when muddled with juniper berries, reflecting one of the primary characteristics of the gin. The pronounced dried fruit of the verjus plays off honey infused with angelica root, a binding agent that connects flavors and suffuses the drink with earthy notes and floral aromatics. Another fermented ingredient, mango kombucha, lends fizzy texture and complex tropical fruit notes.
ingredients: 3/4 parts  Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Ambrato vermouth
3/4 parts kefir yogurt with juniper berries (see Editor’s Note)
1/2 parts  angelica root honey (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients except the mango kombucha into a shake and fill with ice. Throw seven times from tin to tin to get dilution, chill and aeration.
2. Pour into stemmed wine glass over a sphere ice cube for minimal dilution and add mango kombucha.
3. Mix with a spoon slightly, just enough to blend the kombucha with the rest of the ingredients.
4. Garnish the rim with sugar–angelica root powder blend.

title: Swim Up Bar
intro_philosophy: A classic Tom Collins takes a trip to the tropics with this juicy highball. Ginger beer, with its natural affinity for tropical fruit and Jamaican rum, gives the final drink a spicy twist. “A nice hack for this drink is to prime the glass with the ginger beer [and] pour the shaken drink over … instead of topping off,” says Devin Kennedy. “The carbonation will incorporate all the ingredients naturally.”
ingredients: 2 ounces Ten To One Caribbean White Rum
1 ounce  mango nectar (preferably Jumex or Goya)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except the ginger beer in a mixing tin and lightly shake with ice.
2. Pour the ginger beer into a tall Collins glass over ice.
3. Strain the contents of the shaker over the ginger beer.
4. Garnish with a piece of candied ginger and a fresh mint sprig.

title: Rum Flip
intro_philosophy: “The original tavern flip of rum and beer gradually evolved,” writesMartin CateinSmuggler’s Cove. “Egg was added, then beer dropped altogether from the mix.” This is a Smuggler’s Cove adaptation of a classic, originally seen inHow To Mix Drinks, or the Bon-Vivant’s Companion, that illustrates how flash blending whips up egg-based cocktails to frothy perfection.
instructions: 1. Add the ingredients to drink mixer tin and dry flash without ice for 10 seconds.
2. Fill with 12 ounces of crushed ice and 4 to 6 small “agitator” cubes.
3. Flash blend and double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
4. Garnish with  freshly grated nutmeg.

title: The Revenant
intro_philosophy: In stirred drinks, Pamplemousse can add body and texture without pumping up a drink’s ABV. Here, the grapefruit liqueur stands up to three hard-hitting ingredients: blackstrap rum, overproof brandy and amaro. An amalgamation of many of Shae Minnillo’s obsessions over the years, the stirred combination of fruity and bitter makes for an unexpectedly balanced drink.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir.
2. Strain into a stemmed cocktail glass.
3. Express orange peel over the surface and discard.

title: Pomada
intro_philosophy: This version ofthe Menorcan stapleis made using only fresh lemonade, rather than lemon juice and lemon soda. It uses slightly less gin than the standard ratio (one part gin to three parts lemonade or lemon soda) to make it even easier-drinking on a hot summer day—increase if desired. Taste before freezing and add more sugar or lemon juice if needed. For an easier version, rather than freezing, simply chill the mixture and serve over ice cubes. When serving on the rocks, reduce the amount of water in the recipe a touch.
ingredients: a few whole fresh mint leaves
6 tablespoons  sugar, or more as needed
3/4 cup (180 ml) fresh lemon juice (from about 3 ripe lemons)
3/4 cup (180 ml)  gin, preferably Xoriguer gin
instructions: 1. Stuff the mint leaves into an empty 1.5-liter plastic water bottle.
2. Add the sugar, lemon juice and gin.
3. Tighten the lid and vigorously shake to start dissolving the sugar.
4. Add about 2 1/2 cups (600 ml) water, replace the lid, and vigorously shake again.
5. Taste and adjust the sugar or lemon juice if needed.
6. Put in the freezer overnight until frozen, shaking from time to time in the beginning to ensure that the sugar dissolves.
7. Remove from the freezer an hour or two before serving. Carefully cut the bottle in half and put the frozen pomada in a bowl. As it thaws, break up and mash with a fork.
8. When slushy, serve in small glasses.

title: Misi’s Negroni Sour
intro_philosophy: A staple of Brooklyn’s Misi, this recipe turnsthe aperitivo iconinto a fluffy sour thanks to a hit of both orange and lemon juices as well as an egg white for the requisite froth. Central to the drink’s makeup is a house red bitter blend that adds layered complexity beyond what a single expression could provide.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker then dry shake without ice to combine.
2. Add ice, and shake vigorously.
3. Strain into a coupe glass.

title: Fancy Free
intro_philosophy: TheFancy Freeis essentially an Improved Whiskey Cocktail, originally calling for Canadian whisky, that dates to the World War II era. It was first published in Crosby Gaige’sCocktail Guide and Ladies’ Companion(1941) and somehow made its way into the D List canon of the cocktail renaissance. Consultant and industry veteran Jeremy Oertel has been keeping it in his back pocket for the past 15 years and continues to offer it and its variations for guests who want a twist on an Old-Fashioned. It’s currently on the menu at Simmer Down in Wilmington, Delaware.
ingredients: 2 ounces bourbon, preferably Elijah Craig Small Batch or Old Forester
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass.
2. Stir with ice until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled double rocks glass over a big cube.
4. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Rickey Royale
intro_philosophy: The team behind White Lyan played with in-house fermentation, developing a number of mock “wines” that they then integrated into cocktails. Here, they build on a classic rickey formula and kick it up with the addition of a housemade Persian lime “fizz.”
ingredients: 2 ounces London dry gin, preferably Colombo
Iranian Lime Rickey Fizz , to top
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients except the Iranian Lime Rickey Fizz with ice and strain into a chilled Champagne flute.
2. Top with chilled Iranian Lime Rickey Fizz and garnish with a whole lime peel.

title: The Trinity
intro_philosophy: Jim Kearns describes this drink as “a great cocktail for food pairing,” since it contains far more vermouth than gin. The recipe is a “perfect” classic—meaning it contains equal measures dry and sweet vermouth, sourced from theTheSavoy Cocktail Book.
ingredients: 1 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: La Môme
intro_philosophy: “Pisco makes me think of rose petals,” says Natasha David, New York City bartender and consultant. Thanks to thePisco Sour, this Peruvian grape spirit is often thought of as a shaken spirit. “I had never seen pisco included in a delicate, stirred drink,” says David. So she decided to begin with a base of rose-petal infused pisco and French vermouth. Building on this martini riff, she added a bit of smooth, mild grappa and a dash of stone fruit flavor with apricot liqueur. While working with the rose-infused pisco, David had Edith Piaf’s “La Vie en Rose” in mind, and titled the drink for Piaf’s nickname, La Môme, or “little sparrow.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces pisco, rose-infused (preferably Encanto, see Editor's Note below)
1 teaspoon grappa (preferably Clear Creek Pinot Grigio)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass.
2. Add ice and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Beijing Peach
intro_philosophy: One of Julie Reiner’s early modern classic cocktail recipes from New York’s Flatiron Lounge that calls for a base of tea-infused vodka kicked up with lime juice and white peach purée.
ingredients: 2 ounces jasmine tea-infused vodka (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in cocktail shaker filled with ice.
2. Shake until chilled and strain into a cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with an orchid.

title: Poncha Regional
intro_philosophy:
In this version of Madeira’s signature drink, a bit of lemon zest is added to the traditional ingredients of rhum agricole, citrus juice and honey.In Ilda Marques’ words, the ingredient lends the drink a bit more “creaminess,” and it provides an additional hit of citrus tartness and aroma to counter the sweetness of the honey.

On Madeira, ponchais made exclusively with locally made white rhum agricole. This recipe was made using Branca 40 percent, made byEngenhos do Norte, a standard product on the island. In the U.S., Madeiran rum is nearly impossible to find, so look for any other unaged rhum agricole between 80 and 100 proof.

It’s also unlikely you’ll be able to find an authentic caralhinho, the wooden tool used to “whip” the drink, but a wooden spoon does the job.
ingredients: 2 swaths of lemon peel (around 3 grams total)
scant 1 1/2 ounces white rhum agricole, chilled
scant 1 1/2 ounces fresh-squeezed orange juice, chilled
instructions: 1. In a heavy pint glass (or small glass pitcher, if making more than one drink), muddle the lemon peel and sugar, pounding and grinding until you have a uniform paste.

2. Add the rhum agricole, lemon juice, orange juice and honey. Holding a caralhinho (or wooden spoon) between your palms, insert it in the mixture and spin it until the ingredients are integrated and frothy.
3. Taste, adding more lemon juice or honey depending on the flavor of your ingredients; it should be just barely sweet followed by tart and fragrant flavors.
4. Strain the mixture through a sieve into a small, stemmed glass or alternatively, over ice into a tall glass.

title: Eric Alperin’s Tuxedo No. 2
intro_philosophy: This variation on theTuxedococktail—a sherry-spikedMartinivariation—dates to the turn of the 20th century and swaps sherry for dry vermouth, with the addition ofmaraschino liqueurand absinthe. Eric Alperin, co-owner of a hospitality group that includes The Varnish in Los Angeles, and Penny Pound Ice, describes the Martini variation as having a “gentle kiss of fruit and an herbaceous bow-tie finish.”
ingredients: 1/4 ounce cherry liqueur, preferably Maraska Maraschino
2 dashes orange bitters (1:1, Fee Brothers West Indian Orange:Regans Orange Bitters No. 6)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except absinthe, in a mixing glass over cracked ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe rinsed or atomized with absinthe.
3. Express lemon twist, then use as garnish. Finish off with a brandied cherry.

title: Holy Water’s Turf Club
intro_philosophy: John Ottman’s interpretation is close to the Harry Johnson formula for the Turf Club, marshaling two ounces of gin to three-quarters of an ounce of dry vermouth with touches of maraschino and absinthe, but also orange bitters.
ingredients: 3 dashes orange bitters blend (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a coupe.
3. garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Ama’s Americano
intro_philosophy: At Ama in Washington, D.C., co-owner and beverage director Micah Wilder has built out his bar with a Milano-Torino on nitro and an authentic pistola seltz in the style of Milan’s Camparino in Galleria caffè, making the bar perfectly poised to createperfect Americanos. His choice to split both the red bitter and vermouth elements between two products adds layers of complexity that are opened up with carbonation.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce wine-based aperitivo liqueur, preferably Cappelletti
3/4 ounce vermouth di torino, preferably Mulassano
3/4 ounce Italian rosso vermouth, preferably Mulassano
instructions: 1. In a frozen highball glass, add the red bitters and vermouths.
2. Fill the glass three-quarters with ice, top with seltzer, and gently stir a few times to blend without disrupting carbonation.
3. Garnish with 2 orange segments.

title: Golden Cadillac
intro_philosophy: Part of the cream cocktail family, this sweet throwback is a mix of Galliano (a sweet Italian liqueur), white crème de cacao and heavy cream shaken to a frothy head. Poor Red’s BBQ, a roadside bar in El Dorado, California, lays claim to the recipe, which—according to local lore—was created in 1952 when a pair of newly engaged patrons requested a special drink to match their gold Cadillac. This version of the heavy-handed drink was created at theEast Village 1970s meccaof the same name. Instead of heavy cream, it substitutes coconut cream for a semi-tropical twist.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.

title: Thrilla in Manila
intro_philosophy: At Pacific Cocktail Haven in San Francisco, tropical cocktails reign. The bourbon-based Thrilla in Manila is no exception, and the drink—flavored with calamansi, pineapple, shiso and coconut—is the most popular original recipe at the bar.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces bourbon, preferably Evan Williams Black
1 ounce housemade coconut cream (see Editor’s Note) or Coco Lopez
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake with ice.
2. Fine-strain into a rocks glass filled with cobbled ice.
3. Garnish with powdered li hing mui and a shiso leaf.

title: Rubber Soul
intro_philosophy: Young Joni general manager Brandon Sass created this Penicillin riff when the restaurant had to shut down dining due to the pandemic. Part of a takeaway cocktail kit, the Rubber Soul exemplifies how gochujang—the smoky, sweet Korean red pepper paste—can add nuanced spice to a variety of classic cocktails, packing a lot of flavor for an at-home drink. He says the recipe can work with any spirit, though tequila’s earthy flavor pairs especially well with the lapsang souchong tea.
ingredients: 1 ounce Som Ginger Cordial or homemade ginger-vinegar cordial (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and mix well.
2. Pour into a rocks glass with ice.
3. Garnish with a dehydrated lemon, then top with a piece of crystallized ginger and pink peppercorns.

title: Peppermint Bark Eggnog
intro_philosophy: Tom Macy’s single-serve take on classiceggnogblends two essential cool weather liqueurs—crème de cacaoand crème de menthe—with both rum and Cognac. In keeping with eggnog’s essential construction, he adds heavy cream and a whole egg for what, he admits, “would be the dumbest drink ever if it weren’t so damn good.”
ingredients: 1 ounce Cognac, preferably VS or VSOP
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with grated nutmeg and peppermint bark dust.

title: Left Hand
intro_philosophy: A lesser-known modern classic from Sam Ross, creator of the Penicillin and Paper Plane. The drink is essentially aBoulevardierwithmole bittersadded into the equation, though Ross was unaware of the existence of the Boulevardier at the time of its creation.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce sweet vermouth, preferably Carpano Antica Formula
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strained into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a cherry.

title: Banana Manhattan
intro_philosophy: A playful reference to comic book character Bananaman, this banana-accentedManhattanvariation gets its “mystery flavor” from a dash or two of absinthe.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged rum, preferably Hamilton 86 Demerara rum
1/2 ounce banana liqueur, preferably Giffard Banane du Brésil
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except lemon peel in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a cocktail glass.
3. Express the lemon peel and discard.

title: Citrus Cordial
intro_philosophy: “Cordials can aid in sustainability efforts,” Max Venning notes. “For us, it has become an important part of our day-to-day operations,” he says of his London bar, Three Sheets. “We go through a lot of lemon juice in the bar and are often left with piles of husks.” Unlike the cordial used to make theLemon & Cardamom Gimlet, which also requires juice, a more general “citrus cordial” uses only the leftover peels, and can be adapted to work with any type of citrus for a cocktail or non-alcoholic drink.
ingredients: 8 ounces leftover citrus husks (lemon, lime, orange, grapefruit, etc.)
citric acid powder, optional (see Editor's Note)
instructions: 1. Put the spent citrus husks in a bowl and pour the sugar over the husks.
2. Muddle the sugar into the citrus to release the oils. Cover and leave it in a cool place, overnight if possible or at least for a few hours.
3. Add the water and stir until the sugar is dissolved, then let it rest for an hour or so.
4. Strain off the liquid through a coffee filter placed over a funnel into a jug.
5. Taste the cordial for acidity. Add citric acid to taste.
6. Stir to dissolve.
7. Transfer to a 750-ml bottle and seal.
8. To serve, mix 2 ounces spirit of choice (Venning recommends vodka or gin) and 1 ounce citrus cordial over ice in a highball glass. Top with soda water.
9. Non-alcoholic alternative: Pour 1 1/2 ounces citrus cordial over ice in a highball glass and top with soda water.

title: Ward Eight
intro_philosophy: The Ward Eight may have lived on into the 21st century as Boston’s most famous classic cocktail, but it never truly caught on as a riffable template. At the New England–inspired restaurant Smithereens, in New York’s East Village, Logan Rodriguez turns the Whiskey Sour variation on its head with amped-up acidity, boutique distillates, savory flavors and bittersweet alpine liqueur.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces rye whiskey, such as Rye & Sons
3/4 ounce acid-adjusted orange juice (see Editor’s Note)
3/4 ounce  beet shrub grenadine (see Editor’s Note)
1/4 ounce Acid Spirits Smoked Orange (or Rhum J.M Shrubb)
1/4 ounce Acid Spirits Horseradish (or horseradish vodka)
1/4 ounce aperitivo liqueur, such as Cappelletti
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until well-chilled.
3. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Whiskey Peach Smash
intro_philosophy: “When I came up with the Whiskey Smash variation [in the late 1980s], I didn’t just shake the fruit in the drink—I muddled it with mint,” explains Dale DeGroff of this summer-ized rendition of thenontraditional drink, which incorporates fresh peaches and citrus.
instructions: 1. Muddle the fruit and lemon wedges with the Curaçao.
2. Add the mint leaves and the bourbon.
3. Shake well and strain into a double rocks glass filled with ice.
4. Garnish with a peach slice and a mint sprig.

title: Bouquet de Bulles
intro_philosophy: Amy Racine, beverage director at La Marchande, constructed the Bouquet de Bulles from the bones of a French 75 and the flavor of a boozy Arnold Palmer. The classic tea-and-lemon pairing is made even more bright and refreshing with the topper of sparkling wine.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces chamomile tea–infused gin (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients except for the sparkling wine in a shaker.
2. Quickly shake over ice and strain into a coupe glass.
3. Top with sparkling wine, then garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel.

title: Baroque Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy: Theliquidingredients in Apte-Elford’s Old-Fashioned are fairly standard—she feels the classic specs of cane sugar simply syrup and Angostura bitters already gives Elijah Craig a perfect cocktail platform. It’s the over-the-top details that turn Roy’s drink into a baroque masterpiece. That includes bespoke, hand-carved ice cubes—though regular large ice cubes will also do just fine—and an extravagantly boozy cherry garnish that includes another Old-Fashioned, in miniature.
ingredients: ¼ to ½ ounce  simple syrup (2:1 ratio)
instructions: 1. Place OF Ice Cube (see Editor’s Note) into a double Old-Fashioned glass to let the ice temper.
2. Add bourbon, simple syrup and bitters to a mixing glass and fill three-quarters with ice. Stir swiftly.
3. Strain into the double Old-Fashioned glass.
4. Express orange peel over the cocktail and rim the top of the glass with the side of the peel.
5. Garnish with the OF-Filled Cherry set inside the Orange Peel Basket, placing it just between the ice cube and the rim of the glass to stabilize.

title: 15 Romolo’s Sherry Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Given its low proof, sherry runs the risk of being over-diluted in long drinks. Here, however, amontillado, manzanilla and cream sherries are able to stand up to a mound of crushed ice and fresh citrus as the base of this take on the classicSherry Cobbler.
ingredients: 1/4 of an orange, sliced into small pieces
instructions: 1. Combine cream sherry, sugar and orange slices in a cocktail shaker and gently muddle together.
2. Add the remaining ingredients and a cup of crushed ice.
3. Shake gently and pour all ingredients into a Collins glass.
4. Garnish with a straw, mixed berries or seasonal fruit, and a shake of powdered sugar.

title: Blacktail’s Rum and Coke
intro_philosophy: In this elegant variation created for Blacktail’s opening menu in 2016, the carbonation in this drink doesn’t come from soda or soda water, but from Champagne. The Orinoco Bitters used in the cocktail are made for sister bar, The Dead Rabbit, and are easy to purchase online; in a pinch, substitute Angostura or similar aromatic bitters.
ingredients: 1 ounce white rum, preferably Bacardi Facundo Neo
1 dash Dr. Adam Elmegirab's Orinoco Bitters
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except the Champagne, in a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
2. Top with Champagne.
3. Stir to integrate, and garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Hummer
intro_philosophy: Jerome Adams created this boozy ice cream drink in 1968 at Detroit’s Bayview Yacht Club—and he still works there to this day. The Hummer has become legendary among the sailing set, but it’s also a Michigan staple inland, where it’s served in plastic party cups in backyards around the state. (In fancier restaurants you’ll often find it in a wine glass, topped with whipped cream.)
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces  white rum, preferably Bacardi Light
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a blender, add two ice cubes and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a rocks glass.

title: Mondeghili
intro_philosophy: Most Americans know meatballs via the Southern Italian tradition filtered through decades of appropriation that combines some permutation of ground meat covered in red sauce. But in Northern Italy, the meatball has an entirely different personality born of a peasant dish, orpiatto povero, picked up from the sixteenth-century Spaniards that dominated Milan.
ingredients: 1 cup torn stale bread, soaked in 1/4 cup whole milk for 10 minutes
instructions: 1. Place the veal or beef shank in a large pot and cover with water.
2. Bring the pot to a low boil over medium heat, then reduce the heat to low and simmer, skimming any fat that rises to the top.
3. Add the carrot, onion, and garlic. Keep at a low simmer and cook until fork-tender, about 1 1/2 to 2 hours.
4. Drain, reserving the broth for risotto or another dish.
5. After the meat has cooled, shred by hand or with two forks, discarding any fat or bones.
6. Add the shredded meat to a food processor with the cooked vegetables and pulse a few times to break up the mixture.
7. In a medium bowl, combine the meat mixture with the cheese, 1 egg, the nutmeg, and the soaked bread. Season with salt and pepper.
8. Roll the meat into balls slightly smaller than a golf ball.
9. Whisk the remaining egg in a shallow dish. Place the bread crumbs in another shallow dish.
10. Dip the meatballs into the whisked egg and coat in breadcrumbs.
11. In a large fry pan over medium heat, warm the oil. In batches, fry the meatballs, turning to brown until golden on all sides.
12. Place on a paper towel-lined plate to drain

title: Roman Charity
intro_philosophy:
The idea for the Roman Charity came to Gui Jaroschy of theBroken Shakerwhile making toast.

He happened to be using avocado honey mixed with turmeric and moringa seed, whose flavors, naturally, he parlayed into orgeat. First he mixed almond milk with turmeric, moringa and wildflower honey to create a bright yellow hue and dark, intense flavor. To give it a “Miami-style brightness,” he layered Dominican passionfruit liqueur with Dutch gin. St-Germain united the fruit with a hit of floral sweetness. A loose twist on the Saturn, the tiki classic, the Roman Charity is a rich, spiced cocktail that’s undeniably tropical, yet simultaneously comforting.
ingredients: 1 ounce gin, preferably Bobby's Schiedam Dry Gin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake briefly with ice.
2. Strain into a footed pilsner glass and top with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with edible flowers and greens.

title: Flatiron Martini
intro_philosophy: A staple at Julie Reiner’s pioneering New York City bar, Flatiron Lounge, that calls on vodka, Lillet Blanc and Cointreau.
instructions: 1. Rinse a cocktail glass with the Cointreau and throw out excess Cointreau.
2. In a mixing glass filled with ice, combine the vodka and Lillet and stir until chilled.
3. Strain into prepared glass and garnish with orange twist.

title: Rhubarb Gimlet
intro_philosophy: Using Jeffrey Morgenthaler’s unbeatable,no-cook rhubarb syrup, this Gimlet benefits not only from an appetizing pop of color, but also a subtle fruit flavor and a lingering, pleasantly bitter finish that makes the refreshing cocktail feel even more spring-ready.
instructions: 1. Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Ginger Smash
intro_philosophy: In this tequila-based take on the Ginger Smash, Dushan Zaric adds a measure of Rhum Clément’s Creole Shrubb to complement the spice of fresh ginger and to highlight the citrus notes of freshly muddled kumquat and lime.
ingredients: 1 ounce creole shrub, preferably Rhum Clément
instructions: 1. Muddle the ginger root, kumquats and sugar in the bottom of a cocktail shaker.
2. Add the rest of the ingredients to the shaker and add enough ice to fill a rocks glass.
3. Cover and shake hard but briefly.
4. Pour the unstrained mixture into a rocks glass.

title: La Bodega Salt Rim
intro_philosophy: Look no further than your neighborhood corner store to create Tex-Mex-inspired salt mix for Margaritas and more.
ingredients: 2 teaspoons taco seasoning (such as Ortega or McCormick)
instructions: 1. Working in two batches, grind the plantain chips in a spice grinder.
2. Stir together with the salt and taco seasoning in a small bowl.

title: Lynnette Marrero’s Pisco Sour
intro_philosophy:
Considered a classic in Chile and Peru, the Pisco Sour is said to have been created by American expat Victor Morris, who openedMorris’ Bar in Lima in 1916. But the drink—consisting of sugar, citrus and Peru’s national spirit, pisco, plus an egg white and a flourish of Angostura bitters—the drink has, for over a century, failed to earn much of a following Stateside.

That’s not the case at Llama Inn, however, where Lynnette Marrero’s version of the drink has become remarkably popular. (On average, the bar sells about 150 Pisco Sours per week.) Built on a base of Macchu Pisco, plus a split measure of lemon and lime juices and an extra rich sweetener, the drink is flash-blended using a stand mixer, which guarantees a thick layer of froth and makes for a quicker serve. However, when making the drink at home, Marrero prefers to employ a simple dry shake for a velvety texture, which gets finished with a flourish of Angostura bitters.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and dry shake (without ice) until the egg white is very frothy..
2. Add ice and shake again until chilled.
3. Double strain into a coupe glass.

title: The Fixer
intro_philosophy: Sam Johnson’s The Fixer, a play on theBoulevardier, likewise leans on rye, but adds a duo of herbal players—aquavit and Amaro Braulio—to complement the addition of warm-spiced barolo chinato in place of sweet vermouth.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounce rye, preferably Russel’s Reserve Single Barrel
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Serve with a side of candied pecans.

title: Kale and Pineapple Caipirinha
intro_philosophy: On every cocktail menu, The Broken Shaker includes a seasonalCaipirinha, always with a traditional Brazilian cachaça base and a few rotating elements in keeping with the spirit of a fruit-forward drink, blended together with a bit of sugar and a heap of fresh fruit garnish. This version is a health club-meets-nightclub mix of  kale with a tropical topper of pineapple juice.
instructions: 1. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker.
2. Add ice and shake until chilled.
3. Strain over ice into a rocks glass.
4. Garnish with a slice of pineapple.

title: Orlando Franklin McCray’s Ginger Syrup
intro_philosophy: While there are countless recipes for ginger syrup,we enjoy the simplicity of Orlando Franklin McCray’s, which gets an extra spicy kick from red pepper flakes.
ingredients: 1 part ginger juice, extracted using a juicer
1 pinch red pepper flakes (or more, to taste)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a saucepan over medium heat until dissolved.
2. Fine strain into a sealable container and let cool before using.

title: Meet Me at the Blind Tiger
intro_philosophy: With this drink, Choi sought to transport guests to a Prohibition-era barbershop speakeasy, the likes of which often had names like The Blind Pig or The Blind Tiger. This drink’s mix of sweet and sharp—from plum liquor to Bombay Sapphire to almond milk foam—strives to mirror the mix of sensations of visiting a barbershop.
ingredients: 1 ounce pu’erh tea–infused plum liquor (see Editor’s Note)
1/3 ounce lavender jasmine syrup (see Editor’s Note)
1 dash Miracle Mile Bay Rum bitters
instructions: 1. Express a lemon twist into a mixing glass. Add the remaining ingredients to the mixing glass, then fill the mixing glass with ice.
2. Stir until chilled, and strain into a Nick & Nora glass.
3. Froth the almond milk–washed Italicus, and cover the drink with foam.

title: Vaquero
intro_philosophy: Simone Goldberg’s winter Daiquiri layers bourbon with bitter Aperol, fresh lemon juice, spicy Ancho Reyes and aromatic sage. “Kind of a Boulevardier meets an herbal Mai Tai,” she says—or just Christmas on the beach.
instructions: 1. Add the pineapple chunks and sage leaf to a mixing tin and muddle.
2. Add remaining ingredients to the tin and shake.
3. Fine strain into a coupe glass and garnish with a sage leaf.

title: Miami Nice
intro_philosophy: In this playful spin on the Miami Vice,Milo and Miguel Salehiswap the expected strawberry for guava and add a measure of allspice dram to complement the aged rum base alongside the expected lime and coconut cream. “Experimental and conceptual cocktails are fun,” they say, “but we also love drinks like this that are simple and transport you to your favorite beach.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces aged rum, preferably Santa Teresa 1796
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a blender and blend until smooth.
2. Pour into a snifter or another glass and garnish with a lime wheel and umbrella.

title: Heaven’s Clover
intro_philosophy: The sheer number of bars opening under the expertise of Dan Sabo at the forthcoming Hotel Figueroa promise to make it one of downtown LA’s most compelling drinking destinations. Here, the slightly spiced, gin-based Heaven’s Clover offers a taste of what’s to come at Bar Figueroa, the re-imagined lobby bar of the historic hotel.
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake.
2. Strain into a Collins glass over crushed ice.
3. Garnish with a chile de arbol, garam masala, canela and dill.

title: Hospitality Porron Punch
intro_philosophy: “The best porron cocktails are light, effervescent, able to be shared by a group and fun,” explains Ezra Star of the ideal characteristics of any drink served in a Spanish porron. Her mixture of brandy, rum, lemon and grenadine is topped with a healthy dose of Cava; her recommended presentation is over a bed of ice with an optional bib on the side.
ingredients: 4 ounces brandy, preferably Torres 10 Gran Reserva
2 ounces Spanish rum, preferably Navazos Palazzi Cask Strength
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients, except for Cava, in a mixing tin and shake with ice.
2. Double strain into a porron.
3. Top with Cava.
4. Serve the porron on a bed of crushed ice.

title: Clacson Spritz
intro_philosophy: Bar Clacson, the anticipated collaboration between Eric Alperin (The Varnish) and Richard Boccato (Dutch Kills, Fresh Kills), represents a space that’s both neighborhood-friendly and destination-worthy. Their eponymous spritz captures the aperitif-inspired, low-proof nature that carries throughout much of their opening drink list.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce white wine simple syrup (1:1, white wine: granulated sugar)
instructions: 1. Shake all ingredients, save for the soda water, with a small piece of cracked ice.
2. Strain mixture into one half of the shaker tin and top with soda water.
3. Pour the drink into a chilled Collins glass over an ice spear, or ice cubes.

title: Ocho
intro_philosophy: The Ocho is Portland bar Holy Ghost’s spring addition to itsRanch Watermenu. Swapping the typicaltequilafor amezcalinfused with hibiscus-raspberry tea, the rest of the cocktail’s build is fairly straightforward, using fresh lime juice and soda water for a refreshing, floral take.
instructions: 1. Salt the rim of a Collins glass.
2. Add all ingredients with ice.
3. Top with soda water, and stir to incorporate.
4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: The Best Tomato Martini
intro_philosophy: There’s a reason people clamor over tomatoes when they’re at their peak. For many, tomatoes’ bright, garden-fresh quality is the very essence of summer. As such, it’s only natural to want to throw them into a Martini. But there’s another way to capture the flavor of the season, even beyond summer.Laurent Cazottes’ aptly named Tomates, a liqueur that distills the flavors of 72 varieties of heirloom tomatoes, is perfect for the Martini template. It bringsa hint of earthy tomato funkiness and salinity that make for the cleanest take on the dirty Martini, with just a subtle hint of umami and an underlying freshness.
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces navy-strength gin, such as Hayman’s Royal Dock
3/4 ounce dry vermouth, such as Noilly Prat
1/2 ounce tomato liqueur, such as Laurent Cazottes Tomates
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or cocktail glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist, if desired.

title: Spirit of the Beehive
intro_philosophy:
During Shochu Week, bar tastemakers showcase their individual flavor and cocktail flair by incorporating shochu from different Japanese regionalities and ingredients into a special, limited-time cocktail menu—learn more and find a bar near you.

Loosely inspired by the classic Tipperary cocktail, Brian Evans incorporated small amounts of yellow Chartreuse and smoky Islay Scotch to complement the earthy, nutty, almost carrotlike nuances of the sweet potato shochu. The final touch: French lobster oil and housemade shiso oil dot the top of the drink.

“Not only do these oils give an intriguing finish of umami and herbaceousness,” Evans says, “but they lend a captivatingly visual pop as a colorful garnish.”
ingredients: 1/2 ounce  Lustau Los Arcos amontillado sherry
instructions: 1. Stir all ingredients with ice for approximately 30 seconds.
2. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass.
3. Dot the surface with the shiso and lobster oils as garnish.

title: King’s Cobbler
intro_philosophy: Neal Bodenheimer, owner ofCureandCane & Tablein New Orleans, uses Cappelletti Amaro Sfumato as the base in his King’s Cobbler, bringing a bitter smoky note to this twist on a classic. “Sfumato has an incredible drying quality that can clean up even the most unwieldy drinks,” he says. Here, fresh lemon juice and simple syrup accent the amaro’s Alpine berry notes while fresh strawberries play nicely off the rhubarb liqueur.
ingredients: 3/4 ounce simple syrup (1:1, sugar to water)
instructions: 1. Crush one half of a strawberry and add to a shaker.
2. Add the liquid ingredients and shake very briefly, but hard enough to aerate well.
3. Double-strain over cracked ice in a chilled glass or metal cup.
4. Garnish with a mint bouquet and a halved strawberry with top intact.

title: Golden Daylily
intro_philosophy: This drink fromCapucine Prager, bartender atBar Goto, takes its name from the translation of its star ingredient, jin xuan tea. Also known as milky oolong, the tea infuses Japanese whisky as the base of this unconventional Old-Fashioned riff, which is modified with a small measure of Scotch and sweetened with cane syrup. “This drink is inspired by the idea of calm confidence,” Prager says. “It’s a spirit-forward cocktail that doesn’t need to shout to be heard.”
ingredients: 2 ounces tea-infused Japanese whisky (see Editor’s Note)
1/8 teaspoon single malt Scotch, such as Laphroaig
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and briefly stir.
2. Strain into a snifter glass.

title: Bitter Citrus Old-Fashioned
intro_philosophy:
Elijah Craig Bourbon’s annual Old-Fashioned Week returns for its second year supporting the Restaurant Workers’ Community Foundation, October 15-24.Sign up your bar or restaurantto participate by featuring Elijah Craig Old-Fashioned riffs on your menu.

Hartley’s Old-Fashioned riff employs his “no ingredient left behind” mentality, while also upcycling a few underutilized ingredients. He matches the bitterness of naringin (a flavonoid found in citrus fruit pith) and oversteeped black tea with the wood tannins found in Elijah Craig Small Batch. The result is an unusually citrusy, bitter Old-Fashioned.
ingredients: 2 ounces  Elijah Craig Small Batch Bourbon
1/4 ounce  bitter Earl Grey & citrus peel syrup (see Editor’s Note)
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass over ice and stir until chilled.
2. Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
3. Garnish with lemon twist.

title: Yerba Mate Hottie
intro_philosophy: For Nikolas Vagenas, co-owner of Brooklyn’s Mr. Melo, yerba mate, chai and tamarind are a perfect match. Here, they come together in a hot cocktail that can be served without alcohol or spiked with Amaro Braulio and rum.
ingredients: 6 ounces yerba mate tea, room temperature or chilled
1 ounce rum, preferably Ten to One Dark Rum, optional
instructions: 1. If using, add rum and Amaro Braulio to a mug.
2. In a saucepot, heat the tea to 125°F.
3. Slowly pour the syrup into the pot while whisking to combine thoroughly.
4. Pour the hot mixture into the mug and stir to combine.
5. Garnish with star anise.

title: Double Barrel Winchester
intro_philosophy: Brian Miller combines four distinct gins in his upgrade on his very own modern-classic tiki drink, the Winchester. While we cannot disclose Miller’s recipe for ginger syrup, we recommendOrlando Franklin McCray’s ginger syrup.
ingredients: 1/2 ounce New York Distilling Company Perry's Tot Gin
instructions: 1. Combine all ingredients in a mixing tin and shake with four ice cubes.
2. Strain into a tiki mug.
3. Top with crushed ice.
4. Garnish with a half grapefruit wheel, a large piece of ginger, 2 pineapple fronds and a Union Jack parasol.

title: Disco Nap
intro_philosophy: Named in honor of the late-afternoon/early-evening nap one sneaks in to reset for the night ahead, Jon Mullen’s Disco Nap offers a twist on a bitter and bubbly espresso and tonic. The low-proof Piedmontese amaro Bordiga Chiot Montamaro offers chicory notes that pair well with the Varnelli coffee liqueur and shot of cold brew. “What really works great in this drink is the spicy-sweet finish of the Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic,” says Mullen. “It turns the drink into more of a refreshing aperitivo.”
ingredients: 1 1/2 ounces cold brew concentrate or a double shot of espresso
instructions: 1. Combine all the ingredients except the Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water in a mixing tin filled with ice, and shake until chilled.
2. Add the Fever-Tree Aromatic Tonic Water to the mixing tin and double-strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice.
3. Express the orange zest over the surface of the drink and discard.
